en: I
vi: Chapter 1
tr: CHAPTER 1

en: In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since.
vi: During the years when I was young and easily influenced, my father gave me some advice, and it was this advice that changed my thinking from that moment on.
tr: When I was younger and more fragile, my father gave me a piece of advice that I will never forget for the rest of my life.
es: When I was younger and more vulnerable, my father gave me a piece of advice that I have not stopped thinking about since then.

en: “Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone,” he told me, “just remember that all the people in this world haven’t had the advantages that you’ve had.”
vi: "Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone, just remember that not everyone in this world has had the advantages that you've had."
tr: “When you feel like criticizing someone,” he said, “remember that not everyone has had the advantages that you’ve had.”
es: "Before criticizing anyone," he told me, "remember that not everyone has had the advantages you've had."

en: He didn’t say any more, but we’ve always been unusually communicative in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more than that. In consequence, I’m inclined to reserve all judgements, a habit that has opened up many curious natures to me and also made me the victim of not a few veteran bores. The abnormal mind is quick to detect and attach itself to this quality when it appears in a normal person, and so it came about that in college I was unjustly accused of being a politician, because I was privy to the secret griefs of wild, unknown men. Most of the confidences were unsought—frequently I have feigned sleep, preoccupation, or a hostile levity when I realized by some unmistakable sign that an intimate revelation was quivering on the horizon; for the intimate revelations of young men, or at least the terms in which they express them, are usually plagiaristic and marred by obvious suppressions. Reserving judgements is a matter of infinite hope. I am still a little afraid of missing something if I forget that, as my father snobbishly suggested, and I snobbishly repeat, a sense of the fundamental decencies is parcelled out unequally at birth.
vi: My father said. My father didn't say much more, but because there was always a subtle way of communicating between us, I understood that his words contained much deeper meanings. As a result, that advice made me inclined to be cautious in all my judgments, helping me to see and understand the strange natures of those around me, but at the same time, it also made me a victim of not a few who came to bother and annoy me. The characteristic I just mentioned, if manifested in an ordinary person, would quickly attract abnormal minds to them. Therefore, when I was still studying at university, I was often unfairly labeled as a political merchant, because I knew many sad, private, and secret stories of people, even the stories of libertine men I didn't know. It's not that I went out of my way to seek out the private matters of others. I often had to pretend to sleep, pretend to be busy, or act indifferent and unfriendly when I noticed clear signs that a private matter was about to be revealed. In fact, the confessions of young men, or at least the words they used to express themselves, were often just borrowed ideas and phrases from others that they had edited and trimmed, making their thoughts no longer coherent or clear. Being cautious in judgment is actually about constantly nurturing hope. I was always afraid that if I forgot to do so, I would miss out on many things, just like the things my father proudly pointed out and I also proudly repeated, which is that the basic awareness of polite conduct is not always equally distributed to everyone at birth.
tr: He hadn't said anything else, but since we understood each other without much talking, I realized he wanted to convey much more. As a result, I preferred to keep my judgments about people to myself. This habit allowed me to meet many peculiar individuals, but it also condemned me to a considerable number of annoying people. Those who think differently immediately recognize this trait in a normal person and quickly become attached to it. While I was in university, for this very reason, that is, because some crazy, unknown young people did not hesitate to tell me their secrets, I was accused of being overly political for no reason. However, I often did this unintentionally. The moment I sensed someone was about to confide in me, depending on the situation, I would either pretend to be asleep, act as if I were very busy, or dismiss them with a joke. Because these intimate revelations of young people, or at least the expressions they use to tell them, are usually either borrowed from here and there or are suppressed emotions. Keeping judgments about people to oneself is, in my opinion, an endless hope. I still fear forgetting this saying of my father's, which he uttered wisely and I wisely agreed with: some fundamental subtleties are unjustly distributed in the world.
es: That was all, but within our reserve, we have always understood each other in an uncommon way, and I understood that his words meant much more. Consequently, I tend to reserve my judgments, a habit that has allowed me to discover very curious characters and has also made me the victim of quite a few incorrigible bores. The anomalous mind detects and quickly takes advantage of that quality when it perceives it in an ordinary person, and it so happened that at university I was unjustly accused of being an intriguer, for being aware of the secret sorrows of some inaccessible and difficult individuals. Most of the confidences I did not seek: many times I have pretended to sleep, or to be absorbed in my own concerns, or I have shown a hostile frivolity at the first unmistakable sign that an intimate revelation was looming on the horizon; because the intimate revelations of the young, or at least the terms in which they make them, are generally plagiarized and suffer from obvious omissions. Not judging is a reason for infinite hope. I still believe that I would lose something if I forgot that, as my father suggested with a certain snobbery, and as I now repeat with a certain snobbery, the most basic sense of decency is unequally distributed at birth.

en: And, after boasting this way of my tolerance, I come to the admission that it has a limit. Conduct may be founded on the hard rock or the wet marshes, but after a certain point I don’t care what it’s founded on. When I came back from the East last autumn I felt that I wanted the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the human heart. Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was exempt from my reaction—Gatsby, who represented everything for which I have an unaffected scorn. If personality is an unbroken series of successful gestures, then there was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. This responsiveness had nothing to do with that flabby impressionability which is dignified under the name of the “creative temperament”—it was an extraordinary gift for hope, a romantic readiness such as I have never found in any other person and which it is not likely I shall ever find again. No—Gatsby turned out all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.
vi: After boasting about my patience like that, I must also confess that my patience for enduring has its limits. Human conduct can be built on solid rock or on a swampy foundation, but at some point, I no longer care what it was built on. Last autumn, when I returned home from the East, I felt that I wanted the whole world to wear uniforms and to forever stand in ranks with moral uprightness. I no longer wanted noisy, boisterous entertainments with the privilege of glimpsing into people's hearts. Only Gatsby, the person whose name I used for this book, was an exception to my reaction. Gatsby represented everything I scorned. If human nature is a series of successful expressions, then he was indeed admirable. With a heightened sensitivity that could perceive the future, he was like a complex machine capable of recording earthquakes from thousands of miles away. This sensitivity of his had nothing to do with the weak, sentimental sensitivity respected under the term "creative temperament." It was merely a rare gift for hope, a romantic readiness that I have never found in anyone else and probably never will. In the end, Gatsby was good, and it was precisely what tormented and haunted Gatsby, the filthy dust that floated above his awakened dreams, that temporarily closed my interest in the sorrows and short-lived joys of people.
tr: After boasting so much about my tolerance, I must admit that it has its limits. There may be a hard rock or a swamp beneath human behaviors, but after a certain point, I can't say that I care much. When I returned from the east of the country last fall, I realized that I wanted the world to be an example and for honor to reign supreme forever. I no longer wanted those uneasy excursions into the privileged views of people's hearts. I exclude only one person from this, Gatsby, who also gives his name to this book. Gatsby, the person who embodies everything I despise. If a series of successful gestures is a sign of personality, Gatsby had something magnificent, an exaggerated sensitivity to life's promises. He was like those complex devices that can record earthquakes thousands of miles away. But this had nothing to do with that loose sensitivity glorified under the name of "creative temperament." His was an extraordinary ability to hope, a romantic madness that I had never seen before and don't think I will ever see again. No - Gatsby ultimately achieved his desire. It was what caught Gatsby off guard, what covered him in ash and dust when he awoke from his dreams, that caused my interest in the futile sorrows and short-lived happiness of people to disappear for a while.
es: And, after boasting about my tolerance, I find myself forced to admit that it has a limit. I don't care, once a certain point is surpassed, whether the behavior is founded on stone or on swampy ground. When I returned from the East last autumn, I was aware that I desired a world in military uniform, in a kind of permanent moral vigilance; I no longer wanted wild excursions and privileged glimpses into the human heart. The only exception was Gatsby, the man who gives this book its title: Gatsby, who represented everything for which I feel genuine contempt. If personality is an unbroken series of successful gestures, then there was something magnificent about Gatsby, an extraordinary sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were connected to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes from fifteen thousand kilometers away. Such sensitivity has nothing to do with the soft sentimentality that we dignify with the name of "creative temperament": it was an extraordinary gift for hope, a romantic readiness such as I have never found in anyone else and probably never will again. No: Gatsby, in the end, turned out all right. It was what preyed on him, the foul dust that floated in the wake of his dreams, that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.

en: My family have been prominent, well-to-do people in this Middle Western city for three generations. The Carraways are something of a clan, and we have a tradition that we’re descended from the Dukes of Buccleuch, but the actual founder of my line was my grandfather’s brother, who came here in fifty-one, sent a substitute to the Civil War, and started the wholesale hardware business that my father carries on today.
vi: Through three generations, my family has been a reputable and affluent family in this Midwestern city. The Carraway lineage lived like a clan; according to tradition, we are descendants of the Duke of Buccleuch. However, to be precise, the founder of our branch was my grandfather's brother. He came here in 1851, then sent a substitute to fulfill his duty in the Civil War, and established a wholesale business in metal mechanical tools that my father has inherited and managed up to this day.
tr: My family consists of wealthy and respectable people who have lived in this Midwestern city for three generations. We Carraways are like a kind of clan. It is rumored that we are descended from the Duke of Buccleuch. But the real person who laid the foundation of our lineage is my grandfather's brother. After joining the Civil War as a reinforcement force, he settled here in '51 and established the wholesale hardware business that my father now continues.
es: My family has enjoyed influence and well-being in this Midwestern city for three generations. The Carraways are like a clan, and there is a tradition among us that we descend from the Dukes of Buccleuch, but the true founder of our family branch was my grandfather's brother, who arrived here in 1851, paid for someone else to take his place in the Civil War, and founded the wholesale hardware business that my father runs today.

en: I never saw this great-uncle, but I’m supposed to look like him—with special reference to the rather hard-boiled painting that hangs in father’s office. I graduated from New Haven in 1915, just a quarter of a century after my father, and a little later I participated in that delayed Teutonic migration known as the Great War. I enjoyed the counter-raid so thoroughly that I came back restless. Instead of being the warm centre of the world, the Middle West now seemed like the ragged edge of the universe—so I decided to go East and learn the bond business. Everybody I knew was in the bond business, so I supposed it could support one more single man. All my aunts and uncles talked it over as if they were choosing a prep school for me, and finally said, “Why—ye-es,” with very grave, hesitant faces. Father agreed to finance me for a year, and after various delays I came East, permanently, I thought, in the spring of twenty-two.
vi: I have never seen the face of this great-uncle, but I believe I resemble him, based on the stern face in the portrait hanging in my father's room. I graduated from Yale University in New Haven in 1915, exactly a quarter of a century after my father. After that, I joined the fight against the German immigrants, known to everyone as the First World War. I participated in the counterattack so zealously that when I returned home, I was still quite restless. The Midwest is no longer the most exciting center of the world for me; it now seems to have become a tattered edge of the universe. Therefore, I decided to go to the East to learn about stocks and financial securities. Everyone I knew was in this industry, so I thought the market could still support another single young man like me. All my aunts and uncles discussed this matter as if they were choosing a preparatory school for me. Finally, they declared "Alright" with serious and hesitant faces. My father agreed to support me for a year. After various delays, I finally arrived in the East in the spring of 1922, thinking I would stay there forever.
tr: I never met this great uncle, but those who saw the sharp-featured portrait hanging in my father's workplace said I resembled him a lot. In 1915, exactly a quarter-century after my father, I graduated from New Haven. Soon after, I joined the delayed German expansion movement known to the world as the Great War (World War I). Our counterattacks gave me such great pleasure that I was saddened to return. The Midwest had ceased to be a bustling center of the world and had turned into a remote corner of the universe. So I decided to go East and get into the bond business. Everyone I knew was doing this job, and I thought that a bachelor like me could easily make a living this way. After all the aunts, uncles, and cousins had long discussions on the subject as if they were choosing a suitable college for me, they said "Alright" with serious and concerned faces. My father agreed to send me money for a year, and after a few delays, I finally came East and settled permanently in the spring of 1922.
es: I never got to know my great-uncle, but they say I resemble him, especially the stern portrait my father has hanging in his office. I finished my studies in New Haven[2] in 1915, exactly a quarter of a century after my father, and shortly thereafter I participated in that aborted Teutonic migration known as the Great War. I enjoyed the counteroffensive so much that I returned full of unease. The Midwest no longer seemed to me the burning center of the world, but the last and miserable edge of the universe, and I decided to go East and learn the secrets of bond trading. All my acquaintances were involved in bonds, so I thought the business could support one more. My aunts and uncles debated the matter as if they were looking for a school for me, and finally said: "Well, well... yes," very seriously, with an expression of doubt. My father agreed to finance me for a year and, after several postponements, I went East in the spring of 1922, forever, or so I thought.

en: The practical thing was to find rooms in the city, but it was a warm season, and I had just left a country of wide lawns and friendly trees, so when a young man at the office suggested that we take a house together in a commuting town, it sounded like a great idea. He found the house, a weather-beaten cardboard bungalow at eighty a month, but at the last minute the firm ordered him to Washington, and I went out to the country alone. I had a dog—at least I had him for a few days until he ran away—and an old Dodge and a Finnish woman, who made my bed and cooked breakfast and muttered Finnish wisdom to herself over the electric stove.
vi: If I were to look for a room to rent in the city, it would probably be more practical and convenient for me. However, since it was the warm season at that time, and I had just left an area with vast grasslands and plenty of trees, when a young colleague suggested that the two of us rent a house in the suburbs, I immediately thought it was a good idea. My colleague found a house, a weather-beaten wooden bungalow, for eighty dollars a month. But in the end, the company transferred him to Washington, and so I had to move to the suburbs alone. I had a dog - at least it stayed with me for a few days before it ran away - an old Dodge car, and a Finnish maid. Her daily tasks were to help me make the bed, cook breakfast, and mutter Finnish proverbs to herself by the electric stove.
tr: The first thing to do was to rent a room in the city center, but the season was mild and I had just come from a region with vast meadows and friendly trees. When a young boy from work suggested renting a house in one of the nearby suburbs, it seemed like a great idea to me. He found the house. For eighty dollars a month, it was a damp-worn, shabby building. When the company sent him to Washington at the last minute, the house was left to me. I got a dog, but it ran away a few days later. I had an old Dodge car and a Finnish helper who made my bed and prepared my breakfast. She would sit by the electric heater, murmuring something in her own language.
es: The practical thing was to look for accommodation in the city, but it was very hot, and I was coming from a country generous with grass and hospitable trees, so when an office colleague suggested renting a house together in a nearby town, it seemed like a great idea. He found the house, a battered cardboard bungalow, for eighty dollars a month, but at the last minute, the company sent him to Washington, and I went to the countryside alone. I had a dog, or at least I had one for a few days until it ran away, an old Dodge, and a Finnish lady who made my bed and breakfast, and murmured Finnish proverbs next to the electric stove.

en: It was lonely for a day or so until one morning some man, more recently arrived than I, stopped me on the road.
vi: I felt lonely and lost for about a day or so, until one morning when a man who had just moved into the area behind me stopped me on the road.
tr: I spent a couple of days alone like this.
es: I felt lonely for a day, more or less, until one morning someone who had arrived after me stopped me on the road.

en: “How do you get to West Egg village?” he asked helplessly.
vi: "Could you please show me the way to West Egg village?"
tr: Then one morning, a man who apparently had arrived shortly after me stopped me and asked with a bewildered expression on his face, "How can I get to the village of West Egg?"
es: —How do you get to West Egg? —he asked me, confused.

en: I told him. And as I walked on I was lonely no longer. I was a guide, a pathfinder, an original settler. He had casually conferred on me the freedom of the neighbourhood.
vi: This person asked, bewildered. I gave him directions, and as I continued walking, I no longer felt lonely; I had become a guide, a pathfinder, a pioneer. This man, by chance, made me feel comfortable with the area I lived in.
tr: I showed how to get there. When I started walking again, I had the feeling that I was no longer alone. I was a guide, one of the locals, giving directions to those around. Unknowingly, he had granted me the freedom of being his neighbor.
es: I told him. And, when I continued on my way, I no longer felt alone. I was a guide, an explorer, one of the first settlers. That man had bestowed upon me the honor of being a citizen of the place.

en: And so with the sunshine and the great bursts of leaves growing on the trees, just as things grow in fast movies, I had that familiar conviction that life was beginning over again with the summer.
vi: And then, under the rosy sunlight and the explosive sprouting of new buds on the trees, everything around grew rapidly like in a time-lapse film, it reminded me of a common reasoning, that life will start anew when summer comes.
tr: I couldn't help but feel that familiar sense of life beginning anew with the arrival of summer, as the bright sunlight filled those trees with lush green leaves at a speed reminiscent of the movies.
es: And so, with the sunlight and the splendid explosion of leaves growing on the trees like things grow in time-lapse films, I had the well-known certainty that life begins again with the summer.

en: There was so much to read, for one thing, and so much fine health to be pulled down out of the young breath-giving air. I bought a dozen volumes on banking and credit and investment securities, and they stood on my shelf in red and gold like new money from the mint, promising to unfold the shining secrets that only Midas and Morgan and Maecenas knew. And I had the high intention of reading many other books besides. I was rather literary in college—one year I wrote a series of very solemn and obvious editorials for the Yale News—and now I was going to bring back all such things into my life and become again that most limited of all specialists, the “well-rounded man.” This isn’t just an epigram—life is much more successfully looked at from a single window, after all.
vi: There are too many books to read and so much abundant health to be enjoyed from fresh, youthful air. I bought about a dozen sets of books on banking, credit, and stock investment. The sets of books with red and gold-plated covers stood upright on the shelf, looking like freshly minted coins, promising to reveal the excellent secrets known only to Midas, Morgan, and Maecenas. I intend to read many more books. When I was in college, I really liked literature. One year, I wrote a series of coherent and serious editorials for the Yale News school newspaper. Now I will bring all that experience back into my life and once again become the rarest of experts, a well-rounded person. This is not a sarcastic statement - ultimately, life becomes easier to understand when we observe it from just one window.
tr: There were a lot of things to read, but first, I needed to fill my lungs with this fresh, invigorating air and feel healthy. I had placed a dozen books on banking, credit, and investment tools that I brought with me on the shelf. As they waited in front of me with their red and gilded covers like freshly minted crisp money from the mint, I felt that men like Midas, Morgan, and Maecenas were preparing to reveal their secrets known only to themselves. Of course, I would read other books as well. I was interested in literature when I was at university. I had written serious and quality articles for a year in the school newspaper called Yale News. Now I was preparing to bring all of this back into my life. I would become one of those "versatile intellectuals" from the most restricted fields of expertise. This is not just a satire. Life seems much more visible to succeed when viewed from a single window.
es: There was so much to read, on the one hand, and so much health to inhale from the new and invigorating air! I bought a bunch of books on banking, credit, and the stock market, which, standing on the shelf, bound in red and gold, like money freshly minted, promised to reveal to me the radiant secrets that only Midas, Morgan, and Maecenas knew. And I also had the lofty purpose of reading many other books. At university, I had felt certain literary inclinations —one year I wrote a series of editorials for the Yale News, full of clichés and solemnity— and now I was going to revive that until I became the most limited of all specialists, "the complete man." This is not just an epigram, because, after all, life is best observed from a single window.

en: It was a matter of chance that I should have rented a house in one of the strangest communities in North America. It was on that slender riotous island which extends itself due east of New York—and where there are, among other natural curiosities, two unusual formations of land. Twenty miles from the city a pair of enormous eggs, identical in contour and separated only by a courtesy bay, jut out into the most domesticated body of salt water in the Western hemisphere, the great wet barnyard of Long Island Sound. They are not perfect ovals—like the egg in the Columbus story, they are both crushed flat at the contact end—but their physical resemblance must be a source of perpetual wonder to the gulls that fly overhead. To the wingless a more interesting phenomenon is their dissimilarity in every particular except shape and size.
vi: It was truly an opportunity that led me to rent a house in one of the most peculiar places in North America. It is a long, narrow, and rich island stretching eastward from New York. Among the other rare and strange sights there are two strips of land with peculiar shapes. They are about twenty miles away from the city, looking like a pair of giant eggs, identical in shape and separated by a long strip of water, elegantly called a strait. The two eggs protrude, encroaching into the most tamed saltwater area in the Western Hemisphere, the Long Island Sound, a vast wet livestock farm. These two strips of land are not entirely oval. Like the egg in Columbus's anecdote, both are flattened at the end where they connect to the mainland. The similarity in shape is the reason why the seagulls flying overhead are constantly confused. However, for other wingless creatures, the magical allure here lies in the complete difference of everything between the two strips of land, except for shape and size.
tr: It was entirely by chance that I rented a house in a region where the strangest people of North America lived. My house was on that narrow island extending east of New York, in the midst of chaos. Besides the strange natural landscapes here, there were two extraordinary terrestrial formations. About thirty kilometers away from the city center, a pair of gigantic eggs, identical to each other and separated only by a delicate bay, extending to Long Island Sound, the best cultivated saltwater region in the Western Hemisphere. They were not exactly oval. The points where both of them connected to the land were flattened, like the eggs in Columbus's story. There is no doubt that these gigantic eggs were a source of bewilderment for the seagulls flying over them. For us, the wingless ones, the dissimilarity of their features other than shape and size occupies the mind.
es: It was by chance that I rented a house in one of the strangest communities in North America. It was on that narrow and bustling island that extends east of New York and where, among other natural curiosities, two rare land masses are formed. About thirty kilometers from the city, two enormous eggs, identical in profile and separated only by a small bay, stand out in the most domesticated body of saltwater in the Western Hemisphere, the Long Island Sound, a great corral of humidity. They are not perfectly oval—like Columbus's egg, both are flattened on the side they rest on—but their physical resemblance must be a source of perpetual wonder for the seagulls that fly over them. For creatures without wings, their dissimilarity in every detail other than shape and size is a more interesting phenomenon.

en: I lived at West Egg, the—well, the less fashionable of the two, though this is a most superficial tag to express the bizarre and not a little sinister contrast between them. My house was at the very tip of the egg, only fifty yards from the Sound, and squeezed between two huge places that rented for twelve or fifteen thousand a season. The one on my right was a colossal affair by any standard—it was a factual imitation of some Hôtel de Ville in Normandy, with a tower on one side, spanking new under a thin beard of raw ivy, and a marble swimming pool, and more than forty acres of lawn and garden. It was Gatsby’s mansion. Or, rather, as I didn’t know Mr. Gatsby, it was a mansion inhabited by a gentleman of that name. My own house was an eyesore, but it was a small eyesore, and it had been overlooked, so I had a view of the water, a partial view of my neighbour’s lawn, and the consoling proximity of millionaires—all for eighty dollars a month.
vi: My house is in West Egg - comparing the two eggs, this side is less luxurious, however, this is just a common saying to describe the peculiar difference between the two places, it is not a malicious comparison. My house is right at the sharp tip of the egg, only about fifty yards from the strait, wedged between two massive houses whose rental prices range from twelve to fifteen thousand dollars each vacation season. The house to the right of mine is a gigantic architectural structure by any standard. It was built based on the architecture of some town hall in Normandy, France. The house is still new, nestled under sparse ivy vines, it includes a tower built on the side, a marble swimming pool, and over forty acres of lawns and gardens. That is Gatsby's mansion. More precisely, since I had not yet met Gatsby, it was the massive mansion residence of a nobleman by that name. My house next door became an eyesore, but only a small one because no one really paid attention to it. Therefore, I got to enjoy the sea view, a part of the neighbor's lawn, and the comfort of living near millionaires while only paying eighty dollars a month.
tr: I lived in West Egg, the less fashionable of the two. Still, I think this description falls short in expressing the bizarre and ominous contrast between them. My house was at the very tip of the egg and only fifty meters from the Sound. It was squeezed between two huge houses that rented for twelve to fifteen thousand dollars a season. The one on the right was a colossal affair by any standard. It was a replica of the Hotel de Ville in Normandy. Beside the building, there was a tower covered with ivy, a marble swimming pool, and over twenty acres of lawn and garden. This was Gatsby's mansion. Since I didn't know him at the time, it would be more accurate to say a gentleman named Gatsby. My own house, which was an eyesore, didn't attract much attention. For a mere eighty dollars a month, I lived next to a millionaire, overlooking a small part of my wealthy neighbor's garden and the Sound.
es: I lived in West Egg, the..., well, the less fashionable of the two eggs, though this is the most superficial formula to express the strange, rather sinister contrast between them. My house was at the tip of the egg about fifty meters from the strait, squeezed between two imposing mansions that rented for twelve or fifteen thousand dollars a season. The one that rose to my right was colossal without question, a faithful copy of some Hôtel de Ville in Normandy, with a tower on one side, extraordinarily new under a sparse beard of young ivy, a marble pool, and twenty acres of gardens and lawn. It was Gatsby's mansion. Or, more precisely, since I did not know Mr. Gatsby, it was the mansion of a gentleman who went by that name. My house was a horror, but an insignificant horror, which no one had noticed, so it had views of the sea and part of my neighbor's lawn, as well as the comforting proximity of millionaires, all for eighty dollars a month.

en: Across the courtesy bay the white palaces of fashionable East Egg glittered along the water, and the history of the summer really begins on the evening I drove over there to have dinner with the Tom Buchanans. Daisy was my second cousin once removed, and I’d known Tom in college. And just after the war I spent two days with them in Chicago.
vi: On the other side of the bay are the white castles of the luxurious East Egg village, resplendently lining the coast. The historic summer truly began one afternoon when I drove over there to have dinner with Tom Buchanan and his wife. Daisy was my distant cousin, and Tom I had known since college. When the war had just ended, I had stayed with them for two days in Chicago.
tr: Actually, the story of the summer began when I went to the Buchanans for dinner, accompanied by the white mansions stretching along the sea under the evening sun of East Egg on the opposite shore of the delicate bay. His wife Daisy was my second cousin. I knew Tom from university. I had stayed at their house in Chicago right after the war.
es: On the other side of the small bay, the white palaces of the elegant East Egg glittered in the water, and the story of that summer begins precisely the night I went to dine at Tom Buchanan's house. Daisy was a distant cousin of mine, and I knew Tom from university. And, just after the war, I spent a couple of days with them in Chicago.

en: Her husband, among various physical accomplishments, had been one of the most powerful ends that ever played football at New Haven—a national figure in a way, one of those men who reach such an acute limited excellence at twenty-one that everything afterward savours of anticlimax. His family were enormously wealthy—even in college his freedom with money was a matter for reproach—but now he’d left Chicago and come East in a fashion that rather took your breath away: for instance, he’d brought down a string of polo ponies from Lake Forest. It was hard to realize that a man in my own generation was wealthy enough to do that.
vi: In addition to many different physical achievements, Tom, Daisy's husband, was once one of the strongest rugby players in New Haven. He was also considered a player of national stature, who, when at his peak at the age of twenty-one, reached such heights that everything he achieved afterward could never compare. Tom's family was extremely wealthy, and even during his college years, Tom's extravagant spending habits drew much criticism. Now, although Tom has left Chicago to live in the East, his lifestyle still leaves people in awe, such as how he brought an entire herd of polo ponies from Lake Forest. It is hard to imagine that a young man born in the same the generation like mine that has become wealthy enough to spend at that level.
tr: Daisy’s husband, in addition to many athletic achievements, was one of the best forwards to have ever played on the school team in New Haven. He was practically a national hero. By the age of twenty-one, he had achieved such magnificent successes that everything he did afterward was overshadowed by them. His family was extremely wealthy. He was criticized during his university years for having unlimited freedom when it came to money. But now he had left Chicago and come to the East. He did it in such a way that it took people's breath away. For example, he brought along a number of polo ponies from Lake Forest when he came. For my generation, it is hard to even imagine having the wealth to do such a thing.
es: Daisy's husband, among other physical achievements, had been one of the most powerful ends to ever play football at New Haven: a national figure, one might say, one of those men who at twenty-one reach such a degree of excellence in a particular type of activity that everything that comes afterward feels like a disappointment. His family was excessively wealthy—to the point that in college his liberality with money was a subject of censure—but now they had moved from Chicago to the East, with a lifestyle that took one's breath away; for example, he had brought a stable of polo ponies from Lake Forest. It was hard to understand that a member of my generation could be rich enough to afford such a thing.

en: Why they came East I don’t know. They had spent a year in France for no particular reason, and then drifted here and there unrestfully wherever people played polo and were rich together. This was a permanent move, said Daisy over the telephone, but I didn’t believe it—I had no sight into Daisy’s heart, but I felt that Tom would drift on forever seeking, a little wistfully, for the dramatic turbulence of some irrecoverable football game.
vi: I don't know the reason why they moved to live in the East. They once lived in France for a year for no reason at all. After that, they kept drifting from place to place, living anywhere as long as there were polo players and wealthy people gathering. This time they would settle down here permanently, Daisy told me so over the phone, but I didn't believe it. I couldn't see through Daisy's heart, but I felt that Tom would always wander, always yearning to find the emotional excitement of the polo matches of the past that he could never find again.
tr: I don't know the reasons for coming to the East. They had stayed in France for a year without any reason, wandering around places where rich people played polo. This time, Daisy had said on the phone that they were moving permanently. Still, I didn't believe it. I knew what was on Daisy's mind, but I felt that Tom would forever be in search, longing for the excitement of football.
es: I don't know why they came to the East. They had spent a year in France without any specific reason, and then they had gone from place to place, restlessly, wherever polo was played or the rich gathered. Now they had moved for good, Daisy told me over the phone, but I didn't believe it: I couldn't see into Daisy's heart, but I knew that Tom would continue to anxiously and eternally seek the dramatic turbulence of some irretrievable football game.

en: And so it happened that on a warm windy evening I drove over to East Egg to see two old friends whom I scarcely knew at all. Their house was even more elaborate than I expected, a cheerful red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and ran towards the front door for a quarter of a mile, jumping over sundials and brick walks and burning gardens—finally when it reached the house drifting up the side in bright vines as though from the momentum of its run. The front was broken by a line of French windows, glowing now with reflected gold and wide open to the warm windy afternoon, and Tom Buchanan in riding clothes was standing with his legs apart on the front porch.
vi: Then, on a warm and windy afternoon, I drove to East Egg to visit two old friends whom I hardly understood. Their house was built more elaborately and intricately than I had imagined. It was a mansion designed in the Georgian colonial style, painted in cheerful red and white, facing the entire bay. The lawn, nearly a quarter mile long, started from the sea and stretched all the way to the front door, cutting through sundials, brick paths, and vibrant gardens, finally, when it reached the house, it seemed to be on a run, climbing up the side and turning into bright vines. The facade of the house was adorned with a row of tall, wide glass windows. These golden doors were now shining brightly from the reflected sunlight and were wide open to welcome the hot, windy afternoon. In his riding outfit, Tom Buchanan was standing with legs apart on the porch.
tr: Now, on a warm and windy evening, I was heading towards East Egg to see two old friends whom I didn't know very well. Their house had a more refined taste than I had expected. This mansion, built in Georgian Colonial architecture and painted in red and white, was situated on a height overlooking the bay. The green area in front extended from the seashore, advancing a few hundred meters to the main entrance door of the house. Along the way, it passed by occasional sundials, brick-paved walkways, and flower gardens glistening in the daylight, finally leaning against the wall covered with vines as if unable to stop when it reached the house. The glass of the French-style windows separating the front facade glowed golden in the sunlight, and the warm evening breeze flowed in through the open windows. Tom Buchanan, dressed in riding clothes, was waiting at the entrance to greet me.
es: And then, on a windy and hot afternoon, I went to East Egg to see two old friends whom I barely knew. Their house was even more exquisite than I expected, a cheerful red and white colonial mansion, Georgian style, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and stretched for half a kilometer up to the front door, passing sundials, terracotta paths, and lit gardens, until finally, upon reaching the house, as if taking advantage of the momentum, it climbed the wall transformed into healthy vines. The facade was broken by a succession of glass doors, which gleamed with golden reflections and opened wide to the wind and the heat of the afternoon. Tom Buchanan, in riding attire, was standing on the porch, legs apart.

en: He had changed since his New Haven years. Now he was a sturdy straw-haired man of thirty, with a rather hard mouth and a supercilious manner. Two shining arrogant eyes had established dominance over his face and gave him the appearance of always leaning aggressively forward. Not even the effeminate swank of his riding clothes could hide the enormous power of that body—he seemed to fill those glistening boots until he strained the top lacing, and you could see a great pack of muscle shifting when his shoulder moved under his thin coat. It was a body capable of enormous leverage—a cruel body.
vi: Tom had changed since his school years in New Haven. He was now a robust thirty-year-old man, with straw-colored hair, a stern mouth, and a disdainful demeanor. His bright eyes, full of arrogance, gave his face an overwhelming look and gave Tom an aggressive posture, thrusting forward. Even the elegant display through his riding outfit could not hide the immense strength of his body. His legs, tightly pressing against his shiny boots, looked as if they might burst the laces at the top, and one could see the rippling muscles moving each time his shoulders shifted beneath the thin coat. This was a body capable of tremendous strength, a brutal body.
tr: New Haven had changed a lot since we last met. In front of me stood an arrogant man in his thirties, with bright blonde hair, looking down on others. His shining, insolent eyes spread a sense of dominance across his face, and his posture gave the impression that he was leaning forward in anger at something. Even the feminine appearance of his riding outfit couldn't hide the immense power of his body. His feet filled his shiny boots so much that the laces on top could barely be tied. When he moved his shoulders under his thin garment, the massive muscles beneath could be felt. It was a body full of great strength, and at the same time, cruel.
es: He had changed since the days of New Haven. Now he was a thirty-year-old man, strong, blond like straw, with a hard set to his mouth and an air of self-sufficiency. His eyes, shining with arrogance, dominated his face and gave him the appearance of always being aggressively forward. Not even the ostentatious and effeminate elegance of the riding suit could hide the enormous vigor of that body: it seemed to fill those gleaming boots to the point of straining the laces that topped them, and the reaction of the imposing muscle mass was perceptible when the shoulder moved under the light jacket. It was a body capable of developing enormous strength: a cruel body.

en: His speaking voice, a gruff husky tenor, added to the impression of fractiousness he conveyed. There was a touch of paternal contempt in it, even toward people he liked—and there were men at New Haven who had hated his guts.
vi: Tom's high-pitched, hoarse voice further accentuated the gruffness in his manner of speaking. Adding to that was his condescending attitude. Even with those he liked, when he was still in school in New Haven, there was no shortage of people who bitterly hated Tom.
tr: The husky tenor tone of his voice when he spoke further reinforced his fierce appearance. There were traces of a bullying disdain in his voice - even towards those he loved. I remembered that there were a lot of people in New Haven who hated him.
es: When he spoke, his tenor voice, hoarse and rough, increased the impression of indifference that he conveyed. That voice had a hint of paternal disdain, even towards people he liked. There were men in New Haven who detested him.

en: “Now, don’t think my opinion on these matters is final,” he seemed to say, “just because I’m stronger and more of a man than you are.” We were in the same senior society, and while we were never intimate I always had the impression that he approved of me and wanted me to like him with some harsh, defiant wistfulness of his own.
vi: "Don't assume that my opinion on these matters is already decided," When Tom said that, it seemed like he meant "Just because I'm stronger and more of a man than you." The two of us were in the senior student association at school together, although we were never close, I always had the feeling that he liked me and wanted me to like him back in his rough and rebellious way.
tr: With that appearance, it was as if he was saying, "You don't actually need to accept that my ideas are superior just because I'm stronger than you." We were members of the same student club in our senior year of university. Even though we weren't very close, despite his stern and commanding demeanor, he acted as if he cared about me liking him.
es: "Well, don't go thinking that my opinion is definitive," he seemed to say, "just because I'm stronger and more of a man than you." We belonged to the same student association, and although we were never close friends, I always had the impression that he liked me, that he needed my esteem with that sad, hard, and defiant eagerness that was so characteristic of him.

en: We talked for a few minutes on the sunny porch.
vi: We stood chatting with each other for a few minutes on the sunlit porch.
tr: We chatted for a few minutes on the sunny terrace.
es: We talked for a few minutes on the porch, in the sun.

en: “I’ve got a nice place here,” he said, his eyes flashing about restlessly.
vi: "I found this place to be amazing." Tom said, his eyes full of ostentatiousness, constantly moving.
tr: "I made this place beautiful," he said while his sparkling eyes wandered around.
es: —This place is fine —he said, looking around with restless eyes.

en: Turning me around by one arm, he moved a broad flat hand along the front vista, including in its sweep a sunken Italian garden, a half acre of deep, pungent roses, and a snub-nosed motorboat that bumped the tide offshore.
vi: Tom used one hand to turn me around, then extended his broad hand forward to show off. Following the sweep of his hand, I saw an Italian-style sunken garden, half an acre of intensely fragrant roses, and a motorboat with a raised bow bobbing on the offshore waves.
tr: While he was guiding me by holding my arm with one hand, with his other broad, flat hand, he was pointing out the Italian-style garden sunk in the hollow, the fragrant roses in the half-acre area, and the upturned-nose motorboat bouncing on the waves a little off the shore.
es: He made me turn around, grabbing me by the arm, and pointed with his large, open hand at the panorama that stretched out before us, including in his sweep an Italian garden, two thousand square meters of roses with a penetrating and intense fragrance, and a motorboat, flat at the bow, which the tide was rocking a short distance from the shore.

en: “It belonged to Demaine, the oil man.” He turned me around again, politely and abruptly. “We’ll go inside.”
vi: "This house used to belong to Demain, the king of wealth." Tom turned me around once more, politely but abruptly. "Let's go inside."
tr: As he said the sentence, "This land belongs to that oil tycoon Demaine," he turned me around by grabbing my arm and politely said, "Let's go inside."
es: —It was Demaine, the one from the oil —once again he forced me to turn around, brusque and courteous—. Let's go in.

en: We walked through a high hallway into a bright rosy-coloured space, fragilely bound into the house by French windows at either end. The windows were ajar and gleaming white against the fresh grass outside that seemed to grow a little way into the house. A breeze blew through the room, blew curtains in at one end and out the other like pale flags, twisting them up toward the frosted wedding-cake of the ceiling, and then rippled over the wine-coloured rug, making a shadow on it as wind does on the sea.
vi: We walked through a tall corridor into a room of bright pink, with both ends of the room elegantly connected to the house by glass windows. These windows were slightly open, their white frames sparkling in contrast to the fresh green grass outside, which seemed to be trying to grow into the room. A gentle breeze blew through the room, lifting the curtains like flags, twisting them and then inflating them against the ceiling decorated like wedding cake frosting, before continuing to ripple across the wine-colored carpet, creating waves on its surface like the wind on the sea.
tr: We proceeded through a high-ceilinged, spacious hall and arrived at a bright, rose-colored room with French-style windows. The reflections of the slightly ajar windows were falling onto the fresh grass. The curtains were fluttering like pale flags with the breeze filling the room, sometimes rising towards the ceiling that resembled an ornate wedding cake, curling and twisting to create shadows on the wine-colored carpet like the wind rippling the sea.
es: We crossed a high-ceilinged lobby to a pink and luminous space, which was tenuously connected to the house by two glass doors. The glass doors were ajar and shone, white, in contrast with the fresh grass outside, which almost seemed to enter the house. A light breeze blew in the room: it fluttered the curtains like pale flags divided between the inside and the outside, twisted them towards the ceiling, a sort of wedding cake, and rippled the wine-colored tapestry, darkening it, like the wind darkens the sea.

en: The only completely stationary object in the room was an enormous couch on which two young women were buoyed up as though upon an anchored balloon. They were both in white, and their dresses were rippling and fluttering as if they had just been blown back in after a short flight around the house. I must have stood for a few moments listening to the whip and snap of the curtains and the groan of a picture on the wall. Then there was a boom as Tom Buchanan shut the rear windows and the caught wind died out about the room, and the curtains and the rugs and the two young women ballooned slowly to the floor.
vi: The only thing that remained stationary in the room was the enormous long chair with two young women sitting on it, looking as if they were floating on a balloon tethered below. Both were wearing white dresses, their clothes billowing as if they had just been blown back to their original spot after a short flight around the house. I must have stood there quietly for a moment, listening to the flapping sound of the curtains and the creaking groan of the picture hanging on the wall. A loud bang occurred when Tom closed the side window, and the wind ceased entirely, along with the curtains, the rugs, and the balloon containing the two young women slowly descended to the ground.
tr: The only motionless object in the living room was a majestic sofa on which two young women were moving about like buoys tied to an anchor. Both were dressed in white. Their delicate clothes seemed to flutter around the house and then settle where they were, trembling. I must have stood there for a while, listening to the whip-like sounds of the curtains and the moaning of the painting on the wall. Then Tom Buchanan noisily closed the back windows, and the breeze that filled the room died down inside. The curtains, the carpet, and the clothes of the two young women slowly became still.
es: The only object that remained absolutely still in the room was a huge sofa on which two young women floated as if on a balloon tethered to the ground. Both were dressed in white, and their dresses billowed and fluttered as if they had just arrived from a fleeting flight around the house. I had to stand for a while, listening to the whipping of the curtains and the creaking of a picture on the wall. Then there was an explosion: Tom Buchanan had closed the rear windows, and the trapped wind in the room ceased, and the curtains, tapestries, and the dresses of the two women slowly settled back to the floor.

en: The younger of the two was a stranger to me. She was extended full length at her end of the divan, completely motionless, and with her chin raised a little, as if she were balancing something on it which was quite likely to fall. If she saw me out of the corner of her eyes she gave no hint of it—indeed, I was almost surprised into murmuring an apology for having disturbed her by coming in.
vi: Of the two people, I was not acquainted with the younger woman. She lay stretched out at one end of the bench, completely motionless, her chin slightly raised as if trying to balance something on it that was about to fall. In fact, whether she saw me through the corner of her eye or not, I couldn't tell, because she didn't show any expression at all. I was so surprised that I almost mumbled an apology for my presence disturbing them.
tr: I did not know the younger of the two women. She was lying at one end of the divan, staying completely still, holding her chin slightly up as if balancing something. Even if she was glancing at me from the corner of her eye, it was not noticeable. I was almost going to apologize for disturbing her by entering.
es: I didn't know the youngest one. She had lain down in the part of the sofa she occupied, completely still, with her chin slightly raised, as if balancing something that was about to collapse. If she had seen me out of the corner of her eye, she didn't show it, and I almost found myself murmuring an apology for having disturbed her by entering the room.

en: The other girl, Daisy, made an attempt to rise—she leaned slightly forward with a conscientious expression—then she laughed, an absurd, charming little laugh, and I laughed too and came forward into the room.
vi: The second person, Daisy, at least made an effort to sit up. She leaned slightly forward with a cautious expression, then let out a small, charmingly ridiculous laugh. I laughed along and then stepped into the room.
tr: The other one, that is, Daisy, moved as if she was about to get up – slightly bending with a careful expression on her face – then she let out a strange but charming laugh. I laughed too and walked towards her.
es: The other girl, Daisy, made a motion to get up —she leaned forward with a determined expression—, and then she laughed, with an absurd and charming giggle, and I laughed too and moved closer.

en: “I’m p-paralysed with happiness.”
vi: "I was so happy that I was completely stunned," Daisy laughed again as if she had just said something very witty.
tr: “I froze in place from joy,” she said.
es: —I am pa… paralyzed with happiness.

en: She laughed again, as if she said something very witty, and held my hand for a moment, looking up into my face, promising that there was no one in the world she so much wanted to see. That was a way she had. She hinted in a murmur that the surname of the balancing girl was Baker. (I’ve heard it said that Daisy’s murmur was only to make people lean toward her; an irrelevant criticism that made it no less charming.)
vi: Daisy held my hand for a moment, then looked up at my face as if to assure me that she didn't wish to meet anyone more than me; Daisy's manner has always been like that. She whispered to introduce me to the girl performing the balancing act, whose last name was Baker. (I heard rumors that Daisy often whispered just to make people lean closer to her. Such an unjust criticism did not diminish her charm).
tr: Then she laughed again as if she had said something witty. While holding my hand, she was looking at my face as if I were the person she wanted to see most in the world. She was always like this. She leaned in a bit and whispered that the girl trying to balance something on her chin was named Baker. (I had heard that Daisy’s habit of whispering was to make people lean towards her. This unfounded criticism never diminished her charm, of course.)
es: She laughed again, as if she had said something very clever, and held my hand for a moment, looking into my eyes, promising that there was no one in the world she wished to see more. That was how she was. She whispered to me that the young acrobat's last name was Baker. (I have heard it said that the only purpose of Daisy's whisper was to make people lean towards her: an irrelevant criticism that did not diminish her charm.)

en: At any rate, Miss Baker’s lips fluttered, she nodded at me almost imperceptibly, and then quickly tipped her head back again—the object she was balancing had obviously tottered a little and given her something of a fright. Again a sort of apology arose to my lips. Almost any exhibition of complete self-sufficiency draws a stunned tribute from me.
vi: Baker's lips began to move. She nodded to me, so slightly that it was barely noticeable, then quickly tilted her head back as before. The object that Baker was balancing seemed about to fall, making her anxious. Once again, I almost blurted out words that sounded like an apology. I turned back to look at Daisy as my cousin began to ask questions in a deep, resonant voice.
tr: Somehow, Mrs. Baker's lips had moved. After greeting me with a barely perceptible motion, she threw her head back. The object she was trying to balance must have wobbled a bit, as she started slightly. I was about to apologize to her again. For some reason, I have always admired such self-sufficient people.
es: But Miss Baker's lips moved, she leaned almost imperceptibly to greet me, and immediately straightened up again: the object she was balancing had wobbled and given her a fright. Once again, a sort of apology came to my lips. In the face of displays of absolute self-sufficiency, I almost always surrender, stunned.

en: I looked back at my cousin, who began to ask me questions in her low, thrilling voice. It was the kind of voice that the ear follows up and down, as if each speech is an arrangement of notes that will never be played again. Her face was sad and lovely with bright things in it, bright eyes and a bright passionate mouth, but there was an excitement in her voice that men who had cared for her found difficult to forget: a singing compulsion, a whispered “Listen,” a promise that she had done gay, exciting things just a while since and that there were gay, exciting things hovering in the next hour.
vi: I turned back to look at Daisy as my cousin began to ask questions in a deep, resonant voice. It was the kind of voice that made the listener's ears follow its rise and fall, as if each word was an arrangement of musical notes that would never be played again. Daisy's face bore a beautiful melancholy, containing radiant brightness - those were her sparkling bright eyes and her passionately charming mouth. However, the most captivating thing about Daisy was her voice, which held a liveliness that made it very difficult for the men who loved her to forget: for instance, the melodious pleading, the whisper "listen to me," the earnest recounting that she had just experienced joyful moments and that even more joy was coming within the next hour.
tr: I turned again to my cousin, who was asking questions with his hoarse, trembling voice. It was a voice that one would follow its ups and downs as if listening to a melody they would never hear again, a melody that made people perk up their ears. His face was cute and sad, his sparkling eyes and sensual wet lips were noticeable, but what men who were interested in him could never forget was his voice that excited people. It was an enticing song, a promise that whispered "listen," suggesting that he had just done something enthusiastic and provocative, and that he would do something enthusiastic and provocative again within an hour.
es: I looked again at my cousin, who began asking me questions in a deep, disturbing voice. It was one of those voices that the ear follows in its descents and ascents, as if each phrase were a succession of notes that would never sound together again. She had a sad and delightful face, with luminous details —the luminous eyes and the passionate light of the mouth— and there was an emotion in her voice that the men who had loved her could not forget: a singing vehemence, a whispered "hear me," the promise that she had just lived happy and vibrant moments and that happy and vibrant moments awaited in the next hour.

en: I told her how I had stopped off in Chicago for a day on my way East, and how a dozen people had sent their love through me.
vi: I told Daisy about how on my way through the East I had stopped by Chicago, and how about a dozen people had sent their regards to Daisy.
tr: I told him that I had stopped by Chicago for a day on my way here and that a dozen people had sent their regards to him.
es: I told her that I had spent a day in Chicago, on my way to the East, and that everyone had sent kisses for her.

en: “Do they miss me?” she cried ecstatically.
vi: "Do they really miss me?" Daisy exclaimed in ecstasy.
tr: “Did they miss me?” he asked excitedly.
es: —Do you miss me? —she exclaimed, ecstatic.

en: “The whole town is desolate. All the cars have the left rear wheel painted black as a mourning wreath, and there’s a persistent wail all night along the north shore.”
vi: "The entire city was in mourning. All the cars had their left rear wheel painted black to symbolize a mourning wreath, and there were continuous sounds of lamentation throughout the night along the northern shore of the lake."
tr: "The city is in a miserable state. They have painted the left rear wheels of the cars black, as if in mourning. On the northern coast, the laments never cease."
es: —The entire city is desolate. All the cars have the left rear wheel painted black as a sign of mourning, and at night, the weeping on the northern shore of the lake never ends[4].

en: “How gorgeous! Let’s go back, Tom. Tomorrow!” Then she added irrelevantly: “You ought to see the baby.”
vi: "Great! Let's go back there, Tom. Tomorrow!" Then Daisy added something that had nothing to do with the ongoing conversation. "Do you want to meet my child?"
tr: "Great! Let's go back, Tom." “Right away, tomorrow!” Then, quite out of place, she suddenly said, "You should see the baby."
es: —It's wonderful! We have to go back, Tom! Tomorrow! —and incoherently added—. You have to see the girl.

en: “I’d like to.”
vi: "I really want to."
tr: “I would love to.”
es: —I would love to.

en: “She’s asleep. She’s three years old. Haven’t you ever seen her?”
vi: "The little girl has fallen asleep." "She is three years old." "You have never met her, have you?"
tr: “She is sleeping now. She turned three. Hadn't you seen her before?”
es: —She is sleeping. She is three years old. Have you never seen her?

en: “Never.”
vi: "Never."
tr: "No."
es: —Never.

en: “Well, you ought to see her. She’s—”
vi: "Then you should meet her. The girl..."
tr: "Then you absolutely must see it. He-"
es: —Well, you have to see it. It's…

en: Tom Buchanan, who had been hovering restlessly about the room, stopped and rested his hand on my shoulder.
vi: Tom Buchanan had been pacing back and forth in the room, now he stopped and placed his hand on my shoulder.
tr: Tom Buchanan, who was pacing restlessly inside the room, came up to me and put his hand on my shoulder.
es: Tom Buchanan, who had not stopped pacing around the room, stopped and put a hand on my shoulder.

en: “What you doing, Nick?”
vi: "Nick, what are you doing for a living now?"
tr: “What do you do for a living, Nick?”
es: —What do you do for a living, Nick?

en: “I’m a bond man.”
vi: "I issue credit bonds"
tr: “I am a stockbroker”
es: —I'm selling bonds.

en: “Who with?”
vi: "With which company?"
tr: "Whose side are you on?"
es: —With whom?

en: I told him.
vi: I give the answer.
tr: I told her.
es: I told him/her.

en: “Never heard of them,” he remarked decisively.
vi: "I've never heard of these companies." Tom replied decisively.
tr: "I've never heard of it," he said with a definitive tone.
es: —It's the first time I've heard those names —he pointed out bluntly.

en: This annoyed me.
vi: This way of speaking annoyed me.
tr: This had bothered me a bit.
es: It bothered me.

en: “You will,” I answered shortly. “You will if you stay in the East.”
vi: I responded curtly. "You would know if you stayed in the East." "Oh, don't worry, I will definitely stay in the East."
tr: “You will hear,” I answered briefly. “of course, if you stay in the East.”
es: —You will hear them —I cut him off—. You will hear them if you stay in the East.

en: “Oh, I’ll stay in the East, don’t you worry,” he said, glancing at Daisy and then back at me, as if he were alert for something more. “I’d be a God damned fool to live anywhere else.”
vi: Tom said, glancing at Daisy and then back at me, seemingly wary of other reactions. "I would be foolish to go anywhere else."
tr: “I will stay, don't worry,” he said first to Daisy, then looking at me. He seemed to be expecting an objection. “I'm not foolish enough to go somewhere else.”
es: —I will stay in the East, yes, don't worry —he said, looking at Daisy and then at me again, as if he expected us to add something—. I would be a fucking idiot if I lived anywhere else.

en: At this point Miss Baker said: “Absolutely!” with such suddenness that I started—it was the first word she had uttered since I came into the room. Evidently it surprised her as much as it did me, for she yawned and with a series of rapid, deft movements stood up into the room.
vi: At that moment, Baker spoke up, "Of course!" This sudden statement startled me. These were the first words she had uttered since I entered the room. Clearly, this surprised Baker herself just as much as it did me. She yawned and stood up after a series of graceful, swift movements.
tr: Just then, Mrs. Baker shouted "Absolutely!" so quickly that I was startled. It was the first time she had spoken since I entered the room. It was clear that she was at least as surprised as I was. She yawned and got up from her seat with a swift movement.
es: Then Miss Baker let out a "Of course!" so unexpected that it startled me: they were the first words she had spoken since I had entered the room. That surprised her as much as it did me, evidently, because she yawned and with a series of quick and agile movements stood up.

en: “I’m stiff,” she complained, “I’ve been lying on that sofa for as long as I can remember.”
vi: "My body is completely numb, I've been lying here for who knows how long." Baker complained.
tr: "I'm all stiff," she complained, "I don't remember how long I've been lying on this couch."
es: —I can't move —she complained—. I've been lying on that couch since I can remember.

en: “Don’t look at me,” Daisy retorted, “I’ve been trying to get you to New York all afternoon.”
vi: "Don't blame me, I tried my best to persuade you to go to New York all afternoon." Daisy retorted.
tr: “Don’t look at me,” said Daisy, “I’ve been trying to take you to New York since morning.
es: —Don't look at me —replied Daisy—. I've been trying to take you to New York all afternoon.

en: “No, thanks,” said Miss Baker to the four cocktails just in from the pantry. “I’m absolutely in training.”
vi: "No, thank you. I don't drink." Baker declined as four cocktails were just brought up from the dining room. "I'm in training."
tr: Miss Baker glanced at the four cocktail glasses brought from the kitchen and said, “No, I don’t want any, I’m training.”
es: —No, thank you —said Miss Baker, at the sight of the four cocktails arriving from the kitchen at that precise moment—. I am in the middle of training.

en: Her host looked at her incredulously.
vi: The homeowner looked at Baker skeptically.
tr: The landlord was quite skeptical,
es: Her host looked at her incredulously.

en: “You are!” He took down his drink as if it were a drop in the bottom of a glass. “How you ever get anything done is beyond me.”
vi: "Really?" Then Tom drained his glass of wine as if there was only a drop left at the bottom. "I don't know how you manage to get everything done."
tr: “Is it you!” said Tom as he downed his glass, “I can never understand how you manage your affairs.”
es: —Trainings! —Tom drank the cocktail as if it were a drop at the bottom of a glass—. I don't understand how you achieve what you achieve.

en: I looked at Miss Baker, wondering what it was she “got done.” I enjoyed looking at her. She was a slender, small-breasted girl, with an erect carriage, which she accentuated by throwing her body backward at the shoulders like a young cadet. Her grey sun-strained eyes looked back at me with polite reciprocal curiosity out of a wan, charming, discontented face. It occurred to me now that I had seen her, or a picture of her, somewhere before.
vi: I looked at Baker, wondering what she could possibly do. I liked watching Baker. She had a slender body, small breasts, and a straight posture. Baker tried to accentuate her figure even more by pushing her shoulders back like a cadet. Her eyes had a less bright look due to sun fatigue on a charming but weary and irritable face. Baker politely returned my gaze with a curious look of her own. I realized that I had seen her or her picture somewhere before.
tr: I looked at Bayan Baker, I was genuinely curious about what she had "handled". I enjoyed looking at her. She was thin, her breasts were small. She walked upright, throwing her shoulders back like a military school student. She looked at me with a polite expression on her pale face, her gray eyes dazzled by the sun. I thought I had seen her or her photograph somewhere.
es: I looked at Miss Baker, wondering what she was achieving. I enjoyed watching her. She was a slim girl, with small breasts, who walked very upright, something she accentuated by throwing her shoulders back like a cadet. Her eyes, gray and irritated by the sun, met mine with equal curiosity from a sad, friendly, unsatisfied face. Then I realized that I had seen her somewhere before, in person or in a photo.

en: “You live in West Egg,” she remarked contemptuously. “I know somebody there.”
vi: "You live in West Egg, right? I know a few people there."
tr: “I suppose you live in West Egg,” he said with a disdainful expression. “I know someone who lives there.”
es: —You live in West Egg —he stated with disdain—. I know someone from there.

en: “I don’t know a single—”
vi: Baker asked disdainfully. "I don't know anyone."
tr: “I didn't—”
es: —I don't know a single one...

en: “You must know Gatsby.”
vi: "You must know Gatsby."
tr: “I'm sure you know Gatsby.””
es: —You have to meet Gatsby.

en: “Gatsby?” demanded Daisy. “What Gatsby?”
vi: "You must know Gatsby." "Gatsby?" "Which Gatsby?"
tr: “Which Gatsby?” asked Daisy.
es: —Gatsby? —asked Daisy—. Which Gatsby?

en: Before I could reply that he was my neighbour dinner was announced; wedging his tense arm imperatively under mine, Tom Buchanan compelled me from the room as though he were moving a checker to another square.
vi: Daisy asked insistently. Before I had a chance to reply that the person was my neighbor, everyone was informed that dinner was ready. Extending his stiff arm to grip mine tightly, Tom Buchanan pushed me out of the room as if moving a chess piece from one square to another.
tr: Before I had a chance to say he was my neighbor, it was announced that dinner was ready. Tom Buchanan, with a commanding demeanor, placed his tense arm under mine and moved me out of the room as if moving a pawn to another square on a chessboard.
es: Before I could tell him that he was my neighbor, dinner was announced; forcefully and peremptorily intertwining his arm with mine, Tom Buchanan dragged me out of the room as if moving a piece on a chessboard.

en: Slenderly, languidly, their hands set lightly on their hips, the two young women preceded us out on to a rosy-coloured porch, open toward the sunset, where four candles flickered on the table in the diminished wind.
vi: Leisurely, slowly, with their hands lightly resting on their hips, two young women led the way ahead of us, stepping out onto the pink-painted porch facing the evening sunset. On the table, four candles had been lit, flickering gently in the light breeze.
tr: Two young people, walking slowly with their hands on their hips, were moving towards the rose-colored terrace overlooking the sunset, with a delicate woman swaying ahead of us. The lightening wind was flickering the flames of the four candles on the table.
es: Thin and languid, with their hands resting weightlessly on their hips, the two young women preceded us onto the pink porch, open to the sunset, where, on the table, a gentle breeze made the light of four candles tremble.

en: “Why candles?” objected Daisy, frowning. She snapped them out with her fingers. “In two weeks it’ll be the longest day in the year.” She looked at us all radiantly. “Do you always watch for the longest day of the year and then miss it? I always watch for the longest day in the year and then miss it.”
vi: "Why light the candles?" Daisy frowned in protest and then snapped her fingers to extinguish them. "In two weeks, it will be the longest day of the year. Does everyone look forward to the longest day of the year but then let it pass by unnoticed? I always wait for the longest day of the year but then let it slip away."
tr: “What are these candles?” Daisy muttered, frowning. Then she pressed her fingers to the wick and extinguished the candles. “In two weeks, it will be the longest day of the year.” She looked at us cheerfully. “Do you also wait for the longest day and then miss it? I always wait, and I always miss it.”
es: —Why candles? —protested Daisy, frowning. She extinguished them with her fingers—. The longest day of the year will be in two weeks —she looked at us radiantly—. Don’t you spend the whole year waiting for the longest day to come and then, when it arrives, you don’t even notice? I spend the whole year waiting for the longest day to come and when it arrives, I don’t even notice.

en: “We ought to plan something,” yawned Miss Baker, sitting down at the table as if she were getting into bed.
vi: Daisy looked at us with a bright, radiant face. "We should organize to do something." Baker yawned, sitting at the table in a manner that resembled preparing to lie down on a bed.
tr: “We can do something together,” said Mrs. Baker, yawning as she sat in her chair as if she were sitting in her bed.
es: —We have to plan something —yawned Miss Baker, sitting at the table as if she were getting into bed.

en: “All right,” said Daisy. “What’ll we plan?” She turned to me helplessly: “What do people plan?”
vi: "That's right." "What should we organize?" Daisy said, turning to ask me. "What do people usually organize?"
tr: “Okay,” said Daisy. “So, what should we do?” She turned to me with a helpless expression. “I wonder what people would like to do?”
es: —Wonderful —said Daisy—. What can we plan? —she turned to me, uncertain—. What do people plan?

en: Before I could answer her eyes fastened with an awed expression on her little finger.
vi: Before I could answer, Daisy's eyes were fixed on her little finger with a look of horror.
tr: Just as I was about to respond, he directed his gaze to his little finger.
es: Before he could answer, he stared at his pinky finger with an expression of horror.

en: “Look!” she complained; “I hurt it.”
vi: "Look, my finger hurts." Daisy complained.
tr: "Look over there!" he complained; "I hurt my finger."
es: —Look! —he complained—. I've hurt myself.

en: We all looked—the knuckle was black and blue.
vi: We all turned to look, the knuckles were already bruised.
tr: We all looked. Its joints were bruised.
es: We all looked. He had a bruise on his knuckle.

en: “You did it, Tom,” she said accusingly. “I know you didn’t mean to, but you did do it. That’s what I get for marrying a brute of a man, a great, big, hulking physical specimen of a—”
vi: "You did that, Tom," Daisy blamed. "I know you didn't mean to, but it was you who caused it." "That's the price I have to pay for marrying a brute of a man, a hulking specimen."
tr: “You did this, Tom,” she said accusingly. “Maybe you didn't do it on purpose, but you still did it. This is what happens when you marry a brute like you, a big clumsy oaf...”
es: —It was you, Tom —she said, accusing her husband—. I know it was unintentional, but it was you. That's what I get for marrying a brute, a hulk, an enormous, immeasurable specimen of a…

en: “I hate that word ‘hulking,’ ” objected Tom crossly, “even in kidding.”
vi: Sometimes both Daisy and Baker would speak at the same time with sarcastic remarks, not disturbing anyone, not chattering but calm and cool like the clothes they were wearing and like their empty eyes devoid of desire.
tr: "I don't like that word," Tom burst out angrily, "even as a joke, don't say it."
es: —I can't stand the word mole —said Tom, annoyed—, not even as a joke.

en: “Hulking,” insisted Daisy.
vi: Sometimes both Daisy and Baker would speak at the same time with sarcastic remarks, not disturbing anyone, not chattering but calm and cool like the clothes they were wearing and like their empty eyes devoid of desire.
tr: “You are stubborn, but” insisted Daisy.
es: —A monster —insisted Daisy.
