en: Sometimes she and Miss Baker talked at once, unobtrusively and with a bantering inconsequence that was never quite chatter, that was as cool as their white dresses and their impersonal eyes in the absence of all desire. They were here, and they accepted Tom and me, making only a polite pleasant effort to entertain or to be entertained. They knew that presently dinner would be over and a little later the evening too would be over and casually put away. It was sharply different from the West, where an evening was hurried from phase to phase towards its close, in a continually disappointed anticipation or else in sheer nervous dread of the moment itself.
vi: Sometimes both Daisy and Baker would speak at the same time with sarcastic remarks, not disturbing anyone, not chattering but calm and cool like the clothes they were wearing and like their empty eyes devoid of desire. The two young women sat there, accepting the presence of Tom and me, trying politely to make conversation to entertain us or to entertain themselves. Both knew that dinner would eventually end, and soon the afternoon would pass by as well. Life here was completely different from life in the West, where afternoons always rushed from one stage to another until ending in a predictable disappointment or in complete terror of the present moment.
tr: From time to time, he and Mrs. Baker would talk and joke simultaneously, jumping from one topic to another. Their conversation was as calm as their white clothes and languid eyes. They had accepted being here with Tom and me, and without much effort, they were both having fun and entertaining us. They knew that the meal would soon be over, the night would soon end, and everything would be left behind. This place was very different from the West. There, the evenings would rapidly progress towards their end, constantly filled with disappointing predictions or the alarming terror of the moment itself.
es: Sometimes Miss Baker and she would talk at the same time, without raising their voices, with a playful incoherence that never descended into mere chatter, as unperturbed as their white dresses, as their impersonal eyes free of any desire. There they were, and they accepted Tom and me, making an effort, perhaps out of politeness and kindness, to entertain us or entertain themselves. They knew that dinner would soon end, as would the evening, which would be forgotten without much importance. It was very different in the West, where an evening would rush from phase to phase towards its end in a succession of always disappointed expectations or in the pure anguish of the moment.

en: “You make me feel uncivilized, Daisy,” I confessed on my second glass of corky but rather impressive claret. “Can’t you talk about crops or something?”
vi: "Daisy, you make me feel like an uncivilized person." I confided regret after drinking the second glass of red wine with a strong cork smell. "Can you talk about the fields, the harvest, or any other topic?"
tr: While drinking the second glass of a high-quality Bordeaux wine that had absorbed the smell of cork, I confessed, "You make me feel uncivilized, Daisy," "at least talk about cereals or something to complete the picture!"
es: —You make me feel like an uncivilized being, Daisy —I confessed over the second glass of a claret with a slight cork taste, but impressive—. Can’t you talk about harvests or something like that?

en: I meant nothing in particular by this remark, but it was taken up in an unexpected way.
vi: I have no hidden meaning in this statement, but it was received differently.
tr: I didn't say this with a specific purpose, but I encountered a reaction I never expected.
es: I didn't mean anything in particular with my observation, but it was received in an unexpected way.

en: “Civilization’s going to pieces,” broke out Tom violently. “I’ve gotten to be a terrible pessimist about things. Have you read The Rise of the Coloured Empires by this man Goddard?”
vi: Tom exclaimed fiercely. "Civilization will shatter into pieces, I truly feel pessimistic about this matter." "Have you read the book 'The Rise of the Colored Empires' written by some Mr. Goddard?"
tr: “Civilization is collapsing,” Tom shouted angrily, “I am very pessimistic about this matter now. Have you read the book called The Rise of the Colored Empires by that man named Goddard?”
es: —Civilization is collapsing —Tom burst out—. I've become terribly pessimistic. Have you read The Rise of the Colored Empires, by a certain Goddard?[5]

en: “Why, no,” I answered, rather surprised by his tone.
vi: "Not yet, so what?" I replied, feeling surprised by Tom's tone.
tr: "No, I haven't read it," I said, the tone of my voice surprising me.
es: —The truth is, no —I replied, surprised by his tone.

en: “Well, it’s a fine book, and everybody ought to read it. The idea is if we don’t look out the white race will be—will be utterly submerged. It’s all scientific stuff; it’s been proved.”
vi: "It is a good book that everyone should read. The idea of the book is that if we are not careful, the white race will be completely submerged. Those opinions are completely scientific and have been proven."
tr: “A very good book, everyone should read it. It argues that if we are not careful, the white race – you heard it right, the white race – will disappear. It is quite a scientific book, providing evidence for everything it claims.”
es: —Well, it's a great book, and everyone should read it. Its thesis is that, if we don't stay on guard, the white race will end up... will end up completely sinking. It's a scientific fact, proven.

en: “Tom’s getting very profound,” said Daisy, with an expression of unthoughtful sadness. “He reads deep books with long words in them. What was that word we—”
vi: "Tom is becoming more and more erudite." Daisy said with a not very deeply sad expression. "He reads profound books full of long words. Do you remember that word we..."
tr: “Tom has started getting into deep subjects,” said Daisy with a careless sorrow, “He’s reading quite deep books with long sentences in them. What was it called, um...”
es: —Tom is becoming very profound —said Daisy, with a careless air of sadness—. He reads profound books, full of very long words. What was that word that…?

en: “Well, these books are all scientific,” insisted Tom, glancing at her impatiently. “This fellow has worked out the whole thing. It’s up to us, who are the dominant race, to watch out or these other races will have control of things.”
vi: "Actually, these books are all science books." Tom insisted, glancing at his wife impatiently. "This author has researched everything carefully. Everything is now in our hands as the dominant race, we need to keep an eye on other races, otherwise, they will rise up and take control of everything."
tr: “Whatever! Those books are entirely scientific,” said Tom impatiently, “The man has figured out the issue well. Everything depends on us, the dominant race. Either we are careful, or we fall under the hegemony of other races.”
es: —Well, they are scientific books —insisted Tom, looking at her impatiently—. That Goddard has delved deeply into the matter. It is up to us, as the dominant race, to remain vigilant so that the other races do not take control of everything.

en: “We’ve got to beat them down,” whispered Daisy, winking ferociously toward the fervent sun.
vi: "We have to defeat them." Daisy whispered, glaring fiercely towards the scorching sun.
tr: "We need to defeat them," whispered Daisy, blinking her eyes as she looked directly at the sun's rays.
es: —We have to crush them —murmured Daisy, winking fiercely at the blazing sun.

en: “You ought to live in California—” began Miss Baker, but Tom interrupted her by shifting heavily in his chair.
vi: "You two should live in California." Baker spoke up, but Tom interrupted her by turning heavily in his chair.
tr: Bayan Baker had started by saying, "You have to live in California," but Tom interrupted her noisily, shifting in his seat, "According to this view, we are all of Norman descent.
es: —You should live in California —started Miss Baker, but Tom interrupted her, stirring heavily in his chair.

en: “This idea is that we’re Nordics. I am, and you are, and you are, and—” After an infinitesimal hesitation he included Daisy with a slight nod, and she winked at me again. “—And we’ve produced all the things that go to make civilization—oh, science and art, and all that. Do you see?”
vi: "The author puts forth the idea that we are Nordic people. I, you, she, and..." After a brief moment of hesitation, he included Daisy in the list with a slight nod, causing Daisy to wink at me once again. "And it is we who have created all the things that make up civilization, from science to art and everything else. Do you agree?"
tr: Bayan Baker had started by saying, "You have to live in California," but Tom interrupted her noisily, shifting in his seat, "According to this view, we are all of Norman descent. Me, you, you and..." he paused for a moment and slightly bowed his head to include his wife, at which point Daisy winked at me once again "... we have created everything that constitutes civilization. Science, art, and the others, do you understand?" There was a tragic aspect in his being so carried away.
es: —The idea is that we are Nordics. I am Nordic, and you, and you, and... —after an infinitesimal moment of doubt, he included Daisy by slightly bowing his head, and Daisy winked at me again—. And we have produced all the things that constitute civilization, yes, science and art, and everything else. Do you understand?

en: There was something pathetic in his concentration, as if his complacency, more acute than of old, was not enough to him any more. When, almost immediately, the telephone rang inside and the butler left the porch Daisy seized upon the momentary interruption and leaned towards me.
vi: There was something truly pitiable in the way Tom strained his mind, as if Tom's self-satisfaction, now even higher than before, still wasn't enough to help him think. Just at that moment, the telephone rang inside the house, and the butler left the porch to go inside. Daisy took advantage of this interruption to lean towards me and speak.
tr: His arrogance, which had always been excessive, seemed no longer sufficient for him. Just then, when the phone rang and the servant entered, Daisy took advantage of the opportunity to lean towards me.
es: There was something pathetic in his concentration, as if his self-sufficiency, deeper than ever, was no longer enough for him. When, almost immediately, the phone rang inside the house and the butler stepped out of the porch, Daisy took advantage of the pause and leaned towards me.

en: “I’ll tell you a family secret,” she whispered enthusiastically. “It’s about the butler’s nose. Do you want to hear about the butler’s nose?”
vi: "I will reveal to you a family secret." Daisy whispered eagerly. "The story about the butler's nose. Do you want to hear the story about the butler's nose?"
tr: "Let me tell you a family secret," he said in a low voice, "You know our servant's nose, right? Would you like to hear its story?"
es: —I'm going to tell you a family secret —he murmured enthusiastically—. It's about the butler's nose. Do you want to know the story of the butler's nose?

en: “That’s why I came over tonight.”
vi: "Well, I came here precisely because I wanted to hear that story."
tr: “That's why I came here anyway.”
es: —That's why I've come tonight.

en: “Well, he wasn’t always a butler; he used to be the silver polisher for some people in New York that had a silver service for two hundred people. He had to polish it from morning till night, until finally it began to affect his nose—”
vi: "In fact, he was not a butler before, but worked as a silver polisher for someone who had a shop with about two hundred customers in New York. He had to polish silver from morning until night until his nose got poisoned."
tr: He was a silver polisher at a company in New York with two hundred regular customers. Polishing silver from morning till night eventually started to damage his nose.
es: —Well, he hasn't always been a butler: he used to clean the silverware for certain people in New York who had silverware for two hundred people. He spent all day cleaning it from morning till night, until it started affecting his nose...

en: “Things went from bad to worse,” suggested Miss Baker.
vi: "The illness is getting worse and worse." Baker continued the suggestion.
tr: “And his condition has been getting worse,” Mrs. Baker interjected.
es: —Things went from bad to worse —suggested Miss Baker.

en: “Yes. Things went from bad to worse, until finally he had to give up his position.”
vi: "That's right. It kept getting worse until he eventually had to quit what he was doing."
tr: “Yes. It had gotten so bad that he finally had to quit his job.”
es: —Yes. Things went from bad to worse, until finally he had to leave the job.

en: For a moment the last sunshine fell with romantic affection upon her glowing face; her voice compelled me forward breathlessly as I listened—then the glow faded, each light deserting her with lingering regret, like children leaving a pleasant street at dusk.
vi: In a moment, the last drop of sunlight romantically fell on Daisy's radiant face. Her voice made me lean forward and hold my breath just to hear it. Then this radiance gradually faded as each drop of sunlight took turns to bid farewell regretfully, like children having to stop playing and leave the joy-filled street at twilight.
tr: The last rays of the setting sun gently caressed her face, which shone for a moment. As I listened to her breathlessly, the sun completely set, and the lights reluctantly left her face, like children who had to end their games on the street as darkness fell.
es: For an instant, with romantic affection, the last light of the sun shone on her face, radiant: her voice made me lean towards her as I listened without breathing. And then the radiance disappeared, each of the lights left her with sorrow, unwilling to go, like those children who have to leave the pleasure of the street at dusk.

en: The butler came back and murmured something close to Tom’s ear, whereupon Tom frowned, pushed back his chair, and without a word went inside. As if his absence quickened something within her, Daisy leaned forward again, her voice glowing and singing.
vi: The butler returned and whispered something into Tom's ear. Upon hearing it, Tom frowned, pushed his chair back, stood up, and went inside without saying a word. Tom's absence quickly gave Daisy an opportunity; she leaned forward once more, her voice radiant and melodious.
tr: The returning servant bent down and whispered something into Tom's ear. Tom's eyebrows furrowed. He pushed his chair back and stood up, entering inside without saying a word. After he left, Daisy became lively. With her impressive voice, she leaned in cheerfully as if singing a song:
es: The butler returned and whispered a few words into Tom's ear, who frowned, pushed the chair away from the table, and without a word, went into the house. As if that absence had accelerated something inside her, Daisy came closer to me again, and her voice lit up, it sang.

en: “I love to see you at my table, Nick. You remind me of a—of a rose, an absolute rose. Doesn’t he?” She turned to Miss Baker for confirmation: “An absolute rose?”
vi: "Nick, I really like you coming here to have a meal with me. You remind me of a rose, a pure rose. Isn't that right?" Daisy turned to Baker waiting for confirmation. "Isn't it a pure rose?"
tr: "I really enjoy seeing you, Nick," she said, "You remind me of roses, you know? Yes, you resemble a rose. Don't you think so?" she asked Mrs. Baker, seeking confirmation, "Don't you think he resembles one?"
es: —What a joy to see you at my table, Nick. You remind me of... a rose, exactly a rose. Don't you think? —he turned to Miss Baker for confirmation—. Exactly a rose, right?

en: This was untrue. I am not even faintly like a rose. She was only extemporizing, but a stirring warmth flowed from her, as if her heart was trying to come out to you concealed in one of those breathless, thrilling words. Then suddenly she threw her napkin on the table and excused herself and went into the house.
vi: This is not true. I am not even a little bit like a rose. Daisy was really just speaking on a whim, yet the warm breath emanating from her body seemed as if her heart was trying to reveal itself to the listener by hiding under words that carried no breath, transmitting out to touch the hearts of others. Then, suddenly Daisy threw her napkin onto the table, apologized to everyone, and went inside the house.
tr: Of course, this wasn't true. I didn't resemble roses in the slightest. He had spoken impulsively. Still, faced with this warmth overflowing from within, behind the excited words, you were swept away by the feelings that emerged as hidden emotions came to light. Suddenly, he threw his napkin on the table, stood up, apologized, and went inside.
es: It wasn't true. I don't look anything like a rose. Daisy was just improvising, but she exuded an exciting warmth, as if her heart wanted to escape and hide in one of those broken, disturbing words. Then, suddenly, she threw the napkin onto the table and went into the house.

en: Miss Baker and I exchanged a short glance consciously devoid of meaning. I was about to speak when she sat up alertly and said “Sh!” in a warning voice. A subdued impassioned murmur was audible in the room beyond, and Miss Baker leaned forward unashamed, trying to hear. The murmur trembled on the verge of coherence, sank down, mounted excitedly, and then ceased altogether.
vi: Baker and I exchanged a quick glance, deliberately not revealing any ideas. As I was about to speak, Baker swiftly stood up and said "Shh" in a cautious tone. The murmured conversations, trying to be kept low, could be heard from the next room. Without any shame, Baker leaned forward to try to listen. The murmuring grew louder, almost understandable, then lowered again, then rose to an animated level, and finally fell completely silent.
tr: I made eye contact with Ms. Baker. As I was preparing to speak, she straightened up and warned me with a "Shh." In the room behind us, something was being discussed in low voices. Ms. Baker leaned in without hesitation to hear better what was going on. The voices seemed to rise for a moment, then softened. A moment of shouting, then silence again.
es: Miss Baker and I exchanged a lightning glance, deliberately devoid of meaning. I was about to speak when she straightened up in her chair, alert, and said "Shhh," warning me. From the adjoining room came muffled and passionate murmurs, and Miss Baker leaned forward, without any shame, to try to listen. The murmur vibrated on the edge of coherence, grew weaker, rose in a kind of outburst, and ceased definitively.

en: “This Mr. Gatsby you spoke of is my neighbour—” I began.
vi: "Mr. Gatsby, whom you mentioned, is my neighbor.."
tr: “The Mr. Gatsby you just mentioned happens to be my neighbor...” I wanted to start the conversation.
es: —That Mr. Gatsby you talk about is my neighbor —I said.

en: “Don’t talk. I want to hear what happens.”
vi: I prompted. "Don't speak. I want to listen to see what's going on."
tr: “Be quiet for a moment! I want to hear what's going on.”
es: —Quiet. I want to find out what's happening.

en: “Is something happening?” I inquired innocently.
vi: "Is something happening?" I asked innocently.
tr: “Is there a problem?” I asked innocently.
es: —Is something wrong? —I asked innocently.

en: “You mean to say you don’t know?” said Miss Baker, honestly surprised. “I thought everybody knew.”
vi: "You really don't know? I thought everyone knew already." Baker said with genuine surprise.
tr: “Or don't you know?” asked Mrs. Baker, genuinely surprised. “I thought everyone knew.”
es: —Are you telling me that you don't know? —said Miss Baker, genuinely surprised—. I thought everyone knew.

en: “I don’t.”
vi: "I didn't know anything at all."
tr: “I don't know.”
es: —Not me.

en: “Why—” she said hesitantly. “Tom’s got some woman in New York.”
vi: "Really..." Baker hesitated, "Tom has another woman in New York."
tr: “Well,” he said, pausing a bit, “Tom has a mistress in New York”
es: —Ah… —she said, hesitantly—. Tom has a wife, in New York.

en: “Got some woman?” I repeated blankly.
vi: "Is there another woman?" I repeated in a daze
tr: “His mistress?” I repeated naively.
es: —A woman? —I repeated, not understanding.

en: Miss Baker nodded.
vi: Baker nodded
tr: Mr. Baker nodded.
es: Miss Baker nodded.

en: “She might have the decency not to telephone him at dinner time. Don’t you think?”
vi: "If she were a considerate person, she shouldn't call Tom right in the middle of dinner like that. Don't you think so?"
tr: “He should be polite enough not to call during mealtime, right?”
es: —You could have the decency not to call him at dinner time. Don't you think?

en: Almost before I had grasped her meaning there was the flutter of a dress and the crunch of leather boots, and Tom and Daisy were back at the table.
vi: Before I could grasp the meaning of Baker's words, I heard the rustling of a dress and the sound of shoes scraping; both Tom and Daisy had returned to the dining table.
tr: Before I had time to understand what they were saying, the rustle of fabric and the creaking of leather boots were heard, and Tom and Daisy returned to the table.
es: Almost before I grasped the meaning of his words, we heard the rustle of a dress and the creak of leather boots, and Tom and Daisy were back at the table.

en: “It couldn’t be helped!” cried Daisy with tense gaiety.
vi: "I can't resist!" Daisy said loudly with an unnaturally cheerful voice.
tr: Daisy was trying to appear cheerful, but her voice was tense. “Sorry” he said.
es: —It was inevitable! —exclaimed Daisy with forced cheerfulness.

en: She sat down, glanced searchingly at Miss Baker and then at me, and continued: “I looked outdoors for a minute, and it’s very romantic outdoors. There’s a bird on the lawn that I think must be a nightingale come over on the Cunard or White Star Line. He’s singing away—” Her voice sang: “It’s romantic, isn’t it, Tom?”
vi: Daisy sat down, after glancing at Baker and then at me, she continued speaking. "I just went outside for a minute, the scenery is truly poetic. There was a bird perched on the lawn that I guessed was a lark that had followed the Cunard or Starline ship here. The bird was flying and singing.." Daisy's voice was melodious. "Isn't it romantic, Tom?"
tr: He sat down, looking at first Mrs. Baker and then me with questioning eyes. “I just looked outside!” he said, then, “There really is a very romantic view. There was a bird on the grass. I think it’s a nightingale that came here on one of the ships belonging to the Cunard or White Star lines. How it sings,” he continued his speech. He himself was almost warbling, “How romantic, isn’t it Tom?”
es: He sat down, looked scrutinizingly at Miss Baker and then at me, and continued: —I peeked into the garden for a moment. How romantic! There is a bird on the lawn that must be a nightingale arrived on a transatlantic ship from the Cunard or White Star Line company. It is singing… —and her voice sang—. Don't you think it's romantic, Tom?

en: “Very romantic,” he said, and then miserably to me: “If it’s light enough after dinner, I want to take you down to the stables.”
vi: "It's so romantic." Tom replied, then turned to me miserably. "After dinner, if it's still light out, I want to take you down to the stables."
tr: "Yes, that's right," said Tom, turning to me with a weary attitude, "If it hasn't gotten dark by the time we finish eating, I'll take you to the barns."
es: —Very romantic —replied Tom before addressing me in a dejected tone—. If there's still light after dinner, I'd like to take you to the stables.

en: The telephone rang inside, startlingly, and as Daisy shook her head decisively at Tom the subject of the stables, in fact all subjects, vanished into air. Among the broken fragments of the last five minutes at table I remember the candles being lit again, pointlessly, and I was conscious of wanting to look squarely at everyone, and yet to avoid all eyes. I couldn’t guess what Daisy and Tom were thinking, but I doubt if even Miss Baker, who seemed to have mastered a certain hardy scepticism, was able utterly to put this fifth guest’s shrill metallic urgency out of mind. To a certain temperament the situation might have seemed intriguing—my own instinct was to telephone immediately for the police.
vi: The phone in the house rang again, startling everyone. While Daisy looked at Tom and shook her head resolutely, the topic of the stables, or rather all topics, vanished into thin air. In that five-minute interruption, I remembered that the candles on the table had been relit, lost and meaningless. I had the urge to look directly at each person's face but avoided looking into anyone's eyes. I couldn't guess what Daisy and Tom were thinking, but I believed that even Baker, who seemed very skilled at suspicion, could completely dismiss the shrill, urgent call of this fifth guest from his mind. Depending on one's temperament, this situation might amuse some people. But with my instincts, I would immediately call the police.
tr: When the phone rang once again, we all suddenly flinched. When Daisy looked at Tom and shook her head with a definite expression, all the conversation topics suddenly disappeared. From the fragments of the last five minutes at the table, what stuck in my mind was the unnecessary relighting of the candles, and although I wanted to look without hesitation, I was avoiding everyone's gaze. I couldn't know what Tom and Daisy were thinking, but despite their indifferent demeanor, it was impossible for even Mrs. Baker, who usually didn't care, to ignore the sharp ringing of the uninvited fifth person. While this situation might have aroused curiosity in people of different dispositions, I felt an immediate urge to call the police.
es: The phone rang inside the house like an alarm and, while Daisy shook her head emphatically looking at Tom, the idea of the stables, and all ideas, vanished into the air. Among the broken fragments of the last five minutes at the table, I remember that they had relit the candles, who knows why, and that I was aware of wanting to look deeply at everyone, and yet, I avoided looking at anyone. I was unable to guess what Daisy and Tom were thinking, but I wasn't sure that Miss Baker, who seemed to possess an unbreakable skepticism, could overlook the shrill and metallic urgency of the fifth diner. For certain temperaments, the situation might have been suggestive. My instinct urged me to call the police immediately.

en: The horses, needless to say, were not mentioned again. Tom and Miss Baker, with several feet of twilight between them, strolled back into the library, as if to a vigil beside a perfectly tangible body, while, trying to look pleasantly interested and a little deaf, I followed Daisy around a chain of connecting verandas to the porch in front. In its deep gloom we sat down side by side on a wicker settee.
vi: Needless to say, the horses were, of course, no longer mentioned. A few steps apart in the twilight, Tom and Baker leisurely walked into the library, as if to guard a flesh-and-blood corpse. As for me, I tried to appear interesting and slightly feigned deafness, following Daisy across the veranda that extended to the front porch. In the thick darkness, we sat down next to each other on the wicker chair.
tr: Needless to say, the subject of horses was never brought up again. Tom and Mrs. Baker, holding it by the head and feet as if carrying a corpse, walked slowly towards the library, leaving a couple of meters between them in the evening twilight. As for me, I tried to appear interested in the surroundings as if I hadn't heard anything, and followed Daisy onto the terrace along the chain of interconnected verandas. We sat side by side on a wicker sofa in the dim garden.
es: Nobody, it goes without saying, mentioned the horses again. Tom and Miss Baker, separated by a meter of twilight, headed to the library, as if to keep vigil over a perfectly tangible corpse, while I, trying to appear pleasantly interested and a bit deaf, followed Daisy through a series of galleries that branched off from the porch. We sat in the dim light, on a wicker sofa.

en: Daisy took her face in her hands as if feeling its lovely shape, and her eyes moved gradually out into the velvet dusk. I saw that turbulent emotions possessed her, so I asked what I thought would be some sedative questions about her little girl.
vi: Daisy placed her hands on her face as if to feel its graceful and beautiful contours. Her eyes slowly gazed into the velvety twilight. I saw that she was overwhelmed with emotions, so I asked a few questions about the girl to help her calm down.
tr: Daisy, as if feeling her beautiful features, took her face in her hands and turned her gaze to the velvet-colored twilight. I could see that storms were raging inside her. To calm her down, I started asking questions about her little girl.
es: Daisy put her face in her hands as if to feel her perfect features, and her gaze gradually lost itself in the velvet darkness. I realized that she was overwhelmed by the strength of her emotions and, thinking it would calm her, I asked about the child.

en: “We don’t know each other very well, Nick,” she said suddenly. “Even if we are cousins. You didn’t come to my wedding.”
vi: "Nick, although we are cousins, we actually don't understand each other very well." Daisy suddenly said. "You didn't attend my wedding."
tr: “Are you aware, Nick, we don't know each other very well,” she suddenly said, “you didn't even come to my wedding.”
es: —You and I don't know each other very well, Nick —he said suddenly—. Even though we are cousins. You didn't come to my wedding.

en: “I wasn’t back from the war.”
vi: "At that time, there was still war, and you hadn't returned from the battle."
tr: “I hadn't returned from the pole.”
es: —He had not returned from the war.

en: “That’s true.” She hesitated. “Well, I’ve had a very bad time, Nick, and I’m pretty cynical about everything.”
vi: "That's right." Daisy hesitated. "Actually, I went through a painful time. Now I'm bitter about everything."
tr: “I hadn't returned from the pole.” “Right,” he paused, “I went through very bad days, Nick. I started to look at everything with suspicion.”
es: —It's true —she hesitated—. Well, I've had a hard time, Nick, and I've become a cynic.

en: Evidently she had reason to be. I waited but she didn’t say any more, and after a moment I returned rather feebly to the subject of her daughter.
vi: Of course, Daisy had a reason to think that way. I waited for Daisy to continue, but she didn't say anything more. After a while, I timidly turned back to bring up the topic of the little girl.
tr: He was right to look. I waited, but he didn't say anything else. In a rather feeble voice, I started talking about his daughter again.
es: He evidently had reasons to be so. I waited, but he said nothing more, and after a moment I returned without much conviction to the subject of his daughter.

en: “I suppose she talks, and—eats, and everything.”
vi: "I guess your daughter can already talk, eat, and do many things."
tr: “She must be talking by now, eating her meals, doing everything.”
es: —I suppose it talks and… eats, and those things.

en: “Oh, yes.” She looked at me absently. “Listen, Nick; let me tell you what I said when she was born. Would you like to hear?”
vi: "Yes, that's right." Daisy looked dazed. "Listen, Nick. Let me tell you what I said when my daughter was just born. Do you want to hear it?"
tr: “Yes, indeed!” he looked at my face absentmindedly, “Listen Nick, do you want to know what I said when you were born?”
es: —Ah, yes —he looked at me, absent-mindedly—. Hey, Nick: let me tell you what I said when she was born. Do you want to know?

en: “Very much.”
vi: "I really want to listen."
tr: “A lot, indeed.”
es: —Of course.

en: “It’ll show you how I’ve gotten to feel about—things. Well, she was less than an hour old and Tom was God knows where. I woke up out of the ether with an utterly abandoned feeling, and asked the nurse right away if it was a boy or a girl. She told me it was a girl, and so I turned my head away and wept. ‘All right,’ I said, ‘I’m glad it’s a girl. And I hope she’ll be a fool—that’s the best thing a girl can be in this world, a beautiful little fool.’
vi: "After listening, you will know why I have the perspective on life that I do now. The story goes like this: the baby was born less than an hour when Tom disappeared to who knows where, only God knows where he was. After the anesthesia wore off, I woke up with the feeling of being abandoned. I immediately asked the nurse whether the newborn was a boy or a girl. The nurse replied that my child was a girl, and upon hearing that, I turned away, unable to hold back my tears. I said, "That's fine, I'm glad it's a girl. I hope she will become a foolish girl. In this world, the best thing for a girl is to become a beautiful fool."
tr: “Maybe this way you will understand how I view things. It hadn't even been an hour since I gave birth. God knows where Tom was. When I came out of anesthesia, a deep sense of abandonment filled me, and I asked the nurse whether it was a girl or a boy. When I learned it was a girl, I turned my back and cried, 'Alright,' I said to myself, 'I'm glad it's a girl.' I hope she will be a fool. Because in this world, the best thing for a girl is to be a fool and beautiful.”
es: —That will show you what I have come to feel about… everything. Well, the girl was less than an hour old and Tom was God knows where. I woke up from the anesthesia with a feeling of deep abandonment, and I asked the nurse if it was a boy or a girl. She told me it was a girl, and I turned my head and started to cry. “Great,” I said, “I’m glad it’s a girl. And I hope she’s a fool. That’s the best thing a girl can be in this world: a beautiful little fool.”

en: “You see I think everything’s terrible anyhow,” she went on in a convinced way. “Everybody thinks so—the most advanced people. And I know. I’ve been everywhere and seen everything and done everything.” Her eyes flashed around her in a defiant way, rather like Tom’s, and she laughed with thrilling scorn. “Sophisticated—God, I’m sophisticated!”
vi: "You see, I think everything in the world is terrible." Daisy continued with a determined voice. "Everyone thinks so, even the most progressive people. I really know it. I've been everywhere, seen everything, and done everything." Daisy's eyes flashed with a challenging look, glancing around like Tom's eyes, then Daisy burst into a mocking, emotional laugh. "Wise and sophisticated, oh my, I'm so wise and sophisticated."
tr: “You must have realized that I always see the bad side of everything,” he continued in a determined voice, “everyone thinks that way. Even the most educated ones. And I am sure of it. I have been everywhere, seen everything, done whatever I wanted.” His eyes challenged the world, looking just like Tom. He let out a laugh full of contempt, “I am a sophisticated person. God, how sophisticated I am.”
es: You see, I think life is terrible —she continued, very convinced—. Everyone thinks so, the people with the most advanced ideas. And I know it. I’ve been everywhere, I’ve seen everything and I’ve done everything —she cast a defiant look around, in Tom’s manner, and laughed with impressive disdain—. Sophisticated… My God, how sophisticated I am!

en: The instant her voice broke off, ceasing to compel my attention, my belief, I felt the basic insincerity of what she had said. It made me uneasy, as though the whole evening had been a trick of some sort to exact a contributory emotion from me. I waited, and sure enough, in a moment she looked at me with an absolute smirk on her lovely face, as if she had asserted her membership in a rather distinguished secret society to which she and Tom belonged.
vi: Right after Daisy's voice stopped compelling me to listen and believe, I began to realize the insincerity in what she had just said. It made me feel uncomfortable, as if the entire afternoon had been a joke aimed at exploiting my feelings to contribute to that game. I waited, and sure enough, in just a moment Daisy looked at me again with a smug smile on her beautiful face, as if she had confirmed her status in an exclusive elite society of which she and Tom were members.
tr: The moment the voice that had drawn my interest and belief fell silent, I realized how insincere its words actually were. This had disturbed me quite a bit. Everything that happened in the evening seemed to me like schemes designed to evoke sympathetic feelings towards him. I waited silently. A few minutes later, a mocking smile appeared on his charming face. He looked at me as if he and Tom were members of a very important secret organization that no one knew about.
es: As soon as the voice faded and stopped demanding my attention and trust, I became aware of the basic insincerity of everything that had been said. And I felt uncomfortable, as if the whole evening had been a trap to extract a sentimental contribution from me. I waited and, indeed, at that moment she looked at me with a splendid smile of satisfaction, as if she had confessed to me her membership in a distinguished secret society to which both she and Tom were affiliated.

en: Inside, the crimson room bloomed with light. Tom and Miss Baker sat at either end of the long couch and she read aloud to him from the Saturday Evening Post—the words, murmurous and uninflected, running together in a soothing tune. The lamplight, bright on his boots and dull on the autumn-leaf yellow of her hair, glinted along the paper as she turned a page with a flutter of slender muscles in her arms.
vi: Inside the house, the crimson room was illuminated under the light. Tom and Baker each sat at one end of the long bench, with Baker reading the news from the Saturday Evening Post to Tom in a monotonous murmur, the words blending together to form a sound like a caress to soothe. The light shone on Tom's boots, dulled on Bakey's pale yellow hair, and reflected a sparkle along the page as Baker turned it with slender, slightly trembling arms.
tr: Inside, the red room was filled with light. Tom and Mrs. Baker were sitting at the two ends of the long couch, the young woman was reading the Saturday Evening Post magazine aloud. Tom was listening to the words that joined together and turned into a soothing murmur. The lights on the ceiling were shining on his boots, dimming in the girl's autumn-leaf-colored hair, and moving over the pages she turned with her arm muscles.
es: Inside the house, the crimson living room bloomed with light. Tom and Miss Baker sat at the ends of the wide sofa, and Miss Baker read aloud an article from the Saturday Evening Post: the words, in a whisper, without inflections, blended into a melody of soothing effects. The lamp light gleamed on the riding boots, lost its shine in Miss Baker's autumn yellow hair, and flashed on the paper every time she turned the page and the delicate muscles of her arms pulsed.

en: When we came in she held us silent for a moment with a lifted hand.
vi: When the two of us walked in, Baker raised his hand to signal us to keep quiet.
tr: When we entered, he looked at our faces without speaking, his hand suspended in the air for a while.
es: When we entered, he made us, raising a hand, keep silent for a few seconds.

en: “To be continued,” she said, tossing the magazine on the table, “in our very next issue.”
vi: "To be continued, please read the next issue." Baker finally said, throwing the magazine onto the table
tr: "To be continued," he said as he tossed the magazine onto the table.
es: —To be continued —he said, and threw the magazine onto the table— in our next issue.

en: Her body asserted itself with a restless movement of her knee, and she stood up.
vi: Baker shook his knee to adjust his posture, then stood up straight.
tr: Then, hurriedly lowering his leg from over the other, he jumped to his feet.
es: The body asserted its power with an impatient movement of the knees, and Miss Baker stood up.

en: “Ten o’clock,” she remarked, apparently finding the time on the ceiling. “Time for this good girl to go to bed.”
vi: "It's ten o'clock already, a well-behaved girl should go to bed at this hour." Baker said, his demeanor resembling someone checking the time on the ceiling.
tr: “It is ten o'clock,” she said, as if looking at a clock on the ceiling, “It's time for good girls to go to bed.”
es: —Ten o'clock —he noted, as if checking the time on the ceiling—. It's time for this good girl to go to bed.

en: “Jordan’s going to play in the tournament tomorrow,” explained Daisy, “over at Westchester.”
vi: "Jordan will compete tomorrow in Westchester," Daisy explained.
tr: “Jordan will participate in the tournament in Westchester tomorrow,” said Daisy.
es: —Jordan is participating in the Westchester tournament tomorrow —explained Daisy.

en: “Oh—you’re Jordan Baker.”
vi: "Oh, so you are Jordan Baker."
tr: “So you are Jordan Baker.””
es: —Ah, you are Jordan Baker!

en: I knew now why her face was familiar—its pleasing contemptuous expression had looked out at me from many rotogravure pictures of the sporting life at Asheville and Hot Springs and Palm Beach. I had heard some story of her too, a critical, unpleasant story, but what it was I had forgotten long ago.
vi: Now I understand why her face looks so familiar. That adorable disdainful expression had once looked straight at me from photographs published in sports newspapers in cities like Asheville, Hot Springs, and Palm Beach. I had also heard rumors about her, all critical comments about something not very pleasant, but what it was, I had completely forgotten.
tr: Now I understood why his face looked familiar. I had often come across this beautiful face, which looked a bit arrogant, while reading sports news from places like Ashville, Hot Springs, and Palm Beach. Long ago, I had also heard a rather unpleasant story about him, but I didn't quite remember it at that moment.
es: Now I knew why her face seemed familiar to me: that pleasant and disdainful expression had looked at me from many photogravure pictures in the news pages about the sporting life in Asheville, Hot Springs, and Palm Beach. Gossip about her had also reached me, a negative and unpleasant story that I had long forgotten.

en: “Good night,” she said softly. “Wake me at eight, won’t you.”
vi: "Good night. Remember to wake me up at eight o'clock tomorrow morning."
tr: “Good night,” he said in a low voice, “will you wake me up at eight o'clock?””
es: —Good night —he said in a low voice—. Would you mind waking me up at eight?

en: “If you’ll get up.”
vi: Baker said softly.
tr: “If you are going to wake up, why not.”
es: —If you plan to get up.

en: “I will. Good night, Mr. Carraway. See you anon.”
vi: "If you can wake up, then I will do it too." "You can get up." "Good night, Mr. Carraway. Hope to see you again soon."
tr: “I will wake up. Good night Mr. Carraway, see you soon.”
es: —I plan to get up. Good night, Mister Carraway. We will see each other soon.

en: “Of course you will,” confirmed Daisy. “In fact I think I’ll arrange a marriage. Come over often, Nick, and I’ll sort of—oh—fling you together. You know—lock you up accidentally in linen closets and push you out to sea in a boat, and all that sort of thing—”
vi: "You will definitely have a chance to meet again." Daisy confirmed. "Actually, I will arrange a matchmaking for you two." "Nick, you should come here often and I will set you two up, like accidentally locking you both in a closet and then pushing it onto a ship heading out to sea, you know, tricks like that."
tr: “Of course you will meet,” said Daisy. “Maybe I'll get you two married. Visit us often, Nick. In the meantime, I’ll –you know– bring you two together. Maybe I'll lock you in the laundry closet or put you on a boat and set sail for distant seas. I'll do something.”
es: —Of course, you will see each other soon —confirmed Daisy—. And I even plan to organize a wedding. Come often, Nick, and I will see to it… oh, how to bring you together. You know… Accidentally lock you in a closet, or throw you into the sea in a boat, things like that…

en: “Good night,” called Miss Baker from the stairs. “I haven’t heard a word.”
vi: "Good night, you won't hear anything." Baker called down from the stairs.
tr: “Good night,” said Mrs. Baker as she walked up the stairs, “I will pretend I didn't hear this.”
es: —Good evening —said Miss Baker from the stairs—. I haven't heard a single word.

en: “She’s a nice girl,” said Tom after a moment. “They oughtn’t to let her run around the country this way.”
vi: "She is a cute girl. People shouldn't let her wander around like that," Tom said after a while.
tr: “Sweet girl,” said Tom after she left, “it would be better if they didn't let her wander around like that.”
es: —She is a wonderful girl —said Tom after a while—. They shouldn't let her travel around the country like that.

en: “Who oughtn’t to?” inquired Daisy coldly.
vi: "Who shouldn't do that?" Daisy asked coldly.
tr: “Who?” Daisy asked in a cold voice.
es: —Who shouldn't? —asked Daisy, coldly.

en: “Her family.”
vi: "It's her family."
tr: “His family.”
es: —His family.

en: “Her family is one aunt about a thousand years old. Besides, Nick’s going to look after her, aren’t you, Nick? She’s going to spend lots of weekends out here this summer. I think the home influence will be very good for her.”
vi: "Baker only has one aunt who is about a thousand years old as a relative. But Nick will take care of her, won't you Nick? This summer Baker will be here many weekends with us. I think the family atmosphere will have a good influence on Baker."
tr: “The family you mentioned is his hundred-year-old aunt. Besides, Nick will take care of her now, right Nick? Jordan will be here many weekends this summer. The atmosphere of this home will do her a lot of good.”
es: —His family is an aunt who must be a thousand years old. Besides, Nick is going to take care of her, right, Nick? Jordan is going to spend quite a few weekends with us this summer. I think having a home will do him a lot of good.

en: Daisy and Tom looked at each other for a moment in silence.
vi: Daisy and Tom looked at each other for a moment in silence.
tr: They both fell silent and looked at each other.
es: Daisy and Tom looked at each other in silence for a moment.

en: “Is she from New York?” I asked quickly.
vi: "Does she live in New York?" I asked quickly.
tr: "Are you from New York?" I asked.
es: —Are you from New York? —I asked immediately.

en: “From Louisville. Our white girlhood was passed together there. Our beautiful white—”
vi: "From Louisville. In our innocent and pure youth, we grew up there. The time of fresh purity..."
tr: "From Louisville." "We spent the innocent years of our youth there." "That innocence...""
es: —From Louisville. There we spent our immaculate adolescence together. The immaculate and wonderful adolescence…

en: “Did you give Nick a little heart to heart talk on the veranda?” demanded Tom suddenly.
vi: "You've been confiding a lot with Nick on the porch, haven't you?" Tom suddenly interrogated.
tr: “Did you complain to Nick while sitting on the terrace?” Tom suddenly asked.
es: —Have you been telling secrets to Nick on the terrace? —asked Tom suddenly.

en: “Did I?” She looked at me. “I can’t seem to remember, but I think we talked about the Nordic race. Yes, I’m sure we did. It sort of crept up on us and first thing you know—”
vi: "Is that so?" Daisy looked at me. "I don't remember clearly, but I think we talked about the Nordic people. Yes, I definitely remember we talked about that. It was just the way the conversation flowed, and then we realized..."
tr: "Did I do that?" he looked at my face. “Although I don't quite remember, I think we talked about the Normans. Yes, I'm sure it was like that. It suddenly came to our minds, and then we looked and saw that...”
es: —Have I told you secrets? —Daisy looked at me—. I don't remember, but I think we have talked about the Nordic race. Yes, I am sure. Almost without realizing it, you know, the first thing that…

en: “Don’t believe everything you hear, Nick,” he advised me.
vi: "Don't believe everything you hear, Nick." Tom advised me.
tr: "Don't believe everything you hear, Nick," Tom advised.
es: —Don't believe everything they tell you, Nick —Tom advised me.

en: I said lightly that I had heard nothing at all, and a few minutes later I got up to go home. They came to the door with me and stood side by side in a cheerful square of light. As I started my motor Daisy peremptorily called: “Wait!
vi: I gently replied that I hadn't heard anything at all. A few minutes later, I stood up to take my leave. The couple saw me off to the door, standing next to each other in the cheerful light. Just as I started the car, Daisy called me back. "Wait a moment."
tr: I said quietly that I didn't hear anything. A few minutes later, I got up to leave. They stood side by side in the light that rained down on them as they came to the door to see me off. When I got into my car and started the engine, a commanding "Wait!" came from Daisy.
es: I said nonchalantly that they hadn't told me anything, and a few minutes later I got up to go home. They accompanied me to the door and stopped, together, in a radiant square of light. As I started the car, Daisy shouted peremptorily: "Wait!"

en: “I forgot to ask you something, and it’s important. We heard you were engaged to a girl out West.”
vi: "Wait a minute, I forgot to ask you something important. We heard that you got engaged to a young woman in the West."
tr: “I was going to ask you something important, but I forgot. We heard that you got engaged to a girl from the West.
es: —I forgot to ask you something important. We have received news that you got engaged to a girl from the West.

en: “That’s right,” corroborated Tom kindly. “We heard that you were engaged.”
vi: "That's right." Tom chimed in with a friendly tone. "We heard that you got engaged."
tr: “Right,” said Tom in agreement, “we heard you got engaged.””
es: —It's true —Tom corroborated warmly—. They told us that you had gotten engaged.

en: “It’s a libel. I’m too poor.”
vi: "That's just slander. I'm too poor."
tr: “They have slandered me. I don't have enough money to get married.”
es: —It's a lie. I am too poor.

en: “But we heard it,” insisted Daisy, surprising me by opening up again in a flower-like way. “We heard it from three people, so it must be true.”
vi: "But we really did hear it that way." Daisy insisted. I was surprised to see Daisy talking and laughing again like a flower. "We heard it from three people, so it must be true."
tr: “But that's what we heard,” insisted Daisy. I was surprised by her sudden blossoming from her previously calm state. “We heard it from three different people, it must be true.”
es: —Well, they told us —insisted Daisy and, to my surprise, she was opening up again like a flower—. Three people told us, so it must be true.

en: Of course I knew what they were referring to, but I wasn’t even vaguely engaged. The fact that gossip had published the banns was one of the reasons I had come East. You can’t stop going with an old friend on account of rumours, and on the other hand I had no intention of being rumoured into marriage.
vi: Of course, I understand what they are implying, but I have never been engaged, even ambiguously. In fact, those rumors had spread to the church announcements and were one of the reasons I moved to the East. One cannot avoid interacting with a long-time friend just because of rumors. On the other hand, I have no intention of marrying that person just to make the rumors come true.
tr: Of course, I understood what they were talking about, but I hadn't even come close to getting engaged. The rumors circulating about me starting the marriage procedures were one of the reasons I came to the East anyway. You can't stop seeing an old friend because of rumors, but I wasn't going to get married just because there were rumors.
es: Of course, I knew what they were referring to, but I was not even vaguely engaged. The fact that the gossip had announced the banns was one of the reasons I went East. You can't stop seeing an old friend because of rumors, and, on the other hand, I had no intention of getting married just because of what people said.

en: Their interest rather touched me and made them less remotely rich—nevertheless, I was confused and a little disgusted as I drove away. It seemed to me that the thing for Daisy to do was to rush out of the house, child in arms—but apparently there were no such intentions in her head. As for Tom, the fact that he “had some woman in New York” was really less surprising than that he had been depressed by a book. Something was making him nibble at the edge of stale ideas as if his sturdy physical egotism no longer nourished his peremptory heart.
vi: The concern of Tom and his wife moved me and shortened the distance of their wealth from me. Anyway, when they left, I still felt confused, mixed, with a bit of indignation. To me, it seemed like what Daisy should do now was to quickly run out of the house with her child in her arms. But in Daisy's mind, that idea didn't seem to exist. As for Tom, the fact that he truly "had another woman in New York" was perhaps less surprising than him being bored after reading a book. Something had caused Tom to chew on old, boring ideas, as if his pride in his strong physique was no longer enough to sustain his decisive heart.
tr: Tom and Daisy's interest in me had greatly affected me and had somewhat reduced the distance between us, born of their wealth. On the way back home, my mind was a bit confused and I was angry. All Daisy had to do was leave the house as she embraced her daughter. But it was clear that she had no such intention. For Tom, having a mistress in New York was less surprising than getting depressed over a book he read. His ostentatious physical strength was no longer sufficient to nourish that domineering spirit of his, so he was busy gnawing at some stale ideas.
es: The interest of Tom and Daisy moved me quite a bit: they seemed closer, less remotely rich. However, already in the car, I felt confused and a little disgusted. I thought that Daisy's duty was to run out of the house with the child in her arms, although, apparently, she had no intention of doing such a thing. As for Tom, that he had "a woman in New York" was less surprising than the fact that a book had depressed him so much. Something drove him to gnaw at the most superficial aspects of a few stale ideas as if his physical, resounding selfishness was no longer enough to feed his pressing heart.

en: Already it was deep summer on roadhouse roofs and in front of wayside garages, where new red petrol-pumps sat out in pools of light, and when I reached my estate at West Egg I ran the car under its shed and sat for a while on an abandoned grass roller in the yard. The wind had blown off, leaving a loud, bright night, with wings beating in the trees and a persistent organ sound as the full bellows of the earth blew the frogs full of life. The silhouette of a moving cat wavered across the moonlight, and, turning my head to watch it, I saw that I was not alone—fifty feet away a figure had emerged from the shadow of my neighbour’s mansion and was standing with his hands in his pockets regarding the silver pepper of the stars. Something in his leisurely movements and the secure position of his feet upon the lawn suggested that it was Mr. Gatsby himself, come out to determine what share was his of our local heavens.
vi: Summer had long arrived on the roofs of eateries and in front of roadside repair shops, where brand-new red gas pumps stood tall in pools of bright, all-encompassing light. When I got home to West Egg, I parked the car and sat for a moment on the abandoned lawn mower in the yard. The wind had stopped blowing, leaving a bright moonlit night with the sound of birds' wings flapping against the tree leaves and the incessant croaking of frogs, whose life force was being inflated by the earth's breath. There was the shimmering shadow of a cat slinking across the moonlight, and as I turned my head to follow the cat, I realized I was not alone. About fifty yards away from me, a figure had just emerged from the dark shadow of the neighboring mansion. He was standing with his hands in his pockets, gazing at the stars scattered like silver dust across the sky. There was something leisurely and relaxed in his demeanor and the way he firmly planted his feet on the lawn that made me realize he was Gatsby. He was coming out to affirm which of the properties between our residences belonged to him.
tr: The summer atmosphere was strongly felt in the roadside restaurants and repair shops with brightly lit red gasoline pumps in front of them. When I reached my mansion in West Egg, I parked the car in the garage and sat down by the abandoned lawn mower in the garden. A noisy, bright night remained, filled with the sound of wings flapping in the trees, the relentless organ sounds produced by tireless frogs, and the bellows blowing with all their might from the ground. A cat suddenly stumbled under the moonlight. When I turned my head to look at it, I realized I was not alone. Fifteen meters ahead, a figure distinguished from the shadow of the neighboring mansion, with hands in pockets, was watching the silver sprinkling of stars. His relaxed demeanor and confident strides on the grass made me think it was Mr. Gatsby, out for a walk to calculate how much of the paradise around us he owned.
es: You could feel the summer on the rooftops of the roadside hotels and at the service stations, where the new, red pumps stood over pools of light, and when I arrived at my house in West Egg, I parked the car in the shed and sat for a while in the garden, on an abandoned lawnmower. The wind no longer blew, leaving a clear and noisy night, with wings flapping in the trees and the persistent sound of an organ, as if the powerful bellows of the earth were breathing life into the frogs. The silhouette of a cat moved hesitantly in the moonlight and, turning my head to look at it, I saw that I was not alone: about fifteen meters away a figure had emerged from the shadow of my neighbor's mansion and stood, hands in pockets, contemplating the silvery pepper of the stars. Something in the slowness of his movements and the confidence with which he placed his feet on the grass suggested to me that it was the mysterious Gatsby, who had come out to calculate what part of the local firmament belonged to him.

en: I decided to call to him. Miss Baker had mentioned him at dinner, and that would do for an introduction. But I didn’t call to him, for he gave a sudden intimation that he was content to be alone—he stretched out his arms toward the dark water in a curious way, and, far as I was from him, I could have sworn he was trembling. Involuntarily I glanced seaward—and distinguished nothing except a single green light, minute and far away, that might have been the end of a dock. When I looked once more for Gatsby he had vanished, and I was alone again in the unquiet darkness.
vi: I intended to call Gatsby. Baker had mentioned him during the afternoon, so that was enough of an introduction. However, I did not call, because I saw Gatsby suddenly appear as if he wanted to be alone. Gatsby stretched his arms out towards the dark water in front of him, looking curious. From my distance, I could swear I saw him trembling. Unconsciously, I also looked towards the sea, but I saw nothing more than a small, distant green light, perhaps from the end of a dock. When I looked back again, Gatsby had disappeared, and I remained alone in the restless darkness.
tr: I decided to call out. Ms. Baker mentioning him at dinner would also be an excuse for us to meet. But I changed my mind. Because he made a sudden gesture implying he was happy in his solitude. He stretched his arms towards the dark waters, and even though I was quite far, I could have sworn he was trembling. Involuntarily, I turned my gaze towards the sea. All I could see was a small, green light shining alone in the distance. It must have been the far end of a dock or something. I turned back towards where Gatsby had been. He was gone. And I was once again alone in that noisy darkness.
es: I decided to call him. Miss Baker had mentioned his name during dinner, and that would serve as an introduction. But I didn't call him, because suddenly he seemed to feel comfortable alone: he extended his arms in a strange way towards the dark water and, although I was far away, I would have sworn he was trembling. I looked at the sea in an automatic gesture... and saw nothing, except for a green light, distant and tiny, which might have been the end of a dock. When I went to look at Gatsby again, he had disappeared, and I was alone once more in the restless darkness.

en: II
vi: Maecenas: a wealthy patron of artists in ancient Rome.
tr: CHAPTER 2

en: About halfway between West Egg and New York the motor road hastily joins the railroad and runs beside it for a quarter of a mile, so as to shrink away from a certain desolate area of land. This is a valley of ashes—a fantastic farm where ashes grow like wheat into ridges and hills and grotesque gardens; where ashes take the forms of houses and chimneys and rising smoke and, finally, with a transcendent effort, of ash-grey men, who move dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air. Occasionally a line of grey cars crawls along an invisible track, gives out a ghastly creak, and comes to rest, and immediately the ash-grey men swarm up with leaden spades and stir up an impenetrable cloud, which screens their obscure operations from your sight.
vi: Midas: The Greek king with the magical touch that turns anything he touches into gold Morgan: One of the most successful financiers of the United States in the 19th century. According to legend, after discovering America and returning home, at a party, a person jealous of Columbus remarked that the achievement he had accomplished was not admirable at all, anyone could do it. Columbus calmly brought out an egg and challenged that person to make the egg stand upright on its pointed end. No one could do it. Columbus took the egg, cracked one end, and thus the egg could stand balanced on its pointed end. Download eBook at: www. dtv-ebook. com Chapter 2 About halfway from West Egg to New York, the highway joins the railroad track and runs alongside it for a quarter of a mile to avoid passing through a desolate wasteland. This valley is filled with ashes, a vast and unimaginable valley of ashes, where ashes spread out like wheat fields, piled into mounds, heaps, hills, and gardens of strange shapes. The ashes here are piled high like houses with chimneys releasing smoke. In the distance, the faint figures of men can be seen struggling to move in the dusty air. Occasionally, a dismal gray train crawls slowly along the indistinct tracks, emitting eerie squealing sounds, and then comes to a complete stop. Immediately, the dusty gray men swarm in with heavy shovels to dig, creating an impenetrable cloud of dust that obscures their work.
tr: Almost halfway between West Egg and New York, the highway meets the railroad to avoid passing through that desolate area, and for about four hundred meters, the two run side by side. This is the valley of ashes. It is almost like a strange farm where ashes grow like wheat on mountain ridges, hills, and peculiar gardens. So much so that these ashes take the form of houses, chimneys, and the smoke rising from the chimneys; and ultimately, with an incredible effort, they take the shape of people who are already crumbling and disintegrating in the dusty air, wandering vaguely. From time to time, a series of gray trucks slowly move along an invisible road and stop with a terrible screech of brakes, then ash-colored people with leaden shovels in their hands suddenly appear and raise a dense cloud of dust that obscures what they are doing there.
es: Halfway between West Egg and New York, the road suddenly converges with the railroad line and runs alongside it for about four hundred meters, as if trying to avoid a certain stretch of desolate land. It is a valley of ashes: a fantastic farm where ashes grow like wheat until they become ridges, hills, and grotesque gardens; where the ashes take the form of houses and chimneys and smoke and, finally, in a transcendental effort, of ash men who stir like shadows and dissolve into the dusty air. From time to time, a line of gray wagons crawls along an invisible track, shudders with a spectral creak, and stops, and immediately the ash men emerge like a swarm with shovels that seem made of lead and raise an impenetrable cloud that hides their mysterious operations from us.

en: But above the grey land and the spasms of bleak dust which drift endlessly over it, you perceive, after a moment, the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg are blue and gigantic—their retinas are one yard high. They look out of no face, but, instead, from a pair of enormous yellow spectacles which pass over a nonexistent nose. Evidently some wild wag of an oculist set them there to fatten his practice in the borough of Queens, and then sank down himself into eternal blindness, or forgot them and moved away. But his eyes, dimmed a little by many paintless days, under sun and rain, brood on over the solemn dumping ground.
vi: However, above the gray land and the ever-moving dust, if you look closely for a moment, you will see the eyes of Dr. T. J.Eckleburg on a high billboard. The eyes are enormous and blue, with pupils about a foot high. The eyes do not look out from a face but from a pair of gigantic yellow spectacles resting on an indistinct nose. Evidently, some mischievous oculist set up this billboard to attract clients to his practice in Queens, but then either went blind or moved away, leaving the eyes behind. Yet, even though the eyes have faded due to the passage of time and weather without repainting, they still stand there, contemplating the wasteland where ashes from burnt refuse are stored.
tr: Nevertheless, before long, you notice the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg above the gray land and the spasms of bleak dust which drift endlessly over it. These blue eyes are enormous, their irises are over a yard high. They look out of no face, but, instead, from a pair of enormous yellow spectacles which pass over a nonexistent nose. Evidently some wild wag of an oculist set them there to fatten his practice in the borough of Queens, and then sank down himself into eternal blindness, or forgot them and moved away. After a long time under the sun and rain, they had become dimmed and now stared down at the gloomy landscape with a sort of persistent stare.
es: But above the gray earth and the inhospitable gusts of dust that blow incessantly over it, the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg can be distinguished after a moment. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg are blue and gigantic: their pupils almost reach a meter in height. They do not look out from a face, but from enormous yellow glasses that rest on a nonexistent nose. Some foolish and joking oculist must have put them there to increase his clientele in the Queens area, and then sank into eternal blindness, or forgot them and went elsewhere. But his eyes, somewhat faded by the many days exposed to rain and sun without ever receiving a coat of paint, continue to meditate sadly over the solemn dump.

en: The valley of ashes is bounded on one side by a small foul river, and, when the drawbridge is up to let barges through, the passengers on waiting trains can stare at the dismal scene for as long as half an hour. There is always a halt there of at least a minute, and it was because of this that I first met Tom Buchanan’s mistress.
vi: Wrapping around the side of the ash valley is a river with murky, dirty water. When the iron bridge over the river is raised to let the barges pass, the passengers waiting on the train cars can witness the bleak scenery here for about half an hour. No matter what, vehicles are at least delayed there for a minute, so I had the chance to meet Tom Buchanan's mistress for the first time.
tr: On one side of the Valley of Ashes, a small and dirty river stretches out. When the drawbridge over it is raised to allow barges to pass, the passengers inside the waiting train are sometimes forced to look at this depressing view for half an hour. Every train inevitably stops here for at least a minute; it was during such a moment that I had the chance to meet Tom Buchanan's mistress.
es: A dirty stream borders the valley of ashes on one of its flanks, and when the drawbridge rises to let the barges pass, the train passengers can spend half an hour contemplating the gloomy place while they wait. It is inevitable to stop there, even if only for a moment, and precisely for that reason, I met Tom Buchanan's mistress.

en: The fact that he had one was insisted upon wherever he was known. His acquaintances resented the fact that he turned up in popular cafés with her and, leaving her at a table, sauntered about, chatting with whomsoever he knew. Though I was curious to see her, I had no desire to meet her—but I did. I went up to New York with Tom on the train one afternoon, and when we stopped by the ash-heaps he jumped to his feet and, taking hold of my elbow, literally forced me from the car.
vi: Everyone who knows Tom is aware of his affair. These people are very annoyed by the fact that he often takes his mistress to crowded, famous restaurants, then leaves her sitting alone at the table while he leisurely chats with acquaintances around. Although I was curious to see what this woman looked like, I wasn't particularly eager to meet her - but eventually, I did. One afternoon, I went to New York with Tom by train, and when the train stopped beside some ash heaps, Tom stood up, grabbed my elbow, and pulled me off the train.
tr: The news that he had a mistress was already on everyone's lips. Tom's friends were secretly annoyed by him showing up at trendy restaurants with the woman, and even leaving her at the table to wander around chatting here and there. Even though I was curious about this woman, I had no desire to meet her; yet it happened anyway. One afternoon, while I was heading to New York with Tom, we stopped near the ash heaps, and suddenly he jumped up, grabbed my arm, and practically forced me off the train.
es: The fact that he had a lover was much talked about in the circles that Tom frequented. His friends considered it an offense that he would show up with her in trendy bars and, leaving her at a table, would walk around the place, chatting with one person and another. I was curious to see her, but I didn't want to be introduced to her, as eventually happened. One afternoon I went with Tom to New York by train, and when we stopped next to the heaps of ash, he jumped up and, grabbing me by the elbow, literally forced me to get off the carriage.

en: “We’re getting off,” he insisted. “I want you to meet my girl.”
vi: "I'll get off here. I want you to meet my lover," Tom insisted.
tr: “Let's get off,” he insisted, “I will introduce you to my daughter.”
es: —We get off —he emphasized the obvious—. I want to introduce you to my girl.

en: I think he’d tanked up a good deal at luncheon, and his determination to have my company bordered on violence. The supercilious assumption was that on Sunday afternoon I had nothing better to do.
vi: I think Tom drank too much at the dinner preferred because the way he was determined to make me follow was almost too aggressive. Tom arrogantly assumed that I had nothing worthwhile to do on a Sunday afternoon.
tr: Probably because he had too much to drink at dinner, his insistence on me accompanying him had almost turned into bullying. He also had a rather arrogant reason for this; could I have anything better to do on a Sunday afternoon?
es: I think I had drunk too much at lunch, and the determination with which he forced me to accompany him bordered on violence. His arrogance assumed that on a Sunday afternoon I had nothing better to do.

en: I followed him over a low whitewashed railroad fence, and we walked back a hundred yards along the road under Doctor Eckleburg’s persistent stare. The only building in sight was a small block of yellow brick sitting on the edge of the waste land, a sort of compact Main Street ministering to it, and contiguous to absolutely nothing. One of the three shops it contained was for rent and another was an all-night restaurant, approached by a trail of ashes; the third was a garage—Repairs. George B. Wilson. Cars bought and sold.—and I followed Tom inside.
vi: I followed Tom past a low whitewashed fence lying beside the railroad tracks. We walked back along the road about a hundred yards under the watchful gaze of Dr. Eckleburg. Looking around, we only saw a small yellow brick building on the edge of the wasteland. It looked like a miniature main street of a county town, with nothing else around it. One of the three shops in the row had a "For Rent" sign, the second was an all-night diner, accessible by a path covered in ashes. The remaining third shop was a garage, with a sign that read "Repair Shop - GEORGE B. WILSON. Cars Bought and Sold." I followed Tom into the shop.
tr: I climbed over the low whitewashed fence of the railway, and under Doctor Eckleburg's fixed gaze, we walked back about a hundred meters along the road. The only visible structure was a yellow brick block, which, though it consisted of several adjoining buildings as if on a main street, had nothing beyond it. Of the three shops in this building, the first was for rent, the second was a morning diner accessible only by an ashy road, and the last was an automobile garage: Repairs, GEORGE B. WILSON, Cars bought and sold. I followed Tom inside.
es: I followed him when he jumped over the train barrier, painted white, and we retreated about a hundred meters down the road under the persistent gaze of Doctor Eckleburg. The only building in sight was a yellow brick house that stood at the edge of the wasteland, on a sort of minimal main street that was enough to meet its needs and led to absolute nothingness. There were three businesses: one was for rent and another was a restaurant that stayed open all night and was reached by an ash path. The third was a garage —Repairs. GEORGE B. WILSON. Car dealership—, into which I followed Tom.

en: The interior was unprosperous and bare; the only car visible was the dust-covered wreck of a Ford which crouched in a dim corner. It had occurred to me that this shadow of a garage must be a blind, and that sumptuous and romantic apartments were concealed overhead, when the proprietor himself appeared in the door of an office, wiping his hands on a piece of waste. He was a blond, spiritless man, anaemic, and faintly handsome. When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes.
vi: Inside, the shop looked poor and barren. The entire shop only had a dilapidated Ford car covered in dust, hidden dimly in the corner. I thought to myself that this shabby repair shop must be a front, and there would be luxurious, romantic rooms hidden upstairs. Just then, the shop owner appeared at the office door, wiping his hands on a rag. He was a blonde man, weak-looking, with pale skin, somewhat handsome. When he saw us, a flicker of damp hope appeared in his blue eyes.
tr: The interior was unpretentious, almost bare. The only visible car was a wrecked, dust-covered Ford, hidden away in a dark corner. Just as I started to think that this dingy garage might be hiding a well-furnished, romantic love nest somewhere in the back, the garage owner appeared at the office door, cleaning his hands with a rag. The blond man was pale but could be considered handsome. When he saw us, his light blue eyes lit up with hope.
es: The interior, empty, was miserable: the only visible car was the dusty remains of a Ford, huddled in a dark corner. I was thinking that this ghostly garage could only be a smokescreen hiding luxurious and romantic apartments upstairs, when the owner appeared at the office door, wiping his hands with a rag. He was a blond man, timid, anemic, and of a certain faded beauty. He saw us, and his eyes, blue, moist, and very clear, lit up with hope.

en: “Hello, Wilson, old man,” said Tom, slapping him jovially on the shoulder. “How’s business?”
vi: "Hello, my friend Wilson, how's business these days?" Tom said, cheerfully patting the shop owner on the shoulder. "There's nothing to complain about."
tr: “Hello Wilson, you old man,” said Tom, cheerfully patting the man on the shoulder, “How are things going?”
es: —Hello, old Wilson —said Tom jovially, giving him a pat on the shoulder—. How's it going?

en: “I can’t complain,” answered Wilson unconvincingly. “When are you going to sell me that car?”
vi: Wilson replied with a somewhat unconvincing tone. "When will you sell me that car?"
tr: "There's nothing wrong," said Wilson in a not very convincing manner. "When are you going to sell me that car?"
es: —I can't complain —replied Wilson, convincing no one—. When are you going to sell me the car?

en: “Next week; I’ve got my man working on it now.”
vi: "Next week, I am having someone repair it."
tr: “Next week. My man is dealing with that stuff these days.”
es: —Next week: I have the driver fixing it.

en: “Works pretty slow, don’t he?”
vi: "Taking so long to fix, isn't it?"
tr: “Is he perhaps taking it a bit slow?”
es: —He doesn't hurry, does he?

en: “No, he doesn’t,” said Tom coldly. “And if you feel that way about it, maybe I’d better sell it somewhere else after all.”
vi: "It's not like that." "If you feel that way, I can sell it to someone else."
tr: “Absolutely not!” said Tom coldly, “if that's what you think, maybe I should sell the car to someone else.”
es: —You are mistaken —said Tom coldly—. But, if you believe so, perhaps it would be best to sell the car to someone else.

en: “I don’t mean that,” explained Wilson quickly. “I just meant—”
vi: "I didn't mean that at all." Wilson quickly explained. "What I meant was..."
tr: “No, what I meant,” said Wilson hastily, “is just - ”
es: —That's not what I'm saying —Wilson hastened to explain—. What I'm saying is that…

en: His voice faded off and Tom glanced impatiently around the garage. Then I heard footsteps on a stairs, and in a moment the thickish figure of a woman blocked out the light from the office door. She was in the middle thirties, and faintly stout, but she carried her flesh sensuously as some women can. Her face, above a spotted dress of dark blue crêpe-de-chine, contained no facet or gleam of beauty, but there was an immediately perceptible vitality about her as if the nerves of her body were continually smouldering. She smiled slowly and, walking through her husband as if he were a ghost, shook hands with Tom, looking him flush in the eye. Then she wet her lips, and without turning around spoke to her husband in a soft, coarse voice:
vi: Wilson's voice gradually faded as Tom anxiously glanced around the shop.
