I heard footsteps coming down the stairs, and after a moment, I saw the figure of a full-figured woman blocking all the light from the office door. She was around thirty-five years old, full-figured, with round, alluring flesh. In a dark blue polka-dot crepe dress, her face had no features that could be called beautiful. However, one could immediately sense from this woman's body a vibrant energy radiating and a force continuously simmering. She smiled slowly, walked past her husband as if he wasn't there, shook hands with Tom, and looked directly into Tom's eyes in a flirtatious manner. Then she licked her lips, spoke to her husband in a soft but rude voice, without bothering to turn her head to look at him.
tr: He couldn't continue, looked around impatiently. At that moment, I heard footsteps coming from the stairs, then I noticed that a woman standing at the office door, with her somewhat large body, was blocking the light. She was in her mid-thirties, although quite full-figured, she carried her extra weight in an extraordinarily beautiful way that very few women could manage. There was no unusual beauty in her face above her navy blue polka-dotted crepe de chine dress, yet from her body emanated a tremendous vitality that was noticeable at first glance, as if every nerve in her body was burning inside. She smiled, walked past the man as if her husband was invisible, and approached, looking into Tom's eyes for a long time while shaking his hand. She licked her lips and, without turning around, called out to her husband in a low but coarse voice: "Why don't you bring a few chairs?
es: Her voice faded away, and Tom looked around impatiently. Then I heard footsteps on the stairs and, in a moment, the heavy silhouette of a woman blocked the light from the office door. She must have been about thirty-five years old, and she was a bit overweight, but she carried her flesh with that sensuality that some women are capable of. There were no features or hints of beauty in her face, which emerged from a dark blue polka-dotted silk dress, but that woman possessed an immediately perceptible vitality, as if the nerves in her body were always on edge. She smiled calmly, and passing through her husband as if he were a ghost, she shook Tom's hand, looking him intensely in the eyes. She licked her lips and, without turning, said to her husband in a soft and ordinary voice:

en: “Get some chairs, why don’t you, so somebody can sit down.”
vi: "Can you go get a few chairs so the guests can sit?"
tr: Look, people are standing!"
es: —Bring chairs, so people can sit down.

en: “Oh, sure,” agreed Wilson hurriedly, and went toward the little office, mingling immediately with the cement colour of the walls. A white ashen dust veiled his dark suit and his pale hair as it veiled everything in the vicinity—except his wife, who moved close to Tom.
vi: "Sure." Wilson hurriedly obeyed, heading towards the small paper room, immediately blending into the cement color of the brick walls. A layer of white ash clung to the dark clothes he was wearing, and on his pale-colored hair, just like everything else in the shop that the ash was covering, except for his wife.
tr: “Oh sure, right away,” said Wilson, who hurriedly entered the small office and then disappeared into the concrete-colored walls. Apart from the woman approaching Tom, the cloud of ash and dust that covered everything in the surroundings also obscured the man's dark suit and pale hair from view.
es: —Ah, yes —Wilson immediately agreed, and went to the office, blending in at once with the cement color of the walls. White and ashen dust covered his dark suit and pale hair as it covered everything around him, except for his wife, who had approached Tom.

en: “I want to see you,” said Tom intently. “Get on the next train.”
vi: She moved closer to Tom. "I want to meet you, take the next train."
tr: “I must see you!” said Tom insistently. “Catch the next train.”
es: —I want to see you —said Tom decisively—. Take the next train.

en: “All right.”
vi: Tom said firmly. "Sure."
tr: “Okay.”
es: —Very well.

en: “I’ll meet you by the newsstand on the lower level.”
vi: "I will meet you next to the newspaper stand on the lower floor of the station."
tr: “Let's meet in front of the newspaper kiosk below.”
es: —Wait for me at the newspaper stand on the lower platform.

en: She nodded and moved away from him just as George Wilson emerged with two chairs from his office door.
vi: The woman nodded and moved away from Tom as her husband George Wilson came out with two chairs from his office.
tr: The woman nodded her head and moved away from Tom as George Wilson appeared at the office door with two chairs.
es: The woman nodded and moved away from Tom at the precise moment when George Wilson was coming out of the office with two chairs.

en: We waited for her down the road and out of sight. It was a few days before the Fourth of July, and a grey, scrawny Italian child was setting torpedoes in a row along the railroad track.
vi: We waited for her at the end of the road, in a hidden spot where no one could see. Only a few days left until the Independence Day on the Fourth of July, a pale and skinny Italian child is lining up fireworks along the railroad tracks.
tr: We waited down the road, in a secluded corner out of sight. It was a few days before the 4th of July; a scrawny, skinny Italian boy was lining up firecrackers on the tracks at that moment.
es: We waited for her on the road, where they couldn't see us. There were only a few days left until the Fourth of July, and an Italian boy, gray and scrawny, was placing a row of firecrackers on the train tracks.

en: “Terrible place, isn’t it,” said Tom, exchanging a frown with Doctor Eckleburg.
vi: "It really is a dreadful place, isn't it?" Tom said as he exchanged a grimace with Dr. Eckleburg.
tr: “What a terrible place, isn't it?” said Tom, as he exchanged glances with Doctor Eckleburg.
es: —Terrible place, isn't it? —said Tom, exchanging a look of disgust with Doctor Eckleburg.

en: “Awful.”
vi: "Terrible."
tr: "Terrible!"
es: —Horrible.

en: “It does her good to get away.”
vi: "Get her out of here for a while for the better."
tr: “Getting out will do him good too.”
es: —It suits her to go out.

en: “Doesn’t her husband object?”
vi: "Her husband doesn't object?"
tr: “Wouldn't her husband object?”
es: —Doesn't the husband mind?

en: “Wilson? He thinks she goes to see her sister in New York. He’s so dumb he doesn’t know he’s alive.”
vi: "Wilson, huh? He thinks his wife is visiting her sister in New York. He's so stupid, he doesn't even know if he's alive or not."
tr: “Wilson, huh? He thinks she went to see her sister in New York. That fool has no clue about the world!”
es: —Wilson? He thinks he's going to New York to see his sister. He's so dumb he doesn't even know he's alive.

en: So Tom Buchanan and his girl and I went up together to New York—or not quite together, for Mrs. Wilson sat discreetly in another car. Tom deferred that much to the sensibilities of those East Eggers who might be on the train.
vi: After that, Tom Buchanan, his mistress, and I went to New York together. Actually, we didn't travel together; Wilson's wife discreetly took a separate train car. Tom delayed traveling separately like that just to avoid the sensitivity of the people from East. What if they happen to be on the same train?
tr: Thus, we set off towards New York with Tom and his mistress; although it couldn't really be said that we were together, because Mrs. Wilson traveled in another compartment; at least Tom had taken into account the possibility of encountering East Eggers on the train.
es: So Tom Buchanan, his girl, and I went to New York together. Or not exactly together, because Mrs. Wilson traveled discreetly in another car. It was a courtesy from Tom towards the sensitivity of the East Egg residents who might be on the train.

en: She had changed her dress to a brown figured muslin, which stretched tight over her rather wide hips as Tom helped her to the platform in New York. At the newsstand she bought a copy of Town Tattle and a moving-picture magazine, and in the station drugstore some cold cream and a small flask of perfume. Upstairs, in the solemn echoing drive she let four taxicabs drive away before she selected a new one, lavender-coloured with grey upholstery, and in this we slid out from the mass of the station into the glowing sunshine. But immediately she turned sharply from the window and, leaning forward, tapped on the front glass.
vi: Mrs. Wilson had changed into a tight-fitting muslin dress. The dress stretched tightly across her broad hips as Tom helped her down to the New York station platform. At the newsstand, she bought a Town Tattle tabloid and a movie magazine, then went to the drugstore to buy some face cream and a small bottle of perfume. When she reached the upper level of the station, she called for four taxis in a formal manner but rejected each one until she finally accepted the fifth because it looked new. The lavender-colored car, with gray upholstery, whisked us away from the crowded station into the bright sunshine. However, at that moment, she suddenly turned her head away from the window and leaned forward to tap on the glass partition in front.
tr: During this time, the woman had also changed her clothes; with Tom's help, she got off the train wearing a tight, brown-patterned muslin dress that revealed her broad hips as she stretched. She bought a magazine called Kent Gossip and a cinema magazine from the newsstand at the station; from the pharmacy, she got a cream and a small bottle of perfume. Amid the noise and darkness upstairs, after turning down four taxis, she finally liked a gray-upholstered, purple-colored taxi. We were finally escaping the crowd of the station and stepping into the daylight when she suddenly turned her face from the window she was watching outside, leaned forward, and tapped on the glass.
es: Mistress Wilson had changed her dress to a brown muslin one with a print that clung tightly to her wide hips when Tom helped her alight at the New York platform. At the newsstand, she bought the Town Tattle and a movie magazine, and at the station's drugstore, she bought face cream and a perfume. Upstairs, in the solemn, echo-filled entrance, she rejected four taxis before choosing a new lavender-colored one with gray upholstery, and in it, we drove away from the grand station into the splendid sunlight. But immediately Mistress Wilson stopped paying attention to the window, leaned forward, and knocked on the glass that separated us from the driver.

en: “I want to get one of those dogs,” she said earnestly. “I want to get one for the apartment. They’re nice to have—a dog.”
vi: "I want to buy one of those dogs." Tom's girlfriend said earnestly. "I want a dog for my apartment. It would be so cute to have a dog there."
tr: "I want one of those dogs over there," she said in a determined voice, "it will stay in the apartment; we need to get such a dog for there."
es: —I want one of those dogs —she said very seriously—. I want one for the apartment. It's good to have... a dog.

en: We backed up to a grey old man who bore an absurd resemblance to John D. Rockefeller. In a basket swung from his neck cowered a dozen very recent puppies of an indeterminate breed.
vi: We called the car to back up to an old man with white hair who bore an uncanny resemblance to John D. Rockefeller, with a basket hanging from his long neck containing about a dozen newborn puppies of indeterminate breed. "What breed is this dog?"
tr: The taxi reversed until it stopped next to an old man with white hair who strangely resembled John D. Rockefeller. In the basket hanging around the man's neck, a dozen newborn puppies of indeterminate breed were huddled together.
es: We backed up in search of an old gray man who absurdly resembled John D. Rockefeller. In a basket hanging from his neck, a handful of newborn puppies of indeterminate breed cowered in fear.

en: “What kind are they?” asked Mrs. Wilson eagerly, as he came to the taxi-window.
vi: Wilson's wife asked anxiously as the old man approached the car door.
tr: Mrs. Wilson asked the old man who approached the car window, "What breed are they?"
es: —What kind of dogs are they? —asked Mistress Wilson with genuine excitement, as the man approached the taxi window.

en: “All kinds. What kind do you want, lady?”
vi: "We have all breeds." "Which breed would you like to buy, ma'am?"
tr: “There is every kind. What are you looking for?”
es: —Of all types. What type are you looking for, ma'am?

en: “I’d like to get one of those police dogs; I don’t suppose you got that kind?”
vi: "I want to buy the type of German Shepherd that police often keep, do you have any?"
tr: "Actually, I want one of those police dogs. But you don't have that breed, do you?"
es: —I would like a police dog, but I suppose you don't have any of that breed.

en: The man peered doubtfully into the basket, plunged in his hand and drew one up, wriggling, by the back of the neck.
vi: The old man looked into the basket with a suspicious gaze, then reached in, grabbed the nape, and pulled up a wriggling one.
tr: The old man's eyes wandered over the basket with suspicion, and soon he plunged his hand in and grabbed one by the nape, pulling out the wriggling puppy.
es: The man looked with uncertain eyes into the basket, put his hand in, and took out a puppy that wouldn't stop moving, grabbing it by the neck.

en: “That’s no police dog,” said Tom.
vi: "That dog is not the type of German Shepherd that the police usually keep." Tom said.
tr: “This is not a police dog,” said Tom.
es: —It is not a police dog —said Tom.

en: “No, it’s not exactly a police dog,” said the man with disappointment in his voice. “It’s more of an Airedale.” He passed his hand over the brown washrag of a back. “Look at that coat. Some coat. That’s a dog that’ll never bother you with catching cold.”
vi: "No, this one is not truly a German Shepherd." the old man said with a disappointed voice. "It looks more like an Airedale terrier." The old man gently stroked the dog's back, which looked like a brown towel. "Just look at its fur. It's truly special fur. This breed will never bother you by catching a cold."
tr: “This is not a police dog,” said Tom. “Well, not exactly,” said the man, his disappointment reflected in his voice, “Actually, this is an Airedale terrier,” he continued speaking while stroking the animal's brown tufted back, “Look at that fur. This dog will never get sick and make you sad.”
es: —No, it's not exactly a police dog —said the man, with some disappointment—. I would rather say it's an Airedale —he ran his hand over the brown back, which looked like a dishcloth—. Look at the hair. What hair. This dog will never bother you with a cold.

en: “I think it’s cute,” said Mrs. Wilson enthusiastically. “How much is it?”
vi: "I find it very cute." Wilson's wife said cheerfully. "How much does this one cost?"
tr: “What a lovely thing!” said Mrs. Wilson excitedly. “How much?”
es: —I think it's beautiful —said Mrs. Wilson enthusiastically—. How much does it cost?

en: “That dog?” He looked at it admiringly. “That dog will cost you ten dollars.”
vi: "Is that the one?" The old man looked at the dog admiringly and said. "That dog costs ten dollars."
tr: “How much?” “This one?” After looking at the dog with admiration, the man said, “I’ll give it to you for ten dollars.”
es: —This dog? —the man looked at him with true admiration—. For you, it will be ten dollars.

en: The Airedale—undoubtedly there was an Airedale concerned in it somewhere, though its feet were startlingly white—changed hands and settled down into Mrs. Wilson’s lap, where she fondled the weatherproof coat with rapture.
vi: No one doubts that this dog has a bit of Airedale lineage, although its legs are strangely white. The dog was passed around and then placed on Mrs. Wilson's lap. She stroked its all-weather fur passionately.
tr: Although it had some Airedale Terrier in its lineage, the tiny Airedale with overly white feet eventually changed hands and settled into the lap of Mrs. Wilson, who began to caress its airtight fur ecstatically.
es: The Airedale—undoubtedly some remote Airedale had been implicated in the matter, although those paws were strikingly white—changed owners and ended up in the lap of Mistress Wilson, who caressed that weatherproof fur with rapture.

en: “Is it a boy or a girl?” she asked delicately.
vi: "Is this dog a boy or a girl?" Mrs. Wilson asked tactfully and delicately.
tr: “Is it female or male?” the woman asked gently.
es: —Is it a boy or a girl? —he said gently.

en: “That dog? That dog’s a boy.”
vi: "Is that the child? It's a boy."
tr: “This one? Male.”
es: —This dog? It's a boy.

en: “It’s a bitch,” said Tom decisively. “Here’s your money. Go and buy ten more dogs with it.”
vi: "It is a female dog," Tom said decisively. "Here is your money. Take it to buy ten more dogs."
tr: “Oh, it's a female!” Tom said dismissively. “Take your money and go! With this money, you can buy ten more of these!”
es: —It's a bitch —said Tom definitively—. Here is your money. Go and buy yourself ten more dogs.

en: We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon. I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner.
vi: Our car reached Fifth Avenue, the weather was both warm and mild, reminiscent of a Sunday afternoon in the countryside, so much so that if I had seen a flock of white sheep at the corner of the street, I wouldn't have been surprised.
tr: We headed towards Fifth Avenue, on that warm and sweet, even almost rural summer day, I would hardly have been surprised if a flock of white sheep had suddenly appeared from around the corner.
es: We entered Fifth Avenue, warm and drowsy, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon. I wouldn't have been surprised to see a large flock of white sheep appear at a corner.

en: “Hold on,” I said, “I have to leave you here.”
vi: "Wait a moment, I have to say goodbye to the two people here." I said.
tr: “Let's stop,” I said, “I need to get off here.”
es: —Stop —I said—. I have to leave you here.

en: “No you don’t,” interposed Tom quickly. “Myrtle’ll be hurt if you don’t come up to the apartment. Won’t you, Myrtle?”
vi: "That won't do." Tom quickly interrupted. "Myrtle will feel slighted if you don't come upstairs, won't she Myrtle?"
tr: "No way!" Tom objected. "If you don't join us, Myrtle will be very upset, won't you Myrtle?"
es: —Nothing of the sort —Tom interrupted me—. Myrtle would be offended if you don't come up to the apartment. Right, Myrtle?

en: “Come on,” she urged. “I’ll telephone my sister Catherine. She’s said to be very beautiful by people who ought to know.”
vi: "Come up and hang out for a bit," Myrtle, Tom's mistress, pleaded. "I'll call my sister Catherine. Everyone worth knowing says she's beautiful."
tr: “Come on,” insisted the woman. “I will call my sister Catherine and invite her too. Those who know her say she is very beautiful.”
es: —Come on —mistress Wilson insisted to me—. I will call my sister Catherine on the phone. Those who know say she is very beautiful.

en: “Well, I’d like to, but—”
vi: "Actually, I really want to, but..."
tr: “I would love to, but -”
es: —I would like to go, but…

en: We went on, cutting back again over the Park toward the West Hundreds. At 158th Street the cab stopped at one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses. Throwing a regal homecoming glance around the neighbourhood, Mrs. Wilson gathered up her dog and her other purchases, and went haughtily in.
vi: We continued to go further, crossing Park Street towards West Hundreds Street. At 158th Street, the taxi stopped in front of a building in a row of apartment houses, looking like a slice cut from a long white cream cake. Glancing around the neighborhood regally, Myrtle hugged her dog and gathered the newly purchased items, haughtily stepping into the house.
tr: We continued to progress, turning from Central Park and heading towards the West Hundreds. The taxi stopped in front of one of the buildings on 158th Street, which resembled a long, white cake. After glancing around in honor of her return home, Mrs. Wilson proudly entered, gathering her dog and packages.
es: We did not stop, we cut through Central Park towards the west and the Hundred streets again. On One Hundred and Fifty-Eighth Street, the taxi stopped in front of a piece of the great white cake of an apartment building. Throwing a queenly glance at the neighborhood as she returned home, Mistress Wilson grabbed the dog and her other purchases and entered the house with an air of grandeur.

en: “I’m going to have the McKees come up,” she announced as we rose in the elevator. “And, of course, I got to call up my sister, too.”
vi: "I will invite the McKees up here," Myrtle declared as the elevator was going up. "And of course, I will also call my sister."
tr: "I will also invite the McKees," he announced while taking the elevator, "Of course, I also need to call my brother."
es: —I'm going to call the McKees —he announced as we were going up in the elevator—. And my sister, of course.

en: The apartment was on the top floor—a small living-room, a small dining-room, a small bedroom, and a bath. The living-room was crowded to the doors with a set of tapestried furniture entirely too large for it, so that to move about was to stumble continually over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was an over-enlarged photograph, apparently a hen sitting on a blurred rock. Looked at from a distance, however, the hen resolved itself into a bonnet, and the countenance of a stout old lady beamed down into the room. Several old copies of Town Tattle lay on the table together with a copy of Simon Called Peter, and some of the small scandal magazines of Broadway. Mrs. Wilson was first concerned with the dog. A reluctant elevator boy went for a box full of straw and some milk, to which he added on his own initiative a tin of large, hard dog biscuits—one of which decomposed apathetically in the saucer of milk all afternoon. Meanwhile Tom brought out a bottle of whisky from a locked bureau door.
vi: The apartment is located on the topmost floor, consisting of a small living room, a small dining room, a small bedroom, and a bathroom. A set of sofas lined with rugs depicting large, cumbersome decorative scenes stretched from inside to the door, making the room feel cramped. As a result, everyone frequently tripped over the rug with scenes of girls swinging in the gardens of Versailles whenever they walked through the room. On the wall, there was only one oversized picture, depicting a hen standing on a vague rock. However, when viewed from a distance, the hen appeared to be a hat and the face of a plump old lady smiling down at the room. Several old issues of Town Tattle lay on the table along with a novel titled SIMON CALLED PETER and a few small tabloids specializing in digging up Broadway gossip. Upon entering the house, the first thing Myrtle did was take care of the dog. The little boy guarding the elevator reluctantly went to buy a box of straw and some milk when asked. After buying them, he took it upon himself to buy an additional tin box of large, hard biscuits meant for dogs. A piece of biscuit left in the milk dish lay soaking indifferently throughout the entire evening. Tom unlocked the glass cabinet and took out a bottle of whiskey.
tr: A small living room, a small dining room, a small bedroom, and a small bathroom made up the apartment, which was on the top floor. The living room was so filled with furniture that was too large for the room and covered with tapestries that it was impossible to move without stumbling over a few cheerful ladies depicted in the gardens of the Palace of Versailles. The only picture hanging on the wall was an overly enlarged photograph. At first glance, it vaguely resembled a chicken perched on a rock, but upon looking again from a distance, the chicken turned into a bonnet, and the chubby face of a smiling old lady filled the entire room. On the table were a few old issues of “Town Tattler,” Robert Keable's popular novel Simon Called Peter, and some of Broadway's gossip magazines. Mrs. Wilson first attended to the dog. Although it was clear from his demeanor that he was reluctant, the elevator boy was sent to fetch a box filled with straw and some milk. When the boy returned, he had not hesitated to add a large box of dog biscuits, which he had thought of himself, even though these biscuits would just dissolve in a bowl of milk all afternoon. Meanwhile, Tom had taken a bottle of whiskey out of a locked cabinet.
es: The apartment was in the attic: a small living room, a small dining room, a small bedroom, and a bathroom. Up to the door of the living room, the furniture, upholstered and too large, accumulated, and taking a step meant stumbling over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was a very enlarged, blurred photograph of what seemed to be a hen perched on a rock. Viewed from afar, however, the hen turned into a bonnet, and the countenance of an elderly and corpulent lady shone in the room. On the table were several back issues of Town Tattle, a copy of Simon Called Peter[7], and some Broadway gossip magazines. Mistress Wilson took care of the dog first of all. A reluctant elevator operator went to get milk and a crate with straw, to which he added on his own initiative a can of large, hard dog biscuits, one of which spent the afternoon dissolving apathetically in the bowl of milk. And meanwhile, Tom took a bottle of whiskey from a locked dresser.

en: I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it, although until after eight o’clock the apartment was full of cheerful sun. Sitting on Tom’s lap Mrs. Wilson called up several people on the telephone; then there were no cigarettes, and I went out to buy some at the drugstore on the corner. When I came back they had both disappeared, so I sat down discreetly in the living-room and read a chapter of Simon Called Peter—either it was terrible stuff or the whisky distorted things, because it didn’t make any sense to me.
vi: In my life, I have been drunk twice in total, and that afternoon was the second time. Everything that happened to me seemed very vague like it was covered in fog, even though it was already past eight o'clock and the room was still filled with bright sunlight. Sitting on Tom's lap, Wilson's wife was calling many people. When I realized there were no cigarettes, I went out to buy some at a corner drugstore. When I returned, the two of them had disappeared. I cautiously sat in the living room and read a chapter from the book Simon Called Peter. Either the book was terribly written, or the whiskey had distorted everything, I found that nothing written in the book made any sense.
tr: I have only been drunk twice in my life, and the second time happened to me that day. Therefore, even though the apartment was filled with bright sunlight until eight o'clock, everything seemed to be covered in a dim and misty haze. Mrs. Wilson sat on Tom's lap and made phone calls here and there. Then we realized we were out of cigarettes; I left the house to go to the tobacconist at the corner. When I returned, there was no one around. So I sat quietly in the living room and read a section from Simon Called Peter; I don't know if the book was terrible or if the whiskey I drank had muddled my mind, but I couldn't make much sense of what I read.
es: I've only gotten drunk twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon, so a confusing layer of fog clouds everything that happened, although a splendid sun illuminated the apartment until past eight. Sitting on top of Tom, Mistress Wilson called several people on the phone, and then the cigarettes ran out, so I went down to buy some at the corner store. When I came back, the lovers had disappeared, and I prudently sat in the living room and read a chapter of Simon, called Peter: it was either infamous or the whiskey was distorting things, because it made no sense at all.

en: Just as Tom and Myrtle (after the first drink Mrs. Wilson and I called each other by our first names) reappeared, company commenced to arrive at the apartment door.
vi: When Tom and Myrtle reappeared, (after the first glass of wine, Mrs. Wilson and I had started calling each other by t (term of endearment), the invited guests had also arrived at the door.
tr: Just after Tom and Myrtle (after the first drink, I had become quite familiar with Mrs. Wilson) appeared, guests started trickling in one by one.
es: At the moment when Tom and Myrtle (after the first drink, Mistress Wilson and I were on a first-name basis) reappeared, the guests started to arrive at the apartment.

en: The sister, Catherine, was a slender, worldly girl of about thirty, with a solid, sticky bob of red hair, and a complexion powdered milky white. Her eyebrows had been plucked and then drawn on again at a more rakish angle, but the efforts of nature toward the restoration of the old alignment gave a blurred air to her face. When she moved about there was an incessant clicking as innumerable pottery bracelets jingled up and down upon her arms. She came in with such a proprietary haste, and looked around so possessively at the furniture that I wondered if she lived here. But when I asked her she laughed immoderately, repeated my question aloud, and told me she lived with a girl friend at a hotel.
vi: My sister Catherine is a slim, modern person, around thirty years old age, her red hair tightly bunned, her face smeared with milk-white powder. Her eyebrows had been completely plucked and redrawn to appear more refined, but as the real hairs naturally grew back, they looked like two faint smudges on her face. As Catherine moved around, her numerous baked clay bracelets continuously shifted up and down, clinking together to create jingling sounds. She approached with the demeanor of a host, hurriedly glancing around as if she owned everything, giving me the impression that she resided here. However, when I asked her, Catherine laughed exaggeratedly, loudly repeating my question before answering that she was currently living with a girlfriend at a hotel.
tr: Catherine, the sister, had oily, thick, and short red hair; her face was milk white due to excessive powder, she was slender, overly fond of worldly pleasures, and a woman in her thirties. All her eyebrows were plucked, and a new pair of more arched eyebrows were drawn with a pencil, but nature's effort to revive the old line had dulled the expression on her face. The bracelets she wore clinked together with every movement, creating a constant jingling sound. She had entered with the airs of a hostess, eyeing the belongings so possessively that I thought she lived there. When I asked her about it, she burst into laughter, first repeating my question out loud, and then said she was staying at a hotel with a girlfriend.
es: The sister, Catherine, was a thin and worldly woman of about thirty years, red-haired, shaved like a boy and styled with hair gel, and of a milky, cosmetic whiteness. She had plucked her eyebrows and repainted them at a more elegant angle, but nature's efforts to restore the old line gave her face an incoherent expression. When Catherine moved, the jingling of the numerous cheap bracelets on her arms produced an incessant tinkling. She entered with such an anxious proprietorial air, and looked at the furniture so possessively, that I thought perhaps it was her house. But I asked her and she laughed exaggeratedly, repeating my question out loud. She told me she lived with a friend in a hotel.

en: Mr. McKee was a pale, feminine man from the flat below. He had just shaved, for there was a white spot of lather on his cheekbone, and he was most respectful in his greeting to everyone in the room. He informed me that he was in the “artistic game,” and I gathered later that he was a photographer and had made the dim enlargement of Mrs. Wilson’s mother which hovered like an ectoplasm on the wall. His wife was shrill, languid, handsome, and horrible. She told me with pride that her husband had photographed her a hundred and twenty-seven times since they had been married.
vi: The young man McKee, who lived downstairs, was pale and effeminate like a woman. He looked as if he had just shaved because there was still a streak of white shaving cream on his cheek. McKee politely greeted everyone in the room. He informed me that he was playing an "artistic game." It was only later that I learned he was a photographer, the author who had enlarged the blurry photo of Wilson's wife's mother, which now hung like a ghost on the wall. McKee's wife had a shrill voice, a lifeless demeanor, was pretentious, and quite terrifying. She proudly boasted to me that her husband had photographed her a total of one hundred and twenty-seven times since they got married.
tr: Mr. McKee, who was sitting downstairs, was a pale and somewhat effeminate man. From the white foam mark left on his cheekbone, it was clear that he had just shaved. He greeted those in the room with great respect. He had told me that he was “from the art world”; later, I learned that he was a photographer and that he was the one who enlarged the photo of Mrs. Wilson's mother, which stood on the wall like an ectoplasmic manifestation. His wife was a shrill-voiced, sluggish, pleasant, and terrifying woman. She had proudly recounted that since they got married, her husband had taken her photograph one hundred and twenty-seven times.
es: Mister McKee was a feminine, pale man, the neighbor from the floor below. He had just shaved, because he had a white spot of foam on his cheek, and he showed extraordinary respect when greeting everyone present. He informed me that he worked "in the artistic world," and later I found out that he was a photographer and that he had made the blurry enlargement of Mrs. Wilson's mother that floated on the wall like an ectoplasm. His wife was shrill, languid, beautiful, and horrible. She told me proudly that her husband had photographed her one hundred and twenty-seven times since their wedding day.

en: Mrs. Wilson had changed her costume some time before, and was now attired in an elaborate afternoon dress of cream-coloured chiffon, which gave out a continual rustle as she swept about the room. With the influence of the dress her personality had also undergone a change. The intense vitality that had been so remarkable in the garage was converted into impressive hauteur. Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment, and as she expanded the room grew smaller around her, until she seemed to be revolving on a noisy, creaking pivot through the smoky air.
vi: Mrs. Wilson had changed into an elaborate evening dress made of cream-colored tulle, which emitted a constant rustling sound as she moved back and forth in the room. The dress had completely altered her demeanor. The vibrant energy from her body at the garage had now transformed into a distinctly haughty attitude. Her laughter, gestures, and words became increasingly fierce and aggressive. She dominated the space around her, making the room feel cramped. Then she even spun around like a creaking pillar in the hazy, smoke-filled air.
tr: Mrs. Wilson had changed her outfit a while ago; she was now wearing a flamboyant, cream-colored chiffon cocktail dress that filled the room with a rustling sound as she walked; it was as if her personality had changed with the dress. The intense life energy she exuded in the workshop had given way to an immense arrogance. With each passing moment, her laughter, gestures, and speech became more and more artificial; as she puffed up, the space in the room seemed to shrink. Finally, the woman appeared to be revolving on an axis in the smoke-filled room, creaking as she turned.
es: Mistress Wilson had changed clothes shortly before, and now she was wearing a complicated cream-colored chiffon evening dress that left a constant rustle in its wake as she moved around the room. Under the influence of the dress, her personality also underwent a change. The intense vitality of the garage, so perceptible, had transformed into an impressive fatuity. Her laughter, her gestures, her statements became more affected by the moment, and, as she expanded, the room shrank around her, until, noisy and creaking, Mistress Wilson seemed to spin on a pedestal in the smoke-filled air.

en: “My dear,” she told her sister in a high, mincing shout, “most of these fellas will cheat you every time. All they think of is money. I had a woman up here last week to look at my feet, and when she gave me the bill you’d of thought she had my appendicitis out.”
vi: "Hey, sis." Mrs. Wilson loudly and whiningly said to her younger sister. "The people here always just want to deceive us. They only think about money. Last week, I called a woman up here to take care of my feet. When she handed me the bill, if you had seen it, you would have thought she had performed an appendectomy on me."
tr: “My dear,” she called out to her sister in a loud yet coquettish voice, “People are practically swindlers; all they care about is money. Last week, I called a woman here for a pedicure; if you heard the bill she gave me, you'd think she performed an appendectomy instead of a pedicure.”
es: —Darling —she shouted to her sister, with a prim and sharp voice—, all those people will always deceive you. They only think about money. A woman came last week to fix my feet and, when she gave me the bill, it was as if I had had an appendectomy.

en: “What was the name of the woman?” asked Mrs. McKee.
vi: "What is that woman's name?" Mrs. McKee asked.
tr: “What was this woman's name?” asked Mrs. McKee.
es: —What was her name? —asked Mistress McKee.

en: “Mrs. Eberhardt. She goes around looking at people’s feet in their own homes.”
vi: "Eberhardt." "She specializes in home foot care for clients."
tr: “Mr. Ebenhardt. He goes to houses for pedicures.”
es: —Mistress Eberhardt. She dedicates herself to fixing feet at home.

en: “I like your dress,” remarked Mrs. McKee, “I think it’s adorable.”
vi: "I like the dress you are wearing." "It's very cute," Mrs. McKee complimented.
tr: “I absolutely love your dress,” said Mrs. McKee, “It's wonderful!”
es: —I love your dress —observed Mistress McKee—. I think it's wonderful.

en: Mrs. Wilson rejected the compliment by raising her eyebrow in disdain.
vi: Mrs. Wilson rejected the compliment by raising her eyebrows disdainfully.
tr: Mr. Wilson raised his eyebrows and dismissively rejected the compliment, "Oh, this old rag?
es: Mistress Wilson rejected the compliment by disdainfully raising an eyebrow.

en: “It’s just a crazy old thing,” she said. “I just slip it on sometimes when I don’t care what I look like.”
vi: "It's just an old shirt." "I only put it on when I don't care about my appearance."
tr: Mr. Wilson raised his eyebrows and dismissively rejected the compliment, "Oh, this old rag? I just throw it on when I don't care about my appearance."
es: —It's really old —he said—. I only wear it when I don't care about how I look.

en: “But it looks wonderful on you, if you know what I mean,” pursued Mrs. McKee. “If Chester could only get you in that pose I think he could make something of it.”
vi: "But you look very beautiful in it, if you understand what I mean." Mrs. McKee continued to pursue the topic. "If Chester could take a picture of you in this pose, I think he would have a valuable piece."
tr: “But it really looks wonderful on you,” insisted Mrs. McKee. “If Chester could capture this pose of yours, it would make a splendid photograph.”
es: —Well, it suits you wonderfully, I don't know if you understand me —continued Mistress McKee—. If Chester photographed you in that pose, he would make something worthwhile.

en: We all looked in silence at Mrs. Wilson, who removed a strand of hair from over her eyes and looked back at us with a brilliant smile. Mr. McKee regarded her intently with his head on one side, and then moved his hand back and forth slowly in front of his face.
vi: All of us silently watched Mrs. Wilson; she brushed a lock of hair from her eyes and turned to look at us with a radiant smile. Mr. McKee tilted his head to one side, gazing at her intently, then slowly moved his hand back and forth in front of her face, measuring carefully.
tr: We looked at Mrs. Wilson in silence; she sweetly smiled, tossing back a lock of hair that had fallen on her face. Mr. McKee tilted his head to the side and carefully examined the woman, then began to move his hand back and forth at eye level.
es: We all looked silently at Mistress Wilson, who brushed a lock of hair away from her eyes and returned our gaze with a radiant smile. Mister McKee studied her attentively, tilting his head, and then put his hand in front of his face and moved it back and forth.

en: “I should change the light,” he said after a moment. “I’d like to bring out the modelling of the features. And I’d try to get hold of all the back hair.”
vi: After a moment, he spoke. "I should change the light." "I want to highlight her facial features and capture all the hair in the back."
tr: “The light needs to change,” he said after a moment, “I want to bring out the facial features, and the hair in the background needs to be in the frame as well.”
es: —I would change the light —he said after a moment—. I would like to highlight the modeling of the features, and I would try to capture the hair at the nape of the neck.

en: “I wouldn’t think of changing the light,” cried Mrs. McKee. “I think it’s—”
vi: "I don't think we should change the light." Mrs. McKee shouted. "I think it..."
tr: “If you ask me, there's no need to change the light at all,” cried Mrs. McKee, “besides-”
es: —I wouldn't change the light —proclaimed Mistress McKee—. It seems to me that it is…

en: Her husband said “Sh!” and we all looked at the subject again, whereupon Tom Buchanan yawned audibly and got to his feet.
vi: The husband "shushed" the wife and we turned back to look at the model once more. At that moment Tom Buchanan yawned loudly and stood up.
tr: Adam silenced the woman by saying "Shhh!", and we turned back to look at the model again. At that moment, Tom Buchanan stood up, yawning loudly.
es: Her husband said "Shhh" and we all turned to look at the model again, when Tom yawned audibly and stood up.

en: “You McKees have something to drink,” he said. “Get some more ice and mineral water, Myrtle, before everybody goes to sleep.”
vi: "Do you two, Mr. and Mrs. McKee, want something to drink?" Tom asked. "Myrtle, get some more ice and spring water here before everyone goes to bed."
tr: “Come on, McKees, let's have a drink. Myrtle, could you bring some more ice and soda before our guests fall asleep?”
es: —Have a drink, folks —he said to the McKees—. Bring more ice and mineral water, Myrtle, before everyone falls asleep.

en: “I told that boy about the ice.” Myrtle raised her eyebrows in despair at the shiftlessness of the lower orders. “These people! You have to keep after them all the time.”
vi: "I sent the boy to get some ice." Myrtle raised her eyebrows in disappointment at the laziness of the subordinate. "These kinds of people! I always have to keep an eye on them all day long."
tr: “I had already told the child to bring ice,” said Myrtle, raising her eyebrows in frustration at the incompetence of the lower class, “Ah, these people! You can't take your eyes off them for a moment!”
es: —Look, I told the boy to bring ice —Myrtle raised her eyebrows, desperate over the laziness of the lower classes—. What people! You have to be behind them all the time.

en: She looked at me and laughed pointlessly. Then she flounced over to the dog, kissed it with ecstasy, and swept into the kitchen, implying that a dozen chefs awaited her orders there.
vi: Myrtle looked at me and smiled for no reason, then hurried over to the dog, kissed it passionately, and then dragged her dress into the kitchen as if there were a dozen chefs waiting for her orders there.
tr: He looked at me and burst into laughter out of nowhere. Then, he lunged towards the dog, wrapping it up in his arms, smothering it with kisses; immediately after, as if a dozen chefs were waiting for his orders, he stormed into the kitchen.
es: He looked at me and laughed for no reason. Then he picked up and kissed the dog in a fit of passion and entered the kitchen majestically as if a team of cooks were waiting for his orders.

en: “I’ve done some nice things out on Long Island,” asserted Mr. McKee.
vi: "I captured some beautiful scenes in Long Island." McKee said.
tr: "I had some very nice work on Long Island," said Mr. McKee, defensively.
es: —In Long Island, I have done very interesting things —declared Mr. McKee.

en: Tom looked at him blankly.
vi: Tom looked at him blankly.
tr: Tom stared blankly at the man's face.
es: Tom looked at him without understanding.

en: “Two of them we have framed downstairs.”
vi: "Two paintings have been framed and hung on the ground floor of the house."
tr: “We had two of them framed, they are downstairs.
es: —We have two of them framed downstairs.

en: “Two what?” demanded Tom.
vi: "Which two letters?" Tom asked.
tr: “What do you mean by two?” asked Tom.
es: —Two what? —asked Tom.

en: “Two studies. One of them I call Montauk Point—The Gulls, and the other I call Montauk Point—The Sea.”
vi: "Two contemplative pictures. One I named Montauk Point - Seagull. The other I named Montauk Point - The Sea."
tr: “What do you mean by two?” asked Tom. “Of course, I have two works: I named one Montauk Point - Seagulls, and the other Montauk Point - Sea.”
es: —Two studies. One I have titled Montauk Point: the seagulls, and the other Montauk Point: the sea.

en: The sister Catherine sat down beside me on the couch.
vi: Catherine sat down next to me on the long bench.
tr: My sister Catherine sat on the couch next to me.
es: Catherine, the sister, sat next to me on the sofa.

en: “Do you live down on Long Island, too?” she inquired.
vi: "Are you also in Long Island?" she asked.
tr: “Do you also live in Long Island?” he asked.
es: —Do you also live in Long Island? —she asked me.

en: “I live at West Egg.”
vi: "I live in West Egg."
tr: “No, I am in West Egg.”
es: —I live in West Egg.

en: “Really? I was down there at a party about a month ago. At a man named Gatsby’s. Do you know him?”
vi: "Really? I just attended a party there last month at the house of a man named Gatsby. Do you know him?"
tr: “Really? About a month ago, I went there for a party at a man named Gatsby's house. Do you know him?”
es: —Yes? I was there at a party, about a month ago. At the house of a certain Gatsby. Do you know him?

en: “I live next door to him.”
vi: "I am the neighbor right next to his house."
tr: “He is my next-door neighbor.”
es: —He/She lives next to my house.

en: “Well, they say he’s a nephew or a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm’s. That’s where all his money comes from.”
vi: "Well, they say he is a grandson or some kind of cousin of the German Emperor Wilhelm. All his money comes from there."
tr: “It is said that the man is the nephew or cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm. The source of his wealth is also him.”
es: —They say he is the nephew or cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm. That's why he has so much money.

en: “Really?”
vi: "Really?"
tr: “Is that so?”
es: —Yes?

en: She nodded.
vi: She nodded.
tr: The girl nodded her head and continued.
es: He nodded.

en: “I’m scared of him. I’d hate to have him get anything on me.”
vi: "I am very afraid of him. I absolutely hate it when he touches me."
tr: “I was really scared. I don't want him to know anything about me.”
es: —I'm scared. I wouldn't like it at all if he/she took it out on me.

en: This absorbing information about my neighbour was interrupted by Mrs. McKee’s pointing suddenly at Catherine:
vi: The intriguing news about my neighbor was interrupted when Mrs. McKee suddenly pointed at Catherine.
tr: The interesting information about my neighbor was interrupted by Mrs. McKee's intervention, pointing at Catherine with her hand and shouting: "Look Chester, you could do a good job with this girl."
es: This fascinating information about my neighbor was interrupted by Mistress McKee, who suddenly pointed at Catherine with her finger.

en: “Chester, I think you could do something with her,” she broke out, but Mr. McKee only nodded in a bored way, and turned his attention to Tom.
vi: "Mr. Chester, I think you could take a few shots for her." She shouted loudly, but Mckee just nodded indifferently and then turned his attention to Tom.
tr: However, Mr. McKee dismissed her with a weary nod and turned back to Tom:
es: —Chester, I think you could do something with her —he proclaimed, but Mr. McKee just nodded with a bored air and turned his attention back to Tom.

en: “I’d like to do more work on Long Island, if I could get the entry. All I ask is that they should give me a start.”
vi: "I want to take more pictures in Long Island, if I can get some help at the beginning. I just need help at the beginning."
tr: “If I had the opportunity to enter, I would like to do other studies in Long Island. All I want is to be given a chance.”
es: —If I could introduce myself, I would like to work more in Long Island. The only thing I ask is that they let me start.

en: “Ask Myrtle,” said Tom, breaking into a short shout of laughter as Mrs. Wilson entered with a tray. “She’ll give you a letter of introduction, won’t you, Myrtle?”
vi: "Ask Myrtle." Tom said, then burst out laughing as Mrs. Wilson walked in with a tray of drinks. "She'll give you a letter of recommendation, won't she Myrtle?"
tr: “Tell this to Myrtle,” said Tom, then burst into laughter, just as Mrs. Wilson entered with a tray in her hand, “tell her to write a letter of recommendation for you, won't you write it, Myrtle?”
es: —Talk to Myrtle —said Tom, letting out a laugh and taking advantage of mistress Wilson arriving from the kitchen with a tray—. She will give you a letter of introduction, right, Myrtle?

en: “Do what?” she asked, startled.
vi: "Doing what?" Myrtle asked, bewildered.
tr: “What am I supposed to write?” the woman asked, startled.
es: —Give what? —she asked, surprised.

en: “You’ll give McKee a letter of introduction to your husband, so he can do some studies of him.” His lips moved silently for a moment as he invented, “ ‘George B. Wilson at the Gasoline Pump,’ or something like that.”
vi: "I will give Mr. McKee a letter of introduction to my husband, so Mr. McKee can get a photography subject about my husband." Tom tried to find the words, his lips moving without making a sound, then he thought of it. "The subject is George B. Wilson at the gas station, or any subject with a similar name will do."
tr: "Honey, I’m saying, if you could write a letter of introduction for McKee, so he can work with him." Then he quietly muttered a title, "George B. at the Gas Pump Wilson, or something like that."
es: —You will give McKee a letter of introduction to your husband, so he can do a few studies of him —he kept moving his lips, silently, as he made it up—. George B. Wilson at the gas pump, or something like that.

en: Catherine leaned close to me and whispered in my ear:
vi: Catherine leaned towards me and whispered in my ear.
tr: Catherine leaned in and whispered in my ear, "Neither of them can stand their spouses."
es: Catherine leaned over me, very close, and whispered in my ear:

en: “Neither of them can stand the person they’re married to.”
vi: "Neither of them can stand the person they married."
tr: Catherine leaned in and whispered in my ear, "Neither of them can stand their spouses."
es: —Neither of them can stand the person they are married to.

en: “Can’t they?”
vi: "They can't stand it?"
tr: "No way!"
es: —No?

en: “Can’t stand them.” She looked at Myrtle and then at Tom. “What I say is, why go on living with them if they can’t stand them? If I was them I’d get a divorce and get married to each other right away.”
vi: "Can't stand it." She looked at Myrtle and then at Tom. "I mean, why do they keep living as husband and wife if they can't stand their spouse anymore? If I were them, I would have divorced and married each other right away."
tr: “Really!” He looked first at Myrtle and then at Tom, “If you can't stand it, why do you keep it up, right? If I were in their place, I wouldn't wait at all, I would get divorced and then marry the person I love.”
es: —They can't stand them —he looked at Myrtle and then at Tom—. And I say: why do they keep living with those people if they can't stand them? If I were them, I would get a divorce and remarry immediately.

en: “Doesn’t she like Wilson either?”
vi: "Didn't Myrtle also love Wilson?"
tr: “Doesn't Myrtle love Wilson at all?”
es: —Does she not want Wilson either?

en: The answer to this was unexpected. It came from Myrtle, who had overheard the question, and it was violent and obscene.
vi: The answer to my question was unexpectedly provided by Myrtle. She eavesdropped on the question and answered it in a crude and vulgar manner.
tr: The answer to my question came in a way I never expected. Myrtle, who had been eavesdropping, responded to my question with a mouthful of curses.
es: The response was unexpected, because it came from Myrtle, who had heard my question. And it was violent and obscene.

en: “You see,” cried Catherine triumphantly. She lowered her voice again. “It’s really his wife that’s keeping them apart. She’s a Catholic, and they don’t believe in divorce.”
vi: "You see." Catherine exclaimed triumphantly, then lowered her voice again. "Actually, Tom's wife is the one blocking their way. She is a Catholic and does not believe in divorce."
tr: “You see!” cried Catherine triumphantly. Then she lowered her voice again. “Actually, the reason they can't be together is Tom's wife. She's Catholic, you know their divorces are forbidden.”
es: —You see —exclaimed Catherine triumphantly. She lowered her voice again—. It's his wife who separates them. She's Catholic, and Catholics don't believe in divorce.

en: Daisy was not a Catholic, and I was a little shocked at the elaborateness of the lie.
vi: Daisy is not a Christian. I felt a bit surprised by this embellished lie.
tr: Since I knew Daisy wasn't Catholic, I was a bit shaken by this big lie.
es: Daisy wasn't Catholic, and the elaborate nature of the lie impressed me a bit.

en: “When they do get married,” continued Catherine, “they’re going West to live for a while until it blows over.”
vi: "When will they actually get married?" Catherine continued. "They will move to the West for a while, waiting for the storm to pass."
tr: “As soon as they get married,” he continued, “they will go to the West and live there until things settle down.”
es: —When they get married —continued Catherine— they will go West for a while, until everything has passed.

en: “It’d be more discreet to go to Europe.”
vi: "Going to Europe might be more discreetly isolated."
tr: “Why don't they go to Europe!”
es: —It would be more discreet to go to Europe.

en: “Oh, do you like Europe?” she exclaimed surprisingly. “I just got back from Monte Carlo.”
vi: "Oh, you like Europe?" She exclaimed in surprise. "I just returned from Monte Carlo."
tr: “So, you like Europe too?” he exclaimed excitedly, “I just returned from Monte Carlo.”
es: —Ah, do you like Europe? —he exclaimed, surprising me—. I just returned from Monte Carlo.

en: “Really.”
vi: "Is that so."
tr: “Oh, really?”
es: —Yes?

en: “Just last year. I went over there with another girl.”
vi: "Just last year." "I went there with a girlfriend."
tr: “More precisely, I was there last year. I had gone with a female friend.”
es: —Last year. I went with another girl.

en: “Stay long?”
vi: "Have you been there long?"
tr: "Did you stay long?""
es: —Were you there for a long time?

en: “No, we just went to Monte Carlo and back. We went by way of Marseilles. We had over twelve hundred dollars when we started, but we got gyped out of it all in two days in the private rooms. We had an awful time getting back, I can tell you. God, how I hated that town!”
vi: "Not long, just to Monte Carlo and back." "We went via Marseilles." "When we left, we had more than twelve hundred, but within just two days, we were swindled and robbed of everything at the lodging houses." "You must know we were in a miserable state trying to find a way back." "Oh my God, I hate that city."
tr: “No, I can say that our trip to Monte Carlo was as good as our return. We had gone via Marseille. When we set out, we had twelve hundred dollars with us; but we fell for those special rooms and within two days we were penniless. I can't describe what we went through until we returned. My God, I hate that place!”
es: —No, we went to Monte Carlo and came back. We went via Marseille. We had over twelve hundred dollars when we started, and in two days we were fleeced down to the last cent. We had a terrible time on the way back, I can assure you. My God, what a dreadful city!

en: The late afternoon sky bloomed in the window for a moment like the blue honey of the Mediterranean—then the shrill voice of Mrs. McKee called me back into the room.
vi: The late afternoon sky cast rays of sunlight through the window, for a moment resembling the blue honey color of the Mediterranean. The shrill voice of Mrs. McKee pulled me back to the present in the room.
tr: For a moment, I was lost in the sky outside the window, which was tinged with the beloved Mediterranean blue, when Mrs. McKee's shrill voice brought me back to reality:
es: The evening sky, resembling the blue honey of the Mediterranean, shone for a moment in the window, and then the shrill voice of Mistress McKee brought me back to the room.

en: “I almost made a mistake, too,” she declared vigorously. “I almost married a little kike who’d been after me for years. I knew he was below me. Everybody kept saying to me: ‘Lucille, that man’s way below you!’ But if I hadn’t met Chester, he’d of got me sure.”
vi: "I almost made a mistake." She declared forcefully. "I almost married a lowly Jewish guy who had been pursuing me for many years. I knew that he was inferior to me. Everyone said: 'Lucille, that guy is way too inferior for you.' If I hadn't met Chester, I would have definitely married that guy."
tr: “I almost got myself into trouble,” she said excitedly, “I was this close to marrying a man who had been chasing after me for years, even though he was not my equal at all. Everyone around me was warning, ‘Lucille, this man is not worthy of you.’ If I hadn't met Chester, he would have definitely convinced me.”
es: —I also almost made a mistake —she asserted energetically—. I was about to marry an insignificant Jew who had been after me for years. I knew he was not up to my standards. And everyone told me: "Lucille, that man is not up to your standards." But he would have gotten his way, for sure, if I hadn't met Chester.

en: “Yes, but listen,” said Myrtle Wilson, nodding her head up and down, “at least you didn’t marry him.”
vi: "Yes, but listen here." Myrtle nodded her head and said.
tr: “But look,” said Myrtle Wilson, shaking her head, “at least you didn't marry him.”
es: —Yes, but listen —said Myrtle Wilson, nodding her head up and down—, at least you didn't get married.

en: “I know I didn’t.”
vi: "At least I didn't marry that guy."
tr: “Yes, fortunately.””
es: —Of course.

en: “Well, I married him,” said Myrtle, ambiguously. “And that’s the difference between your case and mine.”
vi: "That's right, I didn't take it." "And I have married someone like that." Myrtle said, in a vague and unclear manner. "That is the difference between your case and mine."
tr: “Well, I got married!” he then said suggestively, “and that's the difference between us.”
es: —I did get married —said Myrtle, in a tone of ambiguity. —Why did you get married, Myrtle?

en: “Why did you, Myrtle?” demanded Catherine. “Nobody forced you to.”
vi: "Why did you do that, Myrtle? No one forced you."
tr: “But why, Myrtle?” asked Catherine, “No one had forced you!”
es: —asked Catherine—. No one forced you.

en: Myrtle considered.
vi: Catherine questioned. Myrtle thought for a moment, then finally answered.
tr: Myrtle thought for a moment, "Actually, I married him because I thought he was a gentleman.
es: Myrtle pondered the answer.

en: “I married him because I thought he was a gentleman,” she said finally. “I thought he knew something about breeding, but he wasn’t fit to lick my shoe.”
vi: "I married him because I thought he was a charming and elegant man. I believed he came from a noble family. But in reality, he isn't even worthy to lick my shoes."
tr: Myrtle thought for a moment, "Actually, I married him because I thought he was a gentleman. I believed he was well-mannered, but he wasn't even worthy of licking my shoes.
es: —I got married because I thought he was a gentleman —she finally said—. I thought he knew what a good upbringing was, but he wasn't even worth cleaning my shoes with his tongue.

en: “You were crazy about him for a while,” said Catherine.
vi: "There was a time when she loved him madly." Catherine said. "Madly in love with him!"
tr: “You used to be madly in love with her,” said Catherine.
es: —Well, for a while you were crazy about him —said Catherine.

en: “Crazy about him!” cried Myrtle incredulously. “Who said I was crazy about him? I never was any more crazy about him than I was about that man there.”
vi: Myrtle exclaimed incredulously. "Who said you were madly in love with him? You have never loved him as madly as you loved that other man."
tr: “Was I in love?” Myrtle cried. She seemed unable to believe what she was hearing, “Where did you get that from? I loved him only as much as I love the man sitting over there.”
es: —Crazy about him! —exclaimed Myrtle incredulously—. Who said I was crazy about him? I've never been crazier about him than about that man.

en: She pointed suddenly at me, and everyone looked at me accusingly. I tried to show by my expression that I expected no affection.
vi: Myrtle suddenly pointed at me, causing everyone to turn and look at me as if accusing. I tried to appear as though I had nothing to do with Myrtle's past.
tr: The fact that he was pointing at me had caused everyone to look at me as if I were a criminal, while I tried to show with my facial expression that I definitely had no place in his past.
es: Suddenly, he pointed at me with his finger, and everyone looked at me accusingly. I tried to make my expression clear that I did not aspire to any kind of appreciation.

en: “The only crazy I was was when I married him. I knew right away I made a mistake. He borrowed somebody’s best suit to get married in, and never even told me about it, and the man came after it one day when he was out: ‘Oh, is that your suit?’ I said. ‘This is the first I ever heard about it.’ But I gave it to him and then I lay down and cried to beat the band all afternoon.”
vi: "The only thing that could be considered crazy was that she married him. She immediately knew that she had made a mistake. He had borrowed the nicest suit to wear for the wedding but didn't tell her about it. A day later, when he wasn't home, a man came to retrieve the suit. She asked, 'Oh, so that suit belongs to you? This is the first time I've heard about this.' She returned the suit to the man, then collapsed on the bed and cried her heart out the entire afternoon."
tr: “The only time I acted insanely was the moment I married him. As soon as we got married, I realized it was a huge mistake. It turned out he had borrowed a friend's suit for his own wedding ceremony and hadn't told me a single thing about it. Then one day, while he was not at home, this man showed up, ‘Oh! So the suit is yours?” I said, “This is the first time I'm hearing this from you!’ Still, I gave the suit to the man, then shut myself in the bedroom and cried my heart out until evening.”
es: —My only madness was getting married. And I immediately knew that I had made a mistake. He borrowed his best suit from I don't know who for the wedding, and he didn't say a word to me, and the man came for his suit one day when my husband wasn't home. "Ah, the suit is yours?" I said, "well, now I know." I gave it to him and then I lay on the bed and spent the afternoon crying nonstop.

en: “She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me. “They’ve been living over that garage for eleven years. And Tom’s the first sweetie she ever had.”
vi: "She should have left her husband right then." Catherine continued to tell me. "The two of them have lived at that auto repair shop for eleven years already. Tom is the first lover she has ever had."
tr: "She really needs to leave that man," Catherine continued the story from where she left off, "They have been living in that apartment above the repair shop for exactly eleven years, and Tom is her first lover anyway."
es: —He would have to separate —Catherine summarized to me—. They have been living in the attic of that garage for eleven years. And Tom is the first friend he has had.

en: The bottle of whisky—a second one—was now in constant demand by all present, excepting Catherine, who “felt just as good on nothing at all.” Tom rang for the janitor and sent him for some celebrated sandwiches, which were a complete supper in themselves. I wanted to get out and walk eastward toward the park through the soft twilight, but each time I tried to go I became entangled in some wild, strident argument which pulled me back, as if with ropes, into my chair. Yet high over the city our line of yellow windows must have contributed their share of human secrecy to the casual watcher in the darkening streets, and I saw him too, looking up and wondering. I was within and without, simultaneously enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.
vi: The second bottle of whiskey was continuously passed around for everyone to drink except Catherine, who felt "there's no need to drink to have fun." Tom rang the bell to call the servant and instructed him to buy the famous hamburgers for the afternoon meal. At that moment, I just wanted to leave this place to take a walk south towards the park under the gentle sunset. But every time I took a step to leave, I was pulled back, entangled in fierce debates like ropes tying me to the g End. In the high space above the city where the golden windows we are in are located, we are certainly adding to the secret treasure of humanity, and to the pedestrian walking below on the slowly darkening streets. I saw him look up curiously. I felt as if I were both inside and outside, constantly both fascinated and disgusted by the unpredictable changes of life.
tr: The second bottle of whiskey was now being passed around, and everyone except Catherine, who said she felt good without drinking, was filling their glasses. Tom called the doorman and asked him to bring some sandwiches from the nearby deli, which were famous for being filling enough to be a meal on their own. As evening fell, I wanted to go outside and take a walk eastward, towards the park, in that sweet coolness. But whenever I intended to get up, I would get caught in a fierce and noisy argument that tied me to my seat like a rope, and in the end, I would remain stuck in my chair. In sharing the privacy of a person who happened to be passing through the darkening streets, the series of yellow windows of this apartment over the city certainly had a part. At that moment, I was also someone randomly passing by, almost looking up and wondering what was happening there. With the idea that I was both inside and outside, the inexhaustible variety of life both fascinated and disgusted me.
es: The bottle of whisky—the second one—was now in high demand by everyone present, except for Catherine, who "felt fine without anything." Tom called the concierge and sent him out for some famous sandwiches that were as good as a full dinner. I felt like leaving and walking east towards the park, in the soft twilight, but every time I tried to say goodbye, I found myself entangled in some noisy, senseless discussion that held me back, as if I had been tied up. Dominating the city, however, our row of illuminated windows would offer its share of human secrets to the occasional observer of the dark streets, someone who was also me, watching and marveling. I was both inside and outside, at once enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.

en: Myrtle pulled her chair close to mine, and suddenly her warm breath poured over me the story of her first meeting with Tom.
vi: Myrtle pulled the chair closer to me, suddenly her hot breath wafted over me as she recounted the story of her first meeting with Tom.
tr: Myrtle brought her chair closer to me, and as she began to recount her first meeting with Tom, I could feel her warm breath on my face.
es: Myrtle drew her chair closer, and suddenly her warm breath poured over me the story of her first meeting with Tom.

en: “It was on the two little seats facing each other that are always the last ones left on the train. I was going up to New York to see my sister and spend the night. He had on a dress suit and patent leather shoes, and I couldn’t keep my eyes off him, but every time he looked at me I had to pretend to be looking at the advertisement over his head. When we came into the station he was next to me, and his white shirtfront pressed against my arm, and so I told him I’d have to call a policeman, but he knew I lied. I was so excited that when I got into a taxi with him I didn’t hardly know I wasn’t getting into a subway train. All I kept thinking about, over and over, was ‘You can’t live forever; you can’t live forever.’ ”
vi: "Only the last two narrow seats facing each other were left on the train." I am on my way to New York to visit my sister and stay overnight there. Tom was wearing a suit and finely crafted leather shoes at that time. I couldn't take my eyes off him. But every time he looked back, I pretended to be reading the advertisements above his head. When the train stopped at the station, I found he was already beside me, his white shirt pressing tightly against my arm. I told him I would report him to the police, but he knew very well I was just pretending. I was so overwhelmed that when I got into the taxi with him, I didn't realize I hadn't taken the subway. At that moment, only one thought kept running through my mind. "Life is short, life is short."
tr: “In the compartments, we always sat opposite each other in the least preferred single seats. I was coming to New York to spend the night with my sister. Tom was wearing a suit and patent leather shoes; I couldn't take my eyes off him, but when he looked at me, I pretended to be fixated on the billboard above him. When the train arrived at the station, he was right next to me, resting his starched shirt front on my arm. Even though I said I would call the police, he realized I wasn't serious. When we got into the taxi together, I was so excited that I didn't even notice we had taken a taxi instead of the subway. The same words kept running through my mind, ‘You only live once… You only live once...’”
es: —It was in those two small seats, one facing the other, which are always the last to be free on the train. I was going to New York to see my sister and spend the night. Tom was dressed in formal attire, with patent leather shoes, and I couldn't take my eyes off him, but if he looked at me, I pretended to read the advertisement above his head. When we arrived at the station, I felt him close, and the white front of his shirt pressed against my arm, so I told him I was going to call a policeman, but he knew it wasn't true. I was so excited when I got into the taxi with him that I barely realized we weren't taking the subway. The only thing I kept thinking, over and over, was: "You are not going to live forever; you are not going to live forever."

en: She turned to Mrs. McKee and the room rang full of her artificial laughter.
vi: Myrtle shouted to Mrs. McKee, her laughter echoing artificially throughout the room.
tr: Then she turned to Mrs. McKee and let out a fake laugh.
es: He turned towards Mistress McKee and his artificial laugh echoed in the room.

en: “My dear,” she cried, “I’m going to give you this dress as soon as I’m through with it. I’ve got to get another one tomorrow. I’m going to make a list of all the things I’ve got to get. A massage and a wave, and a collar for the dog, and one of those cute little ashtrays where you touch a spring, and a wreath with a black silk bow for mother’s grave that’ll last all summer. I got to write down a list so I won’t forget all the things I got to do.”
vi: "Sister. I will give you this dress as soon as I no longer use it. Tomorrow I will buy a new one. I will make a list of everything I need to buy. A massager, a hair curler, a collar for the dog, a cute ashtray with a spring button, a wreath with a black silk ribbon to place on my mother's grave throughout the summer. I have to list everything so I don't forget what needs to be done."
tr: “My dear,” she called out, “As soon as I'm done with this dress, I'll give it to you, since I'll be getting a new one tomorrow anyway. In the meantime, it would be good to make a list of my tasks for tomorrow; first a massage, then my hair appointment, I need to get a leash for the dog, then I want to buy some of those cute ashtrays, you know, the spring-loaded ones; and I need to get a wreath with a black silk bow that will last all summer for my mother's grave. To make sure I don't forget, I’d better go and prepare a list.”
es: —Darling —she exclaimed—, I'll give you the dress as soon as I take it off. Tomorrow I plan to buy another one. I'm going to make a list of all the things I need. A massage and a perm, a collar for the dog, one of those lovely ashtrays with a device to swallow the ash, and a crown with a black silk ribbon for my mother's grave, that lasts all summer. I'm going to make a list of all the things I have pending so I don't forget them.

en: It was nine o’clock—almost immediately afterward I looked at my watch and found it was ten. Mr. McKee was asleep on a chair with his fists clenched in his lap, like a photograph of a man of action. Taking out my handkerchief I wiped from his cheek the spot of dried lather that had worried me all the afternoon.
vi: Nine o'clock in the evening, and then just a moment later when I looked back, it was already ten o'clock. Mr. McKee was dozing off on the chair with his hand tightly gripping his thigh, resembling a picture of a man in a fighting stance. I took a handkerchief to wipe off the dried shaving cream stuck on his cheek, which had been bothering me all afternoon.
tr: It was nine o'clock, and shortly after, when I looked at my watch again, I saw that it was ten. Mr. McKee had fallen asleep with his hands in his lap, fists clenched; in this state, he looked like a photo of a vigorous man. I took out my handkerchief and wiped off the dried shaving foam on his cheekbone that had been bothering me all day.
es: It was nine o'clock, and almost immediately I looked at the clock and saw that it was ten. Mr. McKee had fallen asleep in his chair, with his fists clenched on his lap. He looked like the picture of a man of action. I took the handkerchief and wiped the dried shaving foam from his cheek that had bothered me all afternoon.

en: The little dog was sitting on the table looking with blind eyes through the smoke, and from time to time groaning faintly. People disappeared, reappeared, made plans to go somewhere, and then lost each other, searched for each other, found each other a few feet away. Some time toward midnight Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson stood face to face discussing, in impassioned voices, whether Mrs. Wilson had any right to mention Daisy’s name.
vi: The small dog sitting on the table is looking through the smoke with its bleary eyes, occasionally letting out indistinct whines. The people in the house disappear and then reappear, discussing where to go, getting lost, finding each other, and then finding each other again just a few steps away. At some point around midnight, Tom Buchanan and Myrtle stood facing each other, fiercely arguing whether Myrtle had the right to mention Daisy's name.
tr: The tiny dog that had settled on the table was looking through the cigarette smoke with blind eyes, occasionally letting out soft whimpers. People were appearing and disappearing, planning to go somewhere, then losing each other, only to meet again a few steps away. Towards midnight, Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson had engaged in a heated argument about whether Myrtle had the right to mention Daisy's name.
es: The little dog looked from atop the table, blinded by the smoke, and occasionally whimpered weakly. People disappeared, reappeared, made plans to go somewhere, and then got lost, searched for each other, and found themselves a meter apart. Around midnight, Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson, standing face to face, argued passionately about whether Mrs. Wilson had the right to say Daisy's name.

en: “Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson. “I’ll say it whenever I want to! Daisy! Dai—”
vi: "Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!" Myrtle shouted. "I'll call whenever I want. Daisy. Dai..."
tr: “Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson, “I’ll say it whenever I want! Daisy!
es: —Daisy! Daisy! Daisy! Dai..! —shouted Mistress Wilson—. I'll say it as many times as I want!

en: Making a short deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.
vi: With a deft movement, Tom Buchanan struck and broke Myrtle's nose.
tr: Dai-” Tom Buchanan had suddenly slapped her, breaking her nose!
es: With a sharp and swift movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with an open hand.

en: Then there were bloody towels upon the bathroom floor, and women’s voices scolding, and high over the confusion a long broken wail of pain. Mr. McKee awoke from his doze and started in a daze toward the door. When he had gone halfway he turned around and stared at the scene—his wife and Catherine scolding and consoling as they stumbled here and there among the crowded furniture with articles of aid, and the despairing figure on the couch, bleeding fluently, and trying to spread a copy of Town Tattle over the tapestry scenes of Versailles. Then Mr. McKee turned and continued on out the door. Taking my hat from the chandelier, I followed.
vi: Many blood-stained towels were thrown on the bathroom floor, the sound of women scolding, the intermittent groans of pain rising above the chaos. The man Mckee suddenly woke up from his drowsy sleep, half-awake, and quickly headed towards the door. He got halfway there when he suddenly turned around and stared at the scene before him. His wife and Catherine were simultaneously scolding and comforting, stumbling from one place to another among the cramped furniture in the house to get bandages. A figure lay hopelessly on the sofa, blood streaming down, trying to spread the Town Tattle over the Versailles scene on the carpet to cover the blood. Mckee turned his back and continued to walk out the door. Reaching for the hat hanging on the ceiling lamp, I followed suit.
tr: Afterwards, it was complete chaos; bloodied towels scattered here and there in the bathroom, women's voices scolding Tom, and cries of pain rising incessantly, drowning out everything else.
