Mr. McKee, awakened by the noise, jumped up groggily and headed for the door. He stopped halfway, staring at the scene in bewilderment. While his wife and Catherine were running around, bumping into the crowded furniture with bandages in their hands, they were both scolding Tom and trying to console the poor Myrtle, who was struggling to cover their Versailles-view chairs with Kent Gossip magazines to protect them from the blood streaming from her nose. Then Mr. McKee turned his back on this scene and walked out the door, and I immediately grabbed my hat hanging nearby and followed him out.
es: Then there were towels soaked in blood on the bathroom floor, and indignant voices of women, and, above the confusion, an endless and intermittent moan of pain. Mr. McKee woke up and groggily searched for the door. He had not finished leaving when he turned and saw the scene: Catherine and his wife, who were shouting and protesting and trying to offer some comfort while, with things from the first aid kit in hand, they stumbled over all the furniture that crowded the room, and the desperate figure on the sofa, who kept bleeding and tried to protect the upholstery with pages from Town Tattle and its scenes of Versailles. Then Mr. McKee turned around and resumed his way to the door. I grabbed my hat from the candelabrum where I had left it, and followed him.

en: “Come to lunch some day,” he suggested, as we groaned down in the elevator.
vi: "Remember to come have lunch with us sometime." Mckee suggested as the creaky elevator carried the two of us down.
tr: “Come over for dinner one day,” he said, as they descended in the creaky elevator together.
es: —Come over for a meal one day —he suggested, as the elevator descended and groaned.

en: “Where?”
vi: "Where?"
tr: "Where to?" I asked.
es: —Where to?

en: “Anywhere.”
vi: "Anywhere."
tr: “Anywhere will do.”
es: —Anywhere.

en: “Keep your hands off the lever,” snapped the elevator boy.
vi: "Don't touch the lever." Little Thắng grumbled irritably while holding the elevator. "Sorry."
tr: "Take your hand off the lever," the elevator boy scolded.
es: —Don't touch the lever —complained the elevator operator.

en: “I beg your pardon,” said Mr. McKee with dignity, “I didn’t know I was touching it.”
vi: McKee said respectfully.
tr: “I'm sorry,” said Mr. McKee seriously, “I didn't realize I had touched it.”
es: —Excuse me —said Mr. McKee very dignifiedly—. I didn't realize.

en: “All right,” I agreed, “I’ll be glad to.”
vi: "I didn't notice I had bumped into it." "Alright, I will be happy to come."
tr: “Alright,” I said, accepting the suggestion, “I would be pleased.”
es: —Great —I said—. It will be a pleasure.

en: … I was standing beside his bed and he was sitting up between the sheets, clad in his underwear, with a great portfolio in his hands.
vi: I accepted......
tr: ... I was standing next to the bed, while she was sitting under the sheets in her underwear with a huge album in her hands.
es: … And then I was standing, next to the bed, and Mr. McKee, between the sheets and in his underwear, sitting, had a large folder in his hands.

en: “Beauty and the Beast… Loneliness… Old Grocery Horse… Brook’n Bridge…”
vi: Then.. I stood beside McKee's bed, he was sitting between two bed sheets covering his underwear, holding a stack of many photographs, with names like: Beauty and the Beast... Loneliness... The Old Draft Horse... Brooklyn Bridge...... Then..
tr: “Beauty and the Beast, Loneliness, The Old Milkman's Horse, Brooklyn Bridge…””
es: —Beauty and the Beast… Solitude… The horse from the old grocery store… The Brooklyn Bridge…

en: Then I was lying half asleep in the cold lower level of the Pennsylvania Station, staring at the morning Tribune, and waiting for the four o’clock train.
vi: After that. I lay half-awake in the cold lower level of Pennsylvania Station, staring at the Morning Tribune, waiting for the four o'clock train.
tr: … Soon after, lying in the cold lower level of Pennsylvania Station, between sleep and wakefulness, I was staring at the Tribune morning newspaper, waiting for the four o'clock train.
es: Afterwards, I found myself collapsed, half asleep, on the deepest and coldest platform of Pennsylvania Station, staring at the first edition of the Tribune and waiting for the four o'clock morning train.

en: III
vi: Chapter 3
tr: CHAPTER 3

en: There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights. In his blue gardens men and girls came and went like moths among the whisperings and the champagne and the stars. At high tide in the afternoon I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or taking the sun on the hot sand of his beach while his two motorboats slit the waters of the Sound, drawing aquaplanes over cataracts of foam. On weekends his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long past midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. And on Mondays eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.
vi: From my neighbor's house, the sound of music echoed without pause throughout the summer nights. In Gatsby's azure garden, men and women flitted to and fro like moths, amidst whispered laughter, champagne glasses, and the stars in the sky. Every afternoon, as the tide rose, I watched Gatsby's guests diving from the floating raft or sunbathing on the hot sand of the beach behind the house, while two motorboats cut through the waves, towing water skiers through the splashing foam. On weekends, Gatsby's Rolls Royce transformed into a small bus, shuttling guests to and from the city from nine in the morning until past midnight, while his station wagon, like a yellow beetle, zipped back and forth to the train station to meet the arrivals. Every Monday, eight servants, plus the gardener, armed with mops, brushes, hammers, and pruning shears, toiled all day to repair the damage from the night before.
tr: On summer nights, the sounds of music would rise from my neighbor's house. In their blue gardens, men and women would flit about like moths among whispers, champagne, and stars. In the afternoons, as the tide rose, I would watch guests diving from the diving platform on the raft waiting offshore or people sunbathing on the hot sands in front of the mansion, while two motorboats sped through the Bosphorus, leaving foamy trails for water skiers. On weekends, my neighbor's Rolls Royce would be used like a bus from nine in the morning until late at night, constantly ferrying people from the city to the mansion or from the mansion to the city. Meanwhile, their station wagon would meet all incoming trains, shuttling back and forth between the station and the house like a giant yellow bug. By Monday morning, eight servants, including an extra gardener, would work all day with brooms, cloths, brushes, hammers, and garden shears to repair the damage from the previous night and clean up the place.
es: Music came from my neighbor's house on summer nights. In their blue gardens, men and girls went to and fro like moths among the whisperings, the champagne, and the stars. When the tide rose in the evenings, I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or taking the sun on the hot sand of his beach while two motorboats slit the waters of the Sound, drawing aquaplanes over cataracts of foam. On weekends, his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long past midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. And on Mondays, eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.

en: Every Friday five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York—every Monday these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves. There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler’s thumb.
vi: Every Friday, five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York. Every Monday, these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves. There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler's thumb.
tr: Every Friday, five crates of oranges and lemons from a greengrocer in New York would arrive, and every Monday, they would leave the house through the back door as a pyramid of squeezed half-shells. In the kitchen, there was a machine that, with the butler pressing his thumb two hundred times, could squeeze the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour.
es: A fruit shop in New York sent five boxes of lemons and oranges every Friday, and every Monday those same lemons and oranges went out the back door in a pyramid of pulp-less peels. In the kitchen, there was a machine that could squeeze two hundred oranges in half an hour if the butler's thumb pressed a button two hundred times.

en: At least once a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough coloured lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby’s enormous garden. On buffet tables, garnished with glistening hors-d’oeuvre, spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold. In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.
vi: At least twice a week, a group of people from the catering company would come with hundreds of yards of canvas and many colored lights for decoration, enough to turn Gatsby's enormous garden into a Christmas tree. On the buffet tables, the food was lavishly displayed, including glossy appetizers, spiced baked hams nestled among layers of colorful lettuce leaves, puff pastry-wrapped sausages, and turkeys seemingly magically roasted to a golden hue. In the grand hall, a bar was set up with brass racks filled with various types of white wine, distilled spirits, and aperitifs. These bottles of wine were so aged that most of Gatsby's female guests were too young to distinguish one type of wine from another.
tr: Every fifteen days at least, a group of people working in the catering service would come with meters of tarpaulin and enough bulbs to turn Gatsby's enormous garden into a Christmas tree, and they would work. The prepared tables would be adorned with various hors d'oeuvres, colorful salads accompanying a crowd of spicy cold meats, animal-shaped pastries, and roasted bacon and turkeys. The bar set up in the main hall with brass railings would have such drinks that had not been produced for a long time that most of the female guests were not old enough to know these liqueurs and gins. When it was seven in the evening, the musicians would take their places.
es: At least once every fortnight, an army of suppliers would show up with more than a hundred meters of canvas and enough colored lights to turn Gatsby's enormous garden into a Christmas tree. On the buffet tables, adorned with dazzling hors d'oeuvres, spiced hams jostled against harlequin salads, pork pies, and turkeys the color of old gold, as if enchanted. In the main hall, they set up a bar, with an authentic metal footrail, stocked with gins, alcoholic beverages, and liqueurs forgotten for so long that most of the female guests were too young to distinguish one from another.

en: By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs; the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colours, and hair bobbed in strange new ways, and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter, and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other’s names.
vi: Around seven in the evening, the orchestra arrived. It wasn't the type of orchestra with just five instruments, but one that included an entire ensemble of oboes, trombones, saxophones, violins, cornets, piccolos, high drums, and low drums. The last swimmers had also left the beach to change clothes upstairs. Cars from New York were parked in five long rows in the yard. In the hallways, lounges, and porches, every place was filled with colors, hairstyles arranged in various strange styles, and Castile shawls that one could only dream of. The bar was extremely busy, with trays of cocktails being carried out, filling the garden outside, wave after wave until the air came alive with chatter, with boisterous laughter, with casual remarks, with introductions forgotten as soon as they were made, and with the enthusiastic encounters of women who had never known each other's names.
tr: It was not a thin band of three to five people, but a magnificent orchestra consisting of oboe, trombone, saxophone, violin, cornet, flute, and numerous drums of various sizes. The last remaining swimmers would also be returning from the beach and getting dressed upstairs. Those coming from New York by car would fill the first five rows in the parking lot. The rooms, lounges, and verandas would be filled with colorful clothes, strange hairstyles, and shawls more varied than those in Castile would wander around. The bar would start operating at full capacity, and cocktail glasses floating in the air would blend into the night in the garden outside. Conversations and laughter would enliven the atmosphere, casual hints and introductions would be instantly forgotten, and heated conversations would begin among women who didn't even learn each other's names.
es: At seven o'clock the orchestra arrived, not just a simple quintet, but a whole band of oboes and saxophones and trombones and violas and cornets and piccolos and bass drums and snare drums. The last swimmers have just returned from the beach and are getting dressed upstairs; cars from New York are parked five deep in the driveway, and the lobbies, the salons, and the galleries already attract attention with their primary colors and the latest, most unusual hairstyles, and shawls that surpass the dreams of ancient Castile. The bar is buzzing with activity, and the incessant rounds of cocktails float through the garden, permeating it, and even the air is enlivened with conversations and laughter, and insignificant insinuations and instantly forgotten introductions, and enthusiastic encounters between women who have never known each other's names.

en: The lights grow brighter as the earth lurches away from the sun, and now the orchestra is playing yellow cocktail music, and the opera of voices pitches a key higher. Laughter is easier minute by minute, spilled with prodigality, tipped out at a cheerful word. The groups change more swiftly, swell with new arrivals, dissolve and form in the same breath; already there are wanderers, confident girls who weave here and there among the stouter and more stable, become for a sharp, joyous moment the centre of a group, and then, excited with triumph, glide on through the sea-change of faces and voices and colour under the constantly changing light.
vi: The colored lights further enhanced the radiance as the sun had set, at that moment the orchestra began to perform rhythmic music and the opera troupe's singing was raised to a higher note. With each passing minute, laughter became easier, flowing generously or bursting forth from cheerful remarks. The shapes of the groups of guests gathered also changed rapidly, swelling with new arrivals, or dispersing and reassembling within a single breath. Confident and bold young women wandered from place to place, weaving among other more voluptuous and less mobile girls to become the main centers of lively merriment. Then, still in the midst of the lively excitement, they continued to glide among the faces, voices, and ever-changing colors under the constantly shifting lights.
tr: As the Earth moved away from the sun, the lights would shine brighter; when the orchestra started playing a blonde cocktail music, the opera of conversations would rise a few tones. With each passing minute, laughter would be spent more generously, and even a small word would be enough to cheer people up. Groups would change more quickly, swell up with newcomers, disperse in an instant, and gather again in a single breath. There would also be those who wandered around. These would weave in and out among the more stout and motionless ones, become the center of attention of one of the groups in a sharp and cheerful moment, and then, with the excitement of that victory, pass through a sea of faces, voices, and colors, under constantly changing lights.
es: The lights become more intense as the Earth drifts away from the sun, and the orchestra plays cocktail music, and the opera of voices rises a tone. Laughter becomes easier, more abundant, spilling over at any cheerful word. The groups change more quickly, grow with newcomers, dissolve and form in the same breath; now you see, wandering, self-assured girls weaving between more solid and stable guests, becoming for a fleeting and happy moment the center of a group, and, with the thrill of triumph, disappearing silently into the sea of faces and voices and colors under the ever-changing light.

en: Suddenly one of these gypsies, in trembling opal, seizes a cocktail out of the air, dumps it down for courage and, moving her hands like Frisco, dances out alone on the canvas platform. A momentary hush; the orchestra leader varies his rhythm obligingly for her, and there is a burst of chatter as the erroneous news goes around that she is Gilda Gray’s understudy from the Follies. The party has begun.
vi: Suddenly, one of the girls in a shimmering translucent white dress moving around there grabbed a cocktail glass and downed it in one gulp to muster courage, then she started waving her hands like Frisco, dancing alone on the stage. In that moment, the atmosphere suddenly fell into silence, and the conductor hurriedly changed the orchestra's rhythm to match the girl's dance. The noise rose again as everyone whispered a false rumor, saying she was the stand-in for Gilda Gray in the Broadway Follies musicals. And thus, the gala began.
tr: Sometimes, one of these gypsies, while wandering around in her bright, opal-colored dress, would suddenly grab one of the cocktails offered on a tray and, after drinking it in one gulp to boost her courage, would start dancing alone on the spread-out tarpaulin, making strange movements with her hands and arms. After a moment of silence, the orchestra conductor would adjust the music to her movements, and among the guests, false rumors would start circulating that the young woman was the understudy of the Revue star Gilda Gray, but it would quickly become clear that this was not true. That's when the party would really begin.
es: Suddenly, one of those gypsy women, vibrant in her opal dress, catches a cocktail in mid-air, bravely drinks it in one gulp, and, moving her hands like Frisco[8], dances alone on the canvas floor. Momentary silence: the orchestra conductor is forced to match the girl's rhythm, and gossip spreads as the false news circulates that she is Gilda Gray's[9] understudy in the Follies. The party has begun.

en: I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew Gatsby, and after that they conducted themselves according to the rules of behaviour associated with an amusement park. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.
vi: I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby's house, I was one of the few actual guests who were invited. The others who were not invited still came anyway. They jumped into the cars that took them to Long Island, and after that, no one knew how they got to Gatsby's door. Once there, they were introduced by others who knew Gatsby. And just like that, they followed the host's principles and adapted to the behavior of those around them to participate in the festivities. Sometimes they came and went without ever meeting Gatsby; they just used their innocence as a ticket in.
tr: I believe I was one of the few officially invited guests the first night I went to Gatsby's house. People would join the party without waiting for an invitation. They would get into the cars that took them to Long Island and find themselves at Gatsby's house. Upon arrival, someone who knew Gatsby would introduce them to him, and then they would wander around adopting behaviors suitable for the activities in an amusement park. Their entry pass would be the pure intention in their hearts to attend the party.
es: I believe that the first night I was at Gatsby's house, I was one of the few who had actually been invited. People were not invited: they went. They got into cars that took them to Long Island, and, somehow, they ended up at Gatsby's door. Once there, someone who knew Gatsby introduced them and, from that moment on, they behaved according to the conduct norms typical of amusement parks. And some nights they arrived and left without even meeting Gatsby: they came to the party with a naivety of heart that served as their entry.

en: I had been actually invited. A chauffeur in a uniform of robin’s-egg blue crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with a surprisingly formal note from his employer: the honour would be entirely Gatsby’s, it said, if I would attend his “little party” that night. He had seen me several times, and had intended to call on me long before, but a peculiar combination of circumstances had prevented it—signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.
vi: I am It was indeed true that I had been invited by Gatsby. Gatsby's chauffeur, in a robin's egg blue uniform, crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with an unexpected note from Gatsby. The note stated that Gatsby would be greatly honored if I would attend a small party at his house that evening. Gatsby had seen me many times before and had intended to invite me for a long time, but he had been hindered by special circumstances. Below the note was Gatsby's stately signature.
tr: So I really had been invited. Early one Saturday morning, a chauffeur in a robin's egg blue uniform crossed the lawn to deliver a formal invitation from his employer. It said that it would be a great honor if I attended the 'little party' that night. He had seen me many times and had thought of visiting. But he had been unable to do so due to some obstacles. The ostentatious signature at the bottom corner of the invitation read Jay Gatsby.
es: I was truly invited. A chauffeur in a turquoise blue uniform, the color of a robin's egg, crossed the lawn of my house early Saturday morning with an astonishingly formal note from his employer: Gatsby would be very honored, it said, if I could attend his "little party" that night. He had seen me several times, and for a long time had intended to pay me a visit, but a singular combination of circumstances had prevented it. It was signed Jay Gatsby, in majestic handwriting.

en: Dressed up in white flannels I went over to his lawn a little after seven, and wandered around rather ill at ease among swirls and eddies of people I didn’t know—though here and there was a face I had noticed on the commuting train. I was immediately struck by the number of young Englishmen dotted about; all well dressed, all looking a little hungry, and all talking in low, earnest voices to solid and prosperous Americans. I was sure that they were selling something: bonds or insurance or automobiles. They were at least agonizingly aware of the easy money in the vicinity and convinced that it was theirs for a few words in the right key.
vi: Around a little past seven in the evening, dressed in a white flannel suit, I stepped across Gatsby's lawn. After wandering around for a while, I felt a bit awkward amidst the moving wave of people around me whom I didn't know, although occasionally here and there I did recognize a few familiar faces of those who often rode the train with me. I am amazed by the number of young English people scattered around. All of them are dressed elegantly, though they seem a bit gluttonous. They speak in a low voice, seriously and formally, with mature and wealthy Americans. I am certain they are selling something, maybe stocks, insurance, or vehicles. They seem to be tormented by the realization of easy money within this campus and are convinced that with just a few well-placed words, those easy earnings will be theirs.
tr: I wore my white linen suits and around a little past seven, I walked towards his garden. After wandering restlessly among the crowds, I also came across a few familiar faces that I occasionally encountered on the suburban train. The large number of English people who seemed to be scattered around did not escape my notice either. They were all well-dressed. There was a hungry expression on their faces. Each of them was talking in a low voice and with a serious demeanor to the big, wealthy Americans. I was almost certain they were trying to sell something. Stocks, insurance policies, or automobiles. They had caught the scent of easy money floating around and believed that if they used the right words, they could earn it.
es: Clad in a brand-new white flannel suit, I stepped onto his lawn a little after seven and wandered uncomfortably among swirls of people I didn't know, though occasionally I spotted a face I had seen on the train. I was impressed by the number of young English people everywhere: all well-dressed, all looking hungry, all speaking softly and very seriously to solid and prosperous Americans. I assumed they were selling something: bonds, insurance, or automobiles. At the very least, they were painfully aware of the easy money circulating around and were convinced it would be theirs in exchange for a few words in just the right tone.

en: As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.
vi: As soon as I arrived, I tried to find the host, but when I asked two or three people where Gatsby was, they just stared at me as if they were very surprised, then said they didn't know where Gatsby was. So I immediately wandered over to the cocktail table, the only place in the garden where a solitary young man could linger without looking aimless or lonely.
tr: As soon as I arrived, I wanted to find the host. When a couple of people I asked about his whereabouts gave me strange looks and fervently explained that they didn't know, I immediately retreated to the table where drinks were being served. This was the only place where a lonely man could wait without looking friendless and aimless.
es: As soon as I arrived, I tried to greet my host, but the two or three people I asked about him looked at me so astonished and denied so vehemently knowing Gatsby's whereabouts that I slipped away towards the cocktail table, the only place in the garden where someone without company could stay for a while and not seem alone and lost.

en: I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
vi: I was thinking of drinking myself into a stupor to ease my awkwardness and embarrassment when I suddenly saw Jordan Baker just stepping out from the house, standing at the top of the marble steps, looking down at the garden with her back slightly arched and an aloof demeanor.
tr: As he was rapidly advancing on the path to being completely drunk, Jordan Baker appeared at the top of the marble stairs, coming out from inside. She slightly pulled back and began to survey the garden with an arrogant demeanor.
es: I had decided out of sheer bewilderment to get scandalously drunk when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stopped at the top of the marble staircase to, leaning back a little, observe the garden with interest and disdain.

en: Welcome or not, I found it necessary to attach myself to someone before I should begin to address cordial remarks to the passersby.
vi: Regardless of whether Jordan would welcome me warmly or not, I felt that I needed to stand with someone before initiating intimate conversations with strangers on my own.
tr: Rather than uttering polite words to passersby, it seemed more reasonable to approach a familiar person, whether I was welcomed at that moment or not.
es: Whether they received me well or badly, I thought it necessary to stick to someone before I started getting affectionate with everyone who passed by.

en: “Hello!” I roared, advancing toward her. My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden.
vi: "Hello, Miss!" I shouted, walking quickly towards Jordan. My voice was unusually loud, echoing across the garden.
tr: "Hello!" I called out as I walked towards him. My voice had come out a bit too loud, echoing through the garden.
es: —Hello! —I roared, advancing towards her. My voice, in the garden, sounded too loud, abnormal.

en: “I thought you might be here,” she responded absently as I came up. “I remembered you lived next door to—”
vi: "I thought you would definitely be here." Jordan said absentmindedly as I walked up. "I remember you live right next door to..."
tr: “I thought you might be here,” he said as I was going upstairs, “I remembered that you were neighbors.”
es: —I had thought that maybe you were here —he replied absentmindedly as I climbed the stairs—. I remembered that you lived in the house next door…

en: She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.
vi: Jordan casually took my hand to signal that she would attend to me in a moment, then leaned in to listen to two girls in identical yellow dresses standing a few steps away.
tr: He shook my hand with a manner devoid of sincerity. It was as if he was promising to attend to me in a minute. Meanwhile, he was trying to listen to what the two girls, dressed in identical yellow dresses, were saying as they waited on the bottom step of the stairs.
es: He took my hand in an impersonal manner, as a promise that he would take care of me in a few seconds, and listened to two girls who were wearing identical yellow dresses and had stopped at the foot of the staircase.

en: “Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”
vi: "Hello, miss. Unfortunately, you did not win." Both girls greeted loudly.
tr: "Hello," said the girls, "we're sorry you didn't win!"
es: —Hello! —they shouted in unison—. It's a shame you didn't win.

en: That was for the golf tournament. She had lost in the finals the week before.
vi: They are talking about the golf tournament. Jordan lost in the final match the week before.
tr: They were talking about the golf tournament held last week. Jordan was eliminated in the finals.
es: They were talking about the golf tournament. Jordan Baker had lost in the finals the previous week.

en: “You don’t know who we are,” said one of the girls in yellow, “but we met you here about a month ago.”
vi: "Perhaps you don't know who we are, but we met you here about a month ago." One of the two girls in yellow said.
tr: "I guess you don't remember us. We met here about a month ago," said one of the people in yellow dresses.
es: —You don't know who we are —said one of the girls in yellow—, but we met you here about a month ago.

en: “You’ve dyed your hair since then,” remarked Jordan, and I started, but the girls had moved casually on and her remark was addressed to the premature moon, produced like the supper, no doubt, out of a caterer’s basket. With Jordan’s slender golden arm resting in mine, we descended the steps and sauntered about the garden. A tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight, and we sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.
vi: "Since that day, it seems the ladies have dyed their hair a different color." Jordan's comment left me astonished, but the two girls nonchalantly continued walking, as if Jordan's remark was meant for the early-rising moon or the dinner being laid out from the food basket by the catering staff. Jordan's slender golden arm rested lightly on mine, and we strolled down the steps, wandering leisurely through the garden. A tray of cocktails floated over to us under the dim lights, and then we sat down at the same table with the two girls in yellow dresses from earlier and three other men, each of whom introduced himself to us as Mr. Mumble.
tr: “You must have dyed your hair, that’s why,” said Jordan. I was startled, but since the girls had already walked away, no one but the prematurely born moon heard what was said. There was no doubt that this fake moon was also the handiwork of the company that prepared the meals. With Jordan’s delicate, golden arm in mine, we descended the stairs and began walking in the garden. After a tray of cocktails passed in front of us in the twilight, we sat at a table with those two girls in yellow dresses and three men. Each of the men introduced himself as Mr. Mumble.
es: —You have dyed your hair —replied Jordan, and I was startled, but the girls had continued on their way carelessly, and the words were heard by the premature moon, which had undoubtedly come out, like dinner, from the supplier's basket. With Jordan's slender, golden arm resting on mine, we descended the staircase and wandered through the garden. A tray of cocktails floated towards us in the twilight, and we sat at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, who all introduced themselves as mister Mmmm.

en: “Do you come to these parties often?” inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.
vi: "Do you often attend these parties?" Jordan asked the girl sitting next to him.
tr: "Do you come to these parties often?" Jordan asked the girl next to him.
es: —Do you come to these parties often? —Jordan asked the girl next to him.

en: “The last one was the one I met you at,” answered the girl, in an alert confident voice. She turned to her companion: “Wasn’t it for you, Lucille?”
vi: "The last time I came was when I met you." The girl replied in a lively voice. Then she turned to her companion, "You too, right Lucille?"
tr: “I last came to the party where I met you” the girl replied, with a voice full of confidence. “Isn't it the same for you, Lucille?” he asked.
es: —The last one was when I met you —replied the girl with a confident, energetic voice. She turned to her friend—.

en: It was for Lucille, too.
vi: Lucille confirmed.
tr: It was the same for Lucille.
es: You too, right, Lucille? That's how it was.

en: “I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it.”
vi: She added. "I like coming here. I never need to know what I will do, so I am always happy. Last time I was here, I tore my shirt on a chair. He asked for my name and address, and within a week, I received a package from Croirer’s shop with a brand new evening gown inside."
tr: “I like coming here,” said Lucille, “I don't care about what I do. That's why I have a good time. Last time I came, my dress got caught on a chair and tore. Then he asked me for my name and address. Within a week, a package from the Courier store arrived at my house with a brand new dress inside.”
es: —I love coming here —said Lucille—. I don't mind doing anything, so I always have a good time. Last time, my dress got torn by a chair, and he asked for my name and address, and before a week had passed, I received a package from Croirier with a new evening gown.

en: “Did you keep it?” asked Jordan.
vi: "Did you take that shirt?" Jordan asked.
tr: “So, did you accept?” asked Jordan
es: —Did you stay with him? —asked Jordan.

en: “Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”
vi: "Of course, I will accept it. I was supposed to wear it tonight, but the chest area is too wide and needs to be adjusted to fit. The blue dress with beads costs two hundred and sixty-five dollars."
tr: “Of course I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but the chest part was too big. It will need to be altered. It's the color of gas flame, adorned with lilac beads. Exactly two hundred sixty-five dollars.”
es: —Of course. I was going to wear it tonight, but it's too loose in the chest and I need to fix it. It's gas blue with lavender decorations. Two hundred sixty-five dollars.

en: “There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”
vi: "There's something unusual about this guy that makes him do such a thing." The girl said eagerly. "It's like he doesn't want any trouble with anyone."
tr: “There must be something strange about someone who does such things,” said the other girl, sincerely, “Apparently, she doesn't want to fall out with anyone.”
es: —A guy who does those things is not normal —said the other girl vehemently—. He doesn't want to have problems with anyone. —Who doesn't want to have problems?

en: “Who doesn’t?” I inquired.
vi: "Who doesn't want to?" I asked cautiously.
tr: "Who doesn't want it?" I asked.
es: —I asked.

en: “Gatsby. Somebody told me—”
vi: "Gatsby. Someone told me..."
tr: “Gatsby. Someone told me that...”
es: —Gatsby. Someone told me...

en: The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.
vi: The two girls and Jordan leaned in close to each other, appearing secretive.
tr: Two girls and Jordan leaned forward and huddled together.
es: The two girls and Jordan brought their heads together confidentially.

en: “Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”
vi: "Someone told me they think you killed a man."
tr: “Someone had told me that he killed someone in his time.”
es: —Someone told me that he once killed a man.

en: A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.
vi: A shiver ran through all of us. Mr. Grumble leaned forward eagerly to listen.
tr: We were all filled with excitement. The three Mr. Mumbles bent down and started listening with curiosity.
es: We all felt a shiver. The three Mister Mmmm also leaned in, eager to listen.

en: “I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille sceptically; “It’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”
vi: "I don't think it's that serious." Lucille refuted skeptically. "He is more like a German spy during the war."
tr: "I don't think he went that far," said Lucille doubtfully, "but it might be true that he engaged in German espionage during the war."
es: —I don't think it will go that far —replied Lucille, skeptical—. It's more likely that he was a spy for the Germans during the war.

en: One of the men nodded in confirmation.
vi: One of the men nodded in confirmation.
tr: One of the men nodded in approval.
es: One of the men confirmed it:

en: “I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany,” he assured us positively.
vi: "I heard it again from someone who knows him well, who grew up with him in Germany." This man asserted confidently.
tr: “I heard from someone who knows Gatsby very well. They tried to convince us by saying their childhood years were spent together in Germany.”
es: —I heard it from a man who knew him well. He had grown up with him in Germany —he assured us categorically.

en: “Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.” As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”
vi: "Oh, no." The first girl said. "It can't be like that, because he was in the U.S. military during the war." Seeing that we were starting to believe what she was saying, the girl leaned forward excitedly and continued. "Occasionally observe him when he thinks no one is watching. I guarantee he has killed someone."
tr: “No way!” said the first woman, “it can't be true because he was supposedly serving in the American army during the war.” When our attention and gazes turned back to him, he leaned in a bit more as if sharing a secret, "Pay attention to him when he thinks no one is watching. I bet he has killed someone."
es: —No —said the first girl—, that's impossible, because he fought in the American army —seeing that she was regaining our belief, she leaned towards us with enthusiasm—. Watch him when he thinks no one is looking. I'm sure he killed a man.

en: She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.
vi: The girl squinted and shivered, Lucille also shivered. All of us turned to look around for Gatsby. This was as if to verify the fanciful rumors that Gatsby had inspired among those who loved to whisper about everything in the world.
tr: He squinted his eyes and shivered, Lucille was also shivering. We all started looking around for Gatsby. For those who find it difficult to find topics to whisper about in this world, Gatsby was an inspiration for such romantic and mysterious rumors.
es: He half-closed his eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned to look where Gatsby was. Proof of the romantic speculations he inspired was that those who had found little to gossip about in this world murmured at his expense.

en: The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gaiety.
vi: The first dinner began, and there would be another one around midnight. Jordan invited me to sit at the table with the group she was with, who were sitting around a round table on the other side of the garden, consisting of three couples and a guy who was Jordan's date. He was an undergraduate student who frequently made bold insinuations, clearly under the impression that sooner or later, more or less, Jordan would offer herself to him. Instead of engaging in lengthy conversations, this group of people all maintained a dignified demeanor, assuming for themselves the role of representing the noble and calm character of the East Egg residents to look after the West Egg residents. They were always cautious, not wanting to participate in the boisterous festivities.
tr: The first meal service had started - there was another one after midnight. Jordan invited me to sit with her group. They had spread out at one of the tables on the other side of the garden. The group consisted of three married couples and Jordan's companion. This latter was a young university student, insistent on making passionate speeches. With every gesture, he made it clear that he believed he would eventually win over Jordan's body. The group preferred to stay together rather than wander around and chose to represent the dignified suburban society as a whole. The East Eggers had graciously approached the West Eggers but were careful not to get caught up in the colorful and lively atmosphere of the place.
es: They had started serving the first dinner (they served another after midnight), and Jordan invited me to join her group at a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan's date, an insistent student who was fond of unpleasant insinuations and had the obvious impression that, sooner or later, Jordan was going to give herself to him to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of scattering, the group had maintained an honorable homogeneity, assuming the representation of the very serious rural nobility: East Egg showed its condescension towards West Egg but did not lower its guard against its spectroscopic joy.

en: “Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half-hour; “this is much too polite for me.”
vi: After about half an hour of wasting time sitting there feeling out of place, Jordan whispered. "Let's go. This place is too solemn, it doesn't suit me."
tr: “Let's get up,” Jordan whispered after a rather boring half hour, “this place is too fancy for me.”
es: —Let's go —murmured Jordan after a rather insipid and wasted half hour—; this is too fancy for me.

en: We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was making me uneasy. The undergraduate nodded in a cynical, melancholy way.
vi: We stood up, and Jordan explained to everyone that we were going to find the host. "I have never met him before." Jordan said, making me a bit embarrassed. The student nodded in a melancholic and gloomy manner.
tr: As we were leaving the table, he explained that we were going to find the host of the invitation. He didn't know him at all and felt uneasy about it. The university student nodded with a mix of irony and sadness.
es: We got up, and he explained to the group that we were going to look for the host; I didn't know him, he said, and that made me feel uncomfortable. The student nodded with a melancholic, cynical gesture.

en: The bar, where we glanced first, was crowded, but Gatsby was not there. She couldn’t find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn’t on the veranda. On a chance we tried an important-looking door, and walked into a high Gothic library, panelled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.
vi: First, we passed by the bar, which was very crowded, but Gatsby was not there. From the top steps, Jordan couldn't find Gatsby, nor did she see him outside on the porch. Then, by chance, we tried opening a door that looked peculiar, and subsequently entered a Gothic-style library, tall, with door frames made of intricately carved English oak, perhaps taken whole from some relic abroad.
tr: The first place we looked was the bar. It was crowded, but Gatsby wasn't there. We didn't find him at the top of the stairs or on the veranda either. We decided to try our luck at the grand door we came across. We found ourselves in a library decorated in Gothic style with English oak furniture adorned with carvings – likely brought from a building in Europe that was damaged during the war.
es: There were many people in the bar, where we looked first, but Gatsby was not there. Jordan did not see him from the top of the staircase, and he was not in the gallery either. We randomly opened a door that seemed important and entered a Gothic library, with high ceilings and walls covered in carved English oak, probably transported whole from some overseas ruin.

en: A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.
vi: A chubby middle-aged man, wearing large owl-shaped glasses, was sitting drunkenly on the edge of the table, staring blankly at the bookshelves. When the two of us walked in, he spun around with a look of interest, his eyes scanning Jordan from head to toe.
tr: A large, middle-aged man with thick glasses and a sturdy build was sitting at the edge of a table, looking at the books on the shelves. He was slightly drunk. When he noticed us entering, he turned around excitedly and scrutinized Jordan from head to toe.
es: A corpulent individual, middle-aged, with enormous glasses and owl-like eyes, somewhat drunk, was sitting on the edge of a large table and, hesitantly, was concentrating on looking at the bookshelves. When we entered, he turned around nervously and examined Jordan from head to toe.

en: “What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.
vi: "What do you two think?" he asked eagerly.
tr: “What are you thinking?” he suddenly asked.
es: —What do you think? —he asked with genuine fervor.

en: “About what?”
vi: "About what?"
tr: “What about?”
es: —What?

en: He waved his hand toward the bookshelves.
vi: He raised his hand and pointed to the bookshelves.
tr: He pointed to the shelves full of books with his hand.
es: He pointed towards the books with his hand.

en: “About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”
vi: "About them. Truth be told, you two don't need to investigate to confirm it. I've already done it. They are all real."
tr: “These,” he said, “although you don't need to say anything. I have examined them. They are all genuine.”
es: —That. And you don't have to bother checking it. I've checked it myself. They are real.

en: “The books?”
vi: "The books?"
tr: “The books?”
es: —The books?

en: He nodded.
vi: He nodded.
tr: He nodded.
es: He nodded.

en: “Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”
vi: "They are completely real books, with pages and everything. I thought they were just beautiful cardboard pieces that last long. In fact, they are entirely real books. With pages and.. Here, let me show you both."
tr: "Completely real: They have pages, writings, everything. I thought they were just durable, decorative cardboard covers, but they aren't. They are all genuine. Wait, let me show you." He was almost certain that we had doubts.
es: —Absolutely true: they have pages and all those things. I thought they would be hollow, sturdy cardboard. But they are absolutely real. Pages and… Look, let me show you.

en: Taking our scepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the Stoddard Lectures.
vi: Convinced that we were still in doubt, he quickly walked to the bookshelf, then returned with the first volume of "Stoddard Lectures."
tr: He moved towards the shelves and returned with the first volume of the Stoddard Lectures book.
es: Taking our skepticism for granted, he rushed to the shelves and returned with the first volume of Stoddard's Lectures[10].

en: “See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”
vi: "See that." He exclaimed joyfully. "It is a real print. It really fooled me. This guy is truly a professional stage manager. So good. It's so meticulous. Just like the real thing. Moreover, it even knows where to stop, without cutting the page. But what more can I ask for? What more can I hope for?
tr: “Do you see!” he shouted triumphantly, “This is a real book. How wrong I was. This man is a true Belasco! This is a great victory. What a delightful, what a beautiful choice! And he didn't even cut and reduce the pages, knowing his place. What more could one ask for?” 1 David Belasco (1853 – 1931) American playwright.
es: —Look! —he exclaimed triumphantly—. It is an authentic piece of printed material. He had managed to deceive me. This guy is a true Belasco[11]. What a triumph! What meticulousness! What realism! And he also knew where to stop: the pages are uncut, unopened. But what did you expect? What did you want?

en: He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.
vi: He snatched the book from my hand and hurriedly placed it back on the shelf, muttering that if one brick was taken out, the entire library could be at risk of collapsing.
tr: He had a massive library. Translator's Note While snatching the book from my hand and putting it back in its place, he was muttering something about how the entire bookshelf would collapse if a single brick were missing.
es: He snatched the book from me and hurriedly returned it to its shelf, muttering that if we removed one brick, the entire library might collapse.

en: “Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”
vi: "Who brought you here?" he asked. "Or did you come on your own? I was brought here by someone." "Most of the people here were brought."
tr: “Who brought you here?” he suddenly asked, “Or did you just come on your own? For example, someone brought me. Most of the people here came that way too.”
es: —Who brought you here? —he asked—. Or did you come on your own? I was brought here. Almost everyone is brought here.

en: Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.
vi: Jordan looked at him with a lively, cheerful expression but did not respond.
tr: Jordan was listening to him with a smile on his face but did not respond.
es: Jordan watched him very attentively, happy, without responding.

en: “I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”
vi: "I was brought here by a lady named Roosevelt." He continued. "Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you two know her? I met her somewhere last night. I've been drunk like this all week, I thought sitting in the study would sober me up."
tr: “Mrs. Roosevelt brought me. Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? We met last night. I've been wandering around drunk for a week and thought maybe if I sat in a library, I might sober up.”
es: —A woman named Roosevelt brought me here —he continued—. Mistress Claud Roosevelt. Don't you know her? I met her last night, I don't know where. I've been drunk for almost a week, and I thought sitting in a library for a while might clear my head.

en: “Has it?”
vi: "Is there?"
tr: “Did you come to your senses?”
es: —Has it worked?

en: “A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re—”
vi: "I think it has improved a little bit. It's not certain yet, I've only been here for an hour. I have told you two about the books, haven't I? They are all real books. They...
tr: “Eh, a little. Still, I'm not quite sure. I mean, not yet. Because I've only been here for an hour. Did I tell you about these books? They are all genuine books. Moreover-”
es: —A little, yes, I think. It's still early to say. I've only been here for an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They are real. They are...

en: “You told us.”
vi: "He has already told us."
tr: “You had mentioned it.”
es: —He has told us.

en: We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.
vi: Jordan and I solemnly shook his hand and then stepped outside.
tr: After shaking hands seriously, we left the place.
es: We shook his hand solemnly and left.

en: There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps. By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing “stunts” all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a baby act in costume, and champagne was served in glasses bigger than finger-bowls. The moon had risen higher, and floating in the Sound was a triangle of silver scales, trembling a little to the stiff, tinny drip of the banjoes on the lawn.
vi: Everyone was dancing on the tarps spread out in the garden, the old men were pushing the young girls in the opposite direction in endless, shameless, awkward spins. The better couples moved into the corners, guiding each other in stylish, proper dances. A large number of single girls danced alone or took over for the band, giving them a short break by playing the banjo or drums. Around midnight, the excitement increased. A The renowned singer raised his high voice to sing a song in Italian, while a famous female singer with a deep voice sang Jazz music. Interspersed between the acts were acrobatic performances all over the garden, while joy and wild laughter continued to echo throughout the summer sky. A pair of twin actors, who turned out to be the two girls in yellow from earlier, performed a children's costume act. Champagne was now being served from wide-mouthed glasses resembling hand-washing bowls. The moon had risen higher. The silver triangular constellation of Libra floated above the water off the coast, gently trembling to the delicate, thin strains of music emanating from the banjos in the garden.
tr: The dancing session on the canvas tarp in the garden had begun. While the elderly gentlemen were pulling and pushing the young girls with rough movements and drawing circles, the harmonious couples were bending and twisting with fashionable moves, trying not to step outside the tarp. Many young women were dancing alone or occasionally taking over the banjos or drums from the orchestra members to let them rest. As the entertainment peaked around midnight, a famous tenor gave a concert in Italian, and a notorious contralto sang jazz pieces. Between the two concerts, cheerful, empty laughter echoed in the night air, and the garden was filled with people eager to showcase their talents. Two girls dressed as twin babies - I later realized they were our friends in yellow dresses - performed their own show. Champagne was being served in bowl-sized glasses. The moon had risen high. The triangular, silver scales floating on the Bosphorus shimmered with the sharp, tinny sound of the banjo playing in the garden.
es: Now they danced on the garden floor: old men who pushed the girls in desolate eternal circles, high-class couples who embraced tortuously, fashionably, never leaving the corners, and many girls who danced alone and occasionally took over for the banjo or the percussionist of the orchestra. At midnight the joy had increased. A famous tenor sang in Italian, a well-known contralto sang jazz, and between numbers people put on their own sensational show anywhere in the garden, while laughter burst out and, empty and happy, rose to the summer sky. Two twin actresses, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, dressed up as little girls for their performance, and champagne was served in glasses larger than fruit bowls. The moon was higher and over the strait floated a triangle of silver scales, which trembled slightly with the dry and metallic tapping of the banjos in the garden.

en: I was still with Jordan Baker. We were sitting at a table with a man of about my age and a rowdy little girl, who gave way upon the slightest provocation to uncontrollable laughter. I was enjoying myself now. I had taken two finger-bowls of champagne, and the scene had changed before my eyes into something significant, elemental, and profound.
vi: At that time, I was still beside Jordan Baker. We were sitting at the same table with a man around my age and a small, noisy girl who would burst into laughter at the slightest thing. Now I finally felt comfortable. I drank two large glasses of champagne, each as big as a bowl, and they made the scenes before my eyes transform into ones that were more meaningful, fundamental, and profoundly deep.
tr: I was with Hala Jordan Baker. We were at the same table with a man around my age and a petite girl with a tough demeanor. The girl was laughing wildly at every opportunity she got. I had started to have a bit of fun. Since I had drunk two glasses of champagne, what I saw seemed meaningful, necessary, and profound.
es: I was still with Jordan Baker. We were at a table with a man roughly my age and a girl who made a lot of noise and at the slightest provocation would burst into uncontrollable laughter. I was amused. I had drunk two champagne cocktails and the scene had transformed before my eyes into something significant, elemental, and profound.

en: At a lull in the entertainment the man looked at me and smiled.
vi: When the fun had died down, the man looked at me and smiled.
tr: At a moment when the fun had stopped, I saw someone smiling at me.
es: In a moment of respite at the party, the man looked at me and smiled.

en: “Your face is familiar,” he said politely. “Weren’t you in the First Division during the war?”
vi: He spoke politely. "You look familiar. Were you in the third division during the war?"
tr: “Your face doesn't look unfamiliar at all,” he said politely, “were you in the first division during the war?”
es: —Your face looks familiar to me —he said, very politely—. Weren't you in the Third Division during the war?

en: “Why yes. I was in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.”
vi: "That's right." "I used to be in the Ninth Rifle Battalion."
tr: “Yes. The twenty-eighth infantry regiment.”
es: —Yes, yes. I was in the Twenty-Eighth Infantry.

en: “I was in the Sixteenth until June nineteen-eighteen. I knew I’d seen you somewhere before.”
vi: "As for me, I was with the seventh infantry division until June 1918. I knew right away where I had met you."
tr: “I was in the sixteenth regiment until June 1918. I was sure I had seen you before.”
es: —I was in the Sixteenth until June of the year '18. I knew I had seen you somewhere.

en: We talked for a moment about some wet, grey little villages in France. Evidently he lived in this vicinity, for he told me that he had just bought a hydroplane, and was going to try it out in the morning.
vi: We chatted for a while, reminiscing about the damp, gray villages in France. Obviously, he is living around here because he told me that he just bought two seaplanes and will take them out for a test flight in the morning.
tr: We talked briefly about France's gray, rainy, and small villages. I had understood that he lived there. Because he had said that he bought a seaplane and would try it out tomorrow morning.
es: We chatted for a while about the damp and gray villages of France. Evidently, he lived in the neighborhood because he told me that he had just bought a hydroplane and was going to test it in the morning.

en: “Want to go with me, old sport? Just near the shore along the Sound.”
vi: "Do you want to go with me, old friend?" "It's right near the beach along the strait."
tr: "Would you like to come with me, buddy? We can take a stroll by the Bosphorus."
es: —Are you coming with me, buddy? Only to the shore, through the strait.

en: “What time?”
vi: "What time is it?"
tr: "What time?""
es: —What time?

en: “Any time that suits you best.”
vi: "Any time that is convenient for you."
tr: "At the time that suits you best.""
es: —Whichever one you prefer.

en: It was on the tip of my tongue to ask his name when Jordan looked around and smiled.
vi: I was about to blurt out and ask his name when Jordan looked around and smiled, asking me.
tr: Just as I was about to ask for his full name, Jordan looked at me and smiled.
es: I was about to ask her name, I had the question on the tip of my tongue, when Jordan looked around and smiled.

en: “Having a gay time now?” she inquired.
vi: "It's more fun now, isn't it?" "Feeling better now."
tr: “I see you are having fun now,” he said.
es: —Are you finally having a good time?

en: “Much better.” I turned again to my new acquaintance. “This is an unusual party for me. I haven’t even seen the host. I live over there—” I waved my hand at the invisible hedge in the distance, “and this man Gatsby sent over his chauffeur with an invitation.”
vi: After replying, I turned to the new acquaintance again. "The party here is a bit strange for me. I haven't met the host yet. I live in the house over there." I gestured towards the barely visible fence in the distance. "Then this guy Gatsby had his driver send me an invitation."
tr: “Quite a lot, actually. ” Then I turned to my new friend. “An extraordinary party for me. I haven't even seen the host yet. Actually, my house is right over there,” I said, pointing to the barely visible fence in the dark. “A man named Gatsby sent an invitation with his chauffeur.”
es: —Much better —I turned again to my new friend—. This party seems very strange to me. I haven't even seen the host. I live over there —I waved my hand towards the hedge, invisible in the distance—, and that Gatsby sent me an invitation with the chauffeur.

en: For a moment he looked at me as if he failed to understand.
vi: The man looked at me for a moment as if he didn't understand what I was saying.
tr: For a moment, he looked at me as if he didn't understand anything, then suddenly said, "I am Gatsby."
es: He looked at me for a moment as if he didn't understand me.

en: “I’m Gatsby,” he said suddenly.
vi: "I am Gatsby." He suddenly said.
tr: For a moment, he looked at me as if he didn't understand anything, then suddenly said, "I am Gatsby."
es: —I am Gatsby —he said suddenly.

en: “What!” I exclaimed. “Oh, I beg your pardon.”
vi: "Really!" I was astonished. "I truly apologize."
tr: “What?” I shouted, “I am very sorry.”
es: —Sorry —I exclaimed—. I beg you to forgive me.

en: “I thought you knew, old sport. I’m afraid I’m not a very good host.”
vi: "I thought you already knew, old friend. Unfortunately, I have not been a good host."
tr: “I thought you knew, buddy. I'm afraid I'm not a very good host.”
es: —I thought you knew, buddy. I think I'm not a good host.

en: He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it, that you may come across four or five times in life. It faced—or seemed to face—the whole eternal world for an instant, and then concentrated on you with an irresistible prejudice in your favour. It understood you just so far as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you would like to believe in yourself, and assured you that it had precisely the impression of you that, at your best, you hoped to convey. Precisely at that point it vanished—and I was looking at an elegant young roughneck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.
vi: Gatsby smiled sympathetically, in fact, it was more than just sympathy. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it, that you may come across four or five times in life. It faced—or seemed to face—the whole external world for an instant, and then concentrated on you with an irresistible prejudice in your favor. It understood you just as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you would like to believe in yourself, and assured you that it had precisely the impression of you that, at your best, you hoped to convey. Precisely at that point, the smile vanished—and I was looking at an elegant young rough-neck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Before he introduced himself, I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.
tr: A sincere smile that indicated understanding played on his lips. In fact, it was more than just an understanding smile. It was one of those rare smiles you might see four or five times in your life. It could comfort the person in front of him forever. For a moment, it gave the feeling of having faced eternity and, among all it saw, choosing you and turning towards you. A smile that understands you as much as you want, believes in you as much as you do, and accepts that you appear to others in your best form! While I was thinking about these, the smile disappeared. A man in his thirties, stylishly dressed, and youthful-looking was standing in front of me. His speech was overly showy, even exaggerated. Before introducing himself, he gave the impression that he chose his words carefully.
es: He looked at me with understanding, much more than with understanding. It was one of those rare smiles capable of calming us for all eternity, which we only encounter four or five times in life. That smile was offered —or seemed to be offered— to the entire and eternal world, only to then focus on you, exclusively on you, with an irresistible predisposition in your favor. He understood you as far as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you wanted to believe in yourself, and guaranteed that the impression he had of you was the one that, in your best moments, you hoped to produce. And then the smile vanished, and I was looking at a young and elegant thug, one or two years over thirty, with a way of speaking so ceremonious and affected that it bordered on the absurd. Even before he introduced himself, I had the feeling that he chose his words carefully.

en: Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a small bow that included each of us in turn.
vi: As soon as Gatsby confirmed his identity, the butler hurried to his side, informing him that there was a phone call from Chicago. Gatsby excused himself with a slight nod to each of us.
tr: While Mr. Gatsby was introducing himself, his butler hurriedly came up to him and said that he was being called from Chicago. As he left us, greeting each of us with a slight nod, he instructed, "If you need anything, let me know, buddy," and added, "I apologize, I will join you again shortly."
es: Almost at the same moment that Gatsby identified himself, the butler came running up to tell him that he had a call from Chicago. He excused himself with a slight bow to each of us.

en: “If you want anything just ask for it, old sport,” he urged me. “Excuse me. I will rejoin you later.”
vi: "If you need anything, just call someone to get it, old sport," Gatsby encouraged me. "Sorry, I'll be right back." After Gatsby had left, I immediately turned to Jordan, restraining myself from speaking about my surprise.
tr: As he left us, greeting each of us with a slight nod, he instructed, "If you need anything, let me know, buddy," and added, "I apologize, I will join you again shortly."
es: —If you need anything, just ask, buddy —he told me—. Excuse me. I'll see you later.

en: When he was gone I turned immediately to Jordan—constrained to assure her of my surprise. I had expected that Mr. Gatsby would be a florid and corpulent person in his middle years.
vi: After Gatsby had left, I immediately turned to Jordan, restraining myself from speaking about my surprise. I had thought Gatsby was a rosy, stout man in his middle age.
tr: As soon as he left, I immediately turned to Jordan. I thought I needed to explain how astonished I was. For some reason, I had thought Mr. Gatsby was a middle-aged, red-faced, stout man.
es: As soon as he left, I turned to Jordan because I needed to share my surprise with her. I expected Mr. Gatsby to be a middle-aged man, fat and ruddy.

en: “Who is he?” I demanded. “Do you know?”
vi: "Who is he?" "Do you know?" I asked.
tr: "Who is this man?" "Do you know him?" I asked.
es: —Who is it? —I asked—. Do you know?

en: “He’s just a man named Gatsby.”
vi: "He is just a man named Gatsby."
tr: “That's someone called Gatsby.”
es: —It's just someone named Gatsby.

en: “Where is he from, I mean? And what does he do?”
vi: "I asked him where he was from? What did he do?"
tr: “Where is he from? And what does he do?”
es: —Yes, but where is he from? What does he do?

en: “Now you’re started on the subject,” she answered with a wan smile. “Well, he told me once he was an Oxford man.”
vi: "Now it's you who starts the conversation first." Jordan replied with a weary smile. "Once he told me he had studied at Oxford."
tr: "Now, I see that you have also gotten carried away," he said with a faint smile, "once he told me that he studied at Oxford."
es: —You have also gotten into the matter —he replied with a faint smile—. Well, one day he told me that he had studied at Oxford.

en: A dim background started to take shape behind him, but at her next remark it faded away.
vi: A vague and unclear past was beginning to take a clear shape behind Gatsby, but Jordan's next words made it fade away again.
tr: As things started to take shape in the background, the next sentence erased them all.
es: A blurry past was taking shape behind Gatsby, but it dissolved with Jordan's next sentence:

en: “However, I don’t believe it.”
vi: "However, I do not believe."
tr: "But I didn't quite believe it."
es: —But I don't believe it.

en: “Why not?”
vi: "Why?" "I don't know."
tr: “Why?”
es: —Why not?

en: “I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”
vi: Jordan asserted. "But I don't think he ever studied there."
tr: “I don't know,” he said with a determined voice, “I just don't believe what you read there.”
es: —I don't know —he insisted—. But I don't believe he went to Oxford.

en: Something in her tone reminded me of the other girl’s “I think he killed a man,” and had the effect of stimulating my curiosity. I would have accepted without question the information that Gatsby sprang from the swamps of Louisiana or from the lower East Side of New York. That was comprehensible. But young men didn’t—at least in my provincial inexperience I believed they didn’t—drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island Sound.
vi: There was something in Jordan's voice that made me think of the girl's earlier statement, "I think he killed someone," and it piqued my curiosity. Perhaps I would have accepted without a doubt if I had heard someone say Gatsby came from the swamps of Louisiana or the working-class East Side of New York. That would have been more understandable. The idea of young men drifting in from who knows where to buy a castle on the Long Island Sound seemed impossible, at least according to my provincial and inexperienced perspective; I didn't think they would do such a thing.
tr: When she said this, something in her tone reminded me of the other girl saying 'he had killed someone.' This, however, had completely piqued my curiosity. Without thinking, I could have said that Gatsby had emerged from the swamps of Louisiana or the suburbs east of New York. But an obscure young man could not suddenly appear and buy a mansion in a place like Long Island Sound. At least for someone like me, an inexperienced provincial who doesn't know people very well, it was hard to believe this.
es: Something in her tone reminded me of the other girl, "I think he killed a man," and it had the effect of piquing my curiosity. I would have easily accepted the information that Gatsby had emerged from the swamps of Louisiana or the East Side of New York. That was understandable. But —as far as my provincial experience allowed me to suppose— a young man does not calmly come out of nowhere and buy a palace in Long Island.

en: “Anyhow, he gives large parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with an urban distaste for the concrete. “And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”
vi: "Anyway, he often throws big parties." Jordan said, changing the subject with a city dweller's distaste for specifics. "I like big parties. At those, you can be discreet and no one pays attention. But at small parties, you don't get any privacy."
tr: “Anyway, someone who throws such big parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with the nonchalance of those civilized people who dislike concreteness, “I also love those big parties. I find them very sincere. You can't be comfortable at small gatherings; everyone's eyes are on you.”
es: —The thing is, he throws very crowded parties —said Jordan, changing the subject with a polite annoyance at the specifics—. And I like parties with lots of people. They are very intimate. At parties with few people, intimacy is nonexistent.

en: There was the boom of a bass drum, and the voice of the orchestra leader rang out suddenly above the echolalia of the garden.
vi: A drum roll thundered, and the voice of the orchestra conductor suddenly echoed throughout the garden.
tr: The noise of five drums being played at once was suddenly heard. The voice of the orchestra conductor rang out, surpassing the conversations in the garden.
es: The drum boomed, and the voice of the orchestra conductor suddenly rose among the echolalia of the garden.

en: “Ladies and gentlemen,” he cried. “At the request of Mr. Gatsby we are going to play for you Mr. Vladmir Tostoff’s latest work, which attracted so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May. If you read the papers you know there was a big sensation.” He smiled with jovial condescension, and added: “Some sensation!” Whereupon everybody laughed.
vi: "Ladies and gentlemen." He shouted. "At the request of Mr. Gatsby, we will be performing the latest work of Vladimir Tostoff, a piece that has garnered much attention at Carnegie Hall this past May." "If you have read the newspapers, you must know it was a major sensation." He smiled politely and cheerfully, adding, "a real sensation." Everyone burst out laughing.
tr: “Ladies and gentlemen,” he shouted. “At the request of Mr. Gatsby, we will play for you the latest work of Mr. Vladimir Tostoff, which received great acclaim at Carnegie Hall in May. You must have read about the excitement it caused in the newspapers.” Looking down on all of us a bit, he added, “what enthusiasm it was, my God!” and everyone laughed.
es: —Ladies and gentlemen —he shouted—. At the request of Mr. Gatsby, we are going to play for all of you the latest work of Mr. Vladimir Tostoff, which garnered so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May.
