If you read the newspapers, you will know that it caused a real sensation —he smiled with jovial condescendence, and added—. What a sensation! —and everyone burst into laughter.

en: “The piece is known,” he concluded lustily, “as ‘Vladmir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World!’ ”
vi: "And that piece of music is called." He concluded with a strong, loud exclamation. "The History of the World in Jazz, by Vladimir Tostoff."
tr: “The work is called 'Vladmir Tostoff's World Jazz History,'” he concluded with a passionate voice.
es: —The piece —he concluded energetically— is titled The History of the World in Jazz, according to Vladimir Tostoff.

en: The nature of Mr. Tostoff’s composition eluded me, because just as it began my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.
vi: I had not yet had the chance to savor the essence of the music that Tostoff had composed because my eyes suddenly caught sight of Gatsby standing alone on the marble steps, looking from one group of people to another with a satisfied gaze. His sun-tanned skin was alluringly taut on his face, and his short-cropped hair looked as if it were meticulously trimmed every day. I did not see anything sinister in Gatsby. I wondered if Gatsby's abstinence from alcohol made him stand out among the guests. It seemed to me that the more lively the party became, the more composed and dignified Gatsby appeared. When the piece "The History of the World in Jazz" ended, the girls rested their heads affectionately on the shoulders of the boys like little puppies. The girls pretended to faint, falling backward into the arms of the boys or even into the crowd, knowing in their hearts that someone would catch them.
tr: Since my eyes were fixed on Gatsby, I couldn't really focus on Mr. Tostoff's composition. He was standing on the marble stairs, looking appreciatively from one group to another. His tanned skin made his well-defined facial features even more prominent. It was obvious that his short hair was styled every day. There was nothing intimidating about him at all. I couldn't help but think that the only thing that set him apart from his guests was that he didn't drink. Because as the commotion around increased, Gatsby seemed even more composed. When the 'World Jazz History' concert ended, some of the girls snuggled up to the men like kittens and joyfully rested their heads on their shoulders, while others pretended to faint, hoping someone would catch them. But no one threw themselves into Gatsby's arms, no French curls touched his shoulder, and he was not found in the groups singing songs in unison.
es: The nature of mister Tostoff's composition escaped me because, just as it was starting, I saw Gatsby, who, alone, was looking approvingly at the various groups from the marble staircase. His face was tanned, his skin smooth, attractive, and it seemed that his hair, very short, was groomed every day. I found nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he didn't drink helped him stand out from his guests, as it seemed to me that he became more and more proper as the fraternal joy increased. When The History of the World in Jazz ended, the girls rested their heads on the men's shoulders like teenagers, the girls fell backward, fainting, jokingly, into the men's arms, or among the group, knowing that someone would catch their fall. But no one let themselves fall into Gatsby's arms, and no bobbed haircut touched Gatsby's shoulder and no quartet included him among their singers.

en: “I beg your pardon.”
vi: Yet no one leaned into Gatsby, no short French bobbed hair rested on Gatsby's shoulder, and no quartet used Gatsby's head as a gathering point.
tr: "Excuse me"
es: —Excuse me.

en: Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us.
vi: Gatsby's butler suddenly appeared beside us and spoke up.
tr: Gatsby's servant had suddenly appeared beside us.
es: Gatsby's butler was suddenly at our side.

en: “Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.”
vi: "Are you Miss Baker? I'm sorry, Mr. Gatsby would like to have a private conversation with you."
tr: "Are you Mrs. Baker?" he asked, "I'm sorry to bother you, but Mr. Gatsby wants to see you alone."
es: —Miss Baker? —he asked—. Sorry to bother you, but Mister Gatsby would like to speak with you alone.

en: “With me?” she exclaimed in surprise.
vi: "For me?" Jordan was surprised.
tr: “With me?” said the girl in astonishment.
es: —With me? —exclaimed Jordan, surprised.

en: “Yes, madame.”
vi: "Yes, ma'am, that's correct."
tr: “Yes madam.”
es: —Yes, madame.

en: She got up slowly, raising her eyebrows at me in astonishment, and followed the butler toward the house. I noticed that she wore her evening-dress, all her dresses, like sports clothes—there was a jauntiness about her movements as if she had first learned to walk upon golf courses on clean, crisp mornings.
vi: Jordan slowly stood up, raised an eyebrow at me in surprise, and then followed the butler into the house. I noticed that Jordan was wearing an evening gown. It seemed that all of Jordan's dresses had some similarities to sportswear; they all revealed a certain pride in her gait, as if the first time Jordan learned to walk was on a golf course on a fresh and clear morning.
tr: Jordan slowly stood up, raised his eyebrows in surprise, and looked at me, then walked after the butler. As he left, I noticed that he carried his evening dress as if it were sportswear. His walk and demeanor were as relaxed as if he were strolling on a golf course in the cool, fresh morning air.
es: He got up slowly, looked at me, and raised his eyebrows in astonishment, then followed the butler towards the house. I noticed that he was wearing evening attire, and all his clothes, as if they were sportswear. His movements had a special grace: it seemed as if he had learned to walk on the fresh and clear mornings of the golf courses.

en: I was alone and it was almost two. For some time confused and intriguing sounds had issued from a long, many-windowed room which overhung the terrace. Eluding Jordan’s undergraduate, who was now engaged in an obstetrical conversation with two chorus girls, and who implored me to join him, I went inside.
vi: I sat alone; it was around two in the morning. At some point, there were faint noises, almost evoking curiosity, coming from the long room with many windows overlooking the steps. The Jordanian student was chatting about obstetrics with two female singers from the choir, urging me to join him. I declined, avoiding them and going inside the house.
tr: I was left alone. It was two in the morning. For a while, I listened to the incomprehensible but interesting sounds coming from the long room with many windows overlooking the terrace. Jordan’s university student, who was discussing obstetric topics with two dancer girls, invited me to join them. But I escaped and went inside.
es: He was alone and it was almost two o'clock. Confusing and enigmatic noises had been coming for a while from a room with many windows that opened onto the terrace. Eluding Jordan's student, who was at that moment engrossed in a conversation about obstetrics with two chorus girls and was begging for my company, I entered the house.

en: The large room was full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her stood a tall, red-haired young lady from a famous chorus, engaged in song. She had drunk a quantity of champagne, and during the course of her song she had decided, ineptly, that everything was very, very sad—she was not only singing, she was weeping too. Whenever there was a pause in the song she filled it with gasping, broken sobs, and then took up the lyric again in a quavering soprano. The tears coursed down her cheeks—not freely, however, for when they came into contact with her heavily beaded eyelashes they assumed an inky colour, and pursued the rest of their way in slow black rivulets. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.
vi: The large room was packed with people. One of the two girls in yellow was playing the piano, while a young woman from a famous choir band, tall with red hair, stood beside her singing. She had drunk too much champagne, so halfway through the song, she irrationally decided that everything had to become very sad. As a result, she not only sang but also cried. Whenever there was a pause in the song, she filled it with gasping breaths, sobbing, and then continued singing in a high, trembling voice. Tears rolled down her cheeks but did not fall freely; when they reached her heavily mascaraed eyelashes, they turned into ink, then slowly continued down as black streaks. Someone jokingly suggested she sing the notes written on her face, at which point she raised her hands to the sky, collapsed onto a chair, and fell asleep in a drunken stupor.
tr: The spacious hall was filled with people. One of the two girls in yellow dresses was playing the piano, while the tall, red-haired young woman next to her was singing. She had drunk a lot of champagne and, in the middle of the song she was singing, perhaps because she decided that everything was making her very sad, she was crying inappropriately, filling the piece with sobs and hiccups, then continuing to sing from where she left off with her soprano voice trembling. Tears were forming lines on her cheeks, taking on the color of ink on her bead-filled eyelashes before flowing away, then continuing their path as thin black streams. When someone mischievously suggested that she sing by looking at the notes forming on her face, she raised her arms and let herself fall into the nearest chair. She passed out right there. She had fallen into a deep sleep.
es: The living room was full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her, standing, a young red-haired lady, a member of a famous revue company, was singing a song. She had drunk a considerable amount of champagne and, quite unprofessionally, during the course of the song decided that everything was very sad, very sad: not only was she singing, she was also crying. She introduced sobs and broken hiccups into each pause of the song, before returning to the lyrics with a trembling soprano voice. Tears ran down her cheeks; not with complete freedom, however, because when they came into contact with her heavily painted eyelashes, they took on an inky color and continued their path in slow black streams. Someone humorously suggested that she sing the notes written on her face, at which point she raised her hands, collapsed into an armchair, and sank into the deep sleep of wine.

en: “She had a fight with a man who says he’s her husband,” explained a girl at my elbow.
vi: "She just had a quarrel with a man claiming to be her husband." The girl standing close to my elbow explained.
tr: Another girl appeared beside me. “Just now, she had an argument with someone who said he was her husband,” she informed me.
es: —She fought with a man who claims to be her husband —explained a girl next to me.

en: I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.
vi: I looked around. Most of the remaining women were quarreling with the men who claimed to be their husbands. Even the group that came with Jordan, four people from East Egg, were also divided due to disagreements. One of those men was talking unusually attentively to a young actress, while his wife, despite trying to smile with dignity and indifference, could no longer hold back and tried to attack from the side. From time to time, she would suddenly appear beside her husband like a sparkling diamond, hissing into his ear, "You promised me."
tr: I looked around. Most of the women there were arguing with men who claimed to be their husbands. Even in Jordan's group – that East Egg foursome – a quarrel had broken out. One of the men had engaged in a heated conversation with a young actress, and after his wife initially ignored the situation with a proud smile, she had launched an attack. She slithered up to the man like an angry snake, hissing incessantly, "You promised!"
es: I looked around. Most of the women who remained were fighting with men who claimed to be their husbands. Even Jordan's group, the East Egg quartet, had broken up, divided by dissension. One of the men was talking with unusual intensity to a very young actress, and his wife, after trying to laugh off the situation with dignity and indifference, completely lost control and resorted to flanking attacks. She would suddenly appear again and again like an angry diamond and whisper in her husband's ear: "You promised me!"

en: The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.
vi: Reluctance to go home is not limited to stubborn men. In the hall at this moment, there were two men who were not drunk and their two wives who were full of indignation. The two wives loudly lamented their misfortune harm each other.
tr: The reluctance to go home was not exclusive to drunk men. The salon was suddenly occupied by two pitifully sober men and their angry wives. The women were busy commiserating with each other at the top of their voices.
es: The resistance to going home was not exclusive to the disobedient men. The lobby was now occupied by two lamentably sober men and their absolutely indignant wives. The women had hit it off and were speaking slightly louder.

en: “Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”
vi: "Whenever he sees me having fun, he wants to take me away."
tr: “Whenever he sees me having fun, he wants to go home.”
es: —Whenever she sees that I'm having a good time, she wants to go home.

en: “Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”
vi: "In my life, I have never heard of someone as selfish as that"
tr: “I have never heard something so selfish in my life.”
es: —I have never met anyone so selfish.

en: “We’re always the first ones to leave.”
vi: "We always have to be the ones to leave the earliest."
tr: “We are the first to leave every party.”
es: —We always leave first.

en: “So are we.”
vi: "Us too"
tr: “So are we.”
es: —And us.

en: “Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”
vi: "Oh dear, tonight we are almost the last ones here." A husband said sheepishly. "The orchestra left half an hour ago too."
tr: “Fortunately, we are the last ones leaving tonight,” said one of the men shyly, “the orchestra left half an hour ago.”
es: —Well, tonight we are almost the last ones —one of the men said timidly—. The orchestra left half an hour ago.

en: In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.
vi: Although both wives agreed that such a heinous act was truly unbelievable, the quarrel ended with a brief scuffle, both wives were lifted up, their legs kicking wildly, and then carried off into the darkness.
tr: Despite agreeing that such evil could not be endured, the women's argument ended with a brief scuffle. As their husbands lifted them off the ground, they were kicking into the darkness of the night.
es: Despite the women agreeing that such malevolence was inconceivable, the discussion ended in a brief scuffle, and the two women were lifted off their feet and, kicking, disappeared into the night.

en: As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her, but the eagerness in his manner tightened abruptly into formality as several people approached him to say goodbye.
vi: While I was standing in the hall waiting to get my hat, the door to the study opened, and Jordan and Gatsby stepped out together. Gatsby said a few final words to Jordan, but his enthusiastic demeanor suddenly shifted to a more formal tone as several people approached to say their goodbyes.
tr: While I was waiting for the child to bring my hat in the living room, the library door opened. Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. As Gatsby was saying the last few things to the girl, their intimate demeanor suddenly turned formal when people came over to bid farewell.
es: While I was waiting in the lobby to be given my hat, the library door opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying a final sentence, but the anxiety he showed quickly turned into the strictest formality when several people approached him to say goodbye.

en: Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.
vi: Jordan's group called her eagerly from the porch, but she still lingered to shake hands.
tr: While Jordan's group was impatiently calling him at the entrance, he shook our hands a bit slowly and whispered in my ear, "I learned something incredible," and then asked, "How long has it been since we came in?"
es: Jordan's group was calling her impatiently from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake my hand.

en: “I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”
vi: "I just heard something incredibly surprising." Jordan whispered. "How long have we been in there?"
tr: While Jordan's group was impatiently calling him at the entrance, he shook our hands a bit slowly and whispered in my ear, "I learned something incredible," and then asked, "How long has it been since we came in?"
es: —I just found out something amazing, the most amazing thing I've ever heard —he murmured—. How long have we been in there?

en: “Why, about an hour.”
vi: "What?" "About an hour."
tr: “About an hour.”
es: —One hour, more or less.

en: “It was… simply amazing,” she repeated abstractedly. “But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully in my face. “Please come and see me… Phone book… Under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard… My aunt…” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.
vi: "This is truly astonishing." Jordan repeated absentmindedly. "But I swear I won't tell anyone to tease you." Jordan yawned gracefully right in my face. "When you have time, come visit me... The phone directory... Under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard... my aunt..." Jordan said as she hurried out the door. Her rosy brown hand waved a quick goodbye and then blended into the group of people she was with at the door.
tr: “Really unbelievable,” he repeated absentmindedly, “but I swore I wouldn’t tell. I’ve just gotten your hopes up for nothing.” She yawned gently in my face, "Please call me...phone directory...registered under my aunt's name. Mrs. Sigourney Howard" While talking, he was also walking quickly. As he mingled with his friends waiting at the door, he gave a grand salute with his tanned hand.
es: —It has been… simply amazing —she repeated, distracted—. But I have sworn not to tell anyone, and here I am, tempting you with what I cannot give you —she yawned in my face very elegantly—. Come see me, please… Phone book… The number of mistress Sigourney Howard… My aunt… —she was leaving quickly as she spoke, and her tanned hand gave me a cheerful wave as she melted into the group at the door.

en: Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.
vi: Feeling a bit embarrassed for staying too late on my first attendance, I joined the last guests of Gatsby standing around him. I wanted to let Gatsby know that I had been looking for him earlier in the evening to apologize for not recognizing him in the garden.
tr: I was embarrassed for staying so long at a house I had come to for the first time. I joined the last guests gathered around Gatsby. I wanted to say that I couldn't find him when I came to the party and apologize for not recognizing him when I was in the garden.
es: A little embarrassed for having stayed so late on my first visit, I joined Gatsby's last guests, who were gathering around him. I wanted to explain that I had been looking for him at the beginning of the party and apologize for not having recognized him in the garden.

en: “Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.” The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And don’t forget we’re going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning, at nine o’clock.”
vi: "There's nothing to worry about." Gatsby eagerly responded. "Don't think about it anymore, old sport." Gatsby's friendly face was as reassuring as his hand on my shoulder. "And don't forget we have an appointment to fly the seaplane together at nine o'clock tomorrow morning."
tr: “It doesn't matter at all,” he said immediately, “don't bother your head with these things, buddy,” both his words and the hand patting my shoulder felt more like a routine gesture of politeness than genuine sincerity to me. “Don't forget the tour at nine in the morning.”
es: —Don't worry —he ordered me categorically—. Don't overthink it, buddy —there was no more familiarity in that familiar expression than in the comforting hand he placed on my shoulder—. And don't forget that tomorrow morning we test the hydroplane at nine.

en: Then the butler, behind his shoulder:
vi: At that moment, the butler came up behind him: "Sir, there's a phone call from Philadelphia."
tr: At that moment, the servant came and said, "They are calling from Philadelphia, sir."
es: And the butler, behind him:

en: “Philadelphia wants you on the phone, sir.”
vi: At that moment, the butler came up behind him: "Sir, there's a phone call from Philadelphia."
tr: At that moment, the servant came and said, "They are calling from Philadelphia, sir."
es: —They are calling you from Philadelphia, sir.

en: “All right, in a minute. Tell them I’ll be right there… Good night.”
vi: "Alright, wait a moment. Tell them I will listen right away.... Good night"
tr: “Okay. One minute. I'll be right back… Good night”
es: —Yes, right away. Say that I'll be right there... Good night.

en: “Good night.”
vi: "Good night."
tr: “Good night.”
es: —Good evening.

en: “Good night.” He smiled—and suddenly there seemed to be a pleasant significance in having been among the last to go, as if he had desired it all the time. “Good night, old sport… Good night.”
vi: "Good night," Gatsby smiled. Suddenly I felt as if being one of the last people to leave was something special, as if it was what Gatsby had been longing for all evening. "Good night, old sport... Good night."
tr: “Good night,” he said with a smile. Suddenly, I thought that being one of the last to leave from there was important to him and that he had wanted it, “Good night, buddy... good night.”
es: —Good evening. —Good night —he smiled, and suddenly it seemed that being among the last to leave had a heartfelt significance, as if that was what Gatsby had wished for from the beginning—. Good night, buddy… Good night.

en: But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over. Fifty feet from the door a dozen headlights illuminated a bizarre and tumultuous scene. In the ditch beside the road, right side up, but violently shorn of one wheel, rested a new coupé which had left Gatsby’s drive not two minutes before. The sharp jut of a wall accounted for the detachment of the wheel, which was now getting considerable attention from half a dozen curious chauffeurs. However, as they had left their cars blocking the road, a harsh, discordant din from those in the rear had been audible for some time, and added to the already violent confusion of the scene.
vi: However, when I stepped down the stairs, I saw that the evening seemed not to be completely over yet. About fifty meters away from the door, there were about a dozen car lights illuminating a bizarre and noisy scene. A brand new two-seater car that had just left Gatsby's house less than two minutes ago was now stuck in a ditch by the roadside, with its right side lifted up, revealing a wheel that had been completely severed. The sudden protrusion of the wall was the cause of the broken wheel. This incident had piqued the curiosity of about half a dozen drivers, who stopped their cars and got out to look, blocking the entire road. The coarse shouting and the blaring horns from the cars stuck behind had been going on for quite a while, adding to the chaos of the scene.
tr: As I was coming down the stairs, I realized the party was not over yet. A few meters away from the door, a dozen car headlights were illuminating a chaotic and strange scene. A brand new sports car, with one of its wheels broken after falling into the ditch beside the road, was lying on its side. It was one of the guests who had left Gatsby's house two minutes earlier. The wheel had come off due to a sharp protrusion on the wall, and about half a dozen curious drivers had gathered to carefully examine the situation. Since they had all left their cars in the middle of the road, the discordant, high-pitched sounds of the horns from those stuck in between were grating on the ears, further adding to the chaos.
es: But as I was going down the stairs, I saw that the party hadn't ended yet. About fifteen meters from the door, the headlights of the cars illuminated a strange and tumultuous scene. On the road, in the ditch, without having overturned but having lost a wheel due to the violence of the impact, lay a new coupe that had left the driveway of Gatsby's house less than two minutes before. A pronounced protrusion on the wall explained the loss of the wheel, which now attracted the full attention of a group of curious chauffeurs. But, as they had blocked the road with their cars, the loud and dissonant protest of those coming behind had been heard for a while, and that increased the violent confusion of the scene.

en: A man in a long duster had dismounted from the wreck and now stood in the middle of the road, looking from the car to the tyre and from the tyre to the observers in a pleasant, puzzled way.
vi: A man in a long coat stepped out of the wrecked car and stood right in the middle of the road. He looked humorously and confusedly from the car to the wheel and then from the wheel to the people standing and watching.
tr: From the wreckage, a man wearing a long duster coat emerged and stood in the middle of the road. His eyes, looking pleased but bewildered, shifted from the car to the wheel and then to the onlookers.
es: A man with a very long coat had gotten out of the wrecked car and, in the middle of the road, his eyes went from the car to the wheel and from the wheel to the spectators, friendly and perplexed at the same time.

en: “See!” he explained. “It went in the ditch.”
vi: He explained. "See that. It has fallen into the ditch."
tr: "You see," he was explaining, "it entered the channel." It was obvious that she was very surprised.
es: —Look, it has gone into the ditch.

en: The fact was infinitely astonishing to him, and I recognized first the unusual quality of wonder, and then the man—it was the late patron of Gatsby’s library.
vi: It seemed like the event had caused him immense astonishment. At first, I noticed this unusual surprise, and then I recognized him as the guest who had been in Gatsby's library earlier.
tr: First, I noticed this extreme reaction of surprise, and then I realized that I knew the man. He was a late-night regular of Gatsby's library.
es: The fact genuinely astonished him, and I first recognized that unusual sense of wonder, and then the individual: it was the user of Gatsby's library.

en: “How’d it happen?”
vi: "Why is it like that?" "I don't know anything about machinery."
tr: “How did this happen?”
es: —How has it been?

en: He shrugged his shoulders.
vi: He shrugged and said firmly.
tr: He shrugged his shoulders.
es: He shrugged.

en: “I know nothing whatever about mechanics,” he said decisively.
vi: He shrugged and said firmly.
tr: "I don't understand machines at all," he said curtly.
es: —I have no idea about mechanics —he said emphatically.

en: “But how did it happen? Did you run into the wall?”
vi: "But why did it end up like this? Did you run into a wall?"
tr: “So, how did the accident happen? Did you crash into the wall?”
es: —But how did it happen? Did he crash into the wall?

en: “Don’t ask me,” said Owl Eyes, washing his hands of the whole matter. “I know very little about driving—next to nothing. It happened, and that’s all I know.”
vi: "Don't ask me." The sharp-eyed man said, brushing off everything. "I don't really know how to drive, almost not at all. I just know that it was broken, that's all."
tr: "Don't ask me," said the Owl-eyed man, trying to extricate himself from the situation, "I don't really know how to drive, in fact, I don't know at all. It was just an accident. That's all I know."
es: —Don't ask me —said Owl Eyes, washing his hands of the accident—. I don't have much idea about driving, almost none. It happened, and that's all I know.

en: “Well, if you’re a poor driver you oughtn’t to try driving at night.”
vi: "If you are a bad driver, then you shouldn't try to drive at night."
tr: “If you are a bad driver, do not try driving at night.”
es: —Well, if they don't drive well, they shouldn't drive at night.

en: “But I wasn’t even trying,” he explained indignantly, “I wasn’t even trying.”
vi: "But I wasn't trying to drive." He explained indignantly, "I wasn't trying."
tr: “I was using it,” he said a bit hurt, “I wasn't the one using it.”
es: —But I don't know how to drive —he responded, indignant—. I have never driven in my life.

en: An awed hush fell upon the bystanders.
vi: A terrifying silence enveloped those standing around.
tr: A deep silence had settled over those around,
es: A reverential silence enveloped the onlookers.

en: “Do you want to commit suicide?”
vi: "You are very lucky, it's just a tire.
tr: “Do you want to lose your life?”
es: —Do you want to commit suicide?

en: “You’re lucky it was just a wheel! A bad driver and not even trying!”
vi: "You are very lucky, it's just a tire. Being a bad driver and not even thinking about trying."
tr: "You're lucky that only the wheel came off! Not only was he a bad driver, but he also wasn't using it"
es: —You're lucky it was only a wheel! You don't know how to drive! You had never even driven a car in your life!

en: “You don’t understand,” explained the criminal. “I wasn’t driving. There’s another man in the car.”
vi: "You don't understand." The criminal explained. "I wasn't the one driving. There was someone else in the car."
tr: “You don't understand,” he said guiltily, “I wasn't the one driving the car. There's someone else inside.”
es: —They don't understand me —explained the criminal—. I wasn't driving. There is another man in the car.

en: The shock that followed this declaration found voice in a sustained “Ah-h-h!” as the door of the coupé swung slowly open. The crowd—it was now a crowd—stepped back involuntarily, and when the door had opened wide there was a ghostly pause. Then, very gradually, part by part, a pale, dangling individual stepped out of the wreck, pawing tentatively at the ground with a large uncertain dancing shoe.
vi: The prolonged cries of "Aaaa..." expressed everyone's astonishment after hearing this explanation. Then the door of the two-seater car slowly opened. The crowd, now indeed a crowd, instinctively stepped back. Once the car door was fully open, it paused for a moment, looking eerie. Bit by bit, a person with a pale face slowly emerged from the car, staggering out, their large shoes hesitantly feeling the ground.
tr: The astonishment caused by this confession came to life with exclamations of "Aaa!" as the door of the sports car slowly opened. The crowd - we were completely surrounded - reluctantly pulled back. There was a strange stillness when the door opened. A pale-faced, frail man, holding a large dance shoe in his hand, emerged from the wreckage almost piece by piece, clinging to anything he could.
es: The impression caused by this statement was heard in an endless "Ahhh" as the car door opened very slowly. The crowd—it was already a crowd—instinctively stepped back, and when the door finished opening, an eerie silence ensued. Then, very slowly, bit by bit, a pale and staggering individual emerged from the wrecked car, tentatively feeling the ground with an enormous dancing shoe.

en: Blinded by the glare of the headlights and confused by the incessant groaning of the horns, the apparition stood swaying for a moment before he perceived the man in the duster.
vi: Dazzled by the car headlights and confused by the incessant blaring of car horns, the newly appeared figure staggered for a moment before recognizing the man in the long coat.
tr: The ghostly figure, dazzled by the headlights and bewildered by the incessant honking of horns, swayed in place for a while before noticing the man with the long gaiters.
es: Blinded by the glare of the headlights and confused by the incessant wailing of the horns, the apparition staggered for a few seconds before noticing the man in the lab coat.

en: “Wha’s matter?” he inquired calmly. “Did we run outa gas?”
vi: "What's the matter? Are we out of gas?" he asked calmly.
tr: “What happened,” he asked calmly, “did we run out of gas?”
es: —What's wrong? —he asked very calmly—. Have we run out of gas?

en: “Look!”
vi: "Look!"
tr: "Take a look over there if you want"
es: —Look!

en: Half a dozen fingers pointed at the amputated wheel—he stared at it for a moment, and then looked upward as though he suspected that it had dropped from the sky.
vi: About half a dozen fingers pointed at the wheel that had been severed. He stared at it for a moment, then looked up as if suspecting it had fallen from the sky.
tr: Half a dozen index fingers were pointing at the broken wheel. After looking for a while, the man must have thought it fell from above, so he lifted his head and looked at the sky.
es: Half a dozen fingers pointed towards the amputated wheel. He stared at it for a moment and then looked up as if he suspected it had rained down from the sky.

en: “It came off,” someone explained.
vi: "It fell off." Someone explained.
tr: "The wheel has come off," someone explained.
es: —It has come loose.

en: He nodded.
vi: He nodded.
tr: The man nodded his head.
es: He nodded.

en: “At first I din’ notice we’d stopped.”
vi: "I didn't notice that our car had stopped."
tr: “I didn't realize we had stopped.”
es: —At first, I didn't realize that we had stopped.

en: A pause. Then, taking a long breath and straightening his shoulders, he remarked in a determined voice:
vi: Pausing for a moment, then taking a deep breath and straightening his shoulders, he spoke with a determined voice.
tr: Silence again. After taking a deep breath and straightening his shoulders, the man said in a determined voice, "Is there anyone who can tell me where the gas station is?"
es: Silence. Then, taking a breath and standing up very straight, he asked decisively:

en: “Wonder’ff tell me where there’s a gas’line station?”
vi: "Does anyone know where the gas station is?"
tr: After taking a deep breath and straightening his shoulders, the man said in a determined voice, "Is there anyone who can tell me where the gas station is?"
es: —Could you tell me where there is a gas station?

en: At least a dozen men, some of them a little better off than he was, explained to him that wheel and car were no longer joined by any physical bond.
vi: At least about a dozen men, some of whom were more alert than he was, explained to him that there was no longer any piece connecting the wheel to the vehicle.
tr: A dozen or so people, slightly more sober than him, tried to explain that there was no longer a physical connection between the wheel and the car.
es: At least a dozen men, some barely in better condition than him, explained to him that the wheel and the car were no longer connected by any kind of material bond.

en: “Back out,” he suggested after a moment. “Put her in reverse.”
vi: "Reverse." After a moment, he suggested. "Shift to reverse."
tr: A minute passed. “Step back,” said the man, “let's turn the car around and restore it to its original state.”
es: —Back out —he suggested after a moment—. Put it in reverse.

en: “But the wheel’s off!”
vi: "But the WHEEL has already come off!"
tr: "But it has no wheels"
es: —But it's missing a wheel!

en: He hesitated.
vi: He hesitated slightly.
tr: He paused for a moment.
es: The man hesitated.

en: “No harm in trying,” he said.
vi: "There's no harm in trying."
tr: “There's no harm in trying.
es: —Nothing is lost by trying —he said.

en: The caterwauling horns had reached a crescendo and I turned away and cut across the lawn toward home. I glanced back once. A wafer of a moon was shining over Gatsby’s house, making the night fine as before, and surviving the laughter and the sound of his still glowing garden. A sudden emptiness seemed to flow now from the windows and the great doors, endowing with complete isolation the figure of the host, who stood on the porch, his hand up in a formal gesture of farewell.
vi: The car horn sounded like a cat's wail, reaching its peak, I turned my back and walked across the lawn to go home, only glancing back one more time. A thin, full moon was shimmering, casting its light over Gatsby's house, creating a beautiful moonlit evening just like the previous moonlit nights, as if the moon was unaffected by the laughter and noises emanating from the still vibrant garden. A sudden emptiness poured out from the windows and the large doors, completely enveloping and isolating the figure of the host standing on the porch, with his arm raised in a solemn farewell wave.
tr: The blaring of the horns had become unbearable. I moved away from there, crossed the green area in between, and headed home. Before reaching, I turned and looked back once more. The moon shining over Gatsby's house made the night even more beautiful, still giving life to the bright garden where laughter and voices had ceased. An untimely emptiness emanated from the windows and grand doors, bestowing a great loneliness upon the owner standing on the terrace, raising his hand for a formal farewell.
es: The howl of the horns was increasing. I turned around and, stepping on the grass, went home. I turned back to look once. The moon, like a host, shone over Gatsby's house so that the night was as beautiful as before: it had survived the laughter and the noises of the garden, still illuminated. A sudden emptiness now seemed to flow from the immense windows and doors, enveloping the host in absolute isolation, who remained on the porch, with his hand raised in a formal gesture of farewell.

en: Reading over what I have written so far, I see I have given the impression that the events of three nights several weeks apart were all that absorbed me. On the contrary, they were merely casual events in a crowded summer, and, until much later, they absorbed me infinitely less than my personal affairs.
vi: Reading again what I have written so far, I think I have given the reader the impression that the events occurring over three nights, spaced weeks apart, were things I was diligently focused on. On the contrary, they were just ordinary events in a busy summer, and only later did they infinitely capture my interest, even more than my personal issues.
tr: When I look at what I have written so far, I realize that my attention was gathered on three separate nights, spaced a few weeks apart. Yet these were the usual activities of a lively summer season, and until much time had passed, they occupied me far less than my own matters of the heart.
es: Upon rereading what I have written, I believe I may have given the impression that the events of three nights, separated by several weeks, completely absorbed me. Quite the opposite: they were merely insignificant events in a very busy summer, and, until much later, they absorbed me infinitely less than my own affairs.

en: Most of the time I worked. In the early morning the sun threw my shadow westward as I hurried down the white chasms of lower New York to the Probity Trust. I knew the other clerks and young bond-salesmen by their first names, and lunched with them in dark, crowded restaurants on little pig sausages and mashed potatoes and coffee. I even had a short affair with a girl who lived in Jersey City and worked in the accounting department, but her brother began throwing mean looks in my direction, so when she went on her vacation in July I let it blow quietly away.
vi: I spend most of my time working. Every early morning, as the sunlight casts my shadow towards the west, I am hurrying through the white canyons of downtown New York to my workplace called Probity Trust. I am familiar with the secretaries and the young stockbrokers in the office, calling them by their nicknames. We have lunch together in dark, crowded diners with dishes like pork sausages, mashed potatoes, and coffee. I also had a brief romance with a girl who worked in the accounting department and lived in New Jersey. However, when her brother started giving me fierce, hostile looks, I quietly ended this relationship in July when she went on vacation.
tr: I spent most of my time working. In the early hours of the morning, as the sun stretched my shadow westward, I would rush towards Probity Company, passing through the white valleys of New York's lower neighborhoods. I knew the names of all the clerks and young bond sellers at the company. We would sit together in dim and crowded diners, eating sausages and mashed potatoes, and drinking coffee. I even had a small romantic affair with a girl who worked in the accounting department and lived in Jersey City. When I noticed her brother giving me meaningful looks, I quietly let the matter drop, taking advantage of the girl's vacation in July.
es: I spent most of the time working. Early in the morning, the sun cast my shadow to the west as I hurriedly descended the white abysses that lead from the lower part of New York to the Probity Trust. I knew the other employees and the young bond salesmen by their names, and in crowded, dark restaurants, I ate with them pork sausages, mashed potatoes, and coffee. I even had a brief affair with a girl who lived in Jersey City and worked in the accounting department, but her brother started giving me dirty looks, and when the girl went on vacation in July, I ended the matter.

en: I took dinner usually at the Yale Club—for some reason it was the gloomiest event of my day—and then I went upstairs to the library and studied investments and securities for a conscientious hour. There were generally a few rioters around, but they never came into the library, so it was a good place to work. After that, if the night was mellow, I strolled down Madison Avenue past the old Murray Hill Hotel, and over 33rd Street to the Pennsylvania Station.
vi: I usually have dinner at the Yale Club. For some reason, I find this activity to be one of the most melancholic and dreary parts of my day. After that, I go to the library upstairs to diligently research stock investments for an entire hour. Usually, there are a few people making noise at the club, but they never enter the library, so it remains a good place for me to work. Then, as the evening cools down, I stroll down Madison Avenue, past the old Murray Hill Hotel to 33rd Street to reach Pennsylvania Station.
tr: I usually had my dinner at the Yale Club. For some reason, it would be the most boring time of the day for me. Then I would go up to the library on the upper floor and try to gain some knowledge by reading about investments and stocks for about an hour. There were always a few noisy chatterboxes in the club, but they wouldn't go up to the library. Therefore, it was a suitable place to work comfortably. When I finished my work, if the weather was mild, I would walk on Madison Avenue, pass the old Murray Hill Hotel, and reach the Pennsylvania Station from 33rd Street. Street to Pennsylvania Station.
es: I used to have dinner at the Yale Club—I don't know why, but that was the saddest event of the day—and then I would go up to the library and diligently study investments and securities for an hour. There were always a few revelers around, but they never entered the library, so it was a good place to work. Afterwards, if the night was nice, I would take a walk down Madison Avenue, pass the old Murray Hall Hotel, and, via Thirty-third Street, reach Pennsylvania Station.

en: I began to like New York, the racy, adventurous feel of it at night, and the satisfaction that the constant flicker of men and women and machines gives to the restless eye. I liked to walk up Fifth Avenue and pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that in a few minutes I was going to enter into their lives, and no one would ever know or disapprove. Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into warm darkness. At the enchanted metropolitan twilight I felt a haunting loneliness sometimes, and felt it in others—poor young clerks who loitered in front of windows waiting until it was time for a solitary restaurant dinner—young clerks in the dusk, wasting the most poignant moments of night and life.
vi: I began to feel a fondness for New York City, loving the thrilling, scorching sensation of the night and the satisfaction of seeing the continuous flickering from the figures of men, women, and vehicles appearing before my restless eyes. I enjoyed walking against the flow on Fifth Avenue, picking out from the crowd those affectionate women and imagining in my mind that in just a few minutes, I would step into their lives without anyone knowing or objecting. Sometimes, in my imagination, I followed them back to their apartments, somewhere on a hidden corner, and they would turn back and smile at me before disappearing through the door into the warm darkness. In the city's captivating dim light, sometimes I sensed a haunting loneliness, feeling it from others, from the young, impoverished office workers lingering in front of windows waiting for the time to enter the quiet dinner eateries, or from the young secretaries wandering in the twilight, wasting away the bitterest moments of the night and their lives.
tr: I had started to love New York. The lively, adventurous atmosphere of the nights, the light-shadow plays of women, men, and cars were affecting me. 5. While walking on the avenue, I would pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that I would enter their lives a few minutes later. No one would be aware or object. Sometimes in my imagination, I would follow them to the door of their house at the corner of a hidden street, and just as I was about to enter, I would see them look at me and smile, then disappear into the darkness. Sometimes, at the sunset of the metropolis, a strange loneliness would fill me. I would see this in others too. Loitering in front of shop windows, the poor young clerks waiting for the dinner hour they would spend alone would waste the best moments of the night and life in the twilight.
es: I was beginning to like New York, the nighttime sensation of adventure and risk, and the pleasure that the constant fluctuation of men, women, and vehicles provided to the restless gaze. I liked to walk along Fifth Avenue and choose some romantic woman from the crowd and imagine that, in five minutes, I would enter her life, and that no one would ever know it nor disapprove of it. Sometimes, in my imagination, I followed her to her apartment, on the corner of some hidden street, and she would turn and smile at me before crossing a door and vanishing into the warmth and darkness. In the enchanted twilight of the metropolis, some days the loneliness became obsessive, and I even felt it in others, young and poor employees who killed time in front of shop windows and waited for the hour to dine alone in a restaurant; young employees who, at nightfall, wasted the most wonderful moments of the night and of life.

en: Again at eight o’clock, when the dark lanes of the Forties were lined five deep with throbbing taxicabs, bound for the theatre district, I felt a sinking in my heart. Forms leaned together in the taxis as they waited, and voices sang, and there was laughter from unheard jokes, and lighted cigarettes made unintelligible circles inside. Imagining that I, too, was hurrying towards gaiety and sharing their intimate excitement, I wished them well.
vi: Then around eight in the evening, when the dark interior of Forties Street was crowded with five rows of taxis packed with passengers heading towards the theater district, I felt my heart sink. The shapes of people leaning against each other inside the waiting taxis, the cheerful voices, the laughter from indistinguishable jokes, the sparks on the tips of cigarettes sketching out incomprehensible shapes. Just imagine, I too, was hurrying towards the bustling places, sharing with Give them their own private joys. I wish them good things.
tr: At eight in the evening, 40. Watching the taxis moving stop-and-go in five lanes towards the theater districts on the dim streets of the avenue would make me feel suffocated. In the waiting cars, people would huddle together and sing songs, laugh at jokes I couldn't hear, and the smoke from the lit cigarettes would surround the invisible multitude of gestures inside. I would act as if I were impatient to go to the entertainment as well, share their excitement, and at the same time wish for all of them to be happy.
es: At eight o'clock, once again, when the dimly lit roadway of the Forties streets filled with the hustle and bustle of taxis, lined up five in a row, heading to the theater district, I felt a tightness in my heart. The silhouettes inside the taxis waiting to move on merged, voices sang, jokes I couldn't hear elicited laughter, and lit cigarettes traced unintelligible spirals. Imagining that I too was rushing towards joy and sharing their deepest enthusiasm, I wished them the best.

en: For a while I lost sight of Jordan Baker, and then in midsummer I found her again. At first I was flattered to go places with her, because she was a golf champion, and everyone knew her name. Then it was something more. I wasn’t actually in love, but I felt a sort of tender curiosity. The bored haughty face that she turned to the world concealed something—most affectations conceal something eventually, even though they don’t in the beginning—and one day I found what it was. When we were on a house-party together up in Warwick, she left a borrowed car out in the rain with the top down, and then lied about it—and suddenly I remembered the story about her that had eluded me that night at Daisy’s. At her first big golf tournament there was a row that nearly reached the newspapers—a suggestion that she had moved her ball from a bad lie in the semifinal round. The thing approached the proportions of a scandal—then died away. A caddy retracted his statement, and the only other witness admitted that he might have been mistaken. The incident and the name had remained together in my mind.
vi: There was a time I didn't see Jordan Baker again until around mid-summer when I met her again. At first, I felt very proud to go places with Baker because Jordan was a well-known female golf champion. Then later, there were many other things. At that time, I wasn't really in love with Jordan, just felt a very gentle curiosity. Jordan's haughty, bored face when facing everyone around contained something, if it didn't show up at first, it would eventually reveal itself, a look that seemed to hide something. Then one day I found out what it was. When we attended a party held at a house on Warwick, Jordan forgot to close the top of the car she borrowed and left it out in the rain. After that, Jordan lied about it. The incident suddenly reminded me of the story I couldn't recall the night at Daisy's house. At a major golf tournament that Jordan first participated in, there was such an uproar that it almost made the newspapers. Someone accused Jordan of moving her golf ball from a disadvantageous position. This incident had the magnitude of a scandal, but then it was suppressed. The golf ball retriever has retracted his statement, and the sole witness also admitted that he might have been mistaken. The story and the names involved in this case have become intertwined and remain etched in my memory.
tr: For a while, I lost track of Jordan Baker. But towards the middle of summer, we met again. At first, I was even proud to be seen with her because she was a famous golf champion and well-known. Over time, other feelings were added to these. Though I wasn't in love, I felt a warm closeness and interest towards her. I thought she was hiding something behind her weary attitude towards her surroundings and her somewhat arrogant facial expression—all pretentious behaviors are initially aimed at hiding something. One day, I learned what it was. At a house party in Warwick, she had left the borrowed convertible out in the rain and lied about it. Then suddenly, I remembered the story that hadn't come to mind the night we met at Daisy's house. In her first major golf tournament, according to a rumor that caused quite a stir and made it to the newspapers, she had moved the ball in the semi-final. The incident was about to reach scandalous proportions when it was covered up. The caddy had withdrawn his claim, and the second person who said they witnessed the event admitted they might have been mistaken. The incident and the name of its protagonist must have stuck in my mind.
es: I lost sight of Jordan Baker, and in the middle of summer, I met her again. At first, I was flattered to go places with her because she was a golf champion and everyone knew her. And then there was something more. It's not that I had fallen in love, but I felt a kind of curiosity, a tenderness. The face of proud boredom she presented to the world hid something —almost all poses end up hiding something, if they don't hide it from the beginning—, and one day I discovered what it was. We had gone to a party in Warwick, and Jordan left the car that had been lent to her in the rain, without putting up the top, and then lied about the incident, and then it came to my mind what they said about her that I couldn't remember that night at Daisy's house. In her first major golf tournament, there was a scandal that almost made it to the newspapers: someone insinuated that in the semifinals, Jordan moved a ball that had fallen in a bad spot. The case reached scandalous proportions and then deflated. A caddy retracted his statements and the only witness admitted that he might have been mistaken. However, I retained the incident and the name.

en: Jordan Baker instinctively avoided clever, shrewd men, and now I saw that this was because she felt safer on a plane where any divergence from a code would be thought impossible. She was incurably dishonest. She wasn’t able to endure being at a disadvantage and, given this unwillingness, I suppose she had begun dealing in subterfuges when she was very young in order to keep that cool, insolent smile turned to the world and yet satisfy the demands of her hard, jaunty body.
vi: By instinct, Jordan Baker often avoided cunning and shrewd men. And now I realize that Jordan did so because she felt she would be safer with the kind of people who believed that deviations from the rules were impossible. Jordan was an incorrigible liar. She couldn't stand being in a disadvantageous position. I suppose this deceitfulness had been developed since she was young in order to maintain that cold, arrogant smile towards the world around her, while also satisfying the demands of her lively and vigorous body.
tr: Jordan Baker instinctively stayed away from intelligent and cunning men. Now I understood why. She felt safe in environments where it was believed that straying from moral rules was impossible. She was an incorrigible cheat. Unable to tolerate being at a disadvantage, she resorted to evasive methods even in her youth, making it a habit to fulfill the desires of her lively, showy body with that cold and arrogant smile she turned to the world.
es: Jordan Baker instinctively avoided intelligent and perceptive men, and then I understood that she did so because she felt safer in a sphere where deviating from the norm was practically impossible. She was an incurable cheat. She couldn't stand being at a disadvantage and, because of that negative trait, I suppose she had started resorting to subterfuge from a very young age to maintain that cold and insolent smile in front of the world and, at the same time, satisfy the demands of her strong and happy body.

en: It made no difference to me. Dishonesty in a woman is a thing you never blame deeply—I was casually sorry, and then I forgot. It was on that same house-party that we had a curious conversation about driving a car. It started because she passed so close to some workmen that our fender flicked a button on one man’s coat.
vi: That matter didn't change anything in me. The deceit of a woman is something one can never continually blame. I only felt regret for a moment, but then quickly forgot about it. Also, during that party, the two of us had a strange conversation about driving. The story began when Jordan drove too close to a road worker, so close that our car's fender lightly brushed against the worker's button.
tr: From my perspective, nothing changed. We can't blame a woman too much for her lies. At first, I felt a bit sad, but then I forgot. An interesting conversation about driving had taken place at the party that night. Jordan had driven so close to the workers on the roadside that our fender tore off one of the men's buttons.
es: I didn't care. That a woman cheats is something that no one criticizes too much. It bothered me at first, and then I forgot about it. At that party, at someone's house in Warwick, we had a curious conversation about how to drive a car. It started because she passed so close to some workers that the fender brushed a button on one of their jackets.

en: “You’re a rotten driver,” I protested. “Either you ought to be more careful, or you oughtn’t to drive at all.”
vi: "You really are a reckless driver." I protested. "Either you should be more careful, or you shouldn't drive at all."
tr: “You are a terrible driver!” I shouted, “Either drive more carefully or don't drive at all.”
es: —You drive recklessly —I protested—. Either you become more careful, or you should stop driving.

en: “I am careful.”
vi: "I am careful."
tr: “I am paying attention”
es: —I'm being careful.

en: “No, you’re not.”
vi: "Not at all, you weren't careful."
tr: “No, you don't.”
es: —No, you are not careful.

en: “Well, other people are,” she said lightly.
vi: "So, someone else has been careful." Jordan said gently.
tr: "Never mind, the other drivers will pay attention anyway," he said in a joking manner.
es: —Well, others are already being careful —he said without thinking twice.

en: “What’s that got to do with it?”
vi: "So, will that help?"
tr: “What does that have to do with anything now?”
es: —And what does that have to do with anything?

en: “They’ll keep out of my way,” she insisted. “It takes two to make an accident.”
vi: "Those people will avoid you," Jordan said firmly. "It takes two careless people to cause an accident."
tr: “They will get out of my way. An accident involves two people.”
es: —They won't get in my way —he insisted—. It takes two to have an accident.

en: “Suppose you met somebody just as careless as yourself.”
vi: "Suppose you meet someone who is as careless as you."
tr: "What if I come across someone as careless as you.""
es: —Suppose you meet someone as reckless as you.

en: “I hope I never will,” she answered. “I hate careless people. That’s why I like you.”
vi: "I hope I never meet them." Jordan replied. "I hate careless people. That's why I like you."
tr: "I hope such a thing doesn't happen. I hate careless people. That's why I like you."
es: —I hope I never run into him —he replied—. I detest reckless people. That's why I like you.

en: Her grey, sun-strained eyes stared straight ahead, but she had deliberately shifted our relations, and for a moment I thought I loved her. But I am slow-thinking and full of interior rules that act as brakes on my desires, and I knew that first I had to get myself definitely out of that tangle back home. I’d been writing letters once a week and signing them: “Love, Nick,” and all I could think of was how, when that certain girl played tennis, a faint moustache of perspiration appeared on her upper lip. Nevertheless there was a vague understanding that had to be tactfully broken off before I was free.
vi: Jordan's gray eyes, weary from the sun, looked straight ahead, but in truth, Jordan had deliberately changed the relationship between the two of us. For a moment, I thought I was in love with Jordan. However, because I am always deliberate in my thoughts and have many rules of my own, I restrained my desires. I knew I first had to permanently untangle the complicated relationship back home. For a long time, once a week, I would often write letters signing them at the bottom: "Love you. Nick." But at those moments, all I could think about was how that girl, when playing tennis, could sweat so much above her upper lip. Anyway, there was a vague understanding that I had to skillfully sever that relationship before I could be free.
tr: Having grown tired of the sun, without ever taking her gray eyes off the road, she had managed to skillfully divert the direction of our relationship. For a moment, I thought I was in love with her. But I was someone who thought a lot and made decisions slowly. Moreover, I had a lot of rules that restrained my desires. Therefore, the first thing I needed to do was to free myself from that old current I got caught up in before coming here, to New York. I wrote her a letter once a week and signed it 'Love, Nick'. The tiny beads of sweat that would gather on her upper lip while playing tennis still remained vivid in my mind. There was an unspoken agreement between us. To feel free, I needed to skillfully break that agreement.
es: His gray eyes, irritated by the sun, looked straight ahead, unflinching, but Jordan had astutely and deliberately altered the nature of our relationship, and for a moment I thought I loved her. But I think things through carefully and subject myself to a considerable number of inner rules that act as a brake on my desires, and I knew that my first obligation was to free myself from the mess I had left pending in my hometown. I wrote every week and kept signing: "With love, Nick," but the only thing I remembered was a girl who, when playing tennis, would get a fine mustache of sweat, and yet, there was a vague commitment that I had to break gently to feel free.

en: Everyone suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known.
vi: Each person believes that they possess at least one fundamental virtue, and my fundamental virtue is: I am one of the few honest people I have ever known.
tr: Every person believes that they possess at least one great virtue. Mine is being the most honest person among my acquaintances.
es: Everyone believes they possess at least one of the cardinal virtues. Mine is this: I am one of the few honest people I have known in my life.

en: IV
vi: Chapter 4
tr: CHAPTER 4

en: On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn.
vi: On Sunday morning, when the church bells tolled in the coastal villages, everyone, along with their lovers, returned to Gatsby's house, bustling and gliding joyfully across his lawn.
tr: As the bells rang in the villages along the coast on Sunday morning, the world and its favorite, the Sun, were gleaming joyfully on the lawns of Gatsby's garden.
es: On Sunday mornings, while the bells rang in the coastal churches, the whole world and its lover returned to Gatsby's house and gleamed with joy on the lawn.

en: “He’s a bootlegger,” said the young ladies, moving somewhere between his cocktails and his flowers. “One time he killed a man who had found out that he was nephew to Von Hindenburg and second cousin to the devil. Reach me a rose, honey, and pour me a last drop into that there crystal glass.”
vi: "He is a smuggler." The young women whispered to each other as they strolled back and forth between cocktails and flower bushes. "Once, he killed a man just because the man discovered that he was the grandson of Von Hindenburg, and a cousin to the devil." "Could you give me the rose petal, darling, and by the way, pour me the last drop of wine into that crystal glass."
tr: The young ladies were saying, "He was smuggling alcohol," while wandering between the landlord's cocktails and the flowers in the garden, "He once killed someone who found out that he was the nephew of Von Hindenburg and the second cousin of the devil. Pick me a rose from there, darling, and pour a sip of something into that crystal glass."
es: —He is a liquor trafficker —said the young women, among flowers and cocktails—. Once, he killed a man who discovered he was the nephew of Van Hindenburg and second cousin to the devil. Pick me a rose, darling, and fill that glass a little more.

en: Once I wrote down on the empty spaces of a timetable the names of those who came to Gatsby’s house that summer. It is an old timetable now, disintegrating at its folds, and headed “This schedule in effect July 5th, 1922.” But I can still read the grey names, and they will give you a better impression than my generalities of those who accepted Gatsby’s hospitality and paid him the subtle tribute of knowing nothing whatever about him.
vi: Once, I wrote on the blank spaces of a train timetable the names of those who visited Gatsby's house that summer. That timetable, with the note "Schedule effective from July 5, 1922" on its surface, is now old and tattered at the folds. Yet, I can still read the names with faded ink, and they can give us a better impression than my general descriptions of those who accepted Gatsby's hospitality and showed their delicate respect by pretending not to know about him.
tr: Once, in the gaps of the train schedule, I had written the names of those who came and went to Gatsby's house that summer. At the top, I had written '5. July. 1922 program,' and this list had become very old, now starting to tear at the fold lines. Even so, the faded ink was still readable and probably told much more about these people who had accepted Gatsby's hospitality without making any effort to know him than my generalizations ever could.
es: Once I wrote down in the blank spaces of a train schedule the names of those who went to Gatsby's house that summer. It is an old schedule now, and it is falling apart at the folds. The heading says: "This schedule takes effect on July 5, 1922." But I can still read those gray names, which will give you a more accurate impression than my generalities about those who accepted Gatsby's hospitality and paid him the subtle tribute of knowing nothing about him.

en: From East Egg, then, came the Chester Beckers and the Leeches, and a man named Bunsen, whom I knew at Yale, and Doctor Webster Civet, who was drowned last summer up in Maine. And the Hornbeams and the Willie Voltaires, and a whole clan named Blackbuck, who always gathered in a corner and flipped up their noses like goats at whosoever came near. And the Ismays and the Chrysties (or rather Hubert Auerbach and Mr. Chrystie’s wife), and Edgar Beaver, whose hair, they say, turned cotton-white one winter afternoon for no good reason at all.
vi: From East Egg, there were Mr. and Mrs. Chester Becker, Mr. and Mrs. Leech, and a man named Bunsen whom I had known at Yale. There was Dr. Webster Civet, who drowned last summer in the state of Maine. Then there were Mr. and Mrs. Hornbeam, Mr. and Mrs. Willie Voltaire, and the entire Blackbuck family, who always stood together in a corner and raised their noses like goats whenever someone approached. There were Mr. and Mrs. Ismay and Mr. and Mrs. Chrystie (or more precisely, Mr. Hubert Auerbach and Mrs. Chrystie's wife), and Mr. Edgar Beaver, whose hair, as people said, turned white as snow in a single winter afternoon for no apparent reason.
tr: Chester Baker from East Egg and his wife, the Leeches, Bunsen whom I also knew from Yale, Doctor Webster Civet who drowned in the sea last summer in Maine, the Hornbeams, and Willie Voltaire and his wife. Then there was the Blackbuck family, who gathered in a corner and turned up their noses at anyone who approached them, the Ismays, the Chrysties (or rather Hubert Auerbach and Mr. Chrystie's wife), and Edgar Beaver, whose hair supposedly turned white for no reason one winter day.
es: From East Egg came the Chester Beckers and the Leeches, and a certain Bunsen, whom I met at Yale, and Dr. Webster Civet, who drowned last summer in Maine. And the Hornbeams and the Willie Voltaires, and the entire Blackbuck clan, who always gathered in a corner and wrinkled their noses like goats at anyone who approached them. And the Ismays and the Chrysties (or, more precisely, Hubert Auerbach and Mr. Chrystie's wife), and Edgar Beaver, whose hair, against all reason, turned as white as cotton one winter afternoon, or so they say.

en: Clarence Endive was from East Egg, as I remember. He came only once, in white knickerbockers, and had a fight with a bum named Etty in the garden. From farther out on the Island came the Cheadles and the O. R. P. Schraeders, and the Stonewall Jackson Abrams of Georgia, and the Fishguards and the Ripley Snells. Snell was there three days before he went to the penitentiary, so drunk out on the gravel drive that Mrs. Ulysses Swett’s automobile ran over his right hand. The Dancies came, too, and S. B. Whitebait, who was well over sixty, and Maurice A. Flink, and the Hammerheads, and Beluga the tobacco importer, and Beluga’s girls.
vi: If I remember correctly, there was Clarence Endive from East Egg. He came only once wearing knee-length shorts, and got into a fight with a loafer named Etty in the garden. From farther across the island came the Cheadle couple, the O. R. P. Schraeder couple, and the Stonewall Jackson Abram couple from Georgia. There were the Fishguard couple and the Ripley Snell couple. Mr. Snell had been there three days before going to jail; he was dead drunk lying on the gravel path and got his right arm run over by Mrs. Ulysses Swett's car. The Dancy couple also came, and there was S. B. Whitebait who was over sixty years old. There were Maurice A. Flink, the Hammerhead couple, and even the Beluga importer family who brought along their mistresses.
tr: If I'm not mistaken, Clarence Endive was also from East Egg. He had only come once, wearing white golf pants, and had gotten into a fight in the garden with a tramp named Etty. There were also those who came from the farther parts of the island; the Cheadles, O. R. P. Schraeders, Stonewall Jackson Abrams from Georgia. The Fishguards and the Ripley Snell couple. Snell was at Gatsby's just three days before he was thrown in jail: he had gotten so drunk that he passed out on the gravel road, and Mrs. Ulysses Swett ran over his right hand with her car. The Dancies were also frequent visitors, including S. B. Whitebait, who was over sixty at the time, Maurice A. Flink and the Hammerheads, the tobacco importer Beluga and his daughters.
es: Clarence Endive was from East Egg, if I remember correctly. He only appeared once, in white golf pants, and got into a fight with a scoundrel, a certain Etty, in the garden. From more remote corners of the island came the Cheadles and the O. R. P. Schraders, and the Stonewall Jackson Abrams from Georgia, and the Fishguards and the Ripley Snells. Snell was at Gatsby's house three days before going to jail, so drunk that Mrs. Ulysses Swett's car ran over his right hand on the gravel path. The Dancies also came, and S. B. Whitebait, who was already a good sixty years old, and Maurice A. Flink, and the Hammerheads, and Beluga, the tobacco importer, and Beluga's girls.

en: From West Egg came the Poles and the Mulreadys and Cecil Roebuck and Cecil Schoen and Gulick the State senator and Newton Orchid, who controlled Films Par Excellence, and Eckhaust and Clyde Cohen and Don S. Schwartz (the son) and Arthur McCarty, all connected with the movies in one way or another. And the Catlips and the Bembergs and G. Earl Muldoon, brother to that Muldoon who afterward strangled his wife. Da Fontano the promoter came there, and Ed Legros and James B. (“Rot-Gut”) Ferret and the De Jongs and Ernest Lilly—they came to gamble, and when Ferret wandered into the garden it meant he was cleaned out and Associated Traction would have to fluctuate profitably next day.
vi: From West Egg came the Poles, the Mulreadys, Cecil Roebuck, Cecil Schoen, Senator Gulick, and Newton Orchid, who ran the film company Films Par Excellence. There were Eckhaust and Clyde Cohen, Don S. Schwartze (the son) and Arthur McCarty, all of whom were connected to the film industry in one way or another. There were the Catlips, the Bembergs, and Mr. G. Earl Muldoon. Mr. Muldoon's brother later strangled his wife to death. Advertising man Da Fontano also came, as did Ed Legros and James B. ("Rot-Gut") Ferret, the De Jongs, and Ernest Lilly—they came to gamble, and when Ferret wandered through the garden, it meant he had lost everything, and the stock prices of Associated Traction would fluctuate wildly the next day.
tr: The Poles, the Mulreadys, Cecil Roebuck, Cecil Schoen, Senator Gulick, Newton Orchid, the president of Par Excellence Film, Eckhaust, Clyde Cohen, Don S. Schwartz (son) and Arthur McCarthy from West Egg; all of them were somehow involved in the film industry. The Catlips, the Bembergs, and G. Earl Maldoon, the brother of Maldoon who later killed his wife by strangling her, was also among the attendees. Advertiser De Fontano, Ed Legros, and James B. (Rot-Gut) Ferret, De Jong and his wife, and Ernest Lilly would come for gambling; Ferret wandering around the garden after quitting the game indicated he was broke and that the value of Associated Traction shares would drop.
es: From West Egg came the Pole and the Mulready and Cecil Roebuck, and Cecil Schoen and Senator Gulick and Newton Orchid, who directed Films Par Excellence, and Eckhaust and Clyde Cohen and Don S. Schwartze (the son) and Arthur McCarty, all connected in one way or another with the cinema. And the Catlip and the Bemberg and G. Earl Muldoon, brother of that Muldoon who later strangled his wife. Da Fontano, the promoter, also made an appearance, and Ed Legros and James B. (alias Ratkiller) Ferret and the De Jong and Ernest Lilly: they all came to play, and when Ferret was lost in the garden it meant he had been cleaned out and that the shares of Associated Traction would rise the next day.

en: A man named Klipspringer was there so often that he became known as “the boarder”—I doubt if he had any other home. Of theatrical people there were Gus Waize and Horace O’Donavan and Lester Myer and George Duckweed and Francis Bull. Also from New York were the Chromes and the Backhyssons and the Dennickers and Russel Betty and the Corrigans and the Kellehers and the Dewars and the Scullys and S. W. Belcher and the Smirkes and the young Quinns, divorced now, and Henry L. Palmetto, who killed himself by jumping in front of a subway train in Times Square.
vi: A man named Klipspringer was there so often and for so long that he was given the nickname "the boarder." I suspected he didn't have a home anywhere. People from the performing arts who came there included Gus Waize, Horace O'donavan, Lester Meyer, George Duckweed, and Francis Bull. From New York, there were Mr. and Mrs. Chrome, Mr. and Mrs. Backhysson, Mr. and Mrs. Dennicker, Russel Betty, Mr. and Mrs. Corrigan, Mr. and Mrs. Kelleher, Mr. and Mrs. Dewar, Mr. and Mrs. Scully, S. W. Belcher, Mr. and Mrs. Smirke, and the young couple Quinn, now divorced. There was Henry L. Palmetto, who committed suicide by throwing himself in front of a train at Times Square.
tr: There was also Klipspringer, who came so often that they nicknamed him the boarder; frankly, I doubt he had anywhere else to stay. Among the guests were Gus Waize, Horace O’Donovan, Lester Myer, George Duckweed, and Francis Bull from the theater world. Additionally, the Chromes, the Corrigans, the Kellehers, the Dewars, the Scullys, and S. W. Belcher, the Smirks, the young Quinns who are now divorced, and Henry L. Palmetto, who later committed suicide by jumping in front of a subway car in Times Square, came from New York.
es: A certain Klipspringer went so often and stayed so long that they ended up calling him "the Boarder": I doubt he had another home. From the world of theater were Gus Waize and Horace O’Donavan and Lester Myer and George Duckweed and Francis Bull. Also from New York were the Chromes and the Backhyssons and the Dennickers and Russel Betty and the Corrigans and the Kellehers and the Dewars and the Scullys and S. W. Belcher and the Smirkes and the young Quinns, who have already divorced, and Henry L. Palmetto, who killed himself by jumping in front of the subway at Times Square.

en: Benny McClenahan arrived always with four girls. They were never quite the same ones in physical person, but they were so identical one with another that it inevitably seemed they had been there before. I have forgotten their names—Jaqueline, I think, or else Consuela, or Gloria or Judy or June, and their last names were either the melodious names of flowers and months or the sterner ones of the great American capitalists whose cousins, if pressed, they would confess themselves to be.
