vi: Benny McClenahan always arrived with four girls. They were not always the same girls, but they were so identical to one another that it inevitably seemed they had been there before. I had forgotten their names, but I remembered that if it wasn't Jacquelin, it was Consuela, or Gloria, or Judy, or June. As for their last names, they seemed to be melodious names of flowers, months of the year, or the dignified names of some American plutocratic families who, if pressed, would claim kinship.
tr: Benny McClenehan always came with four girls. Although the girls were different each time, they resembled each other so much that you would inevitably confuse them with those who had come before. I forgot their names; maybe it was Jacqueline... It could have been Consuela or Gloria; Judy or June; and when you asked for their last names, they would either give harmonious-sounding flower and moon names or, when pressed, use the family names of famous American capitalists whom they admitted were their cousins.
es: Benny McClenahan always showed up with four girls. They were never the same, but they were all so identical that it inevitably seemed they had been at the house before. I have forgotten their names: Jacqueline, I think, or Consuela or Gloria or Judy or June, and their last names were melodious names of flowers and months, or, more austere, of the great American capitalists, of whom, if pressed hard enough, they would eventually confess to being cousins.

en: In addition to all these I can remember that Faustina O’Brien came there at least once and the Baedeker girls and young Brewer, who had his nose shot off in the war, and Mr. Albrucksburger and Miss Haag, his fiancée, and Ardita Fitz-Peters and Mr. P. Jewett, once head of the American Legion, and Miss Claudia Hip, with a man reputed to be her chauffeur, and a prince of something, whom we called Duke, and whose name, if I ever knew it, I have forgotten.
vi: Besides the aforementioned people, I remember that Faustina O'Brien also came once, along with the Baedeker daughters and Brewer's son, who had his nose shot off in the war. There were Albrucksburger and his fiancée, Miss Haag. There were Mr. and Mrs. Ardita Fitz-Peter and Mr. P. Jewett, who had once led the American Legion veterans' association. There was Miss Claudia Hip and a man rumored to be her driver. There was also some prince everyone called the Duke, whose name, if I ever knew it, I have now forgotten.
tr: Besides these people, I can also mention Faustina O’Brein, who has come at least once, the Baedeker sisters, young Brewer who was shot in the nose during the war, Mr. Albrucksburger and his fiancée Miss Haag, Ardite Fitzpeters, and Mr. P., who was said to have once been the head of the American Legion. I can also name Mr. Jewett, Miss Claudiz Hipp and her accompanying chauffeur, and a prince whom we called the Duke but whose name I forgot before I could fully learn it.
es: Besides all those people, I remember that Faustina O’Brien came at least once, and the Baedeker girls and young Brewer, who lost his nose to a bullet in the war, and Mr. Albrucksburger and Miss Haag, his fiancée, and Ardita Fitz-Peters and Mr. P. Jewett, who presided over the American Legion, and Miss Claudia Hip, with an individual who claimed to be her chauffeur, and the prince of I don’t know what, whom we called Duke, and whose name, if I ever knew it, I have forgotten.

en: All these people came to Gatsby’s house in the summer.
vi: All of these people had come to Gatsby's house that summer.
tr: That summer, all these people had come to Gatsby's house.
es: All those people went to Gatsby's house that summer.

en: At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn.
vi: Around nine o'clock on a late July morning, Gatsby's splendid car wobbled up the rough road leading to my house, emitting a series of musical notes from its three-note horn.
tr: Towards the end of July, around nine in the morning, Gatsby's dazzling car approached slowly, echoing through the street with its three-note horn, and stopped on the stony road in front of my house.
es: At nine o'clock, on a late July morning, Gatsby's magnificent car rattled up the gravel path that led to my door and played an explosive three-note melody with its horn.

en: It was the first time he had called on me, though I had gone to two of his parties, mounted in his hydroplane, and, at his urgent invitation, made frequent use of his beach.
vi: This was the first time Gatsby visited me, although I had attended two parties at his house, had flown a seaplane with him, and had frequently used his beach as he had earnestly invited.
tr: Even though I had attended two of his parties, ridden on his seaplane, and swum in the sea from his private beach at his insistence, this was the first time he was coming to my house.
es: It was the first time Gatsby had come to see me, although I had attended two of his parties, ridden in his hydroplane, and, at his persistent invitations, frequently used his beach.

en: “Good morning, old sport. You’re having lunch with me today and I thought we’d ride up together.”
vi: "Hello, old friend. We We made a lunch date, and I came here to pick you up."
tr: "Good morning, buddy!" he called out. "We're having lunch together today, but how about we go for a walk first?"
es: —Good morning, comrade. Today you are eating with me and I thought we could go together in the car.

en: He was balancing himself on the dashboard of his car with that resourcefulness of movement that is so peculiarly American—that comes, I suppose, with the absence of lifting work in youth and, even more, with the formless grace of our nervous, sporadic games. This quality was continually breaking through his punctilious manner in the shape of restlessness. He was never quite still; there was always a tapping foot somewhere or the impatient opening and closing of a hand.
vi: Gatsby sat confidently on the running board of his car with a sophisticated demeanor that is distinctly American. I believe that this mannerism did not come from weightlifting or a rigid sitting posture from childhood, but rather from the elegance of sports. This distinctive trait continued to manifest in his meticulous and fussy personality, always under the guise of restless energy. Gatsby never stood still, his feet always tapping somewhere or his hands impatiently opening and closing.
tr: With an unusual American skill brought by not having carried heavy loads in our youth or instead of just sitting, playing ruleless, exciting, and chaotic games, he was balancing on the fender of his car. This trait always manifested itself in a guise of restlessness that broke through his formal demeanor. He could never stay still; he would either tap somewhere with one foot to keep a rhythm or move his hands impatiently.
es: He balanced on the running board of the car with that ease of movement so characteristically American, which stems, I suppose, from the absence of heavy labor in youth and, even more, from the formless grace of our sports, so sporadic, so nervous. It was a quality that, in the form of agitation, showed through beneath his meticulous manners. He was never completely still: one foot kept tapping the ground or an impatient hand never stopped opening and closing.

en: He saw me looking with admiration at his car.
vi: Gatsby saw me admiring the car.
tr: When he saw me looking at his car with admiration, he jumped off the fender to give me a better view and said, "Nice car, isn't it?
es: He saw that he was looking at the car with admiration.

en: “It’s pretty, isn’t it, old sport?” He jumped off to give me a better view. “Haven’t you ever seen it before?”
vi: "This car is beautiful, isn't it, old friend?" Gatsby stepped aside so I could get a better look. "Haven't you seen this car before?"
tr: When he saw me looking at his car with admiration, he jumped off the fender to give me a better view and said, "Nice car, isn't it? Hadn't you seen this before?"
es: —It's beautiful, isn't it, buddy? —he jumped off the stirrup so I could admire it better—. Hadn't you seen it?

en: I’d seen it. Everybody had seen it. It was a rich cream colour, bright with nickel, swollen here and there in its monstrous length with triumphant hatboxes and supper-boxes and toolboxes, and terraced with a labyrinth of windshields that mirrored a dozen suns. Sitting down behind many layers of glass in a sort of green leather conservatory, we started to town.
vi: I have seen it before. Everyone has seen it before. The car is dark cream-colored, with shiny chrome plating, incredibly long, bulging here and there with many compartments for storing hats, food boxes, and toolboxes. Above, there are numerous windshields that can reflect dozens of suns. Sitting in the car behind many layers of glass that looked like a greenhouse, we set off into the city.
tr: Is it possible not to see, of course I had seen it. The nickel plating of the extremely long car, with its labyrinths formed by wind shields rising here and there with hats, provisions, and toolboxes, dazzled under the sun in its light cream color. Behind the multi-layered windshield, almost buried in a greenhouse of green leather, we set off towards the city.
es: He had seen it. Everyone had seen it. It was of an intense cream color, with glittering chrome, and of a monstrous length, further exaggerated by a triumphant accumulation of compartments for hats, provisions, and tools, and a labyrinth of successive windshields that reflected a dozen suns. Protected by many layers of glass, in a sort of green leather greenhouse, we headed towards the city.

en: I had talked with him perhaps half a dozen times in the past month and found, to my disappointment, that he had little to say. So my first impression, that he was a person of some undefined consequence, had gradually faded and he had become simply the proprietor of an elaborate roadhouse next door.
vi: I had talked to Gatsby five or six times in the past month, but I was really disappointed to realize that he didn't have much to say. Therefore, my initial impression that he was some important figure gradually faded away. To me, he now was just a complicated roadside innkeeper.
tr: In the last month, I had tried to chat with him at least five or six times; however, each time I was disappointed, thinking he didn't have much to say. The impression he left on me when we first met, that he was a mysterious person, had gradually faded; in the end, he had turned into nothing more than the owner of the magnificent mansion next to mine in my eyes.
es: I might have spoken with Gatsby five or six times recently and had discovered, disappointedly, that he had little to say. So my first impression (that he was an interesting person, of an indefinite but certain interest) gradually faded away, and Gatsby simply became the owner of the ostentatious roadside lodge next to my house.

en: And then came that disconcerting ride. We hadn’t reached West Egg village before Gatsby began leaving his elegant sentences unfinished and slapping himself indecisively on the knee of his caramel-coloured suit.
vi: And then this trip turned my thoughts upside down. When we had not yet reached the village of West Egg, Gatsby began to trail off his elegant and graceful sentences, hesitantly patting his knee in his light brown suit.
tr: I was thinking it was going to be a boring journey. But before we even reached West Egg, Gatsby had stopped using those fancy phrases and had started tapping his caramel-colored trousers indecisively.
es: And then came that bewildering trip. We hadn't yet passed West Egg Village when Gatsby began to leave his most elegant sentences unfinished and to slap his caramel-colored suit's knee uncertainly with the palm of his hand.

en: “Look here, old sport,” he broke out surprisingly, “what’s your opinion of me, anyhow?”
vi: "Listen here, old sport." Gatsby suddenly said. "What do you think of me?"
tr: Then suddenly he turned to me and asked, "What do you think of me, buddy?"
es: —Tell me, comrade —he suddenly blurted out—, what do you think of me?

en: A little overwhelmed, I began the generalized evasions which that question deserves.
vi: Slightly taken aback, I began to give evasive, general answers typically reserved for such questions.
tr: I was stunned and tried to brush him off with generalities that would fit such a question.
es: A bit overwhelmed, I resorted to the evasions and generalities that such a question deserves.

en: “Well, I’m going to tell you something about my life,” he interrupted. “I don’t want you to get a wrong idea of me from all these stories you hear.”
vi: "Alright, I'll tell you a little bit about my life." Gatsby interrupted. "I don't want you to misunderstand me because of the things you've heard."
tr: “It's best if I tell you a few truths about my life,” he interrupted me. “I don't want you to be misled by the nonsense told about me and get the wrong impression.”
es: —Well, I'm going to tell you something about my life —he interrupted me—. I don't want you to get the wrong idea about me with all those stories you must have heard.

en: So he was aware of the bizarre accusations that flavoured conversation in his halls.
vi: It turns out that Gatsby had learned about the bizarre slanders that had spiced up the conversations in the rooms of his house.
tr: So, the one who enlivened their parties was also aware of those interesting rumors about themselves.
es: So he knew all the absurd accusations that seasoned the conversation in their salons.

en: “I’ll tell you God’s truth.” His right hand suddenly ordered divine retribution to stand by. “I am the son of some wealthy people in the Middle West—all dead now. I was brought up in America but educated at Oxford, because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. It is a family tradition.”
vi: "I will tell you the truth." Gatsby's right arm suddenly raised as if to swear. "I am the son of a wealthy family from the Midwest, all of my family members have passed away. I was raised in America but went to school at Oxford because my ancestors have been educated there for many generations. It is a tradition of my family line.
tr: "God is my witness, what I'm about to tell you is absolutely true," he said, raising his right hand to reinforce his oath. I am the son of a wealthy Middle Western family, now none of them are alive. I grew up in America, but like all my ancestors, I also went to Oxford; it is a family tradition for us.”
es: —I swear to God that I will tell you the truth —his right hand immediately commanded that divine punishment be prepared—. I am the son of a well-off family from the Midwest. All of my relatives have died. I grew up in America but was educated at Oxford, because, for many years, all my ancestors have been educated there. It is a family tradition.

en: He looked at me sideways—and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying. He hurried the phrase “educated at Oxford,” or swallowed it, or choked on it, as though it had bothered him before. And with this doubt, his whole statement fell to pieces, and I wondered if there wasn’t something a little sinister about him, after all.
vi: Gatsby glanced sideways at me, and now I knew why Jordan Baker thought he was lying. Gatsby quickly said the phrase "studied at Oxford" as if swallowing the words, as if they had been stuck in his throat and had long caused him discomfort. With this doubt, all of Gatsby's words seemed to shatter into pieces, and I wondered if, in the end, he wasn't harboring something sinister.
tr: He looked with a blank stare; at that moment, I understood why Jordan Baker thought he was lying: when he said, "I went to Oxford," he mumbled the words as if it didn't bother him, swallowing them as if choking on them. Because of my suspicion, what he was saying lost its meaning, and I wondered if there was indeed something a little unsettling in his life.
es: He looked at me out of the corner of his eye, and I understood why Jordan Baker believed that Gatsby was lying. He hurriedly pronounced the phrase "I was educated at Oxford," or almost swallowed it, or it got stuck in his throat, as if it had already caused him trouble before. With this doubt, his entire statement fell apart, and I wondered if, after all, there wasn't something sinister about him.

en: “What part of the Middle West?” I inquired casually.
vi: "Which part of the Midwest?" I asked casually.
tr: Just to ask, I said, "Where in the Midwest are you from?"
es: —Which part of the Midwest? —I asked without much interest.

en: “San Francisco.”
vi: "San Francisco"
tr: “San Francisco.”
es: —From San Francisco.

en: “I see.”
vi: "Is that so."
tr: “So that's how it is.”
es: —Okay.

en: “My family all died and I came into a good deal of money.”
vi: "My entire family passed away, and I inherited a vast fortune."
tr: “When I lost everyone in my family, I inherited a large fortune.”
es: —My family died and I inherited a good amount of money.

en: His voice was solemn, as if the memory of that sudden extinction of a clan still haunted him. For a moment I suspected that he was pulling my leg, but a glance at him convinced me otherwise.
vi: Gatsby's voice was very solemn, as if the memory of the sudden demise of his family still haunted him. For a moment, I suspected Gatsby was joking with me, but when I glanced at him, I completely believed him again.
tr: It was evident from the sorrow in his voice that the sudden loss of his entire family still caused him anguish. For a moment, I thought he was joking with me, but when I looked at his face, I realized he wasn't.
es: His voice was solemn, as if the memory of that sudden extinction of the clan still weighed heavily on his soul. For a moment I suspected he was pulling my leg, but a single look at him was enough to convince me otherwise.

en: “After that I lived like a young rajah in all the capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting a little, things for myself only, and trying to forget something very sad that had happened to me long ago.”
vi: "After that, I lived like a young prince across the capitals of Europe such as Paris, Venice, Rome - Collecting jewelry, mainly rubies, hunting big game, also doing a bit of painting - all personal activities to try to forget the sorrows that had happened to me in the past."
tr: “Then, in Paris, Venice, Rome, and all the great cities of Europe, I lived like a prince; collecting precious stones, especially rubies, participating in hunting parties, and painting, even if only for myself, all the while trying to distract myself with the desire to forget that sorrowful event I experienced long ago.”
es: —Then I lived like a young rajah in all the capitals of Europe: Paris, Venice, Rome, collecting jewels, mainly rubies, practicing big-game hunting, painting a little, exclusively for myself, and trying to forget something very sad that had happened to me a long time ago.

en: With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter. The very phrases were worn so threadbare that they evoked no image except that of a turbaned “character” leaking sawdust at every pore as he pursued a tiger through the Bois de Boulogne.
vi: I had to try hard to keep myself from bursting into skeptical laughter. The words used were so outdated that they evoked no image other than that of a character wearing an Arab-style turban, sawdust falling from every pore as he chased a tiger through the trees of Bois de Boulogne park in western Paris.
tr: I was struggling hard not to laugh. The stories they told were so familiar that, inevitably, a turbaned figure tracking a tiger in the Boulogne Forest, with sawdust flying everywhere, came to mind.
es: With great difficulty, I managed to contain an incredulous laugh. Those phrases were so clichéd and so unconvincing that the only image they managed to evoke was that of a puppet with a turban sweating sawdust while chasing a tiger through the Bois de Boulogne.

en: “Then came the war, old sport. It was a great relief, and I tried very hard to die, but I seemed to bear an enchanted life. I accepted a commission as first lieutenant when it began. In the Argonne Forest I took the remains of my machine-gun battalion so far forward that there was a half mile gap on either side of us where the infantry couldn’t advance. We stayed there two days and two nights, a hundred and thirty men with sixteen Lewis guns, and when the infantry came up at last they found the insignia of three German divisions among the piles of dead. I was promoted to be a major, and every Allied government gave me a decoration—even Montenegro, little Montenegro down on the Adriatic Sea!”
vi: "Then the war broke out, my old friend. At that time, I felt it was a great liberation, I tried everything to die, but it seemed my life had been granted a miraculous blessing. When I first enlisted, I was given the rank of Lieutenant. In the Argonne Forest, I commanded two machine gun squads to advance half a mile ahead between the two armies, where the infantry couldn't reach. We stayed there for two days and two nights with one hundred and thirty soldiers and sixteen Lewis machine guns. When the infantry managed to reach there, they found the insignia of three German divisions among the corpses. I was promoted to Major and all the Allied governments awarded me medals, even Montenegro, the small country on the Adriatic Sea."
tr: “Then the war broke out. This was actually a great consolation for me; I did everything I could to die, but it was as if my life was protected by a charm. I was a lieutenant when the war started. While in the Argonne Forest, I had advanced two machine gun brigades so far at the front that the distance to the infantry companies on either side of us, who couldn't catch up, had exceeded a kilometer each. We stayed in the area for two days and two nights with one hundred and thirty soldiers and sixteen Lewis guns; when the infantry finally arrived, they found the insignia of three German divisions among the piles of corpses. I was promoted to major and received honors from all allied countries, even from that Montenegro. Imagine, from that little Montenegro in the Adriatic!”
es: —Then the war came, comrade. It was a great relief, and I put all my effort into dying, but it was as if a spell protected my life. I received the rank of first lieutenant at the beginning of the war. In the Argonne Forest, I led what was left of my machine gun battalion forward until, on one flank and the other, we cleared a space of about a kilometer through which the infantry could not advance. We held out there for two days and two nights, one hundred and thirty men with sixteen Lewis machine guns, and when the infantry finally arrived, they found the insignia of three German divisions among the heaps of dead. I was promoted to major, and all the allied governments decorated me, even Montenegro, the little Montenegro, on the shores of the Adriatic Sea!

en: Little Montenegro! He lifted up the words and nodded at them—with his smile. The smile comprehended Montenegro’s troubled history and sympathized with the brave struggles of the Montenegrin people. It appreciated fully the chain of national circumstances which had elicited this tribute from Montenegro’s warm little heart. My incredulity was submerged in fascination now; it was like skimming hastily through a dozen magazines.
vi: The small country of Montenegro! Gatsby raised his voice and nodded as he mentioned these words with a smile. A smile that seemed to sympathize with the tangled history of Montenegro and the brave struggle of its people. My skepticism was completely submerged in admiration, and I found myself seemingly rushing through dozens of magazine pages.
tr: Oh, from little Montenegro! He had spoken the words with such elevation, emphasizing each one, and smiled. From this smile, it was understood that he felt a closeness to the pains in Montenegro's history and the heroic struggle of its people. This was also an indication that he evaluated this medal, which had come from the loving little hearts of Montenegrins, considering the conditions they were in. My doubts were now dispersing in a great curiosity, which gave me the feeling of hastily flipping through dozens of magazines.
es: The little Montenegro! He emphasized the words and confirmed them with a smile. The smile took charge of Montenegro's turbulent history and supported the heroic struggles of the Montenegrin people. He appreciated as a whole the chain of national circumstances that had led to the decoration granted by the small and ardent heart of Montenegro. My disbelief was overcome by fascination: it was like hastily flipping through a pile of cheap magazines.

en: He reached in his pocket, and a piece of metal, slung on a ribbon, fell into my palm.
vi: Gatsby reached into his pocket, took out a medal tied with a ribbon, and placed it in my palm.
tr: He put his hand in his pocket and dropped a coin with a ribbon tied to it into my palm.
es: He put his hand in his pocket, and a piece of metal tied to a ribbon fell into my palm.

en: “That’s the one from Montenegro.”
vi: "This dish is a gift from Montenegro."
tr: “Here, this is the medal given by Montenegro,” he said.
es: —It is the decoration of Montenegro.

en: To my astonishment, the thing had an authentic look. “Orderi di Danilo,” ran the circular legend, “Montenegro, Nicolas Rex.”
vi: I was amazed because that object looked very real, with text printed in a circle around it. "Order of Danilo, Montenegro, King Nicholas."
tr: I was astonished to see that it resembled a real medal. On it, in a circular shape, it read ‘Orderi di Danilo. Montenegro Nicolas Rex’.
es: To my astonishment, the medal seemed authentic. "Order of Danilo," it read in a circle, "Montenegro, Nicholas Rex."

en: “Turn it.”
vi: "Flip to the other side and see."
tr: “Look behind you too.”
es: —Turn it around.

en: “Major Jay Gatsby,” I read, “For Valour Extraordinary.”
vi: "Lieutenant Colonel Gatsby. Symbolizes extraordinary courage." I read.
tr: ‘To Major Jay Gatsby – For Displaying Exceptional Heroism’
es: “Major Jay Gatsby,” I read: “For his extraordinary valor.”

en: “Here’s another thing I always carry. A souvenir of Oxford days. It was taken in Trinity Quad—the man on my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.”
vi: "There is one more thing that I always carry with me. A memento from the days in Oxford. The picture was taken at Trinity Quad - the person standing to the left next to me is now the Earl of Dorcaster."
tr: “There is also this,” he said, taking a photo out of his pocket, “I always carry this with me in memory of my Oxford days. It was taken in the Trinity Courtyard. The young man on my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.”
es: —There is something else that always accompanies me. A memory from the days of Oxford. It was taken in the courtyard of Trinity. The one who appears to my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.

en: It was a photograph of half a dozen young men in blazers loafing in an archway through which were visible a host of spires. There was Gatsby, looking a little, not much, younger—with a cricket bat in his hand.
vi: It is a picture of about five or six young men in uniform jackets standing under an arched gate, through which one can clearly see a row of bell towers. In the picture, there is Gatsby, looking younger than he does now but not by much, holding a cricket bat.
tr: In the photograph, there were six young men in sports jackets at an arched passageway with a series of towers visible in the background. Gatsby was also in the photograph with a cricket bat in his hand; although he looked relatively younger than he does now, he didn't seem to have changed much.
es: It was a photo of a group of young people with the university jacket: they were wasting time under an arcade through which an army of spires could be seen. There was Gatsby, who looked a little younger, though not much. He had a cricket bat in his hand.

en: Then it was all true. I saw the skins of tigers flaming in his palace on the Grand Canal; I saw him opening a chest of rubies to ease, with their crimson-lighted depths, the gnawings of his broken heart.
vi: That is indeed the truth. I seem to see the tiger skins being splendidly displayed in his castle on the Grand Canal. I also seem to see him opening a box full of rubies emitting a deep red light to soothe the anguish in his broken heart.
tr: So what they said was true. This time, before my eyes, a man trying to bury the agony gnawing at his heart in the crimson depths of a sparkling ruby chest in his palace adorned with tiger skins on the shores of the Grand Canal in Venice had come to life.
es: So it was all true. I saw the tiger skins, splendid trophies in his palace on the Grand Canal. I saw him opening a chest of rubies to soothe the pain of his broken heart in the depths of their crimson glow.

en: “I’m going to make a big request of you today,” he said, pocketing his souvenirs with satisfaction, “so I thought you ought to know something about me. I didn’t want you to think I was just some nobody. You see, I usually find myself among strangers because I drift here and there trying to forget the sad things that happened to me.” He hesitated. “You’ll hear about it this afternoon.”
vi: "Today I have something important I need your help with." Gatsby said, putting his mementos into his pocket with a satisfied and contented look. "Therefore, I think you need to know more about me. I don't want you to think that I'm just some ordinary person. You see, I'm always surrounded by strangers because I often wander around to try to forget the sad story that happened to me." Gatsby hesitated. "You will hear the story this afternoon."
tr: While proudly putting his precious memories into his pocket, he said, "I have an important request from you," "that's why I thought you should get to know me a little." I don't want you to think that I am an ordinary person. As you can understand, since I have been wandering around like this to forget that painful event that happened to me, I often find myself among strangers I don't know." He paused, then soon said, "I will convey my request to you in the afternoon."
es: —I'm going to ask you for a big favor today —he said, while he put his memories back into his pocket with satisfaction—, and that's why I thought you should know something about me. I didn't want you to think that I'm a nobody. You see, I usually mingle with strangers because I go from one place to another trying to forget that very sad thing that happened to me once —he hesitated—. This afternoon you will know what it was.

en: “At lunch?”
vi: "At lunch?"
tr: “At dinner?”
es: —At lunch?

en: “No, this afternoon. I happened to find out that you’re taking Miss Baker to tea.”
vi: "No, this afternoon." "I happened to find out that you have an appointment with Miss Baker to have tea."
tr: “No, after dinner. In the meantime, don't think I didn't hear you invite Mrs. Baker for tea.”
es: —No, this afternoon. I found out by chance that you are having tea with Miss Baker.

en: “Do you mean you’re in love with Miss Baker?”
vi: "Do you mean that you are in love with Miss Baker?"
tr: “Or are you trying to say that you are in love with Miss Baker?”
es: —Do you mean to tell me that you have fallen in love with Miss Baker?

en: “No, old sport, I’m not. But Miss Baker has kindly consented to speak to you about this matter.”
vi: "No, my old friend. I don't have it. However, Miss Baker has kindly agreed to let me talk to you about this matter."
tr: "Ah buddy, definitely no! However, Miss Baker graciously agreed to talk to you about this matter."
es: —No, comrade, no. But Miss Baker has kindly agreed to talk to you about the matter.

en: I hadn’t the faintest idea what “this matter” was, but I was more annoyed than interested. I hadn’t asked Jordan to tea in order to discuss Mr. Jay Gatsby. I was sure the request would be something utterly fantastic, and for a moment I was sorry I’d ever set foot upon his overpopulated lawn.
vi: I have not the slightest idea about "this matter", but I feel more bothered than curious to know. It's not that I invited Jordan for tea to discuss Mr. Gatsby's affairs. I am sure the request must be for something very thrilling, and for a moment I regretted ever stepping onto his crowded lawn.
tr: Although I had no idea what the 'matter' was, I must say that at that moment I felt more anger than curiosity. My intention in inviting Jordan was not to talk about Gatsby. Moreover, for some reason, I was almost certain that Gatsby's request would be quite strange. For a moment, I wished I had never set foot in his crowded garden.
es: I had no idea whatsoever about the nature "of the matter," but I felt more annoyed than interested. I had not invited Jordan for tea to talk about the mysterious Jay Gatsby. I was sure he was going to ask me for something absolutely fantastic and, for a moment, I regretted ever stepping on his overcrowded lawn.

en: He wouldn’t say another word. His correctness grew on him as we neared the city. We passed Port Roosevelt, where there was a glimpse of red-belted oceangoing ships, and sped along a cobbled slum lined with the dark, undeserted saloons of the faded-gilt nineteen-hundreds. Then the valley of ashes opened out on both sides of us, and I had a glimpse of Mrs. Wilson straining at the garage pump with panting vitality as we went by.
vi: Gatsby did not say another word. He looked even more serious and composed as we approached the street. We passed by Roosevelt Harbor where we could catch a glimpse of the ocean liners with red bands painted on their sides. The car sped quickly along a shabby cobblestone street. On both sides of the road were dimly lit but not empty taverns from the bygone golden era of the early 1900s. The valley of ashes began to appear on either side of the road, and I could catch a glimpse of Wilson’s wife working hard at the gas station, her figure breathing heavily with energy as our car passed by.
tr: He had closed the subject without saying anything else. As we approached the city, the silence grew even heavier. While passing through Roosevelt Harbor, ships with red belts moving forward in the ocean appeared for a moment, then we quickly passed through the cobblestone slums lined with dark bars from the 1900s, whose gilding had faded but had not been abandoned. As we passed through the Valley of Ashes stretching on both sides of us, I caught a glimpse of Mrs. Wilson struggling with the pump with great determination and vigor.
es: He did not speak another word. His correctness grew as we approached the city. We passed Port Roosevelt and the sight of its ocean liners painted with a red stripe, and sped through the poor, cobbled streets, flanked by dark bars, still with customers, from the golden and faded early years of the 20th century. Then the valley of ashes opened to the right and left, and, as we crossed it, for a few seconds I glimpsed Mrs. Wilson, bustling at the gas pump with panting vitality.

en: With fenders spread like wings we scattered light through half Astoria—only half, for as we twisted among the pillars of the elevated I heard the familiar “jug-jug-spat!” of a motorcycle, and a frantic policeman rode alongside.
vi: With the fenders flaring out like wings, our car sped along as if scattering light across half of Long Island City. Only halfway there, while our car was still weaving through the high bridge pillars, I heard the familiar explosive sound of a police motorcycle, and a police officer was aggressively riding alongside.
tr: We sped down the Long Island road, the car's fenders spread like wings, cutting through the air as if flying and radiating light. However, halfway there, while navigating the columned curves of the bridge road, we first heard the familiar "pat-pat" sounds of a motorcycle approaching from behind, and then an enraged police officer suddenly appeared beside us.
es: With fenders that stuck out like wings, we splashed light through half of Astoria, only half, because, while we zigzagged between the pillars of the elevated train, I heard the familiar sputtering of a motorcycle, and a frantic policeman was running alongside us.

en: “All right, old sport,” called Gatsby. We slowed down. Taking a white card from his wallet, he waved it before the man’s eyes.
vi: "Alright, old sport." Gatsby said loudly, slowing down the car. Taking out a white card from his pocket, Gatsby held it up and waved it in front of the policeman.
tr: Gatsby called out, "Alright, got it buddy," pulled over, and shoved a white business card from his wallet under the man's nose.
es: —Very well, old sport! —shouted Gatsby. We reduced the speed. He took a white card out of his wallet and waved it in front of the driver's eyes.

en: “Right you are,” agreed the policeman, tipping his cap. “Know you next time, Mr. Gatsby. Excuse me!”
vi: "Alright." The police officer agreed, lightly touching his hat in salute. "Next time I will recognize you, Mr. Gatsby. Sorry."
tr: “I understand, sir,” said the policeman, touching his hat and saluting, “Rest assured that I will recognize you next time, Mr. Gatsby, my apologies.” “What was that?” “Did you show a picture from Oxford or something?” I said.
es: —Everything is in order —admitted the policeman, taking his hand to his cap—. I will recognize you next time, Mister Gatsby. Excuse me!

en: “What was that?” I inquired. “The picture of Oxford?”
vi: "What is that?" I boldly asked. "Is that a picture of Oxford?"
tr: “What was that?” “Did you show a picture from Oxford or something?” I said.
es: —What have you shown him? The photo of Oxford?

en: “I was able to do the commissioner a favour once, and he sends me a Christmas card every year.”
vi: "I once helped a councilman and he sends me a Christmas card every year."
tr: “I once did a favor for the chief of police, and he, bless him, never fails to send me a greeting card every Christmas.”
es: —Once I had the chance to do a favor for the chief of police, and he sends me a Christmas card every year.

en: Over the great bridge, with the sunlight through the girders making a constant flicker upon the moving cars, with the city rising up across the river in white heaps and sugar lumps all built with a wish out of nonolfactory money. The city seen from the Queensboro Bridge is always the city seen for the first time, in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world.
vi: Walking across the large bridge, sunlight streamed through the beams, creating shimmering, dancing rays continuously on the moving vehicles. On the other side of the river, the city slowly rose before the eyes like white blocks and like sugar cubes built up through a wish from scentless coins. The city, when viewed from the Queensboro Bridge, always seemed like it was being seen for the first time, with a wild promise to offer us the mysteries and beauties of the world.
tr: The city appeared on the other side of the river with its white buildings resembling piles of sugar cubes, as the sunlight filtered through the beams of the large bridge and shimmered on the cars moving over it. It was unknown with what money these buildings were constructed, after all, money has no smell. 2 The author uses the phrase "non-olfactory money" to reference the Latin saying "Pecunia non olet," which means "money does not smell." This saying emphasizes that money retains its value regardless of its source. Sometimes, it also alludes to dubious earnings. Translator's Note Every time I cross the Queensboro Bridge, I look at New York as if I am seeing the city for the first time; its view promises that all the mysteries and beauties of the world are waiting for you there.
es: On the great bridge, the sunlight flickered endlessly through the beams over the moving cars, and the city rose on the other side of the river in white clusters, in sugar lumps built, as if by a wish, with odorless money. The city seen from the Queensboro Bridge is always the city seen for the first time, virgin in its first promise of all the mysterious and wonderful things in the world.

en: A dead man passed us in a hearse heaped with blooms, followed by two carriages with drawn blinds, and by more cheerful carriages for friends. The friends looked out at us with the tragic eyes and short upper lips of southeastern Europe, and I was glad that the sight of Gatsby’s splendid car was included in their sombre holiday. As we crossed Blackwell’s Island a limousine passed us, driven by a white chauffeur, in which sat three modish negroes, two bucks and a girl. I laughed aloud as the yolks of their eyeballs rolled toward us in haughty rivalry.
vi: A funeral procession passed by in a hearse filled with flowers, followed by two horse-drawn carriages with closed curtains, and then more carriages carrying friends who seemed more cheerful. These friends looked up at us with sorrowful eyes, their short upper lips characteristic of the people from Southeastern Europe. I was also glad that the image of Gatsby's splendid car was included in their somber and gloomy funeral day. As we passed by Blackwell's Island, a limousine sped past our car. The driver was a white man, and inside were three black people dressed in the latest fashion, two young men and a girl. I burst out laughing when I saw their eyes glaring at us with envious arrogance.
tr: A funeral vehicle adorned with flowers passed by us, followed by two cars with closed curtains, and immediately after, vehicles that did not appear as mournful as the others. The passengers turned to look at us with sorrowful eyes and the narrow upper lips characteristic of Southeastern Europe. I was glad that Gatsby’s magnificent car was included in this sorrowful scene. As we passed Blackwell Island, a limousine driven by a white chauffeur and carrying three Black individuals—two women and one man—dressed in the latest fashion, passed by us. When they turned their haughty gazes towards us, as if wanting to race, I burst into loud laughter.
es: A dead man passed us in a flower-covered hearse, followed by two carriages with drawn curtains, and by more lively carriages for the friends. The friends, who had the very thin upper lip typical of southeastern Europe, gave us tragic looks, and I was glad that the sight of Gatsby's splendid car was included in their somber procession. When we were crossing Blackwell’s Island, a limousine driven by a white chauffeur passed us, carrying three very fashionable black people, two boys and a girl. I laughed out loud when their eyes turned towards us like eggs with proud rivalry.

en: “Anything can happen now that we’ve slid over this bridge,” I thought; “anything at all…”
vi: "Now Once my car has crossed the bridge, anything can happen." I thought. "Anything at all..."
tr: “Remember how we crossed that bridge as if we were flying,” I thought to myself, “now anything could happen... Absolutely anything!”
es: "Everything is possible now that we have crossed this bridge," I thought; "absolutely everything."

en: Even Gatsby could happen, without any particular wonder.
vi: "Even Gatsby, there was nothing particularly extraordinary."
tr: Even becoming a man like Gatsby was possible, nothing would surprise me anymore.
es: Even Gatsby was possible, without any particular astonishment.

en: Roaring noon. In a well-fanned Forty-second Street cellar I met Gatsby for lunch. Blinking away the brightness of the street outside, my eyes picked him out obscurely in the anteroom, talking to another man.
vi: In the noisy and bustling noon, under the breezy Forty-second Street tunnel, I arranged to meet Gatsby for lunch. After blinking away the dazzling sunlight outside, my eyes adjusted to recognize him in the dim outer room, conversing with another man.
tr: During the noisy lunchtime hours, I met Gatsby for lunch in the basement of a well-ventilated restaurant on 42nd Street. As I entered from the bright street, blinking my eyes and looking around, I saw him right at the entrance, talking to someone.
es: Excellent noon. In a well-ventilated cellar on Forty-second Street, I met Gatsby for lunch. Blinking to get the street light out of my eyes, I glimpsed him in the anteroom. He was talking to another man.

en: “Mr. Carraway, this is my friend Mr. Wolfshiem.”
vi: "Mr. Carraway, this is my friend, Mr. Wolfsheim."
tr: “Mr. Carraway, this is my friend Mr. Wolfshiem.”
es: —Mr. Carraway, let me introduce you to my friend Mr. Wolfshiem.

en: A small, flat-nosed Jew raised his large head and regarded me with two fine growths of hair which luxuriated in either nostril. After a moment I discovered his tiny eyes in the half-darkness.
vi: A small Jewish man, with a flat nose, raised his big head to greet me with two tufts of lush nose hair sticking out from his nostrils. It took me a while to see his tiny eyes in the half-light, half-darkness. ".. Then I watched him."
tr: When the flat and small-nosed Jew lifted his rather large head, the first thing that caught my attention were the tufts of hair protruding from his nostrils, and in that dim light, it was only after a while that I could distinguish his eyes.
es: A small and stocky Jewish man lifted his large head and looked at me with two impressive tufts of hair that grew generously in his nostrils. It took me a few seconds to discover his little eyes in the semi-darkness.

en: “—So I took one look at him,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, shaking my hand earnestly, “and what do you think I did?”
vi: Mr. Wolssheim said as he shook my hand eagerly.
tr: “I glanced at the man,” he said, while firmly shaking my hand. “What do you think I did next?”
es: —… So I looked at him —said Mr. Wolfshiem, shaking my hand vigorously—, and what do you think I did?

en: “What?” I inquired politely.
vi: "And do you know what I thought?" "What are you thinking?" I asked politely.
tr: “What did you do?” I asked politely.
es: —What? —I asked out of courtesy.

en: But evidently he was not addressing me, for he dropped my hand and covered Gatsby with his expressive nose.
vi: It was clear that he was not talking to me, because he let go of my hand and directed his highly expressive nose towards Gatsby.
tr: However, she made it clear that she was not talking to me by letting go of my hand and turning her magnificent nose towards Gatsby.
es: But it was evident that he wasn't addressing me, because he let go of my hand and pointed at Gatsby with his very expressive nose.

en: “I handed the money to Katspaugh and I said: ‘All right, Katspaugh, don’t pay him a penny till he shuts his mouth.’ He shut it then and there.”
vi: "I handed the money to Katspaugh and I said, 'Alright, Katspaugh, don't give him a single penny until he shuts up.' So he shut up immediately, right on the spot."
tr: “After giving the money to Katspaugh, I said, ‘Alright Katspaugh, then don't give him a single penny unless he keeps his mouth shut tight!’ And at that moment, right there, he fell silent.”
es: —I gave the money to Katspaugh and told him, "Alright, Katspaugh, don't pay him a cent until he shuts his mouth." He shut it immediately.

en: Gatsby took an arm of each of us and moved forward into the restaurant, whereupon Mr. Wolfshiem swallowed a new sentence he was starting and lapsed into a somnambulatory abstraction.
vi: Gatsby took both our arms and led us inside the restaurant. At that moment, Mr. Wolfsheim had to swallow a sentence he was about to say and let himself fall into a state like sleepwalking.
tr: Bay Wolfsheim was about to start a new sentence when Gatsby took both of us by the arm and led us towards the inner parts of the restaurant, upon which the man swallowed his words and his face took on the absent expression of a sleepwalker.
es: Gatsby took us by the arm and led us toward the dining room, and Mr. Wolfshiem, swallowing a phrase he had just begun, remained lost in thought, like a sleepwalker.

en: “Highballs?” asked the head waiter.
vi: "Whiskey soda?" the waiter asked.
tr: The head waiter approached and asked, "Would you like some whiskey?"
es: —Whiskey with soda and ice? —asked the maître d'.

en: “This is a nice restaurant here,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, looking at the presbyterian nymphs on the ceiling. “But I like across the street better!”
vi: "This restaurant is beautiful." Wolfsheim said, looking up at the paintings of goddesses from the religion depicted on the ceiling. "But I prefer the restaurant across the street!" "Yes, give me a whiskey soda."
tr: “This is a nice place,” said Mr. Wolfsheim, looking at the pictures of women on the ceiling, “still, I prefer the place across the street.”
es: —This restaurant is fine —said Mr. Wolfshiem, looking at the Presbyterian nymphs on the ceiling—. But I like the one across the street better.

en: “Yes, highballs,” agreed Gatsby, and then to Mr. Wolfshiem: “It’s too hot over there.”
vi: Gatsby replied, then turned to Wolfsheim. "It's very hot over there."
tr: Gatsby called the waiter.
es: —Yes, whiskey with soda —Gatsby nodded, and to Mr. Wolfshiem—. It's too hot in the one across the street.

en: “Hot and small—yes,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “but full of memories.”
vi: "That's right, hot and small." Wolfsheim said. "But full of memories."
tr: “Yes, whiskey,” he said, then turned to Mr. Wolfsheim; “Isn't it very hot there?” “You are right, it is warm and small,” said the man, “but it is filled with memories.”
es: —It's hot and small, yes —said Mr. Wolfshiem—, but it's full of memories.

en: “What place is that?” I asked.
vi: "Which restaurant is that?" I asked.
tr: "Where is this place you mentioned?" I asked.
es: —What place is this? —I asked.

en: “The old Metropole.”
vi: "The old Metropole restaurant." "The old Metropole."
tr: “Old Metropole,” said Mr. Wolfsheim to himself, “Full of partings...
es: —The old Metropole.

en: “The old Metropole,” brooded Mr. Wolfshiem gloomily. “Filled with faces dead and gone. Filled with friends gone now forever. I can’t forget so long as I live the night they shot Rosy Rosenthal there. It was six of us at the table, and Rosy had eat and drunk a lot all evening. When it was almost morning the waiter came up to him with a funny look and says somebody wants to speak to him outside. ‘All right,’ says Rosy, and begins to get up, and I pulled him down in his chair.
vi: Wolfsheim pondered sadly. "Filled with images of faces long gone. Filled with the shadows of friends who have departed forever. As long as I live, I can never forget the night they shot Rosy Rosenthal there. There were six of us sitting at the table, and Rosy had eaten and drunk a lot that night. As dawn was approaching, the waiter came over to him with a strange look and said that someone wanted to talk to him outside. "Alright." Rosy said and began to stand up. I pulled him back into his seat."
tr: “Old Metropole,” said Mr. Wolfsheim to himself, “Full of partings... With memories of many friends we have bid farewell to for eternity... I can never forget the night Rosy Rosenthal was shot. There were six of us. Rosenthal had been eating and drinking all night, and just as it was almost morning, a waiter approached him with a strange expression on his face and told him that someone was waiting outside to see him. When Rosenthal said, ‘Okay,’ and tried to get up, I grabbed his arm and sat him back down, saying, ‘If those bastards want you so much, let them come to you, for my sake, don’t go anywhere!’
es: —The old Metropole —repeated Mr. Wolfshiem sadly and pensively—. Full of dead and disappeared faces. Full of friends who are gone forever. I will never forget the night they killed Rosy Rosenthal as long as I live. There were six of us at the table, and Rosy had eaten and drunk a lot that night. When it was almost daylight, the waiter approached him with a strange gesture and told him that someone wanted to talk to him outside. “Very well,” said Rosy, and began to get up.

en: “ ‘Let the bastards come in here if they want you, Rosy, but don’t you, so help me, move outside this room.’
vi: "Let those bastards in if they want, Rosy, but please help me, don't leave this room."
tr: When Rosenthal said, ‘Okay,’ and tried to get up, I grabbed his arm and sat him back down, saying, ‘If those bastards want you so much, let them come to you, for my sake, don’t go anywhere!’
es: I forced him to sit down: “Let those sons of bitches come here if they want to see you, Rosy, but don’t you dare leave this room.”

en: “It was four o’clock in the morning then, and if we’d of raised the blinds we’d of seen daylight.”
vi: "It was four in the morning, and if we had drawn the curtains to look, we could have seen the sunlight."
tr: “It was past four o'clock; if the curtains were opened, we might have seen that it was almost daylight.”
es: It was four in the morning, and if we had raised the blinds, we would have seen the daylight.

en: “Did he go?” I asked innocently.
vi: "Did he go outside?" I asked innocently.
tr: “So, has Rosenthal left?” I asked innocently.
es: —And did he leave? —I asked innocently.

en: “Sure he went.” Mr. Wolfshiem’s nose flashed at me indignantly. “He turned around in the door and says: ‘Don’t let that waiter take away my coffee!’ Then he went out on the sidewalk, and they shot him three times in his full belly and drove away.”
vi: "He definitely left, didn't he." Wolfsheim's nose turned towards me indignantly. "When he reached the door, he turned around and said, 'Don't let the waiter take my coffee cup away!' Then he went out onto the sidewalk, and they shot him three times right in his full belly before driving away."
tr: “He went out!” Mr. Wolfsheim's nose turned to me in a fury. “In fact, as he approached the door, he turned to us and said, ‘Watch my coffee, don't let the waiter take it back!’ Then he went outside and stepped off the sidewalk, and at that moment, the men shot him three times in the stomach and fled.”
es: —Of course he went out —Mr. Wolfshiem's nose pointed sharply at me, indignant—. He turned at the door and said: "Don't let the waiter take my coffee!" Then he went out to the sidewalk, got shot three times in the belly, and they fled.

en: “Four of them were electrocuted,” I said, remembering.
vi: "The four of them were later executed by electric chair." I continued, recalling the story.
tr: “But all four were caught and executed in the electric chair,” I said, recalling.
es: —They electrocuted four —I said, trying to remember.

en: “Five, with Becker.” His nostrils turned to me in an interested way. “I understand you’re looking for a business gonnegtion.”
vi: "Yes, including Becker." His nostrils flared towards me with interest. "As far as I know, you're looking for a business connection."
tr: “Including Becker, that makes five,” he said, turning his nostrils towards me, “As far as I understand, you are trying to establish some business connections.”
es: —Five, counting Becker —the nostrils flared with interest before me—. I understand that you are looking for connections for your business.

en: The juxtaposition of these two remarks was startling. Gatsby answered for me:
vi: These two consecutive sentences surprised me. Gatsby answered for me.
tr: I was truly surprised by the way these two sentences were connected to each other. However, Gatsby answered this question in my place, "No, it's someone else."
es: The juxtaposition of those two sentences left me perplexed. Gatsby answered for me.

en: “Oh, no,” he exclaimed, “this isn’t the man.”
vi: "Oh, no, not this person."
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Ah, no —he exclaimed—. This is not it.

en: “No?” Mr. Wolfshiem seemed disappointed.
vi: "Isn't it?" Wolfsheim looked disappointed.
tr: He seemed disappointed.
es: —No? —Mr. Wolfshiem seemed disappointed.

en: “This is just a friend. I told you we’d talk about that some other time.”
vi: "This guy is just a friend." "I told you, we will talk about that later."
tr: “This gentleman is a friend of mine. I had told you that we would discuss that matter later.”
es: —He's just a friend. I already told you that we would talk about that another time.

en: “I beg your pardon,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “I had a wrong man.”
vi: "I'm sorry, I mistook you for someone else." Wolfsheim said.
tr: “Sorry, it seems I misunderstood.”
es: —I apologize —said Mr. Wolfshiem—. I was mistaken.

en: A succulent hash arrived, and Mr. Wolfshiem, forgetting the more sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole, began to eat with ferocious delicacy. His eyes, meanwhile, roved very slowly all around the room—he completed the arc by turning to inspect the people directly behind. I think that, except for my presence, he would have taken one short glance beneath our own table.
vi: The delicious minced meat dish was served, Wolfsheim had forgotten the sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole restaurant, and began to eat politely but vigorously. While eating, his eyes slowly rolled around the room, ending his gaze by examining the people sitting right behind him. I suppose, because of my presence, otherwise he would have also glanced under the table he was sitting at.
tr: With the arrival of the delicious dishes, Mr. Wolfsheim had forgotten the sentimental memories of the old Metropole and had hurriedly started eating; he did not neglect to glance around from time to time; finally, he completed his exploration by turning and looking sideways at those sitting behind him. He probably would have bent down to look under the table if I hadn't been there.
es: A succulent stew arrived, and Mr. Wolfshiem, forgetting the sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole, began to eat with a fierce delicacy. His eyes, meanwhile, slowly scanned the entire place. And, to complete the arc, he turned to inspect the people behind him. I believe that, if I hadn't been present, he would have taken a look under the table.

en: “Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”
vi: "Listen here, old sport." Gatsby said, leaning towards me. "I'm afraid I made you a bit upset this morning while we were in the car."
tr: “This morning in the car,” said Gatsby, leaning towards me, “I didn't upset you, did I?”
es: —Listen, old sport —said Gatsby, leaning towards me—. I'm afraid I bothered you this morning in the car.

en: There was the smile again, but this time I held out against it.
vi: The old smile appeared again, but this time I resisted it.
tr: There was that smile on his face again!
es: There was the smile again, but this time I did not give in.

en: “I don’t like mysteries,” I answered, “and I don’t understand why you won’t come out frankly and tell me what you want. Why has it all got to come through Miss Baker?”
vi: "I don't like mysteries." I replied. "And I don't understand why you can't just tell me directly what you want. Why go through Miss Baker?"
tr: But this time I was determined to resist, "Frankly, I don't like secrets," I replied, "I don't understand why you don't tell me what you want directly, why use Miss Baker as an intermediary?"
es: —I don't like mysteries —I replied—, and I don't understand why you don't speak to me frankly and tell me what you want. Why does Miss Baker have to tell me?

en: “Oh, it’s nothing underhand,” he assured me. “Miss Baker’s a great sportswoman, you know, and she’d never do anything that wasn’t all right.”
vi: "Oh, there's nothing clandestine or shady at all." Gatsby reassured me. "Miss Baker is a famous athlete, you know, she wouldn't do anything if it wasn't proper."
tr: "Hey man, don't you dare think this is a shady business!" he tried to encourage me. "You know that Baker is a great athlete, he never gets involved in wrongdoings."
es: —It's nothing shady —he assured me—. Miss Baker is a great athlete, you know, and she would never do anything wrong.

en: Suddenly he looked at his watch, jumped up, and hurried from the room, leaving me with Mr. Wolfshiem at the table.
vi: Suddenly Gatsby looked at the clock and then stood up, hurriedly leaving the room, leaving me and Wolfsheim still at the table.
tr: Then he looked at his watch, suddenly jumped up, and left, leaving me alone with Mr. Wolfsheim.
es: Suddenly he looked at the clock, jumped to his feet, and rushed out of the room, leaving me with Mr. Wolfshiem at the table.

en: “He has to telephone,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, following him with his eyes. “Fine fellow, isn’t he? Handsome to look at and a perfect gentleman.”
vi: "He has to make a phone call." Wolfsheim said, eyes following Gatsby. "He is quite a young man, isn't he? A man both handsome and entirely courteous."
tr: “Someone needs to make a phone call,” said Wolfsheim as he watched him with his eyes, “Isn't he such a nice person? Very handsome, and a complete gentleman too.”
es: —He has to make a phone call —said Mr. Wolfshiem, following him with his gaze—. A great guy, isn't he? It's a pleasure to see him and he is a perfect gentleman.

en: “Yes.”
vi: "That's right."
tr: “Yes.”
es: —Yes.

en: “He’s an Oggsford man.”
vi: "He is from Oggsford"
tr: “Yes.”
es: —He studied at Oggsford.

en: “Oh!”
vi: "Oh, really"
tr: “And from Oxford too!” “Yes?”
es: —Ah!

en: “He went to Oggsford College in England. You know Oggsford College?”
vi: "He studied at Oggsford in England." "Do you know the school Oggsford?"
tr: “Yes, he graduated from Ogsford College in England. Do you know Ogsford?”
es: —He went to Oggsford College, in England. Do you know Oggsford College?

en: “I’ve heard of it.”
vi: "I have heard about this school."
tr: “I had heard.”
es: —I've heard something.

en: “It’s one of the most famous colleges in the world.”
vi: "It is one of the most famous universities in the world."
tr: “It is one of the most famous schools in the world.”
es: —It is one of the most famous colleges in the world.

en: “Have you known Gatsby for a long time?” I inquired.
vi: "Have you known Gatsby for a long time?" I probed.
tr: “How long have you known Gatsby?” I asked.
es: —Have you known Gatsby for long? —I asked.

en: “Several years,” he answered in a gratified way. “I made the pleasure of his acquaintance just after the war. But I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding after I talked with him an hour. I said to myself: ‘There’s the kind of man you’d like to take home and introduce to your mother and sister.’ ” He paused. “I see you’re looking at my cuff buttons.”
vi: "Many years now." Wolfsheim replied contentedly. "I am glad to have known him, right after the war. Only after talking to him for about an hour, I knew I had discovered an outstanding young man. I told myself: 'This is the kind of young man I want to bring home to introduce to my mother and sister.'" Wolfsheim paused for a moment. "I noticed you were looking at my cufflinks."
tr: “For many years,” he said proudly, “I had the honor of meeting him right after the war. An hour of conversation was enough for me to understand that the person in front of me was a nobleman. To myself, I said, ‘This is the kind of gentleman you can invite to your home and introduce to your mother and sister.’” After pausing for a moment, he said, “I see you are looking at my cufflinks.”
es: —Several years —he replied, pleased—. I had the pleasure of meeting him just after the war ended. But I knew that I had discovered a man of excellent upbringing after talking to him for an hour. I said to myself: "This is the kind of man you would happily take home and introduce to your mother and sister" —he paused—. I see you are looking at my cufflinks.

en: I hadn’t been looking at them, but I did now. They were composed of oddly familiar pieces of ivory.
vi: In fact, I wasn't looking, but hearing him say that, I now turned to look. They were made from pieces of ivory in shapes not commonly seen.
tr: Actually, I wasn't looking, but naturally, I looked after hearing those words; they resembled ivory, but for some reason, they seemed very familiar.
es: I was not looking at the binoculars, but then I looked at them. They were made with strangely familiar pieces of ivory.

en: “Finest specimens of human molars,” he informed me.
vi: "They are the most beautiful molars of a human." He informed me.
tr: “These are perfect examples of human teeth,” he informed me.
es: —The finest specimens of human molars —he informed me. —Don't tell me!

en: “Well!” I inspected them. “That’s a very interesting idea.”
vi: "Wow!" I observed. "This is really an amusing initiative."
tr: “Very interesting,” I said, examining it more closely, “An extraordinary idea.”
es: —I examined them—. It's a very interesting idea.

en: “Yeah.” He flipped his sleeves up under his coat. “Yeah, Gatsby’s very careful about women. He would never so much as look at a friend’s wife.”
vi: "That's right." Wolfsheim flipped the two flaps of his coat sleeves outward. "Yes, Gatsby was very cautious about women. He would even avoid looking at your wife."
tr: “Very interesting,” I said, examining it more closely, “An extraordinary idea.” “Indeed it is!” he said, tugging his cuffs inside his jacket. “What were we saying, oh yes, Gatsby is extremely careful when it comes to women, he doesn't even glance at his friends' wives.”
es: —Yes —he quickly covered the cuffs of his shirt with the sleeves of his jacket—. Yes, Gatsby is very respectful towards women. He wouldn't even dare to look at a friend's wife.

en: When the subject of this instinctive trust returned to the table and sat down Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee with a jerk and got to his feet.
vi: When this trustworthy character being talked about returned to sit at the table, Mr. Wolfsheim suddenly drank up his coffee and then stood up.
tr: As soon as Gatsby, who had been deemed worthy of this great trust and praise, returned to the table, Mr. Wolfsheim finished his coffee in one gulp and hurriedly stood up.
es: When the one deserving of that instinctive trust returned and sat at the table, Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee in one gulp and stood up.

en: “I have enjoyed my lunch,” he said, “and I’m going to run off from you two young men before I outstay my welcome.”
vi: "This lunch is very delicious." He said. "But now I must part ways with you before you consider me a nuisance."
tr: “The meal was wonderful. However, I don't want to overstay my welcome, so it would be best if I leave promptly and let you two young men have some time alone.”
es: —It has been a pleasure eating with you —he said—, but I am going to leave you. You are young, and I don't want you to consider me a bore.

en: “Don’t hurry Meyer,” said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mr. Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of benediction.
vi: "There's no need to hurry, Meyer." Gatsby said, but he didn't seem very eager. Mr. Wolfsheim raised his arm in a gesture of salute.
tr: “There was no need, Meyer,” said Gatsby half-heartedly, while Mr. Wolfsheim raised his hand as if preparing to bless us,
es: —Don't be in a hurry, Meyer —said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mister Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of blessing.

en: “You’re very polite, but I belong to another generation,” he announced solemnly. “You sit here and discuss your sports and your young ladies and your—” He supplied an imaginary noun with another wave of his hand. “As for me, I am fifty years old, and I won’t impose myself on you any longer.”
vi: "You are very polite, but I belong to a different generation." He declared solemnly. "You two can sit here and discuss sports, music, and..." He replaced his last imaginative noun with another wave of his hand. "As for me, I am fifty years old, I don't want to bother you any longer."
tr: “You are very kind, but you know, there is a generation gap,” he said with a serious demeanor, “You young people have a lot to talk about among yourselves; the sports you do, the ladies you meet, then…” after raising his hand and waving it once more in an ambiguous gesture, “as for me, I am a man nearing fifty, our time has passed…” I won't take up more of your time.”
es: —You are very kind, but I belong to another generation —he announced solemnly—. You stay here and talk about your amusements, your friends, your… —a vague hand gesture replaced an imaginary name—. As for me, I am fifty years old and I do not want to keep imposing my presence on you.

en: As he shook hands and turned away his tragic nose was trembling. I wondered if I had said anything to offend him.
vi: When Wolfsheim shook hands in farewell and turned to leave, his pitiable nose quivered. I wondered if I had said something to offend him.
tr: Then we shook hands, and just as he was turning away, his strange nose seemed to be twitching; I wondered if I had said something that hurt his feelings.
es: When he shook our hand and turned away, his tragic nose was trembling. I wondered if I had said something that could have offended him.

en: “He becomes very sentimental sometimes,” explained Gatsby. “This is one of his sentimental days. He’s quite a character around New York—a denizen of Broadway.”
vi: "Sometimes he becomes very sentimental," Gatsby explained. "Today is one of his sentimental days. He is truly a special character in New York, a resident of Broadway."
tr: "He gets sentimental from time to time," Gatsby explained, "and it seems today is one of those days. He is known in New York, but actually, he is from Broadway."
es: —Sometimes he gets very sentimental —Gatsby explained to me—. Today is one of his sentimental days. He's quite a character in New York, a neighbor of Broadway.

en: “Who is he, anyhow, an actor?”
vi: "Who is he, an actor?"
tr: “What does he do? Is he an actor?”
es: —Is he an actor?

en: “No.”
vi: "No."
tr: “Ah, no.”
es: —No.

en: “A dentist?”
vi: "Dentist?"
tr: “Dentist?”
es: —Dentist?

en: “Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he’s a gambler.” Gatsby hesitated, then added, coolly: “He’s the man who fixed the World’s Series back in 1919.”
vi: "Myer Wolfsheim? No, he's a gambler." Gatsby hesitated, then added coldly. "He was the man who fixed the 1919 World Series."
tr: “Is it Meyer? What nonsense! He's a gambler,” he said, and after a moment's hesitation, he calmly added, “He is the one who rigged the 1919 Baseball Tournament.”
es: —Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he is a gambler —Gatsby hesitated before adding coldly—. He is the man who fixed the 1919 World Series.

en: “Fixed the World’s Series?” I repeated.
vi: "Arrangements before the World Baseball Classic?" I repeated.
tr: “Did he rig the tournament?” I repeated.
es: —Did you rig the final series? —I repeated.

en: The idea staggered me. I remembered, of course, that the World’s Series had been fixed in 1919, but if I had thought of it at all I would have thought of it as a thing that merely happened, the end of some inevitable chain. It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of fifty million people—with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe.
vi: This understanding stunned me. Of course, I remembered that the 1919 World Series had been fixed, but if I could think about it, I would only consider it a natural event, the result of a series of ordinary developments. In my mind, there had never been the idea that a man could deceive the trust of fifty million people with the same purpose as a thief cracking a safe.
tr: I was astonished by what I heard. Of course, I was aware of the match-fixing in the 1919 Tournament, but since I probably thought it was just a link in a long chain, I dismissed it by saying it just happened and didn't dwell on it much. It never crossed my mind that this was orchestrated by a single person, who, with the precision and skill of a safecracker, could deceive fifty million people.
es: The idea left me stunned. I remembered, of course, that in 1919 they rigged the championship, but if I had thought about it, it would have seemed like something that just happened, the final link in an inevitable chain. It would never have occurred to me that a man could play with the good faith of fifty million people with the determination of a thief cracking a safe.

en: “How did he happen to do that?” I asked after a minute.
vi: "How could he do that?" After a moment, I asked.
tr: A little later, I asked, "How did he do it?"
es: —How did you come up with doing something like that? —I asked.

en: “He just saw the opportunity.”
vi: "When the opportunity presents itself, he seizes it."
tr: “He just saw the opportunity and took advantage of it.”
es: —The opportunity presented itself.

en: “Why isn’t he in jail?”
vi: "Why wasn't he imprisoned?"
tr: “So why isn't it inside?”
es: —Why isn't he in jail?

en: “They can’t get him, old sport. He’s a smart man.”
vi: "They cannot catch him, old friend. He is a clever man."
tr: “They can't prove it, buddy. What a cunning man he is!”
es: —They can't catch him, buddy. He's smart.

en: I insisted on paying the check. As the waiter brought my change I caught sight of Tom Buchanan across the crowded room.
vi: I was determined to pay for the meal. When the waiter brought the change back, I recognized the figure of Tom Buchanan on the other side of the crowded room.
tr: I insisted on the bill; at the moment the waiter brought my change, I saw Tom Buchanan sitting at the other end of the crowded restaurant.
es: I insisted on paying the bill. When the waiter gave me the change, I discovered Tom Buchanan at the back of the crowded place.

en: “Come along with me for a minute,” I said; “I’ve got to say hello to someone.”
vi: "Follow me here for a minute." I said. "I have to go greet this person."
tr: "Will you accompany me?" I said to Gatsby, "I need to greet someone."
es: —Accompany me for a moment —I said—. I have to greet someone.

en: When he saw us Tom jumped up and took half a dozen steps in our direction.
vi: Just then, Tom recognized us, he immediately stood up and took five or six steps towards us.
tr: At that moment, Tom saw us and took a few steps to come towards us.
es: Tom saw us, stood up, and took a few steps towards us.

en: “Where’ve you been?” he demanded eagerly. “Daisy’s furious because you haven’t called up.”
vi: "Where have you been lately?" Tom asked eagerly. "Daisy is upset because you haven't called in a long time."
tr: "Where have you been?" he snapped, "Daisy is very upset that you haven't been visiting, just so you know."
es: —Where have you been? —he asked warmly—. Daisy is furious because you haven't called us.

en: “This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.”
vi: "I introduce, this is Mr. Gatsby and this is Mr. Buchanan."
tr: “This is Mr. Gatsby, and this is Mr. Buchanan,” I introduced them.
es: —I present to you Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.

en: They shook hands briefly, and a strained, unfamiliar look of embarrassment came over Gatsby’s face.
vi: The two of them shook hands briefly, awkwardly, an embarrassed look appearing on Gatsby's face.
tr: As they shook hands; I had noticed an expression of shame on Gatsby's face that I had never seen before.
es: They shook hands briefly, and Gatsby's face took on an expression of discomfort and tension that I had not seen before.

en: “How’ve you been, anyhow?” demanded Tom of me. “How’d you happen to come up this far to eat?”
vi: "How have you been lately?" Tom asked me. "What brings you all the way here to eat?"
tr: "How are you?" asked Tom, "You didn't come all this way just for the food, did you?"
es: —Where have you been? —Tom insisted—. What made you think of coming to eat so far away?

en: “I’ve been having lunch with Mr. Gatsby.”
vi: "I went to have lunch with Mr. Gatsby."
tr: “I am with Mr. Gatsby,” I said, turning around, but Gatsby had disappeared.
es: —I have come to dine with Mr. Gatsby.

en: I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.
vi: I turned to Gatsby but he was no longer standing there.
tr: “I am with Mr. Gatsby,” I said, turning around, but Gatsby had disappeared.
es: I turned toward Gatsby, but he was no longer there.

en: One October day in nineteen-seventeen—
vi: One day in October of the year one thousand nine hundred and seventeen.....
tr: "It was the year 1917, an October morning – (Jordan Baker had started to speak, sitting upright in one of the stiff chairs in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel that same afternoon) – I was walking somewhere, partly on the sidewalk, partly on the grass.
es: One day in October of 1917... (said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting very straight in a chair at the outdoor café of the Plaza Hotel)...

en: (said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting up very straight on a straight chair in the tea-garden at the Plaza Hotel)
vi: (That afternoon, sitting very upright on a straight-backed chair in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel, Jordan began to tell the story).
tr: "It was the year 1917, an October morning – (Jordan Baker had started to speak, sitting upright in one of the stiff chairs in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel that same afternoon) – I was walking somewhere, partly on the sidewalk, partly on the grass.
es: One day in October of 1917... (said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting very straight in a chair at the outdoor café of the Plaza Hotel)...

en: —I was walking along from one place to another, half on the sidewalks and half on the lawns. I was happier on the lawns because I had on shoes from England with rubber knobs on the soles that bit into the soft ground. I had on a new plaid skirt also that blew a little in the wind, and whenever this happened the red, white, and blue banners in front of all the houses stretched out stiff and said tut-tut-tut-tut, in a disapproving way.
vi: "I was wandering around from place to place, sometimes on the sidewalk, sometimes on the grassy areas. I preferred walking on the grass because I was wearing shoes bought from England with rubber soles that easily gripped the soft ground. At that time, I was wearing a plaid skirt that was slightly lifted by the wind. Whenever that happened, the red, white, and blue flags in front of the houses would fly straight out and make a disapproving "tut tut tut tut" sound.
tr: "It was the year 1917, an October morning – (Jordan Baker had started to speak, sitting upright in one of the stiff chairs in the tea garden of the Plaza Hotel that same afternoon) – I was walking somewhere, partly on the sidewalk, partly on the grass. In truth, I was walking more on the grass because I liked how the rubber soles of my English shoes sank into the soft ground. Whenever my pleated skirt seemed about to flutter in the wind, the red, blue, and white flags hanging on the front facades of the houses would also rise, flapping with a pat-pat-pat sound as if mocking me.
es: I was taking a walk, on the sidewalk and on the grass. I liked the grass more because I had some English shoes with rubber studs on the soles that sank into the soft ground. And I had a new Scottish skirt that lifted a bit in the wind while in all the houses the red, white, and blue flags were stretched out and went tut-tut-tut-tut in a tone of disapproval.

en: The largest of the banners and the largest of the lawns belonged to Daisy Fay’s house. She was just eighteen, two years older than me, and by far the most popular of all the young girls in Louisville. She dressed in white, and had a little white roadster, and all day long the telephone rang in her house and excited young officers from Camp Taylor demanded the privilege of monopolizing her that night. “Anyways, for an hour!”
vi: The largest flag and the largest lawn belonged to Daisy Fay's house. At that time, Daisy was only eighteen years old, two years older than you, and was the most famous among the young ladies in Louisville. She always wore white and drove a white two-seater convertible.
