All day long, the phone in her house never stopped ringing, as eager officers from the Taylor military camp called to request the privilege of having Daisy to themselves that evening. "Even if it's just for an hour."
tr: “Both the largest flags and the largest gardens belonged to Daisy Fay's house. She is two years older than me, so she was eighteen at the time. She was the most popular girl in Louisville. She was always dressed in white, and she even had a white, open-top car. Every day, their phone at home would ring incessantly, with young officers in training at the nearby camp competing with each other to get a date with her; in fact, they were even willing to settle for a meeting of just one hour.
es: The largest flag and the largest lawn belonged to Daisy Fay's house. Daisy had just turned eighteen, two years older than me, and was by far the most sought-after girl in Louisville. She dressed in white, had a small convertible, and the phone never stopped ringing at her house: the young officers from Camp Taylor[12] eagerly demanded the privilege of monopolizing Daisy that night. "At least an hour!"

en: When I came opposite her house that morning her white roadster was beside the kerb, and she was sitting in it with a lieutenant I had never seen before. They were so engrossed in each other that she didn’t see me until I was five feet away.
vi: That morning when I passed by Daisy's house, her white convertible was parked close to the sidewalk, and she was sitting in the car with a lieutenant I had never seen before. The two of them were so engrossed in each other that they didn't see me at all. when I was only five steps away from them.
tr: “That morning, while passing by her house, I saw her white car parked by the curb. Daisy was inside, sitting with a lieutenant I saw for the first time that day. They were so engrossed in each other that Daisy didn't notice my approach until I was just two steps away.
es: When I reached the height of her house that morning, the white convertible was next to the curb, and she was sitting at the wheel with a lieutenant whom I had not seen before. They were so absorbed in each other that Daisy did not see me until I was a meter and a half away.

en: “Hello, Jordan,” she called unexpectedly. “Please come here.”
vi: "Hello Jordan." She suddenly called me. "Come here."
tr: “Suddenly, I heard him call out, 'Oh, Hello Jordan,' to be honest, I wasn't expecting that at all, 'Come here!'
es: —Hello, Jordan —he shouted unexpectedly—. Come.

en: I was flattered that she wanted to speak to me, because of all the older girls I admired her most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandages. I was. Well, then, would I tell them that she couldn’t come that day? The officer looked at Daisy while she was speaking, in a way that every young girl wants to be looked at sometime, and because it seemed romantic to me I have remembered the incident ever since. His name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn’t lay eyes on him again for over four years—even after I’d met him on Long Island I didn’t realize it was the same man.
vi: I feel proud because she wants to talk to me; among the older sisters, I admire her the most. She asked me if I went to the Red Cross to get bandaged. At that time, I was really going. She asked me to tell them that she couldn't come that day. While Daisy was talking, the officer kept looking at her with a gaze that every young girl wishes to be looked at with. That scene looked so romantic and affectionate, it made me remember it forever. His name was Jay Gatsby; after that time, I didn't see him again for about four years until I met him again in Long Island, and I still didn't realize they were the same person.
tr: “The fact that she wanted to talk to me had honored me; after all, among the older girls, she was the one I admired the most. ‘Are you going to the Red Cross to pack bandages?’ she asked. I nodded. She had asked me to convey that she wouldn't be able to come that day. While she was talking to me, the lieutenant next to her was looking at her with such admiration that every young girl would want to be looked at like that at least occasionally. His gaze was so romantic that I never forgot that scene. That lieutenant's name was Jay Gatsby. For the next four years, I didn't see him again. In fact, at the end of those four years, when we were introduced in Long Island, I didn't even realize that he was that lieutenant.
es: I was flattered that she wanted to talk to me, because out of all the older girls, she was the one I admired the most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandage packages. Yes, I was going to the Red Cross. Well, would I mind notifying them that she couldn't go that day? The officer was looking at Daisy while she spoke, in a way that any girl would wish to be looked at at least once, and that moment seemed so romantic to me that I haven't forgotten it. The officer's name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn't lay eyes on him again until four years later. Even when I ran into him again, in Long Island, I didn't realize it was the same man.

en: That was nineteen-seventeen. By the next year I had a few beaux myself, and I began to play in tournaments, so I didn’t see Daisy very often. She went with a slightly older crowd—when she went with anyone at all. Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas. She was effectually prevented, but she wasn’t on speaking terms with her family for several weeks. After that she didn’t play around with the soldiers any more, but only with a few flat-footed, shortsighted young men in town, who couldn’t get into the army at all.
vi: That year was the year one thousand nine hundred and seventeen. By the following year, I had a few suitors and I began to participate in competitions. Therefore, I no longer met Daisy frequently. Daisy rarely played with anyone, only socializing with those slightly older than her. There were fierce rumors about her, saying that one winter night her mother discovered her luggage as she was preparing to go to New York to bid farewell to a soldier about to be deployed overseas. She was stopped from going. This incident caused her not to speak to anyone in the house for many weeks. After that, she no longer kept in touch with the soldiers but only socialized with some clumsy local youths with nearsightedness who couldn't join the army.
tr: “This happened in 1917. A year later, I had a few admirers following me. Meanwhile, I had started playing in golf tournaments, so I rarely saw Daisy. Even if she went out, she would only be with friends older than us. Although we didn't see her much, we constantly heard crazy rumors about her. For instance, according to what was said, one winter night, she was caught by her mother while packing her suitcase to go to New York to say goodbye to an officer who was going overseas. Of course, she was prevented from going. It was said that Daisy was so upset with her family that she didn't speak to them for weeks. According to the rumor, Daisy never saw another soldier after that; she only went out with young men who were flat-footed or nearsighted and thus not drafted.
es: That was in 1917. The following year I also had some admirers, and I started participating in tournaments, so I didn't see much of Daisy. She hung out with a slightly older group, when she went out with anyone. Wild rumors circulated about her, about how her mother had caught her packing to go to New York to see off a soldier bound overseas. They absolutely forbade it, but Daisy didn't speak to her family for weeks. Since then, she didn't flirt with soldiers anymore, only with young men who were nearsighted or flat-footed, unfit for military service.

en: By the next autumn she was gay again, gay as ever. She had a début after the armistice, and in February she was presumably engaged to a man from New Orleans. In June she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago, with more pomp and circumstance than Louisville ever knew before. He came down with a hundred people in four private cars, and hired a whole floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
vi: By the following autumn, Daisy was cheerful again, as cheerful as she used to be. She truly stepped out into the world after the armistice, and by February, she was engaged to a man in New Orleans. But by June, she married Tom Buchanan from Chicago. The wedding was an unprecedentedly lavish and magnificent affair in Louisville. Tom brought down a hundred people in four private train cars and rented an entire floor of the Seelbach Hotel. The day before the wedding, he gave her a pearl necklace worth three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
tr: “In the fall, she regained her old cheerfulness. After the signing of the peace, a ball was held in her honor, and she was formally introduced to society. In February, we heard that she had gotten engaged to someone from New Orleans. In June, she married Tom Buchanan from Chicago in Louisville, in an unprecedented, magnificent ceremony. The groom arrived with a hundred people, in four private cars, and took over an entire floor of the Muhlbach Hotel; the night before the ceremony, he gave Daisy a pearl necklace worth three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
es: By autumn she was cheerful again, more cheerful than ever. She made her social debut after the armistice, and by February she was engaged to a guy from New Orleans, or so it was said. In June she married Tom Buchanan, from Chicago, with pomp and solemnity never before seen in the history of Louisville. The groom arrived with a hundred people in four private cars, and rented an entire floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave the bride a pearl necklace valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

en: I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
vi: I was a bridesmaid. About half an hour before the wedding reception started, I went to Daisy's room and saw her lying on the bed in her floral wedding dress, beautiful as a June night. She was completely drunk, holding a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
tr: “I was one of the bride's bridesmaids. When I went up to her room half an hour before the wedding dinner, I found her lying on her bed, looking as charming as the June sun in her floral dress. She was as drunk as a lord; in one hand she held a bottle of Sauterne, and in the other, a letter.
es: I was one of the bridesmaids. I entered Daisy's bedroom half an hour before the gala dinner that preceded the wedding day and found her lying on the bed, beautiful as a June night in her floral dress... and completely drunk. She had a bottle of Sauternes in one hand and a letter in the other.

en: “ ’Gratulate me,” she muttered. “Never had a drink before, but oh how I do enjoy it.”
vi: "Congratulate me." She whispered. "I have never drunk alcohol in my life, but today I find it very delicious."
tr: ‘Aren't you going to congratulate me?’ he said, slurring his words, ‘I had never drunk before, turns out it's such a nice thing.’
es: —Congra… Congratulate me —he murmured—. I had never drunk before, but I love it.

en: “What’s the matter, Daisy?”
vi: "What happened, Daisy?"
tr: ‘Daisy, what's wrong?’
es: —What's wrong with you, Daisy?

en: I was scared, I can tell you; I’d never seen a girl like that before.
vi: Let me tell you, at that moment I was very scared, I had never seen a girl in such a state.
tr: “I must admit I was very scared; until that moment, I had never seen a girl in such a state.
es: I was really scared. I had never seen a girl like that.

en: “Here, dearies.” She groped around in a wastebasket she had with her on the bed and pulled out the string of pearls. “Take ’em downstairs and give ’em back to whoever they belong to. Tell ’em all Daisy’s change’ her mine. Say: ‘Daisy’s change’ her mine!’ ”
vi: "Here you go, darling." She fumbled around the trash can that was on the bed at the time and pulled out a string of pearls. "Take them downstairs and return them to their owner. Tell everyone Daisy has changed her mind. Message that 'Daisy has changed her mind.'
tr: ‘Come here, dear,’ she said, calling me over to her. Then she found the basket on her bed by feel and took out the pearl necklace from it, ‘Take this and return it to its owner, and tell him that I have changed my mind, ‘Daisy is not getting married!’’
es: —Here, take it —he fumbled in a wastebasket he had on the bed and pulled out the pearl necklace—. Go downstairs and return it to its owner. Tell everyone that Daisy has changed her mind. Say: "Daisy has changed her mind!"

en: She began to cry—she cried and cried. I rushed out and found her mother’s maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn’t let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up in a wet ball, and only let me leave it in the soap-dish when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow.
vi: She began to cry, cry, and cry endlessly. I rushed outside to find the maid. The two of us locked the door and gave Daisy a cold bath. She refused to let go of the letter. She took it into the bathtub and crumpled it tightly until it turned into a soaked paper ball. Finally, when she saw it starting to dissolve into pieces like snowflakes, she allowed me to place it on the soap dish.
tr: “She was overcome with sobs; she cried and cried. I rushed outside, found her mother’s maid, then locked the door and put Daisy under a cold shower. However, she wasn’t convinced to let go of the letter in her hand and went into the bathroom with it. But when the wet letter she clutched in her palm turned into a soggy ball and started to fall apart, she allowed me to take it from her hand and place it on the soap dish.
es: She burst into tears, and cried, cried. I ran out and found her mother's maid. We locked the door and bathed her in cold water. She wouldn't let go of the letter. She got into the bathtub with it and squeezed it until it turned into a wet ball, and only let me put it in the soap dish when she saw it was turning into snowflakes.

en: But she didn’t say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her back into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, the pearls were around her neck and the incident was over. Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas.
vi: However, after that, she did not say another word. We let her smell a bit of ammonia, applied ice to her forehead, and put her clothes back on. Only half an hour later, when we stepped out of the room, the pearl necklace was already around her neck, and the matter was considered resolved. At five o'clock the next day, she married Tom Buchanan without a shiver and began a three-month trip to the South Sea.
tr: “Then she didn't speak a single word. We made her smell ammonia, put an ice pack on her head, and then dressed her. Half an hour later, we left her room together with her wearing a pearl necklace, and the matter was closed. The next day in the afternoon, at five o'clock, she married Tom Buchanan without even a tremor in her voice. Then she went on a three-month honeymoon trip to the South Pacific with her husband.
es: But she did not speak another word. We made her smell ammonia, put ice on her forehead, and got her back into the dress, and half an hour later, when we left the bedroom, the pearl necklace was shining on Daisy's neck and the incident was over. The next day, at five in the afternoon, she married Tom Buchanan without the slightest hesitation and embarked on a three-month trip through the South Seas.

en: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they came back, and I thought I’d never seen a girl so mad about her husband. If he left the room for a minute she’d look around uneasily, and say: “Where’s Tom gone?” and wear the most abstracted expression until she saw him coming in the door. She used to sit on the sand with his head in her lap by the hour, rubbing her fingers over his eyes and looking at him with unfathomable delight. It was touching to see them together—it made you laugh in a hushed, fascinated way. That was in August. A week after I left Santa Barbara Tom ran into a wagon on the Ventura road one night, and ripped a front wheel off his car. The girl who was with him got into the papers, too, because her arm was broken—she was one of the chambermaids in the Santa Barbara Hotel.
vi: I met the couple again in Santa Barbara when they returned, and I thought I had never seen a woman so passionately in love with her husband as she was. Whenever he left the room for just about a minute, she would look around seeming very uneasy. She would ask. "Where did Tom go?" and appear very absent-minded until she saw him return through the door. She often sat on the sand with her husband's head resting on her lap for hours. Her fingers gently stroked his eyes, and she looked at him with an incomprehensible joyful gaze. The sight of the two of them together was both touching and amusing. It was August then. A week after I left Santa Barbara, one evening Tom crashed his car into a truck on Ventura Road, and his wheel completely fell off. The girl who was with him at that time also made it to the news because her arm was broken. It turned out she was one of the maids at the Santa Barbara hotel.
tr: "After their return, when we met in Santa Barbara, I thought there couldn't be another girl who loved her husband as much as she did. If Tom left the room even for a minute, she would become restless, looking around for Tom, and that expression on her face wouldn't fade until he returned to the room. On the beach, Daisy would lay Tom's head on her lap, run her fingers over his eyelids for hours, and watch his face with infinite love as she touched him. You would be impressed when you saw them together. It might seem a bit ridiculous, but their demeanor would still captivate you. This was happening in August. Shortly after leaving Santa Barbara, I read that Tom had a car accident on the Ventura road. The front wheel of his car had come off; naturally, the newspapers also mentioned the girl with a broken arm who was with him – this girl was one of the maids at the hotel they were staying at.
es: I saw them in Santa Barbara when they returned, and I thought I had never seen a girl so crazy about her husband. If Tom left the room for a moment, Daisy would look around nervously and say, "Where has Tom gone?" and she would remain absent-minded until she saw him come back through the door. She would sit on the sand with Tom's head in her lap for hours, stroking his eyes with her fingers and looking at him with unfathomable pleasure. It was touching to see them together: it made you silently laugh with fascination. It was August. A week after I left Santa Barbara, Tom crashed into a van on the Ventura road one night, and lost one of the front wheels of his car. The girl who was with him also made the newspapers, because she broke an arm: she was one of the waitresses from the Santa Barbara Hotel.

en: The next April Daisy had her little girl, and they went to France for a year. I saw them one spring in Cannes, and later in Deauville, and then they came back to Chicago to settle down. Daisy was popular in Chicago, as you know. They moved with a fast crowd, all of them young and rich and wild, but she came out with an absolutely perfect reputation. Perhaps because she doesn’t drink. It’s a great advantage not to drink among hard-drinking people. You can hold your tongue and, moreover, you can time any little irregularity of your own so that everybody else is so blind that they don’t see or care. Perhaps Daisy never went in for amour at all—and yet there’s something in that voice of hers…
vi: In April of the following year, Daisy gave birth to a baby girl, and they then went to live in France for about a year. I met them one spring in Cannes, then in Deauville, and afterwards they returned to Chicago to settle down there. Daisy was very well-known in Chicago, as you know. The two of them often gathered with young, wealthy, and wild party-goers, but among them, Daisy always maintained her reputation. Perhaps it was because she didn't drink alcohol. Not drinking among heavy drinkers is also an advantage. You can keep your mouth shut, and moreover, you can do slightly unusual things without anyone noticing or caring. Perhaps Daisy had never been involved in an illicit affair, but there was something in her voice...
tr: “In April, Daisy gave birth to a baby girl and the family went to France for a year. I met them one spring day in Cannes, and later in Deauville. Then the family returned to Chicago and settled there. You know, Daisy was very well-liked there. She was always surrounded by rich, young, fast-living, and wild types. Still, her name was never involved in any scandal, perhaps because she didn't drink. It's always beneficial to stay sober around people who drink a lot. First of all, it ties your tongue, so you don't talk too much. Even better, it allows you to cover up your own faults and mistakes, as no one is in a state to notice you anyway. Because even if they see, they don't care. Daisy perhaps never got involved in a love affair. (There was something in her voice when she said this)
es: In April of the following year, Daisy had a baby girl, and they went to France for a year. I saw them one spring in Cannes, and later in Deauville, before they returned to Chicago, where they settled down. Daisy was very successful in Chicago, as you know. They mingled with a group that liked to have fun, all young, rich, and reckless, but Daisy's reputation remained perfectly intact. Perhaps because she doesn't drink. It's a great advantage not to drink among people who drink a lot. You don't talk too much and at the right moment you can afford some minor indiscretion because everyone is so blind that they either don't notice or don't care. Maybe Daisy never got involved in affairs... but with that voice she has...

en: Well, about six weeks ago, she heard the name Gatsby for the first time in years. It was when I asked you—do you remember?—if you knew Gatsby in West Egg. After you had gone home she came into my room and woke me up, and said: “What Gatsby?” and when I described him—I was half asleep—she said in the strangest voice that it must be the man she used to know. It wasn’t until then that I connected this Gatsby with the officer in her white car.
vi: Then, about six weeks ago, she heard the name Gatsby again for the first time in many years. That was when I asked you, do you remember? I asked if you knew Gatsby over in West Egg. After you had left, Daisy came to my room and woke me up, she asked: 'Which Gatsby?' At that time, I was half asleep, half awake. After hearing my description, she said in the strangest voice that it might be someone she used to know. It wasn't until then that I realized Gatsby was the officer from that day in Daisy's white car.
tr: "Let's not prolong it, about six weeks ago, for the first time in years, I heard the name Gatsby. Remember when I asked you if you knew Gatsby from West Egg? Well, that day after you left, Daisy came to my room, woke me up, and asked, 'Which Gatsby?' When I described the man in my sleepy state, she said with a mysterious air that he could be an old acquaintance. It was only then that I could relate the lieutenant I had seen with Gatsby in his white car!"
es: And, well, about six weeks ago, she heard Gatsby's name for the first time in years. It was when I asked you in West Egg — do you remember? — if you knew Gatsby. After you left, Daisy came into my room, woke me up, and said: "Which Gatsby?" And when I described him — I was half asleep — she said in a very strange voice that it must be the man she knew. Until that moment, she hadn't connected that Gatsby with the officer in the white convertible.

en: When Jordan Baker had finished telling all this we had left the Plaza for half an hour and were driving in a victoria through Central Park. The sun had gone down behind the tall apartments of the movie stars in the West Fifties, and the clear voices of children, already gathered like crickets on the grass, rose through the hot twilight:
vi: When Jordan had finished the story, we had already left the Plaza Hotel about half an hour ago and were driving in the convertible past Central Park. The sun had set behind the towering apartment buildings of movie stars on West Fifties Street. Little girls had gathered together like crickets on the grass, their clear voices rising above the hot twilight.
tr: “When Jordan Baker finished her story, it had been half an hour since we left the Plaza; we were passing through Central Park by carriage. The sun was setting behind the tall buildings of the West Fifties, where movie stars lived. The cheerful chirping of the girls, who had already gathered on the grass like cicadas, was rising in that warm twilight.
es: When Jordan Baker finished telling me everything, it had been half an hour since we had left the Plaza and were crossing Central Park in a victoria, one of those horse-drawn carriages for tourists. The sun had sunk behind the movie stars' apartment buildings on the West Fifties streets, and in the heat of the twilight, clear and childlike voices rose, like a gathering of crickets in the grass:

en: “I’m the Sheik of Araby.
vi: "I am the handsome man from Arabia."
tr: I am an Arab Sheikh
es: I am the Sheikh of Arabia.

en: Your love belongs to me.
vi: Your love originally belongs to me.
tr: Your heart is now mine
es: Your love belongs to me.

en: At night when you’re asleep
vi: At night when you fall into sleep
tr: While you were sleeping at night
es: At night when you sleep

en: Into your tent I’ll creep—”
vi: He crawled into my tent looking for you"
tr: I will come to your tent...
es: I will crawl to your tent[13].

en: “It was a strange coincidence,” I said.
vi: "This is indeed a strange coincidence." I said.
tr: “Strange coincidence,” I said.
es: —It has been a curious coincidence. —No.

en: “But it wasn’t a coincidence at all.”
vi: "Actually, it wasn't a coincidence at all?"
tr: "Actually, it's not a coincidence!""
es: It has not been a coincidence.

en: “Why not?”
vi: "Why not?"
tr: “What do you mean?”
es: —What do you mean, no?

en: “Gatsby bought that house so that Daisy would be just across the bay.”
vi: "Gatsby bought that house to be across the bay from Daisy."
tr: “Gatsby deliberately bought that mansion because it was directly across the bay from Daisy's house.”
es: —Gatsby bought that house because Daisy lived on the other side of the bay.

en: Then it had not been merely the stars to which he had aspired on that June night. He came alive to me, delivered suddenly from the womb of his purposeless splendour.
vi: If that is true, then that June night Gatsby did not go out just to look at the stars. Now I can feel him. Gatsby had suddenly been stripped out of his magnificent, purposeless shell.
tr: “So it wasn't just the stars he was reaching for in the dark that June night.” Suddenly, Gatsby emerged from that aimless splendor, appearing as if he had come to life.
es: So he was not just sighing for the stars that June night. And then Gatsby came to life for me: suddenly he emerged from the womb of his futile splendor.

en: “He wants to know,” continued Jordan, “if you’ll invite Daisy to your house some afternoon and then let him come over.”
vi: "He wants to know," Jordan continued. "If you could invite Daisy to your house some afternoon and then let him come over."
tr: “As for his request from you,” Jordan continued, “all he wants is for you to invite Daisy to your house one day and, of course, to accept him as well.”
es: —He wants to know —Jordan continued— if you would invite Daisy to your house one afternoon so that he could then show up.

en: The modesty of the demand shook me. He had waited five years and bought a mansion where he dispensed starlight to casual moths—so that he could “come over” some afternoon to a stranger’s garden.
vi: This overly modest request moved me. He had waited five long years, bought a massive castle where he could distribute starlight to the moths, just so that one day he might "drop by" the garden of a stranger.
tr: His humility in his request had astonished me: He had waited for five years, and then he had acquired that magnificent mansion, which with its light shining like stars would attract the night moths to it. Was all this just to spend an afternoon with him in a stranger's garden?
es: The modesty of the request puzzled me. He had waited five years and had bought a mansion where he spread starlight among moths that came by chance, just to be able to "show up" one afternoon in a stranger's garden.

en: “Did I have to know all this before he could ask such a little thing?”
vi: "Do I need to know everything like this before he can ask for a small favor like that?"
tr: “To answer such a small request, what was the need for me to learn all this?”
es: —And did I have to know the whole story before you asked me for something so insignificant?

en: “He’s afraid, he’s waited so long. He thought you might be offended. You see, he’s regular tough underneath it all.”
vi: "He is afraid, he has waited too long. He thinks you will be displeased. You see, beneath that tough and strong exterior, he is just an ordinary person."
tr: “He is afraid. He has waited so long. He is worried that you will be offended. After all, behind all those behaviors, ultimately he is also a young man.”
es: —He is scared. He has waited a long time. He thought you might get upset. Deep down, you see, he is not as tough as he seems.

en: Something worried me.
vi: There is something that makes me uneasy.
tr: Something was on my mind.
es: Something was worrying me.

en: “Why didn’t he ask you to arrange a meeting?”
vi: "Why didn't he ask me to arrange the meeting?"
tr: “Why didn't they want you to arrange this meeting?”
es: —Why doesn't he ask you to set up a date for him?

en: “He wants her to see his house,” she explained. “And your house is right next door.”
vi: "He wants Daisy to see his house." Jorsan explained. "And his house is right next door."
tr: "Because he wants Daisy to see his house," he explained, "and your house is next to his.""
es: —He wants Daisy to see his house —he explained to me—. And your house is next door.

en: “Oh!”
vi: "Oh."
tr: “Ah, I understand!”
es: —Ah!

en: “I think he half expected her to wander into one of his parties, some night,” went on Jordan, “but she never did. Then he began asking people casually if they knew her, and I was the first one he found. It was that night he sent for me at his dance, and you should have heard the elaborate way he worked up to it. Of course, I immediately suggested a luncheon in New York—and I thought he’d go mad:
vi: "He thought that one evening Daisy might wander into one of his parties." Jordan continued. "But she never did. After that, he would casually ask others if they knew Daisy. You were the first person he found. That was the night at the ball when he had someone invite you in to meet him. You should have heard how he beat around the bush. Of course, I immediately suggested a lunch in New York, and I thought he had gone mad:
tr: “He was probably hoping that Daisy would show up to one of the parties he threw,” Jordan continued, “But that never happened. Then he started asking around if anyone knew her, trying to hide his feelings. The first person he found was me. You remember the party where we ran into each other that day, he wanted to talk to me privately. You should have seen him, he was stammering just to get a word in. When I understood the situation, I suggested arranging a lunch in New York, but he was furious.
es: —I think he harbored some hope of seeing Daisy some night at one of his parties —continued Jordan—. It didn't happen. Then he started asking people, as if by chance, if they knew her, and I was the first one he came across. It was the night he called me during the party and you should have heard how convoluted and studied his talk about the matter was. I immediately suggested, naturally, a lunch in New York, and I thought he was going to lose his nerves: «I don't want to do anything improper!

en: “ ‘I don’t want to do anything out of the way!’ he kept saying. ‘I want to see her right next door.’
vi: 'I don't want to have to do anything troublesome that involves going so far away' He kept saying, 'I just want to meet her right next to my house.''
tr: ‘I don’t want to meet her in some far-off, secluded place,’ he had burst out, ‘I want to meet her in the house right next to mine, just beside me.’
es: I immediately suggested, naturally, a lunch in New York, and I thought he was going to lose his nerves: «I don't want to do anything improper! I want to see her in the house next door».

en: “When I said you were a particular friend of Tom’s, he started to abandon the whole idea. He doesn’t know very much about Tom, though he says he’s read a Chicago paper for years just on the chance of catching a glimpse of Daisy’s name.”
vi: "When he heard you say that you were a special friend of Tom, he abandoned all his schemes. He didn't know much about Tom, although he had read the Chicago newspapers for many years just hoping to find Daisy's name mentioned."
tr: “When he learned that you were Tom's friend, he seemed to back out of his plan. Even though he has been reading all the Chicago newspapers for years in the hope of finding news about Daisy, he doesn't know Tom very well.”
es: When I told him you were a close friend of Tom's, he almost gave up the idea. He doesn't know much about Tom, although he says he's been reading a Chicago newspaper for years just in the hope of seeing Daisy's name.

en: It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. Suddenly I wasn’t thinking of Daisy and Gatsby any more, but of this clean, hard, limited person, who dealt in universal scepticism, and who leaned back jauntily just within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to beat in my ears with a sort of heady excitement: “There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.”
vi: It was now completely dark, as the two of us walked under the foot of a small bridge, I put my arm around Jordan's delicate shoulders and pulled her closer to me, I invited Jordan to dinner. Suddenly I no longer thought about Daisy or Gatsby, but only about this well-proportioned, firm girl. A phrase began to ring in my ears, rising to my head with excitement: "Here there is only one person being pursued, one person pursuing, one busy person, and one tired person."
tr: The sky had already darkened, and as we passed under a small bridge, I wrapped my arm around her golden shoulder, pulling her close to me, and suggested we go out for dinner together. Suddenly, both Daisy and Gatsby had vanished from my mind; all I could think about at that moment was this clean, challenging, controlled, and slightly skeptical girl who had nestled against me so recklessly under my arm. In my head, these words kept spinning with dizzying excitement, “There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.”
es: It had grown dark and, as we passed under a small bridge, my arm encircled Jordan's golden shoulder, I drew her towards me and invited her to dinner. I was no longer thinking about Daisy or Gatsby, but about that healthy, difficult, concrete person who professed a universal skepticism, and who leaned back, satisfied, within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to hammer in my ears in a kind of intoxication: "There are only the pursued and the pursuers, the active and the tired."

en: “And Daisy ought to have something in her life,” murmured Jordan to me.
vi: "Daisy ought to have something in her life as well." Jordan whispered in my ear.
tr: “Daisy's life needs a little bit of color,” said Jordan.
es: —And Daisy should have something in life —murmured Jordan.

en: “Does she want to see Gatsby?”
vi: "Does Daisy want to meet Gatsby?"
tr: “Does he want to meet Gatsby?”
es: —Do you want to see Gatsby?

en: “She’s not to know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to know. You’re just supposed to invite her to tea.”
vi: "She shouldn't know about this. Gatsby doesn't want her to know. He just pretended to invite her for tea."
tr: “She doesn't know about this meeting, Gatsby doesn't want her to know. Your only task is to invite her to tea.”
es: —She doesn't have to find out. Gatsby doesn't want her to know anything. You just have to invite her for tea.

en: We passed a barrier of dark trees, and then the façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, a block of delicate pale light, beamed down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I had no girl whose disembodied face floated along the dark cornices and blinding signs, and so I drew up the girl beside me, tightening my arms. Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.
vi: We walked past a row of dark trees to the main face of Fifty Ninth Street, a soft pale shadow cast down in the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I didn't have any girlfriends whose faces fleetingly passed over the dark eaves or brightly lit billboards. So I pulled the girl next to me closer, my hands tightening around her. Jordan's tired and disdainful mouth smiled, and so I pulled her even closer, right up to my face.
tr: When we crossed a dark grove, we could see 59th Street, with pale beams of light spilling from its front facade reaching the park. Since I didn’t have a lover like Gatsby or Tom Buchanan, whose face would flit about in imaginary dark sills or glowing signs, I pulled the girl next to me closer and held her tightly. When a smile appeared on her pale and mocking lips, I drew even closer to her, bringing her face near mine.
es: We left behind a barrier of trees in the twilight and the facades of Fifty-ninth Street, a strip of weak and pale light, shone over the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I didn't have a girl whose incorporeal features floated in the dark cornices and blinding neon signs, so I drew the girl next to me closer, holding her in my arms. Her disdainful, sad mouth smiled, so I drew her closer, towards my face this time.

en: V
vi: Chapter 5
tr: CHAPTER 5

en: When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire. Two o’clock and the whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light, which fell unreal on the shrubbery and made thin elongating glints upon the roadside wires. Turning a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby’s house, lit from tower to cellar.
vi: When I returned home to West Egg that night, and for a moment I thought my house was on fire. It was two in the morning, and the entire corner of the peninsula seemed to be ablaze with light. The light fell like an illusion, enveloping the bushes and extending into sparkling rays along the electric wires on the road. As I turned the corner, I saw that it was Gatsby's house, lit up from the top of the tower down to the basement.
tr: That night, as I was coming to West Egg, I was momentarily afraid that my house was on fire. It was two in the morning, and this corner of the peninsula was sparkling with long lights that fell with a makeshift touch on the bushes and the electric wires by the roadside. As I turned the corner, I saw that Gatsby's mansion was illuminated from its tower to its cellar.
es: When I returned to West Egg that night, I feared for a moment that my house was on fire. It was two o'clock and the tip of the peninsula was glowing with a light that fell unreal over the hedges and produced elongated flashes on the road's electric cables. As I turned a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby's house, illuminated from the tower to the basement.

en: At first I thought it was another party, a wild rout that had resolved itself into “hide-and-go-seek” or “sardines-in-the-box” with all the house thrown open to the game. But there wasn’t a sound. Only wind in the trees, which blew the wires and made the lights go off and on again as if the house had winked into the darkness. As my taxi groaned away I saw Gatsby walking toward me across his lawn.
vi: At first, I thought it was another party with the chaotic, frenzied crowd that had turned into a game of "hide and seek" or "sardines in a can," using the entire house as the playground. However, I didn't hear a single sound. There was only the rustling sound of the wind blowing through the branches, swaying the power lines, and making the lights flicker on and off as if the house was winking at the surrounding darkness. As the taxi that brought me back creaked away, I saw Gatsby walking across the lawn towards me.
tr: At first, I thought he was throwing one of his usual wild parties, opening every corner of the house to games like 'hide and seek' or 'sardines in a can.' But there was no sound. Only the wind rustling through the trees could be heard. It was shaking the wires on the poles and flickering the lights. The house seemed to be winking in the night. As the taxi I arrived in drove away, I saw Gatsby walking from his garden towards mine.
es: At first, I thought it was another party, a colossal and wild binge that had ended with the guests playing hide and seek all over the house. But there wasn't a sound. Only the wind in the trees, the wind that shook the wires and caused the lights to go out and come back on as if the house were blinking in the dark. As my taxi groaned away, I saw Gatsby approaching across the lawn.

en: “Your place looks like the World’s Fair,” I said.
vi: "Your house looks like a world's fair." I said.
tr: "The house has turned into a fairground," I said.
es: —Your house looks like the World's Fair —I said.

en: “Does it?” He turned his eyes toward it absently. “I have been glancing into some of the rooms. Let’s go to Coney Island, old sport. In my car.”
vi: "Does it look alike?" He looked at it with a blank stare. "I am just checking out some rooms." Let's go to Coney Island, old friend. Take my car."
tr: “Is that so?” he said, looking at the house with absent eyes, “I was glancing into some of the rooms. Let's go to Coney Island, buddy. In my car.”
es: —Yes? —he turned to look, as if absent—. I've been taking a look at some rooms. Let's go to Caney Island, buddy. In my car.

en: “It’s too late.”
vi: "It's late now."
tr: “It's very late.”
es: —It's very late.

en: “Well, suppose we take a plunge in the swimming pool? I haven’t made use of it all summer.”
vi: "How about we swim in the pool? I haven't used it all summer."
tr: “So, what do you say about swimming in the pool? I haven't even dipped my foot in all summer.”
es: —How about we take a dip in the pool? I haven't used it all summer.

en: “I’ve got to go to bed.”
vi: "I have to go to sleep."
tr: “I need to go to bed immediately.”
es: —I have to go to bed.

en: “All right.”
vi: "Fine, whatever."
tr: “Alright.”
es: —Very well.

en: He waited, looking at me with suppressed eagerness.
vi: He looked at me expectantly, trying to suppress his impatience.
tr: He looked at my face, trying to suppress his excitement. He waited a bit.
es: He waited, looking at me, holding back his impatience.

en: “I talked with Miss Baker,” I said after a moment. “I’m going to call up Daisy tomorrow and invite her over here to tea.”
vi: "I have talked to Ms. Baker already." After a moment, I said. "I will call Daisy tomorrow and invite her here for tea."
tr: “I talked to Mrs. Baker,” I said after a while of silence, “Tomorrow I will call Daisy and invite her here for tea.”
es: —I have spoken with Miss Baker —I said at once—. Tomorrow I will call Daisy and invite her to tea.

en: “Oh, that’s all right,” he said carelessly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble.”
vi: "Oh, that's fine." He said indifferently. "I don't want to bother you."
tr: “It wasn't really that important,” he said, trying to appear as if he was downplaying it, “I don't want to bother you with it.”
es: —Ah, perfect —he said, as if it didn't matter to him—. I don't want to cause you any trouble.

en: “What day would suit you?”
vi: "Which day is convenient for you?" "Which day is more convenient for you?"
tr: “Which day is suitable for you?”
es: —What day works for you? —What day works for you?

en: “What day would suit you?” he corrected me quickly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble, you see.”
vi: Gatsby quickly corrected me. "I don't want to put you in a difficult situation, you know."
tr: “Which day is actually convenient for you?” he corrected. “You know I don't want to trouble you.”
es: —he immediately corrected me—. I don't want to cause you any trouble, really.

en: “How about the day after tomorrow?”
vi: "How about the day after tomorrow?" he hesitantly suggested.
tr: "How about the day after tomorrow?""
es: —The day after tomorrow?

en: He considered for a moment. Then, with reluctance: “I want to get the grass cut,” he said.
vi: Then, hesitantly "I want the lawn to be mowed." He said.
tr: After thinking for a moment, reluctantly. "These grasses need to be cut," he said.
es: He thought about it for a few seconds. And, not very convinced, he said: —We should mow the lawn.

en: We both looked down at the grass—there was a sharp line where my ragged lawn ended and the darker, well-kept expanse of his began. I suspected that he meant my grass.
vi: Both of us looked out at the lawn. There was a distinct line dividing my shaggy, unkempt lawn from his neatly trimmed, lush green lawn. I thought he was implying something about the grass on my side.
tr: We both looked at the garden. Right behind my neglected grass, his dark green, well-kept grass began. I suspected that he was referring to mine.
es: We looked at the grass: a well-defined line marked where my uneven, neglected lawn ended, and his darker, perfectly maintained one began to spread. I suspected he was referring to my grass.

en: “There’s another little thing,” he said uncertainly, and hesitated.
vi: "There's one more small matter." Gatsby hesitated, not very sure.
tr: “There is one more small point,” he said.
es: —There is another insignificant thing —he said, unsure, hesitant.

en: “Would you rather put it off for a few days?” I asked.
vi: "Or do you want to postpone it a few more days?" I asked.
tr: "If you want, it can be in a few days.""
es: —Do you prefer that we delay it a few days? —I asked.

en: “Oh, it isn’t about that. At least—” He fumbled with a series of beginnings. “Why, I thought—why, look here, old sport, you don’t make much money, do you?”
vi: "Oh, it's not because of that. At least..." He awkwardly fumbled for opening words. "I suppose.... - listen here..., old friend, you don't make much money, do you?"
tr: “No, that's not the issue,” he seemed unsure of how to start, “I was thinking... well, don't get me wrong buddy, but I don't think your earnings are very good.” “Not too many.””
es: —No, that's not it. But… —he tried several beginnings—. Well, I've been thinking… Yes, look, buddy, you don't make much money, do you?

en: “Not very much.”
vi: "Not much."
tr: “Not too many.””
es: —Not much.

en: This seemed to reassure him and he continued more confidently.
vi: This answer seemed to reassure Gatsby, and he continued to speak more confidently. "I think so too.
tr: This had restored his self-confidence. Now he was speaking more decisively, "I thought so too.
es: This seemed to calm him down, and he continued with more confidence.

en: “I thought you didn’t, if you’ll pardon my—you see, I carry on a little business on the side, a sort of side line, you understand. And I thought that if you don’t make very much—You’re selling bonds, aren’t you, old sport?”
vi: If you forgive my words, you see, I have a small retail business, like a side business. And I think if you don't make much money... Are you trading stocks, old friend?"
tr: If you don't mind... you know, I'm also dealing with a small job. A second occupation, you understand? Since your earnings are low, I... you were selling bonds and securities, right buddy?"
es: —It was what I thought, if you can forgive my… I have, as a complement, a small business, something additional, you know. And I thought that if you don't earn much… You sell bonds. Isn't that right, buddy?

en: “Trying to.”
vi: "Also trying."
tr: “Yes, I am trying to sell it.”
es: —I try.

en: “Well, this would interest you. It wouldn’t take up much of your time and you might pick up a nice bit of money. It happens to be a rather confidential sort of thing.”
vi: "In that case, this will interest you. It won't take much of your time and you can make a decent amount." "This business is a bit discreet."
tr: "Then maybe such a job would interest you. It won't take much of your time. The earnings are good too. It just requires a bit of secrecy."
es: —Well, this might interest you. It wouldn't require too much of your time and you could make good money from it. It's something confidential.

en: I realize now that under different circumstances that conversation might have been one of the crises of my life. But, because the offer was obviously and tactlessly for a service to be rendered, I had no choice except to cut him off there.
vi: I suddenly realized that in a different situation, this conversation could have been one of the turning points in my life. However, because it was presented so clearly and clumsily as if to repay a favor, I had no choice but to interrupt the story here.
tr: Now that I think about it, I realize that under different circumstances, the conversation that night could have been a turning point in my life. But he had so clumsily made it clear that his proposal was a quid pro quo for the service I would provide that I had no choice but to immediately cut him off.
es: Now I realize that, under different circumstances, that conversation could have caused one of the crises of my life. But, since Gatsby made his offer in a rather unsubtle way and without the slightest tact for a service that had yet to be rendered, I had no choice but to cut him off abruptly.

en: “I’ve got my hands full,” I said. “I’m much obliged but I couldn’t take on any more work.”
vi: "I'm very busy right now." I replied. "I really appreciate it, but at this moment I can't take on any more work."
tr: “I am very busy,” I said, “thank you, but I don't have time to deal with another task.”
es: —I have too much work —I said—. I appreciate it, but I can't take on more.

en: “You wouldn’t have to do any business with Wolfshiem.” Evidently he thought that I was shying away from the “gonnegtion” mentioned at lunch, but I assured him he was wrong. He waited a moment longer, hoping I’d begin a conversation, but I was too absorbed to be responsive, so he went unwillingly home.
vi: "You don't have to do any work with Wolfsheim." Clearly, Gatsby thought I was hesitant and wanted to avoid the "business" that Wolfsheim had mentioned during lunch. I reassured Gatsby that it wasn't the case. Gatsby waited a bit longer, hoping I would start talking about something else, but I was in no mood for conversation, so he reluctantly left.
tr: “If you work with Wolfsheim, you won't have to bother with a job.” I think he thought I was apprehensive about the connection mentioned during lunch that day. I assured him that it wasn't the case. He waited a little longer for me to start a new conversation, but my mind was so occupied that I had no energy to talk. Upon this, he reluctantly headed home.
es: —You wouldn't have to deal with Wolfshiem —he evidently thought that I, scared, was avoiding the "connections" mentioned during lunch, but I assured him he was mistaken. He waited a moment, attentive to me starting some conversation, but it was hard for me to react, so absorbed was I, and Gatsby reluctantly went back to his house.

en: The evening had made me lightheaded and happy; I think I walked into a deep sleep as I entered my front door. So I don’t know whether or not Gatsby went to Coney Island, or for how many hours he “glanced into rooms” while his house blazed gaudily on. I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea.
vi: This evening has made my head light with happiness. When I just opened the door and stepped into the front house, I thought I had already fallen into a deep sleep. Therefore, I didn't know whether Gatsby went to Coney Island or not, or how many hours he spent "glancing through the rooms" in his brightly lit house. The next morning, I called Daisy and invited her over for tea.
tr: I was happy because of what happened in the evening. You know, I almost fell into a deep sleep as soon as I walked through the door. So I don't know if Gatsby went to Coney Island or stayed and continued to check 'some of the rooms' by turning on all the lights in his house. The next day, I called Daisy from the office and invited her to tea at my house.
es: The afternoon had made me feel irresponsible and happy, and I believe that, as I entered my house, I sank into a deep sleep. So I don't know if Gatsby did or did not go to Caney Island. Or how many hours he spent "taking a look at some rooms" while his house gleamed with ostentation. The next morning I called Daisy from the office and invited her for tea.

en: “Don’t bring Tom,” I warned her.
vi: "Don't bring Tom along." I instructed Daisy.
tr: "Don't bring Tom!" I also warned.
es: —Don't bring Tom.

en: “What?”
vi: "What?"
tr: “What?”
es: —How?

en: “Don’t bring Tom.”
vi: "Don't bring Tom along."
tr: “Don't bring Tom!”
es: —Don't bring Tom.

en: “Who is ‘Tom’?” she asked innocently.
vi: "Who is Tom?" Daisy asked innocently.
tr: “Tom who?” he said with an innocent voice.
es: "Who is Tom?" she asked innocently.

en: The day agreed upon was pouring rain. At eleven o’clock a man in a raincoat, dragging a lawn-mower, tapped at my front door and said that Mr. Gatsby had sent him over to cut my grass. This reminded me that I had forgotten to tell my Finn to come back, so I drove into West Egg Village to search for her among soggy whitewashed alleys and to buy some cups and lemons and flowers.
vi: On the appointed day, it poured rain. Around eleven o'clock, a man in a raincoat dragged a lawnmower to my door and said Mr. Gatsby had sent him to trim my lawn. This reminded me that I had forgotten to ask the Finnish woman to help with the chores. So I drove into the village of West Egg through the muddy, whitewashed alleys to find her and also to buy a few cups, some lemons, and a few flowers.
tr: On the appointed day, it was raining cats and dogs. At eleven o'clock, a man wearing a raincoat and dragging a lawn mower behind him knocked on the front door. When he said that Mr. Gatsby had sent him to cut the grass, I suddenly remembered that I had forgotten to call my Finnish servant that day. Without wasting any time, I went to the village of West Egg and looked for him in the wet, narrow streets lined with white-painted houses. Then I bought a few cups, lemons, and a few bunches of flowers and returned home.
es: The agreed day was pouring rain. At eleven, a man in a raincoat dragging a lawnmower knocked on the door and told me that Mr. Gatsby had sent him to cut the grass. That reminded me that I had forgotten to tell my Finnish maid to come, so I went by car to West Egg Village to look for her, through whitewashed and soaked alleys, and to buy cups, lemons, and flowers.

en: The flowers were unnecessary, for at two o’clock a greenhouse arrived from Gatsby’s, with innumerable receptacles to contain it. An hour later the front door opened nervously, and Gatsby in a white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-coloured tie, hurried in. He was pale, and there were dark signs of sleeplessness beneath his eyes.
vi: Actually, buying flowers was not necessary, because around two in the afternoon, an entire garden of flowers grown indoors was brought from Gatsby's house to mine with countless vases for arranging them. Then, an hour later, my door was opened hastily, and Gatsby appeared in a white flannel suit, a silver shirt, and a gold tie, rushing in. He looked pale, with dark circles under his eyes indicating sleeplessness.
tr: At around two o'clock, when the flowers Gatsby had sent, enough to fill a greenhouse, and vases of every size to put them in, arrived at the door, I realized that I had bought the flowers in vain. An hour later, he appeared on the threshold in his white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-colored tie. He was anxious, the pallor of his complexion and the dark circles under his eyes proving that his night had been sleepless.
es: The flowers were not necessary, for at two o'clock a genuine greenhouse arrived from Gatsby with countless containers to hold it. An hour later, the door timidly opened, and Gatsby, in a white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-colored tie, suddenly entered. He was pale and had shadows under his eyes that indicated a lack of sleep.

en: “Is everything all right?” he asked immediately.
vi: "Is everything in order?" he immediately asked.
tr: "Is everything alright?" he asked as soon as he entered.
es: —Is everything alright? —he asked immediately.

en: “The grass looks fine, if that’s what you mean.”
vi: "The lawn looks nice, if that's what you meant to ask."
tr: "If you're asking about that, the grass turned out great"
es: —The grass looks great, if that's what you mean.

en: “What grass?” he inquired blankly. “Oh, the grass in the yard.” He looked out the window at it, but, judging from his expression, I don’t believe he saw a thing.
vi: "What grass?" Gatsby asked bewilderedly. "Oh, the grass in the yard." Through the window, Gatsby looked out at the lawn, but judging by his expression, I believed he saw nothing at all.
tr: “What grass?” he asked in astonishment, “Oh, the grass in the front yard.” He moved closer to the window to see, but it was clear from his face that he didn't see anything.
es: —What grass? —he asked, as if lost—. Ah, the garden grass —he looked out the window, but, judging by his expression, I don't think he saw anything—.

en: “Looks very good,” he remarked vaguely. “One of the papers said they thought the rain would stop about four. I think it was The Journal. Have you got everything you need in the shape of—of tea?”
vi: "Looks pretty good." Gatsby said vaguely. "One of the newspapers predicted that the rain would stop around four o'clock. It seems to be the Journal. Have you prepared everything for... the tea party?"
tr: “It looks very good,” he said vaguely, “one of the newspapers mentioned that the rain would stop around four o'clock. I think I saw it in the Journal. Is there anything missing for tea?”
es: Yes, excellent —he remarked, distracted—. I read in a newspaper that it would stop raining around four o'clock. I think it was the Journal. Do you have everything you need to prepare…, for tea?

en: I took him into the pantry, where he looked a little reproachfully at the Finn. Together we scrutinized the twelve lemon cakes from the delicatessen shop.
vi: I took Gatsby into the kitchen, he looked at the Finnish woman as if reproaching her. We carefully tended to the lemon cakes bought from the store.
tr: I took it to the kitchen. After giving the Finnish woman a cold look, Gatsby and I examined the twelve lemon cakes I bought from the pastry shop.
es: I took him to the kitchen, where he looked at the Finnish woman with some disdain. Together we examined the twelve lemon pastries from the delicatessen shop.

en: “Will they do?” I asked.
vi: "Is that okay now?" I asked.
tr: “Is there anything missing?” I asked.
es: —Do they seem okay to you?

en: “Of course, of course! They’re fine!” and he added hollowly, “… old sport.”
vi: "Of course, of course! Well done... my old friend."
tr: “Alright, everything is very good,” he said, then added in a shy voice, “buddy.”
es: —Yes, of course! Wonderful! —and he added, though it sounded insincere—… comrade.

en: The rain cooled about half-past three to a damp mist, through which occasional thin drops swam like dew. Gatsby looked with vacant eyes through a copy of Clay’s Economics, starting at the Finnish tread that shook the kitchen floor, and peering towards the bleared windows from time to time as if a series of invisible but alarming happenings were taking place outside. Finally he got up and informed me, in an uncertain voice, that he was going home.
vi: By around half-past three in the afternoon, the rain became lighter and turned into a drizzle, although occasionally there were still drops falling like dew. Gatsby's godless eyes wandered absently over the pages of Clay's Economics book. He was startled when the Finnish woman stepped heavily, causing the kitchen floor to shake. He then frequently looked through the misty windows as if a series of invisible, worrying events were happening outside. Finally, Gatsby stood up and told me in a doubtful voice that he was going home.
tr: Around half-past three, the rain had given way to a damp mist. Every now and then, small droplets resembling dew would fall. Gatsby was busy wandering his empty gaze over Clay's Economics book. Every time he heard the Finnish woman's footsteps shaking the kitchen, he would jump, and sometimes he would look out the window as if there were some invisible, worrying things happening outside. Finally, he stood up and said in a rather uncertain voice that he was going home.
es: The rain eased off around half past three and turned into a humid mist, in which an occasional tiny drop, like dew, floated. Gatsby was absentmindedly leafing through a copy of Clay's Economics, startled whenever the Finnish woman's steps made the kitchen floor tremble, and occasionally looked at the fogged-up windows as if a series of invisible but alarming events were happening outside. He finally stood up and, with an uncertain voice, informed me that he was going home.

en: “Why’s that?”
vi: "Why so?"
tr: “Why then?”
es: —And why is that?

en: “Nobody’s coming to tea. It’s too late!” He looked at his watch as if there was some pressing demand on his time elsewhere. “I can’t wait all day.”
vi: "It's late now, no one is coming for tea." Gatsby looked at his watch as if something somewhere needed his attention. "I can't wait all day."
tr: “No one is coming for tea or anything. It's getting late!” He spoke as if he had urgent business elsewhere, “I'm not going to wait here all day!” he said.
es: —No one will come to have tea. It's too late! —he looked at the clock as if his time were urgently required elsewhere—. I can't wait all day.

en: “Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”
vi: "Don't be so silly, it's only two minutes to four."
tr: “Don't be ridiculous, there are still two minutes to four.”
es: —Don't be silly; it's two minutes to four.

en: He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane. We both jumped up, and, a little harrowed myself, I went out into the yard.
vi: Gatsby sat down again miserably as if I had forced him to sit. At that very moment, there was the sound of a car driving into my driveway. Both of us stood up abruptly, even I felt nervous at this point, and I went out into the garden.
tr: He sat back down with an unhappy expression, as if I had pushed him by the chest and forcibly held him. Just then, we heard the sound of an approaching motor at the door. We jumped up from our seats. I was also tense. I walked towards the garden.
es: He sat down, dejected, as if he had been pushed, and at that moment the sound of an engine entering the path to my house was heard. We both jumped to our feet and I, a little anxious as well, went out to the garden.

en: Under the dripping bare lilac-trees a large open car was coming up the drive. It stopped. Daisy’s face, tipped sideways beneath a three-cornered lavender hat, looked out at me with a bright ecstatic smile.
vi: Beneath the bare branches of the lilac trees with dripping raindrops, a large convertible car was making its way down the path. The car stopped, Daisy's face hidden under the tilted brim of a tricorn hat in lilac color, looking at me with a captivating smile.
tr: An open-top car was approaching the door, passing under the dripping lilac trees. It stopped near the steps. The radiant smile of Daisy, who was looking at me from under a three-cornered purple hat, appeared.
es: Under the bare and dripping lilacs, a large convertible was coming up the road. It stopped. Daisy's face, tilted under a lavender tricorn hat, looked at me with an ecstatic and radiant smile.

en: “Is this absolutely where you live, my dearest one?”
vi: "Is this where you live, my dearest love?"
tr: “Do you live here, my dear?”
es: —Is this where you live, my love?

en: The exhilarating ripple of her voice was a wild tonic in the rain. I had to follow the sound of it for a moment, up and down, with my ear alone, before any words came through. A damp streak of hair lay like a dash of blue paint across her cheek, and her hand was wet with glistening drops as I took it to help her from the car.
vi: Daisy's cheerful, babbling voice was a wild resonance amidst the rain. It took a moment for me to focus and listen to their melodious sound with keen ears before I could understand them. A wet lock of hair lay like a green streak of paint across Daisy's cheek. Her hand was wet with sparkling raindrops as I took it to help Daisy out of the car.
tr: The tantalizing vibrations of her voice mingled with the rain. For a moment, I waited, doing nothing but listening to this voice. Her voice rose and fell, a strand of hair stuck to her cheek looked like a stroke of blue paint, and the wet hand I held to help her out of the car sparkled.
es: The stimulating whisper of her voice was a very strong tonic in the rain. I had to follow the melody for a moment, up and down, just with my ear, before catching the words. A strand of wet hair stuck to her cheek like a blue brushstroke, and her hand was damp with bright droplets when I took it to help her get out of the car.

en: “Are you in love with me,” she said low in my ear, “or why did I have to come alone?”
vi: "Are you in love with me?" Daisy whispered in my ear, "if not, why did you ask me to come alone?"
tr: "Or are you in love with me?" he whispered in my ear, leaning in, "Why did you want me to come alone?"
es: —Have you fallen in love with me? —she whispered in my ear—. If not, why did I have to come alone?

en: “That’s the secret of Castle Rackrent. Tell your chauffeur to go far away and spend an hour.”
vi: "That is the secret of Rackrent Castle." "Tell the driver to go somewhere far away for about an hour."
tr: "This is the secret of Rackrent Castle." "Tell your driver to leave and come back in an hour.""
es: —That is the secret of Rackrent Castle[14]. Tell the driver to leave and come back in an hour.

en: “Come back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then in a grave murmur: “His name is Ferdie.”
vi: "Brother Ferdie, go somewhere for about an hour and then come back." Then Daisy turned to me and whispered, "His name is Ferdie."
tr: "Come in an hour, Ferdie," he said, then slowly added, "his name is Ferdie."
es: —Come back in an hour, Ferdie —and in a grave murmur—. His name is Ferdie.

en: “Does the gasoline affect his nose?”
vi: "Does gasoline have any effect on his nose?"
tr: “Is your nose affected by gasoline?”
es: —Does gasoline affect your nose?

en: “I don’t think so,” she said innocently. “Why?”
vi: "I don't think so," Daisy asked innocently. "Why?"
tr: "I don't think so," he said innocently, "Why did you ask?"
es: —I don't think so —he said innocently—. Why?

en: We went in. To my overwhelming surprise the living-room was deserted.
vi: We went inside the house. I was extremely surprised to see the living room completely empty.
tr: When we entered, I saw with great astonishment that the living room was empty.
es: We entered. To my surprise and confusion, there was no one in the living room.

en: “Well, that’s funny,” I exclaimed.
vi: "Well, that's strange." I exclaimed.
tr: “This is very funny,” I shouted.
es: —Well, this is really funny.

en: “What’s funny?”
vi: "What the heck?"
tr: "What is supposed to be funny?""
es: —What is funny?

en: She turned her head as there was a light dignified knocking at the front door. I went out and opened it. Gatsby, pale as death, with his hands plunged like weights in his coat pockets, was standing in a puddle of water glaring tragically into my eyes.
vi: Daisy turned her head when she heard a light knock on the front door. I stepped out to open the door. Gatsby, his face pale as a corpse, his hands hanging heavily in his coat pockets, stood in a puddle, staring straight into my eyes.
tr: Hearing the door being gently knocked, Daisy turned her head. I went and opened the door. Standing in front of me, with his face as white as a ghost, Gatsby was looking at me with his hands in his pockets and a tragic anger in his eyes, standing on the wet ground.
es: He turned his head just as some soft and solemn knocks sounded on the door. I went to open it. It was Gatsby, pale as death; with his hands sunk like weights in the pockets of his jacket, standing over a puddle of water, he looked tragically into my eyes.

en: With his hands still in his coat pockets he stalked by me into the hall, turned sharply as if he were on a wire, and disappeared into the living-room. It wasn’t a bit funny. Aware of the loud beating of my own heart I pulled the door to against the increasing rain.
vi: With his hands still thrust in the pockets of his coat, Gatsby stealthily followed me into the hallway, making a sharp turn as if walking on a tightrope, and then disappeared into the living room. The scene was not at all funny. I heard my heart pounding, I reached out to close the door, and outside, the rain was getting heavier and heavier.
tr: He quickly passed by me and dashed into the living room, then, like an acrobat on a tightrope, made a sharp maneuver into the sitting room and disappeared from sight. What happened was not funny at all. I felt as if I could hear my own heart beating rapidly. I closed the door, leaving the increasingly heavy rain outside.
es: With his hands still in the pockets of his jacket, he majestically crossed the foyer beside me, suddenly turned as if walking on a tightrope, and disappeared into the living room. There was nothing graceful about it. Aware of how my heart was pounding, I closed the door to the increasing rain.

en: For half a minute there wasn’t a sound. Then from the living-room I heard a sort of choking murmur and part of a laugh, followed by Daisy’s voice on a clear artificial note:
vi: In the span of about half a minute, I didn't hear a single sound. Then I heard something coming from the living room that sounded like a mix of murmuring, choking, and joyful laughter, followed by Daisy's artificially clear voice.
tr: There was a deep silence that lasted for about half a minute. At one point, some strange murmurs and a short burst of laughter rose from my living room.
es: For a few seconds, not a sound was heard. Then, from the living room, a sort of muffled murmur reached me, an interrupted laugh, and Daisy's voice, clear and artificial.

en: “I certainly am awfully glad to see you again.”
vi: "I am so indescribably happy to see you again."
tr: Then I heard Daisy say in an extremely artificial tone, "You have no idea how glad I am to see you again."
es: —Of course: I am very happy to see you again.

en: A pause; it endured horribly. I had nothing to do in the hall, so I went into the room.
vi: Then there was an unbearable silence. I had nothing to do in the hallway, so I had to step inside.
tr: The next silence was frightening and lasted quite a long time. Since there was nothing to do in the living room, I went inside.
es: A pause; it was dreadfully prolonged. I had nothing to do in the foyer, so I entered the room.

en: Gatsby, his hands still in his pockets, was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom. His head leaned back so far that it rested against the face of a defunct mantelpiece clock, and from this position his distraught eyes stared down at Daisy, who was sitting, frightened but graceful, on the edge of a stiff chair.
vi: Gatsby, with both hands still in his pockets, was standing leaning against the fireplace with a completely artificial air of forced nonchalance. His head was tilted back too far, resting against the face of the broken clock on the mantelpiece. In this position, Gatsby's frantic eyes stared intently at Daisy, who was sitting on the edge of a chair, looking frightened but gracefully charming.
tr: Gatsby, who still kept his hands in his pockets, was leaning against the fireplace with a supposedly relaxed, forced demeanor, pretending to be somewhat bored. He was leaning back so far that his head was resting on the broken clock on the mantle. Without breaking this awkward position, he fixed his piercing gaze on Daisy, who, though a bit frightened, maintained her grace as she sat on the edge of a hard chair.
es: Gatsby, with his hands still in his pockets, had leaned against the mantelpiece in a forced imitation of absolute naturalness, even boredom. His head was thrown back in such a way that it rested on the face of a defunct clock, and from that position, he looked with disturbed eyes at Daisy, frightened but very elegant, sitting on the edge of a chair.

en: “We’ve met before,” muttered Gatsby. His eyes glanced momentarily at me, and his lips parted with an abortive attempt at a laugh. Luckily the clock took this moment to tilt dangerously at the pressure of his head, whereupon he turned and caught it with trembling fingers, and set it back in place. Then he sat down, rigidly, his elbow on the arm of the sofa and his chin in his hand.
vi: "We knew each other from before." Gatsby said softly. His eyes glanced at me briefly, his lips parted trying to smile but couldn't. Fortunately, the clock chose that moment to tilt and almost fall due to the weight of his head. Gatsby turned back to catch it with trembling fingers, then placed it back in its original position. After that, Gatsby sat down, stiff, elbows on the armrest, hands supporting his chin.
tr: "We have met before," murmured Gatsby, turning his gaze to me for a moment. He was trying to smile but couldn't manage it. Just then, as the clock he was leaning his head on toppled over and he faced the danger of it falling, he quickly turned and, with trembling fingers, caught it and put it back in place. Then he rested his elbow on the arm of the couch, placed his hand on his chin, and sat down.
es: —We already knew each other —murmured Gatsby. He looked at me for a few seconds, and his lips parted in a failed attempt at laughter. Luckily, the clock took advantage of that moment to tilt dangerously under the pressure of Gatsby's head, who turned and caught it with trembling fingers to put it back in its place. Then he sat down, rigid, with his elbow on the arm of the sofa and his chin in his hand.

en: “I’m sorry about the clock,” he said.
vi: "I'm sorry about the watch," he said.
tr: “I am sorry about the time,” he said.
es: —I'm sorry about the watch —he said.

en: My own face had now assumed a deep tropical burn. I couldn’t muster up a single commonplace out of the thousand in my head.
vi: My face is now burning hot. I can't piece together a single coherent sentence from the thousands in my head.
tr: Meanwhile, my face had started to redden and burn as if it had been under a tropical sun. I couldn't pick and say even one of the thousands of sentences running through my head.
es: My face was burning as if we were in the tropics. I wasn't able to find a single cliché out of the thousand I have in my head.

en: “It’s an old clock,” I told them idiotically.
vi: "It's just a watch "It's just old." I told them foolishly.
tr: “It was already old,” I said finally, somewhat foolishly.
es: —It's an old watch —I said stupidly.

en: I think we all believed for a moment that it had smashed in pieces on the floor.
vi: I think all of us for a moment believed that the clock had shattered into pieces on the floor.
tr: We were acting as if the clock had fallen to the ground and shattered into pieces.
es: I think that, for a moment, the three of us thought that it had shattered against the ground.

en: “We haven’t met for many years,” said Daisy, her voice as matter-of-fact as it could ever be.
vi: "We haven't seen each other for many years." Daisy said, her voice sounding as if it were normal.
tr: “We hadn't seen each other for years,” said Daisy, trying to keep her voice as close to the real thing as possible.
es: —It's been many years since we last saw each other —said Daisy, with the most neutral voice possible.

en: “Five years next November.”
vi: "November coming will be five years."
tr: “It will be five years in November.”
es: —Five years next November.

en: The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute. I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray.
vi: Gatsby's mechanical response made us fall into an awkward silence for another minute. I found an excuse for the two of them to stand up by suggesting they help me make tea in the kitchen, but at that moment, the possessed Finnish woman brought up the tea tray.
tr: Gatsby's hasty response caused all of us to remain silent for at least another minute. Upon my desperate suggestion that they come to the kitchen to prepare tea, both of them jumped to their feet, just as my crazy Finnish helper burst in with a tray in hand.
es: Gatsby's automatic response paralyzed us for at least another minute. He had made them get up with the desperate suggestion that they help me prepare the tea in the kitchen when the devilish Finnish woman brought it on a tray.

en: Amid the welcome confusion of cups and cakes a certain physical decency established itself. Gatsby got himself into a shadow and, while Daisy and I talked, looked conscientiously from one to the other of us with tense, unhappy eyes. However, as calmness wasn’t an end in itself, I made an excuse at the first possible moment, and got to my feet.
vi: Thanks to bustling around with the tea cups and the cakes, everyone managed to regain their composure. While Daisy and I were chatting, Gatsby withdrew into silence, attentively watching one person after another with tense, sad eyes. However, tranquility was not the goal; as soon as I had the chance, I hastily excused myself and stood up.
tr: The anxiety that enveloped us while distributing the cups and cakes had given way to politeness. Gatsby, who had withdrawn into a corner, kept shifting his tense, unhappy gaze from one of us to the other as I spoke with Daisy. Since I anticipated that this stagnant atmosphere would not bring any resolution, I asked for permission to step outside as soon as I found the opportunity.
es: Amid the timely confusion of cups and cakes, a certain physical cordiality was established. Gatsby withdrew into the shade and, while Daisy and I talked, he alternately looked at each of us deeply, with eyes full of tension and unhappiness.
