But, since serenity was not an end in itself, I excused myself as soon as I could and stood up.

en: “Where are you going?” demanded Gatsby in immediate alarm.
vi: "Where are you planning to go?" Gatsby asked, sounding worried.
tr: "Where are you going?" asked Gatsby, suddenly panicking.
es: —Where are you going? —asked Gatsby, alarmed.

en: “I’ll be back.”
vi: "I will be right back."
tr: “I will be right back.”
es: —I will return.

en: “I’ve got to speak to you about something before you go.”
vi: "I want to talk to you about a few things before you go."
tr: "I want to talk to you about something before you leave.""
es: —I need to talk to you before you leave.

en: He followed me wildly into the kitchen, closed the door, and whispered: “Oh, God!” in a miserable way.
vi: Gatsby took me into the kitchen, closed the door, and whispered:
tr: He came after me, like a madman, into the kitchen and closed the door. “Oh, God,” he whispered in pain.
es: He followed me to the kitchen, distraught, closed the door, and murmured completely dejected: —My God.

en: “What’s the matter?”
vi: "Oh my God!" his voice was despondent. "What's going on?" "This is a very wrong thing to do."
tr: “What is it, what happened?”
es: —What's happening?

en: “This is a terrible mistake,” he said, shaking his head from side to side, “a terrible, terrible mistake.”
vi: Gatsby said, shaking his head back and forth. "A terrible, terrible mistake."
tr: “This is a big mistake,” he said, shaking his head from side to side, “a very big one!”
es: —It has been a terrible mistake —he said, shaking his head—, a terrible, terrible mistake.

en: “You’re just embarrassed, that’s all,” and luckily I added: “Daisy’s embarrassed too.”
vi: "Because you were too emotional, that's all." Luckily, I added, "Daisy was emotional too."
tr: “You were just a bit shy, that's all,” I said, thankfully adding, “Can't you see that Daisy is shy too?”
es: —You feel awkward, that's all —and luckily I added—. Daisy feels awkward too.

en: “She’s embarrassed?” he repeated incredulously.
vi: "Was she moved too?" Gatsby repeated my words skeptically.
tr: “So, he is afraid too?” he repeated, unable to believe it. “Of course.
es: —Do you feel violent? —he repeated, incredulous.

en: “Just as much as you are.”
vi: "No different from you."
tr: He is as shy as you are.”
es: —As much as you.

en: “Don’t talk so loud.”
vi: "Don't speak too loudly."
tr: “Don't speak loudly.”
es: —Don't speak so loudly.

en: “You’re acting like a little boy,” I broke out impatiently. “Not only that, but you’re rude. Daisy’s sitting in there all alone.”
vi: "You are acting like a child," I said impatiently. "Not only that, but you are also being rude." "Daisy is sitting out there all alone."
tr: “You are acting like a child,” I said, my patience wearing thin, “and that's not all. By leaving him alone inside, you are being rude.”
es: —You are acting like a child —I cut in, impatiently—. Not only that: you are acting like a rude person. There is Daisy, alone.

en: He raised his hand to stop my words, looked at me with unforgettable reproach, and, opening the door cautiously, went back into the other room.
vi: Gatsby raised his hand to stop me from speaking. He looked at me with an unforgettable look of shame, then carefully opened the door and went back to the living room.
tr: He raised his hand to stop me from saying more. He looked at me reproachfully, carefully opened the door, and returned to the room. I went out the back door and circled around to the front.
es: He raised his hand to stop my words, gave me an unforgettable look of reproach, and, opening the door very carefully, went back to the other room.

en: I walked out the back way—just as Gatsby had when he had made his nervous circuit of the house half an hour before—and ran for a huge black knotted tree, whose massed leaves made a fabric against the rain. Once more it was pouring, and my irregular lawn, well-shaved by Gatsby’s gardener, abounded in small muddy swamps and prehistoric marshes. There was nothing to look at from under the tree except Gatsby’s enormous house, so I stared at it, like Kant at his church steeple, for half an hour. A brewer had built it early in the “period” craze, a decade before, and there was a story that he’d agreed to pay five years’ taxes on all the neighbouring cottages if the owners would have their roofs thatched with straw. Perhaps their refusal took the heart out of his plan to Found a Family—he went into an immediate decline. His children sold his house with the black wreath still on the door. Americans, while willing, even eager, to be serfs, have always been obstinate about being peasantry.
vi: I went out of the house through the back way, just as Gatsby had done about half an hour earlier when he was nervously pacing around the house. I quickly ran to hide under a large, gnarled tree, whose lush foliage formed a rain shelter for me. Then the sky poured rain down onto my rugged garden, which Gatsby's gardener had meticulously trimmed. The lawn was now pockmarked with puddles and muddy patches, looking like prehistoric terrain. Standing under the tree, there was nothing to look at except Gatsby's grand house, so I stared at it for half an hour, just like Kant gazing at his church steeple. A bootlegger had built it a decade ago during the trend of constructing houses in classical architecture. According to the story, he had agreed to pay property taxes for all the neighboring houses for five years if the owners would thatch their roofs. Perhaps the refusal of these people had disappointed him to the point of losing interest in his project. His health immediately deteriorated severely. His descendants then sold the house while the mourning wreath was still hanging on the door. Americans, while occasionally willing to bow down as slaves, are always stubbornly unwilling to be farmers.
tr: Half an hour earlier, Gatsby had done the same thing, running in a semicircle in the rain. I took shelter under the tree in the front yard, its black trunk full of knots, and its large leaves resisting the raindrops. The rain had intensified, creating small ponds and swamps in my neglected garden covered with the short grass cut by Gatsby's gardener. The only place I could see from under the tree was Gatsby's magnificent mansion. Like Kant gazing at the church bell tower, I stared at it for half an hour. The building had been constructed ten years ago by a beer manufacturer in accordance with the 'period' fashion. According to a rumor, he had promised to cover the taxes for a year for the owners of the surrounding cottages if they agreed to thatch their roofs. The neighborhood's lack of enthusiasm for this family plan must have broken his heart, as his health suddenly deteriorated, and his children sold the mansion without even waiting for the black wreath on the door to be taken down. Americans occasionally desire to be bound to the land, but they have always resisted being part of the peasant class.
es: I went out through the back door—the same path that Gatsby, nervous, had taken half an hour earlier to go around the house—and ran towards an immense and gnarled black tree whose leafy branches wove a screen against the rain. It was pouring again, and my uneven lawn, freshly mowed by Gatsby's gardener, was teeming with tiny muddy swamps and prehistoric marshes. There was nothing to look at from the base of the tree except Gatsby's enormous house, so I dedicated myself to looking at it, like Kant at the steeple of his church, for half an hour. A brewer had built it at the beginning of the "period architecture" fashion, ten years earlier, and it was said that he had committed to paying the taxes of all the neighboring country houses for five years if the owners thatched their roofs. Perhaps the general rejection dissuaded the brewer from his plan to Found a Family: the decline began immediately. His children sold the house while the funeral wreath still hung on the door. Americans, willing to be servants and even eager to be so, have always been reluctant to be country folk.

en: After half an hour, the sun shone again, and the grocer’s automobile rounded Gatsby’s drive with the raw material for his servants’ dinner—I felt sure he wouldn’t eat a spoonful. A maid began opening the upper windows of his house, appeared momentarily in each, and, leaning from the large central bay, spat meditatively into the garden. It was time I went back. While the rain continued it had seemed like the murmur of their voices, rising and swelling a little now and then with gusts of emotion. But in the new silence I felt that silence had fallen within the house too.
vi: About half an hour later, the sun began to shine again. The food delivery truck drove into Gatsby's yard to deliver goods for the cook to prepare dinner, but I was certain Gatsby wouldn't eat a spoonful. A maid began to open the windows on the upper floor of Gatsby's house, her figure flickering through each window, then she stepped to a large central window and calmly leaned out to spit into the garden below. It was time for me to go back inside. When it was still raining, the sound of the rain was like the murmur of the two of them, occasionally rising and echoing full of emotion. But now I felt a new silence, and this silence seemed to envelop the house.
tr: Half an hour later, when the sun came out, the grocery wagon carrying the servants' dinner - I'm sure Gatsby didn't eat a spoonful of it - appeared in the back yard of the mansion. The maid opened the windows upstairs. She appeared at each window for a moment and then disappeared. When she reached the large window in the middle, she stuck her head out and spat into the garden. It was time to return. While it was raining, I felt as if I could hear the murmurs at home rising and falling with the increasing excitement. But that new silence seemed to have enveloped the house as well.
es: Half an hour later, the sun began to shine again, and the grocer's car took the road to Gatsby's house with the raw materials for the servants' dinner: he was sure Gatsby wouldn't eat anything. A maid began to open the windows on the upper floor of the house, appeared for a moment at each one, and, leaning out of the wide main balcony, spat meditatively into the garden. It was time to go back. The rain, while it lasted, seemed like the murmur of Gatsby and Daisy's voices, rising, growing occasionally in bursts of emotion. But now, in the new silence, I felt that silence had also fallen over the house.

en: I went in—after making every possible noise in the kitchen, short of pushing over the stove—but I don’t believe they heard a sound. They were sitting at either end of the couch, looking at each other as if some question had been asked, or was in the air, and every vestige of embarrassment was gone. Daisy’s face was smeared with tears, and when I came in she jumped up and began wiping at it with her handkerchief before a mirror. But there was a change in Gatsby that was simply confounding. He literally glowed; without a word or a gesture of exultation a new well-being radiated from him and filled the little room.
vi: I stepped into the house, trying every possible way to make noise in the kitchen, almost toppling the stove, but I believe they didn't hear anything. The two of them were sitting at opposite ends of the sofa, looking at each other as if they had asked or were still asking each other something, with all traces of awkwardness gone. Daisy's face was streaked with tears, and when she saw me enter, she stood up abruptly and began to wipe her tears with a handkerchief in front of the mirror. However, there was an astonishing change in Gatsby. He looked radiant, though he didn't say a word or make any joyful gesture, a bright happiness emanated from him, filling the entire room.
tr: I entered the room, making every kind of noise except throwing the oven to the floor. But I was sure they hadn't heard anything. They were sitting at opposite ends of the couch, looking at each other as if one had asked a question and the other was waiting for an answer, or as if the question was still hanging in the air. The initial shyness had disappeared. The traces of tears were still on Daisy's cheeks. When I entered, she jumped up and started wiping them off in front of the mirror. I couldn't believe the change I saw in Gatsby. Even while standing still and silent, he was literally glowing, and the light and happiness emanating from him filled the small room.
es: I entered —after making all the noise possible in the kitchen, short of knocking over the stove—, but I don't think they heard anything. They were sitting at the two ends of the sofa, looking at each other as if waiting for the answer to a question, or as if a question floated in the air, and all traces of discomfort had disappeared. Daisy's face was full of tears, and when I entered, she jumped up and started drying them with a handkerchief in front of a mirror. But in Gatsby, there had been a change that was simply bewildering. He literally glowed. Without a word or gesture of joy, he radiated a new well-being that filled the room.

en: “Oh, hello, old sport,” he said, as if he hadn’t seen me for years. I thought for a moment he was going to shake hands.
vi: "Oh, hello old friend." Gatsby said as if he hadn't seen me for many years. For a moment, I even thought he would reach out to shake my hand.
tr: "Hey, hello buddy," he said as if we hadn't seen each other in years. For a moment, I even thought he would shake my hand.
es: —Ah, hello, friend —he said, as if he hadn't seen me in years. I thought for a moment that he was going to shake my hand.

en: “It’s stopped raining.”
vi: "The rain has stopped."
tr: “The rain has stopped,” I said.
es: —It has stopped raining.

en: “Has it?” When he realized what I was talking about, that there were twinkle-bells of sunshine in the room, he smiled like a weather man, like an ecstatic patron of recurrent light, and repeated the news to Daisy. “What do you think of that? It’s stopped raining.”
vi: "Is that so?" When Gatsby realized what I had just said, the cheerful, sparkling rays of sunlight were already dancing throughout the room. He smiled like a meteorologist, like an enthusiastic regular guest upon seeing the sunlight return. He repeated this news to Daisy. "What do you think? The rain has stopped."
tr: “Is that so?” Understanding what I meant and seeing the sun streaming into the room, he smiled as if he were a meteorologist or the exuberant master of the entering rays and conveyed the news to Daisy. “What do you say to this? The rain has stopped”
es: —Yes? —when he understood what I had just told him, that little bells of sunlight were sparkling in the room, he smiled like a meteorologist, like the ecstatic sponsor of the returning light, and repeated the news to Daisy—. What do you think? It has stopped raining.

en: “I’m glad, Jay.” Her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty, told only of her unexpected joy.
vi: "I'm very happy, Jay." Daisy's throat was filled with a poignant beauty just to express unexpected joys.
tr: "I'm very happy about this, Jay," she said, her sorrowful yet beautiful voice filled with traces of unexpected happiness.
es: —I'm glad, Jay —her throat, filled with a sad and aching beauty, spoke only of her unexpected happiness.

en: “I want you and Daisy to come over to my house,” he said, “I’d like to show her around.”
vi: "I want to invite you and Daisy to visit my house," Gatsby said. "I want to take Daisy around the house."
tr: “I want you and Daisy to come to my place. I will show her my house,” said Gatsby.
es: —I want you to come home with me. I would like to show it to Daisy.

en: “You’re sure you want me to come?”
vi: "Do you really want me to leave?"
tr: “Are you sure you want me to come?”
es: —Are you sure you want me to go?

en: “Absolutely, old sport.”
vi: "Definitely want to, old friend."
tr: “Of course, buddy.”
es: —Absolutely, comrade.

en: Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.
vi: Daisy went upstairs to wash her face while Gatsby and I stood waiting on the lawn. Too late, I felt embarrassed thinking about my face towels in the bathroom.
tr: Daisy had gone upstairs to wash her face. For a moment, I felt embarrassed thinking about the state of my towels, but it was too late now. We started waiting in the garden with Gatsby.
es: Daisy went up to wash her face —and too late I remembered, with humiliation, my towels— while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.

en: “My house looks well, doesn’t it?” he demanded. “See how the whole front of it catches the light.”
vi: "My house looks very beautiful, doesn't it?" Gatsby asked. "Look, the entire facade is illuminated."
tr: “My house looks beautiful, doesn't it?” she asked, “Look how nicely the front gets sunlight.”
es: —My house is nice, right? —he asked me—. Look at how the light hits the facade.

en: I agreed that it was splendid.
vi: I agree the house is indeed magnificent.
tr: I confirmed that it was magnificent.
es: I recognized that it was splendid.

en: “Yes.” His eyes went over it, every arched door and square tower. “It took me just three years to earn the money that bought it.”
vi: "That's right." Gatsby's eyes glanced over the house, through each arched door to the square tower peak. "It only took me three years to make enough money to buy it."
tr: “Yes,” he said, letting his eyes wander over the arched doors and angular towers of the house, “I earned the money needed to buy it in just three years.”
es: —Yes —he scanned it with his eyes, lingering on the arch of each door, on the solidity of each tower—. It took me three years to earn the money to buy it.

en: “I thought you inherited your money.”
vi: "I thought your money was inherited?"
tr: “I thought you had inherited it.”
es: —I thought you had inherited your money.

en: “I did, old sport,” he said automatically, “but I lost most of it in the big panic—the panic of the war.”
vi: "That's right, old sport." Gatsby replied mechanically. "But I lost everything during the crisis, the war crisis."
tr: “Yes, that's right, buddy,” he said without hesitation, “but I lost a significant portion of that money during the great panic. I'm talking about the panic before the war.”
es: —And I inherited it, my friend —he said immediately—, but I lost almost everything in the great panic..., the panic of the war.

en: I think he hardly knew what he was saying, for when I asked him what business he was in he answered: “That’s my affair,” before he realized that it wasn’t an appropriate reply.
vi: I think he actually doesn't know what he's talking about, because when I asked him what his profession was, he answered "That's my personal business" before realizing that his answer was inappropriate.
tr: I think he wasn't really aware of what he was saying, because when I asked what he did for a living, he said, "That's something for me to know." He didn't think he had given an inappropriate answer.
es: I thought he didn't really know what he was saying, because when I asked him what kind of business he was in, he replied, "That's my business," before realizing that it wasn't an appropriate answer.

en: “Oh, I’ve been in several things,” he corrected himself. “I was in the drug business and then I was in the oil business. But I’m not in either one now.” He looked at me with more attention. “Do you mean you’ve been thinking over what I proposed the other night?”
vi: "Oh, I have worked in many professions." Gatsby corrected. "I used to work in the pharmaceutical industry and then moved to the oil industry. But now I have left both." He looked at me more intently. "Are you implying that you are considering the proposal I made the other night?"
tr: “It can be said that I have done a lot of work,” he tried to correct his mistake. “First, I was in the pharmaceutical business, then I got into oil. These days, I have quit both.” He looked at my face carefully. “Are you trying to say that you have thought about my suggestion from the other night?”
es: —Ah, I have gotten into various things —he corrected—. I have dedicated myself to the drugstore business and to the oil business. But I have left both —he looked at me more attentively—. Do you mean that you have thought about what I proposed to you the other night?

en: Before I could answer, Daisy came out of the house and two rows of brass buttons on her dress gleamed in the sunlight.
vi: Before I could answer, Daisy had already stepped out of the house, the rows of brass buttons on her shirt sparkling under the sunlight.
tr: Before I had time to respond, Daisy appeared. The two rows of brass buttons on her dress were shining in the sun.
es: Before he could answer her, Daisy came out of the house and two rows of brass buttons shone in the sun.

en: “That huge place there?” she cried pointing.
vi: "Is THAT the huge house?" Daisy exclaimed, pointing towards the house.
tr: “Are you talking about that huge building?” he shouted, pointing at the mansion with his hand.
es: —That enormous house over there? —he exclaimed, pointing with his finger.

en: “Do you like it?”
vi: "Do you like it?"
tr: “Did you like it?” “I loved it!
es: —Do you like it?

en: “I love it, but I don’t see how you live there all alone.”
vi: "I like it but I don't understand how you can be there alone."
tr: But I didn't quite understand how you lived there alone.”
es: —I love it, but I don't know how you can live there completely alone.

en: “I keep it always full of interesting people, night and day. People who do interesting things. Celebrated people.”
vi: "You always invite interesting people to the house, day and night. People who have done remarkable things. Famous personalities."
tr: “I fill it with a lot of interesting people morning and evening. Interesting people doing interesting jobs, famous faces.”
es: —I always have it full of interesting people, day and night. People who do interesting things. Famous people.

en: Instead of taking the shortcut along the Sound we went down to the road and entered by the big postern. With enchanting murmurs Daisy admired this aspect or that of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling odour of jonquils and the frothy odour of hawthorn and plum blossoms and the pale gold odour of kiss-me-at-the-gate. It was strange to reach the marble steps and find no stir of bright dresses in and out the door, and hear no sound but bird voices in the trees.
vi: Instead of taking a shortcut along the bay shore, we went out onto the road and then entered through the main gate. With a mesmerizing whisper, Daisy praised every feature of the house, which stood towering and casting its shadow against the sky. She admired the garden with the rich, sparkling scent of perennial daffodils, the sharp, effervescent aroma of hawthorn and plum blossoms, and the pale yellow fragrance of kiss-me-at-the-gate flowers. Strangely, as we approached the granite steps, we did not see the colorful dresses fluttering in and out of the door, nor did we hear any sound except for the chirping of birds on the branches.
tr: Instead of taking the shortcut along the Bosphorus, we went down to the main road and entered through the grand front gate of the mansion. Daisy was praising the right and left sides of the house or its feudal silhouette rising to the sky with her enchanting voice. She was captivated by the gardens, the sharp scent of jonquils, the foamy scent of hawthorn and plum blossoms, and the pale yellow fragrance of honeysuckle. When we reached the marble stairs, it struck me as odd not to see women in colorful dresses going in and out and to hear nothing but the sound of birds in the trees.
es: Instead of taking the coastal shortcut, we went down to the road and entered through the large gate. With charming whispers, Daisy admired this or that aspect of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling scent of the daffodils, the bubbling scent of the hawthorns and the blooming plum trees, and the pale golden scent of the honeysuckle. It was strange to arrive at the marble staircase and not find a flurry of radiant dresses, coming in and out of the house, and only hear the song of the birds in the trees.

en: And inside, as we wandered through Marie Antoinette music-rooms and Restoration Salons, I felt that there were guests concealed behind every couch and table, under orders to be breathlessly silent until we had passed through. As Gatsby closed the door of “the Merton College Library” I could have sworn I heard the owl-eyed man break into ghostly laughter.
vi: As we entered the house and passed through the music rooms decorated in the style of Queen Marie Antoinette and the living rooms decorated in the English Renaissance style, I felt as if there were guests hiding behind each chair, behind each table, as if they were following orders to hold their breath and remain silent until we passed by. When Gatsby closed the door of the library room "the Merton College Library," I swear I heard the voice of the owl-eyed man let out a ghostly laugh.
tr: Inside, while wandering through the music rooms furnished in Marie Antoinette style and the salons adorned with antiques from the 17th and 18th centuries, I had the feeling that guests were hiding behind every chair or table and silently waiting until we moved away. When Gatsby closed the door of the 'Merton University Library,' I almost heard the ghost of the owl-eyed man laughing behind us.
es: And inside, as we walked through music rooms à la Marie Antoinette and Restoration-style salons, I had the feeling that there were guests hidden behind every sofa and every table, with orders to keep silent, not even to breathe, until we had passed. When Gatsby closed the door of the "Merton College Library," I could have sworn I heard the spectral laughter of the man with owl eyes.

en: We went upstairs, through period bedrooms swathed in rose and lavender silk and vivid with new flowers, through dressing-rooms and poolrooms, and bathrooms with sunken baths—intruding into one chamber where a dishevelled man in pyjamas was doing liver exercises on the floor. It was Mr. Klipspringer, the “boarder.” I had seen him wandering hungrily about the beach that morning. Finally we came to Gatsby’s own apartment, a bedroom and a bath, and an Adam’s study, where we sat down and drank a glass of some Chartreuse he took from a cupboard in the wall.
vi: We went upstairs, passing by bedrooms decorated in an old-fashioned style with pink silk, purple silk, and vibrantly displayed freshly picked flowers. Passing by the dressing rooms, billiard rooms, and bathrooms with sunken tubs, we inadvertently entered a room where a guest in pajamas with disheveled hair was performing liver exercises on the floor. It was Klipspringer, the "boarder." I had seen him wandering hungrily by the sea every morning. Finally, we reached Gatsby's private quarters, which included a bedroom, a bathroom, and a study decorated in the Adam style. We sat in the study and drank a glass of Chartreuse that Gatsby had just taken from a shelf on the wall.
tr: We went upstairs. We passed through bedrooms and dressing rooms furnished in various period styles, covered with rose and lilac-colored silks, decorated with fresh flowers, billiard rooms, and bathrooms with built-in tubs. When we entered one of the rooms, a man with disheveled hair and beard, wearing pajamas, was doing gymnastics exercises. This was Mr. Klipspringer, who was said to be a 'boarder.' I had seen him in the morning, wandering on the beach with a look on his face that revealed his hunger. Finally, we arrived at Gatsby's private suite. Inside, there was a bedroom, a bathroom furnished in classic Scottish style, and a study in the style of James and Robert Adam. We sat there and drank a glass of Chartreuse that he took out from a cupboard in the wall.
es: We went up to the second floor, passed through period bedrooms upholstered in pink and lavender silk and enlivened by fresh flowers, and dressing rooms and billiard rooms, and bathrooms with sunken bathtubs, and we appeared uninvited in a room where a man in pajamas, lying down and disheveled, was doing liver exercises. It was Mr. Klipspringer, the Boarder. That morning I had seen him wandering anxiously along the beach. We finally arrived at Gatsby's apartment, a bedroom with a bathroom, and an Adam-style study, where we sat and drank a Chartreuse that he kept in a cupboard.

en: He hadn’t once ceased looking at Daisy, and I think he revalued everything in his house according to the measure of response it drew from her well-loved eyes. Sometimes too, he stared around at his possessions in a dazed way, as though in her actual and astounding presence none of it was any longer real. Once he nearly toppled down a flight of stairs.
vi: Gatsby never took his eyes off Daisy; I think he was valuing everything in his house based on the reaction in her lovely eyes. Sometimes, he would also stare blankly at his possessions, as if in the very real and astonishing presence of Daisy, those things ceased to be real. Once, he almost fell down the stairs.
tr: Gatsby had not taken his eyes off Daisy for even a moment. He must have been reevaluating everything in his house based on the reaction he saw in her beautiful eyes. Sometimes he looked at the items in the house as if none of them were real compared to Daisy's captivating presence. He had stumbled once while coming down the stairs. He almost fell.
es: He hadn't stopped looking at Daisy for a moment, and I think he recalculated the value of everything in the house based on the reaction it provoked in her beloved eyes. And sometimes, he looked at his possessions as if dazed, as if in the material and wondrous presence of Daisy, nothing was real anymore. He almost fell down the stairs.

en: His bedroom was the simplest room of all—except where the dresser was garnished with a toilet set of pure dull gold. Daisy took the brush with delight, and smoothed her hair, whereupon Gatsby sat down and shaded his eyes and began to laugh.
vi: Compared to the other rooms, Gatsby's room was the simplest, except for the mirrored table with a gold-plated grooming set. Daisy delightedly picked up the comb and brushed her hair. At that moment, Gatsby sat down, covered his eyes with his hand, and burst out laughing.
tr: The most simply furnished place was the bedroom. Except for the sets on the dressing table, everything was made of matte pure gold. When Daisy picked up a brush from there and started to fix her hair, Gatsby sat on a chair and began to laugh, shielding his eyes with his hand.
es: His bedroom was the simplest, except for a set of pure matte gold dresser accessories that adorned the dresser. Daisy picked up the brush with delight and smoothed her hair, at which Gatsby sat down, put his hand to his eyes, and burst out laughing.

en: “It’s the funniest thing, old sport,” he said hilariously. “I can’t—When I try to—”
vi: "This is the funniest thing, old chap." Gatsby chuckled. "I can't... When I try..."
tr: "This is the funniest thing I've ever seen, buddy," he said while laughing consecutively, "I can't stop it even if I wanted to..."
es: —It's the most fun, buddy —he said, laughing—. I can't... When I try to...

en: He had passed visibly through two states and was entering upon a third. After his embarrassment and his unreasoning joy he was consumed with wonder at her presence. He had been full of the idea so long, dreamed it right through to the end, waited with his teeth set, so to speak, at an inconceivable pitch of intensity. Now, in the reaction, he was running down like an over-wound clock.
vi: Gatsby clearly had gone through two stages and now he was entering the third stage. After awkwardness and then indescribable joy, he was now savoring the miraculous feeling of Daisy's presence. Gatsby had waited for this day for so long, dreamed about it, or one could say, waited for it with unimaginable tension. Yet now, when faced with it, he was like a broken clock wound too tight. After a moment of composure, Gatsby opened
tr: That day had passed through two visible stages and was now about to enter the third. It had started with shyness and transitioned into an inexplicable joy. Now, however, he was floundering in amazement at Daisy's presence there. Having burned with the desire to do this for years, having imagined everything down to the finest detail, and having waited with incredible longing and patience, he had become like a clock whose spring had unwound from being overly wound.
es: He had evidently gone through two states of mind and was reaching a third. After the discomfort and the irrational joy, he was now consumed by the miracle of Daisy's presence. He had let himself be absorbed by that idea for a long time, dreaming it from beginning to end while waiting with gritted teeth, so to speak, with an unimaginable degree of intensity. Now, as a reaction, he was beginning to wind down like an overwound clock.

en: Recovering himself in a minute he opened for us two hulking patent cabinets which held his massed suits and dressing-gowns and ties, and his shirts, piled like bricks in stacks a dozen high.
vi: showed us two enormous wardrobes, inside which hung layer upon layer of suits, pajamas, and ties, while the shirts were neatly and orderly stacked on top of each other like dozens of bricks.
tr: After a while, he pulled himself together and began to show the suits, dressing gowns, and ties that filled the insides to the brim, by opening the polished doors of the two wardrobes wide open, as well as the shirts carefully folded and stacked like bricks.
es: He recovered immediately and opened for us two heavy and powerful wardrobes that contained his many suits, dressing gowns, and ties, and his shirts, stacked like bricks by the dozen.

en: “I’ve got a man in England who buys me clothes. He sends over a selection of things at the beginning of each season, spring and fall.”
vi: "I found someone in England to buy clothes for me. Every early spring and winter, he sends me all kinds of selected items."
tr: “A man in England buys my clothes. He selects and sends them to me at the beginning of spring and autumn.”
es: —I have someone in England responsible for buying my clothes. They send me a selection of garments at the beginning of the season, in spring and autumn.

en: He took out a pile of shirts and began throwing them, one by one, before us, shirts of sheer linen and thick silk and fine flannel, which lost their folds as they fell and covered the table in many-coloured disarray. While we admired he brought more and the soft rich heap mounted higher—shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple-green and lavender and faint orange, with monograms of indian blue. Suddenly, with a strained sound, Daisy bent her head into the shirts and began to cry stormily.
vi: Gatsby took out a stack of shirts and began throwing them down, one by one, in front of us. The shirts made of thin linen, thick silk, and fine flannel were crumpled as they were thrown down, covering the table in a mix of colors. While we were still admiring them, Gatsby brought out even more, piling them up into a high, smooth, colorful heap. Long-striped shirts, patterned stripes, checkered stripes in coral, light green, light purple, light orange, and light blue. Daisy suddenly let out a strange sound, then buried her face in the shirts and began to sob uncontrollably.
tr: He reached for one of the piles of shirts. The folds of the linen, thick silk, and fine flannel shirts he threw in front of us one by one were getting disheveled as they fell to the ground. The top of the table soon turned into a colorful flower garden. While Daisy and I stood in awe, he began to rummage through the other piles. The soft mound forming on the table was steadily rising. As I looked at the striped, plaid, coral, apple green, lavender, and orange shirts with his initials embroidered in blue thread on all of them, I suddenly heard a sob. Daisy was crying, collapsed over the shirts.
es: He grabbed a bunch of shirts and started throwing them, one by one, in front of us, shirts of pure linen, thick silk, fine flannel, which unfolded as they fell and covered the table in a multicolored confusion. While we expressed our admiration, Gatsby kept pulling out shirts and the soft and sumptuous pile kept growing: striped shirts and ones with arabesques and prints in coral, apple green, lavender, and light orange, with monograms in an indigo shade. Suddenly, amidst muffled sounds, Daisy buried her face in the shirts and began to cry inconsolably.

en: “They’re such beautiful shirts,” she sobbed, her voice muffled in the thick folds. “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.”
vi: "Everything is so beautiful." Daisy sobbed, her voice choked in the thick folds. "It makes me sad because I've never seen such beautiful dresses before."
tr: "These are very beautiful," he said, his voice muffled as it was buried in the shirts. "Suddenly, a sadness enveloped me, because I had never seen such beautiful shirts."
es: —These are such wonderful shirts —she sobbed, and the folds, the fabric, muffled her voice—. I cry because I had never seen such... such wonderful shirts.

en: After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.
vi: Behind the house, we planned to step outside to visit the garden, the swimming pool, the seaplane, and the flowers blooming in the middle of summer. However, outside the window, it started raining again, so we stood in a row looking out at the rippling water in the bay.
tr: After touring the house, we were going to go outside to see the gardens, the swimming pool, the seaplane, and the summer flowers, but when we saw from the window in Gatsby's room that the rain had started again, the three of us went to the window and began to watch the water of the Bosphorus wrinkle with the falling drops.
es: After the house, we had to see the gardens and the pool, the hydroplane, and the summer flowers, but it started to rain again, so we stayed watching the rippling waters of the sound from Gatsby's window.

en: “If it wasn’t for the mist we could see your home across the bay,” said Gatsby. “You always have a green light that burns all night at the end of your dock.”
vi: "If there were no fog, we could see your house across the bay." Gatsby said. "There is always a green light burning all night at the end of your dock."
tr: "If the weather hadn't been hazy, we could have seen your house across the bay," said Gatsby. "There is a green light that burns all night at the end of your dock."
es: —If there wasn't fog, we would see your house on the other side of the bay —said Gatsby—. You always have a green light that shines all night at the end of the dock.

en: Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Possibly it had occurred to him that the colossal significance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that had separated him from Daisy it had seemed very near to her, almost touching her. It had seemed as close as a star to the moon. Now it was again a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.
vi: Daisy suddenly linked her arm through Gatsby's, but he seemed to be lost in the words he had just spoken. Perhaps he had just realized that the great significance of the green light would forever vanish from now on. Compared to the vast distance separating him and Daisy, the green light seemed very close to her, almost within her reach. It was almost like a star near the moon. Now the green light shone again as it did every day. The things he had been passionately obsessed with every day now had one less.
tr: Daisy took his arm, but Gatsby was lost in what he had just said. Perhaps he was thinking that the great significance he had given to that light had vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that separated him from Daisy, that light had seemed much closer to the woman, close enough to touch. As close as the stars are to the moon. Now it would just be any light at the end of the dock. One of the enchanting bonds between them had diminished.
es: Daisy suddenly took him by the arm, but Gatsby seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Perhaps he realized that the colossal significance of that light had just vanished forever. Compared to the immense distance that had separated him from Daisy, the green light seemed very close to her, almost touching her. It seemed as close as a star is to the moon. And now it was once again a green light on a dock. The number of enchanted objects had diminished by one.

en: I began to walk about the room, examining various indefinite objects in the half darkness. A large photograph of an elderly man in yachting costume attracted me, hung on the wall over his desk.
vi: I wandered aimlessly around the room, examining everything in the dim light. A picture of a middle-aged man in a sailor's outfit hanging on the wall, right above Gatsby's desk, caught my attention.
tr: I started walking inside the room. I was examining objects that I randomly came across in the semi-darkness. A large photograph of an old man dressed in a captain's uniform, hanging on the wall opposite the desk, had caught my attention.
es: I started to walk around the room, examining things, indistinct in the semi-darkness. The large photo of an older man dressed for yachting, hanging on the wall above the desk, caught my attention.

en: “Who’s this?”
vi: "Who is there?"
tr: "Who is this?"”
es: —Who is it?

en: “That? That’s Mr. Dan Cody, old sport.”
vi: "That person? That's Mr. Dan Cody, my old friend."
tr: “Oh him? That's Dan Cody, buddy.”
es: —That one? That's mister Dan Cody, buddy.

en: The name sounded faintly familiar.
vi: The name sounds somewhat familiar to me.
tr: The name seemed familiar.
es: The name seemed vaguely familiar to me.

en: “He’s dead now. He used to be my best friend years ago.”
vi: "He has passed away." "Many years ago, he was a close friend of mine."
tr: “He is no longer alive. Years ago, he was my best friend.”
es: —He died years ago. He was my best friend.

en: There was a small picture of Gatsby, also in yachting costume, on the bureau—Gatsby with his head thrown back defiantly—taken apparently when he was about eighteen.
vi: There was a small picture of Gatsby on the desk, also in a sailor's outfit. In the picture, Gatsby stood with his head tilted defiantly, probably taken when he was about eighteen years old.
tr: On the desk was a small photograph of Gatsby, taken when he was eighteen, dressed in a captain's uniform. He had posed with his head thrown back defiantly, as if challenging the world.
es: There was a small photo of Gatsby, also dressed for sailing, on top of the desk —Gatsby, defiantly, threw his head back—, from when he must have been about eighteen years old.

en: “I adore it,” exclaimed Daisy. “The pompadour! You never told me you had a pompadour—or a yacht.”
vi: "I really like this picture." Daisy exclaimed. "Slicked-back hair! You never told me you had slicked-back hair - or a yacht."
tr: "I loved this," Daisy shouted. "Hair pompadour3! You never told me you styled it like this, nor that you had a yacht, of course." 3 Jeanne-Antoinette Poisson, Marquise de Pompadour. The pompadour hairstyle, created by sweeping the hair back, is dedicated to her.
es: —I love it —exclaimed Daisy—. The toupee! You never told me you had a toupee, nor a yacht.

en: “Look at this,” said Gatsby quickly. “Here’s a lot of clippings—about you.”
vi: "Look here," Gatsby said swiftly. "There are many newspaper clippings about you here."
tr: "Look at these," said Gatsby, "the articles about me in the newspapers and magazines."
es: —Look —Gatsby hurried to say—. There are a lot of newspaper clippings… about you.

en: They stood side by side examining it. I was going to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby took up the receiver.
vi: The two of them stood close together looking through the pieces of newspaper. I was about to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby picked up the receiver.
tr: They were standing side by side, looking at the writings. Just as I was about to ask about the famous ruby collection, the phone rang. Gatsby picked up the receiver.
es: One next to the other, standing, they began to watch them. I was going to ask him to show me the rubies when the phone rang and Gatsby picked up.

en: “Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I can’t talk now, old sport… I said a small town… He must know what a small town is… Well, he’s no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town…”
vi: "Alright... alright, I can't talk right now... I can't talk right now old friend... I said a SMALL town... he has to know what a small town is. Well, he's just useless to us if he thinks Detroit is a small town..."
tr: “Yes. I can't talk now... I said I can't talk now, buddy... I said it was a small town... he should know what a small town means... if he thinks Detroit is a small town, then he's no use to us anyway...”
es: —Yes… Alright, but I can't talk right now… I can't talk, buddy… I said a small city. Small… He knows what a small city is, doesn't he? If Detroit is a small city to him, it won't work for us…

en: He rang off.
vi: He hung up.
tr: He hung up the phone.
es: He hung up.

en: “Come here quick!” cried Daisy at the window.
vi: "Get here QUICKLY!" Daisy shouted from the window.
tr: “Come here quickly!” Daisy called out, standing in front of the window.
es: —Come, come, quickly! —shouted Daisy at the window.

en: The rain was still falling, but the darkness had parted in the west, and there was a pink and golden billow of foamy clouds above the sea.
vi: The rain is still falling, but the darkness has lifted from the west. The fluffy clouds, tinged with pink and yellow, look like cotton pillows floating on the sea.
tr: The rain continued, but the weather had started to clear from the west, and the clouds over the sea had turned into piles of pink and golden foam.
es: It was still raining, but the shadows had parted to the west, and over the sea there was a pink and gold wave of clouds that looked like foam.

en: “Look at that,” she whispered, and then after a moment: “I’d like to just get one of those pink clouds and put you in it and push you around.”
vi: "Look." Daisy whispered, then continued after a moment: "I want to reach out and grab one of those pink clouds, put you on it, and push you everywhere."
tr: "Look over there," Daisy said in a whisper, "I wish I could catch one of those pink clouds, put you inside it, and take you for a ride," she continued a minute later.
es: —Look! —whispered Daisy, and fell silent for a few seconds—. I would like to catch one of those pink clouds and lift you up and push you.

en: I tried to go then, but they wouldn’t hear of it; perhaps my presence made them feel more satisfactorily alone.
vi: I tried to say goodbye, but they pretended not to hear. Perhaps my presence made them feel more natural when being next to each other.
tr: When I said that I wanted to leave, both of them said they didn't even want to hear it. Perhaps my presence with them was comforting.
es: I tried to leave then, but they didn't want to hear about it; maybe they felt better alone if I was there.

en: “I know what we’ll do,” said Gatsby, “we’ll have Klipspringer play the piano.”
vi: "I know what we should do." Gatsby said. "We will call Klipspringer to play the piano."
tr: "I know what we will do now," said Gatsby. "I will call Klipspringer here and ask him to play the piano for us."
es: —I know what we are going to do —said Gatsby—. Klipspringer is going to play the piano.

en: He went out of the room calling “Ewing!” and returned in a few minutes accompanied by an embarrassed, slightly worn young man, with shell-rimmed glasses and scanty blond hair. He was now decently clothed in a “sport shirt,” open at the neck, sneakers, and duck trousers of a nebulous hue.
vi: Gatsby stepped out of the room and called out "Ewing!", a few minutes later he returned with a young man who had a shy, tired demeanor, wearing tortoiseshell glasses and sparse blonde hair. This young man was now dressed in a neat sports coat, open-necked shirt, sports shoes, and dark-colored trousers.
tr: “Ewing!” he called out as he left the room. A few minutes later, he returned with a shy, lightly dressed, blond young man with thin hair and wearing horn-rimmed glasses. The man's previously disheveled state was gone. He was wearing a sporty shirt, rubber shoes, and pale-colored canvas trousers.
es: He left the room shouting "Ewing" and returned a few minutes later accompanied by a somewhat worn-out, dazed young man, with tortoiseshell-framed glasses and thin, blond hair. At that moment, he was wearing a sports shirt, open at the neck, rubber-soled shoes, and drill trousers of a nebulous color.

en: “Did we interrupt your exercise?” inquired Daisy politely.
vi: "Did we disturb you while you were rehearsing?" Daisy asked politely.
tr: “Did we prevent you from doing gymnastics?” Daisy asked politely.
es: —Have we interrupted your exercises? —asked Daisy, very politely.

en: “I was asleep,” cried Mr. Klipspringer, in a spasm of embarrassment. “That is, I’d been asleep. Then I got up…”
vi: "I was sleeping." Klipspringer said loudly, humbly ashamed. "Indeed, I was sleeping. Then I woke up..."
tr: “I was sleeping,” Mr. Klipsinger replied hesitantly, “I mean, I dozed off but then I got up and...”
es: —I was sleeping —mister Klipspringer complained with a shiver of embarrassment—. That is to say, I had been sleeping. Then I got up and…

en: “Klipspringer plays the piano,” said Gatsby, cutting him off. “Don’t you, Ewing, old sport?”
vi: "Klipspringer, play the piano." Gatsby interrupted. "You can play, can't you, old sport?"
tr: “Klipsinger plays the piano very well,” said Gatsby, cutting in, “isn't that right, Ewing, old sport?”
es: —Klipspringer plays the piano —said Gatsby, interrupting him—. Isn't that right, old sport?

en: “I don’t play well. I don’t—hardly play at all. I’m all out of prac—”
vi: "I'm not very good at playing. I... hardly ever play. I haven't practiced in a long time..."
tr: “I don't play very well. I haven't played for a long time. I haven't practiced much...”
es: —I don't play it well. No..., I hardly even know how to play it. And I haven't played in...

en: “We’ll go downstairs,” interrupted Gatsby. He flipped a switch. The grey windows disappeared as the house glowed full of light.
vi: "Let's go downstairs." Gatsby interrupted. He raised his hand to turn off the light, the gray window frames seemed to disappear as the house filled with light.
tr: “Let's go downstairs,” she interrupted the man again. As she touched the button, the dark windows disappeared and everything was bathed in light.
es: —Let's go downstairs —Gatsby interrupted him. He flipped a switch. The gray windows disappeared as the house flooded with light.

en: In the music-room Gatsby turned on a solitary lamp beside the piano. He lit Daisy’s cigarette from a trembling match, and sat down with her on a couch far across the room, where there was no light save what the gleaming floor bounced in from the hall.
vi: In the music room, Gatsby turned on the solitary standing lamp beside the piano. He tremulously lit a cigarette for Daisy, then sat down next to her on a chair on the other side of the room, where the light couldn't reach, to complement the flickering light from the hallway that shone through the door onto the floor.
tr: When they entered the music room, Gatsby turned on the lamp standing next to the piano. After lighting Daisy's cigarette, the two of them sat together on the couch in a dim corner of the room. The only thing illuminating their surroundings was the polished floor shining with the light coming from the corridor.
es: In the music room, Gatsby only lit one lamp, next to the piano. He brought a trembling match to Daisy's cigarette and sat with her on a sofa at the back of the room, where there was no other light except for that which, coming from the lobby, reflected off the shiny floor.

en: When Klipspringer had played “The Love Nest” he turned around on the bench and searched unhappily for Gatsby in the gloom.
vi: When Klipspringer finished playing The Love Nest, he turned around to look for Gatsby in the dim darkness, his face pained.
tr: When Klipsinger finished playing the piece titled 'Love Nest,' he turned in a half-circle on the stool and searched for Gatsby in the dark with his sorrowful eyes.
es: When Klipspringer played The Love Nest[15], he turned on his stool and, desolate, looked for Gatsby in the dim light.

en: “I’m all out of practice, you see. I told you I couldn’t play. I’m all out of prac—”
vi: "You see, I haven't practiced for a long time. I told you I couldn't play. I haven't practiced for a long time..."
tr: "My fingers are not ready, you saw it too. I told you I couldn't play well, regular practice..."
es: —You see, I should practice more. I had told you that I don't know how to play. And I should pra…

en: “Don’t talk so much, old sport,” commanded Gatsby. “Play!”
vi: "Don't talk too much, old sport," Gatsby ordered. "Play on!"
tr: “Don't talk too much, just play, buddy!” ordered Gatsby.
es: —Don't talk so much, buddy —ordered Gatsby—. Play!

en: “In the morning,
vi: "FROM EARLY MORNING
tr: In the mornings
es: During the day,

en: In the evening,
vi: TO THE EVENING
tr: In the evenings
es: at night,

en: Ain’t we got fun—”
vi: ARE WE HAPPY?
tr: Didn't we have a lot of fun...’
es: Didn't we have a good time?[16]

en: Outside the wind was loud and there was a faint flow of thunder along the Sound. All the lights were going on in West Egg now; the electric trains, men-carrying, were plunging home through the rain from New York. It was the hour of a profound human change, and excitement was generating on the air.
vi: Outside, the wind was blowing hard, and in the distance, the faint sound of thunder echoed from the bay. The houses in the village of West Egg had already lit up. The electric trains carrying people from New York were rushing through the rain. This was the moment of profound human change, and excitement began to spread through the air.
tr: A strong wind was blowing outside, and the sound of lightning striking over the distant sea could be heard. The sky had darkened, and lights had started to come on in West Egg. Trains loaded with people coming from New York were passing through the rain, dropping everyone off at their homes. It was the busiest hour of the day. A great excitement and rush had enveloped the surroundings.
es: Outside, the wind was blowing strongly and there were very faint thunderclaps in the strait. In West Egg, all the lights were already on; the electric trains, arriving from New York loaded with people, were rushing home through the rain. It was the hour when a profound change occurs in humanity and the atmosphere generates tension.

en: “One thing’s sure and nothing’s surer
vi: "THERE IS ONE THING CERTAIN - NOTHING IS MORE CERTAIN"
tr: ‘One thing is certain, more than anything else,
es: There is one thing certain, more certain than any other:

en: The rich get richer and the poor get—children.
vi: The rich get richer, the poor have more children
tr: The rich make money, the poor make children
es: the rich make money and the poor make… children.

en: In the meantime,
vi: IN THE MIDST OF IT, IN THE MIDST OF IT...
tr: These days,
es: In the idle hours,

en: In between time—”
vi: IN THE MIDST OF IT, IN THE MIDST OF IT...
tr: Between times...'
es: between moments.

en: As I went over to say goodbye I saw that the expression of bewilderment had come back into Gatsby’s face, as though a faint doubt had occurred to him as to the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy tumbled short of his dreams—not through her own fault, but because of the colossal vitality of his illusion. It had gone beyond her, beyond everything. He had thrown himself into it with a creative passion, adding to it all the time, decking it out with every bright feather that drifted his way. No amount of fire or freshness can challenge what a man can store up in his ghostly heart.
vi: When I stepped up to say goodbye, I saw the look of confusion and bewilderment reappear on Gatsby's face, as if a slight doubt had just crossed his mind about the happiness he was experiencing. It had been five years, and surely there had been moments, even moments that afternoon, when Daisy had not been exactly as he had imagined her in his dreams. It was not Daisy's fault, but rather the immense, intense illusion that Gatsby had created. Gatsby had thrown himself into this illusion with a passionate creativity, each day adding to it, embellishing it with bright feathers that carried him away. No blaze or freshness could compare to what a man holds in the emptiness of his heart.
tr: When I went to them for Veda, I noticed that the astonishment had returned and settled on Gatsby's face as it had when they first met. It seemed that some doubts had arisen in his mind about his happiness at that moment. After all, five long years had passed! Even on that day, he must have seen something in Daisy that did not match the person he had kept alive in his imagination. This did not mean that the girl had done something wrong, of course. The real reason was that Gatsby had magnified her in his mind over the years. His imagination had surpassed everything, including Daisy. Because with the creativity of his passion, he had let himself into a world of imagination, constantly adding new images, adorning it with every bright feather that came his way. Nothing can destroy what a lonely person accumulates in their imagination, no fresh passion, no new fire.
es: When I went to say goodbye, I saw that the expression of perplexity had returned to Gatsby's face, as if he had just felt a slight doubt about the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! Even that afternoon there must have been a moment when Daisy did not live up to his dreams, not so much because of Daisy herself, but because of the colossal vitality of his own illusion. His illusion went beyond Daisy, beyond everything. And to that illusion Gatsby had surrendered with a creative passion, incessantly increasing it, adorning it with any feather he caught on the fly. There is no fire or cold that can challenge what a man keeps among the ghosts of his heart.

en: As I watched him he adjusted himself a little, visibly. His hand took hold of hers, and as she said something low in his ear he turned toward her with a rush of emotion. I think that voice held him most, with its fluctuating, feverish warmth, because it couldn’t be over-dreamed—that voice was a deathless song.
vi: When I looked at him, Gatsby clearly adjusted his posture a bit. His hands tightly grasped Daisy's hands, and when Daisy whispered something in his ear, he turned to look at her with an expression full of emotion. I suppose that the deep, warm, and passionate voice had moved him more than anything else, no dream could be higher than it - it was an immortal song.
tr: While Durmuş was looking at him, Gatsby changed his stance. When Daisy took his hand into her palms, she whispered something into his ear. Gatsby turned to her excitedly. It must have been her voice that affected him the most. That undulating, burning hot voice could not be exalted even by dreams. It was an immortal melody.
es: While I was watching him, he visibly pulled himself together. His hand took Daisy's, she whispered something in his ear, and at the sound of her voice, Gatsby turned to look at her, moved. I think it was that voice that most captivated him, with its feverish and vibrant warmth, because it couldn't fit into a dream: that voice was an immortal song.

en: They had forgotten me, but Daisy glanced up and held out her hand; Gatsby didn’t know me now at all. I looked once more at them and they looked back at me, remotely, possessed by intense life. Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.
vi: They both completely forgot about me. Although Daisy glanced up and waved at me, Gatsby seemed to have no idea who I was. I looked at them once more, and they looked back at me, distant, completely consumed by the intense vitality within them. Then I walked out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them behind.
tr: They both had forgotten me. Daisy lifted her head and reached out her hand, but Gatsby acted as if he didn't know me. I looked at them once more, and they looked back at me. They had gone far away, experiencing intense emotions. Then I left the room, walked down the marble stairs, and walked towards my home in the rain.
es: They had forgotten about me, but Daisy looked up and waved at me; Gatsby no longer had any awareness of who I was. I looked at them once more and they returned my gaze, from very far away, possessed by the intensity of life. Then I left the room and went down the marble steps in the rain, leaving them together.

en: VI
vi: Chapter 6
tr: CHAPTER 6

en: About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
vi: During this time, one morning, a young, eager journalist from New York knocked on Gatsby's door to ask if he had anything to declare.
tr: In those days; one morning, an ambitious young reporter from New York knocked on Gatsby's door and asked if he had anything to say.
es: At that time, a young and ambitious journalist from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby's door and asked if he had anything to say.

en: “Anything to say about what?” inquired Gatsby politely.
vi: "What needs to be declared?" Gatsby asked politely.
tr: Gatsby asked politely, "About what?"
es: —Anything to say? About what? —asked Gatsby, very properly.

en: “Why—any statement to give out.”
vi: "Then anything that can be declared."
tr: "I don't know, you might have something to say."
es: —Well, any statement to make.

en: It transpired after a confused five minutes that the man had heard Gatsby’s name around his office in a connection which he either wouldn’t reveal or didn’t fully understand. This was his day off and with laudable initiative he had hurried out “to see.”
vi: It took a bewildering five minutes afterwards to realize that this young reporter had overheard at the editorial office that Gatsby's name was related to something he was determined not to disclose, or perhaps he didn't know much about it himself. Taking advantage of his day off, with commendable initiative, he hurried to the place to "see what was going on."
tr: After five long minutes of continuing in such a strange manner, the matter was understood. The young journalist had heard Gatsby's name mentioned in the office, in connection with a link that he either avoided explaining at that moment or perhaps did not fully grasp. Taking advantage of that day being his day off, with a commendable initiative, he had headed straight to Gatsby's house.
es: It was known after five minutes of confusion that the individual had heard Gatsby's name in the newspaper in connection with something he did not want to reveal or had not fully understood. It was his day off and he had immediately taken the commendable initiative to come "see."

en: It was a random shot, and yet the reporter’s instinct was right. Gatsby’s notoriety, spread about by the hundreds who had accepted his hospitality and so become authorities upon his past, had increased all summer until he fell just short of being news. Contemporary legends such as the “underground pipeline to Canada” attached themselves to him, and there was one persistent story that he didn’t live in a house at all, but in a boat that looked like a house and was moved secretly up and down the Long Island shore. Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.
vi: This was just a random act, but it turned out that the young reporter's intuition was accurate. Gatsby's reputation was spread by the mouths of hundreds of people who had experienced his hospitality, and they became reliable sources for his past. This reputation grew throughout the summer, almost making him newsworthy. The contemporary anecdote about the 'tunnel leading to Canada' was associated with his name. There was also a persistent story that Gatsby did not live in his house but on a ship built like a house, which secretly moved up and down the coast of Long Island. Why these fabrications fascinated the young man James Gatz from North Dakota is hard to answer.
tr: Actually, there was no basis for it, but still, his instincts had proven right. The rumors on the tongues of hundreds of people, who thought they had a say over his past just because they took advantage of his hospitality, had branched out so much over the summer that Gatsby was almost about to make it to the newspapers. His name was mentioned along with urban legends, like an underground pipeline said to extend all the way to Canada. According to another rumor, he supposedly lived not in a house but on a luxurious ship he had built in the shape of a house, secretly cruising up and down the Long Island shores. It was not easy to understand how such rumors could be a source of satisfaction for James Gatz from North Dakota. 4 When alcohol production and sale were banned in America, one of the many fantastic methods devised to smuggle alcohol into the country was ÇN
es: He shot at random, but his journalistic instinct was accurate. The notoriety of Gatsby, spread by the hundreds of people who had accepted his hospitality and thus became specialists on his past, grew throughout the summer to the point where Jay Gatsby was on the verge of becoming news. Contemporary legends, like that of the "underground conduit to Canada,"[17] linked him to them, and it was persistently said that he did not live in a house, but in a boat that looked like a house and secretly sailed along the coast of Long Island. Why such inventions were a source of satisfaction for James Gatz, from North Dakota, is not easy to explain.

en: James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name. He had changed it at the age of seventeen and at the specific moment that witnessed the beginning of his career—when he saw Dan Cody’s yacht drop anchor over the most insidious flat on Lake Superior. It was James Gatz who had been loafing along the beach that afternoon in a torn green jersey and a pair of canvas pants, but it was already Jay Gatsby who borrowed a rowboat, pulled out to the Tuolomee, and informed Cody that a wind might catch him and break him up in half an hour.
vi: James Gatz, that was truly Gatsby's name, or at least the name on paper. He changed his name at the age of seventeen, at the very moment that marked the beginning of a career, the moment when he saw Dan Cody's yacht anchored in the hazardous shallows of Lake Superior. That afternoon, while wandering along the shore, he was still James Gatz, wearing a tattered blue shirt and canvas pants. But by the time he borrowed a boat and rowed out to the yacht TOULOMÊ, he had become Jay Gatsby. Jay Gatsby informed Cody that within half an hour, a strong wind would blow and it could capsize the yacht.
tr: James Gatz, at least his real name, or rather his legal name, was this. At the age of seventeen, in the early years of stepping into life, he decided to change his name the moment he saw Cody's yacht anchored on the shore of Lake Superior. That afternoon, walking along the shore of the lake in his torn green sweater and canvas pants, he was James Gatz. He immediately arranged for a boat and rowed to the Tuolomee, then climbed onto the deck of the yacht to warn Cody that a storm was approaching and that if he didn't leave within half an hour, his yacht could be shattered.
es: James Gatz: that was his real name or, at least, his legal name. He changed it at the age of seventeen at the exact moment he witnessed the beginning of his career: when he saw Dan Cody's yacht drop anchor in the most treacherous shoal of Lake Superior. It was James Gatz, the boy who was loafing around the beach that afternoon in a torn green sweater and canvas pants, but it was already Jay Gatsby who borrowed a rowboat, approached the Tuolomee, and informed Cody that the wind could catch him and wreck him within half an hour.

en: I suppose he’d had the name ready for a long time, even then. His parents were shiftless and unsuccessful farm people—his imagination had never really accepted them as his parents at all. The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty. So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end.
vi: I believe that Gatsby had chosen this name for himself a long time ago. His parents were unsuccessful farmers who didn't know how to manage. In his imagination, Gatsby had never truly accepted them. They are his parents. The truth is that the young man Jay Gatsby from the village of West Egg on Long Island was self-conceived through pure imagination. He is the son of God, in the truest sense of the word, so he must serve the work of the Father, serving a vast, superficial, and artificial beauty. Thus he created a Jay Gatsby, a kind of person that the mind of a seventeen-year-old boy could conceive, and he remained faithful to this concept until the end of his life.
tr: He had probably chosen this name before. He always despised his poor farmer family, never accepting them as his mother and father. In fact, Jay Gatsby, who lived in West Egg, Long Island, was born from a platonic conception of himself. He was the son of God – whatever that meant, that was its meaning. As a son, he had to fulfill his duty to his father by serving a vast, rough, and flamboyant beauty. That is why he created a Jay Gatsby that only a seventeen-year-old boy could create, but he remained faithful to this dream to the end.
es: I suppose he had the name prepared for a long time. His parents were country folk, without ambitions or fortune: his imagination never accepted them as parents. The truth was that Jay Gatsby, from West Egg, Long Island, emerged from the platonic idea of himself. He was a son of God —a phrase that, if it means anything, means exactly that—, and he had to take care of his Father's business[18], in the service of an immense, vulgar, and mercenary beauty. So he invented the type of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy could invent, and he remained faithful to that idea until the end.

en: For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed. His brown, hardening body lived naturally through the half-fierce, half-lazy work of the bracing days. He knew women early, and since they spoiled him he became contemptuous of them, of young virgins because they were ignorant, of the others because they were hysterical about things which in his overwhelming self-absorption he took for granted.
vi: For more than a year, Gatsby had to toil hard to make a living along the shores of Lake Superior by catching clams, fishing, or doing any job that could bring him food and shelter. Gatsby's sun-tanned, sturdy body became even more resilient through the arduous yet leisurely tasks he undertook to get by each day. Gatsby became acquainted with women very early, and because they spoiled him, he grew to despise them. He despised the virginal girls because they were so naive and foolish. He despised the other women because they were madly obsessed with things he considered ordinary.
tr: For more than a year, he had been harvesting mussels and fishing for salmon along the southern shores of Lake Superior, working here and there just for food to find a place to stay. He spent his active life intertwined with nature, sometimes pushing his sun-darkened muscular body to the limit, sometimes surrendering to laziness. Spoiled by the constant attention of women he had known from an early age, he had come to disdain them; he scorned young virgins for their ignorance, and the others for losing themselves in their infatuation with him, a reaction they had by nature to someone who only cared about himself.
es: For a year, he traveled along the southern coast of Lake Superior, gathering clams and fishing for salmon, or doing anything else in exchange for food and a bed. His body, tanned and growing stronger every day, instinctively took advantage of those invigorating days of work, between harshness and indolence. Very soon, he met women and, since they pampered him, they ended up seeming despicable to him: the young virgins because they knew nothing; the others because they became hysterical over things that he, with overwhelming presumption, took for granted.

en: But his heart was in a constant, turbulent riot. The most grotesque and fantastic conceits haunted him in his bed at night. A universe of ineffable gaudiness spun itself out in his brain while the clock ticked on the washstand and the moon soaked with wet light his tangled clothes upon the floor. Each night he added to the pattern of his fancies until drowsiness closed down upon some vivid scene with an oblivious embrace. For a while these reveries provided an outlet for his imagination; they were a satisfactory hint of the unreality of reality, a promise that the rock of the world was founded securely on a fairy’s wing.
vi: However, Gatsby's heart had always been incessantly rebellious. The most ridiculous and bizarre fantasies always haunted him each night as he went to bed. Every night, when an indescribably gaudy and colorful world appeared in his mind, the clock on the washstand continued to tick, and the moonlight spread wet streaks over the scattered pieces of clothing on the floor. Each night, Gatsby added new strokes to his fantasies until they culminated in a splendid, colorful scene, then faded into dreamy oblivion as he gradually fell asleep. For a period of time, these fantasies provided him an escape for his imagination. They were a fitting reminder of impractical realities, a promise that shook the world, which had been firmly created on mythical wings.
tr: However, a never-ending turbulent chaos reigned in his heart. When night fell, the most unlikely and unimaginable thoughts swarmed into his bed. As the wet light of the moon wandered among the ticking of the clock above the sink and over the clothes he had tossed around, an indescribably magnificent universe rose in his mind. Every night, until sleep came to close those colorful scenes and make them forgotten, another dream was added to these, expanding this universe even further. These dreams, which for a time served as an outlet for his creative power, provided a satisfying sign of the unreality of reality, telling him that the foundation of the world rested on the wings of a fairy girl.
es: But his heart lived in a constant, turbulent upheaval. The most grotesque and fantastic ambitions assaulted him at night, in bed. A universe of unspeakable extravagances developed in his brain while the clock ticked on the sink and the moon bathed the clothes, carelessly thrown on the floor, in a damp light. Each night the plot of his fantasies grew until drowsiness ended some especially vivid scene with an embrace of forgetfulness. For a while, these reveries were an outlet for his imagination: they were a satisfying indication of the unreality of reality, a promise that the rock of the world was firmly founded on a fairy's wing.

en: An instinct toward his future glory had led him, some months before, to the small Lutheran College of St. Olaf’s in southern Minnesota. He stayed there two weeks, dismayed at its ferocious indifference to the drums of his destiny, to destiny itself, and despising the janitor’s work with which he was to pay his way through. Then he drifted back to Lake Superior, and he was still searching for something to do on the day that Dan Cody’s yacht dropped anchor in the shallows alongshore.
vi: A few months earlier, the premonition of a glorious future had led Gatsby to enroll at the small St. Olaf Lutheran school in southern Minnesota. After only two weeks, Gatsby became disheartened by the school's cruel indifference to the drumbeat of his destiny, or to what is generally called destiny, and by the contempt he faced for the janitorial work he did to make ends meet. Thus, Gatsby drifted to Lake Superior. On the day Dan Cody's yacht anchored in the shallow waters along the lake's shore, Gatsby had still not found anything for himself.
tr: A few months earlier, driven by an instinct that could be considered a herald of future fame and fortune, he had enrolled at St. Olaf Lutheran College in southern Minnesota. However, he left this school after only two weeks, disillusioned by the indifferent drumbeats of fate, and even fate itself, and because he hated the janitorial job he took to pay for school expenses. He returned to Lake Superior, and from that day on, he searched for work until he saw Dan Cody's yacht anchored in shallow waters.
es: The instinct for future glory had led him months earlier to Saint Olaf, the small Lutheran College, in southern Minnesota. He endured two weeks, demoralized by the fierce indifference of the place towards the drums of his destiny, towards destiny itself, and hating the janitorial work with which he was going to pay for his stay. He returned to Lake Superior, and was still looking for something to do the day Dan Cody's yacht dropped anchor in the shallows off the coast.

en: Cody was fifty years old then, a product of the Nevada silver fields, of the Yukon, of every rush for metal since seventy-five. The transactions in Montana copper that made him many times a millionaire found him physically robust but on the verge of soft-mindedness, and, suspecting this, an infinite number of women tried to separate him from his money. The none too savoury ramifications by which Ella Kaye, the newspaper woman, played Madame de Maintenon to his weakness and sent him to sea in a yacht, were common property of the turgid journalism in 1902. He had been coasting along all too hospitable shores for five years when he turned up as James Gatz’s destiny in Little Girl Bay.
vi: At that time Cody was fifty years old, he was a product of the silver mines in the state of Nevada, of the Yukon River, and of all the metal hunts since the year one thousand eight hundred seventy-five. The copper transactions in the state of Montana had turned him into a multimillionaire and gave him a strong body but a soft heart. Discovering this weakness, countless women tried to extract money from him. Among these women, none was as skillful as Ella Kaye, a female journalist. The story of her playing the role of Madame de Maintenon, exploiting his weakness and luring him on a yacht trip, was commonly seen in the newspapers of 1901.
