Cody had sailed along all the safe and gentle coastlines for about five years, until the day he changed the fate of the young man James Gatz at Little Girls Point.
tr: At that time, Cody, who was in his fifties, had come from the silver mines of Nevada and the Yukon region. Since 1875, he seemed to have tracked down every kind of mine. He had made millions from the copper mines of Montana. Although his physical health and appearance were in good condition, the same could not be said for his mental health. Numerous women who had sensed this had made great efforts to get hold of the man's fortune. The same had happened in his tumultuous love affair with journalist Ella Kaye. After Kaye, who had discovered Cody's weaknesses, adopted the manners of Madame de Maintenon, the man had set sail with his yacht to save himself, which provided good material for the tabloid press in the year 1902 when the incident occurred. Until that encounter at Little Girl Bay that would change the fate of James Gatz, Cody had roamed from bay to bay for a full five years.
es: Cody was fifty years old then, and he was a product of the silver mines of Nevada, the Yukon, and all the mining booms since 1875. The copper operations in Montana that made him much more than a multimillionaire found him still strong, physically speaking, but close to intellectual decrepitude, and, suspecting this, an infinite number of women tried to separate him from his money. The not-too-tasteful entanglements with which journalist Ella Kaye played the role of Madame de Maintenon at the expense of Cody's weakness and pushed him to set sail on a yacht were common in the indigestible journalism of 1902. Cody had been coasting along overly hospitable shores for five years when, in Little Girl Bay, he became the destiny of James Gatz.

en: To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world. I suppose he smiled at Cody—he had probably discovered that people liked him when he smiled. At any rate Cody asked him a few questions (one of them elicited the brand new name) and found that he was quick and extravagantly ambitious. A few days later he took him to Duluth and bought him a blue coat, six pairs of white duck trousers, and a yachting cap. And when the Tuolomee left for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby left too.
vi: For the young man James Gatz, who was then leaning on two oars looking up at the deck, the yacht represented all the beauty and allure of the world. I guess he smiled at Cody; he must have discovered that people would like him if he smiled at them. In any case, Cody asked him a few questions (one of which led to the birth of a brand new name) and discovered that this young man was very quick-witted and full of wild ambitions. A few days later, Cody took Gatsby to Duluth and bought him a new blue coat, six pristine white pants, and a sailor hat. So when the yacht TUOLOMEE set sail for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby went along.
tr: This yacht, by letting go of the oars and looking at the deck surrounded by railings, was a symbol of all the beauty and splendor in the world for Gatz; it must have been enough for him to lift his head and smile at the man to get what he wanted – he had discovered long ago that his smile had an effect on people. Cody asked him some questions, and the answer he gave to one of these questions became the new name he would use from that day forward. Cody immediately noticed the intelligence and ambition in the boy. A few days later, he took Gatz to Duluth and bought him a blue jacket, six white trousers, and a yachtsman's cap. Before long, when the Tuolomee set sail for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby was on its deck.
es: For the young Gatz, who leaned on the oars and looked toward the deck, the yacht represented all the beauty, all the glamour of the world. I suppose he smiled at Cody: he had probably discovered that when he smiled, people liked him. The fact is that Cody asked him a few questions (from one of those questions came the new name) and discovered that he was smart and ambitious to the point of extravagance. A few days later, he took him to Duluth and bought him a blue jacket, six pairs of white drill trousers, and a sailor's cap. And when the Tuolomee set sail for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby set sail too.

en: He was employed in a vague personal capacity—while he remained with Cody he was in turn steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and even jailor, for Dan Cody sober knew what lavish doings Dan Cody drunk might soon be about, and he provided for such contingencies by reposing more and more trust in Gatsby. The arrangement lasted five years, during which the boat went three times around the Continent. It might have lasted indefinitely except for the fact that Ella Kaye came on board one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody inhospitably died.
vi: Gatsby was hired to work on the yacht in an undefined position. During his time with Cody, he alternated between various tasks, from manager, assistant, navigator, secretary, and even overseer. A sober Dan Cody knew what a drunken Dan Cody would do with money, so he increasingly placed his trust in Gatsby. Such a life lasted for five years. During this time, the yacht circumnavigated the continent three times. The situation might have lasted even longer until one night when Ella Kaye boarded the ship in Boston. A week later, Dan Cody passed away.
tr: It was hard to discern exactly what Yatta was doing; sometimes he was a steward, sometimes an assistant captain, and at other times a clerk, or even a guard. For sober Dan Cody knew very well what he might do when he got drunk, and thus, he increasingly relied on Gatsby to prevent potential disgrace. They lived this way for five years; during this period, the yacht circled the European coasts three times. This lifestyle would likely have continued if Ella Kaye hadn't shown up that day they docked in Boston, and if Dan Cody hadn't died within a week, displaying a rather unwelcoming behavior.
es: His role was not precise: while he stayed with Cody, he was successively a waiter, second-in-command, yacht captain, secretary, and even jailer, because, when sober, Dan Cody knew what excesses he was prone to when drunk, and he prevented such contingencies by placing more trust in Gatsby each day. The arrangement lasted five years, during which the yacht circled the continent three times. It could have lasted indefinitely, but Ella Kaye came aboard one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody, rather inhospitably, died.

en: I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. It was indirectly due to Cody that Gatsby drank so little. Sometimes in the course of gay parties women used to rub champagne into his hair; for himself he formed the habit of letting liquor alone.
vi: I remember seeing Cody's portrait hanging in Gatsby's bedroom, a man with salt-and-pepper hair, a ruddy, stern, empty face, a man who roamed and explored, living a life of debauchery, who, in a certain era of American society, brought the savage brutality of brothels and frontier saloons to the eastern seaboard. It was Cody who indirectly caused Gatsby not to drink much. At the raucous parties, women would often pour alcohol over his hair because he had made it a habit not to drink.
tr: The portrait of this impressive man with gray hair, a stern but expressionless face, and rosy cheeks still lingers in my mind, hanging in Gatsby's bedroom. He was an incorrigible rake, known for his hedonism; in a period of American life, he had brought the brutalities of brothels and gambling dens from the wild frontier regions back to the balls on the eastern shores. Indirectly, it was Cody who caused Gatsby's aversion to alcohol. Sometimes at those wild parties, when women poured champagne over their hair, Gatsby later chose to stay away from alcohol.
es: I remember his portrait in Gatsby's bedroom, a healthy man, with gray hair and a hard, empty expression: the dissipated pioneer who, during a phase of American life, brought back to the East Coast the wild violence of the brothels and slums of the frontier. It was indirectly due to Cody that Gatsby hardly drank. Sometimes, at parties, women would pour champagne on his hair. He had a habit of not touching alcohol.

en: And it was from Cody that he inherited money—a legacy of twenty-five thousand dollars. He didn’t get it. He never understood the legal device that was used against him, but what remained of the millions went intact to Ella Kaye. He was left with his singularly appropriate education; the vague contour of Jay Gatsby had filled out to the substantiality of a man.
vi: Cody left a legacy for Gatsby - twenty-five thousand dollars. However, he never received it. Gatsby never understood what legal maneuver was used to prevent him from getting it, but all the remaining millions completely fell into the hands of Ella Kaye. Gatsby was left with only the capital of experience he had learned from Cody. From it, the vague characteristics of a young Jay Gatsby were solidified and developed into the real substance of a man. It was much later that Gatsby told me this story.
tr: As for the famous inheritance, all that was left from Cody to Gatsby was a mere twenty-five thousand dollars, but he couldn't even get that money. He never learned how the lawyers had schemed to prevent him from touching the inheritance. Cody's millions were transferred as they were to Ella Kaye, without Gatsby even laying a hand on them. What remained for him were the experiences he had gone through, and during this time, his vague outlines filled with solidity and strength, emerging as a man.
es: And from Cody he inherited the money: twenty-five thousand dollars that he never received. He never understood what legal trickery was used against him, but what remained of the millions ended up entirely in the hands of Ella Kaye. Gatsby was left with his education, so appropriate, so unique: the vague outline of Jay Gatsby took on the substance of a man.

en: He told me all this very much later, but I’ve put it down here with the idea of exploding those first wild rumours about his antecedents, which weren’t even faintly true. Moreover he told it to me at a time of confusion, when I had reached the point of believing everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.
vi: I write these things down here with the intention of dispelling the crazy rumors that have no truth about his past. Moreover, Gatsby told it to me at a time when I was still confused and bewildered, when I was in a place where I believed everything I heard about him, without exception. Therefore, I took advantage of this interruption, so to speak, when Gatsby was taking a break, to dispel all the misconceptions about him.
tr: He had told me all of this much later, yet I found it appropriate to recount these to dispel the rumors that had nothing to do with the truths about his ancestors. Moreover, at the times he was telling me these, my mind was in turmoil, and I had reached a point where I was confused about what to believe. Therefore, to correct misunderstandings, I wanted to take advantage of this pause where Gatsby had momentarily caught his breath.
es: He told me all this much later, but I write it now with the idea of dispelling those initial absurd rumors about his background, which were not remotely true. He also told me this at a moment of confusion, when I had come to believe everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this brief interruption, while Gatsby, so to speak, was catching his breath, to dispel all those false ideas.

en: It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For several weeks I didn’t see him or hear his voice on the phone—mostly I was in New York, trotting around with Jordan and trying to ingratiate myself with her senile aunt—but finally I went over to his house one Sunday afternoon. I hadn’t been there two minutes when somebody brought Tom Buchanan in for a drink. I was startled, naturally, but the really surprising thing was that it hadn’t happened before.
vi: At that time, there was also a disruption in the connection between me and his life. For many weeks, I had neither seen nor heard him call. Mostly because I was in New York, busy hanging out with Jordan and trying to win over her elderly aunt. However, one Sunday afternoon, I finally dropped by Gatsby's house. I had been there for less than two minutes when someone brought Tom Buchanan into his house. Of course, I was extremely surprised, but the real surprise was that it had taken this long for it to happen.
tr: Actually, there had been a pause in our relationship as well. I had neither seen him nor spoken to him on the phone for a few weeks. I was mostly spending that time by following Jordan to New York and trying to get into the good graces of her senile aunt. Finally, one Sunday afternoon, I visited him at his home; I had barely been there for two minutes when a few people dropped by. Tom Buchanan had also tagged along with these guests to have a drink. Naturally, I was uncomfortable; on the other hand, I couldn't help but be surprised that this hadn't happened before.
es: There was also an interruption in my relations with him. For several weeks we stopped seeing each other and talking on the phone —he spent most of the time in New York, hanging out with Jordan and trying to ingratiate himself with her aunt, an old hag—, but I finally went to his house one Sunday afternoon. I hadn't been there for even two minutes when someone appeared with Tom Buchanan, to have a drink. I was startled, naturally, though the truly astonishing thing is that it hadn't happened before.

vi: "She threw a very large party and he wouldn't know a single soul there." Tom frowned. "I wonder where this guy ever met Daisy in the first place." For God's sake, I might be an old-fashioned person, but the type of women who socialize a lot these days don't suit me. They know all kinds of people."
tr: “Tonight is a big feast; he doesn't know any of the guests,” he continued, frowning, “Where did he meet Daisy?” You might call me old-fashioned, but in my opinion, women these days are out and about too much. Then they end up meeting such rascals here and there.”
es: —He gives a big party where that Gatsby won't know anyone —he frowned—. I wonder where the hell he met Daisy. For God's sake, maybe my ideas are out of fashion, but, in my opinion, today's women are too loose. And they run into all kinds of lunatics.

tr: Sloane called out to Tom, "Come on, hurry up! We're very late, we must leave now." Then he turned to me and said, "Please tell him that we're in a hurry and can't wait, okay?"

en: Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged a cool nod, and they trotted quickly down the drive, disappearing under the August foliage just as Gatsby, with hat and light overcoat in hand, came out the front door.

tr: We shook hands with Tom and bid farewell to the others with a cold gesture. The guests had just disappeared among the trees, riding their horses swiftly down the driveway, when Gatsby appeared at the door with his hat and overcoat in hand.
es: Tom and I shook hands; with the others, I exchanged a cold nod, and they disappeared at a trot, down the road, among the August foliage, just as Gatsby was coming out the front door with a hat and a light coat in hand.

en: Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-coloured, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.
vi: Tom clearly began to fear Daisy going out alone frequently, because the following Saturday night he went with his wife to attend a party at Gatsby's house. Perhaps his presence gave that evening a stifling atmosphere that made my memory of it stand out more than all the other parties that summer. It was still the usual guests, or at least the same type of people. There was still an abundance of champagne, the same colors, the usual chaotic noise, yet I felt an unease in the air, a sharpness spreading that had never been there before. Or perhaps because I had become familiar with it, had come to accept West Egg as a complete world with its own rules, with its own notable characters, not inferior to anywhere else because it did not feel inferior. Now I saw it again through Daisy's eyes. There is nothing sadder than seeing through new eyes what you have used all your strength to perfect.
tr: Tom must have been suspicious of Daisy wandering around alone, as they came together to Gatsby's party on Saturday night. The reason for the strange tension noticeable that night was probably Tom. Out of all the parties Gatsby threw that summer, this is the only one that remains in my mind, likely due to that tension I mentioned. The usual people had come – or rather, the people who came were of the usual type – once again we had plenty of champagne, and once again the party was dominated by a colorful and noisy chaos; however, there was an unpleasant atmosphere, a tension that never quite released, which I hadn't felt at the previous ones. Perhaps I had grown accustomed to these parties by starting to see West Egg, with its unique standards and types, as a world of its own that could easily defy the outside world because it didn't care about anything beyond itself. That night, I was looking at everyone and everything at the party through Daisy's eyes. Seeing things that we find contrary to our own values from a new perspective always saddened me.
es: It evidently disturbed Tom that Daisy went out alone, and the following Saturday night, he accompanied her to Gatsby's party. His presence might have given the evening a special sense of oppression: I remember that party among all the ones Gatsby threw that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same type of people, the same abundance of champagne, the same bustle of voices and colors, but I sensed something unpleasant in the air, a harshness in everything that hadn't existed before. Or maybe I had simply become accustomed to accepting West Egg as a complete world in itself, with its own rules and its own great figures, not inferior to anything because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was seeing it again, through Daisy's eyes. It is inevitably sad to look at things with new eyes to which we have already applied our own capacity for focus.

en: They arrived at twilight, and, as we strolled out among the sparkling hundreds, Daisy’s voice was playing murmurous tricks in her throat.
vi: They arrived at twilight, and while we were strolling among hundreds of excited guests, Daisy's voice emerged, gurgling in a whisper from her throat.
tr: When Daisy and Tom arrived, the sun was about to set. As they wandered together among the colorful crowd, Daisy was chirping something with her wonderful voice.
es: They arrived at dusk, and, as we walked among hundreds of glowing beings, Daisy's whispering voice played tricks in her throat.

en: “These things excite me so,” she whispered. “If you want to kiss me any time during the evening, Nick, just let me know and I’ll be glad to arrange it for you. Just mention my name. Or present a green card. I’m giving out green—”
vi: "The things here make me so excited." Daisy whispered. "If you want to kiss me at any time tonight, Nick, just let me know and I'll arrange it for you. Just call my name, or show the green card. Now I'm giving you the green card...."
tr: “Places like this excite me so much,” she whispered, “if you want to kiss me in the middle of the night, don't hesitate to tell me, Nick, we'll find a way. Just saying my name is enough or showing this green card...”
es: —These things excite me so much… —she murmured—. If you want to kiss me during the party, Nick, just tell me and I'll be happy to make it happen. All you have to do is say my name. Or present a green card. I'm going to hand out cards…

en: “Look around,” suggested Gatsby.
vi: "Look around here." Gatsby suggested.
tr: “Just take a look around,” Gatsby said to Tom.
es: —Look around you —suggested Gatsby.

en: “I’m looking around. I’m having a marvellous—”
vi: "I'm looking." "I see, it's wonderful...."
tr: “Just take a look around,” Gatsby said to Tom. “I am already watching, and I am having a lot of fun.”
es: —I am looking. I am having a wonderful time…

en: “You must see the faces of many people you’ve heard about.”
vi: "You will see many faces of famous people you have heard of."
tr: "You will see many celebrities you know"
es: —You will see in person many people you have heard about.

en: Tom’s arrogant eyes roamed the crowd.
vi: Tom's haughty, arrogant eyes swept over the crowd. "We don't travel much." Tom said.
tr: "You will see many celebrities you know"
es: Tom's arrogant gaze swept over the crowd.

en: “We don’t go around very much,” he said; “in fact, I was just thinking I don’t know a soul here.”
vi: "In fact, I don't know anyone here."
tr: After casting his conceited glances around, he said, "We don't go out much at night," and added, "I must admit, when you asked, I also thought I didn't know a single person.""
es: —We don't go out much —he said—; in fact, I was thinking that I don't know anyone.

en: “Perhaps you know that lady.” Gatsby indicated a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared, with that peculiarly unreal feeling that accompanies the recognition of a hitherto ghostly celebrity of the movies.
vi: "Maybe you know her." Gatsby pointed to a woman, more dazzling and beautiful like an orchid than a person, sitting motionless under the white plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared with a different feeling that one gets when recognizing a famous character from the movies whom they have never met before.
tr: “You surely know this lady,” said Gatsby, pointing to an extremely attractive woman sitting majestically under a blossoming plum tree, resembling an orchid more than a human. Seeing a star they could only see in movies, alive and in person, had excited Tom and Daisy just like everyone else.
es: —Perhaps I know that lady —Gatsby pointed to a magnificent orchid-like woman, barely human, sitting with regal dignity under a white plum tree. Tom and Daisy looked at her surprised, with that peculiar feeling of unreality that accompanies us when we recognize a movie celebrity, ghostly until that moment.

en: “She’s lovely,” said Daisy.
vi: "She is so beautiful." Daisy said.
tr: “A very beautiful woman,” said Daisy
es: —It's beautiful —said Daisy.

en: “The man bending over her is her director.”
vi: "The person bending down next to her is the director,"
tr: “The man next to her, leaning towards her, is also the director,”
es: —The man who is now leaning over her is her director.

en: He took them ceremoniously from group to group:
vi: Gatsby stylishly introduced them to each group one by one.
tr: Later, in a ceremonial manner, he began to parade them around, from one group to another.
es: Gatsby ceremoniously led them from group to group:

en: “Mrs. Buchanan… and Mr. Buchanan—” After an instant’s hesitation he added: “the polo player.”
vi: "Mrs. Buchanan... Mr. Buchanan..."After a moment of hesitation, he added. "The house plays polo."
tr: “This is Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Buchanan,” he paused for a moment, “Mr. Buchanan is a famous polo player.”
es: —Mistress Buchanan… and Mister Buchanan —after hesitating for a few seconds, he added—. The polo player.

en: “Oh no,” objected Tom quickly, “not me.”
vi: "Oh, no, it's not me," Tom protested.
tr: Tom interrupted by objecting, "He's joking, I'm not."
es: —No —protested Tom—, not me.

en: But evidently the sound of it pleased Gatsby for Tom remained “the polo player” for the rest of the evening.
vi: However, it was clear that such an introduction pleased Gatsby, because Tom continued to be introduced as the polo player for the rest of the evening.
tr: Gatsby must have liked this manner of introduction, for that night Tom was introduced to everyone as the 'famous polo player.'
es: But it was evident that the sound of those words had pleased Gatsby, and Tom remained "the polo player" all night.

en: “I’ve never met so many celebrities,” Daisy exclaimed. “I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.”
vi: "I have never met so many famous people before." Daisy declared. "I like that man, what is his name again? The man with the nose that looks like it's blue."
tr: "I have never seen so many celebrities together," Daisy shouted excitedly, "I really liked that man over there - what was his name? You know, the one with the bluish nose..."
es: —I had never seen so many celebrities —exclaimed Daisy—. That man was nice… What’s his name? The one with the nose like blue.

en: Gatsby identified him, adding that he was a small producer.
vi: Gatsby introduced the man's name, adding that he was a small producer.
tr: After Gatsby revealed the man's identity, he also added that he was a small-scale producer.
es: Gatsby told him who he was and added that he was a small producer.

en: “Well, I liked him anyhow.”
vi: "I still like him."
tr: “Anyway, I liked the man.”
es: —Well, I like him anyway.

en: “I’d a little rather not be the polo player,” said Tom pleasantly, “I’d rather look at all these famous people in—in oblivion.”
vi: "I don't want to be a polo goalie anymore. I'd rather sit and watch all the famous people and let myself fade into oblivion." Tom joked.
tr: Tom interrupted with a laugh, "I guess I should give up on becoming a famous polo player," he said. "I would prefer to be more indifferent towards all these celebrities."
es: —I would almost prefer not to be the polo player —said Tom, content—. I would like to see all those famous people… incognito.

en: Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by his graceful, conservative foxtrot—I had never seen him dance before. Then they sauntered over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour, while at her request I remained watchfully in the garden. “In case there’s a fire or a flood,” she explained, “or any act of God.”
vi: Daisy and Gatsby stepped out to dance. I remember being surprised by his elegant classical style in the fox-trot. Before that, I had never seen him dance. Afterwards, the two of them wandered over to my house and sat on the steps for about half an hour while I was assigned by Daisy to keep watch in the garden "in case of fire, flood, or disaster," Daisy explained.
tr: Daisy and Gatsby danced. Gatsby's elegant yet unpretentious moves during the Foxtrot had astonished me; I had never seen him dance before. Then they slipped through the garden into the garden of my house and sat on the steps in front of the door for about half an hour. At Daisy's request, I kept watch in the garden; she had explained the reason for her request by saying, "You never know, a flood might come, a fire might break out... The world is full of all sorts of possibilities, isn't it?"
es: Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by the graceful, conservative way Gatsby danced the fox-trot: I had never seen him dance before. And then they took a walk to my house and spent half an hour sitting on the steps, while, at Daisy's request, I kept watch in the garden. «In case of fire or flood,» she explained, «or in case of force majeure».

en: Tom appeared from his oblivion as we were sitting down to supper together. “Do you mind if I eat with some people over here?” he said. “A fellow’s getting off some funny stuff.”
vi: Tom appeared from 'oblivion' while we were sitting and eating. "Do you mind if I go over and eat with those people over there?" "That guy over there is really funny," Tom asked. "You just go."
tr: Tom's indifference seemed to have passed, as he sat down to eat with the other guests and asked, "You don't mind if I eat with that group over there, do you? There's someone among them, you should hear the funny stories he has!"
es: Tom came out of his disguise when the three of us sat down to dinner. —Do you mind if I have dinner with those people over there? —he said—. A guy is telling very funny stories.

en: “Go ahead,” answered Daisy genially, “and if you want to take down any addresses here’s my little gold pencil.”… She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.
vi: Daisy replied kindly. "If you need to write down someone's address, use this gold pencil of mine." Daisy looked around for a moment and told me that the girl over there "isn't anything special but is pretty." I was certain that except for the half hour she spent alone with Gatsby, Daisy didn't find much joy in anything.
tr: Daisy said with a smile, "Of course, go ahead, you might need to take someone's address, let me give you my small gold fountain pen too."" When her husband walked away, she turned to me and said, "The girl is a bit vulgar, but she's beautiful." I realized that, apart from the half hour she spent alone with Gatsby, she didn't have much fun.
es: —Go ahead, go —replied Daisy, happily—, and if you want to write down any address, here is my gold pencil. A moment later, he turned to look at me and said that the girl was "vulgar but pretty," and I realized that, apart from the half hour alone with Gatsby, he was not having a good time.

en: We were at a particularly tipsy table. That was my fault—Gatsby had been called to the phone, and I’d enjoyed these same people only two weeks before. But what had amused me then turned septic on the air now.
vi: We were sitting at a table where everyone was already quite tipsy. That was also my fault. Gatsby was busy talking on the phone, while I preferred to chat with people I had met two weeks before. However, what I thought would make me happy ended up polluting the atmosphere.
tr: Everyone at our table was tipsy, and I was responsible for it because it was my suggestion to go to that table. Gatsby was called to the phone at one point, and I was looking at these people I had fun with just two weeks ago, thinking about how the things I liked then were now bothering me.
es: We shared a table with an especially drunk group. It was my fault. Gatsby had been called on the phone, and I had had a good time with those people just two weeks ago. But what had amused me then was now poisoned in the air.

en: “How do you feel, Miss Baedeker?”
vi: "How are you, Ms. Baedeker?"
tr: “Your health isn't bad, is it, Mrs. Baedeker?”
es: —How are you, Miss Baedeker?

en: The girl addressed was trying, unsuccessfully, to slump against my shoulder. At this inquiry she sat up and opened her eyes.
vi: The young woman I greeted was trying to lean on my shoulder, but she couldn't. Hearing my greeting, she sat up, opening her eyes wide.
tr: The girl who was the subject of this question had been trying to rest her head on my shoulder for quite some time. When she heard her name, she lifted her head and opened her eyes, "What?"
es: The girl they were talking to was unsuccessfully trying to lean on my shoulder. Upon hearing the question, she straightened up and opened her eyes.

en: “Wha’?”
vi: "What?"
tr: When she heard her name, she lifted her head and opened her eyes, "What?"
es: —How?

en: A massive and lethargic woman, who had been urging Daisy to play golf with her at the local club tomorrow, spoke in Miss Baedeker’s defence:
vi: A large and sluggish woman, who had once urged Daisy to play golf with her at a club the next day, spoke up in defense of Miss Baedeker.
tr: She answered on behalf of Mrs. Baedeker, a large, sluggish woman who insisted on playing golf at the city club the next day, "Don't worry, she'll come around soon.
es: A commanding and lethargic woman, who had been asking Daisy to play golf with her the next day at the local club, took up the defense of Miss Baedeker.

en: “Oh, she’s all right now. When she’s had five or six cocktails she always starts screaming like that. I tell her she ought to leave it alone.”
vi: "Oh, she's fine. When she drinks five or six cocktails, she always screams like that. I've told her not to touch alcohol anymore."
tr: Whenever she downs five or six cocktails, this happens. Yet, I've told her countless times to quit drinking."
es: —He's perfectly fine now. As soon as he has five or six cocktails, he always starts shouting like that. I've told him he should stop.

en: “I do leave it alone,” affirmed the accused hollowly.
vi: "I didn't touch anything." The recently defended person asserted with a slurred voice.
tr: "But I don't drink anymore," the girl defended herself.
es: —I have left him —affirmed the accused with a cavernous voice.

en: “We heard you yelling, so I said to Doc Civet here: ‘There’s somebody that needs your help, Doc.’ ”
vi: "I heard you shouting, so I spoke to Dr. Civet here. "Someone needs your help, doctor."
tr: "Of course, my dear, when I heard your cries, I even reported the situation to Doctor Civet,"
es: —We heard her scream, so I said to Dr. Civet, who is present here: "There is someone who needs your help, doctor."

en: “She’s much obliged, I’m sure,” said another friend, without gratitude, “but you got her dress all wet when you stuck her head in the pool.”
vi: "I'm sure she was very appreciative." Another friend said, but there was no sign of gratitude. "However, he got her clothes all wet when he dunked her head into the lake."
tr: “I am sure she is grateful to you, but,” another person interrupted, “I still wish you hadn't dipped her head into the pool, the poor girl's lovely dress is soaking wet.”
es: —And she is very grateful to you, I am sure —said another of the friends, without the slightest gratitude—, but you have soaked her entire dress when you dunked her head in the pond.

en: “Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,” mumbled Miss Baedeker. “They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.”
vi: "What I hate the most is being dunked in the pool. There was a time when people almost drowned me in New Jersey."
tr: “If there is one thing I truly hate, it is having my head dunked in the pool!” grumbled Mrs. Baedeker, “One time in New Jersey, they almost drowned me.”
es: —If there is something I can't stand, it's sticking my head in a pond —muttered Miss Baedeker—. They almost drowned me in New Jersey.

en: “Then you ought to leave it alone,” countered Doctor Civet.
vi: "If that's the case, then don't touch alcohol anymore." Dr. Civet attacked.
tr: "Then you will absolutely have to quit alcohol as well," the Doctor attempted to say. “You should look at yourself first!”
es: —You see, you should give it up —replied Dr. Civet.

en: “Speak for yourself!” cried Miss Baedeker violently. “Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!”
vi: "Look at yourself." Ms. Baedeker shouted fiercely. "Your hands are shaking all over. I wouldn't dare let you operate on me."
tr: Mrs. Baedeker retorted. “Your hands are shaking, man! If I needed surgery, I would never agree to let you do it.”
es: —Look who's talking! —Miss Baedeker shouted violently—. Your hands are shaking! I would never let you operate on me!

en: It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.
vi: Roughly speaking, that's how it was. Almost the last thing I remember is standing next to Daisy, watching the film director and his movie star. The two of them were still sitting under the white plum tree, their faces close together, separated only by a thin layer of pale moonlight. I suddenly realized that the whole evening he had been slowly and gradually leaning towards her to achieve this close distance. While observing, I saw him lean down one final time and then kiss her on the cheek.
tr: So it went on like this. The last thing I remember is watching the famous star with the film director, side by side with Daisy. They were still under that plum tree, their faces now so close to each other that the faint moonlight could barely seep through. We couldn't help but think that the man had slowly inched closer to the woman throughout the night to reach this point. As we stood there watching them, the director moved a millimeter closer and finally kissed the woman on the cheek.
es: That's how things were. Almost the last thing I remember is that I went with Daisy to watch the film director and his star. They were still under the white plum tree and between their faces, which were touching, there was only a pale and very thin moonbeam. It occurred to me that the director had been slowly leaning towards the star all night until he reached this proximity, and then, while I was watching them, I saw him descend one last degree and kiss her on the cheek.

en: “I like her,” said Daisy, “I think she’s lovely.”
vi: "I like her." "She is very beautiful," Daisy said.
tr: “I like this woman very much,” said Daisy, “Magnificent!”
es: —I like it —said Daisy—. I think it's beautiful.

en: But the rest offended her—and inarguably because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented “place” that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a shortcut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.
vi: However, everything else made Daisy inexplicably uncomfortable and annoyed, not because of attitude or gestures, but because of a feeling. Daisy was terrified by West Egg, a place like no other, created by the Broadway society from a fishing village on Long Island. Daisy was frightened by its crude and rustic vitality that provoked people through distorted ancient words, and by the overly offensive circumstances that drove its inhabitants along a shortcut from nowhere to nowhere. Daisy saw terrifying and disgusting points in the simple and rustic life that she could not understand.
tr: However, everything except this woman had gotten on his nerves; the fact that he reflected his discomfort in his emotions rather than his actions made it impossible to argue about it. He had been disgusted by West Egg, this unparalleled 'place' that Broadway had derived from this fishing village of Long Island. He was horrified by the raw vitality behind those old literary words and this slimy fate that drove all these people from one nothingness to another in the shortest way possible. Behind this simplicity, he saw something terrible that he struggled to comprehend.
es: But everything else offended her, and without discussion, because it was not a pose, but a feeling. She was repulsed by West Egg, that unprecedented "branch" that Broadway had spawned in a Long Island fishing village: she was repulsed by its obscene vigor, which impatiently pushed beneath the old euphemisms, and she was repulsed by the shameless fate that had gathered its inhabitants in that shortcut between nothing and nothing. She saw something terrible in that simplicity that she could not understand.

en: I sat on the front steps with them while they waited for their car. It was dark here in front; only the bright door sent ten square feet of light volleying out into the soft black morning. Sometimes a shadow moved against a dressing-room blind above, gave way to another shadow, an indefinite procession of shadows, who rouged and powdered in an invisible glass.
vi: I sat on the front steps with Tom and Daisy for a while as they waited for their car. The front of the house was very dark, with only about ten yards of light cast from the doorway into the darkness. Occasionally, a moving shadow would be cast on the curtain in the upstairs dressing room, replaced by another shadow, the process of changing shadows continuing for those who came to powder themselves before an invisible mirror.
tr: While waiting for their cars, I had sat down with them at the bottom of the stairs: It was dark, the bright light spilling from the open street door illuminated only a few square meters in the sweet twilight of the morning. From time to time, a shadow would fall on the closed curtain of the dressing room, then it would be replaced by another shadow, freshening its powder and lipstick in an invisible mirror.
es: I sat on the entrance steps while they waited for the car. We were in the dark: only the illuminated door cast a few square meters of light over the dark and soft dawn. Sometimes a shadow moved behind the blind of one of the upstairs dressing rooms, giving way to another shadow, to an uncertain procession of shadows, who painted their lips and powdered themselves before an invisible mirror.

en: “Who is this Gatsby anyhow?” demanded Tom suddenly. “Some big bootlegger?”
vi: "Who is this Gatsby?" Tom suddenly asked. "Is he some kind of bootlegger?"
tr: “Who is this Gatsby character?” Tom asked suddenly, “Is he a bootlegger?”
es: —But who is this Gatsby? —Tom suddenly blurted out—. A big-time bootlegger?

en: “Where’d you hear that?” I inquired.
vi: "Where did you hear that?" I probed.
tr: "Where did you hear this from?" I asked.
es: —Where did you hear that? —I asked.

en: “I didn’t hear it. I imagined it. A lot of these newly rich people are just big bootleggers, you know.”
vi: "I didn't hear it anywhere. I just imagined it. There are many people who have recently become wealthy who are smugglers, you know."
tr: "Where did you hear this from?" I asked. “I haven't heard it from anyone, but it's obvious. You know that most of these new rich people are bootleggers,”
es: —I haven't heard it. I've imagined it. Almost all these new rich people are big-time traffickers, you know.

en: “Not Gatsby,” I said shortly.
vi: "Not Gatsby." I said briefly.
tr: "Not Gatsby," I said briefly.
es: —Gatsby no —I replied curtly.

en: He was silent for a moment. The pebbles of the drive crunched under his feet.
vi: Tom was silent for a moment. The pebbles on the road crunched under his feet.
tr: He did not answer, the gravel laid on the road was crunching under his feet.
es: Tom remained silent for a moment. The gravel on the path crunched under his feet.

en: “Well, he certainly must have strained himself to get this menagerie together.”
vi: "Then he must have struggled a lot to be able to gather the animals in this circus troupe."
tr: “So, he must have worked very hard to gather this herd of wild animals.”
es: —Well, it must have cost him quite a bit to set up this zoo.

en: A breeze stirred the grey haze of Daisy’s fur collar.
vi: A gentle breeze blew away the gray dust covering the fur collar of Daisy.
tr: As the wind gently fluttered the gray fur on her collar, Daisy said, forcing herself, "At least they're more interesting than the people around us."
es: The breeze stirred the gray mist of Daisy's fur collar.

en: “At least they are more interesting than the people we know,” she said with an effort.
vi: "At least they ought to be more interesting than the people we know." Daisy tried to say.
tr: As the wind gently fluttered the gray fur on her collar, Daisy said, forcing herself, "At least they're more interesting than the people around us."
es: —At least they are more interesting than the people we know —he said with effort.

en: “You didn’t look so interested.”
vi: "But you don't seem to be enjoying it at all."
tr: “But you didn't seem very interested.”
es: —You didn't show too much interest —replied Tom.

en: “Well, I was.”
vi: "Actually, I do."
tr: “Yes, they caught my attention.”
es: —Well, he had it.

en: Tom laughed and turned to me.
vi: Tom burst out laughing and turned to me.
tr: Tom turned to me laughing, "Did you see the look on Daisy's face when that girl asked her to put herself under a cold shower?"
es: Tom laughed and turned to me.

en: “Did you notice Daisy’s face when that girl asked her to put her under a cold shower?”
vi: "Did you notice Daisy's face when that girl asked her to stand under the cold water?"
tr: Tom turned to me laughing, "Did you see the look on Daisy's face when that girl asked her to put herself under a cold shower?"
es: —Did you notice Daisy's face when that girl asked her to shower her with cold water?

en: Daisy began to sing with the music in a husky, rhythmic whisper, bringing out a meaning in each word that it had never had before and would never have again. When the melody rose her voice broke up sweetly, following it, in a way contralto voices have, and each change tipped out a little of her warm human magic upon the air.
vi: Daisy began to softly sing a tune with a deep, rhythmic voice that brought out the meaning of each lyric, as it had never done before and would never do again. When the note rose high, her voice soared with it, breaking sweetly in perfect harmony like those of contralto singers. Each time she changed her voice like that, she poured a bit of warm, enchanting humanity into the space.
tr: Daisy, in a low and rhythmic whisper, began to hum a song, imbuing each word with new meanings that it had never carried before and would never carry again. When the melody rose, her voice would falter, then continue in a manner typical of contralto voices, gently releasing each changing note, adding the warm magic of her soul.
es: Daisy began to sing, to accompany the music with a rhythmic and husky whisper, and from each word she extracted a meaning that it had never had and would never have again. When the melody rose a few tones, her voice broke softly as she followed it, as often happens with contralto voices, and each change spilled a bit of her warm, human magic into the air.

en: “Lots of people come who haven’t been invited,” she said suddenly. “That girl hadn’t been invited. They simply force their way in and he’s too polite to object.”
vi: "There are many people who weren't invited but still came." Daisy suddenly said. "That girl wasn't invited either. They just came on their own and he was too polite to object."
tr: “Most people come uninvited,” he suddenly said, “that girl was one of them. They just show up without warning, and out of politeness, he doesn't turn any of them away.”
es: —A lot of people who haven't been invited are coming —he said suddenly—. That girl wasn't invited. They sneak in, and he is too polite to protest.

en: “I’d like to know who he is and what he does,” insisted Tom. “And I think I’ll make a point of finding out.”
vi: "He wants to know who he is and what he does." Tom was determined to find out.
tr: “I really wondered who he was and what he did,” insisted Tom, “and I think I will find out somehow.”
es: —I would like to know who he is and what he does —insisted Tom—. And I think I'm going to make it my business to find out.

en: “I can tell you right now,” she answered. “He owned some drugstores, a lot of drugstores. He built them up himself.”
vi: "And he is determined to get the answer." "You can tell me right now," Daisy replied. "He owns several pharmacies, to be precise, a lot of pharmacies. He built them from scratch with his own hands."
tr: “Let me enlighten you right away,” Daisy replied, “He is in the pharmaceutical business, or rather, he has a chain of pharmaceutical markets. He did it all by himself.”
es: —I'm telling you right now —replied Daisy—. He owns several drugstores, many drugstores. He set them up himself.

en: The dilatory limousine came rolling up the drive.
vi: The limousine, arriving late, rolled into the yard.
tr: The delayed car finally approached slowly.
es: The long-awaited limousine was already coming up the road.

en: “Good night, Nick,” said Daisy.
vi: "Goodbye, Nick." Daisy said.
tr: “Good night,” said Daisy.
es: —Good evening, Nick —said Daisy.

en: Her glance left me and sought the lighted top of the steps, where “Three O’Clock in the Morning,” a neat, sad little waltz of that year, was drifting out the open door. After all, in the very casualness of Gatsby’s party there were romantic possibilities totally absent from her world. What was it up there in the song that seemed to be calling her back inside? What would happen now in the dim, incalculable hours? Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.
vi: Daisy's eyes left me to look up at the highest steps illuminated by bright lights, where the open door echoed the melancholic music of the song THREE O'CLOCK IN THE MORNING. Finally, in Gatsby's naturally unceremonious party, there was a touch of romance, something entirely absent in her world. Was there something in the high music that seemed to be inviting Daisy to return? What would happen in those unforeseen dark moments? Perhaps a guest would unexpectedly arrive late, an extraordinarily rare person, a young, dazzling girl with a fresh glance at Gatsby, a magical moment of encounter that would erase those five years of devoted fidelity.
tr: She turned her gaze away from me and looked at the open door behind us, from which the melodies of the beautiful and short waltz, “Three in the Morning,” one of the beloved songs of the year, were coming. Despite everything, there were romantic possibilities at Gatsby’s casual parties that did not exist in Daisy’s world. What was calling her back in the song? What would happen in these dark, unpredictable hours? Perhaps a very young, dazzling, and even dizzyingly beautiful woman would appear and turn her lively gaze towards Gatsby; and, caught up in the magic of the moment, who knows, perhaps the loyalty and dependency that had not diminished for five years would suddenly vanish.
es: Her gaze left me to seek the highest point of the illuminated staircase, where Las tres de la mañana[19], a sad, wonderful, and insignificant waltz from that year, was coming out through the open door. After all, the randomness of Gatsby's parties entailed romantic possibilities completely unknown in her world. What was in that song that seemed to call her, to ask her to re-enter the house? What would happen now, in the murky and unpredictable hours? Perhaps some incredible guest would appear, an infinitely rare person to marvel at, some truly radiant girl, who with a single glance at Gatsby, in a magical and instantaneous encounter, would annihilate those five years of unwavering devotion.

en: I stayed late that night. Gatsby asked me to wait until he was free, and I lingered in the garden until the inevitable swimming party had run up, chilled and exalted, from the black beach, until the lights were extinguished in the guestrooms overhead. When he came down the steps at last the tanned skin was drawn unusually tight on his face, and his eyes were bright and tired.
vi: That night I stayed late. Gatsby asked me to stay until he was free. I lingered in the garden until the familiar groups of daily bathers had all run up from the dark, chilly beach, exhilarated, and until the lights in the guest bedrooms had been turned off. Finally, Gatsby stepped down the stairs, his unusually taut tanned skin on his face, his eyes bright but weary.
tr: I stayed until late that night. Gatsby had asked me to wait until the guests had left. So I lingered in the garden until the inevitable swimming party on the dark beach ended with the guests running home in a frozen state and all the lights in the guest rooms went out. When he finally came to me, his sunburned face was unusually tense, and his sparkling eyes were tired.
es: That night I stayed up very late. Gatsby asked me to wait until he was free, and I wandered around the garden until the inevitable group of bathers, cold and exhilarated, came running from the dark beach, until the lights in the guest rooms upstairs went out. When Gatsby finally came down the stairs, his tanned skin was tighter than ever, and his eyes were bright and tired.

en: “She didn’t like it,” he said immediately.
vi: "She doesn't like it." Gatsby said immediately
tr: Then: “He didn't like it,” he said.
es: —He didn't like it at all —he said immediately.

en: “Of course she did.”
vi: "Of course I like it."
tr: “Of course, he liked it.”
es: —Of course he liked it.

en: “She didn’t like it,” he insisted. “She didn’t have a good time.”
vi: "She doesn't like it." Gatsby asserted. "She is not very happy."
tr: “No, he didn't like it at all,” he insisted, “he didn't have any fun either.”
es: —He didn't like it at all —he insisted—. He didn't have a good time.

en: He was silent, and I guessed at his unutterable depression.
vi: Gatsby became silent, I guessed he was experiencing an unspeakable despondency.
tr: Then he/she fell silent, I could feel the sadness that had enveloped him/her.
es: He fell silent, and I imagined his indescribable dismay.

en: “I feel far away from her,” he said. “It’s hard to make her understand.”
vi: "I feel very distant from her," Gatsby said. "It's hard to make her understand."
tr: “I feel very distant from him,” she said, “it's hard to explain to him.”
es: —I feel very far from her —he said—. It's hard to make her understand.

en: “You mean about the dance?”
vi: "Do you mean the dance performance?"
tr: “Are you referring to the dance?”
es: —Are you referring to the dance?

en: “The dance?” He dismissed all the dances he had given with a snap of his fingers. “Old sport, the dance is unimportant.”
vi: "The dance parties?" Gatsby dismissed all the dance parties he had organized with just a snap of his fingers. "Old sport, the dance parties aren't what matter."
tr: “Dance?” He snapped his fingers and dismissed everything related to dance from his mind, “No buddy, dance is not important at all,”
es: —The dance? —he dismissed all the dances he had organized with a snap of his fingers—. Comrade, the dance is not important.

en: He wanted nothing less of Daisy than that she should go to Tom and say: “I never loved you.” After she had obliterated four years with that sentence they could decide upon the more practical measures to be taken. One of them was that, after she was free, they were to go back to Louisville and be married from her house—just as if it were five years ago.
vi: Gatsby wanted nothing more than for Daisy to say to Tom: "I never loved you." After Daisy erased four years with Tom with that statement, the two of them would be able to come to a decision to resolve matters satisfactorily. One of those resolutions was that, once she was free, she would return to Louisville and get married again from her own home, just as she had five years earlier.
tr: He was not willing to settle for anything less than Daisy confronting Tom and saying, "I never loved you." After erasing the four years spent with him with this sentence, they would decide on one of the more convenient solutions. For instance, after Daisy gained her freedom, they could go to Louisville and get married there; just as they had planned five years ago, Daisy could get married from her own home.
es: He wanted nothing less than for Daisy to go to Tom and say, "I never loved you." When she had erased four years with that phrase, they would decide the most practical steps to take. One was that, as soon as Daisy was free, they would return to Louisville and get married, leaving from the bride's house, just as if it were five years ago.

en: “And she doesn’t understand,” he said. “She used to be able to understand. We’d sit for hours—”
vi: "She doesn't understand. She used to understand before. We used to sit together for many hours..."
tr: “But she can't understand these,” he said, “it wasn't like this before, we used to sit for hours-”
es: —And she doesn't understand it —said Gatsby—. She used to understand everything. We would spend hours and hours...

en: He broke off and began to walk up and down a desolate path of fruit rinds and discarded favours and crushed flowers.
vi: Gatsby was silent, then paced back and forth on the desolate ground littered with fruit peels and crushed flower branches.
tr: He couldn't continue, and started pacing back and forth on the road littered with discarded fruit peels and crushed flowers.
es: He stopped and began to pace up and down a desolate path of fruit peels, denied favors, and crushed flowers.

en: “I wouldn’t ask too much of her,” I ventured. “You can’t repeat the past.”
vi: "If it were me, I wouldn't ask too much of Daisy." I ventured. "You can't repeat the past."
tr: “If I were you, I wouldn't get my hopes up too much,” I said, gathering my courage, “the past is in the past, you can't bring it back.”
es: —I wouldn't ask too much of her —I dared to say to him—. We can't repeat the past.

en: “Can’t repeat the past?” he cried incredulously. “Why of course you can!”
vi: "Can't repeat the past?" Gatsby exclaimed incredulously. "Of course you can."
tr: “Can't we bring it back!” he exclaimed with suspicion, “No, of course we can.”
es: —Can't we repeat the past? —he exclaimed, incredulous—. Of course we can!

en: He looked around him wildly, as if the past were lurking here in the shadow of his house, just out of reach of his hand.
vi: Gatsby looked around himself in a bewildered manner, as if the past were lurking somewhere in the shadows of the house, just out of his reach.
tr: As if it were hidden in a dark corner of his past home, he scanned his surroundings with wild eyes, as if reaching out would touch it, "I will do this, I will restore everything to its former state," he said, nodding his head with conviction, "He will see this too!"
es: He looked everywhere, frantic, as if the past were hiding among the shadows of the house, almost within reach.

en: “I’m going to fix everything just the way it was before,” he said, nodding determinedly. “She’ll see.”
vi: "I will straighten everything out and make them like they were in the past." Gatsby nodded firmly and said resolutely. "She will see."
tr: As if it were hidden in a dark corner of his past home, he scanned his surroundings with wild eyes, as if reaching out would touch it, "I will do this, I will restore everything to its former state," he said, nodding his head with conviction, "He will see this too!"
es: "I am going to return everything to its place, just as it was before," he said, nodding his head very decisively. Daisy will see it.

en: He talked a lot about the past, and I gathered that he wanted to recover something, some idea of himself perhaps, that had gone into loving Daisy. His life had been confused and disordered since then, but if he could once return to a certain starting place and go over it all slowly, he could find out what that thing was…
vi: Gatsby talked a lot about the past, I realized he seemed to be trying to find something, perhaps thoughts for himself, things he had lost since loving Daisy. His life had become confused and chaotic since then, if he could go back to some starting point in the past and let it pass by slowly, he might discover what that something was........
tr: Then, he talked about the past for a long time; it was as if he wanted to fix something about himself, related to leaving when he was in love with Daisy. His later life was disordered and chaotic; however, he was hopeful that if he could go back to a certain time in the past and then slowly move forward through all those days again, he would find what he was looking for.
es: He spoke a lot about the past, and I came to the conclusion that he wanted to recover something, a certain idea of himself, perhaps, that depended on his love for Daisy. Since then, he had led a confused and disordered life, but if he could go back to the starting point and review everything slowly, he would discover what he was looking for.

en: … One autumn night, five years before, they had been walking down the street when the leaves were falling, and they came to a place where there were no trees and the sidewalk was white with moonlight. They stopped here and turned toward each other. Now it was a cool night with that mysterious excitement in it which comes at the two changes of the year. The quiet lights in the houses were humming out into the darkness and there was a stir and bustle among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye Gatsby saw that the blocks of the sidewalks really formed a ladder and mounted to a secret place above the trees—he could climb to it, if he climbed alone, and once there he could suck on the pap of life, gulp down the incomparable milk of wonder.
vi: One autumn night five years ago, the two of them walked side by side on the street under the falling leaves. They walked to a place without trees and the whole sidewalk lit up under the moonlight. They stopped there facing each other. The cool evening contained mysterious stirrings that came only twice a year at the change of seasons. The gentle light from the houses softly spread out into the darkness, and there was something like a tremor, like a stir among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye, Gatsby saw the paving stones of the sidewalk shifting, stacking up to form a ladder reaching to some secret place atop the trees. If he were alone, he could climb it. Once at the top, he could suck on the nipple of life and gulp down great draughts of its incomparable milk.
tr: Five years ago, on an autumn night when the leaves were falling, while wandering the streets, they came to a treeless avenue and stopped on a sidewalk illuminated by the moonlight. They turned and looked into each other's faces. That mysterious excitement, encountered only twice a year when the seasons change, had dominated the cool night. As the faint lights in the windows of the houses filtered into the darkness of the night, the stars seemed to be in a hurry, constantly twinkling; when Gatsby glanced out of the corner of his eye, he had indeed seen a staircase made of cobblestones climbing towards a hidden realm at the tops of the trees. If he could have climbed there, he could have absorbed the essence of life waiting for him at the peak and sipped the unique milk of miracles.
es: … One autumn night, five years before, they were walking down the street, and the leaves were falling, and they reached a place where there were no trees and the sidewalk was white in the moonlight. They stopped there and looked at each other. It was already cold and the night had that mysterious emotion that is felt during the changes of season. The silent lights of the houses vibrated in the darkness and there was a tremor, an agitation among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye, Gatsby saw that the cobblestones of the sidewalk formed a path that rose to a secret place, beyond the treetops. If he climbed it alone, he would climb it, and once at the top, he could suckle from the udder of life, swallow the incomparable milk of wonder.

en: His heart beat faster as Daisy’s white face came up to his own. He knew that when he kissed this girl, and forever wed his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never romp again like the mind of God. So he waited, listening for a moment longer to the tuning-fork that had been struck upon a star. Then he kissed her. At his lips’ touch she blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete.
vi: Gatsby's heart beat faster and faster as Daisy's pale face drew closer to his. Gatsby knew that when he kissed this girl, the ineffable visions he had would forever be entwined with her perishable breath. His mind would never be as serene as the mind of God. So he paused, waiting, listening a little longer to the tuning fork that had been struck upon a star. And then he kissed Daisy. At the touch of his lips, Daisy blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete.
tr: As Daisy's radiant face approached his, his heart was pounding wildly. After kissing her and surrendering his indescribable dreams to her mortal breath, his thoughts would never again surge and play like those in God's mind. Listening to the sound of a tuning fork striking a star, he waited with these thoughts for a moment. Then he kissed her. At the moment their lips met, the girl blossomed for him like a flower, and creation was complete.
es: His heart was beating faster and faster as Daisy's pale face came closer to his. He knew that, when he kissed that girl and forever bound his ineffable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never again soar like the mind of God. So he waited, and for a few more seconds heard the tuning fork that had just struck a star. Then he kissed her. And at the touch of his lips, she blossomed like a flower and the incarnation was complete.

en: Through all he said, even through his appalling sentimentality, I was reminded of something—an elusive rhythm, a fragment of lost words, that I had heard somewhere a long time ago. For a moment a phrase tried to take shape in my mouth and my lips parted like a dumb man’s, as though there was more struggling upon them than a wisp of startled air. But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.
vi: Through everything Gatsby said, even through his sentimental and mawkish nature, it naturally reminded me of something - like a forgotten rhythm or a few words in a sentence I had heard from long ago. For a moment, these words began to form in my mouth and my lips parted like an idiot, as if struggling with them rather than a trembling breath. Yet they made no sound, and what I almost remembered was never spoken.
tr: Despite its eerie sentimentality, as he was recounting these, I remembered something; a melody I had heard who knows when, and a few lost words I couldn't place... For a moment, a word began to form in my mouth. As if there was more than just a wisp of air touching my tongue, my lips moved in vain like a mute person. The words I vaguely remembered remained unsaid.
es: Everything he said, including his dreadful sentimentality, reminded me of something: an elusive rhythm, a fragment of forgotten words that I had heard somewhere, a long time ago. A phrase tried to take shape in my mouth and my lips opened like those of a mute, as if something more than a frightened breath of air resisted them. But they made no sound, and what I had been about to remember became incommunicable forever.

en: VII
vi: Chapter 7
tr: CHAPTER 7

en: It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. Only gradually did I become aware that the automobiles which turned expectantly into his drive stayed for just a minute and then drove sulkily away. Wondering if he were sick I went over to find out—an unfamiliar butler with a villainous face squinted at me suspiciously from the door.
vi: While the curiosity about Gatsby was reaching its peak, one Saturday evening the lights in his house suddenly did not turn on anymore, and his career, like Trimalchio's, became as obscure as it was in the beginning. Gradually, I realized that the cars that unexpectedly turned into his driveway only stayed for about a minute before gloomily turning away in disappointment. Wondering if he was ill, I went over to inquire, and a strange but fierce-looking butler glanced at me suspiciously from the door.
tr: At a time when interest and curiosity about her had peaked, I saw that the lights of her house were off on a Saturday night. Just as Gatsby had mysteriously appeared suddenly as a Trimalchio5, he had vanished in the same way. I later noticed that the cars heading towards the mansion for fun were grumbling and turning back after a few minutes. Thinking he might be ill, I went to his house. A butler with a treacherous face, whom I had never seen before, opened the door and scrutinized me with narrowed eyes and suspicion. 5 Trimalchio. A character in the novel Satyricon written by Petronius during the Roman period. He was famous for the lavish dinners he hosted.
es: One Saturday night, when curiosity about Gatsby had reached its peak, the lights of his house did not turn on and, as darkly as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio[20] came to an end. Only gradually did I realize that the cars that eagerly took the turn into the driveway barely stopped for a moment and then drove away disappointed. Wondering if he might be ill, I went over to inquire. A butler with an undesirable face whom I did not know looked at me from the door with a grim and distrustful expression.

en: “Is Mr. Gatsby sick?”
vi: "Is Mr. Gatsby sick?"
tr: Translator's Note “Is Mr. Gatsby uncomfortable?”
es: —Is Mr. Gatsby sick?

en: “Nope.” After a pause he added “sir” in a dilatory, grudging way.
vi: "No." After a brief pause, he reluctantly added the words "Sir" in a resentful tone.
tr: After saying "No," he added the word "sir" with some difficulty.
es: —None of that —after a pause, resisting and reluctantly, he added "sir."

en: “I hadn’t seen him around, and I was rather worried. Tell him Mr. Carraway came over.”
vi: "Lately, I haven't seen him, so I feel a bit worried. Please tell Mr. Carraway to come visit."
tr: “He hasn't been seen for a while, so I got worried. You say Mr. Carraway has arrived.”
es: —I don't see him around here, and I was worried. Tell him that Mr. Carraway has come.

en: “Who?” he demanded rudely.
vi: "Who?" he asked rudely.
tr: "Kim?" he asked in a rough manner.
es: —Who? —he asked, rudely.

en: “Carraway.”
vi: "Carraway."
tr: "Carraway"
es: —Carraway.

en: “Carraway. All right, I’ll tell him.”
vi: "Carraway." "Alright. I will leave a message."
tr: “Carraway. Alright, okay, I'll tell him.”
es: —Carraway. Very well, I will tell him.

en: Abruptly he slammed the door.
vi: He abruptly slammed the door shut.
tr: He slammed the door in my face.
es: And without another word, he slammed the door.

en: My Finn informed me that Gatsby had dismissed every servant in his house a week ago and replaced them with half a dozen others, who never went into West Egg village to be bribed by the tradesmen, but ordered moderate supplies over the telephone. The grocery boy reported that the kitchen looked like a pigsty, and the general opinion in the village was that the new people weren’t servants at all.
vi: My Finnish housekeeper informed me that about a week ago, Gatsby had fired all the household staff and replaced them with about a dozen others. These people had never been to West Egg before, so the delivery men found it difficult to bribe or persuade them. They ordered a lot of food over the phone. The delivery boy reported that the kitchen now looked like a pigsty, and others in the village agreed that not all of these new workers were actually household staff.
tr: My Finnish, that Gatsby had dismissed all the servants working at home a week ago, and that the six people he had hired in their place did not go down to the village to avoid taking bribes from the West Egg tradesmen, instead ordering a reasonable amount of food and drink by phone. She had heard from the grocer's apprentice that the kitchen had turned into a stable, and also added that the prevailing opinion in the neighborhood was that the newcomers did not quite resemble servants.
es: My Finnish woman informed me that Gatsby had fired all the servants in the house a week ago and had replaced them with others, who no longer went to West Egg Village to be bribed by the shopkeepers, but instead made very modest orders by phone. The grocery store boy said that the kitchen looked like a pigsty, and the general opinion in the town was that the newcomers were not servants at all.

en: Next day Gatsby called me on the phone.
vi: The next day Gatsby called me on the phone
tr: The next day, Gatsby called me.
es: The next day Gatsby called me on the phone.

en: “Going away?” I inquired.
vi: "Are you going far?" I asked.
tr: "Are you going somewhere?" I asked.
es: —Are you leaving? —I asked him.

en: “No, old sport.”
vi: "It's not like that, old friend."
tr: “No, buddy.”
es: —No, comrade.

en: “I hear you fired all your servants.”
vi: "I heard that you fired all the helpers."
tr: “I heard that he fired his servants.”
es: —I have been told that you have dismissed the service.

en: “I wanted somebody who wouldn’t gossip. Daisy comes over quite often—in the afternoons.”
vi: "I want to hire people who don't make much fuss." "Daisy comes here often, in the afternoons."
tr: “I wanted people who wouldn't gossip. Daisy often comes in the afternoons, you know.”
es: —I needed people who wouldn't gossip. Daisy comes very often... in the afternoons.

en: So the whole caravansary had fallen in like a card house at the disapproval in her eyes.
vi: So that's how it is, the entire boarding house collapsed like a house built of cards just because of the displeased look from the beautiful woman.
tr: So, the grand caravanserai had collapsed like houses made of playing cards because of the displeasure he saw in Daisy's eyes!
es: So the entire caravanserai had come crashing down like a house of cards due to a disapproving look from Daisy.

en: “They’re some people Wolfshiem wanted to do something for. They’re all brothers and sisters. They used to run a small hotel.”
vi: "They are the people whom Wolfsheim wants to help. All of them are siblings, who used to run a small hotel."
tr: "The newcomers are actually a family that Wolfsheim wants to help. They are all siblings. They used to run a small hotel."
es: —They are people whom Wolfshiem wanted to help. They are all brothers and sisters. They ran a small hotel.

en: “I see.”
vi: "Is that so."
tr: “I understand.”
es: —Okay.

en: He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there. Half an hour later Daisy herself telephoned and seemed relieved to find that I was coming. Something was up. And yet I couldn’t believe that they would choose this occasion for a scene—especially for the rather harrowing scene that Gatsby had outlined in the garden.
vi: Gatsby called me, at Daisy's request, asking if I wanted to come to Daisy's house the next day. Baker would also be there. Half an hour later, Daisy herself called to invite me and felt reassured knowing that I would visit. I guessed something was up, but I couldn't believe they would choose this time to cause trouble, especially the kind of trouble Gatsby had outlined to me while we were in the garden.
tr: He said that Daisy had asked him to call me. Would I come to lunch at the Buchanans' tomorrow? Miss Baker would also be there. Half an hour later, Daisy called as well. She was very happy to hear that I would come. Something was going on. But I didn't think they were waiting for that day to cause a scene, especially to carry out that strange plan Gatsby had explained in the garden that night.
es: Daisy had asked her to call me: could I go to lunch tomorrow at the Buchanans' house? Miss Baker would also be there. Half an hour later, Daisy herself called me and seemed relieved when she found out I would go. Something was going to happen, and yet, I didn't think they would choose that occasion to create a scene: especially the horrible scene that Gatsby had rehearsed in the garden.

en: The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. As my train emerged from the tunnel into sunlight, only the hot whistles of the National Biscuit Company broke the simmering hush at noon. The straw seats of the car hovered on the edge of combustion; the woman next to me perspired delicately for a while into her white shirtwaist, and then, as her newspaper dampened under her fingers, lapsed despairingly into deep heat with a desolate cry. Her pocketbook slapped to the floor.
vi: The next day was scorching hot, perhaps the last and hottest day of summer. When my train passed through the tunnel into the light, there was nothing but the scorching whistles of the National Biscuit Company shattering the sweltering, silent atmosphere. The straw-stuffed seats in the carriage seemed almost ready to catch fire. The woman sitting next to me was drenched in sweat around her white shirt, and then, when the pages of the newspaper she was reading became damp under her fingers, she let out a sigh amidst the oppressive heat. Her notebook fell with a thud to the floor of the train.
tr: The next day, the weather was so hot that everywhere was scorching. It was definitely the hottest day of the summer, perhaps the last hot day. When the suburban train I was on emerged from the tunnel into the light, the only thing piercing the unbearable heat of the midday sun was the sharp whistle sound from the factory chimney of the National Biscuit Company. The wicker seats of the carriage I was in were burning hot from the heat. After sweating gently for a while under her white blouse, the woman sitting next to me surrendered to the extreme heat with a desperate cry when the newspaper between her fingers became soaking wet. At that moment, when she dropped her handbag to the ground, she shouted, "Damn it!"
es: The next day was scorching, almost the last of summer and undoubtedly the hottest. When my train emerged from the tunnel, into the sunlight, only the warm siren of the National Biscuit Company broke the boiling silence of noon. The seats of the train were nearing the ignition point; the woman next to me delicately stained her white blouse with sweat and then, when the newspaper became damp at the touch of her fingers, she surrendered to the unbearable heat with despair and a desolate moan. Her purse fell to the floor.

en: “Oh, my!” she gasped.
vi: "Oh, my God". She cried out, almost out of breath.
tr: At that moment, when she dropped her handbag to the ground, she shouted, "Damn it!"
es: —My God! —he sighed.

en: I picked it up with a weary bend and handed it back to her, holding it at arm’s length and by the extreme tip of the corners to indicate that I had no designs upon it—but everyone near by, including the woman, suspected me just the same.
vi: I wearily bent down to pick up the notebook and handed it back to her, holding it slightly by the corner and keeping an arm's length distance to show that I had no ill intentions, yet the people around, including the woman, looked at me with suspicion.
tr: I was tired and exhausted, but I bent down, picked up the bag from the ground, and handed it to the woman.
