To show that I had no bad intentions, I had made sure to hold it by the fingertips, keeping it away from myself. But everyone around us, including the woman, had their eyes fixed on me with suspicion.
es: I picked it up with a tired inclination and returned it to him, holding it by a corner, by the tip, and extending my arm to make it clear that my gesture did not hide any ulterior motives, but everyone nearby, including the woman, suspected the same of me.

en: “Hot!” said the conductor to familiar faces. “Some weather!… Hot!… Hot!… Hot!… Is it hot enough for you? Is it hot? Is it… ?”
vi: "It's so hot!" The ticket inspector said to the familiar faces. "Why is it so hot, hot! hot! hot! Isn't it hot enough already? It's so hot, isn't it? Isn't it...?"
tr: “Hot!” muttered the conductor, looking at familiar faces, “What weather! Hot! Hot!... Hot! Does it feel hot to you too? Hot? Hot...”
es: —What heat! —said the conductor in front of the faces that seemed familiar to him—. What weather! What heat, what heat. Do you think it's not much? Aren't you hot?

en: My commutation ticket came back to me with a dark stain from his hand. That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!
vi: My train ticket was returned with his dirty fingerprints on it. In this dreadful heat, who cares to notice which rosy lips they have kissed or whose head is drenched on their pajama chest pocket.
tr: When he returned my ticket, I saw that his fingerprint was on it. In this heat, do you think anyone cares whose lips they've kissed or whose head they've rested on the chest pocket of their pajamas!
es: He returned the train voucher to me with a dark stain that his hand had left. How could anyone care, in such heat, whose feverish lips they kissed, or whose head dampened the pocket of their pajamas, over their heart?

en: … Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
vi: .... A cool breeze blew through the Buchanan's front hall, carrying the sound of a ringing phone to where Gatsby and I were standing, waiting at the door.
tr: …While waiting with Gatsby in front of the open door of the Buchanans, a gentle breeze from the living room brought the sound of the ringing telephone to us.
es: But in the vestibule of the Buchanan house, a gentle breeze blew, carrying the sound of the telephone to the door where Gatsby and I were waiting.

en: “The master’s body?” roared the butler into the mouthpiece. “I’m sorry, madame, but we can’t furnish it—it’s far too hot to touch this noon!”
vi: The butler shouted loudly into the receiver. "I'm sorry, madam, but we can't get it done - this afternoon is unbearably hot and we can't touch it."
tr: “Did you say the gentleman's body?” the servant was shouting into the receiver, “I'm sorry ma'am, but we can't do it today, it's noon right now and we can't touch anything because of the heat!” 6 The author continues his thoughts about the heat in the train by having the servant express them, thus sharing this imagination with the reader. In the next line, he conveys the servant's real conversation on the phone. Translator's Note
es: —The master's corpse! —roared the butler into the device—. I'm sorry, madam, but we cannot deliver it to you. It's too hot to touch it at midday!

en: What he really said was: “Yes… Yes… I’ll see.”
vi: Actually, what he said was just: "Yes... yes... let me see."
tr: In reality, he was saying, "Yes... yes... I understand."
es: What he really said was: —Yes. Yes. I'm going to see.

en: He set down the receiver and came toward us, glistening slightly, to take our stiff straw hats.
vi: He put down the receiver and came out to meet us, taking our stiff straw hats.
tr: When he came over to get our straw hats after putting the receiver back, his face was covered in sweat.
es: He hung up and approached us, shining with sweat, to take our straw hats.

en: “Madame expects you in the salon!” he cried, needlessly indicating the direction. In this heat every extra gesture was an affront to the common store of life.
vi: "The hostess is waiting for you two inside!" he shouted without bothering to point the way. In this terrible heat, making any additional gesture is an insult to everyone's reserve of vitality.
tr: “The lady is waiting in the living room,” he said, pointing us in the direction with an unnecessary gesture. In this heat, every extra gesture felt like an insult to one's life energy.
es: —Madame is waiting for you in the living room! —she shouted and, unnecessarily, pointed the way for us. With that heat, every superfluous gesture was an offense against the normal reserves of life.

en: The room, shadowed well with awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.
vi: The room was shaded by canvas awnings, making it somewhat dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan were lying on a huge couch, looking like two silver idols resting on their white dresses to keep them from being blown away by the gentle breeze of the fans.
tr: The living room, with its shutters tightly closed, was dim and cool. Daisy and Jordan, in their white dresses, were sprawled on a large couch, surrendering themselves to the buzzing breeze of the fans. They looked like silver statues.
es: The room, in the shade of the awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan were lying on a huge sofa, like silver idols whose weight held down their white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.

en: “We can’t move,” they said together.
vi: "We can't move." Both of them spoke at once.
tr: "We can't move," they shouted in unison.
es: —We can't move —they said in unison.

en: Jordan’s fingers, powdered white over their tan, rested for a moment in mine.
vi: The fingers, powdered white on Jordan's sun-tanned skin, pressed lightly against my fingers
tr: Jordan placed his bronze hand, which he had powdered to prevent sweating, in my palm for a moment.
es: Jordan's fingers, with whitening powders over the tan, rested for a moment on mine.

en: “And Mr. Thomas Buchanan, the athlete?” I inquired.
vi: "And where is the athlete Thomas Buchanan?" I asked.
tr: "Where is the famous athlete Mr. Thomas Buchanan?" I asked.
es: —And Mr. Tom Buchanan, the athlete? —I asked.

en: Simultaneously I heard his voice, gruff, muffled, husky, at the hall telephone.
vi: Right then I heard Tom's voice, rough and rude, hoarse and raspy, talking on the phone in the h hallway.
tr: At the same time, we heard Tom's muffled and low voice talking on the phone inside.
es: Simultaneously I heard Tom's voice, grumpy, muffled, hoarse, on the lobby phone.

en: Gatsby stood in the centre of the crimson carpet and gazed around with fascinated eyes. Daisy watched him and laughed, her sweet, exciting laugh; a tiny gust of powder rose from her bosom into the air.
vi: Gatsby stood right in the middle of the deep red carpet, gazing around with passionate eyes. Daisy looked at him and burst into laughter, a sound full of sweet joy. A bit of powder dust from her chest floated up into the air.
tr: Gatsby was standing in the middle of the red carpet, looking around as if mesmerized. As Daisy looked at him and let out one of her sweet, thrilling laughs, a fine puff of powder rose from her chest and mingled with the air.
es: Gatsby, standing in the center of the crimson carpet, looked at everything with fascinated eyes. Daisy, watching him, laughed with her sweet and exciting laugh: a tiny puff of pink powder rose from her chest.

en: “The rumour is,” whispered Jordan, “that that’s Tom’s girl on the telephone.”
vi: "According to the rumors," Jordan whispered, "the person on the phone is Tom's mistress."
tr: “The person who keeps calling is said to be Tom's girlfriend,” Jordan whispered in my ear.
es: —There's a rumor —murmured Jordan— that the one on the phone is Tom's girl.

en: We were silent. The voice in the hall rose high with annoyance: “Very well, then, I won’t sell you the car at all… I’m under no obligations to you at all… and as for your bothering me about it at lunch time, I won’t stand that at all!”
vi: We were all silent. The voice from the hallway rose louder, full of irritation. "If that's the case, I won't sell you the car anymore. I'm not obligated to sell it to you... Regarding you calling and disturbing me during lunch like this, I can't tolerate it."
tr: We were all silently waiting. The voice coming from the hallway rose in anger. “Alright then, I won't sell you that car either...I don't have to do this... and I won't tolerate you bothering me about it during meal time!”
es: We remained silent. The voice from the lobby rose irritably: —Very well, then. I am not selling you the car, in any way... I have no commitment to you... And I do not tolerate, in any way, being disturbed during my meal!

en: “Holding down the receiver,” said Daisy cynically.
vi: "Then put the receiver down." Daisy said suspiciously.
tr: "Shutting the mouth of the fool," Daisy mocked.
es: —You have the phone microphone covered —said Daisy cynically.

en: “No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”
vi: "No, he doesn't have it." I reassured her. "This is an honest business. I happened to know about this."
tr: "No, he isn't," I assured, "this is a real job interview, I am aware of it too."
es: —No —I assured him—. He is genuinely negotiating. I know the matter.

en: Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.
vi: Tom opened the door and walked in. For a moment, his large frame blocked the entire doorway, then he hurried into the room.
tr: Tom, who opened the door with a rush, stood at the threshold for a moment with his thick body, then quickly entered the room.
es: Tom suddenly opened the door, blocked it for a few seconds with his ample body, and rushed into the room.

en: “Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”
vi: "Hello Gatsby!" Tom extended his broad hand in greeting, skillfully masking his disdain. "I am pleased to meet you, sir.... Hello Nick."
tr: “Mr. Gatsby,” he said, extending his large, flat hand. He was good at hiding that he didn't quite like him, “I'm glad to see you, sir... Nick, hello...”
es: —Mr. Gatsby! —he extended his hand, broad and open, with well-disguised annoyance—. I'm glad to see you… Nick…

en: “Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.
vi: "Make everyone a cold drink." Daisy said loudly.
tr: "Why don't you prepare us something cold to drink?" Daisy called out.
es: "Prepare us something cold to drink," ordered Daisy.

en: As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.
vi: When Tom left the room, Daisy stood up, walked over to Gatsby, pulled his face down, and kissed him on the lips.
tr: When Tom left the room, she stood up and went to Gatsby, bringing her face close to his and kissed him on the lips.
es: She stood up when Tom left the room, approached Gatsby, made him tilt his head, and kissed him on the mouth.

en: “You know I love you,” she murmured.
vi: "You know I love you, don't you." Daisy whispered.
tr: "You know that I love you," she murmured.
es: —You know I love you —he murmured.

en: “You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.
vi: "You forget that there is a woman present here." Jordan said.
tr: “You forget that there is a woman here,” said Jordan.
es: —You forget that there is a lady present —said Jordan.

en: Daisy looked around doubtfully.
vi: Daisy looked around with a doubtful expression.
tr: Daisy looked around suspiciously.
es: Daisy looked around, hesitant.

en: “You kiss Nick too.”
vi: "I also kissed Nick."
tr: "Then you kiss Nick too," he said.
es: —You kiss Nick.

en: “What a low, vulgar girl!”
vi: "Indeed, she is such a lowly and vulgar girl." "You are so reckless!"
tr: “She is neither vulgar nor simple.”
es: —What a rude and vulgar girl! —I don't care!

en: “I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.
vi: Daisy shouted, standing in front of the brick fireplace. Then suddenly remembering the heat, Daisy sat back down regretfully just as a neatly dressed nanny led a little girl into the room.
tr: “I don't care,” shouted Daisy, as she stood in front of the brick fireplace for a while. Then, remembering how hot it was, she sat back down on the couch with a guilty expression on her face, as a nanny in a pressed uniform entered with a little girl.
es: —shouted Daisy and started to dance on the chimney bricks. Then he remembered the heat and sat on the sofa with a guilty look just as a very clean and freshly ironed nanny entered the room with a little girl.

en: “Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”
vi: "Mommy's little girl." Daisy cuddled and hugged her daughter. "Come here, let mommy love you."
tr: "My precious," Daisy said, opening her arms, "come to your loving mother."
es: —Bless-ed pre-cious-ness! —hummed Daisy, extending her arms—. Come to your mother who adores you.

en: The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.
vi: The child left the nanny's hand, dashed across the room, and then shyly nestled into its mother's clothes.
tr: The child, who let go of the nanny's hand, ran to his mother and stood by her dress, shyly.
es: The girl, free from the nanny, ran across the room and timidly grabbed her mother's dress.

en: “The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”
vi: "Mommy's darling! Have I sprinkled powder on your golden hair yet? Stand up, say hello to the guests."
tr: “My precious, has your mother sprinkled powder on your blonde hair? Come on, get up and ask the guests 'how are you'.”
es: —My blessed precious one! Did mommy fill your precious blonde hair with powder? Stand up straight and say: How are you?

en: Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.
vi: Gatsby and I bent down to take the child's small, timid hand. After that, he kept looking at the child with a look of surprise. I suppose he had never really thought that the child actually existed.
tr: Gatsby and I bent down and shook the little hand that the reluctant girl extended. Gatsby, without taking his eyes off the girl, was gazing at her with astonished looks. I think until that moment, he hadn't really believed in her existence.
es: Gatsby and I leaned down to take the tiny and reluctant hand. Then Gatsby continued to look at the child with surprise. I think that until then he had not truly believed in her existence.

en: “I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.
vi: "I already changed my clothes before lunch." The child hurriedly turned back and said to the mother.
tr: "I would change my clothes for dinner," said the child excitedly, looking at his mother.
es: —I dressed up for the meal —said the girl, turning towards Daisy with impatience.

en: “That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”
vi: "Because mommy wants to show you off." Daisy's face lowered, burying into the small, white, chubby neck of her child. "My baby. You are truly as beautiful as a dream."
tr: “Because your mother wants to show you off to everyone,” he said, bringing his face closer to the single line on the girl's tiny, white neck. “You are the angel of my dreams. You are my dream.”
es: —Because your mother wanted to show you off —Daisy's face moved closer to the only wrinkle on the small white collar—. You are a dream, you are a very small dream.

en: “Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”
vi: "Yes." The child answered softly and gently. "Aunt Jordan is also wearing a white dress."
tr: “Yes,” said the child in a calm voice, “Aunt Jordan's dress is also white.”
es: —Yes —admitted the girl, calmly—. Aunt Jordan is also wearing a white dress.

en: “How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”
vi: "Do you like Mommy's friends?" Daisy turned around to face Gatsby. "Do you think they are pretty?"
tr: "So, how did you find mommy's friends?" Daisy took the little one by the shoulders and turned her face towards Gatsby. "Did you like them?"
es: —What do you think of mom's friends? —Daisy turned her around to look at Gatsby—. Do you think they are handsome?

en: “Where’s Daddy?”
vi: "Where's Dad?"
tr: "Where is my father?"
es: —Where is dad?

en: “She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”
vi: "The girl doesn't look like her father," Daisy explained. "She looks like me. She looks like me in her hair and face."
tr: “He doesn't look like his father at all,” Daisy explained, “He looks just like me. Especially, he got his hair and face shape from me.”
es: —He doesn't look like his father —explained Daisy—. He looks like me. He has my hair and the shape of my face.

en: Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.
vi: Daisy sat down on the chair. The nanny stepped forward and reached out to take the baby.
tr: When Daisy sat back down, the nanny stepped forward and extended her hand.
es: Daisy climbed onto the sofa. The nanny took a step and reached out her hand towards the girl.

en: “Come, Pammy.”
vi: "Come here, Pammy."
tr: "Come, Pammy.""
es: —Let's go, Pammy.

en: “Goodbye, sweetheart!”
vi: "Hello, my dear daughter!"
tr: “Bye bye, my dear.”
es: —Goodbye, treasure!

en: With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.
vi: With a regretful glance back, the obedient child took the nanny's hand and was pulled out of the door just as Tom returned with four glasses of gin and tonic filled with clinking ice cubes.
tr: The well-mannered little girl, after looking back once, reluctantly took her nanny's hand. As the woman led her to the door, Tom entered following the servant who was carrying four tall glasses filled with ice.
es: Turning to look, the girl, reluctant, very well-mannered, took the nanny's hand, who led her away, just as Tom returned with four gin and sodas with lime juice, clinking with ice.

en: Gatsby took up his drink.
vi: Gatsby took his glass of wine.
tr: Gatsby took his drink.
es: Gatsby picked up his glass.

en: “They certainly look cool,” he said, with visible tension.
vi: "It looks cool." Gatsby said, his demeanor clearly showing tension.
tr: “It really looks cold,” he said with obvious unease.
es: —They seem really cold —he said, visibly tense.

en: We drank in long, greedy swallows.
vi: We gulped down long sips.
tr: We started drinking the beverages quickly with large gulps.
es: We gave long and eager speeches.

en: “I read somewhere that the sun’s getting hotter every year,” said Tom genially. “It seems that pretty soon the earth’s going to fall into the sun—or wait a minute—it’s just the opposite—the sun’s getting colder every year.
vi: "I once read somewhere that each year the sun becomes hotter." Tom said intimately. "So sooner or later the earth will fall into the sun - wait - it seems to be the opposite - the sun becomes colder each year."
tr: “I read somewhere that the sun gets a little hotter every year,” said Tom with the air of a polite host, “the world will soon fall into the sun – wait a minute – I think it was the other way around. That is, the sun gets a little colder every year,” he said
es: —I read somewhere that the sun gets hotter every year —said Tom, very amiably—. It seems that very soon the earth will fall into the sun, or, wait a moment, no, it's exactly the opposite: the sun gets cooler every year.

en: “Come outside,” he suggested to Gatsby, “I’d like you to have a look at the place.”
vi: "Come here." Tom suggested to Gatsby. "I want you to come out and see this."
tr: "Come outside," he suggested to Gatsby, "I want you to see the surroundings."
es: Come on —he suggested to Gatsby—. I would like you to see the house.

en: I went with them out to the veranda. On the green Sound, stagnant in the heat, one small sail crawled slowly toward the fresher sea. Gatsby’s eyes followed it momentarily; he raised his hand and pointed across the bay.
vi: I went with them out into the hallway. Outside, the green strait's water seemed stagnant in the heat, a small sailboat slowly gliding towards the refreshing open sea. Gatsby watched the sail for a moment, then he raised his hand to point across the bay.
tr: I also stepped out onto the veranda with them. In the green waters of the Bosphorus, under the heat, a sailboat was slowly gliding towards fresher waters. Gatsby, who watched it with his eyes for a while, reached out his hand and pointed to the opposite shore.
es: I went out with them to the gallery. Over the narrow, green, heat-stagnant strait, a tiny sail was gliding very slowly towards cooler waters. Gatsby's eyes followed it for a moment; he raised his hand and pointed to the other shore of the bay.

en: “I’m right across from you.”
vi: "My house is across from your house on the other side."
tr: “I am sitting right in front of you.”
es: —I live exactly in front of your house.

en: “So you are.”
vi: "Is that so."
tr: “Yes, it seems so.”
es: —Okay.

en: Our eyes lifted over the rose-beds and the hot lawn and the weedy refuse of the dog-days alongshore. Slowly the white wings of the boat moved against the blue cool limit of the sky. Ahead lay the scalloped ocean and the abounding blessed isles.
vi: Our eyes glanced over the rose beds, across the blazing lawn, and the grass accustomed to summer heat growing along the water's edge. The white sails of the boat moved slowly towards the cool boundary of the sky. Ahead was the shell-shaped ocean and the fortunate islands.
tr: Our eyes wandered over rose beds, grass scorched by the sun, and debris left from the hot days of summer stretching along the shore. The white wings of the boat were receding, dividing the skyline. Further ahead lay the choppy ocean and a multitude of islands, big and small.
es: We looked beyond the rose bushes, the warm lawn, and the algae debris left along the coast on the stifling days. The wings of the ship moved slowly against the cold blue edge of the sky. Before us stretched the undulating ocean and the blessed and abundant islands.

en: “There’s sport for you,” said Tom, nodding. “I’d like to be out there with him for about an hour.”
vi: "It's an interesting sport," Tom nodded and said. "I want to go out there and play with it for about an hour."
tr: “This is real sport for you,” said Tom, nodding his head, “I would have liked to be there next to that man, even if only for an hour.”
es: —Now that's a sport —said Tom, nodding his head—. I would like to spend an hour on that boat.

en: We had luncheon in the dining-room, darkened too against the heat, and drank down nervous gaiety with the cold ale.
vi: We had lunch in the dining room, which had been darkened to escape the heat, and drank away our joy and restlessness with cold beers.
tr: We ate lunch in the living room. The room was dim when the curtains were tightly drawn to keep it cool. We were sipping our beers in a tense cheerfulness.
es: We had lunch in the dining room, in the shade, against the heat, and drank nervous joy with the cold beer.

en: “What’ll we do with ourselves this afternoon?” cried Daisy, “and the day after that, and the next thirty years?”
vi: "What should we do this afternoon to pass the time?" Daisy said loudly. "And then the day after that, and the next thirty years."
tr: “What would you like to do this afternoon?” shouted Daisy, “Or tomorrow or the day after, or even for the next thirty years.”
es: —What are we going to do this afternoon? —exclaimed Daisy—. And tomorrow, and in the next thirty years?[21]

en: “Don’t be morbid,” Jordan said. “Life starts all over again when it gets crisp in the fall.”
vi: "Don't think in such an unhealthy way," Jordan said. "Life will start anew when the cool autumn arrives."
tr: “Don't be ridiculous,” said Jordan, “life starts anew when the weather cools down in the fall anyway.”
es: —Don't be morbid —said Jordan—. Life starts over when it gets cool in the fall.

en: “But it’s so hot,” insisted Daisy, on the verge of tears, “and everything’s so confused. Let’s all go to town!”
vi: "But now it's too hot." Daisy continued, her eyes looking like she was about to cry. "And everything seems so confusing and mixed up. Let's go downtown."
tr: “But it's so hot,” insisted Daisy, almost on the verge of tears, “and everything is so complicated.” Let's all go down to the city together!"
es: —But it's so hot —insisted Daisy, on the verge of tears— and everything is so confusing… Let's go to the city!

en: Her voice struggled on through the heat, beating against it, moulding its senselessness into forms.
vi: Daisy's voice seemed to be struggling with the heat, as if beating it, molding its insensitivity into shapes.
tr: The sound was forcing its way through the heat, reshaping it.
es: His voice struggled and crashed against the heat, giving shape to the senselessness of that climate.

en: “I’ve heard of making a garage out of a stable,” Tom was saying to Gatsby, “but I’m the first man who ever made a stable out of a garage.”
vi: "I heard that people use horse stables to make garages." At that moment, Tom was talking to Gatsby. "But I am the first person to use a garage as a horse stable."
tr: "I had heard of people converting barns into garages," Tom was saying to Gatsby, "but I am the first person to convert a garage into a barn."
es: —I have heard of stables being turned into garages —Tom was saying to Gatsby—, but I am the first to have turned a garage into a stable.

en: “Who wants to go to town?” demanded Daisy insistently. Gatsby’s eyes floated toward her. “Ah,” she cried, “you look so cool.”
vi: "Does anyone want to go out to the street?" Daisy kept asking, not giving up on the idea. Gatsby's eyes lazily drifted towards Daisy. "Ah," Daisy shouted. "You look so cool,"
tr: “Who wants to go to the city?” Daisy was saying stubbornly. When Gatsby's gaze shifted that way, she continued, “You look very good.”
es: —Who wants to go to the city? —asked Daisy insistently. Gatsby's gaze flew towards her—. Ah —exclaimed Daisy—, it seems you're not hot.

en: Their eyes met, and they stared together at each other, alone in space. With an effort she glanced down at the table.
vi: Their eyes met and then they gazed at each other passionately as if in this space only the two of them existed. With an effort, Daisy averted her gaze and looked down at the table.
tr: Their eyes met and they looked at each other for a long time as if they were the only two in the universe. Then Daisy, with great effort, turned her eyes to the table.
es: Their eyes met and they looked at each other, alone in the space. With effort, Daisy lowered her gaze to the table.

en: “You always look so cool,” she repeated.
vi: "You look so cool." Daisy repeated.
tr: “You always look good anyway,” he repeated what he said.
es: —It seems like you're never hot —he repeated.

en: She had told him that she loved him, and Tom Buchanan saw. He was astounded. His mouth opened a little, and he looked at Gatsby, and then back at Daisy as if he had just recognized her as someone he knew a long time ago.
vi: Daisy's demeanor revealed to Gatsby that she loved him. Tom witnessed everything. He became stunned, mouth agape, looking from Gatsby to Daisy as if he had just realized she was someone he had known long ago.
tr: Tom Buchanan saw them just as she was saying she loved him. He was surprised, stunned! He opened his mouth and looked first at Gatsby, then once more at Daisy. It was as if he had seen someone he knew from long ago.
es: She had told him that she loved him, and Tom Buchanan saw it. He was astonished. His mouth fell open slightly, and he looked at Gatsby, and then at Daisy, as if he had just recognized an old friend.

en: “You resemble the advertisement of the man,” she went on innocently. “You know the advertisement of the man—”
vi: "You look like someone in an advertisement," Daisy continued to say unintentionally. "Do you know the advertisement of that guy....."
tr: “You look like the man in that advertisement,” Daisy continued innocently, “you know, the man who acts in those commercials.”
es: —You look like the man from the ad —Daisy continued innocently—. You know, the ad with the man…

en: “All right,” broke in Tom quickly, “I’m perfectly willing to go to town. Come on—we’re all going to town.”
vi: "Alright." Tom quickly interrupted. "I really want to go out to the street too. Let's go, all of us together."
tr: “Okay,” Tom suddenly interrupted, “I want to go to the city too. Let's all go together.”
es: —Very well —Tom interrupted her immediately—. I am willing to go to the city, of course. Come on, we are all going to the city.

en: He got up, his eyes still flashing between Gatsby and his wife. No one moved.
vi: Tom stood up, his eyes flashing as he looked back and forth between Gatsby and his wife. No one moved.
tr: He stood up. His gaze was still shifting between Daisy and Gatsby. No one had moved from their place.
es: He stood up, and his eyes flashed between Gatsby and his wife. Nobody moved.

en: “Come on!” His temper cracked a little. “What’s the matter, anyhow? If we’re going to town, let’s start.”
vi: "Let's go." Tom started to get angry. "What's going on here?" "If you want to go downtown, then let's go right away."
tr: “What is wrong with you!” he almost succumbed to his anger for a moment, “What is your problem? If we are going to the city, let's get going.”
es: —Come on! —he was starting to lose his patience—. What is it now? If we're going to the city, let's get moving!

en: His hand, trembling with his effort at self-control, bore to his lips the last of his glass of ale. Daisy’s voice got us to our feet and out on to the blazing gravel drive.
vi: Tom's hand, trembling with the effort of self-control, lifted the glass to his lips and drained the last drops of beer. Daisy's voice compelled us to stand up and walk out onto the gravel path under the blazing sun.
tr: With a trembling hand, caused by the effort to control his nerves, he brought the beer glass to his lips. Daisy's voice made all of us get up from our seats, and we stepped onto the sun-scorched gravel path.
es: The hand, trembling from the effort of self-control, brought the remnants of the beer glass to his lips. Daisy's voice forced us to get up and step out onto the incandescent gravel path.

en: “Are we just going to go?” she objected. “Like this? Aren’t we going to let anyone smoke a cigarette first?”

es: "Are we leaving already?" he objected. "Like this? Can't we at least smoke a cigarette first?"

es: —Whatever you say —said Daisy—. Let's go, Jordan.

en: They went upstairs to get ready while we three men stood there shuffling the hot pebbles with our feet. A silver curve of the moon hovered already in the western sky. Gatsby started to speak, changed his mind, but not before Tom wheeled and faced him expectantly.
vi: Two women went upstairs to change clothes while three men continued to stand there, shuffling the hot pebbles beneath their feet. A crescent silver moon hung suspended in the western sky. Gatsby intended to speak, then changed his mind, but Tom had already turned around and was looking directly at him with an expectant expression.
tr: While we three men stood there, kicking the warm pebbles with the tips of our shoes, they went upstairs to get ready. Already, the silver crescent of the moon had become visible in the west. Gatsby was about to say something but changed his mind and remained silent, yet Tom suddenly turned and saw him, becoming expectant.
es: They went up to get ready while the three of us men dragged our feet over the hot stones. The silver curve of the moon was already floating in the sky, to the west. Gatsby went to speak and changed his mind, but not before Tom turned to look at him, expectant.

en: “Have you got your stables here?” asked Gatsby with an effort.
vi: Gatsby reluctantly asked. "Is your stable here?"
tr: "Do you have a stable here as well?" Gatsby asked, forcing himself.

en: “About a quarter of a mile down the road.”

es: —About four hundred meters down the road.

en: “Oh.”
vi: "Is that so."
tr: "How beautiful!""
es: —Ah.

en: A pause.
vi: Silence.
tr: Silence.
es: Pause.

en: “I don’t see the idea of going to town,” broke out Tom savagely. “Women get these notions in their heads—”
vi: "I don't understand why we have to go downtown." Tom blurted out sharply. "Women always come up with silly things."
tr: "Why are we going to the city, I don't know," Tom suddenly said angrily, "Women always come up with such strange ideas."
es: —I don't understand the idea of going to the city —Tom burst out, fiercely—. Women have some crazy ideas…

en: “Shall we take anything to drink?” called Daisy from an upper window.
vi: "Should I bring something to drink?" Daisy called down from the window.

es: —I'm going to get whisky —replied Tom. He entered the house.

en: Gatsby turned to me rigidly:
vi: Gatsby turned to me with a stiff demeanor.
tr: Gatsby suddenly turned and looked at me.

en: “I can’t say anything in his house, old sport.”
vi: "In this house, I can't say anything, old friend"
tr: "I can't say anything while at that man's house, buddy."
es: —I can't speak in the husband's house, comrade.

en: “She’s got an indiscreet voice,” I remarked. “It’s full of—” I hesitated.
vi: "Daisy has a careless, imprudent voice." I remarked. "Daisy's voice is full of..." I hesitated.
tr: “That Daisy is a blabbermouth,” I said hesitantly, “In her voice...”
es: —Daisy has an indiscreet voice —I pointed out—. It's full of… —I hesitated.

en: “Her voice is full of money,” he said suddenly.
vi: "Her voice is full of money." Gatsby suddenly continued.
tr: “There is a sound of money clinking in your voice,” he suddenly completed my sentence.
es: —It's a voice full of money —said Gatsby suddenly.

en: That was it. I’d never understood before. It was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it… High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl…
vi: That's right. Yet before, I couldn't understand this. Daisy's voice truly carried the essence of money - It was a mesmerizing, undying melody, tinkling and melodious like the music of the song "... In the high, towering white palace, there was a golden princess, the king's daughter..."
tr: Yes, this was very true. I hadn't understood it before. There was the sound of money in her speech. The destructive allure that drew people in with its ups and downs came from this. From that jingle in her voice, that high-pitched melody reminiscent of a bell... She was a king's daughter living in an ivory palace. She was the golden girl!
es: That's how it was. I hadn't understood it until then. Full of money: that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in that voice, its jingling, its song of cymbals and bells… At the summit of a white palace, the king's daughter, the golden girl…

en: Tom came out of the house wrapping a quart bottle in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan wearing small tight hats of metallic cloth and carrying light capes over their arms.
vi: Tom stepped out of the house with a bottle of wine wrapped in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan, each wearing a small metallic fabric hat that fit snugly on their heads, and carrying two light cloaks on their arms.

es: Tom left the house with a bottle wrapped in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan, who had put on little hats made of a metallic fabric and were carrying light capes on their arms.

en: “Shall we all go in my car?” suggested Gatsby. He felt the hot, green leather of the seat. “I ought to have left it in the shade.”
vi: "Everyone ride in my car?" Gatsby suggested, touching the scorching green leather seat. "I should have parked in the shade."
tr: “Shall we all get into my car?” asked Gatsby, while touching the warmed, green leather seats. “I wish I had left it in the shade.”
es: —Shall we all go in my car? —suggested Gatsby. He felt the very hot green leather seat—. I should have left it in the shade.

tr: “Manual transmission?” said Tom.
es: —Is the gear shifting normal? —asked Tom.

en: “Yes.”
vi: "That's right."
tr: “Yes.”

tr: "You take my sports car, and I'll take yours."
es: —Then take my coupe and let me drive your car to the city.

vi: The suggestion made Gatsby uncomfortable, and he objected.

en: “I don’t think there’s much gas,” he objected.
vi: "I think my car doesn't have much gas left."

es: —I think it doesn't have enough gasoline.

en: “Plenty of gas,” said Tom boisterously. He looked at the gauge. “And if it runs out I can stop at a drugstore. You can buy anything at a drugstore nowadays.”
vi: "There's still plenty of gas." Tom said loudly and then looked at the fuel gauge. "If it runs out of gas, I can stop at some drugstore." "Nowadays, you can buy anything at drugstores."
tr: “He might not have much gas,” he tried to argue. "There's plenty of gas," said Tom, glancing at the gauge, "if it runs out, we'll get some from one of your pharmacies anyway. These days, everything is sold in pharmacies."
es: —There's plenty —said Tom, impetuously. He looked at the gauge—. And if it runs out, I can stop at a drugstore. These days you can buy anything at a drugstore.

en: A pause followed this apparently pointless remark. Daisy looked at Tom frowning, and an indefinable expression, at once definitely unfamiliar and vaguely recognizable, as if I had only heard it described in words, passed over Gatsby’s face.
vi: Everyone fell silent after this meaningless and out-of-place comment. Daisy looked at Tom with a frown, and on Gatsby's face there was a fleeting, indescribable expression, an expression that I was certain I had never seen before but also vaguely familiar, as if I had only heard it described in words.
tr: After this unnecessary information, there was a deep silence. Daisy frowned and looked at Tom. On Gatsby's face, there passed an indescribable expression that seemed both familiar and unrecognizable at the same time, as if I had only heard it described in words.
es: A silence followed this remark, seemingly without any ulterior motives. Daisy looked at Tom with furrowed brows, and an indefinable expression, at once irremediably strange and vaguely recognizable, as if I had only heard the words that described it, passed over Gatsby's face.

en: “Come on, Daisy,” said Tom, pressing her with his hand toward Gatsby’s car. “I’ll take you in this circus wagon.”
vi: "Go Daisy." Tom said, using his hand to push Daisy towards Gatsby's car. "I will take you home in this circus wagon."

es: —Let's go, Daisy —said Tom, pushing her towards Gatsby's car—. I'll take you in this circus wagon.

tr: "Take Nick and Jordan with you." "We'll follow behind in the small car."”

en: She walked close to Gatsby, touching his coat with her hand. Jordan and Tom and I got into the front seat of Gatsby’s car, Tom pushed the unfamiliar gears tentatively, and we shot off into the oppressive heat, leaving them out of sight behind.
vi: Daisy walked closer to Gatsby, gently placing her hand on Gatsby's coat. Jordan, Tom, and I stepped into the upper bench seat of Gatsby's car. Tom hesitantly reached out to pull the unfamiliar gear shift, and then we sped off into the stifling heat, leaving the other two behind.
tr: He approached Gatsby and touched his jacket. Jordan, Tom, and I settled into the front seat of Gatsby's car. Tom engaged an unfamiliar gear and we sped into the oppressive heat, leaving them far behind and out of sight.
es: He approached Gatsby and touched his jacket. Jordan, Tom, and I sat in Gatsby's car, all three of us in the front. Tom fumbled with the unfamiliar clutch and gear shift, and we shot off into the oppressive heat, losing sight of those left behind.

en: “Did you see that?” demanded Tom.
vi: "Did you see that?" Tom asked.
tr: "You saw it, didn't you?" said Tom.
es: —Have you noticed? —asked Tom.

en: “See what?”
vi: "See what?"
tr: “What did we see?”
es: —In what?

en: He looked at me keenly, realizing that Jordan and I must have known all along.
vi: Tom threw me a sharp look, suddenly realizing that both Jordan and I had certainly known everything for a long time.
tr: He turned and looked at my face sternly. At that moment, he realized that Jordan and I knew the situation.
es: He looked at me intently, realizing that Jordan and I knew everything.

en: “You think I’m pretty dumb, don’t you?” he suggested. “Perhaps I am, but I have a—almost a second sight, sometimes, that tells me what to do. Maybe you don’t believe that, but science—”
vi: "You all think I'm very stupid, don't you?" Tom asked. "Maybe I'm stupid, but I have something that sometimes acts almost like a second pair of eyes, it tells me what I should do. Maybe you all don't believe me, but science..."

es: —You think I'm an idiot, don't you? —he suggested—. Maybe I am, but I have... Sometimes I have a special instinct that tells me what I should do. You might not believe it, but science...

en: He paused. The immediate contingency overtook him, pulled him back from the edge of theoretical abyss.
vi: Tom stopped. The obviousness in front of him immediately took hold of him, pulling him away from the edge of the unrealistic abyss.
tr: He fell silent. The possibility that came to his mind had pulled him out from the depths of the scientific assumptions he had approached.
es: He fell silent. The immediate emergency situation imposed itself on him, pulling him away from the edge of the theoretical abyss.

en: “I’ve made a small investigation of this fellow,” he continued. “I could have gone deeper if I’d known—”
vi: "I did a little investigation on this guy." Tom continued. "I could have investigated more thoroughly if I had known..."
tr: "I did a little research on that sheriff," he continued, "If I had known the situation, I would have certainly deepened the research..."
es: —I did a little research on that guy —he continued—. And, if I had known, I would have delved deeper.

es: —Do you mean you've been to a medium? —Jordan asked jokingly.

vi: "What? A fortune teller? What for?"

es: —What? —he looked at us confused while we laughed—. A medium?

en: “About Gatsby.”
vi: Tom asked in bewilderment, staring at the two of us while we burst into laughter.

es: —To ask him about Gatsby.

vi: "To ask about Gatsby." "Ask the fortune teller about Gatsby! No, that's not it. I said that I had done a little investigation into his past."
tr: “For Gatsby? No, I didn't go. I just mean I did a little research on his past.”
es: —Gatsby! No, I haven't gone. I said that I did a little research on his past.

vi: "And he found out that he was from Oxford," Jordan suggested.
tr: “I suppose you learned that he went to Oxford,” said the helpful Jordan.
es: —And you discovered that he studied at Oxford —said Jordan, contributing.

vi: "Oxford people!" Tom said with a tone full of doubt. "Not even close." He was wearing a pink suit."

es: —And you discovered that he studied at Oxford —said Jordan, contributing. —Oxford! —he exclaimed, incredulous—. What nonsense! And he's wearing a pink suit!

en: “Nevertheless he’s an Oxford man.”
vi: "After all, he is still an Oxford alumnus." "There is an Oxford in the state of New Mexico."
tr: “Still, he read it.”
es: —But he has studied at Oxford.

en: “Oxford, New Mexico,” snorted Tom contemptuously, “or something like that.”
vi: Tom snorted derisively.
tr: "That's the Oxford in New Mexico," Tom grumbled, "Or something like that."
es: —In Oxford, New Mexico —Tom let out a snort of disdain—, or somewhere like that.

en: “Listen, Tom. If you’re such a snob, why did you invite him to lunch?” demanded Jordan crossly.
vi: "Or somewhere similar." "Listen here, Tom. If you're so arrogant and condescending, why did you invite him to lunch?" Jordan asked irritably. "Because Daisy invited him.
tr: "Alright, Tom. Why did you invite someone you look down on so much to dinner, then?" said Jordan, suddenly getting angry.
es: —Tell me, Tom. If you're such a snob, why did you invite him to lunch? —asked Jordan moodily.

en: “Daisy invited him; she knew him before we were married—God knows where!”
vi: She knew him before we got married. God knows where they met."
tr: “Daisy called. She knew him before they got married. God knows from where!”
es: —Daisy invited him: she knew him before we got married. God knows where!

en: We were all irritable now with the fading ale, and aware of it we drove for a while in silence. Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
vi: The alcohol in our bodies had dissipated, making all of us become easily irritable. Aware of this, we tried to keep silent as the car drove for a long while. When the faded eyes of ophthalmologist T. J. Eckleburg appeared at the end of the road, I suddenly remembered Gatsby's reminder about the gasoline.
tr: As the effects of the beers diminished, we were becoming more irritable. Moreover, we were aware of this. We continued on our way for a while without speaking. Doctor T. J. When the pale eyes of Eckleburg suddenly appeared at the beginning of the road, I remembered Gatsby saying that his gas was running low.
es: Now the three of us were irritable because the effects of the beer were wearing off and, realizing this, we traveled in silence for a while. When the faded eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg appeared at the end of the road, I remembered Gatsby's warning about the gasoline.

en: “We’ve got enough to get us to town,” said Tom.
vi: "We still have enough gas to get to town," Tom said.
tr: “He will take you to the city,” said Tom.

en: “But there’s a garage right here,” objected Jordan. “I don’t want to get stalled in this baking heat.”
vi: "But there's a repair shop right here." Jordan protested. "I don't want the car to break down in this scorching heat."
tr: "There is a repair shop over there," said Jordan, "I don't want to be stranded and roast in this heat."
es: —But there is a service station right there —objected Jordan—. I don't want to stay stuck in this oven.

en: Tom threw on both brakes impatiently, and we slid to an abrupt dusty stop under Wilson’s sign. After a moment the proprietor emerged from the interior of his establishment and gazed hollow-eyed at the car.
vi: Tom impatiently slammed both brakes, the car skidded to a dusty halt right under Wilson's sign. After a moment, the shop owner emerged, his deep-set eyes staring intently at the car.
tr: When Tom impatiently pressed both brakes, the car skidded and stopped near the dusty pit right under the sign that read Wilson's Place. A minute later, the shop owner came out from inside and squinted at the car.
es: Tom, impatient, used both brakes at once and we skidded to a dusty, barren corner under the sign that read Wilson. After a few seconds, the owner emerged from inside the garage and gave the car a blank stare.

en: “Let’s have some gas!” cried Tom roughly. “What do you think we stopped for—to admire the view?”
vi: "Fill up the gas and let's go." Tom said loudly in a rude manner. "What do you think we stopped the car here for? To enjoy the scenery here?"
tr: "Let's get some gas," Tom called out roughly, "Why do you think we stopped, for the scenery?"
es: —Gasoline! —Tom shouted, brutally—. What do you think we stopped for? To admire the scenery?

en: “I’m sick,” said Wilson without moving. “Been sick all day.”
vi: "I'm sick." Wilson said without moving. "I've been sick all day."
tr: "I am very sick," said Wilson without moving, "I have been sick all day."
es: —I am sick —said Wilson without moving—. I've been sick all day.

en: “What’s the matter?”
vi: "What's wrong?"
tr: "What's wrong?""
es: —What's wrong with him?

en: “I’m all run down.”
vi: "I have lost all my strength."
tr: "I am very exhausted.""
es: —I am exhausted.

en: “Well, shall I help myself?” Tom demanded. “You sounded well enough on the phone.”
vi: "So I have to do it myself?" Tom said. "You sounded very energetic on the phone earlier."
tr: “What, do you expect me to fill the tank myself?” asked Tom. “You didn't sound sick at all on the phone.”
es: —Well, shall I help myself? —asked Tom—. Over the phone, he seemed perfectly fine.

en: With an effort Wilson left the shade and support of the doorway and, breathing hard, unscrewed the cap of the tank. In the sunlight his face was green.
vi: Trying his best, Wilson stepped out of the shadow and the door he was leaning on, gasping heavily as he opened the fuel tank cap. Under the sunlight, his face looked pale.
tr: Wilson came from the shaded area at the doorway, struggling to breathe with great effort. As he opened the gas tank cap, I noticed that his face was completely green.
es: Wilson, with effort, left the shadow and support of the door and, breathing with difficulty, removed the cap from the tank. In the sunlight, his face was green.

en: “I didn’t mean to interrupt your lunch,” he said. “But I need money pretty bad, and I was wondering what you were going to do with your old car.”
vi: "I don't mean to disturb your lunch." Wilson said. "However, I am in urgent need of money and I don't know what you plan to do with your old car."
tr: "I didn't want to call in the middle of your meal, but I really need money. That's why I was trying to find out what you were going to do with your old car."
es: —It was not my intention to bother you during lunch —he said—. But I need money quickly and wanted to know what you plan to do with your old car.

en: “How do you like this one?” inquired Tom. “I bought it last week.”
vi: "Do you like this car?" Tom asked. "I just bought it last week."
tr: “How did you find this? I just got it last week.”
es: —Do you like this one? —asked Tom—. I bought it last week.

en: “It’s a nice yellow one,” said Wilson, as he strained at the handle.
vi: "This yellow car is very beautiful," Wilson said as he pulled the fuel lever.
tr: "Beautiful." "The fact that it's yellow is also nice," said the man, while trying to fill up the gas.
es: —It's great, yellow —said Wilson, as he busied himself with the pump handle.

en: “Like to buy it?”
vi: "Do you want to buy it?"
tr: “Do you want to take it then?”
es: —Do you want to buy it?

en: “Big chance,” Wilson smiled faintly. “No, but I could make some money on the other.”
vi: "It's very unlikely." Wilson smiled weakly. "But I could make a little profit if I manage to buy that one."
tr: “It would be nice,” he said, trying to smile, “but I don't want it. Maybe I can make a little profit from the other one.”
es: —It's too much —Wilson smiled weakly—. No, but I could get some money out of the other one.

en: “What do you want money for, all of a sudden?”
vi: "Why do you suddenly need money like that?"
tr: “Why do you suddenly need money?”
es: —And why do you need money so urgently?

en: “I’ve been here too long. I want to get away. My wife and I want to go West.”
vi: "I have been here for quite a long time. I want to move somewhere else. My wife and I want to move to the West."
tr: “I have been here for a very long time. I want to go far away now. My wife and I both want to go West.”
es: —I've been here too long. I want to leave. My wife and I want to go to the West.

en: “Your wife does,” exclaimed Tom, startled.
vi: "Your wife wants to move out?" Tom was astonished.
tr: “Your wife?” Tom shouted in astonishment.
es: —His wife wants to leave —exclaimed Tom, very surprised.

en: “She’s been talking about it for ten years.” He rested for a moment against the pump, shading his eyes. “And now she’s going whether she wants to or not. I’m going to get her away.”
vi: "She has been talking about this for ten years." Wilson stood leaning against the gas pump to rest for a moment, shading his eyes from the sun. "Now, whether she wants to or not, she has to go. I will drag her away."
tr: “He has been talking about this for ten years,” he said, shielding his eyes with his hand as he leaned against the gas pump, “now, whether he wants to or not, we will go. I will take him away from here.”
es: —He has been talking about that for ten years —he leaned on the pump for a moment, shielding his eyes from the sun—. And now he is going to leave whether he wants to or not. I'm planning to take her with me.

en: The coupé flashed by us with a flurry of dust and the flash of a waving hand.
vi: The cup motorbike sped past us, kicking up a cloud of dust and a fleeting wave of a hand.
tr: Tom's sports car passed by us leaving a cloud of dust, and the people inside did not forget to wave.
es: The coupe sped past us with a whirlwind of dust and the glint of a waving hand.

en: “What do I owe you?” demanded Tom harshly.
vi: "How much money is this?" Tom asked hurriedly.
tr: “How much is my debt?” Tom asked in a harsh voice.
es: —How much do I owe you? —asked Tom in an unpleasant voice.

en: “I just got wised up to something funny the last two days,” remarked Wilson. “That’s why I want to get away. That’s why I been bothering you about the car.”
vi: "Just two days ago, I discovered something suspicious," Wilson recounted. "That's why I want to move out." "That's why I bothered you about the car."
tr: “I realized about two days ago that strange things were happening behind my back,” said the man, “That's why I want to get away from here. I wanted to know from him what you would do with your old car.”
es: —I have noticed something strange these past few days —pointed out Wilson—. That's why I want to leave. And that's why I bothered you about the car.

en: “What do I owe you?”
vi: "How much money is this?"
tr: “How much do I owe you?”
es: —How much do I owe you?

en: “Dollar twenty.”
vi: "One dong two."
tr: “One dollar, twenty cents.”
es: —One dollar twenty.

en: The relentless beating heat was beginning to confuse me and I had a bad moment there before I realized that so far his suspicions hadn’t alighted on Tom. He had discovered that Myrtle had some sort of life apart from him in another world, and the shock had made him physically sick. I stared at him and then at Tom, who had made a parallel discovery less than an hour before—and it occurred to me that there was no difference between men, in intelligence or race, so profound as the difference between the sick and the well. Wilson was so sick that he looked guilty, unforgivably guilty—as if he had just got some poor girl with child.
vi: The oppressive heat made my mind numb, and I felt uncomfortable for a while until I suddenly realized that Wilson's suspicion was not directed at Tom. Wilson had discovered that Myrtle's life had somewhat diverged from his own, leading her into another world. This shock had made him sick and exhausted. I looked at Wilson and then turned to look at Tom. Like Wilson, Tom had only just discovered the same thing an hour ago. This made me think that there is no intellectual or racial difference between people, unlike the clear difference between the sick and the healthy. Wilson was so sick that he looked as if he were bearing an unforgivable sin, a sin like having made some poor girl pregnant.
tr: The relentless heatwave must have clouded my mind. Because while the man was talking, a constant fear gripped me until I realized he wasn't suspicious of Tom. He had understood that Myrtle had a completely different life in a completely different world, and he had fallen ill from the shock of learning this. I looked first at him, then at Tom, who had experienced a similar event about an hour earlier. Suddenly, it occurred to me that apart from illness and health, there was no difference between men in terms of intelligence or race. Wilson was so sick that he acted as if he had committed an unforgivable crime. It was as if he had seduced a young girl and gotten her pregnant.
es: The relentless heat began to daze me, and I felt unwell for a few seconds until I realized that Wilson did not suspect Tom. He had discovered that Myrtle was leading some kind of life outside of their marriage, in another world, and the shock had made him physically ill. I looked at Wilson and then at Tom, who had made a parallel discovery an hour earlier, and it occurred to me that there is no difference between men, neither in intelligence nor in race, as profound as the difference between the sick and the healthy. Wilson was so sick that he seemed guilty, unforgivably guilty, as if he had just gotten a poor girl pregnant.

en: “I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom. “I’ll send it over tomorrow afternoon.”
vi: "I will sell you that car," Tom said. "I will have someone deliver it to you tomorrow afternoon."
tr: “I will give you the car,” said Tom, “I will send it tomorrow.”
es: —I will sell him the car —said Tom—. I will send it to him tomorrow afternoon.

en: That locality was always vaguely disquieting, even in the broad glare of afternoon, and now I turned my head as though I had been warned of something behind. Over the ash-heaps the giant eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg kept their vigil, but I perceived, after a moment, that other eyes were regarding us with peculiar intensity from less than twenty feet away.
vi: This place always seems to give people a vague feeling of anxiety and worry, even though it is in the middle of a bright sunny afternoon. I turned my head back, sensing as if something was happening behind me. On the other side of the ash heaps, the giant eyes of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg were watchfully guarding. However, after a moment, I noticed that about twenty meters away from us, another pair of eyes was staring at us unusually intently.
tr: The place we were in, even at noon, in daylight, was chilling and unsettling. Feeling as if there was something behind me, I turned and looked back. Doctor T. J. Eckleburg's eyes were, of course, always upon us. But it was certain that another pair of eyes a few meters away was also watching us closely.
es: That place always had something unsettling, even in the clear light of the afternoon, and I turned my head as if I had been warned that something was lurking behind me. Over the heaps of ash, the gigantic eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg remained vigilant, but after a moment, I realized that other eyes were watching us with special intensity from less than six meters away.

en: In one of the windows over the garage the curtains had been moved aside a little, and Myrtle Wilson was peering down at the car. So engrossed was she that she had no consciousness of being observed, and one emotion after another crept into her face like objects into a slowly developing picture. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was an expression I had often seen on women’s faces, but on Myrtle Wilson’s face it seemed purposeless and inexplicable until I realized that her eyes, wide with jealous terror, were fixed not on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom she took to be his wife.
vi: In one of the upstairs windows of the garage, the curtain was slightly drawn back, and Myrtle Wilson was peeking down at the car. She was so engrossed in looking that she didn't realize she was being watched. Various emotions flitted across her face like a photograph slowly developing. Myrtle's expression bore a familiar curiosity, the kind I often saw on the faces of women. But in Myrtle, that look seemed undefined and inexplicable, until I realized that her eyes, wide with a horrified jealousy, were not fixed on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom Myrtle mistakenly thought was Tom's wife.
tr: The curtain of one of the windows on the upper floor of the garage was slightly parted. Myrtle Wilson was standing by the window, examining the car. She was so engrossed that she didn't even notice someone was watching her. Her face was taking on a series of changing expressions, passing through various phases like a developing photograph. These were not unfamiliar to me at all. It was an expression often seen on women's faces. While pondering what kind of explanation there could be, I suddenly realized that her eyes, radiating fear, horror, and jealousy, were fixed not on Tom but on Jordan, whom she mistook for his wife.
es: In one of the windows on the upper floor of the garage, the curtains had moved, parting slightly, and Myrtle Wilson was looking towards the car. She was so absorbed that she was unaware she was being watched, and one emotion after another appeared on her face like objects in a photo that slowly develops. Her expression was curiously familiar: it was an expression I had seen many times on women's faces, but on Myrtle's face, it seemed gratuitous and inexplicable until I discovered that her eyes, wide open with the terror of jealousy, were not fixed on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom she had mistaken for his wife.

en: There is no confusion like the confusion of a simple mind, and as we drove away Tom was feeling the hot whips of panic. His wife and his mistress, until an hour ago secure and inviolate, were slipping precipitately from his control. Instinct made him step on the accelerator with the double purpose of overtaking Daisy and leaving Wilson behind, and we sped along toward Astoria at fifty miles an hour, until, among the spidery girders of the elevated, we came in sight of the easygoing blue coupé.
vi: There is no confusion that can compare to the confusion of a shallow person. As we drove away from that place, Tom felt as if he were being lashed by the scorching whips of panic. An hour ago, both his wife and his lover were securely and inviolably his. Now, both of them were quickly slipping out of his control. Instinctively, Tom pressed hard on the accelerator pedal with two purposes: to catch up with Daisy and to leave Wilson behind. And so our car sped at fifty-five miles per hour towards Astoria, until the web-like girders of the bridge loomed overhead and the silhouette of the blue car leisurely driving on the road appeared.
tr: There is nothing as disturbing as a mind that is quite confused. When we set off again, Tom was writhing in the grip of worries, suffering as if he were being whipped. Within an hour, the two women in his grasp, both his wife and his mistress, had flown away at the same time. As his instincts told him to catch up with Daisy and get away from Wilson, he pressed the gas pedal harder. While driving towards Astoria at a speed of one hundred kilometers per hour, we first saw the spider-web-like girders of the railway bridge, and then the slow-moving blue sports car.
es: There is no confusion like the confusion of a simple mind, and as we drove away, Tom felt the lashes of panic. His wife and his lover, secure and unblemished until an hour ago, were precipitously escaping his control. Instinct drove him to press the accelerator with the dual purpose of overtaking Daisy and leaving Wilson behind, and we sped towards Astoria at eighty kilometers per hour until, between the spider-leg-like pillars of the elevated train, we saw the blue coupe leisurely driving along.

en: “Those big movies around Fiftieth Street are cool,” suggested Jordan. “I love New York on summer afternoons when everyone’s away. There’s something very sensuous about it—overripe, as if all sorts of funny fruits were going to fall into your hands.”
vi: "The big movie theaters around Fifty Street are really cool." Jordan suggested. "I like New York in the summer afternoons when everyone has left. There is something very sensual, ripe about it, like all kinds of exotic fruits falling into your hands."
tr: "50. Jordan threw out an idea, saying, "The movie theaters on the Avenue are very cool. I love the afternoons of summer days. Everyone has scattered somewhere, and New York becomes empty. This feels very erotic to me. I feel as if all kinds of ripe, fun fruits are about to fall into my hands."
es: —The big theaters on Fifty Street are air-conditioned —suggested Jordan—. I love New York in the summer afternoons when there's no one around. They have something very sensual, like ripe fruit, as if all kinds of exotic fruits were about to fall into our hands.

en: The word “sensuous” had the effect of further disquieting Tom, but before he could invent a protest the coupé came to a stop, and Daisy signalled us to draw up alongside.
vi: The word sensuality made Tom even more restless, but before he could think of something to refute it, the scooter had already stopped, and Daisy signaled for us to move closer to the side.
tr: The word 'Erotic' had completely unsettled Tom. Just as he was about to object, those in front of us stopped. Daisy signaled us to pull over.
es: The word "sensual" had the effect of unsettling Tom even more, but before he could come up with a protest, the coupe stopped, and Daisy signaled us to stop beside her.

en: “Where are we going?” she cried.
vi: "Where are we going?" Daisy shouted.
tr: “Where are we going?” he shouted.
es: —Where are we going? —he shouted.

en: “How about the movies?”
vi: "How about going to the movies?"
tr: “What do you say to the movies?”
es: —Shall we go into a movie theater?

en: “It’s so hot,” she complained. “You go. We’ll ride around and meet you after.” With an effort her wit rose faintly. “We’ll meet you on some corner. I’ll be the man smoking two cigarettes.”
vi: "It's very hot." Daisy complained. "You all go ahead. The two of us will run around and meet everyone later." Daisy tried to sound humorously dull. "We'll meet everyone at some street corner. I'll pretend to be the man smoking two cigarettes."
tr: “It's very hot,” he complained, “You go ahead, we'll drive around a bit, then meet you at a corner.” He forced himself to speak wittily, “We'll pull over to the side, for example, and I'll play the role of a man smoking two cigarettes at the same time.”
es: —It's too hot —complained Daisy—. You all go ahead. We'll take a walk and then we'll see you —with an effort, her wit lifted slightly—. We'll meet at any corner. I'll be the man smoking two cigarettes.

en: “We can’t argue about it here,” Tom said impatiently, as a truck gave out a cursing whistle behind us. “You follow me to the south side of Central Park, in front of the Plaza.”
vi: "We can't argue here." Tom said impatiently as a truck behind us honked angrily. "You two follow me to the south side of Central Park, right in front of the Plaza Hotel."
tr: "Let's not discuss these here," said Tom impatiently. The truck driver waiting behind us was honking as if he were swearing. “Do not leave my side until we reach the south exit of Central Park, let's stop and talk in front of the Plaza.”
es: —We can't talk about it here —said Tom impatiently, and at that moment, behind us, a truck honked angrily—. Follow me to the south side of Central Park, in front of the Plaza.

en: Several times he turned his head and looked back for their car, and if the traffic delayed them he slowed up until they came into sight. I think he was afraid they would dart down a side-street and out of his life forever.
vi: Every now and then, Tom would turn his head to look at their car following behind, and if the traffic caused their car to fall behind, he would slow down until their car came back into view. I think Tom was afraid they would take another road and disappear from his life forever.
tr: While on the road, he looked back several times to check if they were coming. When they were delayed by traffic, he slowed down and waited. Perhaps he was afraid they would suddenly turn onto one of the side streets and disappear from his life.
es: Several times Tom turned to look at his car, and when the traffic forced them to fall behind, he slowed down until he could see them again. I think he feared they would take a side street and disappear from his life forever.

en: But they didn’t. And we all took the less explicable step of engaging the parlour of a suite in the Plaza Hotel.
vi: However, they did not do so, and then we all made a decision that required less explanation: renting a large room with many compartments in the Plaza Hotel.
tr: But they didn't do it. And taking a step that is hard to explain, we decided to book a suite at the Plaza Hotel.
es: But they didn't do it. And we all ended up taking a much less explainable step: we rented the lounge of a suite at the Plaza Hotel.

en: The prolonged and tumultuous argument that ended by herding us into that room eludes me, though I have a sharp physical memory that, in the course of it, my underwear kept climbing like a damp snake around my legs and intermittent beads of sweat raced cool across my back. The notion originated with Daisy’s suggestion that we hire five bathrooms and take cold baths, and then assumed more tangible form as “a place to have a mint julep.” Each of us said over and over that it was a “crazy idea”—we all talked at once to a baffled clerk and thought, or pretended to think, that we were being very funny…
vi: I no longer remember anything about the long and noisy debate that finally ended with us being herded into that room. However, I still vividly remember that in that situation, my underwear felt like a wet snake crawling around my legs and the cool sweat beads rolling down my back. First, Daisy suggested renting a room with five bathrooms so we could cool off with a bath. Then the suggestion was changed to a more practical one: "a place to drink mint juleps." Each of us repeatedly said that it was a crazy idea. We all simultaneously told the confused hotel staff and then assumed, or pretended to think, that we were all being humorous.
tr: What remained in my mind from that long and stormy argument, which resulted in all of us being confined to a room, were some physical events such as my underwear wrapping around my legs like a wet snake and the sweat droplets slowly trickling down my back. In fact, Daisy initially suggested renting a room with five bathrooms and taking a cold shower, then the idea developed a bit more and became more reasonable, progressing towards finding a place to drink an 'Iced Mint Liqueur Cocktail.' We kept saying in unison that it was a 'crazy idea,' explaining something to the bewildered receptionist all at once, thinking we were in funny situations, or pretending to think so.
es: I have forgotten the long and tumultuous discussion that ended up bringing us together in that room, although I retain a physical and clear memory that, during the course of the debate, my underwear kept insisting on climbing up my legs like a snake and that cold drops of sweat intermittently ran down my back. The idea was born from Daisy's suggestion that we rent five bathrooms and take cold baths, and then it took the more tangible form of "finding a place to drink a mint julep." We all repeated and repeated that it was "nonsense," and we all talked at the same time to a perplexed concierge and thought, or pretended to think, that we were very funny...

en: The room was large and stifling, and, though it was already four o’clock, opening the windows admitted only a gust of hot shrubbery from the Park. Daisy went to the mirror and stood with her back to us, fixing her hair.
vi: The room was very spacious but suffocatingly stuffy. Although it was already four in the afternoon, even with the windows wide open, only a hot breeze from the scorching park trees could be felt. Daisy stepped towards the mirror to fix her hair, her back turned towards us,
tr: The room was spacious but stifling. Even though it was four o'clock, opening the windows hadn't helped; on the contrary, the heat rising from the trees in the park had filled the room. Daisy stood in front of the mirror and began to fix her hair.
es: In the room, which was very spacious, it was unbearably hot and, although it was already four o'clock, when the windows were opened, barely a warm breeze from the park's trees came in. Daisy approached the mirror and, with her back to us, fixed her hair.

en: “It’s a swell suite,” whispered Jordan respectfully, and everyone laughed.
vi: "This room is really luxurious." Jordan whispered respectfully and then we all burst out laughing.
tr: “A magnificent suite,” said Jordan respectfully. Upon this, we all burst into laughter.
es: —It's a very chic suite —Jordan murmured very seriously, and we all laughed.

en: “Open another window,” commanded Daisy, without turning around.
vi: "Open another window." Daisy said, not turning around.
tr: "Open another window," Daisy said without looking back.
es: —Open another window —ordered Daisy, without turning around.

en: “There aren’t any more.”
vi: "There isn't any left to open"
tr: "There is no other window."
es: —There is no more.

en: “Well, we’d better telephone for an axe—”
vi: "In that case, I have to call to have them bring up the axe."
tr: “Then let's ask for an axe...”
es: —Very well, then we will order an axe by phone.

en: “The thing to do is to forget about the heat,” said Tom impatiently. “You make it ten times worse by crabbing about it.”
vi: "It's better to forget about the heat." Tom said impatiently. "You make it ten times worse by complaining like that."
tr: "The best thing is to get the heat out of our heads," said Tom, who was impatient again, "The more you talk like this, the worse it gets."
es: —What you need to do is forget about the heat —said Tom impatiently—. You multiply it by ten by complaining.

en: He unrolled the bottle of whisky from the towel and put it on the table.
vi: Tom unwrapped the bottle of wine and placed it on the table.
tr: He unwrapped the whiskey from the towel and placed the bottle on the table.
es: He unwrapped the bottle of whisky from the towel and placed it on the table.

en: “Why not let her alone, old sport?” remarked Gatsby. “You’re the one that wanted to come to town.”
vi: "Why don't you leave her alone, old sport?" Gatsby criticized. "You're the one who wanted to go to town."
tr: “Why don't you leave the girl alone, buddy,” said Gatsby, “you were the one who wanted to come to the city.”
es: —Why don't you leave Daisy alone, buddy? You are the one who wanted to come to the city.

en: There was a moment of silence. The telephone book slipped from its nail and splashed to the floor, whereupon Jordan whispered, “Excuse me”—but this time no one laughed.
vi: A moment passed in silence. The phone directory book slipped off the nail and fell heavily to the floor. Jordan whispered. "Sorry." But this time, no one laughed.
tr: Suddenly, silence fell over the room. At that moment, when the thick phone directory hanging on a nail on the wall came loose and fell, Jordan slowly said "Sorry" again. This time, no one laughed.
es: There was a moment of silence. The phone book came off the nail and crashed to the floor, and Jordan murmured "Forgive me," but this time no one laughed.

en: “I’ll pick it up,” I offered.
vi: "Let me pick it up for you." I said.
tr: "I'll lift it," I said.
es: —I'm going to get it —I offered.

en: “I’ve got it.” Gatsby examined the parted string, muttered “Hum!” in an interested way, and tossed the book on a chair.
vi: "I picked it up already." Gatsby said, examining the broken string with a focused look, muttering "Hmm" and then throwing the book onto a chair.
tr: "I'll lift it," I said. "I already bought it," said Gatsby. He examined the thinned rope, said "Hmm" with a knowledgeable attitude, and tossed the guide onto one of the chairs.
es: —I've got it now —Gatsby examined the broken string, let out an interrogative "Hmm" and placed it on a chair.

en: “That’s a great expression of yours, isn’t it?” said Tom sharply.
vi: "Isn't that the way you like to talk the most?" Tom said abruptly.
tr: “I’ve heard this way of addressing most often from you!” said Tom in a harsh voice.
es: —That's one of his great expressions, isn't it? —said Tom, sharply.

en: “What is?”
vi: "What?"
tr: “Which one?”
es: —Which one?

en: “All this ‘old sport’ business. Where’d you pick that up?”
vi: "Those words 'old buddy'. Where did you pick them up from here?"
tr: “That word 'buddy.' Where did it stick to your tongue from?”
es: —That "comrade" thing. Where did you get it from?

en: “Now see here, Tom,” said Daisy, turning around from the mirror, “if you’re going to make personal remarks I won’t stay here a minute. Call up and order some ice for the mint julep.”
vi: "Come on, Tom." Daisy said, turning away from the mirror. "If If you continue to make such personal jabs, I won't stay here for another minute. Call someone to bring up some ice for the drinks."
tr: "Know this well, Tom," said Daisy, turning her back to the mirror, "if you're going to keep dealing with personal conflicts, I won't stay here for even a minute. Call reception and ask for some ice for the liquors."
es: —Pay attention to me, Tom —said Daisy, stopping looking at herself in the mirror—, if you're going to make personal remarks, I won't stay here for even a minute. Call and ask for ice for the mint julep.

en: As Tom took up the receiver the compressed heat exploded into sound and we were listening to the portentous chords of Mendelssohn’s Wedding March from the ballroom below.
vi: When Tom picked up the phone, the pent-up heat exploded into sound. We could hear the prelude of Mendelssohn's wedding march drifting from the ballroom downstairs.
tr: Just as Tom was about to lift the receiver, the stifling heat was joined by voices. We all began to listen to the familiar melody of Mendelssohn's Wedding March rising from the ballroom downstairs.
es: When Tom picked up the receiver, the compressed heat burst into sounds, and we heard the mighty chords of Mendelssohn's Wedding March coming from downstairs, from the ballroom.

en: “Imagine marrying anybody in this heat!” cried Jordan dismally.
vi: "Just imagine having to get married in this kind of heat." Jordan said loudly in a dejected manner.
tr: "Imagine getting married in this heat," said Jordan with a sorrowful tone.
es: —Imagine getting married in this heat —said Jordan in a somber tone.

en: “Still—I was married in the middle of June,” Daisy remembered. “Louisville in June! Somebody fainted. Who was it fainted, Tom?”
vi: "It's okay. I got married in the middle of June." Daisy recalled. "Oh dear, Louisville in June. Someone fainted. Who fainted, Tom?"
tr: “I also… got married in mid-June,” Daisy remembered, “June in Louisville! Can you imagine? Someone had fainted. Who was it that fainted, Tom?”
es: —Hush, I got married in the middle of June —recalled Daisy—. Louisville in June! Someone fainted. Who fainted, Tom?

en: “Biloxi,” he answered shortly.
vi: "Biloxi." Tom answered briefly.
tr: “Biloxi!” said Tom briefly.
es: —Biloxi —he responded, curtly.

en: “A man named Biloxi. ‘Blocks’ Biloxi, and he made boxes—that’s a fact—and he was from Biloxi, Tennessee.”
vi: "A guy named Biloxi. The guy 'blocks' Biloxi and he makes barrels. It's true, he comes from Biloxi, Tennessee."
tr: “Yes, the man called Biloxi. ‘blocker’ Biloxi. He was a box manufacturer –that’s absolutely true- and he was from the village of Biloxi in Tennessee.”
