es: —One who was called Biloxi, "Blocks" Biloxi, a box manufacturer (this is authentic), and he was from Biloxi, in Tennessee.

en: “They carried him into my house,” appended Jordan, “because we lived just two doors from the church. And he stayed three weeks, until Daddy told him he had to get out. The day after he left Daddy died.” After a moment she added as if she might have sounded irreverent, “There wasn’t any connection.”
vi: "They carried him to your house." Jordan continued. "Because your house is only two doors away from the church." He stayed at your house for three weeks, until your father had to kick him out. One day after he left, your father passed away." After a moment, Jordan added. "The two events are unrelated."
tr: “They had moved him to our house,” Jordan added, “the house was very close to the church. There were only two buildings in between. The man stayed with us for three weeks. In the end, my father had to tell him that he needed to leave. One day after he left, my father died.” He paused for a moment. “There was no connection, of course.”
es: —They took him to my house —said Jordan— because we lived two steps away from the church. And he stayed for three weeks, until my father told him to leave. The next day my father died —after a few seconds he added—. There is no relation between the two events.

en: “I used to know a Bill Biloxi from Memphis,” I remarked.
vi: Previously, I knew a person named Bill Biloxi in Memphis," I remarked.
tr: "I also know someone named Bill Biloxi from Memphis," I said.
es: —I knew a certain Bill Biloxi, from Memphis —I pointed out.

en: “That was his cousin. I knew his whole family history before he left. He gave me an aluminium putter that I use today.”
vi: "That guy is a cousin. I know the history of his entire family before he left. He gave me an aluminum golf club that I still use to this day."
tr: “He must be our cousin from Biloxi. Before the man left, I had learned his entire family's life story. I still use the aluminum golf club he gave me back then.” said Jordan.
es: —He was her cousin. He told me the whole family history before leaving. He gave me an aluminum putter that I still use.

en: The music had died down as the ceremony began and now a long cheer floated in at the window, followed by intermittent cries of “Yea—ea—ea!” and finally by a burst of jazz as the dancing began.
vi: The music had quieted down as the wedding ceremony began, the cheers of congratulations floated in through the windows, followed by intermittent shouts of "Yea-ea-ea", and finally burst into jazz music as the dance began.
tr: When the wedding ceremony began, the music downstairs stopped. A little later, long-lasting applause sounds filled the room through the window. Occasionally. 'Yes. Yeees!' shouts were heard, and suddenly a jazz song bursting out was also a sign that the dance was about to begin.
es: The music had died down when the ceremony began, and at that moment a long ovation reached us through the window, followed by intermittent shouts of "Yes, Yes, Yes," and finally, an explosion of jazz that marked the beginning of the dance.

en: “We’re getting old,” said Daisy. “If we were young we’d rise and dance.”
vi: "We have become old. If we were still young, we would have stood up and danced right away," Daisy said.
tr: “We're getting old,” said Daisy. “If we were young, we would immediately get up and dance.”
es: —We are getting old —said Daisy—. If we were young, we would get up and start dancing.

en: “Remember Biloxi,” Jordan warned her. “Where’d you know him, Tom?”
vi: "Remember the example of that Biloxi guy." Jordan advised Daisy. "Where did you meet him, Tom?"
tr: "Think about Biloxi!" Jordan warned. "How did you know him, Tom?"
es: —Remember Biloxi —Jordan warned her—. Where did you meet him, Tom?

en: “Biloxi?” He concentrated with an effort. “I didn’t know him. He was a friend of Daisy’s.”
vi: "Biloxi?" Tom tried to recall. "I don't know him." "He is a friend of Daisy's."
tr: “Biloxi?” he was trying to remember, “I didn't know him. He was a friend of Daisy's.”
es: —Biloxi? —he made an effort to concentrate—. I didn't know him. He was a friend of Daisy's.

en: “He was not,” she denied. “I’d never seen him before. He came down in the private car.”
vi: "He is not my friend," Daisy retorted. "I have never met him before. He came in his own car."
tr: “No, it wasn't,” Daisy objected. “I saw him there for the first time. He had already come in his own car.”
es: —No —said Daisy—. I had never seen him in my life. He arrived in one of the rented carriages.

en: “Well, he said he knew you. He said he was raised in Louisville. Asa Bird brought him around at the last minute and asked if we had room for him.”
vi: "Really, he said he knows you. He said he grew up in Louisville. Asa Bird showed him around and at the last minute asked if we had a place for him to stay."
tr: "Anyway. The man said he knew you. He grew up in Louisville. Asa Bird brought him at the last minute and asked if we had any extra space."
es: —Well, he said he knew you. He said he had grown up in Louisville. Asa Bird brought him to us at the last minute and asked if we had room for him.

en: Jordan smiled.
vi: Jordan smiled.
tr: “He was probably someone trying to hitchhike home.
es: Jordan smiled.

en: “He was probably bumming his way home. He told me he was president of your class at Yale.”
vi: "Perhaps he is trying to find his way back home." "He told me that he was your class president at Yale."
tr: “He was probably someone trying to hitchhike home. He told me he was your class representative at Yale,” said Jordan with a smile.
es: —He probably wanted to hitch a ride home. He told me he was the president of your class at Yale.

en: Tom and I looked at each other blankly.
vi: "He told me that he was your class president at Yale."
tr: Tom and I exchanged bewildered glances.
es: Tom and I looked at each other without understanding.

en: “Biloxi?”
vi: "Biloxi?" "Biloxi?"
tr: “Biloxi?”
es: —Biloxi?

en: “First place, we didn’t have any president—”
vi: Both Tom and I looked at each other in confusion. "First of all, we don't have a class monitor at all.."
tr: “But we don't have a class representative...”
es: —First of all, we didn't have a president.

en: Gatsby’s foot beat a short, restless tattoo and Tom eyed him suddenly.
vi: Gatsby nervously tapped his foot repeatedly in short rhythms, and Tom suddenly turned his eyes towards him.
tr: Upon Gatsby impatiently starting to tap his foot, Tom suddenly turned to him.
es: Gatsby's foot was tapping rhythmically on the floor, nervously, and Tom suddenly looked at him.

en: “By the way, Mr. Gatsby, I understand you’re an Oxford man.”
vi: "By the way, may I ask, Mr. Gatsby, I heard that you are a former Oxford student."
tr: "By the way, Mr. Gatsby, I heard you went to Oxford," he said.
es: —By the way, Mr. Gatsby, I understand that you are a former Oxford student.

en: “Not exactly.”
vi: "It's not exactly like that."
tr: “Not exactly like that.”
es: —Not exactly.

en: “Oh, yes, I understand you went to Oxford.”
vi: "It's true, I heard that you studied at Oxford."
tr: “Still, you went to Oxford.”
es: —Yes, I understand that he went to Oxford.

en: “Yes—I went there.”
vi: "Yes, I studied there."
tr: “Yes, that's true.”
es: —Yes, I went to Oxford.

en: A pause. Then Tom’s voice, incredulous and insulting:
vi: The atmosphere fell into silence. Then Tom's voice rose, full of suspicion and insult.
tr: Silence. Then Tom, with a voice full of doubt and disdain, said, "I suppose you were at Oxford while Biloxi was at Yale."
es: Pause. And then Tom's voice, incredulous and insulting.

en: “You must have gone there about the time Biloxi went to New Haven.”
vi: "You must have been there at the same time Biloxi was attending school in New Haven."
tr: Then Tom, with a voice full of doubt and disdain, said, "I suppose you were at Oxford while Biloxi was at Yale."
es: —It must have been around the same time that Biloxi went to New Haven.

en: Another pause. A waiter knocked and came in with crushed mint and ice but the silence was unbroken by his “thank you” and the soft closing of the door. This tremendous detail was to be cleared up at last.
vi: Following those words was silence again. The waiter knocked on the door and brought in mint and ice, but his thank you and the soft closing of the door couldn't break the silence in the room. This terrible detail had finally come to light.
tr: Again, silence. The waiter who came for room service entered with mint liqueur, soda, and crushed ice in hand. But neither his saying 'thank you' nor his slowly closing the door behind him as he left broke the silence. This tremendous detail finally needed to be clarified.
es: Another pause. A waiter knocked on the door with mint and crushed ice, but neither his "thank you" nor the door closing softly broke the silence. That extraordinary detail was finally going to be clarified.

en: “I told you I went there,” said Gatsby.
vi: "I told you I had studied there." Gatsby said.
tr: "I told you I went there," said Gatsby.
es: —I already told you that I was in Oxford.

en: “I heard you, but I’d like to know when.”
vi: "I have heard you speak, but I want to know during what time period."
tr: “I heard you. I want to know the time.”
es: —I have heard it, but I would like to know when.

en: “It was in nineteen-nineteen, I only stayed five months. That’s why I can’t really call myself an Oxford man.”
vi: "I went to school there in nineteen nineteen. I only studied there for five months. That's why I can't really call myself an Oxford alumnus."
tr: "In 1919." "I stayed there for only five months." "Therefore, I do not consider myself a true Oxfordian."
es: —It was in 1919. I was only there for five months. That's why I can't consider myself an alumnus of Oxford.

en: Tom glanced around to see if we mirrored his unbelief. But we were all looking at Gatsby.
vi: Tom glanced around to see if we were as astonished as he was. But at that moment, all of us were looking at Gatsby.
tr: Tom looked around to see if he could spot himself. We, on the other hand, were looking at Gatsby.
es: Tom glanced around to see if, like a mirror, we reflected his disbelief. But we were looking at Gatsby.

en: “It was an opportunity they gave to some of the officers after the armistice,” he continued. “We could go to any of the universities in England or France.”
vi: "That was the opportunity that the government granted to officers after the Armistice." Gatsby continued. "We could attend any university in England or France."
tr: "After the ceasefire, some officers were granted such a right," he continued, "we could go to any university in England or France if we wanted.""
es: —It was an opportunity given to some officers after the armistice —he continued—. We could go to any university in England or France.

en: I wanted to get up and slap him on the back. I had one of those renewals of complete faith in him that I’d experienced before.
vi: At that moment, I wanted to stand up and pat Gatsby on the back. I had completely regained my faith in him as I had once experienced before.
tr: I was struggling to resist the urge to stand up and give him a friendly slap on the shoulder. What had happened before had happened again, and my trust in Gatsby was renewed.
es: I felt like getting up and giving him a pat on the back. I felt one of those renewals of absolute confidence in him that I had experienced before.

en: Daisy rose, smiling faintly, and went to the table.
vi: Daisy stood up, smiled gently, and walked to the table.
tr: Daisy stood up and walked towards the table with a slight smile on her lips.
es: Daisy stood up, smiling faintly, and approached the table.

en: “Open the whisky, Tom,” she ordered, “and I’ll make you a mint julep. Then you won’t seem so stupid to yourself… Look at the mint!”
vi: "Open the whiskey, Tom," Daisy ordered. "I'll make you a mint julep. Then you won't be foolish anymore... Look at this pile of mint."
tr: "Open the whiskey, Tom," he ordered, "I'll prepare the mint cocktail. Then maybe you won't feel so stupid! How much liqueur should I put?"
es: —Open the whiskey, Tom —he ordered—. And I'll make you a mint julep. Then you won't feel so stupid... Tell me how much mint to put in.

en: “Wait a minute,” snapped Tom, “I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question.”
vi: "Wait a minute." Tom snapped.
tr: "Wait a minute," Tom snapped. "I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question."
es: —Wait a second —Tom interrupted her, violently—. I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question.

en: “Go on,” Gatsby said politely.
vi: "I want to ask Gatsby one more question." "Feel free." Gatsby replied politely.
tr: "Go ahead," Gatsby said politely.
es: —Go ahead —said Gatsby, very properly.

en: “What kind of a row are you trying to cause in my house anyhow?”
vi: "What are you planning to stir up in my family."
tr: “What kind of trouble are you trying to stir up in my home, tell me!”
es: —What kind of conflict are you trying to provoke in my house?

en: They were out in the open at last and Gatsby was content.
vi: In the end, what needed to be said was said, and it made Gatsby happy.
tr: Finally, everything had come to light, and Gatsby was pleased with it.
es: At last they were speaking openly and Gatsby seemed satisfied.

en: “He isn’t causing a row,” Daisy looked desperately from one to the other. “You’re causing a row. Please have a little self-control.”
vi: "He didn't cause any trouble." Daisy looked pleadingly from one person to another. "You're the one causing the scene. Please keep your composure, can't you?"
tr: “She isn't causing any trouble,” said Daisy, looking desperately from one to the other, “You are the one causing it. Please control yourself a bit.”
es: —He is not causing any conflict —Daisy looked at one and the other in desperation—. You are the one causing it. Please, control yourself a little.

en: “Self-control!” repeated Tom incredulously. “I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife. Well, if that’s the idea you can count me out… Nowadays people begin by sneering at family life and family institutions, and next they’ll throw everything overboard and have intermarriage between black and white.”
vi: "Self-control!" Tom repeated skeptically. "Do you mean to say that I should just sit and wait for some insignificant man from who knows where to come and sleep with my wife? Well, if that's the idea you want me to follow. Now people are starting to mock family life and the institution of family, and later they will throw everything away and accept white and black people marrying each other."
tr: “Saying I should control myself!” repeated Tom, foaming with rage, “What, while Mr. Nobody is flirting with my wife, I should just sit and allow it? If that's what you think, don't include me in this game... These days, people have started to thoroughly despise the institution of marriage and family life. Soon they will push everything aside, even blacks and whites will marry.”
es: —Control me! —repeated Tom, incredulous—. I suppose the latest trend is to sit back and let some Nobody from I don't know where fall in love with your wife. Well, if that's the idea, don't count on me… These days, it starts with despising family life and the family institution, and the next step will be throwing everything overboard and allowing marriages between whites and blacks.

en: Flushed with his impassioned gibberish, he saw himself standing alone on the last barrier of civilization.
vi: With these incoherent and agitated stammering words, Tom had pushed himself to the very edge of civilization.
tr: He had declared himself the unyielding last bastion of civilization, flushed red with the fervor of the nonsense he defended.
es: In the euphoria of his passionate absurdities, he already saw himself defending the last barrier of civilization alone.

en: “We’re all white here,” murmured Jordan.
vi: "We are all white people." Jordan whispered.
tr: "We're all white anyway," Jordan muttered.
es: —Here we are all white —murmured Jordan.

en: “I know I’m not very popular. I don’t give big parties. I suppose you’ve got to make your house into a pigsty in order to have any friends—in the modern world.”
vi: "I know I'm not liked by many, I don't throw big parties. Do I have to turn my house into a pigsty just to hope for friends - in this modern world..."
tr: “I know I'm not very popular. Maybe I don't throw big parties. If you want to find a place for yourself in the modern world, it seems you need to turn your home into a mess.”
es: —I know I'm not very likable. I don't throw big parties. I suppose you have to turn your house into a pigsty to have friends… in the modern world.

en: Angry as I was, as we all were, I was tempted to laugh whenever he opened his mouth. The transition from libertine to prig was so complete.
vi: Just like me, everyone in the room felt angry. However, I wanted to burst out laughing every time Tom opened his mouth. He had completely transformed from a playboy into a self-righteous preacher.
tr: Despite being filled with anger - we were all in the same situation - I struggled to keep myself from laughing whenever Tom opened his mouth. He was about to complete the transition from being a libertine to being conservative.
es: Although it had put me in a bad mood —like everyone else—, I felt true temptations to laugh every time Tom opened his mouth. His transition from libertine to prude had been perfect.

en: “I’ve got something to tell you, old sport—” began Gatsby. But Daisy guessed at his intention.
vi: "I have something I need to say to YOU, old sport.." Gatsby began, but Daisy had already guessed Gatsby's intention.
tr: “I have things to say to you too, buddy,” Gatsby began. Daisy understood his intention.
es: —I have something to tell you, comrade —Gatsby began. But Daisy guessed his intention.

en: “Please don’t!” she interrupted helplessly. “Please let’s all go home. Why don’t we all go home?”
vi: "Please don't!". Daisy interrupted urgently. "Let's go home. Why don't we leave?"
tr: In desperation, she interrupted, saying, “Please don't.” “Please, let's go home now. Why don't we disperse to our homes immediately?”
es: —Enough, please! —he interrupted him with a gesture of helplessness—. Please, let's go home. Why don't we all go home?

en: “That’s a good idea,” I got up. “Come on, Tom. Nobody wants a drink.”
vi: "That's a good idea." I stood up. "Let's go, Tom. No one wants to drink anymore."
tr: “Good idea,” I said, standing up. "Come on, Tom, nobody wants a drink anyway."
es: —It's a good idea —I stood up—. Let's go, Tom. No one feels like having a drink.

en: “I want to know what Mr. Gatsby has to tell me.”
vi: "I want to hear what Mr. Gatsby has to say to me."
tr: “Mr. Gatsby, I wondered what you would say.”
es: —I want to know what mister Gatsby has to say to me.

en: “Your wife doesn’t love you,” said Gatsby. “She’s never loved you. She loves me.”
vi: "Your wife doesn't love you," Gatsby said. "She never loved you. She loves me."
tr: “Mr. Gatsby, I wondered what you would say.” "Your wife doesn't love you. She never did, the person she loves is me."
es: —His wife doesn't love him —said Gatsby—. She never loved him. She loves me.

en: “You must be crazy!” exclaimed Tom automatically.
vi: "You are truly crazy!" Tom shouted like a machine.
tr: "You've gone mad!" Tom suddenly shouted.
es: —You must be crazy! —exclaimed Tom automatically.

en: Gatsby sprang to his feet, vivid with excitement.
vi: Gatsby stood up abruptly, intensely emotional.
tr: Gatsby, trembling with excitement, had jumped to his feet.
es: Gatsby jumped to his feet, tense with emotion.

en: “She never loved you, do you hear?” he cried. “She only married you because I was poor and she was tired of waiting for me. It was a terrible mistake, but in her heart she never loved anyone except me!”
vi: "She never loved you, do you hear?" Gatsby said loudly. "She married you only because I was poor and because she was tired of waiting for me. It was a colossal mistake, but in her heart, she has never loved anyone except me."
tr: “She never loved you, do you hear me?” he shouted, “I was penniless and she was tired of waiting. That's why she married you. It was a terrible mistake. She never loved anyone but me.”
es: —She has never loved you, do you hear? —he shouted—. She only married you because I was poor and she was tired of waiting for me. It was a terrible mistake, but in her heart, she has never loved anyone, only me.

en: At this point Jordan and I tried to go, but Tom and Gatsby insisted with competitive firmness that we remain—as though neither of them had anything to conceal and it would be a privilege to partake vicariously of their emotions.
vi: By this time, both Jordan and I wanted to leave that place, but Tom and Gatsby were equally determined to keep us there, as if they had nothing to hide and considered it a privilege to share their emotions with us.
tr: At that moment, Jordan and I got up to leave. But both Tom and Gatsby insisted that we stay, as if they were competing with each other. Both of them acted as if they had nothing to hide, as if it were a privilege to watch them reveal their feelings and share in their excitement.
es: At that moment, Jordan and I tried to leave, but Tom and Gatsby, competing in firmness, insisted that we stay, as if neither of them had anything to hide and it was a privilege to indirectly share their emotions.

en: “Sit down, Daisy,” Tom’s voice groped unsuccessfully for the paternal note. “What’s been going on? I want to hear all about it.”
vi: "Sit down, Daisy." Tom commanded with a superior tone, but it was unsuccessful. "What happened? I want to hear everything."
tr: "Sit down, Daisy," said Tom. He was trying to give his voice an authoritative tone but wasn't very successful. “What is happening? I want to know everything.”
es: —Sit down, Daisy —Tom was trying, unsuccessfully, to find a paternal tone—. What happened? I want to know everything.

en: “I told you what’s been going on,” said Gatsby. “Going on for five years—and you didn’t know.”
vi: "I told you what happened." Gatsby said. "It happened five years ago and you knew nothing about it."
tr: “I told you what happened,” said Gatsby, “I’m talking about something that spans five years and many things you don’t know about.”
es: —I have already told you what happened —said Gatsby—. For five years… And you didn't know.

en: Tom turned to Daisy sharply.
vi: Tom turned abruptly towards Daisy.
tr: Tom suddenly turned to Daisy.
es: Tom, cuttingly, turned towards Gatsby.

en: “You’ve been seeing this fellow for five years?”
vi: "You've been seeing this guy for five years already?" "It wasn't about meeting each other."
tr: “Have you been seeing this guy for five years?”
es: —Have you been seeing this guy for five years?

en: “Not seeing,” said Gatsby. “No, we couldn’t meet. But both of us loved each other all that time, old sport, and you didn’t know. I used to laugh sometimes”—but there was no laughter in his eyes—“to think that you didn’t know.”
vi: Gatsby explained. "No, we never met. But in our hearts, we always loved each other. Old sport. You didn't know this. I often laughed thinking that you didn't know anything." But there was nothing resembling a laugh in Gatsby's eyes.
tr: “No, we weren't meeting,” said Gatsby, “We couldn't meet. But we loved each other, buddy, and you didn't know that. Sometimes I would think and laugh,” his eyes weren't smiling as he spoke, “it would seem funny to me that you didn't know.”
es: —Seeing, no —said Gatsby—. No, we couldn't. But we have loved each other all this time, old sport, and you didn't know it. Sometimes I laughed —but there was no laughter in his eyes— thinking that you didn't know it.

en: “Oh—that’s all.” Tom tapped his thick fingers together like a clergyman and leaned back in his chair.
vi: "Oh, that's all." Tom tapped his thick fingers together like a monk and leaned back in his chair.
tr: Sometimes I would think and laugh,” his eyes weren't smiling as he spoke, “it would seem funny to me that you didn't know.” “So that's how it is,” said Tom, leaning back and touching his large fingertips together with a priestly air.
es: —Ah, that's all —Tom joined his thumbs together like a priest and leaned back in the armchair—.

en: “You’re crazy!” he exploded. “I can’t speak about what happened five years ago, because I didn’t know Daisy then—and I’ll be damned if I see how you got within a mile of her unless you brought the groceries to the back door. But all the rest of that’s a God damned lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she loves me now.”
vi: "You are truly insane!" Tom fumed. "I don't touch on things that happened five years ago because I didn't know Daisy back then. And I also want to know how you got close to my wife within a mile unless you were the food delivery guy coming in through the back door. But everything else is a lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she still loves me now."
tr: “You’re crazy!” he burst out, “I can’t say anything about what happened five years ago because I didn’t know Daisy then. Besides, I can’t fathom how you could have gotten within a mile of her during that time – unless, of course, you were the one delivering the grocery orders through the back door. The rest is all a big lie. Daisy married me because she loved me and she still does.”
es: You're crazy! —he burst out—. I can't talk about what happened five years ago, because I didn't know Daisy then. But damn me if I understand how you could get within a kilometer of Daisy unless you were delivering groceries to the service door. Everything else is a damn lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she still loves me.

en: “No,” said Gatsby, shaking his head.
vi: "Not true." Gatsby shook his head and said.
tr: "No," said Gatsby, shaking his head from side to side.
es: —No —said Gatsby, shaking his head.

en: “She does, though. The trouble is that sometimes she gets foolish ideas in her head and doesn’t know what she’s doing.” He nodded sagely. “And what’s more, I love Daisy too. Once in a while I go off on a spree and make a fool of myself, but I always come back, and in my heart I love her all the time.”
vi: "She does. It's just that sometimes she gets foolish thoughts in her head and doesn't know what she's doing." Tom nodded solemnly. "Besides, I also love Daisy. Sometimes I foolishly go out with friends to have fun, but I always come back. In my heart, I always love her."
tr: “Yes, he loves. Sometimes his mind gets stuck on silly things and he doesn't know what to do. That's all.” Then he added with great seriousness, “of course, I love him too. Sometimes I stray and do foolish things, but I have always returned to him. The love I feel in the depths of my heart has never diminished.”
es: —She loves me, despite everything. The problem is that sometimes she gets silly ideas in her head and doesn't know what she's doing —Tom nodded wisely—. And, what's more, I also love Daisy. Every now and then I go on a spree and act like an idiot, but I always come back and, deep down in my heart, I've never stopped loving her.

en: “You’re revolting,” said Daisy. She turned to me, and her voice, dropping an octave lower, filled the room with thrilling scorn: “Do you know why we left Chicago? I’m surprised that they didn’t treat you to the story of that little spree.”
vi: "He's repenting." Daisy said. She turned to me, her voice dropping, filling the room with feelings of contempt. "Do you know why we left Chicago?" I'm surprised they haven't told you the story of their escapades."
tr: "You are disgusting," said Daisy, then she turned to me and her voice, laden with reproach and dropping an octave in anger, resonated in the room. "Do you know why we left Chicago? I wonder how they didn't involve you in that little 'going astray' story."
es: —You are disgusting —said Daisy. She turned to me, and her voice, dropping an octave, filled the room with emotion and disdain—. Don't you know why we left Chicago? I'm amazed that they haven't told you the story of that spree.

en: Gatsby walked over and stood beside her.
vi: Gatsby stepped forward to stand next to Daisy and spoke passionately.
tr: Gatsby got up from his seat and took a few steps toward her.
es: Gatsby took a few steps and stood by her side.

en: “Daisy, that’s all over now,” he said earnestly. “It doesn’t matter any more. Just tell him the truth—that you never loved him—and it’s all wiped out forever.”
vi: "Daisy, everything is over, it's no longer an issue. Tell him the truth, the truth that you never loved him and that everything has been erased."
tr: “It's over now, Daisy,” he said sincerely, “it doesn't matter at all. Tell him the truth. Explain that you never loved him. Let everything be clarified forever.”
es: —Daisy, all of that is over —he said passionately—. It doesn't matter anymore. Tell him the truth, that you never loved him, and everything will be over forever.

en: She looked at him blindly. “Why—how could I love him—possibly?”
vi: Daisy looked at Gatsby in a daze. "How - How could you love him?"
tr: Daisy looked at him with unseeing eyes. “How can I love him? How is this possible?” she said.
es: Daisy looked at him without seeing him. —But how, how could I have wanted it?

en: “You never loved him.”
vi: "I have never loved him."
tr: “You never loved him.”
es: —You have never loved him.

en: She hesitated. Her eyes fell on Jordan and me with a sort of appeal, as though she realized at last what she was doing—and as though she had never, all along, intended doing anything at all. But it was done now. It was too late.
vi: Daisy hesitated. Her eyes looked at Jordan and me imploringly, as if she had finally realized what she was doing, as if she had never intended to do anything until now. But now the story had unfolded, it was too late.
tr: Daisy was in hesitation. She looked at me and then at Jordan as if asking for help. It was as if she was just realizing what she had done. And as if she hadn't really wanted to do them. But what was done was done. It was too late now.
es: Daisy hesitated. She looked at Jordan and me as if pleading, as if she finally realized what she was doing, and as if she had never, during all that time, had the slightest intention of doing anything. But it was already done. It was too late.

en: “I never loved him,” she said, with perceptible reluctance.
vi: "I have never loved him." Daisy said with evident reluctance.
tr: “I never liked him,” the words slipped out of her mouth unintentionally.
es: —I have never wanted it —he said with evident reluctance.

en: “Not at Kapiolani?” demanded Tom suddenly.
vi: "Even at Kapiolani?" Tom asked abruptly.
tr: "Even when you were in Kapiolani?" he asked.
es: —Not even in Kapiolani? —asked Tom suddenly.

en: “No.”
vi: "No."
tr: “No.”
es: —No.

en: From the ballroom beneath, muffled and suffocating chords were drifting up on hot waves of air.
vi: From the ballroom downstairs, the chords, sounding like they were suffocating, floated up with the hot air.
tr: The suffocating sounds rising from the ballroom below continued to reach us over the waves of hot air.
es: From the ballroom, amidst waves of hot air, muffled and stifling chords reached us.

en: “Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry?” There was a husky tenderness in his tone… “Daisy?”
vi: "Including the day you carried me off the Punch Bowl to keep my shoes dry? Right, Daisy?" Tom's voice carried a gentle, melancholic tone. "Please don't!".
tr: “Well, what about that day when I carried you in my arms so your shoes wouldn't get wet in the rain?” the voice was soft and affectionate, “Huh, Daisy?”
es: —Not even the day I carried you in my arms from the Punch Bowl so your shoes wouldn't get wet, Daisy? —there was a hoarse tenderness in his tone.

en: “Please don’t.” Her voice was cold, but the rancour was gone from it. She looked at Gatsby. “There, Jay,” she said—but her hand as she tried to light a cigarette was trembling. Suddenly she threw the cigarette and the burning match on the carpet.
vi: "Please don't!". Daisy's voice, though cold, had lost its tone of hostility. Daisy looked up at Gatsby. "Jay". Daisy said, her trembling hand reaching up to light a cigarette. Suddenly, Daisy threw the burning cigarette onto the carpet.
tr: “Well, what about that day when I carried you in my arms so your shoes wouldn't get wet in the rain?” the voice was soft and affectionate, “Huh, Daisy?” "Please don't," Daisy's voice was icy, but her resentment seemed slightly diminished. She looked at Gatsby, "I did it, Jay," she said. Her hand, trying to light a cigarette, was trembling. Suddenly, she threw both the cigarette and the lit match onto the carpet.
es: —Please, stop —the voice sounded cold, but the resentment had disappeared. She looked at Gatsby—. You see, Jay —she said, but her hand trembled when she tried to light a cigarette. Suddenly, she threw the cigarette and the lit match onto the carpet—.

en: “Oh, you want too much!” she cried to Gatsby. “I love you now—isn’t that enough? I can’t help what’s past.” She began to sob helplessly. “I did love him once—but I loved you too.”
vi: "You ask for too much!" Daisy said loudly to Gatsby. "I love you now, isn't that enough." "I can't do anything about the past." Daisy sobbed. "I once loved him - but I also loved you."
tr: “But you want too much!” he shouted, “I love you, isn't that enough? I can't erase the past!” She had started crying. “Once upon a time, I loved him. But I loved you too.”
es: You ask too much! —she shouted at Gatsby—. I love you, isn't that enough? I can't erase the past —she began to sob uncontrollably—. I loved him, but I also loved you.

en: Gatsby’s eyes opened and closed.
vi: Gatsby's eyes opened and then closed.
tr: Gatsby blinked his eyes.
es: Gatsby's eyes opened and closed.

en: “You loved me too?” he repeated.
vi: He repeated. "You love me too, don't you?"
tr: “So, you loved me too,” he repeated.
es: —Did you also love me? —he repeated.

en: “Even that’s a lie,” said Tom savagely. “She didn’t know you were alive. Why—there’s things between Daisy and me that you’ll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.”
vi: "Even if it was just a lie." Tom said cruelly. "She doesn't know that you're still alive. Why? There are things that happened between Daisy and me that you k We will never know. There are things that neither of us will ever forget."
tr: “That's a lie,” said Tom bitterly, “He wasn't even aware that you existed. There are things between my wife and me that you couldn't understand even one of them. Things that neither of us will ever forget.”
es: —Even that is a lie —said Tom ruthlessly—. I didn't even know if you were still alive. There are things between Daisy and me that you will never know, things that neither of us will ever forget.

en: The words seemed to bite physically into Gatsby.
vi: These words seemed to have torn Gatsby's body apart.
tr: It was as if the words were wounding Gatsby's body.
es: The words seemed to bite into Gatsby's body.

en: “I want to speak to Daisy alone,” he insisted. “She’s all excited now—”
vi: "I want to speak privately with Daisy. She is emotional right now." Gatsby insisted.
tr: "I want to talk to Daisy alone," he insisted, "she is very worried right now..."
es: —I want to speak alone with Daisy —he insisted—. She is too upset right now…

en: “Even alone I can’t say I never loved Tom,” she admitted in a pitiful voice. “It wouldn’t be true.”
vi: "Even if it's just the two of us, I can't say that I never loved Tom. That wouldn't be true," Daisy confessed miserably.
tr: “Even if we are alone, I can't say that I never loved Tom,” said Daisy. Her voice was full of pain. "This can't be real."
es: —Not even when I'm alone can I say that I never loved Tom —admitted Daisy with a broken voice—. It wouldn't be true.

en: “Of course it wouldn’t,” agreed Tom.
vi: "Of course, that's not right." Tom agreed.
tr: "Of course not," Tom agreed.
es: —Of course not —agreed Tom.

en: She turned to her husband.
vi: Daisy turned her head to look at her husband.
tr: "As if he cares about any of this," said Daisy, turning to her husband.
es: Daisy turned to her husband.

en: “As if it mattered to you,” she said.
vi: "You act as if that matters to you."
tr: "As if he cares about any of this," said Daisy, turning to her husband.
es: —As if you cared —he said.

en: “Of course it matters. I’m going to take better care of you from now on.”
vi: "Of course it's important. From now on, I promise to take better care of you."
tr: "Of course I care. From now on, I will take much better care of you."
es: —Of course I care. I'm going to take better care of you from now on.

en: “You don’t understand,” said Gatsby, with a touch of panic. “You’re not going to take care of her any more.”
vi: "Actually, you don't understand. You won't be able to take care of Daisy anymore." Gatsby said, his voice showing signs of panic.
tr: "I guess you didn't understand," Gatsby's voice had a slight hint of panic, "you won't be taking care of her anymore."
es: —You haven't understood —said Gatsby with a shadow of panic—. She will not take care of her again.

en: “I’m not?” Tom opened his eyes wide and laughed. He could afford to control himself now. “Why’s that?”
vi: "I can't?" Tom's eyes widened and then he burst out laughing. Now he had regained his composure. "Why is that?"
tr: “Is that so?” said Tom. He opened his eyes wide and laughed, "Why is that?" “He is leaving you.”
es: —No? —Tom opened his eyes wide and burst out laughing. He no longer had trouble controlling himself—. And why is that?

en: “Daisy’s leaving you.”
vi: "Because Daisy will leave you."
tr: “He is leaving you.”
es: —Daisy is going to leave him.

en: “Nonsense.”
vi: "Nonsense."
tr: “Nonsense.”
es: —Nonsense.

en: “I am, though,” she said with a visible effort.
vi: "That's right." Daisy said with a noticeable effort.
tr: “Yes, it is,” said Daisy, making a visible effort.
es: —Well, it's true —she said with evident effort.

en: “She’s not leaving me!” Tom’s words suddenly leaned down over Gatsby. “Certainly not for a common swindler who’d have to steal the ring he put on her finger.”
vi: "She will not leave me!" Tom's words suddenly turned towards Gatsby. "Surely she will not leave me to follow a fraud, who would have to steal even a wedding ring to put on her finger."
tr: “She won't leave me.” Tom's words were disheartening Gatsby, “She would never do that for a lowly swindler like you who even had to steal the wedding ring you put on her finger.”
es: —She is not going to leave me! —Tom's words suddenly fell upon Gatsby—. And, of course, not for a common swindler who would have to steal the ring he put on her finger.

en: “I won’t stand this!” cried Daisy. “Oh, please let’s get out.”
vi: "I can't take it anymore. Please, let's get out of here." Daisy said loudly.
tr: “I can't stand it,” cried Daisy, “Please, let's get out of here already!”
es: —This is unbearable! —shouted Daisy—. Let's go, please!

en: “Who are you, anyhow?” broke out Tom. “You’re one of that bunch that hangs around with Meyer Wolfshiem—that much I happen to know. I’ve made a little investigation into your affairs—and I’ll carry it further tomorrow.”
vi: "Who do you think you are?" Tom burst out laughing. "You're just one of those guys who hang around Meyer Wolfsheim, I already know everything. I've had people investigate your activities and tomorrow I'll continue to investigate further."
tr: “Who do you think you are!” Tom was shouting, “you’re just one of those people hanging around Meyer Wolfsheim.” “That’s all I know for now.” “I’ve done a little investigation on you.” “Tomorrow I’ll learn more.””
es: —Because who are you after all? —Tom concluded—. One of the gang that surrounds Meyer Wolfshiem, from what I have been able to find out. I've looked into your affairs a bit, and tomorrow I will continue.

en: “You can suit yourself about that, old sport,” said Gatsby steadily.
vi: "Feel free to make yourself at home, old sport." Gatsby calmly said.
tr: "As you wish, buddy," said Gatsby without hesitation.
es: —You can do whatever you think is appropriate about it, comrade —said Gatsby calmly.

en: “I found out what your ‘drugstores’ were.” He turned to us and spoke rapidly. “He and this Wolfshiem bought up a lot of side-street drugstores here and in Chicago and sold grain alcohol over the counter. That’s one of his little stunts. I picked him for a bootlegger the first time I saw him, and I wasn’t far wrong.”
vi: "I have discovered what his pharmacies are really doing." Tom turned back to us and said hurriedly. "He and this guy Wolfsheim bought up a lot of drugstores here and in Chicago to sell bootleg liquor. That was just one of his small-time operations. I guessed right away that he was a bootlegger the first time I met him. And I wasn't too wrong, was I?"
tr: "I also know what's going on in your pharmacies." Then he turned to us. "These two have opened a bunch of stores on the streets of New York and Chicago and sold tons of grain alcohol on the market. That's just one of their tricks. I suspected he was a bootlegger the moment I saw him. I wasn't wrong."
es: —I have discovered what their drugstores were —he addressed us, speaking very quickly—. He and that Wolfshiem bought a bunch of drugstores in alleys here and in Chicago and dedicated themselves to selling bootleg liquor. That is one of their tricks. He seemed like a bootlegger to me the first time I saw him, and I wasn't too far off.

en: “What about it?” said Gatsby politely. “I guess your friend Walter Chase wasn’t too proud to come in on it.”
vi: "So what?" Gatsby said politely. "I guess your friend Walter Chase wasn't too proud to get involved in this work."
tr: “So what if it is? said Gatsby without breaking his politeness. “Your friend Walter Chase got involved in that too but later regretted it.”
es: —And what? —said Gatsby with great correctness—. I believe that pride did not prevent your friend Walter Chase from participating in the business.

en: “And you left him in the lurch, didn’t you? You let him go to jail for a month over in New Jersey. God! You ought to hear Walter on the subject of you.”
vi: "And you abandoned him in his time of need, didn't you? You let him go to jail for a month in New Jersey. Oh my! You should hear Walter tell stories about you."
tr: “As soon as he fell into a difficult situation, you abandoned him. You didn't say a word about him spending a month in a New Jersey prison. My God! If only you could hear what Walter says about you.”
es: —And you left him in the lurch, didn't you? You let him spend a month in the New Jersey jail. Good heavens! You should hear what Walter says about you.

en: “He came to us dead broke. He was very glad to pick up some money, old sport.”
vi: "When he came to find us, he didn't have a penny left. He had earned a little money and was already very happy, old friend."
tr: “The man approached us when he was penniless. He quite enjoyed earning some money, my friend.”
es: —He came to us without a cent. He was very happy to take some money with him, comrade.

en: “Don’t you call me ‘old sport’!” cried Tom. Gatsby said nothing. “Walter could have you up on the betting laws too, but Wolfshiem scared him into shutting his mouth.”
vi: "Don't call me 'old buddy'!" Tom shouted. Gatsby did not reply. "Walter can put you guys in jail for illegal betting. But Wolfsheim threatened him to keep his mouth shut."
tr: "Stop calling me 'buddy'," Tom shouted. Gatsby didn't say anything. “Walter was going to get into trouble for running bets, but Wolfsheim threatened him to keep his mouth shut.”
es: —Don't call me comrade! —shouted Tom. Gatsby said nothing—. Walter could have reported them for the betting affair, but Wolfshiem scared him into keeping his mouth shut.

en: That unfamiliar yet recognizable look was back again in Gatsby’s face.
vi: The unusual but easily recognizable expression of Gatsby appeared on his face again.
tr: That unusual but familiar expression had appeared on Gatsby's face again.
es: Gatsby's face had regained that expression of his, strange and yet recognizable.

en: “That drugstore business was just small change,” continued Tom slowly, “but you’ve got something on now that Walter’s afraid to tell me about.”
vi: "The business at the drugstores is just a trivial matter. You guys are involved in something else that Walter is still too afraid to reveal to me."
tr: “Actually, that pharmacy business was just a drop in the ocean,” Tom continued, “now, whatever kind of business you're after, Wolfsheim even avoided telling me.”
es: —The drugstore business was just small change —Tom continued slowly—, but now he's got something going on that Walter doesn't dare to tell me about.

en: I glanced at Daisy, who was staring terrified between Gatsby and her husband, and at Jordan, who had begun to balance an invisible but absorbing object on the tip of her chin. Then I turned back to Gatsby—and was startled at his expression. He looked—and this is said in all contempt for the babbled slander of his garden—as if he had “killed a man.” For a moment the set of his face could be described in just that fantastic way.
vi: I glanced at Daisy, who was fearfully standing and looking between Gatsby and her husband. Then I looked over at Jordan, who was balancing some invisible object on her chin. When I turned back to look at Gatsby, I was surprised by his expression. He looked like he had "just killed someone" - to use the absurd slanders I had heard with disdain in his garden. When that expression had faded away, Gatsby began to explain to Daisy in an agitated manner.
tr: I looked at Daisy. She was looking at Gatsby and then at her husband with eyes full of terror. Jordan, on the other hand, was focusing all her attention on balancing an imaginary object on her chin. When I turned my gaze back to Gatsby, I was stunned by the expression I saw on his face. Let me use the phrase that a gossiping guest at one of the parties used; 'he looked like he had killed someone.' For a moment, what I saw on his face could only be described in such a fantastical way. His face changed.
es: I observed Daisy, who was staring, terrified, at Gatsby or her husband, and Jordan, who had started to balance an invisible but absorbing object on her chin. Then I turned to Gatsby and was frightened by his expression. He seemed —and I say this with absolute contempt for the slanders heard in his garden— to have killed someone. For a moment, the expression on his face could have been described in that fantastic way.

en: It passed, and he began to talk excitedly to Daisy, denying everything, defending his name against accusations that had not been made. But with every word she was drawing further and further into herself, so he gave that up, and only the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room.
vi: He dismissed everything and defended his reputation against the slanders that had just been mentioned. However, the more he spoke, the more Daisy recoiled, so in the end, Gatsby had to give up. Only his dying dream continued to struggle, trying to hold onto the fading afternoon, desperately reaching for what was no longer real to him, struggling painfully, not despairing towards the voice that was fading away on the other side of the room.
tr: He started talking to Daisy excitedly. He was denying everything, making great efforts to clear himself even on matters he wasn't accused of. But with every word that came out of his mouth, Daisy retreated further into herself. And finally, he gave up. All that was left was the struggle of a dead dream, desperately and hopelessly trying to touch what had already slipped away with the passing time, towards the lost voice at the other end of the room.
es: That moment passed, and Gatsby began to speak to Daisy very nervously, denying everything, defending his name from accusations that no one had made. But with each word, she retreated further into herself, and Gatsby gave up, and only the dead dream continued its struggle as the afternoon faded, trying to reach what was no longer tangible, fighting without luck and without despair, searching for the lost voice at the back of the room.

en: The voice begged again to go.
vi: That voice pleaded to return once more.
tr: The voice pleaded once more to leave.
es: The voice pleaded again for us to leave.

en: “Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”
vi: "PLEASE, Tom! I can't take it anymore."
tr: “Please Tom! I can't take it anymore,” she said
es: —Please, Tom! I can't take it anymore.

en: Her frightened eyes told that whatever intentions, whatever courage she had had, were definitely gone.
vi: Daisy's eyes, full of fear, showed that all her intentions or all the courage she once had were now gone.
tr: Daisy's eyes filled with horror told that everything she wanted to do and all her courage had flown away never to return.
es: Her frightened eyes said that all her courage and all her intentions, whatever they might have been, had disappeared definitively.

en: “You two start on home, Daisy,” said Tom. “In Mr. Gatsby’s car.”
vi: "Daisy, you two go home, go by Gatsby's car."
tr: "You two get into Mr. Gatsby's car again," said Tom.
es: —Go home with him, Daisy —said Tom—. In Mr. Gatsby's car.

en: She looked at Tom, alarmed now, but he insisted with magnanimous scorn.
vi: Tom said. Daisy looked at Tom worriedly, yet he still insisted on speaking with a tone of lofty contempt.
tr: The woman looked at him in panic, but her husband insisted disdainfully.
es: Daisy looked at Tom, alarmed, but he insisted with magnanimous disdain:

en: “Go on. He won’t annoy you. I think he realizes that his presumptuous little flirtation is over.”
vi: "Go ahead. He won't bother you anymore. I think he has realized that his petty flirtations have come to an end."
tr: “Go on, leave. He won't bother you anymore. I think he has realized that the period of his inappropriate flirting is over.”
es: —Come in. It won't bother you. I think he has realized that his ridiculous and presumptuous flirting is over.

en: They were gone, without a word, snapped out, made accidental, isolated, like ghosts, even from our pity.
vi: The two of them walked away without saying a word, disappearing quickly, independent, separate, like ghosts right before our pity.
tr: Both of them left like ghosts, without saying a single word, shattered, randomly pieced together, and deprived even of our mercy.
es: They left, without a word, excluded, turned into something insignificant, isolated, like ghosts, on the fringes, even, of our pity.

en: After a moment Tom got up and began wrapping the unopened bottle of whisky in the towel.
vi: A moment later, Tom stood up and began wrapping the unopened bottles of wine back into the cloth.
tr: After they left, Tom stood up and, while wrapping the unopened whiskey bottle he had brought with him back in the towel, asked us, "Would you like some of this, Nick? Jordan?"
es: A few minutes later, Tom got up and started wrapping the unopened bottle of whiskey in the towel.

en: “Want any of this stuff? Jordan?… Nick?”
vi: "Do you want this? Jordan? Nick?"
tr: After they left, Tom stood up and, while wrapping the unopened whiskey bottle he had brought with him back in the towel, asked us, "Would you like some of this, Nick? Jordan?"
es: —Do you want a drink? Jordan? Nick?

en: I didn’t answer.
vi: I did not answer.
tr: I did not respond.
es: I didn't answer.

en: “Nick?” He asked again.
vi: "Nick?" he asked once again.
tr: “Nick?” she said again.
es: —Nick? —she asked me again.

en: “What?”
vi: "What's going on?"
tr: “What?”
es: —What?

en: “Want any?”
vi: "Want a little?"
tr: "Do you want it?" “No.
es: —Do you want? —No.

en: “No… I just remembered that today’s my birthday.”
vi: "No..." "I just remembered that today is my birthday."
tr: You know, I just remembered that today is my birthday.”
es: I just remembered that today is my birthday.

en: I was thirty. Before me stretched the portentous, menacing road of a new decade.
vi: I am thirty years old. In front of me is a long road full of the threatening challenges of a new decade.
tr: I had turned thirty. A brand new period full of danger and adventure lay ahead of me.
es: I was turning thirty. Before me stretched the wondrous and threatening path of a new decade.

en: It was seven o’clock when we got into the coupé with him and started for Long Island. Tom talked incessantly, exulting and laughing, but his voice was as remote from Jordan and me as the foreign clamour on the sidewalk or the tumult of the elevated overhead. Human sympathy has its limits, and we were content to let all their tragic arguments fade with the city lights behind. Thirty—the promise of a decade of loneliness, a thinning list of single men to know, a thinning briefcase of enthusiasm, thinning hair. But there was Jordan beside me, who, unlike Daisy, was too wise ever to carry well-forgotten dreams from age to age. As we passed over the dark bridge her wan face fell lazily against my coat’s shoulder and the formidable stroke of thirty died away with the reassuring pressure of her hand.
vi: When we got into his two-seater car to head to Long Island, it was already seven in the evening. Tom talked cheerfully and laughed continuously. However, from where Jordan and I were sitting, his voice seemed distant, like the strange shouting on the sidewalk or the bustling noise heard from above. Human compassion has its limits; we were happy to let their sorrowful arguments fade away along with the streetlights left behind. Thirty years old, a promise of a decade full of loneliness, of a dwindling list of single young friends, of a briefcase holding thinning enthusiasm, and of thinning hair. But I still had Jordan beside me; unlike Daisy, this girl was wiser and would never carry with her the forgotten dreams from time to time. As our car crossed the dark bridge, Jordan's weary, tired face lazily rested on my coat shoulder. And then the dreadful bell toll marking my thirtieth year was silenced when Jordan's hand gripped mine as a promise.
tr: It was seven o'clock when we got into Tom's sports car and set off towards Long Island. He kept talking, telling stories and laughing, but in reality, he was as distant from us as the hum of pedestrians on the sidewalk and the noise of trains passing over the railway above us. There are limits to human tolerance. Both Jordan and I had left their pathetic arguments behind us along with the city lights. The thirties! A decade that brings nothing but loneliness, where the number of single men you know, your desire to work, and your hair all steadily decrease... But beside me was Jordan, a girl smart enough not to carry her lost dreams within her for years like Daisy. As we crossed an unlit bridge, she gently rested her head on my shoulder. All the turmoil and fears of being thirty vanished the moment she squeezed my hand with hers that lay in my palm.
es: It was seven o'clock when we got into the coupe with Tom and headed towards Long Island. Tom didn't stop talking and laughing, exuberant, but his voice seemed as distant to Jordan and me as the clamor of strangers on the sidewalks or the clatter of the elevated train above our heads. Compassion has its limits, and we were glad that the tragic arguments of others were left behind and faded away like the city lights. Thirty years: the promise of a decade of loneliness, a dwindling list of bachelors to meet, a dwindling reserve of enthusiasm, dwindling hair. But beside me was Jordan, who, unlike Daisy, was too smart to drag forgotten dreams from one era to another. As we crossed the dimly lit bridge, her pale and lazy face rested on the shoulder of my jacket and the reassuring pressure of her hand calmed the formidable blow of thirty years.

en: So we drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.
vi: And so, we drove towards the direction of death, through the gradually cooling twilight darkness.
tr: In the twilight of the evening that was starting to cool, we were rapidly heading towards death.
es: Thus we continued the journey towards death through the evening, which was beginning to cool down.

en: The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He had slept through the heat until after five, when he strolled over to the garage, and found George Wilson sick in his office—really sick, pale as his own pale hair and shaking all over. Michaelis advised him to go to bed, but Wilson refused, saying that he’d miss a lot of business if he did. While his neighbour was trying to persuade him a violent racket broke out overhead.
vi: The young Greek man, Michaelis, who owned a café right next to the ash heaps, was the primary witness of the investigation. He had slept through the heat until five in the afternoon. When he walked to the garage, he found Wilson, who was ill, sitting in the office. Wilson was very ill, his face as pale as his pale hair, his whole body trembling. Michaelis advised Wilson to go to bed and rest, but Wilson refused, saying that doing so would cause him to lose many customers. While the neighbor was trying to persuade Wilson, loud crashing noises came from upstairs.
tr: The Greek young man Michaelis, who ran the coffee shop next to the piles of ash, was the most important witness heard during the investigation. He had spent that hot day sleeping until five o'clock, then went to the repair shop and saw that George Wilson was very sick. The poor man was in terrible condition. His face was as yellow as his hair and he was trembling all over. Michaelis suggested that he go upstairs and lie down, but Wilson refused. He said he would lose money because he couldn't attend to the comings and goings. While Michaelis was trying to persuade him, a terrible noise was heard from upstairs.
es: Michaelis, the young Greek who ran the café next to the heaps of ashes, was the main witness in the investigation. He had fallen asleep due to the heat until after five, then he had taken a walk to the garage and found George Wilson, sick in his office, truly sick, pale like his faded hair, and shivering, trembling. Michaelis advised him to lie down, but Wilson refused, saying that if he did, he would lose a lot of money. While his neighbor tried to convince him, a violent commotion broke out upstairs.

en: “I’ve got my wife locked in up there,” explained Wilson calmly. “She’s going to stay there till the day after tomorrow, and then we’re going to move away.”
vi: "I locked my wife up there." Wilson calmly explained. "I plan to keep her up there until the day after tomorrow, then we will move far away from here."
tr: “I locked my wife in the room!” Wilson explained in a calm voice, “she will stay there until the next day. Then we will leave this place.”
es: —I have my wife locked up —explained Wilson very calmly—. She will be there until the day after tomorrow. And that day we are leaving.

en: Michaelis was astonished; they had been neighbours for four years, and Wilson had never seemed faintly capable of such a statement. Generally he was one of these worn-out men: when he wasn’t working, he sat on a chair in the doorway and stared at the people and the cars that passed along the road. When anyone spoke to him he invariably laughed in an agreeable, colourless way. He was his wife’s man and not his own.
vi: Michaelis was astonished; they had been neighbors for four years, and it seemed Wilson had never had the ability to make such a statement. Generally, he was the type of weak-willed man who, if he wasn't working, would sit on the chair at the doorway staring blankly at the people and cars passing by on the street. Whenever someone came to chat, he would give them a fixed, insipid, ingratiating smile. Wilson was the type of man who was weak and afraid of his wife.
tr: Michaelis was astonished. He thought that a neighbor of four years wouldn't even be capable of saying, let alone doing, such a thing. Because he was one of those weary men who would sit on the chair in front of the door and watch people pass by when he wasn't working. Whenever something was said, he would always respond with his soulless and calm smile. It wasn't him who was dominant at home, but his wife.
es: Michaelis was astonished; they had been neighbors for four years, and he had never believed Wilson capable of saying something like what he had just said. Usually, he was one of those defeated men: when he wasn't working, he would sit in a chair at the entrance and watch the people and cars passing by on the road. If someone spoke to him, he would always laugh in a pleasant and naive way. It was about his wife, not about himself.

en: So naturally Michaelis tried to find out what had happened, but Wilson wouldn’t say a word—instead he began to throw curious, suspicious glances at his visitor and ask him what he’d been doing at certain times on certain days. Just as the latter was getting uneasy, some workmen came past the door bound for his restaurant, and Michaelis took the opportunity to get away, intending to come back later. But he didn’t. He supposed he forgot to, that’s all. When he came outside again, a little after seven, he was reminded of the conversation because he heard Mrs. Wilson’s voice, loud and scolding, downstairs in the garage.
vi: Of course, Michaelis tried to understand what had happened. However, Wilson did not reveal a word; instead, he started casting suspicious and curious glances towards his neighbor and asked what Michaelis had been doing and at what time on which day. When Michaelis began to feel uncomfortable, a few workers passed by the door heading towards his restaurant. Michaelis took this opportunity to leave, but with the intention of returning. However, Michaelis did not return. Perhaps he simply forgot, that's all. When he stepped outside the door again, it was just past seven o'clock, and he heard Wilson's wife shouting and yelling downstairs at the garage, which reminded him of the earlier conversation with Wilson.
tr: Michaelis naturally tried to find out what had happened between them. But he couldn't get a single word out of him. On the contrary, Wilson looked at him with curiosity and suspicion and started asking strange questions. He kept asking where he was and what he was doing at certain days and times. Although he was tired of this suspicious interrogation, Michaelis, trying not to succumb to his anger, said he would be back soon and escaped when he saw a few workers heading towards a diner. He never returned. He probably forgot all about it. But when he stepped out in front of his shop around seven in the evening, he remembered the conversation he had with Wilson. Because he heard Mrs. Wilson, who had gone mad with rage, severely scolding her husband.
es: And, naturally, Michaelis tried to find out what had happened, but Wilson didn't say a word and cast strange suspicious glances at his neighbor, asking him what he had done at certain hours on certain days. Michaelis was starting to feel annoyed when some workers passed by the door on their way to the restaurant, and he took the opportunity to leave, intending to return later. But he did not return. He thinks he forgot. When he went out again, shortly after seven, he remembered the conversation because he heard Mistress Wilson's indignant shouts on the ground floor of the garage.

en: “Beat me!” he heard her cry. “Throw me down and beat me, you dirty little coward!”
vi: "Hit me!" Michaelis heard Myrtle crying. "Just pin me down and hit me, you despicable coward."
tr: “Come on, hit me,” the woman was shouting, “Drag me on the ground. Come on, hit me, let's see. You cowardly man!”
es: —Hit me! —he heard her scream—. Throw me to the ground and hit me, you disgusting coward, miserable!

en: A moment later she rushed out into the dusk, waving her hands and shouting—before he could move from his door the business was over.
vi: A moment later, Wilson's wife ran quickly outside into the darkness, waving her hands and calling out. Before Michaelis had a chance to step out the door, it was all over.
tr: One minute later, the woman ran outside, wildly waving her arms and shouting. By the time the man ran from his shop and reached her, everything had already happened.
es: A moment later, she rushed into the darkness of the street, waving her arms and screaming, and before Michaelis could move from his door, it was all over.

en: The “death car” as the newspapers called it, didn’t stop; it came out of the gathering darkness, wavered tragically for a moment, and then disappeared around the next bend. Mavro Michaelis wasn’t even sure of its colour—he told the first policeman that it was light green. The other car, the one going toward New York, came to rest a hundred yards beyond, and its driver hurried back to where Myrtle Wilson, her life violently extinguished, knelt in the road and mingled her thick dark blood with the dust.
vi: "The Death Car," as the newspapers dubbed it, did not stop; it shot out from the blending darkness, swerving tragically back and forth, then disappeared as it sped past the curve in the road. Michaeils was not very sure about the color of the car; he reported to the first arriving police officer that the car was green. Another car, heading towards New York, stopped after about a hundred yards, and the driver hurried to Myrtle's body, where life had been tragically snuffed out, lying crumpled on the road, in a pool of thick, dark blood mixed with the dust of the road.
tr: The car, referred to as the ‘death vehicle’ in the newspapers, continued on its way without slowing down after the incident. A few meters later, it seemed to hesitate, not knowing what to do. Then it turned onto a nearby road, blending into the encroaching darkness and disappearing from sight. Michaelis couldn’t quite make out the color of the car. In his initial statement to the police, he said it was light green. The other car heading towards New York had stopped a few meters away. Its driver ran towards Myrtle Wilson, who had met a brutal end in the middle of the road, her dark blood mingling with the dust.
es: The "death car," as the newspapers called it, did not stop; it emerged from the increasingly dark night, tragically hesitated for a moment, and disappeared around the nearest curve. Michaelis was not sure of the color: he told the first policeman that it was light green. Another car, heading towards New York, stopped almost a hundred meters further on, and its driver hurried back to where Myrtle Wilson, after violently losing her life, had ended up kneeling on the road, mixing her thick, dark blood with the dust.

en: Michaelis and this man reached her first, but when they had torn open her shirtwaist, still damp with perspiration, they saw that her left breast was swinging loose like a flap, and there was no need to listen for the heart beneath. The mouth was wide open and ripped a little at the corners, as though she had choked a little in giving up the tremendous vitality she had stored so long.
vi: Michaelis and this man were the first two to reach Myrtle's body, but when they tore open her sweat-drenched shirt, they saw that her left chest had been torn open like a wing, making it unnecessary to listen for breath beneath her ribcage. Her mouth was wide open, torn at the corners, as if she had choked while expelling the fierce vitality she had stored within herself for so long.
tr: The first to reach the woman were Michaelis and that man. When they tore Myrtle's blouse, still wet with sweat, they saw her left breast torn and flapping like a wing. There was no need to listen to see if her heart was beating. The corners of her open mouth were torn, as if struggling to stop the great energy she had carried in her body for years from escaping.
es: That man and Michaelis arrived first, but when they tore open her blouse, still damp with sweat, they saw that her left breast, loose, moved like a flap, and it was unnecessary to try to hear the heartbeat. Her mouth had opened wide, with the corners slightly torn, as if it had been traumatic for her to release the tremendous vitality she had accumulated for so long.

en: We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away.
vi: We saw about three or four cars parked and a crowd when we were still some distance away.
tr: As we approached the scene, we immediately noticed three or four cars parked on the side of the road and the gathered crowd.
es: We saw the three or four cars and the group of people when we were still at a certain distance.

en: “Wreck!” said Tom. “That’s good. Wilson’ll have a little business at last.”
vi: "Car crash." Tom said. "That's good." "Finally, Wilson will have something to do."
tr: “There is rubble,” said Tom, “at least Wilson has some work to do.”
es: —An accident! —said Tom—. That's good. Finally, Wilson will have some work.

en: He slowed down, but still without any intention of stopping, until, as we came nearer, the hushed, intent faces of the people at the garage door made him automatically put on the brakes.
vi: Tom slowed the car down but had no intention of stopping until we got closer; the tense, silent faces of the people standing at the garage door immediately made him hit the brakes.
tr: We had slowed down, but Tom had no intention of stopping until he noticed the silence and the expressions on the faces of those standing at the door of the repair shop. As soon as he saw the situation, he hit the brakes.
es: He slowed down, although he still had no intention of stopping, until, closer, the muted and concentrated faces of the people at the garage door forced him to brake automatically.

en: “We’ll take a look,” he said doubtfully, “just a look.”
vi: "Let's go in and take a look," Tom said doubtfully. "Just to look."
tr: "Let's go and see," he said, pausing a little, "we'll be right back."
es: —Let's take a look —he said, unsure—, just a look.

en: I became aware now of a hollow, wailing sound which issued incessantly from the garage, a sound which as we got out of the coupé and walked toward the door resolved itself into the words “Oh, my God!” uttered over and over in a gasping moan.
vi: I began to notice the continuous, hoarse sound of crying coming from the repair shop as we stepped out of the car as I moved towards the door, this sound transformed into gasping moans of "Oh my God" repeated over and over.
tr: I could hear a sound similar to crying echoing in the workshop. As I got out of the car and walked towards the door, the incessant moans turned into the repeatedly uttered words "Oh my God!"
es: I became aware at that moment of a dull, plaintive sound that was incessantly emanating from the garage, a sound that, as we got out of the coupe and approached the door, turned into the words "My God, my God," whispered over and over in a kind of death rattle.

en: “There’s some bad trouble here,” said Tom excitedly.
vi: "Something bad is happening here." Tom said excitedly.
tr: "Bad things have happened here!" said Tom excitedly.
es: —Something serious has happened here —said Tom, worried.

en: He reached up on tiptoes and peered over a circle of heads into the garage, which was lit only by a yellow light in a swinging metal basket overhead. Then he made a harsh sound in his throat, and with a violent thrusting movement of his powerful arms pushed his way through.
vi: He stood on tiptoe to look over the heads of the crowd into the repair shop, which was only dimly lit by a yellow light placed inside a zinc basket hanging loosely overhead. Tom let out a gruff sound from his throat and forcefully used his muscular arms to push the crowd aside to step forward.
tr: He looked at the workshop illuminated by the yellow light inside a hanging wire basket, rising on his tiptoes over the circle of human heads. He let out a painful sound from the depths of his chest and pushed the crowd aside with his strong arms, diving inside.
es: She stood on tiptoe to look over a circle of heads into the garage's interior, illuminated by a solitary yellow light that, protected by a metal grille, hung from the ceiling. Her throat then emitted a hoarse sound, and, shoving, she made her way through with the strength of her arms.

en: The circle closed up again with a running murmur of expostulation; it was a minute before I could see anything at all. Then new arrivals deranged the line, and Jordan and I were pushed suddenly inside.
vi: The circle of the crowd immediately closed up again with murmurs of criticism and comments, and it took me about a minute to see everything clearly. Then the newcomers disturbed the crowd again, and Jordan and I were suddenly pushed inside.
tr: After he passed, it took me some time to see anything because people had resumed their old places with murmurs full of criticism. However, as the surroundings became more lively with the newcomers, Jordan and I found ourselves pushed inside.
es: The circle closed again with an energetic murmur of protest and for a moment I couldn't see anything. Then more people arrived, the line broke, and suddenly, Jordan and I were pushed inside.

en: Myrtle Wilson’s body, wrapped in a blanket, and then in another blanket, as though she suffered from a chill in the hot night, lay on a worktable by the wall, and Tom, with his back to us, was bending over it, motionless. Next to him stood a motorcycle policeman taking down names with much sweat and correction in a little book. At first I couldn’t find the source of the high, groaning words that echoed clamorously through the bare garage—then I saw Wilson standing on the raised threshold of his office, swaying back and forth and holding to the doorposts with both hands. Some man was talking to him in a low voice and attempting, from time to time, to lay a hand on his shoulder, but Wilson neither heard nor saw. His eyes would drop slowly from the swinging light to the laden table by the wall, and then jerk back to the light again, and he gave out incessantly his high, horrible call:
vi: The body of Myrtle Wilson was wrapped inside a blanket, with an additional blanket outside, as if she were experiencing a chill on a hot evening. The body was placed on the work table by the wall. Tom was then turning his back to us, leaning forward, motionless. Beside him was a motorcycle policeman, laboriously writing a name into a small notebook, sweating profusely and crossing out repeatedly. At first, I couldn't identify whose high-pitched groans were echoing loudly in the empty garage, but then I realized Wilson was standing on the step of his office, swaying back and forth, gripping the doorpost with both hands. A man was speaking softly to Wilson and occasionally placing a hand on his shoulder, but Wilson seemed neither to hear nor see anything. His eyes slowly roved from the swaying lamp to the heavy table by the wall and then back to the lamp, continuously uttering shrill, mournful cries:
tr: Myrtie Wilson's body, wrapped in two blankets as if she were cold despite the warm night, was lying on the large counter against the wall, and Tom, who had his back to us, was leaning over her, standing still. The motorcycle policeman next to him was taking notes in his notebook, sweating profusely and making a great effort to correct his mistakes. When I first entered, I couldn't find the source of the wailing that echoed in the empty, bare repair shop. Then I saw Wilson, swaying back and forth, holding onto either side of the door at the high threshold of the place used as an office. Next to him stood a man trying to console him, occasionally placing his hand on Wilson's shoulder. Wilson neither saw nor heard him. He would shift his gaze from the lamp above to the table against the wall, then suddenly look back at the lamp again, his terrible moaning echoing through the place.
es: The body of Myrtle Wilson, covered by a blanket over which another blanket had been thrown, as if she had felt cold that hot night, lay on a worktable, next to the wall, and Tom, with his back to us, was leaning over it, motionless. Beside him, a traffic policeman, sweating and making many corrections, was jotting down names in a notebook. At first, I couldn't locate the source of the words and the sharp wails that echoed loudly in the unfurnished garage, and then I saw Wilson, in the doorway of his office, standing on the only step, swaying, clutching the door jambs with both hands. A man was speaking to him in a low voice and, from time to time, tried to put a hand on his shoulder, but Wilson neither heard nor saw. He very slowly lowered his eyes, from the light hanging from the ceiling to the table and its burden next to the wall, only to return with a spasm to the light, without ever ceasing his sharp and terrible cry:

en: “Oh, my Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od! Oh, Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od!”
vi: "Oh my God, oh my.... God! oh my.... God! oh my.... God!"
tr: He kept saying, 'Oh. God! Oh my God! Oh God! God!’
es: —My God! My God! My God!

en: Presently Tom lifted his head with a jerk and, after staring around the garage with glazed eyes, addressed a mumbled incoherent remark to the policeman.
vi: At that moment, Tom abruptly lifted his head, staring around the garage with vacant eyes, then mumbled something to the police officer that was inaudible.
tr: At one point, Tom lifted his head and cast his vacant gaze around. Then he turned to the police and mumbled something.
es: Suddenly, as if startled, Tom lifted his head and, after scanning the garage with a glassy gaze, mumbled something incoherent to the policeman.

en: “M-a-v—” the policeman was saying, “—o—”
vi: "M-a-y." The policeman said, "-o-"
tr: “M-a-v,” said the policeman. “h…”
es: —E, m, a, v... —said the policeman at that moment—, o...

en: “No, r—” corrected the man, “M-a-v-r-o—”
vi: "No, r-" the police officer corrected himself, "M-a-v-r-o-"
tr: "No, there's an 'r' in between," someone corrected, "M-a-v-r-o-"
es: —No, it's erre… —corrected the man—. E, m, a, r, r, o…

en: “Listen to me!” muttered Tom fiercely.
vi: "Listen to me!" Tom growled fiercely.
tr: "Listen to me," said Tom angrily.
es: —Pay attention to me! —murmured Tom, fiercely.

en: “r—” said the policeman, “o—”
vi: "r" the policeman said, "o-"
tr: “-r” said the police, “o”
es: —uh… —said the policeman—, or…

en: “g—” He looked up as Tom’s broad hand fell sharply on his shoulder. “What you want, fella?”
vi: "W-" He looked up when Tom's large hand clapped heavily on his shoulder. "What do you need, buddy?" "What happened?"
tr: “G” he said as Tom's big hand landed on his shoulder. “What do you want, sir?”
es: —Wh… —he looked up when Tom's broad hand suddenly fell on his shoulder—. What do you want, friend?

en: “What happened?—that’s what I want to know.”
vi: "That's what I want to know."
tr: "What happened? I want to know that."
es: —What happened? That's what I want to know.

en: “Auto hit her. Ins’antly killed.”
vi: "The car hit her. She died instantly."
tr: “A car hit him. He died instantly.”
es: —A car hit her. It killed her instantly.

en: “Instantly killed,” repeated Tom, staring.
vi: "Instant death." Tom repeated, staring intently.
tr: “He died instantly,” said Tom, looking at the table.
es: —He killed her on the spot —repeated Tom, with a distant look.

en: “She ran out ina road. Son-of-a-bitch didn’t even stopus car.”
vi: "She ran out onto the street, The bastard didn't stop the car at all."
