tr: “The woman suddenly jumped onto the road. The one who hit… pulled the child and left without stopping.”
es: —He ran out onto the road. That son of a bitch didn't even stop the car.

en: “There was two cars,” said Michaelis, “one comin’, one goin’, see?”
vi: "There were two cars in all." Michaelis said. "One coming, one going, understand?"
tr: “There were two cars,” said Michaelis, “One was coming and the other was going, do you understand?”
es: —There were two cars —said Michaelis—. One was going and the other was coming, do you understand?

en: “Going where?” asked the policeman keenly.
vi: "Where are you running to?" the police officer asked enthusiastically.
tr: “Where were they going?” said the police with interest.
es: —Where was I going? —asked the police officer with great interest.

en: “One goin’ each way. Well, she”—his hand rose toward the blankets but stopped halfway and fell to his side—“she ran out there an’ the one comin’ from N’York knock right into her, goin’ thirty or forty miles an hour.”
vi: "Each one went in a different direction." “She...” Michaelis raised his hand to point towards the blanket, but his arm fell to his side halfway through the motion. "She ran outside." "The car coming from New York hit her, it was going about thirty or forty miles an hour at the time."
tr: “They were going in separate directions. The woman…” she was about to point to the pile of blankets but changed her mind, “darted out of the garage and the car coming from the direction of New York hit her. It was going at fifty or sixty.”
es: —Each one in a different direction. Well, she… —the hand lifted towards the blankets but stopped halfway and fell back to her side—. She ran out and the car coming from New York hit her directly. It was going fifty or sixty kilometers per hour.

en: “What’s the name of this place here?” demanded the officer.
vi: "What is this place called?" the police officer asked.
tr: "What is this place called?" asked the Police.
es: —What is this place called? —asked the agent.

en: “Hasn’t got any name.”
vi: "No name at all."
tr: "It has no name"
es: —It has no name.

en: A pale well-dressed negro stepped near.
vi: A well-dressed black man, looking pale, approached.
tr: A pale-skinned, well-dressed black man approached them.
es: A pale black man, well-dressed, approached.

en: “It was a yellow car,” he said, “big yellow car. New.”
vi: He spoke. "The yellow car. The big yellow car. Still new. "
tr: “It was a yellow car,” he said. “A huge yellow car. Brand new.”
es: —It was a yellow car —he said—, yellow and big. New.

en: “See the accident?” asked the policeman.
vi: "Did you witness the accident?" the police officer asked.
tr: "Did you see the accident?" asked the police.
es: —Did you see the accident? —asked the police officer.

en: “No, but the car passed me down the road, going faster’n forty. Going fifty, sixty.”
vi: "No, but the car passed by me at the end of the road, going faster than forty miles. Around fifty, sixty."
tr: “No, but it sped past me down the road. It wasn't fifty or sixty, it was seventy or eighty kilometers per hour.”
es: —No, but the car passed by me on the road. It was going over sixty. It was going eighty or ninety.

en: “Come here and let’s have your name. Look out now. I want to get his name.”
vi: "Come over here so I can write down your name." "Move aside." "I want to write down his name."
tr: "Come this way, let me take your name. Be careful. I'm trying to learn the man's name."
es: —Come and tell me your name. Now, silence. I want to write down your name.

en: Some words of this conversation must have reached Wilson, swaying in the office door, for suddenly a new theme found voice among his grasping cries:
vi: Surely some of these conversations must have reached Wilson's ears as he was swaying behind the office door, because right after that his crying took on a new tone.
tr: Some of the words spoken in this conversation must have reached Wilson's ears, who was hanging around the office door. He stopped his lament.
es: Some words from the conversation must have reached Wilson, who was swaying in the office doorway, because suddenly a new topic found voice among his moaning shouts.

en: “You don’t have to tell me what kind of car it was! I know what kind of car it was!”
vi: "No need to tell me what kind of car that is. Because I know what kind of car it is."
tr: "You don't need to tell me what kind of car it is. I know it!" he shouted.
es: —You don't need to tell me what the car was like! I know what it was like!

en: Watching Tom, I saw the wad of muscle back of his shoulder tighten under his coat. He walked quickly over to Wilson and, standing in front of him, seized him firmly by the upper arms.
vi: Observing Tom, I noticed the muscles on his back tensing up under his coat. He quickly walked towards Wilson, stood right in front of him, and wrapped his arms tightly around him.
tr: I looked at Tom, it was evident that his back muscles were tensed under his jacket. He went over to Wilson and grabbed the man tightly by his upper arms.
es: I looked at Tom and saw the muscles in his back tense under his jacket. He went towards where Wilson was and, stopping in front of him, grabbed him firmly by the arms.

en: “You’ve got to pull yourself together,” he said with soothing gruffness.
vi: "You need to calm down." Tom said in a rough soothing voice.
tr: "You need to pull yourself together!" he said, his voice both stern and soothing.
es: —You have to get a grip —he said brusquely, to reassure him.

en: Wilson’s eyes fell upon Tom; he started up on his tiptoes and then would have collapsed to his knees had not Tom held him upright.
vi: Wilson's eyes recognized Tom, he stood up on his tiptoes but then collapsed to his knees if Tom hadn't supported him to stand upright.
tr: Wilson lifted his head and tried to rise on his tiptoes. If Tom hadn't held him, his knees would have buckled, and he would have fallen.
es: Wilson's eyes fixed on Tom. He rose up on his tiptoes, and if Tom hadn't caught him, he would have collapsed to his knees.

en: “Listen,” said Tom, shaking him a little. “I just got here a minute ago, from New York. I was bringing you that coupé we’ve been talking about. That yellow car I was driving this afternoon wasn’t mine—do you hear? I haven’t seen it all afternoon.”
vi: "Listen here," Tom said, shaking Wilson a little. "I just got here from New York about a minute ago. I brought you the coupe we discussed. The yellow car I was driving this afternoon isn't mine. Did you hear what I said? I haven't seen it all afternoon."
tr: “Listen to me!” said Tom, shaking her, “I just came from New York. I was bringing you the sports car I promised. The yellow car I was driving this afternoon wasn't mine. Do you understand? I haven't seen it for hours.”
es: —Listen —said Tom, shaking him—. I just arrived from New York a moment ago. I brought the coupe we had talked about. The yellow car I was driving this afternoon is not mine. Do you hear me? I haven't seen you all afternoon.

en: Only the negro and I were near enough to hear what he said, but the policeman caught something in the tone and looked over with truculent eyes.
vi: Only the black guy and I stood close enough to hear what Tom was saying, but the policeman seemed to have guessed something from the tone of voice and watched with aggressive eyes.
tr: Only I and that well-dressed black man had heard what he said. But the police must have discovered something suspicious in Tom's tone of voice, as they turned their stern gaze towards us.
es: The black man and I were the only ones close enough to hear what Tom was saying, but the policeman caught something in the tone of his voice and looked at us with hostile eyes.

en: “What’s all that?” he demanded.
vi: "What's going on?" he asked.
tr: “What is happening there?” he asked.
es: —What's going on there? —he asked.

en: “I’m a friend of his.” Tom turned his head but kept his hands firm on Wilson’s body. “He says he knows the car that did it… It was a yellow car.”
vi: "I am his friend." Tom turned his head to answer but his hands still tightly gripped Wilson. "He said he knew the car that caused the accident. It was a yellow car."
tr: “What is happening there?” he asked. Tom turned his head but did not take his hands off Wilson's body. “I am a close friend of this man. He says he saw the car that caused the accident... it was a yellow car.”
es: —I am his friend —Tom turned his head, but his hands continued to firmly hold Wilson's body—. He says he knows the car from the accident… It was a yellow car.

en: Some dim impulse moved the policeman to look suspiciously at Tom.
vi: A slight urge arose in his heart, and the police officer looked at Tom suspiciously.
tr: The police looked at Tom with suspicion, driven by an impulse that was hard to understand.
es: By some indeterminate instinct, the police officer considered Tom suspicious.

en: “And what colour’s your car?”
vi: "And what color is your car?"
tr: "What color is your car?" he asked.
es: —And what color is his car?

en: “It’s a blue car, a coupé.”
vi: "Blue color, type of cub bike."
tr: “Blue, blue sport.”
es: —Blue. It's a coupe.

en: “We’ve come straight from New York,” I said.
vi: "We traveled from New York." I said.
tr: "We just arrived from New York," I said.
es: —We have come directly from New York —I said.

en: Someone who had been driving a little behind us confirmed this, and the policeman turned away.
vi: Someone who had been driving behind our car confirmed this, and so the police officer turned away.
tr: Upon one of the cars behind us on the road confirming this, the police moved away from us.
es: One person who had followed us with his car for a while confirmed what I was saying, and the police officer turned around.

en: “Now, if you’ll let me have that name again correct—”
vi: "Now, if you let me write down the name correctly..."
tr: “Now, say your name properly so we can write it down,” he said, turning to the black man.
es: —Let's see if I can write your name correctly now…

en: Picking up Wilson like a doll, Tom carried him into the office, set him down in a chair, and came back.
vi: Wilson was lifted like a doll, Tom carried him into the office, sat him down on a chair, then turned around and left.
tr: Tom, who lifted Wilson like a baby and carried him into the office, sat him down on a chair and came over to us.
es: Grabbing Wilson like a doll, Tom put him in the office, sat him in a chair, and returned.

en: “If somebody’ll come here and sit with him,” he snapped authoritatively. He watched while the two men standing closest glanced at each other and went unwillingly into the room. Then Tom shut the door on them and came down the single step, his eyes avoiding the table. As he passed close to me he whispered: “Let’s get out.”
vi: "If someone comes here to sit with him." Tom said as if giving an order. Tom glanced as the two men standing closest exchanged looks and then reluctantly stepped into the room. Tom closed the door behind them and then stepped down a level, his eyes directed towards the table. As he got closer to me, he whispered, "Let's go."
tr: “Someone come here and sit next to the poor man,” he said in an authoritative voice. The two men closest to each other looked at each other's faces and reluctantly headed inside. Our guy didn't take his eyes off them until they entered through the door. Then he closed the door in between and came to us in one swift move, trying not to look at the table. "Let's get out of here," he whispered as he passed by me.
es: —Please, someone come and keep him company —he commanded with genuine authority. He remained vigilant until the two men who were closest exchanged a look and reluctantly entered the room. Tom then closed the door, stepped down the single step, and avoided looking toward the garage table. When he passed by me, he murmured: —Let's go.

en: Self-consciously, with his authoritative arms breaking the way, we pushed through the still gathering crowd, passing a hurried doctor, case in hand, who had been sent for in wild hope half an hour ago.
vi: Embarrassed and awkward, with Tom's authoritative arms clearing the way, we squeezed through the still-crowded throng, passing by a doctor hurrying along, carrying his tools, having been called about half an hour earlier with vain hopes.
tr: As he made his way through the ever-growing crowd with his strong arms, clearing a path ahead of us, he quickly entered with his bag in hand, passing by the doctor who had been summoned in a desperate attempt half an hour earlier.
es: Timidly, but with the authority of Tom's arms to clear the way, we advanced through the group of people, which continued to grow, and left behind a doctor who was arriving in a hurry with his briefcase in hand, and who had been called half an hour earlier in a burst of wild hope.

en: Tom drove slowly until we were beyond the bend—then his foot came down hard, and the coupé raced along through the night. In a little while I heard a low husky sob, and saw that the tears were overflowing down his face.
vi: Tom drove slowly until we passed the roundabout, then he pressed the accelerator hard, and the car sped into the darkness. After a while, I heard a low, muffled sobbing sound and saw tears streaming down Tom's face.
tr: We went slowly until we reached the upcoming bend. Then Tom suddenly stepped on the gas and the car shot forward like an arrow through the darkness. When I heard the sobs she was trying to suppress, I saw tears streaming down her cheeks.
es: Tom drove slowly until we passed the curve. Then he floored the accelerator and the coupe sped into the night at full speed. Shortly after, I heard a rough, stifled sob, and saw tears streaming down his face.

en: “The God damned coward!” he whimpered. “He didn’t even stop his car.”
vi: "You despicable coward!" Tom sobbed. "He didn't even stop the car."
tr: “Damn coward!” he muttered angrily, “He didn't even stop to look.”
es: —Damn cowardly son of a bitch! —he whimpered—. He didn't even stop.

en: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. Tom stopped beside the porch and looked up at the second floor, where two windows bloomed with light among the vines.
vi: The Buchanan family's house suddenly drifted towards us through the rustling shadows of the dark trees. Tom stopped the car beside the porch and looked up at the second floor where two windows were brightly lit amidst the vines.
tr: The Buchanan's mansion suddenly appeared through the dark tree trunks. Tom stood on the terrace and looked up. Light streaming from two windows on the second floor filtered through the ivy.
es: The Buchanan's house suddenly floated towards us through the murmur and darkness of the trees. Tom stopped in front of the porch and looked up at the second floor, where two windows opened illuminated among the vines.

en: “Daisy’s home,” he said. As we got out of the car he glanced at me and frowned slightly.
vi: "Daisy has gone home." Tom said. When we got out of the car, he glanced at me and slightly frowned.
tr: “Daisy has come,” said Tom while trying to get out of the car. Then, looking at my face and frowning slightly, “I wish I had dropped you off at West Egg, Nick.
es: —Daisy is at home —he said. As we got out of the car, he looked at me and furrowed his brow—.

en: “I ought to have dropped you in West Egg, Nick. There’s nothing we can do tonight.”
vi: "I should have taken you home to West Egg, Nick. There’s nothing more that can be done tonight."
tr: Then, looking at my face and frowning slightly, “I wish I had dropped you off at West Egg, Nick. There’s nothing we can do here tonight anyway.”
es: I should have left you in West Egg, Nick. Tonight we can't do anything.

en: A change had come over him, and he spoke gravely, and with decision. As we walked across the moonlight gravel to the porch he disposed of the situation in a few brisk phrases.
vi: A change had occurred in Tom; he spoke solemnly and decisively. As we walked across the gravel path bathed in moonlight towards the porch, Tom arranged the matter with a few brief sentences.
tr: His behavior was different from usual. His voice was more serious than usual, and his speech was more determined. As he approached the door, crushing the pebbles that shone in the moonlight, he intervened in the situation with a few short sentences.
es: He had undergone a change, and he spoke with gravity and decision. We walked by moonlight along the gravel path that leads to the porch, and Tom settled the situation with a couple of conclusive phrases.

en: “I’ll telephone for a taxi to take you home, and while you’re waiting you and Jordan better go in the kitchen and have them get you some supper—if you want any.” He opened the door. “Come in.”
vi: "I will call a taxi to take you home. In the meantime, you and Jordan should go into the kitchen so the staff can prepare something for you to eat, if you want anything. Please come in." Tom opened the door. "No, I won't come in, thank you.
tr: "Let me find a taxi to take you home. While you wait, you and Jordan can go to the kitchen and have something prepared to snack on. If you want, of course," he said, opening the door. "Come in."
es: —I will call a taxi to take you home, and while you wait, it's best if you go with Jordan to the kitchen so they can prepare some dinner for you, if you feel like it —he opened the door—. Come in.

en: “No, thanks. But I’d be glad if you’d order me the taxi. I’ll wait outside.”
vi: "No, I won't come in, thank you. But please call a taxi for me. I'll wait out here."
tr: “Thank you, I won't come in. But I would appreciate it if you could call a taxi. I'll wait outside.”
es: —No, thank you. But I would appreciate it if you could call me a taxi. I'll wait outside.

en: Jordan put her hand on my arm.
vi: Jordan wrapped his arm around mine.
tr: "Won't you come in, Nick?" said Jordan as she placed her hand on my arm.
es: Jordan put his hand on my arm.

en: “Won’t you come in, Nick?”
vi: "Aren't you coming in, Nick?"
tr: "Won't you come in, Nick?" said Jordan as she placed her hand on my arm.
es: —Don't you want to come in, Nick?

en: “No, thanks.”
vi: "No, thank you."
tr: “No, thank you!””
es: —No, thank you.

en: I was feeling a little sick and I wanted to be alone. But Jordan lingered for a moment more.
vi: I felt like I was sick and wanted to be alone, but Jordan stayed with me for a while.
tr: I was feeling a bit sick and wanted to be alone. But Jordan lingered by my side a little longer.
es: I felt bad and wanted to be alone. But Jordan insisted a little more.

en: “It’s only half-past nine,” she said.
vi: "It's only nine-thirty in the evening," Jordan said.
tr: “It's only half past nine,” he said.
es: —It's only nine-thirty —he said.

en: I’d be damned if I’d go in; I’d had enough of all of them for one day, and suddenly that included Jordan too. She must have seen something of this in my expression, for she turned abruptly away and ran up the porch steps into the house. I sat down for a few minutes with my head in my hands, until I heard the phone taken up inside and the butler’s voice calling a taxi. Then I walked slowly down the drive away from the house, intending to wait by the gate.
vi: I would be crazy to step into the house. I had endured them all day long and suddenly I felt the same way about Jordan. Jordan probably noticed my expression, so she turned abruptly and hurried up the porch into the house. I sat down for a few minutes, burying my head in my hands until I heard the phone ringing inside the house and the butler calling for a taxi. Then I slowly walked down the road, away from the house, intending to wait for the taxi at the gate.
tr: I absolutely did not want to go inside. What I had experienced was too much for one day. I was fed up with all of them, including Jordan. He must have finally understood, as he turned around, ran up the stairs, and went into the house. I sat on the steps with my head in my hands until I heard the servant inside pick up the receiver and call a taxi. Then I got up and walked slowly away from the house along the gravel path. My intention was to wait for the taxi in front of the garden gate.
es: Staying would have been a curse: an entire day in their company already seemed enough to me, and that, unexpectedly, also included Jordan, who must have sensed something of that in my expression, because he turned around, ran up the porch stairs, and went into the house. I sat for a while with my head in my hands until I heard the phone being picked up and the butler's voice asking for a taxi. Then I slowly walked down the path with the idea of waiting by the gate.

en: I hadn’t gone twenty yards when I heard my name and Gatsby stepped from between two bushes into the path. I must have felt pretty weird by that time, because I could think of nothing except the luminosity of his pink suit under the moon.
vi: I had not walked twenty meters when I heard someone calling my name. Gatsby stepped out from between two nearby bushes. I might have been feeling very strange because I couldn't think of anything else except the dazzling light of the pink suit Gatsby was wearing shining under the moonlight.
tr: I had taken a few steps when I heard my name being called and saw Gatsby emerging from the bushes at the side of the road. My mind must have been quite confused because I stood there doing nothing but thinking how beautifully his pink suit shone in the moonlight.
es: I had not gone twenty meters when I heard my name and Gatsby emerged from between two bushes. I must have been very distracted at that moment because all I could think about was the brightness of Gatsby's pink suit under the moon.

en: “What are you doing?” I inquired.
vi: "What are you doing here?" I asked.
tr: "What are you doing?" I asked.
es: —What are you doing? —I asked.

en: “Just standing here, old sport.”
vi: "Just stand here, old friend."
tr: “I'm just passing the time, buddy”
es: —Just being here, buddy.

en: Somehow, that seemed a despicable occupation. For all I knew he was going to rob the house in a moment; I wouldn’t have been surprised to see sinister faces, the faces of “Wolfshiem’s people,” behind him in the dark shrubbery.
vi: It seems that the act is of a despicable and vile profession. I could only think that he was preparing to rob the house. I might not be surprised if I saw the vicious faces, the faces of Wolfsheim's henchmen, standing behind Gatsby, hidden in the dark bushes.
tr: For some reason, this seemed like a despicable endeavor to me. He might attempt to rob the house soon. I wouldn't be surprised to see Wolfsheim's men or other sinister faces emerging from those dark bushes.
es: It seemed to me a despicable occupation, I don't know why. For all I knew, he could rob the house at any moment; I wouldn't have been surprised to see the sinister faces of "Wolfshiem's gang" behind him, in the darkness of the bushes,

en: “Did you see any trouble on the road?” he asked after a minute.
vi: "Did you see what happened on the road?" Gatsby asked after a minute.
tr: "Did you see anything bad on the way here?" he asked a minute later.
es: —Have you seen anything on the road? —he asked after a few seconds.

en: “Yes.”
vi: "Yes."
tr: "Yes"
es: —Yes.

en: He hesitated.
vi: Gatsby hesitated
tr: He hesitated.
es: —Yes.

en: “Was she killed?”
vi: "Is the woman dead?"
tr: “So, is he dead?” he asked.
es: —Has he died?

en: “Yes.”
vi: "That's right."
tr: “Yes.” “I understood.
es: —Yes.

en: “I thought so; I told Daisy I thought so. It’s better that the shock should all come at once. She stood it pretty well.”
vi: "I think so too. I told Daisy I thought so too. It's also good that the shocks all come at once. She endures quite well."
tr: I even told Daisy. I thought it was appropriate for her to learn immediately. She held up quite well, all things considered.”
es: —That's what I thought, and I told Daisy. It was better for her to get the impression all at once. She handled it very well.

en: He spoke as if Daisy’s reaction was the only thing that mattered.
vi: Gatsby said it was as if only Daisy's reaction was the only thing that mattered.
tr: It was as if he was talking as though only Daisy's reaction mattered.
es: He spoke as if Daisy's reaction were the only thing that mattered.

en: “I got to West Egg by a side road,” he went on, “and left the car in my garage. I don’t think anybody saw us, but of course I can’t be sure.”
vi: "I returned to West Egg by a different route." Gatsby continued. "Then I put the car in the garage. I don't think anyone saw us, but I'm not entirely sure."
tr: “Eve, I came from the less-used side road. I put the car in the garage,” he continued. “I don't think anyone saw me, but I'm not entirely sure.”
es: —I went to West Egg by a back road —he continued— and left the car in my garage. I think no one saw us, but, of course, I'm not sure.

en: I disliked him so much by this time that I didn’t find it necessary to tell him he was wrong.
vi: At this moment, I truly hated Gatsby and didn't feel sorry for him or that he had misspoken.
tr: I hated him so much that I didn't even bother to tell him he was wrong.
es: It had become so unpleasant for me that I didn't consider it necessary to tell him that he was wrong.

en: “Who was the woman?” he inquired.
vi: "Who is that woman?" Gatsby asked.
tr: “Who is that woman?” he asked.
es: —Who was the woman? —he asked.

en: “Her name was Wilson. Her husband owns the garage. How the devil did it happen?”
vi: "Her last name is Wilson. Her husband is a garage owner. How did this atrocious incident happen?"
tr: “Her name is Wilson. She is the wife of the owner of the repair shop. How the damn accident happened.”
es: —His name was Wilson. Her husband is the owner of the garage. How the hell did it happen?

en: “Well, I tried to swing the wheel—” He broke off, and suddenly I guessed at the truth.
vi: "Actually, I tried to swerve the steering wheel." Gatsby left the sentence unfinished, and suddenly I guessed the truth.
tr: “Actually, I tried to turn the steering wheel, but...” When I suddenly stopped, I understood the truth.
es: —I tried to turn the steering wheel… —he stopped talking and suddenly I guessed the truth.

en: “Was Daisy driving?”
vi: "Was Daisy the one driving at that time?" "Right." It took Gatsby a while to respond.
tr: “Was Daisy the one driving the car?”
es: —Was Daisy driving?

en: “Yes,” he said after a moment, “but of course I’ll say I was. You see, when we left New York she was very nervous and she thought it would steady her to drive—and this woman rushed out at us just as we were passing a car coming the other way. It all happened in a minute, but it seemed to me that she wanted to speak to us, thought we were somebody she knew. Well, first Daisy turned away from the woman toward the other car, and then she lost her nerve and turned back. The second my hand reached the wheel I felt the shock—it must have killed her instantly.”
vi: "But of course, I will say that I was the one driving. You know, when we left New York, she was very emotional and wanted to drive to calm down. As our car had just passed a car going in the opposite direction, that woman suddenly ran out and collided with our car. It all happened in a minute; it seemed like she wanted to talk to us, she thought we were someone she knew. At first, Daisy swerved to avoid the woman towards the other car, but then Daisy became scared and turned the wheel back. The moment I grabbed the wheel, I felt There was a strong collision. The woman must have been killed on the spot."
tr: “Yes,” he said and paused for a moment, then, “But of course, I'll say I was driving. He was very angry when we left New York. He thought he would calm down a bit if he took the wheel. As we were passing by the car coming from the opposite direction, that woman jumped in front of us. Everything happened in an instant. For some reason, it seemed to me that the woman wanted to talk to us. I guess she thought there was someone she knew in the car. Daisy first swerved the wheel towards the car passing by us, then panicked and turned it the other way. The moment I reached for the wheel, I felt the impact. She must have died immediately.”
es: —Yes —he said after a few seconds—, but I will say that it was me, of course. You know, when we left New York she was very nervous and thought that driving would calm her down… And that woman appeared running just as we were passing a car coming in the opposite direction. Everything happened in an instant, but I think the woman wanted to tell us something, that she mistook us for someone she knew. Well, Daisy first turned towards the other car to avoid the woman, but then she lost her nerve and turned back. At the moment my hand reached the steering wheel, I felt the impact. It must have killed her instantly.

en: “It ripped her open—”
vi: "It tore her body apart..."
tr: "His chest is shattered,"
es: —He destroyed it.

en: “Don’t tell me, old sport.” He winced. “Anyhow—Daisy stepped on it. I tried to make her stop, but she couldn’t, so I pulled on the emergency brake. Then she fell over into my lap and I drove on.
vi: "Don't tell me, old sport." Gatsby shrank back in fear. "Anyway, Daisy hit the brakes. I tried to help Daisy stop the car, but she couldn't do it, so I pulled the emergency brake. Daisy collapsed onto my lap, and I had to take over and continue driving.
tr: “It would be better if you don't tell, buddy,” he said, shuddering, “anyway, Daisy floored the gas pedal. I tried to make her stop. But she just couldn't do it. Then I pulled the handbrake. She collapsed into my lap, half-unconscious. So I continued driving.”
es: —Don't tell me, buddy —he made a gesture of pain—. Well, Daisy sped up. I tried to make her stop, but she couldn't, so I pulled the handbrake. Then she threw herself into my arms and I kept driving.

en: “She’ll be all right tomorrow,” he said presently. “I’m just going to wait here and see if he tries to bother her about that unpleasantness this afternoon. She’s locked herself into her room, and if he tries any brutality she’s going to turn the light out and on again.”
vi: "By tomorrow Daisy will be fine." Gatsby continued. "I will stand here to see if Tom bothers Daisy about this afternoon. Daisy locked herself in the room. If he behaves violently, Daisy will turn the light on and off as a signal to me."
tr: He paused and thought for a moment. “There will be nothing left for tomorrow,” she said, “I want to stay here and prevent Tom from bothering him because of the unpleasant incident in the afternoon. She locked herself in her room. If her husband resorts to brute force, she will signal by turning the lights on and off.”
es: She'll be fine tomorrow —he added quickly—. I'm going to wait here in case he tries to bother her because of what happened this afternoon, so unpleasant. She has locked herself in her room, and if he tries any brutality, she'll turn the light on and off several times.

en: “He won’t touch her,” I said. “He’s not thinking about her.”
vi: "Tom doesn't touch Daisy. He isn't thinking about Daisy at the moment."
tr: “He won't do anything,” I said, “Right now, he's not thinking about Daisy.”
es: —Tom won't touch it —I said—. He doesn't think about it.

en: “I don’t trust him, old sport.”
vi: "I don't trust him, old friend."
tr: “I don't trust her, buddy.”
es: —I don't trust him, mate.

en: “How long are you going to wait?”
vi: "How long do you plan to wait here?"
tr: “How long will you wait?”
es: —How long are you going to wait?

en: “All night, if necessary. Anyhow, till they all go to bed.”
vi: "All night, if necessary." "At least until they all go to sleep."
tr: “If necessary, all night. At least until everyone goes to bed.”
es: —All night, if necessary. At least until everyone goes to bed.

en: A new point of view occurred to me. Suppose Tom found out that Daisy had been driving. He might think he saw a connection in it—he might think anything. I looked at the house; there were two or three bright windows downstairs and the pink glow from Daisy’s room on the ground floor.
vi: I suddenly had a new perspective. Suppose if Tom found out that Daisy was the one driving the car, he might think he saw a connection - he might come up with all sorts of things. I looked at the house, two or three windows on the lower floor were lit, and Daisy's room on the second floor was also glowing with a pink light.
tr: There was a topic that was on my mind. I assumed that Tom realized Daisy was driving the car. He might have thought there was an intent or a connection. In fact, anything could have come to his mind. I turned my head and looked at their house. There were lights in two or three of the ground floor windows. On the upper floor, except for Daisy's room, the others were dark.
es: Then I saw the matter from another perspective. Suppose Tom discovered that the one driving was Daisy. He could sense some connection, anything... I looked toward the house; there were two or three windows with light, and on the second floor, the pink glow of Daisy's room.

en: “You wait here,” I said. “I’ll see if there’s any sign of a commotion.”
vi: "You wait here. I'll go in and check for any signs of trouble."
tr: “Wait here,” I said, “let me go and check if there is a problem!””
es: —Wait here —I said to Gatsby—. I'm going to see if there's any sign of trouble.

en: I walked back along the border of the lawn, traversed the gravel softly, and tiptoed up the veranda steps. The drawing-room curtains were open, and I saw that the room was empty. Crossing the porch where we had dined that June night three months before, I came to a small rectangle of light which I guessed was the pantry window. The blind was drawn, but I found a rift at the sill.
vi: I said. I stepped back to the edge of the grass, gently walked back along the small path, then cautiously stepped up the steps of the porch. The living room curtains were still open, and I saw that the room was empty. Crossing the porch where we had once sat and eaten on an evening in June three months ago, I approached a square window illuminated by light, which I guessed was the kitchen window. The curtain had been lowered, but I found a gap at the side of the door.
tr: I walked towards the house from the edge of the green area. I quietly crossed the gravel path and reached the back. Tiptoeing, I climbed the steps of the terrace. The curtain of the living room was open. There was no one inside. After passing the veranda where we had dinner three months ago on a June evening, I saw a rectangular-shaped light. This must have been the kitchen window. The curtains were closed, but I found a small gap and looked inside.
es: I returned skirting the lawn, crossed the gravel path without making a sound, and tiptoed up the steps of the gallery. The living room curtains were open, and I checked that there was no one in the room. Passing the porch where we had dined that night in June three months earlier, I reached a small rectangle of light that I imagined to be the window of the scullery. The shutter was down, but I discovered a crack in the windowsill.

en: Daisy and Tom were sitting opposite each other at the kitchen table, with a plate of cold fried chicken between them, and two bottles of ale. He was talking intently across the table at her, and in his earnestness his hand had fallen upon and covered her own. Once in a while she looked up at him and nodded in agreement.
vi: Daisy and Tom are sitting opposite each other at the table in the kitchen, with a plate of cold fried chicken and two bottles of wine in front of them. Across the table, Tom is engrossed in conversation with Daisy, his hand earnestly holding Daisy's hand. Occasionally, Daisy looks up at Tom and nods in agreement.
tr: Daisy and Tom were sitting at the kitchen table. In the middle of the table, there was a plate with fried chicken, and in front of them, there were glasses of non-alcoholic beer. Tom was leaning towards Daisy, excitedly telling her something. His hand was on the table, over his wife's hand. Every now and then, Daisy would lift her head to look at him, nodding to show she agreed with what he was saying.
es: Daisy and Tom sat at the kitchen table, facing each other, with a plate of cold chicken between them and two bottles of beer. He spoke with absolute concentration and, very seriously, placed his hand on Daisy's hand, covering it. From time to time, she would look up, look at him, and nod her head.

en: They weren’t happy, and neither of them had touched the chicken or the ale—and yet they weren’t unhappy either. There was an unmistakable air of natural intimacy about the picture, and anybody would have said that they were conspiring together.
vi: The two of them did not look happy; neither touched the chicken or the bottle of wine. However, they were not miserable either. There was an unmistakable closeness in this scene, anyone could see that the two of them were plotting and scheming together.
tr: They didn't look very happy. They hadn't touched the food in front of them, but they weren't unhappy either. In the visible scene, it was clear that there was an undeniable closeness between the couple. Anyone who saw them would think they were planning something together.
es: They were sad, and they hadn't touched either the chicken or the beer, but they didn't feel miserable. There was an air of intimacy, of naturalness in the scene, and anyone would have taken them for two conspirators.

en: As I tiptoed from the porch I heard my taxi feeling its way along the dark road toward the house. Gatsby was waiting where I had left him in the drive.
vi: As I tiptoed out from the porch, I heard the sound of a taxi and sensed it was driving down the dark road towards the house. Gatsby was still standing there, where I had left him on the road.
tr: As I tiptoed down the stairs and turned back, I heard the summoned taxi advancing towards the house on the dark road. Gatsby was waiting for me where I had left him.
es: When I was tiptoeing out of the porch, I heard my taxi approaching the house on the dark road. Gatsby was waiting on the path, where I had left him.

en: “Is it all quiet up there?” he asked anxiously.
vi: "Is it quiet up there now?" Gatsby asked anxiously.
tr: "How is it, is everything calm?" he asked anxiously.
es: —Is everything calm? —he asked me, worried.

en: “Yes, it’s all quiet.” I hesitated. “You’d better come home and get some sleep.”
vi: "Yes, everything is silent now." I hesitated. "You'd better go home to sleep."
tr: “Yes, yes, calm down,” I said, and after pausing for a moment, I couldn't help but add, “You should come home with me and get some sleep too.”
es: —Yes, everything is calm —I stammered—. It would be better if you came home to sleep.

en: He shook his head.
vi: Gatsby shook his head.
tr: He shook his head from side to side.
es: He shook his head no.

en: “I want to wait here till Daisy goes to bed. Good night, old sport.”
vi: "I want to wait here until Daisy goes to sleep. Goodbye, old friend."
tr: "I want to wait here until he goes to bed. Good night, buddy," he said.
es: —I will wait here until Daisy goes to bed. Good night, buddy.

en: He put his hands in his coat pockets and turned back eagerly to his scrutiny of the house, as though my presence marred the sacredness of the vigil. So I walked away and left him standing there in the moonlight—watching over nothing.
vi: Gatsby put his hands into his coat pockets and turned back to continue his watch, as if my presence would ruin the sanctity of what he was doing. Therefore, I left him standing under the moonlight, keeping watch over nothing.
tr: He put his hands in his pockets and turned his back. He was ready to continue watching the house. He acted as if my presence was hindering his sacred duty. I left him waiting under the moonlight, keeping watch over something that wasn't there. I walked away and got into a taxi.
es: He put his hands in the pockets of his jacket and once again scrutinized the house jealously, as if my presence tainted the sanctity of his sentinel mission. So I left and left him there, in the moonlight, watching over nothing.

en: VIII
vi: Chapter 8
tr: CHAPTER 8

en: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. Toward dawn I heard a taxi go up Gatsby’s drive, and immediately I jumped out of bed and began to dress—I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and morning would be too late.
vi: The entire night I couldn't sleep, the foghorn for ships at sea wailed continuously, echoing outside the strait. I tossed and turned as if in a half-sick state, caught between absurd truths and terrifying nightmares. As dawn approached, I heard the sound of a taxi driving into Gatsby's driveway, and I immediately jumped out of bed and got dressed. I felt I had to tell Gatsby something, to warn him. I feared that if I waited until morning, it would be too late.
tr: I couldn't sleep all night; amidst the incessantly blowing foghorns on the Bosphorus, I was tossed between bizarre realities and wild, terrifying dreams. As dawn was breaking, I heard the sound of a taxi turning onto Gatsby's driveway and immediately jumped out of bed and started getting dressed. I thought there were things I needed to tell him, I needed to warn him, because if I waited until morning, it might be too late.
es: I couldn't sleep all night; a foghorn kept wailing in the strait, and I tossed and turned like a sick person between grotesque reality and deranged, terrifying nightmares. Towards dawn, I heard a taxi coming up the road to Gatsby's house, and I immediately jumped out of bed and started to get dressed: I felt that I had something to tell him, that I needed to warn him about something, and that by morning it would already be too late.

en: Crossing his lawn, I saw that his front door was still open and he was leaning against a table in the hall, heavy with dejection or sleep.
vi: As I passed by Gatsby's lawn, I saw that the front door was still open and he was leaning against a table in the hallway, immersed in either dejection or sleeplessness.
tr: After crossing the garden, I saw that the front door was open, and I found Gatsby sitting at the table in the foyer, exhausted from sleeplessness.
es: When I was crossing the lawn, I saw that the main door was still open and that Gatsby was leaning on the hall table, overcome by dejection or sleep.

en: “Nothing happened,” he said wanly. “I waited, and about four o’clock she came to the window and stood there for a minute and then turned out the light.”
vi: "Nothing happened." Gatsby said weakly. "I waited, around four o'clock Daisy came to the window and stood there for about a minute, then she turned off the light."
tr: "Nothing happened," he said, his face was pale. "I waited; around four o'clock, he approached the window and stood there for about a minute, then he turned off the light."
es: —Nothing happened —he said, weakly—. I waited, and around four o'clock Daisy looked out the window for a minute and then turned off the light.

en: His house had never seemed so enormous to me as it did that night when we hunted through the great rooms for cigarettes. We pushed aside curtains that were like pavilions, and felt over innumerable feet of dark wall for electric light switches—once I tumbled with a sort of splash upon the keys of a ghostly piano. There was an inexplicable amount of dust everywhere, and the rooms were musty, as though they hadn’t been aired for many days. I found the humidor on an unfamiliar table, with two stale, dry cigarettes inside. Throwing open the French windows of the drawing-room, we sat smoking out into the darkness.
vi: I felt that Gatsby's house had never seemed as monstrously gigantic as it did that night when we searched around the house for cigarettes. We lifted the large curtains like tent cloths, groping through countless feet of dark walls to find the light switches. At one point, I stumbled over the keys of the eerie grand piano. It was inexplicable how there was so much dust, covering everything, and the rooms were filled with a musty smell as if they hadn't been aired out for days. I found the cigarette box on an unfamiliar table with only two stale and dry cigarettes left. Throwing open the glass doors in the living room, we sat together smoking, letting the smoke drift into the darkness.
tr: Until that night when we searched for cigarettes together in those immensely large rooms, I hadn't realized how big Gatsby's house was. We struggled to pull the curtains aside as if they were stage curtains, traversing meters to reach the light switches, and at one point, I stumbled and fell onto the piano keys that appeared before me like a ghost. Interestingly, everything was covered in dust, and the rooms smelled musty as if they hadn't been aired out for days. I found the tobacco box on a peculiar table, and inside were two dried-up cigarettes. After opening the French windows of the guest room wide, we sat and smoked our cigarettes in the dark.
es: The house had never seemed so enormous to me as it did that early morning, when we launched into a hunt for cigarettes through the immense rooms. We drew back curtains that were like tents and groped for light switches along countless meters of walls in darkness. I fell once scandalously onto the keyboard of a ghostly piano. Dust covered everything in an inexplicable way, and the rooms smelled musty as if they hadn't been aired out for many days. I found the tobacco case on a table where it had never been before, with only two yellowed and dry cigarettes. We opened the glass doors of the living room and sat down to smoke in the darkness.

en: “You ought to go away,” I said. “It’s pretty certain they’ll trace your car.”
vi: "You should go somewhere else." I said. "They will definitely trace it back to your car."
tr: “You should go,” I said, “it's not unlikely that they will trace the car.”
es: —You should leave —I told him—. They will locate the car, for sure.

en: “Go away now, old sport?”
vi: "Going out at THIS time, old friend?"
tr: “How should I go now, buddy?”
es: —Leave right now, comrade?

en: “Go to Atlantic City for a week, or up to Montreal.”
vi: "Go to Atlantic City for about a week, or go up to Montreal, that's fine too."
tr: “Go to Atlantic City or Montreal and stay for a week.”
es: —To Atlantic City for a week, or even to Montreal.

en: He wouldn’t consider it. He couldn’t possibly leave Daisy until he knew what she was going to do. He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.
vi: However, Gatsby did not heed my advice. He could not leave Daisy at this moment until he knew what Daisy intended to do. Gatsby was holding onto a sliver of hope, and I couldn't bring myself to tell him to give up.
tr: He wasn't even considering doing this. He probably wouldn't leave her without finding out what Daisy would do. He was clinging to his last hope; and I couldn't tear him away from it.
es: He didn't even want to think about it. He couldn't separate from Daisy before knowing what she was going to do. He clung to a last hope and I didn't feel capable of shaking him free.

en: It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I think that he would have acknowledged anything now, without reserve, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.
vi: It was on this very evening that Gatsby recounted to me the strange story of his youth and Dan Cody - he told me this story because "Jay Gatsby" had now shattered like glass struck by the cruel malice of Tom, and the wild, absurd secret that had been concealed for so long was now considered exposed and concluded. I thought Gatsby would reveal everything, without any reservations, yet he only wanted to talk about Daisy.
tr: He had also recounted the early years he spent with Dan Cody that night; the reason for his recounting was clear: in the face of Tom's treachery, "Jay Gatsby" had shattered into pieces, and the hidden and long love story had finally come to an end. Now, without any secrets, he could tell everything as it was. Nevertheless, what he really wanted to talk about was still Daisy.
es: That early morning he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody. He told it to me because "Jay Gatsby" had shattered like glass against the relentless malice of Tom, and the spectacular setup and its secret, which had lasted so long, were coming to an end. I believe that at that moment he would have admitted anything, without reservations, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.

en: She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before. But what gave it an air of breathless intensity, was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motorcars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.
vi: Daisy was the first "proper" girl that Gatsby had ever known. In daily interactions, he had come into contact with such people, but it seemed as though there were always invisible barbed wires between him and them. Gatsby found Daisy very charming. At first, Gatsby went to Daisy's house with other officers from Camp Taylor, but later he went alone. Daisy's house overwhelmed him; Gatsby had never set foot in such a splendid house. But what truly took his breath away was not the house but the girl living in it, Daisy. Daisy lived there naturally and comfortably, just as Gatsby lived in his military camp. The house contained a ripe mystery. It evoked the impression that the bedrooms upstairs were more beautiful and cooler than other bedrooms, that joyful and cheerful parties took place along the corridors, that romantic affairs never withered but were kept fresh, always full of life, reminiscent of shiny motorcycles in the year and dance parties where the flowers never wilted. Another thing that made Gatsby even more interested and focused on Daisy was the fact that so many young men admired her, which in Gatsby's eyes only increased her value. Gatsby could feel the presence of these young men around the house, filling the air with their shadows and the echoes of their still-vivid emotions.
tr: Daisy was the first "graceful" girl he knew. He had met and had relationships with similar girls before, but he had always felt the presence of a barbed wire between them. He found Daisy excitingly attractive. He first went to her house with other officers from Taylor Camp, and later visited her alone. The house amazed him; he had never seen such a beautiful house before. However, it was, of course, Daisy's presence that gave the house its breathtaking atmosphere. Yet, just as it was ordinary for him to live in a tent at the camp, it was also ordinary for Daisy. The house had a mysterious air; the bedrooms upstairs were more beautiful and spacious than the others, and the corridors radiated joy and vitality. The romance in that house was not moldy; rather, it was preserved in lavender; the sparkle of the latest model cars always remained fresh and lively, and the flowers of the dance balls never wilted. Moreover, the multitude of Daisy's admirers excited him and increased her value in his eyes. In every corner of the house, he felt their presence, the shadows and reflections of their passionate feelings lingering in the air.
es: She was the first "well-off" girl he had met. In some job he didn't specify, he had had contact with similar people, but always with an invisible fence in between. Daisy seemed overwhelmingly desirable to him. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. He was astonished: he had never set foot in such a wonderful house. But what gave the house an intensity that made it hard to breathe was that Daisy lived there. And to her, the house seemed as normal as Gatsby's tent at the camp seemed to him. Deep and mysterious, it promised more beautiful and cooler bedrooms upstairs than other bedrooms, radiant and joyful activities along its hallways, romances that didn't smell of mustiness and lavender, but new, fragrant and throbbing like the splendid latest model cars, like the dances where the flowers had just begun to wilt. And his fervor increased because many men had already loved Daisy: this made her more valuable in his eyes. He felt the presence of those strangers in every corner of the house, permeating the air with the shadows and echoes of emotions that still lived.

en: But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.
vi: However, Gatsby knew that his entry into Daisy's house was merely a great coincidence. No matter how glorious and illustrious his future under the name Jay Gatsby might be, at that moment he was just a penniless young man, a person without roots, and at any time, the protective cloak of his military uniform could slip off his shoulders. Because of this, Gatsby enjoyed his time to the fullest. He tried to seize whatever he could at that moment, voraciously, without hesitation. And thus, he won Daisy over on a quiet October night, won Daisy because he had no legitimate right even to touch her hand.
tr: He was also aware that going to Daisy's house was a very big coincidence. No matter how bright his future was as Jay Gatsby, ultimately, he was a penniless young man without a past, and the invisible cloak of his uniform could slip off his shoulders at any moment. Therefore, he made good use of his time. He took whatever he could with passion and without thinking, and in the end, on a calm October evening, perhaps knowing that he didn't even have the right to hold her hand, he won Daisy over.
es: But he knew he was at Daisy's house by a colossal chance. As glorious as his future as Jay Gatsby might be, for the moment he was just a young man without money and without a past, and overnight the cloak that made him invisible, his officer's uniform, could fall from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took everything within his reach, voraciously, without scruples. And he took Daisy one quiet October night. He took her because he had no right to hold her hand.

en: He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretences. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same strata as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.
vi: Gatsby should have despised himself for having won Daisy through deceit. My point here is not that Gatsby won Daisy by trading his illusory millions, but by calculatingly giving Daisy a sense of security, making her believe that Gatsby was at least in the same social class as her and that he had the ability to protect her life. But the truth was not so; Gatsby did not possess those abilities, he did not have a well-off family supporting him, he had to rely on a capricious and inhumane government, and he could be sent away to any corner of the world.
tr: Actually, he should have been ashamed of himself because he had practically deceived the girl with lies and trickery to win her over. Of course, I'm not saying he took advantage of his imaginary millions for this, but somehow he had gained her trust, made her believe they were from the same social class, and convinced her that he could take care of her in the way she deserved. In reality, he had no such means; not only did he lack the support of a wealthy family, but he could also be sent to the farthest corner of the world at any moment by an order.
es: He might have despised himself, because it is undeniable that he won her over with deceit. I'm not saying he resorted to his phantasmagoric millions, but, with premeditation, he gave Daisy a sense of security, made her believe that he was a person of her same social class: that he was fully capable of taking care of her. The truth is that those were not his capabilities: he did not have the backing of a wealthy family, and he was subject to the impersonal whim of a government that could send him anywhere in the world.

en: But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.
vi: However, Gatsby did not despise himself, and the situation did not unfold as he had imagined. His initial intention was merely to seize what he wanted and then make a swift getaway - but now he realized that he had plunged himself into a futile and arduous pursuit. Gatsby knew that Daisy was an exceptionally unusual girl, but he could not comprehend just how exceptionally unusual a "proper" girl could be. Daisy vanished into her wealthy home, into her affluent life of abundance, leaving Gatsby with nothing. Gatsby felt as if he had married Daisy, and that was all.
tr: However, he did not feel ashamed of what he did, moreover, events did not unfold as he had imagined. In fact, his initial intention was to leave after taking what he could get, but he found himself chasing a dream. He already knew that Daisy was an extraordinary girl, but he hadn't realized at that time how exceptionally "graceful" she could be. When Daisy disappeared into her lavish life and her grand house, Gatsby was left standing there in the middle. At that moment, all he wanted was to marry her.
es: But he did not despise himself, and things did not turn out as he had imagined. His intention was probably to take what he could and leave, but suddenly he realized that he had devoted himself to the search for the Holy Grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he was not aware of just how extraordinary a "well-bred" girl could be. Daisy vanished into her very wealthy home, into her life of riches and abundance, and left Gatsby with nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.

en: When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.
vi: Two days after they met again, it was Gatsby who felt suffocated and believed he was the one betrayed. Daisy's porch was illuminated by luxurious furniture that shone like the stars. The wicker sofa creaked elegantly as Daisy turned towards Gatsby, and he kissed her lovely, sensual lips. At that moment, Daisy had a cold, making her voice even huskier and more charming than ever. Gatsby was stunned to realize that youth and mystery had been imprisoned and preserved in the wealth, the freshness of countless clothes, and Daisy, shimmering like silver, safe and proud above all the harsh struggles of men. Poor times.
tr: At their meeting two days later, it was Gatsby who was left breathless and feeling somehow betrayed. On the veranda illuminated by the luxury of purchased stars, when the girl approached him and Gatsby kissed her intriguing, beautiful lips, the wicker lounge chair gently creaked. Daisy had caught a cold; this made her voice sound huskier and more alluring than ever. When he realized that the enchanting vitality of that youth, that mystery, and those brand-new clothes, wrapped and protected by wealth, shone confidently and proudly like silver over the struggles and hardships of the poor, Gatsby's presence was filled with embarrassment and shame.
es: When they saw each other again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was exhausted and, in a way, betrayed. The newly bought luxury of the stars illuminated the porch; the wicker sofa trembled and creaked in the latest fashion as she looked at Gatsby and he kissed her on the mouth, precious and rare. Daisy had caught a cold and her voice was huskier, more seductive than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth conceals and preserves, of the freshness that a good wardrobe provides, and of Daisy, radiant like silver, proud and safe, above the bitter struggles of the poor.

en: “I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”
vi: "Old friend, I can't describe to you how surprised I was when I discovered that I had fallen in love with Daisy. There was a time when I even hoped Daisy would leave me, but Daisy didn't do that because she loved me too. Daisy thought I was very knowledgeable because what I knew was different from what Daisy knew. That's how it was, that's the story, I surpassed my own ambitions, sinking deeper into love every moment, and suddenly I no longer cared about anything else. Doing great things in life no longer meant anything if I could tell Daisy what I wanted to do."
tr: “I can't tell you how surprised I was when I realized I was in love with her, buddy. In fact, at one point, I even hoped she would brush me off, but she didn't. Because she had fallen for me too. She thought I was very cultured because I knew things different from what she knew. I had shed my ambitions and with each passing minute, I was falling for her more and more, all without me realizing, it happened all at once. What was the point of doing bigger things when I could spend time alone with her, telling her what I would do!”
es: —I can't describe to you how surprised I was to discover that I had fallen in love with her, my friend. In fact, for a while, I hoped she would leave me, but she didn't, because she had also fallen in love with me. I believed that I knew many things because I knew different things from what she knew… Well, there I was, far from my ambitions, more and more in love, and suddenly all that stopped mattering to me. Why do great things if I could have more fun telling her what I was going to do?

en: On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.
vi: One last afternoon before Gatsby was deployed overseas, Gatsby sat holding Daisy in his arms, for a long time, very quietly. That day was a cold autumn day, under the firelight of the fireplace in Daisy's house, her cheeks were rosy. Occasionally Daisy moved her body and Gatsby adjusted his arm a bit, once he kissed her dark, shiny hair. The afternoon made them quiet and serene, as if to imprint deep memories in their minds before the long separation of the next day. The two of them had never been closer in a month of loving each other, nor felt more deeply connected when Daisy placed her silent, wordless lips on Gatsby's coat shoulder, or when Gatsby gently and tenderly stroked Daisy's fingers as if she were sleeping.
tr: On the last day before leaving for duty, they had sat for a long time without saying a word, holding Daisy in his arms. It was a cold autumn day, and Daisy's cheeks were flushed from the heat of the fireplace. When Daisy moved, Gatsby slightly shifted his arm and then kissed her shining black hair. These midday hours had silenced them, as if wanting to leave them with memories they couldn't forget during the long days of separation that would start the next day. During their month-long relationship, they had never been this close, never entered such deep communication; as if afraid of waking Daisy up, Gatsby gently touched the girl's fingers, while Daisy brushed her silent lips against the shoulder of his jacket.
es: The afternoon before leaving for Europe, he held Daisy in his arms for a long time, in silence. It was a cold autumn day, there was a fire in the fireplace, and her cheeks were flushed. From time to time she moved, and he slightly adjusted his arm's position and at one point kissed her dark, shiny hair. The afternoon had granted them a moment of tranquility, as if to leave them with a deep memory before the long separation that the next day promised. They had never felt so close in their month of love, they had never understood each other so deeply, as when she, in silence, brushed her lips against the shoulder of his uniform, or when he carefully touched her fingertips, as if she were asleep.

en: He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.
vi: Gatsby was promoted very quickly during the war. He was promoted to captain before going to the battlefield, and after the battles in Argonne, he was promoted to major, commanding the division's rifles. After the armistice, Gatsby tried every way to return home, but due to mistakes and complications, he was sent to Oxford. At this time, Gatsby was very worried, in the letters that Daisy sent him contained desperate anxieties. Daisy could not understand why he could not return home. Daisy felt a lot of pressure from the world around her and she wanted to meet Gatsby, to be by his side and to be reassured by him that what she was doing was right.
tr: Gatsby had shown extraordinary achievements in the war, becoming a captain even before going to the front, and after the battle of Argonne, he was promoted to major and took command of the machine gun brigade. After the armistice, he tried to return to his country, but due to a misunderstanding or confusion, he found himself in Oxford. At that time, he was very worried because of the disappointment he sensed in Daisy's letters. Daisy could not understand why he couldn't return. She felt the pressure of the outside world, wanted to see him, feel his presence beside her, and ultimately be sure that she was doing the right thing by waiting for him.
es: His behavior in the war was extraordinary. He was a captain before leaving for the front, and after the battles of Argonne, he was promoted to major and took command of the machine gun section of his division. After the armistice, he desperately tried to return home, but some misunderstanding or complication ended up taking him to Oxford. He was worried: Daisy's letters had an undertone of desperation and anxiety. He didn't understand why he wasn't returning. The pressure of the outside world affected her, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence and the reassurance that, despite everything, he was doing the right thing.

en: For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the “Beale Street Blues” while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the grey tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.
vi: Daisy is still too young, the artificial world around her is always filled with the fragrant scent of orchids and brimming with joy, full of bustling pretensions, orchestras arranging rhythms for the entire year to summarize past sorrows and suggest new melodies for the life ahead. Throughout the night, the saxophone's wailing and lamenting the desperate sounds of the song BEALE STREET BLUES, while hundreds of golden and silver shoes kick up sparkling dust. At tea time, there are always rooms bustling endlessly in a gentle, sweet fever, while fresh faces glide from place to place like rose petals blown around the floor by the sad breath of trumpets.
tr: After all, he was still very young and his fake world was filled with orchid scents, cheerful, pleasant, and self-satisfied people, and of course, orchestras that conveyed the meaning and sorrow of life with the year's fashionable rhythms. At nights, saxophones would cry with the hopeless rendition of "Beale Street Blues," and hundreds of pairs of gold and silver shoes would sweep the glittering dust off the floor. During the gray tea hours, while the halls smoldered with this soft and sweet fire, new faces would be swept from one place to another like scattered rose petals by the melancholy melodies pouring from the orchestra around the dance floor.
es: For Daisy was young and her artificial world smelled of orchids, of pleasant and cheerful snobbery, of orchestras marking the rhythms of the year, blending the sadness and fascination of life into new melodies. All night long the saxophones wailed their hopeless commentary to Beale Street Blues[22] while a hundred pairs of golden and silver dancing shoes shuffled over luminous dust. At the gray hour of tea, there were always rooms still throbbing with that sweet and gentle, inexhaustible fever, while young faces floated everywhere like rose petals blown by the sad brass instruments over the dance floor.

en: Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening-dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.
vi: In that twilight world, Daisy began to resume her activities as the season changed. Daisy suddenly accepted half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen young men, only to fall asleep at dawn with beads and evening gowns strewn haphazardly among the withered hyacinth flowers on the floor beside the bed. Yet, deep inside, Daisy was always driven by a yearning for a decision. Daisy wanted her life to be restructured - immediately - and that decision needed to have a power to be executed - a power that came from love, money, and practical certainty right beside her.
tr: With the opening of the entertainment season, Daisy had started to show up again in this twilight world, just like before, dating half a dozen men a day, and at dawn, she would throw her necklace, the tulle of her evening dress, and her dried orchids beside her bed and fall asleep. However, something inside her was telling her that she needed to make a decision. She had to steer her life, and without delay. Love, money, or common sense, whichever was closest to her, she would steer her life with it!
es: In this twilight universe, Daisy began to move again when the season started; suddenly she found herself with six dates a day with six different men, and falling asleep at dawn, with the beads and gauze of her evening dress tangled on the floor, among the dying orchids. And something inside her never ceased to demand a decision. She wanted her life to take shape now, immediately, and the decision had to be imposed by some force — love, money, or undeniable practical sense — within her reach.

en: That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby while he was still at Oxford.
vi: That strength came in the middle of spring when Tom Buchanan appeared. In Tom was a comprehensive inclusion of all aspects with a massive grandeur from the person, family background to status, which made Daisy feel proud. Undoubtedly, Daisy harbored internal conflicts along with a sense of relief. The letter reached Gatsby's hands while he was still studying at Oxford.
tr: In the middle of spring, Tom Buchanan entered her life, and she finally got what she had been waiting for. The young man's social status and appearance gave the impression of being reliable and solid, which flattered Daisy's pride. After struggling with indecision and doubt, she made her decision and felt relieved. The letter announcing this decision reached Gatsby while he was at Oxford.
es: That force materialized in full spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. His person and his social position had a healthy volume, and Daisy felt flattered. There was, undoubtedly, some resistance and some relief. The letter reached Gatsby when he was still in Oxford.

en: It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with grey-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.
vi: Dawn had arrived in Long Island, and we went around opening all the windows downstairs, filling the house with a light that was half pale gray and half golden yellow. The shadow of a tree lay stretched across the night mist, and ghostly birds sang among the green leaves. The atmosphere seemed to hold a gentle, slow movement, not a breeze, but a promise of a cool, pleasant, and beautiful new day.
tr: Dawn was breaking on Long Island; we began to open all the windows on the lower floor together, the dawn turning from gray to gold filled the house. Suddenly, a tree shadow fell on the damp grass and birds began to chirp among its blue leaves. The light and pleasant breeze in the air indicated that it would be a cool and beautiful day.
es: Dawn had already broken in Long Island, and we began opening the other windows on the ground floor, filling the house with a light that shifted from gray to golden. The shadow of a tree suddenly fell over the dew, and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a pleasant and gentle movement in the air, barely a breeze, promising a cool, beautiful day.

en: “I don’t think she ever loved him.” Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. “You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.”
vi: "I don't think Daisy ever loved Tom." Gatsby turned away from a window and looked at me without acknowledgment. "Old sport, you must know that Daisy was very agitated yesterday afternoon. He said things with the intention of frightening Daisy and making me look like a despicable fraud. As a result, Daisy didn't know what she was saying.
tr: "I don't think she ever loved Tom," said Gatsby, looking defiantly at me from the window he stood before, "We must not forget that what happened yesterday had a great impact on Daisy. The guy told everything in a way that would scare her, trying to make me look like a despicable fraud. Naturally, Daisy was not aware of what she was saying."
es: —I don't think she ever loved him —Gatsby turned his back to the window and looked at me, defiantly—. Remember, old sport, how nervous she was yesterday afternoon. He told her all those things to scare her, to make me look like a common swindler. And the result was that in the end she barely knew what she was saying —he sat down, dejected—.

en: He sat down gloomily.
vi: Gatsby sat down, gloomy and melancholic.
tr: He sat in a corner in a sad state.
es: And the result was that in the end she barely knew what she was saying —he sat down, dejected—.

en: “Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?”
vi: "Perhaps she loved him for a moment when they first got married, but at that time Daisy still loved me more, did you notice that?".
tr: “Of course, when they first got married, he might have loved her for a moment, but he still loved me more, do you understand?”
es: Yes, maybe she loved him for a moment, when they had just gotten married, and even then she loved me more, do you understand?

en: Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.
vi: Suddenly, Gatsby uttered a strange remark.
tr: Suddenly, these strange words slipped out of his mouth, "Anyway, it was personal.""
es: —and he concluded with a strange remark—.

en: “In any case,” he said, “it was just personal.”
vi: "In any case," he said. "It's just a personal matter."
tr: Suddenly, these strange words slipped out of his mouth, "Anyway, it was personal.""
es: In any case, that's something personal.
