en: What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?
vi: What did I perceive through that statement, if not the doubt in Gatsby's mind, which was harboring intense and immeasurable emotions?
tr: What meaning could be derived from this? Although I wasn't very sure, it was clear that he perceived everything with an immeasurable intensity.
es: What reaction was possible to those words, if not to suspect that Gatsby's notion of the matter exceeded any measure in intensity?

en: He came back from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the last of his army pay. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had always seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.
vi: Gatsby returned from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their honeymoon. After that, he used the last wages he received from the army to make a painful but irresistible journey back to Louisville. Gatsby stayed there for a week, walking through the streets where the two of them had once strolled together on a November evening. He even visited farther places they had gone to in Daisy's white car. Just as Daisy's house was always more mysterious and joyful than other houses to Gatsby, his thoughts about this city were the same; although Daisy was no longer there, its beauty still carried a melancholic charm.
tr: While Tom and Daisy were on their honeymoon, Gatsby had returned from France; he couldn't help but make a miserable journey to Louisville with his last paycheck from the army. He stayed there for a week, wandered the streets they had walked together on a November night, and revisited the secluded places they had gone to with Daisy's little white car. Just as he had always found the house more mysterious and colorful than the others in those days, despite her absence, it was the same again, and he was once more struck by the melancholic beauty of the house.
es: He returned from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their honeymoon, and spent what was left of his soldier's pay on an unfortunate and inevitable visit to Louisville. He stayed there for a week, walking the streets where their steps had echoed together that November night and revisiting the secluded places they had gone to in the white car. And just as Daisy's house had always seemed more mysterious and cheerful than the other houses, a melancholic beauty continued to permeate his idea of the city, even though Daisy was no longer there.

en: He left feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.
vi: Gatsby left the city with the feeling that if he had tried harder, he could have found Daisy, that he was the one who abandoned Daisy. On the train - with an empty pocket - the weather was scorching hot. Gatsby went out to the train car corridor and sat down on a folding chair. The train station began to recede, gliding past unfamiliar buildings into the spring fields. A yellow tram raced alongside for about a minute, inside it were passengers who might have once glimpsed Daisy's ethereal, pale face on the street.
tr: As he was leaving Louisville, he kept saying to himself, ‘If I had conducted a more thorough investigation, I would have surely found her,’ and these thoughts made him feel like he was leaving the girl he loved behind. He was penniless, and the passenger car was very hot. He stepped into the passage between the cars, opened a folding chair, and sat down; the station and buildings he had never seen before were slipping past him. As they passed through the fields, he looked at a yellow car they were momentarily neck and neck with, and thought that the passengers inside might have accidentally seen Daisy’s white and enchanting face while walking on the street.
es: He left with the feeling that if he had searched more thoroughly, he would have found her, that he had left her behind. In the cheapest train he found —he had run out of money— it was very hot. He went out to the open platform, took a folding seat, and the station began to move slowly, and he saw the backs of buildings he did not know recede into the distance. Then the spring fields appeared, where a yellow tram kept pace with the train for a few seconds, carrying people he might have seen once, on any street, Daisy's face, pale and magical.

en: The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.
vi: The tracks curved and the train was now turning its back on the sun, which was sinking lower and lower. It seemed to be bestowing blessings upon the city that was gradually fading away, the city that had once breathed life into Daisy. Gatsby stretched out his hand desperately as if trying to grasp, even just a small fragment of air, to hold onto a bit of space, the space that Daisy had made so beautiful for him. But now everything was slipping away too quickly for his dimming eyes, and Gatsby knew that he was losing part of it, losing the freshest, best part of it forever.
tr: The railway curved, and the train began to move away from the sun, which was spreading over the city where Daisy’s breath mingled, as if blessing it. With the desire to take a part of these places beautified by the woman he loved with him, he raised his hands and desperately tried to trap a piece of air in his palm. Everything was passing by very quickly in front of his tear-filled eyes; he felt that he had forever lost the most beautiful and exciting period of his life.
es: The road made a curve and veered away from the sun, which, as it set, seemed to spill out a blessing over the city where she had breathed, and which was gradually fading away. He reached out desperately as if to grasp at least a breath of air, to hold onto a fragment of the place that Daisy had made extraordinary for him. But everything was already passing too quickly before his tear-filled eyes, and he knew that he had lost that reality, the best and most vivid one, forever.

en: It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavour in the air. The gardener, the last one of Gatsby’s former servants, came to the foot of the steps.
vi: By nine in the morning, we had finished breakfast and stepped out onto the front porch. The night had passed, creating a clear difference in the weather, and the air was filled with the essence of autumn. The gardener, the last of Gatsby's old staff, approached the steps.
tr: By nine o'clock, we had finished our breakfast and stepped out onto the veranda. During the night, the weather had suddenly turned; now there was the scent of autumn in the air. The gardener, the last of the old servants of the mansion, came and stood in front of the steps, "Mr. Gatsby, soon the leaves will start to fall; I think I'll drain the pool today, the pipes get clogged otherwise."
es: It was nine in the morning when we finished breakfast and went out to the porch. The night had suddenly changed the weather and the air already tasted like autumn. The gardener, the last of Gatsby's old servants, approached the foot of the staircase.

en: “I’m going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby. Leaves’ll start falling pretty soon, and then there’s always trouble with the pipes.”
vi: "I will drain the swimming pool today, Mr. Gatsby. The leaves are about to fall, and they will cause trouble for the pipes."
tr: The gardener, the last of the old servants of the mansion, came and stood in front of the steps, "Mr. Gatsby, soon the leaves will start to fall; I think I'll drain the pool today, the pipes get clogged otherwise."
es: —I'm going to empty the pool today, Mister Gatsby. The leaves have started falling too early, and then there are always problems with the drains.

en: “Don’t do it today,” Gatsby answered. He turned to me apologetically. “You know, old sport, I’ve never used that pool all summer?”
vi: "Let's not do it today." Gatsby replied. He turned to me to explain. "Old friend, you know, I haven't used the swimming pool all summer."
tr: “Don't touch it today,” said Gatsby, then he turned to me and apologetically said, “You know buddy, I haven't gone into this pool even once all summer,” he said.
es: —Don't empty it today —replied Gatsby. He turned to me, as if apologizing—. You know, old sport, I haven't used the pool all summer?

en: I looked at my watch and stood up.
vi: I looked at the clock and stood up.
tr: Looking at the time, I stood up, "I have twelve minutes left for my train," I said.
es: I looked at the clock and got up.

en: “Twelve minutes to my train.”
vi: "My train departs in twelve minutes."
tr: Looking at the time, I stood up, "I have twelve minutes left for my train," I said.
es: —My train leaves in twelve minutes.

en: I didn’t want to go to the city. I wasn’t worth a decent stroke of work, but it was more than that—I didn’t want to leave Gatsby. I missed that train, and then another, before I could get myself away.
vi: I don't want to go into the city. I don't have the energy to work anymore, but the main thing is I don't want to leave Gatsby at this moment. I missed that train, then missed another one before I could muster the strength to leave.
tr: I didn't want to go to the city; I didn't want to travel that far just for accounting, but the main reason for my reluctance was that I didn't feel right leaving Gatsby alone. By the time I left the house, I had missed the train, and even the next one.
es: I didn't feel like going to the city. I wasn't in any condition to work decently, and there was something else: I didn't want to leave Gatsby alone. I missed that train, and the next one, before leaving.

en: “I’ll call you up,” I said finally.
vi: "I will call you." Finally, I said.
tr: "I'll call you," I said finally as I was leaving.
es: —I'll call you on the phone —I finally said.

en: “Do, old sport.”
vi: "Remember to call, old friend."
tr: “Well then, buddy.”
es: —Yes, comrade.

en: “I’ll call you about noon.”
vi: "I will call you at noon."
tr: “Around noon, then,” we slowly descended.
es: —I'll call you around noon.

en: We walked slowly down the steps.
vi: We both walked slowly down the steps.
tr: “Around noon, then,” we slowly descended.
es: We slowly went down the steps.

en: “I suppose Daisy’ll call too.” He looked at me anxiously, as if he hoped I’d corroborate this.
vi: "I think Daisy will call me too." Gatsby looked at me with a puzzled expression, as if he wanted me to confirm what he said.
tr: "Maybe Daisy will call too," he said, looking at my face anxiously, as if seeking approval.
es: —I suppose Daisy will call too —he looked at me anxiously, as if hoping I would confirm it.

en: “I suppose so.”
vi: "I think so too."
tr: “I think he will call too.”
es: —I suppose so.

en: “Well, goodbye.”
vi: "Goodbye for now."
tr: “Well then, goodbye.”
es: —Goodbye.

en: We shook hands and I started away. Just before I reached the hedge I remembered something and turned around.
vi: We shook hands and I walked away. But just as I reached the fence, I suddenly remembered something and turned back.
tr: We shook hands, and I was heading home when something came to my mind by the fence, and I turned around and shouted: "They're all worthless bastards!"
es: We shook hands and I started walking. Before reaching the gate, I remembered something and turned back.

en: “They’re a rotten crowd,” I shouted across the lawn. “You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.”
vi: "Those people are just a bunch of scoundrels." I shouted loudly across the grassy garden. "You are worth more than all of them put together."
tr: We shook hands, and I was heading home when something came to my mind by the fence, and I turned around and shouted: "They're all worthless bastards!" Even if they all came together, they wouldn't amount to one of you."
es: —They are bad people —I shouted to him across the lawn—. You are worth more than all of them put together.

en: I’ve always been glad I said that. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I disapproved of him from beginning to end. First he nodded politely, and then his face broke into that radiant and understanding smile, as if we’d been in ecstatic cahoots on that fact all the time. His gorgeous pink rag of a suit made a bright spot of colour against the white steps, and I thought of the night when I first came to his ancestral home, three months before. The lawn and drive had been crowded with the faces of those who guessed at his corruption—and he had stood on those steps, concealing his incorruptible dream, as he waved them goodbye.
vi: I am always glad I said that sentence. It was the only compliment I ever gave Gatsby because from beginning to end I always disapproved of him. At first, Gatsby nodded politely and courteously, then his face lit up with a sympathetic smile as if we had always agreed on this matter. His beautiful pink suit, now wrinkled, formed a bright contrast next to the white stone steps, reminding me of the first night I came to his old mansion three months ago.
tr: I have always been pleased to have said this. This was the only compliment I made to her, because I did not approve of anything she did from beginning to end. First, she nodded gracefully, then that radiant and understanding smile spread across her face as if we had always been in this together. Her flashy pink suit looked like a bright spot on the marble stairs. I remembered that night three months ago when I first went to her house. A crowd of people, speculating about her deceit, had filled her house and garden; she, however, had stood on these steps while bidding farewell to her guests, waving after us, concealing that pristine thought from all of us.
es: I have always been glad I told him. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I found him reprehensible from beginning to end. First he nodded, very polite, and then his face lit up with a radiant and conspiratorial smile, as if in that matter we had always been unwavering accomplices. The magnificent rags of his pink suit were a vivid splash of color against the white steps, and I remembered the night I first went to his ancestral home, three months earlier. The lawn and the path were then overrun by the faces of those speculating about his corruption, while he, standing on those steps, hiding his incorruptible dream, waved them goodbye.

en: I thanked him for his hospitality. We were always thanking him for that—I and the others.
vi: I thank Gatsby for his hospitality. All of us, myself and everyone else, thank Gatsby for this kindness.
tr: I thanked him for his hospitality. In fact, all the guests, all of us, would often thank him for it.
es: I thanked him for his hospitality. The others and I never stopped thanking him for it.

en: “Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”
vi: "Goodbye." I said loudly. "Breakfast was delicious, Gatsby."
tr: “Goodbye!” I called out. “The breakfast was very nice, thank you.”
es: —Goodbye —I shouted—. Breakfast was wonderful, Gatsby.

en: Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. Just before noon the phone woke me, and I started up with sweat breaking out on my forehead. It was Jordan Baker; she often called me up at this hour because the uncertainty of her own movements between hotels and clubs and private houses made her hard to find in any other way. Usually her voice came over the wire as something fresh and cool, as if a divot from a green golf-links had come sailing in at the office window, but this morning it seemed harsh and dry.
vi: When I arrived in the city, I had to struggle for a while to record the prices of the stocks on the endlessly long price boards, then fell asleep on my swivel chair. The ringing phone woke me up around noon, I woke up startled with sweat all over my forehead. The caller was Jordan Baker, Jordan often called me at this time because Jordan frequently moved irregularly from one hotel to another, to clubs, and private houses, so this was the most convenient time to call. Usually, Jordan's voice over the phone sounded very cheerful and warm, like a small patch of grass from the green golf course being knocked up and landing on my office window. But this morning, that voice seemed harsh and dry.
tr: When I arrived in the city, I started preparing the endless list of promissory notes; however, I soon fell asleep in my revolving chair. At noon, I woke up with a start to the sound of the phone, and beads of sweat were dripping from my forehead. It was Jordan Baker; she usually called around this time because the uncertainty and lack of planning in her shuttling between hotels, clubs, or house parties didn't allow her to call at other times. Usually, her voice on the phone sounded lively and fresh, as if a piece of grass from the green golf course had suddenly entered my office through the window, but that morning it was dry and sharp.
es: In New York, I spent a while trying to jot down the quotes from an endless list of stocks, and then I fell asleep in my swivel chair. I got a scare when, shortly before twelve, the phone woke me up. My forehead was covered in sweat. It was Jordan Baker: she usually called me at that hour because the uncertainty of her own movements between hotels, clubs, and private houses made it difficult to reach her otherwise. Usually, her voice came to me through the telephone line as something young and fresh, as if a handful of grass from the golf course had flown in through the office window, but that morning it seemed harsh, dry.

en: “I’ve left Daisy’s house,” she said. “I’m at Hempstead, and I’m going down to Southampton this afternoon.”
vi: khan. "I have left Daisy's house." Jordan said. "I am now in Hempstead and I will go down to Southhampton this afternoon."
tr: "I just left Daisy, I'm in Hampstead," he said, "I'll head to Southampton in the afternoon."
es: —I have left Daisy's house —he said—. I am in Hempstead and I am going to Southampton this afternoon.

en: Probably it had been tactful to leave Daisy’s house, but the act annoyed me, and her next remark made me rigid.
vi: Perhaps leaving Daisy's house at this moment would be tactful. However, it made me feel uneasy and annoyed, and Jordan's next words left me frozen.
tr: Although leaving the house was a considerate gesture, frankly, it had disturbed me, and I was utterly frozen by what he said last.
es: It was probably a tactful test to leave Daisy's house, but it bothered me, and what she said afterward managed to make me tense.

en: “You weren’t so nice to me last night.”
vi: "Last night, you didn't treat me very well."
tr: “You were not kind to me at all last night.”
es: —Last night you weren't very kind to me.

en: “How could it have mattered then?”
vi: "At that moment, that matter wasn't important at all."
tr: “What importance could it have had at that moment?
es: —And what importance did that have last night?

en: Silence for a moment. Then:
vi: A prolonged silence ensued. Then:
tr: There was a moment of silence, then, "I still want us to meet."
es: Silence. And then:

en: “However—I want to see you.”
vi: "However - I want to meet you."
tr: “Me too.”
es: —In any case, I would like to see you.

en: “I want to see you, too.”
vi: "I also want to meet you."
tr: “Me too.”
es: —I would also like to see you.

en: “Suppose I don’t go to Southampton, and come into town this afternoon?”
vi: "What if you didn't go to Southampton but met me in town this afternoon?"
tr: “Well, what if I come to the city instead of Southampton in the afternoon.”
es: —And if I don't go to Southampton and go to the city this afternoon?

en: “No—I don’t think this afternoon.”
vi: "No - I think this afternoon is not convenient."
tr: “Actually, I don't think it will be possible this afternoon.”
es: —No, I can't this afternoon.

en: “Very well.”
vi: "Alright."
tr: "Alright."
es: —Very well.

en: “It’s impossible this afternoon. Various—”
vi: "This afternoon is not possible. There are many...."
tr: “Today is impossible because I have a lot of - ”
es: —This afternoon is impossible for me. I have several...

en: We talked like that for a while, and then abruptly we weren’t talking any longer. I don’t know which of us hung up with a sharp click, but I know I didn’t care. I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.
vi: We talked like that for a while, and then abruptly we weren't talking any longer. I don't know which of us hung up with a sharp click, but I know I didn't care. I couldn't have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world. The two of us were talking nonsense for a while like that when suddenly I realized we were no longer talking. I don't clearly remember which one of us suddenly hung up first, but I don't need to know either. I couldn't talk to Jordan at the tea table that day if I was never going to talk to her again in this world.
tr: Our conversation continued like this for a while longer; then we both fell silent. I'm not aware of which of us hung up the phone first; frankly, it didn't matter. Even if we were never to meet again, I was not in a state to have tea and chat with him today.
es: We talked for a while, and then, suddenly, we stopped talking. I don't know which of us hung up the phone abruptly, but I know it didn't matter to me. That day I wouldn't have been able to sit down and talk and have tea with her, even if it meant never speaking to her again in my life.

en: I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my timetable, I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.
vi: A few minutes later, I called Gatsby's house, but the line was busy. I tried calling a total of four times, and finally, the irritated operator informed me that the line was busy with a long-distance call from Detroit. Taking out the train schedule, I circled the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair, trying to think. It was just noon.
tr: I called Gatsby shortly after; the line was busy. After persistently trying four times, an irate operator finally told me that the line was being kept open for a long-distance call with Detroit. I took the train schedule out of my pocket and marked the 15. 50 train by circling it. It was noon, and I leaned back and tried to think.
es: I called Gatsby's house after a few minutes, but the line was busy. I tried four times. Finally, a desperate operator told me that the line was waiting for a long-distance call from Detroit. I looked at my train schedule and circled the three-fifty train. I leaned back in the chair and tried to think. It was exactly twelve o'clock.

en: When I passed the ash-heaps on the train that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I supposed there’d be a curious crowd around there all day with little boys searching for dark spots in the dust, and some garrulous man telling over and over what had happened, until it became less and less real even to him and he could tell it no longer, and Myrtle Wilson’s tragic achievement was forgotten. Now I want to go back a little and tell what happened at the garage after we left there the night before.
vi: That morning on the train, as we passed by the ash heaps, I deliberately avoided sitting on the other side of the carriage. I guessed that there was probably a curious crowd gathering around the place all day with little children searching for black spots in the dusty area, with some boastful, talkative man repeatedly recounting what had happened, telling the story over and over until it sounded less and less true, even to himself, and then he would stop telling it, and the tragedy of Myrtle Wilson would fade into oblivion. At this moment, I want to recount what happened at the repair shop after we left there the previous evening.
tr: That morning, as we passed through the heaps of ashes by train, I got up in the compartment and sat on the opposite side. I thought I would see a curious crowd there, that their little children would search for dried blood stains on the dust, that a chatterbox would narrate the incident so much that they would eventually stop believing their own words and cease telling the story, and thus, the tragic Myrtle Wilson incident would be forgotten. Now, I want to go back a bit and tell you about what happened after we left there the previous night.
es: When that morning I passed by train through the heaps of ashes, I preferred to sit on the other side of the carriage. I supposed that at the site of the accident there would be a crowd of onlookers, and children looking for sinister stains in the dust, and some charlatan who would tell the story over and over again, until everything became less real, even for him, who would no longer be able to keep telling his story, and the tragic tale of Myrtle Wilson would fall into oblivion. But now I would like to go back a bit and tell what happened in the garage after we left the previous night.

en: They had difficulty in locating the sister, Catherine. She must have broken her rule against drinking that night, for when she arrived she was stupid with liquor and unable to understand that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. When they convinced her of this, she immediately fainted, as if that was the intolerable part of the affair. Someone, kind or curious, took her in his car and drove her in the wake of her sister’s body.
vi: It was very difficult for people to find her younger sister Catherine. That night, she might have broken her own rule of not drinking alcohol because when she arrived, she was so drunk that she was unaware and not sober enough to understand that the ambulance had already taken the body to Flushing. By the time people made her believe what had just happened, she immediately fainted as if this part of the whole event was unbearable. Someone, whether out of curiosity or kindness, helped her into his car and took her to her sister's body.
tr: It had been difficult to find her sister Catherine. She must have abandoned her decision to stay away from alcohol, at least for that night, as I heard she had gone to the scene dead drunk. She had a hard time realizing that the ambulance had already set off for Flushing, and when she finally understood, she fainted right there as if this was the most tragic part of the whole incident. One of those present, perhaps out of curiosity or maybe out of pity for the poor girl, took the woman into their car and followed the ambulance carrying her sister's body.
es: There were problems locating the sister, Catherine. It seems that she broke her rule of not drinking that night, because when she arrived she was dazed from the alcohol and was unable to understand that the ambulance had already left for Flushing. Immediately, when they finally managed to convince her, she fainted, as if that detail was the only intolerable part of the matter. Someone, kind or curious, took her in their car following the trail of her sister's corpse.

en: Until long after midnight a changing crowd lapped up against the front of the garage, while George Wilson rocked himself back and forth on the couch inside. For a while the door of the office was open, and everyone who came into the garage glanced irresistibly through it. Finally someone said it was a shame, and closed the door. Michaelis and several other men were with him; first, four or five men, later two or three men. Still later Michaelis had to ask the last stranger to wait there fifteen minutes longer, while he went back to his own place and made a pot of coffee. After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.
vi: Long past midnight, the crowd continued to gather around the front door of the repair shop, with one person replacing another as they left, while Wilson sat nodding off on the chair inside. The office door remained open for a long time, and those who entered the house could not resist glancing inside. Finally, someone remarked that it was shameful to do so, and thus the door was closed. Michaelis, along with several other men, stayed by Wilson's side; initially, there were four or five people, but eventually, only two or three remained. Eventually, Michaelis had to ask the last stranger to stay for about fifteen more minutes while he went back to his shop to brew a pot of coffee. After that, Michaelis stayed with Wilson until dawn.
tr: As the hours passed and it got well past midnight, another group had gathered in front of the repair shop. Meanwhile, George Wilson was rocking back and forth on the couch in his office; since the door to the office was wide open, everyone who entered the garage couldn't help but watch the man. Finally, someone had the sense to close the door, deeming it inappropriate. Michaelis and four or five others stayed there with the man for a while; then the number of this group dwindled to two or three. Eventually, Michaelis asked the last person to stay for another fifteen minutes, during which he went to his shop, made coffee, brought it to the repair shop, and stayed with Wilson until morning.
es: Until very late past midnight, an ever-changing crowd enjoyed the spectacle in front of the garage, while inside, George Wilson rocked himself on the sofa. The office door remained open for a moment, and everyone who entered the garage couldn't help but peek inside. Someone finally said it was a shame, and closed the door. With Wilson were Michaelis and several others, four or five at first, then two or three. Later, Michaelis had to ask the last newcomer to wait fifteen more minutes while he went to his place and made coffee. And then, he stayed alone with Wilson until dawn.

en: About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he had a way of finding out whom the yellow car belonged to, and then he blurted out that a couple of months ago his wife had come from the city with her face bruised and her nose swollen.
vi: Around three in the morning, Wilson's indistinct mumblings began to change. He became less talkative and started talking about the yellow car. He declared that he had a way to find out who owned that car and even blurted out that about two months ago, his wife came home from the street with a bruised face and a swollen nose.
tr: Towards the morning, around three o'clock, Wilson's meaningless ramblings, sobs, and groans had subsided; after calming down a bit, he started talking about the yellow car. He said he would definitely investigate and find out who the car belonged to, then began to tell how his wife had returned from the city about two months ago with a swollen nose and her face covered in bruises.
es: Around three in the morning, the nature of Wilson's incoherent murmuring changed; it became calmer, and he began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he knew how to find out who the yellow car belonged to, and let slip that a couple of months earlier his wife had come back from the city with a bruised face and a swollen nose.

en: But when he heard himself say this, he flinched and began to cry “Oh, my God!” again in his groaning voice. Michaelis made a clumsy attempt to distract him.
vi: However, when he himself heard the words he was saying, he became hesitant and began to shout again, "Oh, my God!" in a moaning voice. Michaelis awkwardly tried to find a way to make him forget about it.
tr: Then he shuddered again and was overwhelmed with sobs, starting to moan, 'Oh, my God!' Michaelis, in a futile attempt to divert his attention, asked, 'How long have you been married, George?'
es: But, when he heard that, he made a grimace of pain and began to complain, "My God, my God," in a moaning voice. Michaelis tried to distract him without much skill.

en: “How long have you been married, George? Come on there, try and sit still a minute, and answer my question. How long have you been married?”
vi: "How long have you been married, George?" Listen here, try to sit still for a minute and answer my question. How long have you been married?"
tr: Michaelis, in a futile attempt to divert his attention, asked, 'How long have you been married, George?' 'Come on, pull yourself together a bit, try to calm down and answer my question. How long have you been married?'
es: —How long had you been married, George? Come on, stay still for a moment and answer me. How long had you been married?

en: “Twelve years.”
vi: "Twelve years."
tr: "For twelve years.""
es: —Twelve years.

en: “Ever had any children? Come on, George, sit still—I asked you a question. Did you ever have any children?”
vi: "Do you have any children? Listen here George, sit still so I can ask you a question. Do you have any children?"
tr: "Do you have a child? Come on, stop stalling, I asked you a question: Do you have a child?"
es: —Haven't you had children? Come on, George, stop. I've asked you a question. Haven't you had children?

en: The hard brown beetles kept thudding against the dull light, and whenever Michaelis heard a car go tearing along the road outside it sounded to him like the car that hadn’t stopped a few hours before. He didn’t like to go into the garage, because the work bench was stained where the body had been lying, so he moved uncomfortably around the office—he knew every object in it before morning—and from time to time sat down beside Wilson trying to keep him more quiet.
vi: The brown beetles kept crashing into the dim light, and every time he heard the sound of a car passing by outside, Michaelis thought it was the car that had refused to stop a few hours earlier. He didn't want to go into the garage because the desk was still stained with blood where the body had lain. So he had to move uncomfortably around the office. It wasn't yet dawn, but Michaelis had become familiar with every item in the room - occasionally he would sit down next to Wilson, trying to calm him down.
tr: Whenever Michaelis heard the sound of a car from outside, he likened the engine noise to that of the car he had failed to stop a few hours earlier. Since the large table on which the corpse had been placed was still covered in blood after the unfortunate accident, Michaelis avoided entering the garage. Having nothing else to do but sit restlessly in the office, he had examined everything in the room one by one until morning, occasionally sitting next to Wilson and continuing his efforts to calm him down.
es: The beetles, brown and hard, continued to produce a dull noise when they collided with the poor electric light, and every time Michaelis heard a car speeding by on the road, he thought he heard the car that hadn't stopped a few hours earlier. He didn't like going into the garage because, on the table, in the spot where the corpse had lain, there was a stain, so he kept pacing around, uncomfortable, in the office —before dawn he had already memorized every single object inside— and from time to time he would sit with Wilson and try to calm him down.

en: “Have you got a church you go to sometimes, George? Maybe even if you haven’t been there for a long time? Maybe I could call up the church and get a priest to come over and he could talk to you, see?”
vi: "Do you often go to church anywhere, George? Even those churches that you haven't visited for a long time?" "Or should I call a church and invite a priest to come and talk to you, is that okay?"
tr: "Do you go to church, George? Even if you haven't gone for a long time, it's not a problem. If you want, I can call right now and find a priest to talk to you."
es: —Do you have any church that you go to sometimes, George, even if you haven't gone in a long time? I could call for a priest to come and talk to you, couldn't I?

en: “Don’t belong to any.”
vi: "I don't follow any church."
tr: “I am not affiliated with any church.”
es: —I don't belong to any church.

en: “You ought to have a church, George, for times like this. You must have gone to church once. Didn’t you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn’t you get married in a church?”
vi: "You should belong to a church, George, for situations like this. You must have gone to church at least once. Did you get married in a church, George? Listen here, George, listen to my question. Did you get married in a church?"
tr: “You should be, George, especially for times like these. You must have gone to a church at least once in your life. For example, when you got married. Are you listening, George? Listen to me, didn't you get married in a church?”
es: —You should have a church, George, for occasions like this. You must have gone to church at some point. Didn't you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn't you get married in a church?

en: “That was a long time ago.”
vi: "That happened a long time ago."
tr: “This was a long time ago.”
es: —That was a long time ago.

en: The effort of answering broke the rhythm of his rocking—for a moment he was silent. Then the same half-knowing, half-bewildered look came back into his faded eyes.
vi: The effort to answer the questions disrupted Wilson's nodding rhythm, and he became quiet for a moment. But then the half-understanding, half-confused look reappeared in his cloudy eyes.
tr: The effort he made to respond had somewhat prevented him from swaying and made him stop talking for a moment. Then, a slightly surprised, slightly suggestive look appeared in his swollen eyes:
es: The effort to respond broke the rhythm of his swaying: he fell silent for a moment. Then his faded eyes regained their expression, somewhere between cunning and bewildered.

en: “Look in the drawer there,” he said, pointing at the desk.
vi: "Look inside that drawer over there." He said, pointing towards the desk.
tr: "Could you open that drawer?" he said, pointing to the writing desk.
es: —Look in that drawer —he said, pointing to the desk.

en: “Which drawer?”
vi: "Which drawer?"
tr: "Which one?"
es: —In which drawer?

en: “That drawer—that one.”
vi: "That drawer - yes, that one."
tr: “That one, over there.”
es: —In that one, the only one there is.

en: Michaelis opened the drawer nearest his hand. There was nothing in it but a small, expensive dog-leash, made of leather and braided silver. It was apparently new.
vi: Michaelis opened the drawer closest to him. Inside the drawer, there was nothing except for an expensive dog collar, made of leather and trimmed with silver. It looked very new.
tr: When Michaelis opened the nearest drawer, he found a small, leather-made, silver-trimmed, expensive dog collar inside. It looked as if it were new.
es: Michaelis opened the drawer that was closest to him. The only thing inside was a very expensive dog leash, made of leather with silver decorations. It looked new.

en: “This?” he inquired, holding it up.
vi: "Is this it?" Michaelis asked, picking it up.
tr: “There is this,” Michaelis had said, pointing to the leash.
es: —This? —he asked, lifting it.

en: Wilson stared and nodded.
vi: Wilson stared and nodded.
tr: Wilson nodded, "Yes, I found it yesterday.
es: Wilson stared at her intently and nodded.

en: “I found it yesterday afternoon. She tried to tell me about it, but I knew it was something funny.”
vi: "I found it yesterday. She tried to explain it to me, but I knew something was wrong."
tr: Wilson nodded, "Yes, I found it yesterday. My wife told me something, but I sensed there was something illogical."
es: —I found her yesterday afternoon. She tried to explain it to me, but I realized that there was something strange.

en: “You mean your wife bought it?”
vi: "Do you mean your wife bought it?"
tr: "Did your wife buy this?""
es: "Do you mean that your wife bought it?"

en: “She had it wrapped in tissue paper on her bureau.”
vi: "She wrapped the words in thin paper and placed them on the vanity table."
tr: “Yes, I found it wrapped in a handkerchief on top of the dresser.”
es: —She kept it in the dresser, wrapped in tissue paper.

en: Michaelis didn’t see anything odd in that, and he gave Wilson a dozen reasons why his wife might have bought the dog-leash. But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.
vi: Michaelis didn't find anything strange about this; he gave a dozen reasons why Wilson's wife might buy a dog collar. Perhaps Wilson had also heard similar explanations from Myrtle, because he started moaning "Oh my God!" again, causing the person comforting him to abandon other explanations that hadn't yet been said.
tr: Michaelis, who couldn't see anything strange in this, had listed a bunch of reasons for the woman to take the leash. But Wilson must have heard similar explanations from Myrtle, as he started to moan again, "Oh, God, oh!" and Michaelis's attempt to comfort him caused these possible reasons to remain unresolved.
es: Michaelis didn't see anything strange and gave Wilson a series of reasons why his wife might have bought the dog leash. But it wasn't hard to imagine that Wilson had already heard some of those explanations before, and precisely from Myrtle, because he started murmuring "Oh my God, oh my God" again, and the friend who was consoling him left several explanations hanging in the air.

en: “Then he killed her,” said Wilson. His mouth dropped open suddenly.
vi: "So he killed my wife." Wilson said, his mouth suddenly gaping open.
tr: Then Wilson had said, "He killed that man," his tongue loosening.
es: —Then he killed her —said Wilson. His mouth suddenly opened.

en: “Who did?”
vi: "Who did it?"
tr: “Which man?”
es: —Who killed her?

en: “I have a way of finding out.”
vi: "I have a way to find out."
tr: “I will learn this somehow.”
es: —I know how to find out.

en: “You’re morbid, George,” said his friend. “This has been a strain to you and you don’t know what you’re saying. You’d better try and sit quiet till morning.”
vi: "Your mind is not clear, George," Michaelis said. "This situation has exhausted you and you no longer know what you are saying. You should try to rest until morning."
tr: "You're not well, George," his friend had said, "You still haven't gotten over the shock of the incident, you don't know what you're saying. It would be better if you tried to sit calmly until morning."
es: —Don't be morbid, George —said his friend—. You've had to endure a lot of stress and you don't know what you're saying. It's better for you to rest until tomorrow.

en: “He murdered her.”
vi: "He has plotted against my wife."
tr: “He killed the man.”
es: —He murdered her.

en: “It was an accident, George.”
vi: "It was just an accident, George."
tr: “It was an accident, George.”
es: —It was an accident, George.

en: Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his mouth widened slightly with the ghost of a superior “Hm!”
vi: Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed, and his mouth opened slightly to utter a "Hmm."
tr: Wilson shook his head from side to side, then squinted his eyes and spread his mouth into a thoughtful expression; "No, it wasn't.
es: Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his lips slightly parted as he hinted at a superior "hmm."

en: “I know,” he said definitely. “I’m one of these trusting fellas and I don’t think any harm to nobody, but when I get to know a thing I know it. It was the man in that car. She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.”
vi: "I know." Wilson said decisively. "I am one of those who easily trust people, and I never think ill of anyone, but when I figure something out, it is correct. It was the guy sitting in that car. She ran out to talk to him but he refused to stop."
tr: I know. The people around me trust me, and besides, I normally wouldn't even think that someone would hurt anyone. But if I say I know something, I know it. The man in the car was him. Myrtle stepped out to talk to him, but he didn't stop."
es: —I know —he said firmly—. I'm one of those confident guys who don't think badly of anyone, but when I know something, I know it. It was the man who was in that car. She ran out to tell him something and he didn't stop.

en: Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it. He believed that Mrs. Wilson had been running away from her husband, rather than trying to stop any particular car.
vi: Michaelis also witnessed that scene, but he did not think there was anything particularly unusual about it. He believed that Wilson's wife was running away from her husband rather than trying to stop any car.
tr: Actually, Michaelis had seen it that way too, but it hadn't seemed to him as if there was a special reason for it. He had thought that Mrs. Wilson was trying to stop that car not for any other reason, but because she was trying to escape from her husband.
es: Michaelis had also seen it, but he didn't think it had any special significance. He believed that Mrs. Wilson wanted to escape from her husband rather than stop a particular car.

en: “How could she of been like that?”
vi: "Why does your wife have to do that?" "She is a profound and thoughtful person."
tr: “How could your wife have done this?”
es: —And why did he do it?

en: “She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”
vi: Wilson replied, as if that was an answer. "A...."
tr: “She was an incomprehensible woman,” said Wilson, as if that was the answer to the question, “Oh, oh!”
es: —She is very smart —said Wilson, as if that settled the matter—. Ahhh…

en: He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.
vi: He started trembling all over again. Michaelis stood fidgeting with the dog's collar in his hand.
tr: Then it had started to shake again, and Michaelis stood there tugging at the leash in his hand.
es: She was rocking again, and Michaelis stood up, twisting the strap between his fingers.

en: “Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”
vi: "Or do you have a friend somewhere that I can call for you, George?"
tr: “Is there a friend you want me to call?”
es: —Do you have any friend I can call on the phone, George?

en: This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.
vi: This was just a vain hope because Michaelis was almost certain that Wilson had no friends at all; he devoted himself entirely to his wife, and that was not enough. A moment later, Michaelis felt relieved when he noticed a change in the room, a blue hue spreading from the window, and he realized that dawn was not far away. By around five o'clock, the blue light was sufficient to turn off the lamp.
tr: It was an empty hope; he was almost certain the man didn’t have a single friend; after all, he hadn’t even managed to win his wife’s friendship. A little later, when he noticed through the window that the sky was turning blue, Michaelis was pleased. By five o’clock, the daylight outside was enough to turn off the light in the office.
es: It was a remote hope; Michaelis was almost sure that Wilson had no friends: he didn't even have enough for his wife. He was glad when he noticed a change in the room, a sign of blue life in the window, and realized that it wouldn't be long before dawn. Around five, the blue outside became intense enough to turn off the light.

en: Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ash-heaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.
vi: Wilson's vacant eyes stared out at the ash heaps, where clouds of gray dust were forming into a grotesque shape and being scattered by the faint dawn breeze.
tr: Wilson's expressionless gaze was fixed on the ash heaps, where the clouds were drifting here and there under the influence of the light morning breeze, forming interesting shapes.
es: Wilson's glassy eyes turned towards the heaps of ash, where gray clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried back and forth with the morning breeze.

en: “I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window”—with an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it—“and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’ ”
vi: "I told her." Wilson muttered, after a long silence. "I told her that she could deceive me but she couldn't deceive God. I dragged her to the window." With an effort, he stood up, walked to the window, and pressed his face against the window frame. "And told her 'God knows what you're doing, knows everything you're doing. You can deceive me, but you can't deceive God.'
tr: “I had spoken to him,” Wilson murmured after a long silence. “I told him that he could deceive me, but he could never deceive God, then I took him to the window…” at that moment, he struggled to get up and moved towards the window at the back, then continued with his cheek pressed against the glass, “God knows what you have done, I told him, He sees everything you do! You can deceive me but never the all-seeing God!”
es: —I spoke with her —he murmured after a long silence—. I told her that she could deceive me, but she couldn't deceive God. I took her to the window —he stood up with effort and went to lean against the window at the back of the office, with his face pressed against the glass— and I said to her: "God knows what you have done, everything you have done. You can deceive me, but not God!"

en: Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.
vi: Standing right behind Wilson, Michaelis was astonished to realize that he was looking up at the enormous pale blue eyes of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg, which had just appeared in the vanishing darkness.
tr: When Michaelis realized that he was speaking while looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, who had just appeared with his large, dull blue eyes as the night dissipated, he was astonished.
es: Standing behind him, Michaelis was startled to see that Wilson was looking into the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, enormous and pale, from the dissolving night.

en: “God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.
vi: "God sees everything." Wilson repeated.
tr: "God sees everything!" Wilson had repeated.
es: "God sees everything," repeated Wilson.

en: “That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.
vi: "It's just a billboard." Michaelos reassured Wilson. There was something that made him turn his head away from the window and only look inside the room. However, Wilson still stood there for a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding towards the dim darkness.
tr: Michaelis, trying to instill confidence in him by saying, "It's just a billboard," had caused the man to turn his gaze from the window to the room, prompted by something he couldn't understand at that moment. Wilson, on the other hand, was still there, his face pressed against the window frame, continuing to shake his head as he stared at the brightening sky.
es: —That is an advertisement —Michaelis assured him. Something made him stop looking out the window and turn his gaze back to the room. But Wilson stayed at the window for a long time, glued to the glass, nodding his head to the twilight light.

en: By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so he cooked breakfast for three, which he and the other man ate together. Wilson was quieter now, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he awoke four hours later and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was gone.
vi: By around six in the morning, Michaelis had become exhausted, and he was relieved to hear the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the men who had kept watch the previous night and had promised to return. He prepared breakfast for three people, but only he and the other man ate together. Wilson had calmed down, so Michaelis went back to his own house to sleep. Four hours later, when he woke up and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was already gone.
tr: Michaelis was quite pleased to hear a car stop outside around six o'clock because he was too exhausted to stand. The person who arrived was the man who had waited with them at the garage the previous night and had promised to return when he left. After Michaelis prepared breakfast for the three of them, they all sat down and ate together. Taking advantage of Wilson having relatively calmed down at that moment, Michaelis had gone home to get some sleep. However, when he rushed back to the repair shop after four hours of sleep, Wilson was nowhere to be found.
es: Shortly before six, Michaelis, exhausted, heard with gratitude that a car was stopping in front of the garage. It was one of the onlookers from the previous night who had promised to return, so he prepared breakfast for three, which the man and he ate together. Wilson was already calmer, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he woke up four hours later and immediately returned to the garage, Wilson was gone.

en: His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Thus far there was no difficulty in accounting for his time—there were boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road. Then for three hours he disappeared from view. The police, on the strength of what he said to Michaelis, that he “had a way of finding out,” supposed that he spent that time going from garage to garage thereabout, inquiring for a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.
vi: Wilson's movement - entirely on foot - was eventually traced to Roosevelt Harbor and then to Gal's Hill. There he bought a meat pie but did not eat it, and a a cup of coffee. Perhaps he was very tired and walked very slowly, so it wasn't until noon that he reached Gas's Hill. By that time, tracking what he had done wasn't very difficult. The little children said they saw a man "acting crazy." People driving by said they saw him sitting by the road staring at them in a strange way. But then, for about three hours, he disappeared and no one saw him. The police, based on what Wilson had told Michaelis that he "had a way to find out," believed he spent that time going around to various garages asking about the yellow car. However, no mechanic who had met him came forward to report it. Perhaps he had an easier and more certain way to find what he was looking for. Around two-thirty, Wilson appeared in West Egg. There, he asked people around for directions to Gatsby's house. That was when he learned Gatsby's name.
tr: It was later understood where the man had gone: he had walked to Port Roosevelt and from there to Gad’s Hill, ordered a cup of coffee and a sandwich but had not even touched the sandwich. The fact that he had walked slowly due to his exhaustion explained why he only reached Gad’s Hill around noon. It had not been difficult to learn what he did at Gad’s Hill. For children had seen a man “acting like a madman,” and drivers had seen a man standing by the roadside looking at them strangely. However, no one had seen him in the last three hours. Having received the information that the man had told Michaelis the previous night ‘I will find out about this somehow,’ the police thought he might have spent this time visiting nearby garages to investigate the yellow car. Yet, none of the garage owners had seen him. Therefore, it was considered that he had found an easier and more certain way to learn what he wanted. Later, it was heard that he was seen in West Egg around half-past two in the afternoon, asking someone about Gatsby’s house. So by that time, he had already obtained Gatsby’s name.
es: His movements —always on foot— were later reconstructed: from Port Roosevelt to Cad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich he did not eat and a coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, as he did not reach Cad’s Hill until noon. It was not difficult up to that point to reconstruct his hours: there were kids who saw an individual behaving "like a madman," and drivers whom he stared at in a strange way from the roadside. Then he disappeared for three hours. The police, based on what he had told Michaelis, that he "knew how to find out," assumed he had been going from garage to garage in the area, asking about a yellow car. But among the garage owners, none reported having seen him, and he might have resorted to an easier and safer way to find out what he wanted to know. No later than two-thirty, he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby's house. So by that time, he already knew Gatsby's name.

en: At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing-suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out under any circumstances—and this was strange, because the front right fender needed repair.
vi: At two o'clock, Gatsby changed into his swimming suit and left a message with the butler that if anyone called, they should find him at the swimming pool. Gatsby stopped by the garage to get the inflatable mattress, which had been a source of entertainment for his guests all summer long. The driver helped Gatsby inflate the mattress. Gatsby also instructed that the car should not be taken out under any circumstances - This was a bit strange because the right front fender needed to be repaired.
tr: At two o'clock, Gatsby, who had put on his swimsuit, told his servant that he would be at the swimming pool in case a phone call came. He stopped by his garage, found the air mattress that had entertained his guests all summer, and then inflated it with the help of his driver. Before leaving, he ordered that his convertible should not be taken out of the garage under any circumstances, but since the front bumper needed to be fixed, this order seemed quite strange to his staff.
es: At two o'clock Gatsby put on his swimsuit and told the butler that if anyone called for him, he should be notified at the pool. He spent some time in the garage picking up an inflatable mattress that had entertained his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him inflate it. Then Gatsby gave him instructions not to take out the convertible under any circumstances, which was strange because the right front fender needed repair.

en: Gatsby shouldered the mattress and started for the pool. Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.
vi: Gatsby shouldered the swimming mattress and walked towards the lake. He stopped once to adjust it a bit, the chauffeur asked if Gatsby wanted his help, but Gatsby shook his head and after a moment disappeared among the rows of yellow leaves.
tr: Gatsby shouldered his inflatable mattress and headed towards the pool, occasionally stopping to adjust his load. Although the chauffeur, who saw him, offered to help, he shook his head to indicate he didn't want any assistance. Then he disappeared among the trees that had started to turn yellow.
es: Gatsby threw the mattress over his shoulder and headed to the pool. He stopped once to get a better grip, and the chauffeur asked if he needed help, but he shook his head no and disappeared among the trees, which were already turning yellow.

en: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come, and perhaps he no longer cared. If that was true he must have felt that he had lost the old warm world, paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked up at an unfamiliar sky through frightening leaves and shivered as he found what a grotesque thing a rose is and how raw the sunlight was upon the scarcely created grass. A new world, material without being real, where poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air, drifted fortuitously about… like that ashen, fantastic figure gliding toward him through the amorphous trees.
vi: No phone call came, yet the butler still did not sleep and he kept waiting like that until four in the afternoon - until if the phone did ring, there would be no one left for him to report to. I suppose even Gatsby himself did not believe he would get a call, or perhaps he no longer wanted to know. If that were true, he must have felt that he had lost the cozy world of before, that he had paid too high a price to live too long in just one dream. He surely looked up at the unfamiliar sky through the trembling and fearful leaves as he realized how absurdly grotesque the rose looked, how harsh the sunlight shone on the sparse grass. A new world, where material things were unreal, where miserable ghosts were breathing dreams like breathing air, drifting aimlessly... Like that strange gray figure sliding towards him through the shapeless trees.
tr: There had been no phone call, but the butler still gave up his nap that afternoon and waited until four o'clock, though if it were going to come, the news would have already arrived by then. If you ask me, Gatsby also knew that the call he was waiting for wouldn't come, and perhaps he wasn't relying on it much anymore. If this is true, he must have been thinking that he had lost his old warm world and was paying a heavy price for living with just a dream for so long. He had probably lifted his head and looked at an unfamiliar sky through the frightening leaves, shuddering as he noticed how strange the roses were and how the sun's rays looked so raw on the newly sprouting sparse grass. It was a new world where unfortunate ghosts, breathing dreams instead of air, wandered aimlessly; an unreal material, just like that gray and bizarre shadowy unfortunate ghost he saw gliding towards him through the pale and shapeless trees...
es: Nobody called on the phone, but the butler missed his nap and waited until four: long after there was no one to notify in case of a call. I have the impression that even Gatsby no longer expected that call, and that he probably didn't care in the slightest. If this is true, he must have felt that he had lost his old world, its warmth, and that he had paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked at a strange sky through the terrifying foliage, and shivered upon discovering how grotesque a rose is and how raw the sunlight is on grass that is still not fully created. A new world, material but not real, where poor ghosts who breathe dreams instead of air moved aimlessly, at random..., like that ashen and fantastic figure that glided towards him through the shapeless trees.

en: The chauffeur—he was one of Wolfshiem’s protégés—heard the shots—afterwards he could only say that he hadn’t thought anything much about them. I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first thing that alarmed anyone. But they knew then, I firmly believe. With scarcely a word said, four of us, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I hurried down to the pool.
vi: The driver, one of the people sponsored by Wolfsheim, heard the gunshots. But later he only testified that at the time he didn't think it was anything serious. I drove straight from the train station to Gatsby's house, the way I anxiously hurried up the front steps was the first alarm for everyone. It was only then that they knew, I am sure of it. Without saying a word, the four of us, including the driver, the butler, the gardener, and myself, hurried out to the pool.
tr: The driver under Wolfsheim's patronage had heard the gunshot, but as he later mentioned, he thought it was unrelated to them. After getting off the train, my hurried drive to Gatsby's house and my frantic rush up the stairs were the first things that alarmed the household. But at that moment, I'm sure they suddenly understood everything. The driver, the butler, the gardener, and I... All four of us, without saying a single word, ran to the pool at once.
es: The chauffeur —he was one of Wolfshiem's protégés— heard the shots; then he simply said that he had not paid attention to them. I went directly from the station to Gatsby's house, and my frantic dash up the porch stairs was the first thing that caused alarm. But they already knew, I'm sure. Without saying hardly a word, four people, the chauffeur, the butler, the gardener, and I, ran towards the pool.

en: There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water.
vi: The water surface ripples very gently, almost imperceptibly, as new water is introduced from one side of the lake and pushed towards the drain on the other side. The small ripples are not enough to form waves that could push the heavy buoy drifting erratically to the end of the lake. A strong wind blows across, not enough to wrinkle the water surface but enough to disturb its random path with its random burden. A cluster of floating leaves touches it, causing it to slowly spin like a compass needle drawing a red circle on the water surface.
tr: The clean water entering from one side of the pool and exiting from the other side creates a slight current on the surface, and these tiny ripples cause the inflatable mattress to move back and forth along with its load. Although the sudden wind only causes small ripples on the surface of the water, it is enough to change the random course of the mattress and its unfortunate load, and the touch of a cluster of leaves turns this mattress like a compass needle on a thin and red circle in the water.
es: There was a weak movement in the water, barely perceptible: the clean stream that entered from one end flowed towards the drain on the other side. With minimal undulations that didn't even reach the shadows of waves, the mattress carried its load, erratically, across the pool: a breath of wind that barely wrinkled the surface was enough to disturb its fortuitous course with its fortuitous load. The brush with a tangle of leaves made it slowly spin, tracing, like a compass, a red circle in the water.

en: It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.
vi: It was only after we brought Gatsby's body into the house that the gardener saw Wilson's body lying far away on the lawn, and thus the story of the mass killing came to an end.
tr: While we were all carrying Gatsby home together, the gardener saw Wilson's corpse lying on the grass a little further away. The massacre was complete!
es: We were already taking Gatsby towards the house when the gardener saw Wilson's corpse among the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

en: IX
vi: Download eBook at: www. dtv-ebook. com
tr: CHAPTER 9

en: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope stretched across the main gate and a policeman by it kept out the curious, but little boys soon discovered that they could enter through my yard, and there were always a few of them clustered open-mouthed about the pool. Someone with a positive manner, perhaps a detective, used the expression “madman” as he bent over Wilson’s body that afternoon, and the adventitious authority of his voice set the key for the newspaper reports next morning.
vi: Chapter 9 Two years have passed, and the only thing I can remember from that day, that night, and the following day is the constant coming and going of police officers, photographers, and journalists in front of Gatsby's house. A rope was stretched across the main gate, and a policeman stood beside it, preventing curious onlookers from approaching. But it wasn't long before the children discovered that they could sneak into the house from my garden. And so, after that, there were always at least a few of them gathered around the pool, standing with their mouths agape. That afternoon, a man, perhaps a detective, with a determined demeanor, used the term "madman" to describe Wilson as he bent down to look at the body. His voice, carrying an air of incidental authority, set the tone for the newspaper reports the following morning.
tr: After two years, from the day of the incident, the night, and the following day, what remained in my mind were the relentless visits of the police, photographers, and journalists, wearing down Gatsby's door. Although a tape guarded by a police officer was stretched in front of the garden gate to keep the curious away, the children soon discovered that they could pass through my yard to the house. Therefore, there was no shortage of people standing by the pool, looking around with their mouths open. A man, whom I guessed to be a detective and who seemed extremely sensible, used the term 'mad' while leaning over Wilson's corpse that day; the unusual authority in his voice carried this word to the headlines of the next day.
es: Two years later I remember the rest of that day, and that night, and the following day, as an endless coming and going of police officers, photographers, and journalists through the front door of Gatsby's house. A rope, tied from one end of the gate to the other, and a policeman kept the curious at bay, but the children soon discovered they could enter through my garden, and there was always a group around the pool, with their mouths open. Someone with decisive gestures, perhaps a detective, used the word "crazy" when he leaned over Wilson's corpse that afternoon, and the unexpected authority of his voice set the tone for the reports that the newspapers published the next morning.

en: Most of those reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had been into no mischief whatever. She convinced herself of it, and cried into her handkerchief, as if the very suggestion was more than she could endure. So Wilson was reduced to a man “deranged by grief” in order that the case might remain in its simplest form. And it rested there.
vi: Most of those articles were equally terrible, containing absurdity, self-interpretation, and falsehoods. When Michaelis's testimony during the inquest revealed that Wilson had suspicions about his wife, I thought that soon the entire story would be presented in the press as a sensational and thrilling libel. However, Catherine, who could have said something, did not utter a single word. She displayed a surprising determination and looked at the coroner with resolute eyes under her redrawn eyebrows. She swore that her sister had never met Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, and that her sister was not involved in any shady business. Catherine made herself believe in what she was saying, then buried her face in her handkerchief and cried, as if she couldn't bear any other hypothesis. Therefore, to simplify the case as much as possible, Wilson was reduced to being merely considered "mentally deranged by grief." And then the case was closed there.
tr: Most of what was written was like a nightmare; strange, irrelevant, provocative, and fabricated lines. When Michaelis stated that Wilson was suspicious of his wife's fidelity, I thought that at least for a while, this whole story would provide material for harsh and fiery criticisms. However, Catherine, whom I thought could explain everything, had not uttered a single word. In fact, displaying a surprising sense of judgment on the matter, she had looked at the inquest judge with determined eyes from under her plucked eyebrows and sworn that her sister had never known Gatsby, that she had a very happy marriage with her husband, and that she had never betrayed him. She seemed to have convinced herself of what she said, as she kept crying with a handkerchief in her hand, as if to show that such a claim was beyond her endurance. Thus, without further probing into the matter, Wilson was labeled as a man who had 'lost his sanity due to the suffering he experienced,' and the case was closed! However, this aspect of the matter was already unimportant to me.
es: Most of those reports were a nightmare: grotesque, inconsequential, biased, and false. When Michaelis's testimony during the investigation brought to light Wilson's suspicions about his wife, I thought that immediately some sensationalist rag would serve us the complete story, but Catherine, who could have said anything, didn't say a word. She demonstrated a surprising firmness of character: she looked at the coroner with eyes full of determination under her plucked eyebrows, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby in her life, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had never taken a wrong step. She convinced herself of what she swore and soaked her handkerchief with tears, as if the slightest insinuation was more than she could bear. So Wilson was reduced to an "individual distraught with grief" to simplify the case as much as possible, and that was that. But that part of the story seems distant and insubstantial to me.

en: But all this part of it seemed remote and unessential. I found myself on Gatsby’s side, and alone. From the moment I telephoned news of the catastrophe to West Egg village, every surmise about him, and every practical question, was referred to me. At first I was surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house and didn’t move or breathe or speak, hour upon hour, it grew upon me that I was responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end.
vi: However, all these developments seemed too distant and non-essential. I was beside Gatsby, only me alone. From the moment I called to report this tragedy to the village of West Egg, all speculation about Gatsby or any related questions were directed at me. At first, I felt surprised and confused, but then, while Gatsby was lying in the house, motionless, not breathing, not speaking, hour after hour, I gradually felt that I had to take responsibility because no one else cared. Caring, I mean the warm personal concern that everyone is entitled to at the end of their life, even if it's just vaguely.
tr: However, this aspect of the matter was already unimportant to me. Because I had been left all alone on Gatsby's side. After calling the people I deemed necessary in West Egg to deliver the bad news, all the suspicions about him, all those unanswered questions, had started to be directed at me. At first, I was surprised, even bewildered; but then, as he lay there breathless, motionless, and silent in his home, I began to feel a sense of responsibility with each passing hour, because there was no one else to care for him. By care, I mean that intense personal attention that every person deserves at the end of their life.
es: But that part of the story seems distant and insubstantial to me. I found myself completely alone, next to Gatsby. From the moment I called West Egg to break the news of the catastrophe, all the conjectures about Gatsby and all the practical matters fell upon me. At first, I felt surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house, neither moving, nor breathing, nor speaking, hour after hour, I became convinced that I had to take responsibility, because there was no one else interested: interested, I say, with that intense personal interest to which anyone has a certain right when their end comes.

en: I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them.
vi: About an hour and a half after finding Gatsby's body, I instinctively and without hesitation called to find Daisy. However, Daisy and Tom had left the house early that afternoon, taking all their luggage with them.
tr: Half an hour after finding him in the pool, I instinctively called Daisy without thinking. However, that afternoon I learned that they had left the house with a few suitcases along with Tom.
