es: I called Daisy half an hour after we found him, I called her instinctively and without the slightest hesitation. But Tom and she had left earlier that afternoon, taking the luggage with them.

en: “Left no address?”
vi: "Didn't leave any contact address?"
tr: “Didn't they leave an address?”
es: —Haven't they left an address?

en: “No.”
vi: "No."
tr: “No.”
es: —No.

en: “Say when they’d be back?”
vi: "Did they say when they would come back?"
tr: "Did they say when they will return?"
es: —Have they said when they will return?

en: “No.”
vi: "No."
tr: “No.”
es: —No.

en: “Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?”
vi: "Do you know where they are now?" "How can I contact them?"
tr: “Don't you know where they are? I need to reach them?”
es: —Do you have any idea where they might be? How could I get in touch with them?

en: “I don’t know. Can’t say.”
vi: "I don't know either. Don't know anything but still talk."
tr: “I don't know, unfortunately.”
es: —I don't know. I can't tell you.

en: I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: “I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me and I’ll get somebody for you—”
vi: I want to find some people to come to Gatsby. I want to go into the room where he is lying and assure him: "I will go find someone to come here with you, Gatsby. Don't worry. Trust me, I will find someone..."
tr: I wanted to find someone for him. Going to that room where he lay, I wanted to say, "Don't worry, Gatsby. I will make sure someone comes for you, don't be sad. Trust me, I will definitely bring someone," to comfort him.
es: I wanted to find someone to accompany him. I wanted to enter the room where he lay and reassure him: "I will find someone for you, Gatsby. Don't worry. Trust me and I will find someone to keep you company."

en: Meyer Wolfshiem’s name wasn’t in the phone book. The butler gave me his office address on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I had the number it was long after five, and no one answered the phone.
vi: Meyer Wolfsheim's name was not listed in the phone directory. The butler gave me the address of his office on Broadway. I called the operator, but by the time the line connected, it was already past five in the afternoon, and no one at the office answered the phone.
tr: Meyer Wolfsheim's name was not in the directory. The servant found the address of his office on Broadway for me; I got his number from the switchboard; but by the time I reached his number, it was already past five o'clock, so no one answered the phone.
es: The name Meyer Wolfshiem did not appear in the phone directory. The butler gave me the address of his office on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I got the number it was already past five, and the phone was not answered.

en: “Will you ring again?”
vi: "Could you please call again?"
tr: “Would you call again?”
es: —Can you call again?

en: “I’ve rung three times.”
vi: "I have called three times already."
tr: “I called three times.”
es: —I have already called three times —said the operator.

en: “It’s very important.”
vi: "This is of utmost importance."
tr: “This is very important.”
es: —It's very important.

en: “Sorry. I’m afraid no one’s there.”
vi: "Sorry, but no one was there." I returned to the living room and at that moment thought that there were guests who happened to drop by, but it turned out that the people entering the house were all officials.
tr: “I'm sorry. I'm afraid there's no one.”
es: —I'm sorry. I'm afraid there's no one here.

en: I went back to the drawing-room and thought for an instant that they were chance visitors, all these official people who suddenly filled it. But, though they drew back the sheet and looked at Gatsby with shocked eyes, his protest continued in my brain:
vi: I returned to the living room and at that moment thought that there were guests who happened to drop by, but it turned out that the people entering the house were all officials. When these people lifted the cloth covering Gatsby and stared at him with indifferent eyes, Gatsby's pleas continued to echo in my mind.
tr: I returned to the guest room again; for a moment, I thought that all these officers filling the hall were, in a way, his visitors too. But as they kept pulling back the sheet and looking at Gatsby with motionless eyes, I felt as if I could hear his objection.
es: I returned to the living room and for a moment I thought that all those officials who had suddenly filled the house were people who had shown up by chance. But, when they lifted the sheet and looked at the corpse with astonished eyes, Gatsby's protest echoed in my brain: "Listen, buddy, bring someone to keep me company.

en: “Look here, old sport, you’ve got to get somebody for me. You’ve got to try hard. I can’t go through this alone.”
vi: "Listen here, old friend, you have to try to find someone for me. You have to try even harder. I can't leave in such loneliness."
tr: "Buddy; you must find someone for me. Come on, try a little harder! I don't want to finish this job alone."
es: But, when they lifted the sheet and looked at the corpse with astonished eyes, Gatsby's protest echoed in my brain: "Listen, buddy, bring someone to keep me company. Do everything you can. I can't bear this alone."

en: Someone started to ask me questions, but I broke away and going upstairs looked hastily through the unlocked parts of his desk—he’d never told me definitely that his parents were dead. But there was nothing—only the picture of Dan Cody, a token of forgotten violence, staring down from the wall.
vi: Someone asked me some questions, but I avoided them and hurriedly went upstairs to search through Gatsby's unlocked desk drawers. He had never clearly told me whether his parents had passed away. I found nothing - except for a picture of Dan Cody, symbolizing a forgotten turbulent past, staring down from the wall.
tr: A man approached and started asking some questions; I barely managed to escape from him and went upstairs. He had never explicitly told me that his parents were dead, so I hurriedly rummaged through the unlocked drawers of his desk, hoping to find a clue, but there was nothing in the room related to his past except for the photo of Dan Cody on the wall, which symbolized his complicated past.
es: Someone started asking me questions, but I slipped away and went up to the second floor to search the drawers of the desk that were not locked: he had never explicitly told me that his parents had died. But there was nothing: only the photo of Dan Cody, a sign of forgotten violence, staring at me fixedly from the wall.

en: Next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter to Wolfshiem, which asked for information and urged him to come out on the next train. That request seemed superfluous when I wrote it. I was sure he’d start when he saw the newspapers, just as I was sure there’d be a wire from Daisy before noon—but neither a wire nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one arrived except more police and photographers and newspaper men. When the butler brought back Wolfshiem’s answer I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all.
vi: The next morning, I sent the butler to New York to deliver a letter to Wolfsheim, asking for news and telling him to take the next train. When writing the letter, I realized that my request was redundant; I was certain he would come here immediately once he read the news in the paper, just as I was certain Daisy would wire back before noon. However, neither the telegram nor Wolfsheim arrived. No one stopped by except for the police, photographers, and reporters. When the butler returned with Wolfsheim's reply, I began to develop a feeling of both defiance and contempt, shared by both Gatsby and me, towards all of them.
tr: The next morning, I handed the letter I had written to Wolfsheim to the servant and sent him to New York. I wanted him to come on the first train and inform me of the situation. Although this seemed unnecessary to me while writing; as soon as he saw the newspapers, he would definitely set out; moreover, I was sure I would receive a telegram from Daisy before noon. However, neither the telegram nor Mr. Wolfsheim arrived; no one came except for more police, photographers, and reporters. When the servant brought Wolfsheim's reply, a sense of rebellion arose within me, and I felt a solidarity between Gatsby and myself that scorned them all.
es: The next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter for Wolfshiem, asking for information and requesting that he come on the next train. This seemed superfluous to me when I wrote it. I was sure he would set out as soon as he read the newspapers, just as I was sure that, before noon, a telegram from Daisy would arrive. But neither the telegram nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one came, except more police, more photographers, and more journalists. When the butler returned with Wolfshiem's reply, I began to feel a sense of defiance, contempt, and solidarity between Gatsby and me against everyone.

en: Dear Mr. Carraway. This has been one of the most terrible shocks of my life to me I hardly can believe it that it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I cannot come down now as I am tied up in some very important business and cannot get mixed up in this thing now. If there is anything I can do a little later let me know in a letter by Edgar. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out.
vi: Dear Mr. Carraway. This is one of the most terrible incidents in my life; even now, I still can't believe it's true. The crazy actions of that person make all of us think. I can't go there right now because I am busy with important work and cannot let it be disrupted at this moment. If there is anything you need my help with later, let me know by writing a letter and giving it to Edgar. I no longer remember where I was when I heard this news, and I am still in shock.
tr: Dear Mr. Carraway, This is one of the most shocking disasters I have experienced in my life, I can't comprehend that all of this has happened. The madness that man has committed should make us all think. It is not possible for me to come there right now. Due to very important matters, I cannot move from where I am and cannot be among you. If there is anything I can do later, please write to me and send it with Edgar. Believe me, I am devastated in the face of such incidents; I am shattered by this incident as well, and I am at a loss for words and actions.
es: Dear Mr. Carraway: This has been one of the most terrible blows of my life and I find it hard to believe it's true. An act as senseless as that man's should make us think. It is impossible for me to go at this moment because I am tied up with a very important matter and now I cannot get involved in that. If there is something I can do later, send me a letter with Edgar letting me know. I almost don't even know where I am when I hear something like this, and I feel totally devastated, knocked out.

en: Yours truly
vi: Respectfully yours
tr: Yours sincerely,
es: Sincerely,

en: Meyer Wolfshiem
vi: MEYER WOLFSHIEM
tr: MEYER WOLFSHEIM
es: Meyer Wolfshiem

es: And he added hastily:

en: Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all.
vi: Let me know the news about the funeral, etc. I don't know anything about his family.
tr: ‘Let me know about the needs related to the funeral and other arrangements. I have no information about his family.’
es: Keep me informed about the funeral, etc. I don't know his family.

en: When the phone rang that afternoon and Long Distance said Chicago was calling I thought this would be Daisy at last. But the connection came through as a man’s voice, very thin and far away.
vi: That afternoon when the phone rang and the long-distance operator announced that the call was from Chicago, I thought that Daisy had finally called me i. But when the line was reconnected, it was the voice of a man, sounding very small and distant.
tr: When they said a call had come from Chicago that day, I thought Daisy had finally come to her senses: but when the connection was made, I heard a faint male voice from the depths.
es: When the phone rang that afternoon and the switchboard announced a long-distance call from Chicago, I thought it was finally Daisy. But a weak and distant man's voice reached me.

en: “This is Slagle speaking…”
vi: "This is Sladge..."
tr: When they said a call had come from Chicago that day, I thought Daisy had finally come to her senses: but when the connection was made, I heard a faint male voice from the depths.
es: —Here Slagle...

en: “Yes?” The name was unfamiliar.
vi: "What's going on?" This person's name sounds unfamiliar to me.
tr: "Ben Slagle."" "Here you go," I had never heard this name before.
es: —Yes? —that name didn't ring a bell.

en: “Hell of a note, isn’t it? Get my wire?”
vi: "The telegram is quite sensational, isn't it? Have you received my telegram yet?"
tr: "What's up, man! Did you get my telegram?""
es: —Shit merchandise. Did you receive my telegram?

en: “There haven’t been any wires.”
vi: "Haven't received any telegrams yet."
tr: “No telegram or anything came.”
es: —No telegram has arrived.

en: “Young Parke’s in trouble,” he said rapidly. “They picked him up when he handed the bonds over the counter. They got a circular from New York giving ’em the numbers just five minutes before. What d’you know about that, hey? You never can tell in these hick towns—”
vi: "The young guy Parker is in trouble." The person on the phone said quickly. "The police caught the kid while he was handing out the bonds at the counter. They received information from New York about those numbers just five minutes earlier. Hey, do you know anything about this? You can never predict these small towns..."
tr: “Young Parke is in trouble,” he was speaking quickly, “He got caught as soon as he put the bonds on the market over the counter. Apparently, a circular with the registered numbers had been sent from New York five minutes earlier. What do you think about that? Who knows what might happen to him in this backwater - ”
es: —Young Parker is in trouble. They caught him when he was trying to sell the bonds. They received a circular from New York with the numbers five minutes earlier. What do you say? One never knows what to expect in these backward cities...

en: “Hello!” I interrupted breathlessly. “Look here—this isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby’s dead.”
vi: "Hello!" I interrupted, speaking as if out of breath. "Listen, I'm not Gatsby. Gatsby has passed away."
tr: "Hello!" I interrupted, breathless, "Listen to me, I am not Gatsby, Mr. Gatsby is dead."
es: —Listen —I interrupted him, choking—, listen, I am not Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby is dead.

en: There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.
vi: On the other end of the line, there was a sudden silence for a long moment, followed by a sigh... then a sharp click as the phone was hung up.
tr: There was a long silence on the other end of the line, then a cry of surprise was heard. After that, the signal started beeping, they had hung up!
es: There was a long silence on the other end of the line, followed by an exclamation, and immediately a dry squawk when the call was cut off.

en: I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came.
vi: I remember around the third day, a telegram was sent from a city in the state of Minnesota, signed Henry C. Gatz. The telegram simply stated that the sender was immediately setting out on a journey, requesting the funeral to be postponed.
tr: If I'm not mistaken, on the third day, a telegram arrived from a Minnesota town, signed by Henry C. Gatz. The sender had written only that he would set out immediately and that the funeral should be delayed until he arrived.
es: I believe it was on the third day when a telegram arrived from a town in Minnesota, signed by Henry C. Gatz. It only said that the sender was leaving immediately for New York and that the funeral should be postponed until his arrival.

en: It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse grey beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.
vi: That person was Gatsby's father, a dignified old man who looked very bewildered and dispirited. The old man wore a long, cheap overcoat despite the sweltering September weather, with tears continuously falling from his emotional eyes. When I took the basket and umbrella from his hands, he kept tugging at his sparse white beard, making it difficult for me to remove his coat. The old man seemed on the verge of collapsing, so I led him into the music room to sit and rest for a long while as I called for someone to bring him some food. However, he did not eat or drink anything, and the milk spilled over his trembling hand.
tr: The dignified, bewildered, and exhausted old man who had arrived was Gatsby's father. On that warm September day, he was wrapped in an old and long coat. Probably from excitement, his eyes were constantly watering. As I took his bag and umbrella, he started tugging at his sparse and graying beard, and since he wouldn't stop, I had quite a hard time taking off his coat. He looked exhausted, so I took him to the music room and settled him in a chair, then sent for some food. However, he didn't eat anything, and when he tried to drink the milk, he spilled it all over himself due to his trembling hands.
es: He was Gatsby's father, a solemn, desolate, and confused old man, who protected himself from the hot September day with a long, cheap coat. Tears kept welling up in his eyes from the emotion, and when I took his suitcase and hat, he started tugging at his sparse gray beard so insistently that I had trouble taking off his coat. He was about to collapse, so I took him to the music room and made him sit down while I ordered something for him to eat. But he couldn't eat, and the glass of milk spilled in his trembling hand.

en: “I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”
vi: "I read this news in the Chicago newspaper." The old man said. "This news was fully reported in the Chicago newspaper." "I hurried here immediately."
tr: “I read it in the Chicago newspaper; they wrote everything. I set out immediately,” he said.
es: —I saw the newspaper in Chicago —he said—. The Chicago newspaper covered everything. I came right away.

en: “I didn’t know how to reach you.”
vi: "I didn't know how to find you."
tr: “I didn't know how to reach you.”
es: —I didn't know how to locate him.

en: His eyes, seeing nothing, moved ceaselessly about the room.
vi: The old man's eyes kept moving around the room, but it seemed like he couldn't see anything.
tr: He was constantly looking around with unseeing eyes.
es: Her eyes, which looked without seeing, incessantly scanned the room.

en: “It was a madman,” he said. “He must have been mad.”
vi: "That guy is a madman. He is definitely a madman," the old man said.
tr: “He must be crazy!” he said, “Of course, if he weren't crazy, would he ever do this?”
es: —He was crazy —he said—. He had to be crazy.

en: “Wouldn’t you like some coffee?” I urged him.
vi: "Would you like some coffee?" I insisted.
tr: "Would you like some coffee?" I asked.
es: —Would you like some coffee? —I insisted.

en: “I don’t want anything. I’m all right now, Mr.—”
vi: "I don't need anything. I'm fine, you...."
tr: "I don't want anything." "I feel better now, Mr. --?"
es: —I don't want anything. I'm already fine, mister…

en: “Carraway.”
vi: "Carraway."
tr: “Carraway.”
es: —Carraway.

en: “Well, I’m all right now. Where have they got Jimmy?”
vi: "I'm feeling better now. Where did they put Jimmy?"
tr: “Yes, I'm quite fine like this. Where is Jimmy?”
es: —I'm fine now. Where have they put Jimmy?

en: I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys had come up on the steps and were looking into the hall; when I told them who had arrived, they went reluctantly away.
vi: I took the old man to the living room where his son was lying and left him there. A few small children crowded around the steps to look inside the house, and when I told them who had arrived, they reluctantly left.
tr: I took him to the guest room where his son was sleeping and left his side. A few little ones were curiously looking at the foyer from the top of the stairs. After I told them who the arriving person was, they reluctantly moved away.
es: I took him to the living room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some kids had climbed the steps and were peeking into the vestibule; when I told them who had just arrived, they left reluctantly.

en: After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendour of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride. I helped him to a bedroom upstairs; while he took off his coat and vest I told him that all arrangements had been deferred until he came.
vi: A moment later, Mr. Gatz opened the door and went outside, his mouth agape, his face slightly red, and his eyes shedding solitary, belated tears. He had reached an age where death no longer surprised or terrified him, and as he stood looking around for the first time, seeing the grand, magnificent foyer and the large rooms extending from one to another, his sorrow began to mix with an astonished pride. I helped him up to the bedroom upstairs. As he took off his outer coat and inner coat, I informed him that the funeral had been postponed to await his arrival.
tr: Not long after, Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out; his lips slightly parted, his face slightly flushed, and tears streaming from his eyes. He was at an age where death was no longer sudden. After a while, he lifted his head and looked around carefully for the first time; seeing the height and grandeur of the living room and the enormous rooms opening from here to other rooms, a tremendous pride mixed with his sorrow. I accompanied him as he went up to one of the bedrooms upstairs. As he took off his coat and vest, I told him that we hadn't started the funeral preparations yet because we were waiting for him.
es: Shortly after, Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth slightly open, his face slightly red, his eyes moist with some isolated and untimely tear. He had reached an age where death had lost its quality of terrible surprise and, when he then looked around and saw for the first time the height and splendor of the hall and the immense rooms that branched off from it and led to other rooms, his grief began to mix with a reverent pride. I helped him up to one of the bedrooms on the second floor; while he was taking off his jacket and vest, I told him that any arrangements had been postponed until his arrival.

en: “I didn’t know what you’d want, Mr. Gatsby—”
vi: "I don't know what you need, Mr. Gatsby.."
tr: “We didn't know what kind of ceremony you wanted, Mr. Gatsby.”
es: —I didn't know what you were planning to do, Mister Gatsby…

en: “Gatz is my name.”
vi: "My last name is Gatz."
tr: “My name is Gatz.”
es: —My name is Gatz.

en: “—Mr. Gatz. I thought you might want to take the body West.”
vi: "Mr. Gatz. I think you might want to take the body back to the West."
tr: "Yes, Mr. Gatz. Maybe you would like to take him to the West."
es: —… Mister Gatz. I thought you might want to take your son back West.

en: He shook his head.
vi: Mr. Gatz shook his head.
tr: He shook his head, meaning no, "Jimmy would have preferred the East.
es: He shook his head.

en: “Jimmy always liked it better down East. He rose up to his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy’s, Mr.—?”
vi: "Jimmy always preferred the East. He achieved his current position thanks to the East. Are you a friend of my son, you....?"
tr: He shook his head, meaning no, "Jimmy would have preferred the East. He got everything he desired here. Were you a friend of my son, Mr. --?"
es: —Jimmy always liked the East more. He reached his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy, mister…?

en: “We were close friends.”
vi: "We are best friends."
tr: “We were close friends.”
es: —We were close friends.

en: “He had a big future before him, you know. He was only a young man, but he had a lot of brain power here.”
vi: "My child still has a bright future ahead, you know that. He is still a young man, but he is full of spiritual strength right here."
tr: “His future was very bright, you know. How old was he anyway?
es: —He had a great future ahead of him, you know? He was just a boy, but he had brains… A lot of strength here…

en: He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.
vi: The old man touched his head in a very emotional manner. I nodded.
tr: Still, his mind worked very well,” he had said, bringing his hand to his head with pride. I nodded in agreement.
es: He touched his head very seriously, and I nodded.

en: “If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”
vi: "If it were still alive, it would be a great person. A person like James J. Hill. It could have helped build the nation."
tr: "If he had lived, he would have become a great man, like James J. Hill. He would have served the development of his country."
es: —If he had lived, he would have become a great man. A man like James J. Hill[23]. He would have contributed to building up the country.

en: “That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.
vi: "That's right." I replied somewhat unnaturally and uncomfortably.
tr: "You're right," I said, not really believing it.
es: —That's true —I said, uncomfortable.

en: He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.
vi: The old man reached out to feel the embroidered bedspread, pulled it up, then lay down straight and immediately fell asleep,
tr: She started tugging at the embroidered bedspread, and although it was difficult, she managed to open it. She lay stiffly on the bed and fell asleep immediately afterward.
es: He tried to remove the embroidered quilt from the bed, lay down very straight, and fell asleep instantly.

en: That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
vi: That night, someone called, and he clearly seemed frightened and demanded to know who I was before revealing his name.
tr: That night, a man with a sense of urgency in his voice called and insisted on learning my name before saying who he was.
es: That night, a person who could not hide their panic called on the phone and wanted to know who I was before telling me their name.

en: “This is Mr. Carraway,” I said.
vi: "My name is Carraway." I replied.
tr: Finally: "Ben Carraway," I said
es: —Talk to Mr. Carraway —I told him.

en: “Oh!” He sounded relieved. “This is Klipspringer.”
vi: "Oh!" The man's voice sounded noticeably relieved. "I am Klipspringer."
tr: “Ah, is that so?” he said, his voice sounding relieved. “I am Klipspringer.”
es: —Ah —he sounded calmer—. I am Klipspringer.

en: I was relieved too, for that seemed to promise another friend at Gatsby’s grave. I didn’t want it to be in the papers and draw a sightseeing crowd, so I’d been calling up a few people myself. They were hard to find.
vi: Hearing this, I also felt relieved and comfortable, knowing that there would be one more person attending Gatsby's funeral. I didn't want to publish an obituary in the newspaper, as it would attract a crowd of curious onlookers who would come just to see the scene, so I made phone calls to a few people myself. Finding these people was really difficult.
tr: I too was relieved at the thought that finally a friend who wanted to attend Gatsby’s funeral had emerged. In order to prevent a curious crowd from gathering, I did not want to announce the day and time of the ceremony in the newspaper. Therefore, although it was never easy to reach people, I was trying to inform them of the day and time by calling around myself.
es: I also felt more at ease because his call seemed to promise another friend for Gatsby's funeral. I didn't want to announce it in the newspapers and attract a crowd that would come as if to a show, so I made a few phone calls. It wasn't easy to find anyone.

en: “The funeral’s tomorrow,” I said. “Three o’clock, here at the house. I wish you’d tell anybody who’d be interested.”
vi: "The funeral is tomorrow." I said. "Three o'clock in the afternoon, here at this house. I hope you can pass the message to others who want to know."
tr: “The ceremony is tomorrow,” I said, “at 3 PM, it will be held here at his own house; I would appreciate it if you could inform those who are interested.”
es: —The funeral is tomorrow —I told Klipspringer—. At three, in the house. Notify everyone who might be interested…

en: “Oh, I will,” he broke out hastily. “Of course I’m not likely to see anybody, but if I do.”
vi: "Alright, I'll do it." He hurriedly interrupted. "I'm not sure if I'll meet anyone, but if I do, I'll pass the message."
tr: “Oh, of course,” he said immediately, “I don't think I'll see anyone, but if I do, I'll certainly tell them.”
es: —Ah, yes —he interrupted me—. I don't think I'll see anyone, but I'll do it if I get the chance.

en: His tone made me suspicious.
vi: His voice made me suspicious.
tr: His tone made me suspicious, "Of course, you will come," I said.
es: His tone made me suspicious.

en: “Of course you’ll be there yourself.”
vi: "But of course, you will come, won't you?"
tr: “Of course, of course, I will try to come.
es: —You will come, of course.

en: “Well, I’ll certainly try. What I called up about is—”
vi: "Well, let's see, I will definitely try my best. The reason I'm calling now is..."
tr: “Of course, of course, I will try to come. I was going to -”
es: —Well, I'll try, yes. The reason I was calling was because...

en: “Wait a minute,” I interrupted. “How about saying you’ll come?”
vi: "Wait a moment." I interrupted. "How about just saying that you will come?"
tr: "One minute," I interrupted, "First, why don't you say for sure whether you will come or not?"
es: —Wait a moment —I interrupted him—. Will he come or not?

en: “Well, the fact is—the truth of the matter is that I’m staying with some people up here in Greenwich, and they rather expect me to be with them tomorrow. In fact, there’s a sort of picnic or something. Of course I’ll do my best to get away.”
vi: "Well, to be honest, I'm with some people in Greenwich and they want me to go with them tomorrow. It seems like a picnic or something. Of course, I will do my best to find a way to back out."
tr: "Actually, the thing is, I am currently with some friends in Greenwich. And they expect me to join them tomorrow, they've planned a picnic or something like that. But of course, I will do my best to get out of it."
es: —Well, the fact is that... The truth is that I'm with some people in Greenwich, and they want me to spend the day with them tomorrow. There's a picnic or something like that. But yes, I'll do my best to get away.

en: I ejaculated an unrestrained “Huh!” and he must have heard me, for he went on nervously:
vi: I couldn't stop myself from exclaiming "Hmph," and he surely heard me, so he continued speaking in a flustered manner.
tr: I couldn't hold myself back, I blurted out, "Ha!"
es: I couldn't hold back a "yeah, right" and he must have heard me because he continued, nervously:

en: “What I called up about was a pair of shoes I left there. I wonder if it’d be too much trouble to have the butler send them on. You see, they’re tennis shoes, and I’m sort of helpless without them. My address is care of B. F.—”
vi: "The reason I called is because I left a pair of shoes there. I don't know if it would be too much trouble for you to have the housekeeper send them back to me. You know, those shoes are tennis shoes, and without them, we would be in a lot of trouble. Send them to me under the recipient name B. F...."
tr: He must have heard my voice because he continued in an irritated manner: "The reason I'm calling is the shoes I left there, if it's not too much trouble, I would be very grateful if you could send them to me with the servant. They are my tennis shoes, you know, I would be in a difficult situation without them. Here is the address: B. By F.'s hand –"
es: —Well, I called because I left a pair of shoes there. I don't know if it would be too much trouble to send them to me with the butler. They are tennis shoes and I feel quite helpless without them. My address is B. F….

en: I didn’t hear the rest of the name, because I hung up the receiver.
vi: I couldn't hear the rest of the name because I hung up the phone immediately.
tr: I didn't hear the rest because I had hung up the phone.
es: I didn't hear the rest of the name because I hung up.

en: After that I felt a certain shame for Gatsby—one gentleman to whom I telephoned implied that he had got what he deserved. However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.
vi: After that event, I felt ashamed for Gatsby. A man who answered when I called hinted that Gatsby deserved what happened to him. However, it was indeed my fault, because that man was someone who regularly drank the liquor at Gatsby's house to muster the courage to bitterly mock him. I should have remembered that and not called him.
tr: Later, when one of the gentlemen I called implied that Gatsby got what he deserved, I felt ashamed on Gatsby's behalf. But the fault was mine, because he was one of the most critical of Gatsby for attempting bootlegging, I should have known not to call him.
es: After that, I felt a certain shame for Gatsby: a gentleman I called on the phone insinuated that he had gotten what he deserved. The fault was mine, because I was one of those who, emboldened by Gatsby's liquor, used to speak of Gatsby with more disdain, and I should have been smart enough not to call him.

en: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that I pushed open, on the advice of an elevator boy, was marked “The Swastika Holding Company,” and at first there didn’t seem to be anyone inside. But when I’d shouted “hello” several times in vain, an argument broke out behind a partition, and presently a lovely Jewess appeared at an interior door and scrutinized me with black hostile eyes.
vi: On the morning of the funeral, I went to New York to meet Meyer Wolfsheim; otherwise, I truly had no other option. Following the directions of the elevator boy, I pushed open the door marked "Swatika Company," and it seemed there was no one inside. But when I loudly called "hello" several times, almost in vain, I heard arguing behind a screen. Then a beautiful Jewish woman appeared from the inner door, scrutinizing me with unfriendly dark eyes.
tr: On the morning of the funeral, I went to New York to see Meyer Wolfsheim; it seemed like I couldn't reach him any other way. On the door directed by the elevator boy, it said 'Swastika Holding': when I pushed the door and entered, I saw that no one was there. I called out 'Hello' a few times in vain, then I noticed some arguing voices coming from behind the partitions, and immediately after, a beautiful Jewish woman came out from one of the inner rooms and scrutinized me with her black eyes, with a hostile attitude.
es: The morning of the funeral I went to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; there seemed to be no other way to locate him. On the door that I opened, following the elevator operator's instructions, there was a sign that read The Swastika Holding Company, and at first, I thought there was no one there. But, after shouting "Good morning" in vain several times, an argument started in the adjoining room and soon a very attractive Jewish woman appeared at an interior door and examined me with black, hostile eyes.

en: “Nobody’s in,” she said. “Mr. Wolfshiem’s gone to Chicago.”
vi: "There is no one here, Mr. Wolfsheim has gone to Chicago." She said. The first part of the statement is clearly incorrect, because at that moment there was the sound of someone whistling off-key to the tune of "The Rosary" inside.
tr: “There is no one,” he said. “Mr. Wolfsheim is in Chicago.”
es: —There is no one —he said—. Mr. Wolfshiem has gone to Chicago.

en: The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
vi: The first part of the statement is clearly incorrect, because at that moment there was the sound of someone whistling off-key to the tune of "The Rosary" inside.
tr: However, it immediately became apparent that what they were saying was a lie, because someone inside had started to play the song 'Rosary' with a discordant whistle.
es: The first thing was evidently false, because inside someone had started whistling out of tune The rosary[24].

en: “Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
vi: "Please let him know that Mr. Carraway is here to see him."
tr: "Please tell him that Mr. Carraway wants to see him."
es: —Please do me the favor of telling him that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.

en: “I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
vi: "I have no way to make him come back from Chicago."
tr: “Do you think it’s possible for me to bring him from Chicago?
es: —Am I going to look for him in Chicago?

en: At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
vi: At that moment, a voice called out from behind the door, "Stella!" There was no mistaking it, it was Wolfsheim's voice.
tr: Just then, someone called out “Stella” from behind the door, and it was undoubtedly Wolfsheim’s voice.
es: At that moment a voice, unmistakably that of Mr. Wolfshiem, shouted "Estella!" from the other side of the door.

en: “Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
vi: "Just leave your business card on the table, I will hand it to him once he returns." She said hurriedly.
tr: "Leave your card on the table, I will definitely give it to him as soon as he returns," he said quickly.
es: —Leave your name on the table —she said—. I will give him the message as soon as he returns.

en: “But I know he’s there.”
vi: "But I know he is in there."
tr: “But I know that he is inside.”
es: —But I know it's here.

en: She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
vi: She took another step towards me, her hands moving up and down her hips in anger.
tr: He took a step closer and raised his hands in anger, then placed them on his hips and scolded, "You young people thought you could drop by here whenever you wanted," saying, "We are fed up and tired of it!
es: He took a step towards me and started running his hands up and down his hips.

en: “You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
vi: "Young people like you think you can barge in here anytime you want." She scolded. "We are really too fed up and tired of this kind of thing already." "When I say he is in Chicago, he is indeed in Chicago."
tr: He took a step closer and raised his hands in anger, then placed them on his hips and scolded, "You young people thought you could drop by here whenever you wanted," saying, "We are fed up and tired of it! If I say it's in Chicago, it's in Chicago."
es: —You young people think you can come in here whenever you feel like it —he scolded me—. And we're fed up with it, to the point of nausea. When I say he's in Chicago, he's in Chicago.

en: I mentioned Gatsby.
vi: I mentioned Gatsby's name.
tr: I told her about Gatsby.
es: I mentioned Gatsby.

en: “Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
vi: "Oh....." She looked at me once more. "If that's the case, then please....
tr: "Ah!" After scrutinizing me once more, “One moment... What was your name?”
es: —Ah —he looked at me again—. Could you… repeat your name for me?

en: She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
vi: What is your name?" She immediately disappeared, and a moment later Meyer Wolfsheim appeared, standing solemnly at the door, extending both hands to welcome me. He led me into the office, speaking to me with great respect, saying that this was a time of sorrow for everyone. Then he offered me a cigar.
tr: He disappeared. Soon after, Meyer Wolfsheim appeared at the door with a dignified expression on his face, extending both hands as he approached. Taking my hand between his, he said in a respectful voice that these days were sorrowful and difficult for all of us, then took me to his office and offered me a cigar.
es: He vanished. At that moment, Meyer Wolfshiem solemnly appeared at the door, extending both hands to me. He led me into his office while commenting in a reverent voice that it was a very sad time for all of us, and he offered me a cigar.

en: “My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
vi: "I still remember the first time I met him. At that time, he was a recently discharged major, still wearing all the medals he had earned in the war. He was so poor that he couldn't afford civilian clothes and had to keep wearing his military uniform. The first time I met him was when he came to the Winebrenner billiard hall on Forty Street to ask for a job. He hadn't eaten anything for two or three days. I invited him to 'come have lunch with me'. In just half an hour, he had eaten four dollars' worth of food."
tr: “I remember the day we first met,” he said. “He was a young major, freshly discharged, with his chest full of medals earned in the war. He was so hard up that he couldn't afford civilian clothes and walked around in his uniform. When I first saw him, he had come to the Winebrenner billiard hall on 43rd Street to ask for a job. He hadn't had a bite to eat for two days. ‘Come, let's eat together,’ I had said. He devoured four dollars' worth of food in half an hour.”
es: —Memory takes me back to the day I met him —he said—. A major, very young, recently discharged and covered in medals he had won in the war. He didn't have a cent: he kept wearing the uniform because he didn't have money to buy clothes. I saw him for the first time at Winebrenner's billiards, on Forty-third Street, where he came in to ask for a job. He hadn't eaten for two days. «Come have lunch with me», I said to him. He devoured more than four dollars' worth of food in half an hour.

en: “Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
vi: "Did you help him start his career?" I probed.
tr: "Did you hire him?" I asked
es: —Did you introduce him to the business?

en: “Start him! I made him.”
vi: "Help him get started? Actually, I was the one who built him up."
tr: "I didn't just hire him! I created him-"
es: —Introduce him! I made him a businessman.

en: “Oh.”
vi: "Oh"
tr: “Hey!’”
es: —Ah.

en: “I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
vi: "I pulled him up from nothing, dragged him out of the gutter. I immediately recognized that he was a handsome, courteous young man, and when he said he had studied at Oxford, I knew I had a place to use him. I got him to join the American Legion, where he held a very high position. At the beginning, he worked for one of my clients in Albany. "We have been close like this in everything." Wolfsheim raised his two banana-shaped fingers, "always side by side."
tr: “I created him from nothing, pulled him out of the mire. It was evident at first glance that he was actually a well-groomed young gentleman; moreover, when I heard he had studied at Oggsford, I was sure he would benefit me as well. I got him into the American Legion, where he also proved himself and gained respect, immediately solving a client's issue from Albany. We bonded, became inseparable. That's how we were!” he said, bringing his two chubby fingers together to show, “as you can understand, nothing could come between us.”
es: —I pulled him out of nowhere, straight from the gutter. I immediately realized he was a young man with good looks and a gentlemanly air, and when he told me he had been at Oggsford, I knew he could be very useful to me. I advised him to join the American Legion, where he was highly regarded. He then did a job for one of my clients in Albany. We were this close —he raised two bulbous fingers—, always together.

en: I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
vi: I wonder in my heart whether that cooperation between the two included arranging the 1919 football championship in advance.
tr: I was wondering if they had any involvement in the match-fixing scandal of the 1919 World Cup.
es: I wondered if that society had included the operation of Major League Baseball in 1919.

en: “Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
vi: "Now he has passed away." After a moment, I said. "You were Gatsby's closest friend, so I know you will want to attend Gatsby's funeral this afternoon."
tr: “He is no longer alive,” I said a minute later, “As his closest friend, I am sure you will be at the funeral ceremony this afternoon.”
es: —And now he is dead —he said after a few seconds—. You were his closest friend, so I know you want me to go to the funeral this afternoon.

en: “I’d like to come.”
vi: "I really want to attend."
tr: "I would like to come"
es: I would like to go.

en: “Well, come then.”
vi: "In that case, just go."
tr: "Then let's go.""
es: —Very well, then come.

en: The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
vi: The tuft of hair in his nose quivered slightly, and he shook his head, his eyes glistening with tears.
tr: The thick hairs sprouting from his nostrils seemed to tremble again; as he shook his head from side to side, his eyes filled with tears.
es: The hairs in his nostrils vibrated slightly and, while shaking his head, his eyes filled with tears.

en: “I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
vi: "I can't go - I can't get involved." He said.
tr: “I can't, I can't get involved in this.”
es: —I can't… I can't get involved in that —he said.

en: “There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
vi: "There is nothing involved. Everything is over."
tr: “I can't, I can't get involved in this.” "There is no issue to interfere with; everything is over now."
es: —There is nothing to get involved in. Everything is already over.

en: “When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
vi: "When someone is killed, I never want to get involved. I stay away. When I was younger, I was different; back then, if a friend of mine died, no matter the cost, I would stay with them until the end. You might consider that sentimental, but it really was like that; I stayed with them until the bitter end."
tr: “If there is a murdered man involved, I absolutely do not want to get involved in that matter. I stay away. Was I like this when I was young? It was different then of course: when a friend of mine died, even if my hands were covered in blood, I would be by his side to send him off on his final journey. You might find me overly emotional, but even if it ended in death, I would be there for him.”
es: —When they kill a man, I don't like to get involved. I stay on the sidelines. When I was young, it was different: if a friend died, no matter how, I stayed by their side until the end. It may seem sentimental to you, but I'm serious: until the end, no matter how bitter it was.

en: I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
vi: I realized that for some personal reason, he definitely would not attend the funeral, so I stood up.
tr: I understood that he had his own reasons for not coming, and I stood up to leave.
es: I saw that, for some particular reason, he had decided not to attend the funeral, so I stood up.

en: “Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
vi: "An "Have you gone to college yet?" Wolfsheim suddenly asked.
tr: “Did you go to university?” he asked, out of the blue.
es: —Have you been to university? —he asked suddenly.

en: For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
vi: For a moment, I thought he wanted to propose a "business deal," but he just nodded and shook my hand.
tr: For a moment, I thought he was going to propose a 'partnership' as he would say, but I was wrong; he just greeted me and shook my hand.
es: For a moment, I thought he was going to propose a "coneggsion" to me, but he just nodded and shook my hand.

en: “Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”
vi: "We should express our feelings to a person while he is still alive, not after he has died," he advised. "Other than that, my principle is not to get involved in anything."
tr: “It is important to show affection to our friends while they are alive, not after they have died!” he pontificated. “After death, I leave everything just as it is.”
es: —We have to learn to show our friendship to a man when he is alive and not after he is dead —he suggested—. Afterwards, my rule is not to move things.

en: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
vi: When I left Wolfsheim's office, the sky had already darkened, and I returned to West Egg in the drizzle. After changing clothes, I went next door and found Mr. Gatz pacing back and forth in the house, agitated. His pride in his son and what he had accomplished kept growing. Now you have something to show me.
tr: When I left there, I noticed the dark clouds gathered in the sky; as soon as I reached West Egg, it started to rain. I changed my clothes and immediately went to my neighbor's house. I found Mr. Gatz pacing up and down in the living room; he was very excited. He was becoming increasingly proud of his son and his son's wealth.
es: When I left the office, the sky had darkened, and it was drizzling as I arrived at West Egg. I changed clothes, went over to the neighboring house, and found Mr. Gatz walking around the foyer, excited. The pride for his son and his son's possessions had not stopped growing, and he wanted to show me something.

en: “Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
vi: "Jimmy sent me this picture." The old man took a wallet out of his pocket with trembling fingers. "Look at this."
tr: He said he wanted to show me something. “With trembling hands, he took out a photo from his wallet, "Jimmy had sent this to me," he said, "Look!"
es: —Jimmy sent me this photo —he took out the wallet with trembling fingers—. Look.

en: It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
vi: That is a picture of Gatsby's mansion, the corner of the picture is torn and dirty with many fingerprints. The old man eagerly pointed out every detail in the picture to me. "Look here." He said while looking into my eyes, searching for admiration in them. He had shown the picture so many times that I thought to him the picture might be more real than the actual mansion outside.
tr: This was a photo of the house we were in. The edges were worn, and it was dirty from being passed from hand to hand. "Look at this?" he eagerly showed me all the details, then looked at me, searching for a sign of admiration in my eyes. He had shown it to so many people that I got the impression that this photo seemed more real to him than the house itself.
es: It was a photograph of the house, torn at the corners and dirty from many hands. He pointed out every detail with fervor. «Look at this!», and he sought admiration in my eyes. He had shown it so many times that I believe it was more real to him than the house itself.

en: “Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
vi: "Jimmy sent this picture to me." "I think this picture is very beautiful." "It is very sharp."
tr: “Jimmy sent this to me. Isn't it a beautiful photo? It shows everything so clearly.’”
es: —Jimmy sent it to me. I think it's a very good photo. Everything looks great in it.

en: “Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
vi: "Yes, very distinctive." "Have you seen him recently?"
tr: “Really beautiful. Have you met recently?
es: —Yes, very well. Had you seen your son lately?

en: “He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
vi: "It visited me about two years ago and bought me the house I am living in now. Of course, when it left home, our family was still very poor, but now looking back, I understand that it left for a reason. My son saw a bright future ahead of him. Then, after becoming successful, he was very generous with me."
tr: “He visited me two years ago and bought me the house I am currently living in. When he left the house, our relationship was understandably strained; but now I can see that there was a reason for it. He had already realized back then that he had a bright future ahead of him! Even after becoming successful, he always treated me generously.”
es: —He came to see me two years ago and bought me the house where I live now. He left us devastated when he ran away from home, but now I see he had reasons to do it. I knew he had a great future ahead of him. And as soon as he started to succeed, he was very generous with me.

en: He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
vi: The old man reluctantly did not want to put away the picture, trying to hold it for one more minute, lingering to hold it in front of me. Then he put the picture into his wallet, pulling out from his pocket an old, worn, and tattered notebook titled "HOPALONG CASSIDY".
tr: He seemed reluctant to put the photograph away; for a while longer, he held it in front of my eyes as if to stall. After putting it back in his wallet, this time he took out an old book called Hopalong Cassidy from his pocket.
es: It seemed to resist putting the photo away and let me see it for a few more seconds. Then he put away the wallet and took out of his pocket a very old, grimy, and unbound copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy[25].

en: “Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
vi: "Look here, this book was his when he was little, proving what kind of person he is."
tr: "Look at this, he never put it down when he was a child. It was clear even back then."
es: —Look, this book was his, from when he was a little boy. Now you'll see.

en: He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
vi: The old man opened the book from the back cover, then turned it around and handed it to me to see. On the last page of the book, the words "schedule" were written, and the date recorded there was September 12, 1906. Below that, it was written:
tr: He opened the back cover and turned the book towards me so I could see; on the last blank page, it was written in handwriting: PROGRAM. The date September 12, 1906, was inscribed above it, and below it was a schedule:
es: He opened it from the end and turned it around so I could see it. On the flyleaf, they had written the word SCHEDULE in block letters and the date, September 12, 1906. And below:

tr: Getting out of bed 6. 00
es: Wake up 6:00

tr: Weight training and the wall climbing training 6. 15 - 6. 30
es: Gymnastics and weights 6. 15-6. 30

vi: Study electricity, etc............ 7. 15-8. 15 "
tr: Work on electricity, etc. 7. 15 - 8. 15
es: Study electricity, etc 7. 15-8. 15

vi: Playing baseball and sports............. 4. 30-5. 00 "
tr: Baseball and sports 16. 30 - 17. 00
es: Baseball and sports 16. 30-17. 00

vi: Practice speaking and how to maintain a composed demeanor 5.00-6.00 "
tr: Eloquence, good posture and
es: Practical exercises in eloquence and savoir-faire 17. 00-18. 00

vi: Research necessary initiatives........... 7.00-9.00 "
tr: stance study 17. 00 – 18. 00 Necessary inventions examination 19. 00 - 21. 00

en: General Resolves
vi: COMMON RESOLUTIONS
tr: DECISIONS TAKEN
es: GENERAL PURPOSES

en: No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
vi: Do not waste time at Shafters' house or (insert someone's name, I couldn't read it).
tr: * Shafters or (the name here was unreadable) no dawdling and wasting time
es: Don't waste time at Shafters or (illegible name)

en: No more smokeing or chewing.
vi: Quit smoking, quit chewing gum.
tr: * No smoking and no chewing gum
es: Quit smoking and chewing gum

en: Bath every other day
vi: Bathe every other day.
tr: * A bath will be taken every other day
es: Bathing every other day

vi: Read one book or a specialized magazine to enhance knowledge every week.
tr: * Every week, a good book or magazine will be read
es: Read a useful magazine or book each week

vi: Save $5.00 (crossed out) $3.00 a week.

vi: Behave well with parents.
