en: “I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
vi: "I happened to find this notebook. It shows what kind of person my child is." The old man said.
tr: “I found this book by chance,” said the old man, “it explains the situation very well, doesn't it?” “Yes.
es: —I found this book by chance —said the old man—. Isn't it revealing?

en: “It just shows you.”
vi: "You are right."
tr: It explains.”
es: —It's revealing.

en: “Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
vi: "Jimmy is someone who definitely has to rise up. He always has that determination. Did you notice what he wrote about what needs to be done to develop his mind? He has always been excellent at that. Once he called me as dumb as a pig, and I hit him for daring to say that."
tr: “It was certain that Jimmy would advance in life. He always made decisions like this. Did you see what he did to improve himself? He always did that. Once, he told me I ate like a pig, and I beat him up.”
es: —Jimmy was destined to succeed. He was always setting goals like that. Do you realize how much he cared about cultivating his intelligence? In that, he was exemplary. Once he told me that I ate like a pig, and I hit him.

en: He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.
vi: The old man reluctantly did not want to close the notebook, kept reading each part aloud, then turned to look at me eagerly. I think he hoped that I would copy what was in the notebook to use for myself.
tr: He didn't seem very willing to close the book; after reading each item aloud, he would look at my face. I think he wanted me to memorize this list for my own use.
es: He resisted closing the book, reading each line aloud and looking at me anxiously. I think he even expected me to copy the list for my own use.

en: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
vi: Around nearly three o'clock, the Protestant minister arrived from Flushing. I began to look out the window uncontrollably to see if any other cars were coming. Gatsby's father did the same. Time passed by like that, as the household servants gathered and stood in a line inside, at which point the old man's eyes started blinking, showing signs of impatience, anxiously remarking indistinctly if it would rain. The minister glanced at his watch many times, so I pulled him aside to ask him to wait for another half hour. But it didn't help at all. No one came.
tr: Before the three Protestant ministers called from Rushing arrived, I couldn't help but stand at the window and wait for other cars to come. Gatsby's father was doing the same thing. Time passed. When the servants began to gather in the hall and wait, Mr. Gatz started blinking his eyes and talking about the rain in a sorrowful voice, not really knowing what to say. He was also frequently checking his watch. I pulled him aside and asked him to wait another half hour. However, it was of no use. No one had come.
es: Shortly before three, the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look out the windows involuntarily to see if more cars would appear. Gatsby's father did the same. And, as time passed, when the servants were already waiting in the vestibule, he began to blink nervously and talk about the rain with concern and uncertainty. The minister looked at his watch a couple of times, so I took him aside and asked him to wait half an hour. But it was useless. No one came.

en: About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
vi: Around five o'clock, our three cars arrived at the cemetery, stopping by the gate under a misty drizzle. Leading the way was the black and soaked hearse, followed by Mr. Gatz, the priest, and me in the limousine, a bit further behind were about four or five servants and mail carriers from West Egg in Gatsby's station wagon, all of them drenched like drowned rats. As we began to step through the cemetery gate, I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone's footsteps splashing on the waterlogged ground. I looked around. The newcomer was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had once seen standing in awe before Gatsby's books one evening three months ago.
tr: At around five in the evening, our procession of three cars reached the cemetery gate and stopped under a light drizzle. In the front was the pitch-black and wet hearse, behind it was the limousine with Mr. Gatz, the priest, and me, and a little behind us was Gatsby's station wagon with five or six drenched servants and the West Egg postman. As we passed through the main gate and walked towards the cemetery, I heard a car stop and then someone splashing through puddles behind us. When I turned around, I recognized the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had seen admiring the books in Gatsby's library about three months ago.
es: Around five o'clock, our procession of three cars arrived at the cemetery and stopped at the entrance under a persistent drizzle: first the hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz, the minister, and I in the limousine, and very shortly after, in Gatsby's van, four or five servants and the West Egg postman, all soaked to the bone. As we were entering the cemetery, I heard a car stop and the sound of someone splashing in the wet ground behind us. I turned to look. It was the man with owl-like glasses whom I had discovered one night, three months ago, marveling at the books in Gatsby's library.

en: I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
vi: Since that time, I have not seen him again. I do not know why he knew about the funeral, I don't even know his name. Raindrops trickled down his thick glasses, he took them off and wiped them dry so he could see the cloth covering the grave being opened.
tr: I hadn't seen him since that night. I didn't know how or where he learned about the funeral, nor did I even know his name. Rainwater was flowing down his glasses; he took them off and wiped them to see the tarpaulin spread over Gatsby's grave.
es: I hadn't seen him since then. I don't know how he found out about the burial, I don't even know his name. The rain ran down his very thick glasses, and he took them off and dried them to see how they lifted the tarp that protected Gatsby's grave.

en: I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
vi: I tried to concentrate my thoughts to remember Gatsby for a moment, he had gone too far already. I could only recall, without a hint of resentment, that Daisy had never sent a message or a flower. I heard someone murmuring indistinctly, "Blessings be upon the deceased when rain falls on their grave." Then the owl-eyed man said "Amen" in a resolute voice.
tr: I was trying to think of Gatsby, but he was now far away. Though I wasn't offended, my mind was stuck on the fact that Daisy hadn't sent any news or even a flower. I heard someone in the distance murmur, 'Blessed are the dead who are touched by rain,' and the man with owl-eyed glasses responded boldly, "Amen!"
es: I tried to think about Gatsby for a moment, but he was already too far away, and the only thing I could remember, without resentment, was that Daisy had not sent a message or a single flower. I barely heard a vague murmur: "Blessed are the dead upon whom the rain falls." And the man with owl eyes answered forcefully: "Amen."

en: We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
vi: We struggled to quickly get to the car in the rain. Mr. Sharp-Eyed told me as we reached the cemetery gate.
tr: As I left the crowd and ran towards the soaking wet cars, the owl-eyed one came up to me.
es: We hurried back to the cars, under the rain. Owl Eyes spoke with me at the door:

en: “I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
vi: "I couldn't make it home in time." He explained.
tr: "I couldn't come home," he said.
es: —I couldn't go to the house.

en: “Neither could anybody else.”
vi: "No one came either."
tr: "In fact, no one could come."
es: —No one has been able to go.

en: “Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
vi: "Is that so." He was astonished. "Oh my, why, the people who frequent that place usually number in the hundreds."
tr: “Come on!” he said in astonishment, “Oh my God, hundreds wouldn't come out of that house.”
es: —Don't tell me! —he burst out—. My God! They were going hundreds.

en: He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
vi: He took off his glasses to clean them once more from the inside out.
tr: He took off his glasses again and cleaned them, this time both inside and outside.
es: He took off his glasses and cleaned them again, inside and out.

en: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.
vi: "So miserable." He said.
tr: “Poor rascal!” he said.
es: —The poor son of a bitch —he said.

en: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
vi: One of the most vivid and profound memories in me is the times when I returned home in the West for Christmas holidays from preparatory school, and later from university. Students whose homes were farther than the city of Chicago would gather together at six o'clock in the evening on a December day under the dim lights of the old Union Station train station. There were also a few friends from Chicago, who were ready to join in their own holiday festivities, present at the platform to bid a hasty farewell to their friends. I still remember the image of fur coats worn by female students returning home from the women's dormitories, the chattering voices from breaths that had turned into mist, and the hands raised high above their heads waving as they caught sight of familiar faces from before. Then the invitations to respond, "Are you going to the Ordways' family? Or the Herseys' family? Or the Schultzes' family?" After that, the long green train tickets were tightly held in our gloved hands. Finally, the image of the yellow train cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul lines, looking as cheerful as Christmas Eve, lying on the tracks next to the platform gate.
tr: One of my most vivid memories is my return to the West during Christmas time, first when I was in the preparatory class of the university, and later during my faculty years. Those of us who were going beyond Chicago would gather at six o'clock on a December evening at the old and dark Union Station, hurriedly bidding farewell to our Chicagoan friends who had already embraced the holiday spirit. I will never forget the girls from Miss so-and-so’s school, wrapped in their furs, chatting away with steam coming from their mouths, eagerly waving their frostbitten hands when they ran into an acquaintance, calling out from one place to another, “Are you going to the Ordways? To the Herseys? To the Schuttzes?” and those long, green tickets we held tightly in our gloved hands. When the dirty yellow carriages of the Chicago, Milwaukee, and St. Paul line pulled into the station, we would cheer up as if the Christmas festivities had begun.
es: One of my most vivid memories is the return to the West from school and, later, from university during Christmas. Those who continued their journey beyond Chicago gathered at the old Union Station at six on a December evening with some friends from Chicago who, already immersed in the holiday cheer, came to see them off. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss So-and-So's school, and the conversations amidst the frosty breath, and the hands raised in greeting when we saw old friends, and how we compared our invitation lists, "Are you going to the Ordways', the Herseys', the Schultzes' party?" And the train tickets, long and green, tightly held in gloved hands. And, finally, on the track, near the entrance, the gloomy carriages of the Chicago, Milwaukee, and Saint Paul line, which seemed as cheerful to us as Christmas itself.

en: When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
vi: When our train plunged into the winter night, the white snow—yes, the very real snow of our homeland—began to stretch out on both sides of the tracks, reflecting and sparkling through the train's windows. The flickering lights of the small stations in Wisconsin quickly passed by, and a wave of thrilling excitement suddenly filled the air. We took a deep breath of that air as we walked back to our seats from dinner, passing through the cold corridors. In this brief and strange hour, we became aware, in an indescribable way, of our distinct characteristics compared to this homeland before we would be indistinguishably blended into it.
tr: When the train moved and plunged into the winter nights, the real snow, that is, our snow, would start to stretch out on either side of us and stain the windows. As the feeble lights of the Wisconsin stations appeared and disappeared, the surroundings would suddenly take on a sharp and wild atmosphere. While returning to our seats from the dining car, in the cold passages between the cars we passed through, we would inhale this air into our lungs and deeply feel our connection with this country, at least for this strange hour-long period, before melting back into it and disappearing.
es: When we ventured into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to spread everywhere and to twinkle and crash against the train windows, and the dim lights of the small Wisconsin stations passed by, the air suddenly hardened, sharp and cutting. We inhaled it deeply when we returned from dinner across the frozen platforms, inconceivably aware for an extraordinary hour of our identification with the country, before joining and blending with it once again.

en: That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
vi: That is my Midwestern homeland, not the wheat fields, or the meadows, or the remote Swedish towns, but the emotionally charged train journeys that take me back to my childhood, to the streetlights, the sleigh bells of horse-drawn sleds in the cold dark night, and the shadows of holiday wreaths hanging on doors, illuminated on the white snow from the brightly lit windows. I am a part of those things, a bit solemn and full of emotions with these long cold winters, a bit complacent because I was born and raised in the house of the Carraway family, in a city where houses have been called by family names for decades. Now I see that in the end, the story that just happened was ultimately a story of the West. Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan, and I, we were all from the West, and perhaps we all shared some flaws that made us unable to adapt to life in the East.
tr: This was my Midwest; not wheat fields, prairies, and dilapidated Swedish villages, but my youthful, excited train rides home, the street lamps in the frosty darkness, the jingling sounds of sleds, and the shadows cast by holly Christmas wreaths on the windows illuminated by lights. I am a part of these, with a bit of the weight given by those long winter nights upon me, and a sense of contentment from having grown up in the Carraway house in a town where homes are known by the family names of those who have lived in them for decades. Today, I understand that all these things I have described are actually the story of the West: Tom and Gatsby, Daisy, Jordan, and I; we were all Westerners, and perhaps we shared a common flaw that secretly prevented us from fully adapting to the life of the East.
es: That was my Midwest, not the wheat or the prairies or the lost towns of the Swedes, but the thrilling trains of my youth on which I returned, and the street lamps and the sleigh bells in the frosty darkness and the shadows of the holly wreaths that the lit windows cast upon the snow. I am part of that world, a bit solemn due to the feeling of those long winters, a bit proud for having grown up in the Carraway house, in a town where houses are still known for decades by the name of the family that owns them. Now I understand that, after all, this story has been a story of the West: Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I are from the West, and perhaps we suffer in common from some deficiency that makes us subtly unadaptable to life in the East.

en: Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. Gravely the men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.
vi: Even when the Eastern United States fascinated me the most, even when I was about to deeply realize its superiority compared to the dull cities sprawling and expanding on the other side of the Ohio River, with endless judicial investigations leaving only children and the elderly, even then it still seemed distorted to me. Especially West Egg still appeared in my bizarre dreams. I saw it like an evening scene in a painting by the famous artist El Greco: hundreds of houses, a mix of both traditional and absurdly bizarre, hiding under a gloomy, heavy, sorrowful sky and a dim moon. The main foreground of the painting is four solemnly dressed men in suits walking along the sidewalk, carrying a stretcher on which lies a woman in a white evening gown, completely drunk. Her arm hangs loosely beside the stretcher, sparkling coldly with jewelry. Solemnly, the men turn into a house, a house that is not hers. Yet no one knows the name of that woman, nor do they care.
tr: Even on the days that excited me the most; even when I was acutely aware of the superiority of the East compared to those boring, expanding, and sprawling cities beyond Ohio, with their endless interrogations spared only for small children and the elderly, the East always seemed somewhat skewed to me. Especially West Egg, which adorned my most incredible dreams. I liken this place, with its hundred traditional yet grotesque houses crouching under a low, sullen sky and a dull, lackluster moon, to a night scene painted by El Greco. In the foreground, four serious men, dressed in tailcoats, walk with a stretcher in their hands, on which a woman in a white dress lies drunk. The hand dangling from the stretcher sparkles with jewelry. The men leave the woman at a house with a serious demeanor, but no one knows her name, nor do they care that they have left her at the wrong address.
es: Even when the East impressed me more, even when I was more aware of its superiority over the boring, soulless, and sluggish cities beyond Ohio, with their inquisitive and endless snooping from which only children and the very elderly are spared, even then the East had a note of distortion for me. West Egg, especially, continues to appear in my most fantastic dreams. I see it as a nocturnal scene painted by El Greco: a hundred houses, both conventional and grotesque, huddled under a sullen and oppressive sky and a lusterless moon. In the foreground, four solemn men, dressed in formal attire, walk along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in an evening gown. The hand, hanging to one side, sparkles jeweled and cold. Very serious, the men enter a house, a wrong house. But no one knows the woman's name, nor does anyone care.

en: After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.
vi: After Gatsby's death, the East had become haunted for me, it had been distorted and twisted Even the power of my eyes could not correct it. So when the blue smoke from the dry leaves rose into the air and the winds blew straight through the wet clothes hanging on the line, I decided to return to my hometown.
tr: After Gatsby's death, the East seemed haunted to me, distorted beyond my ability to correct with my eyes. Therefore, as blue smoke rose from the dried leaves and the wind stiffened the laundry on the lines, I decided to go home.
es: After Gatsby's death, the East seemed enchanted, distorted, beyond my eyes' ability to correct it. So, when the smoke from the dry leaves was already floating in the air and the damp clothes began to freeze on the clotheslines at the breath of the wind, I decided to return home.

en: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
vi: There is one thing I need to do before leaving, an awkward and uncomfortable matter that I should have left alone. However, I want everything to be settled before I go, not trusting those eager and indifferent waves of the sea to wash away my redundant and trashy affairs. I went to meet Jordan Baker to talk about what had happened between us and what happened afterward to me alone. She sat in a large chair listening, completely motionless.
tr: There was one more thing I had to do before leaving, maybe it would be better to leave it as it is; an unpleasant, disagreeable thing. Still, I wanted to set everything right before leaving, I couldn't just rely on the ready and indifferent sea to clean up my remnants. So I went to see Jordan Baker. We talked about what had happened to us first, and then what had happened to me; she had just sat there in a big chair, listening to me with an extremely calm demeanor.
es: There was something I had to do before I left, something unpleasant and embarrassing that probably would have been better left undone. But I wanted to leave everything in order and not rely on the indifferent and diligent sea to take away my trash. I saw Jordan Baker and talked about what had happened between us, and what had happened to me afterward, and she listened to me, very still, in a large armchair.

en: She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the colour of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.
vi: Jordan was dressed in golf attire, I remember thinking she looked like a beautiful illustration, her chin slightly raised in an aristocratic manner, her hair the color of autumn leaves, her rosy brown face resembling a fingerless glove resting on her knee. After listening to me, she didn't comment but simply stated that she was engaged to someone else. I doubted her words, even though I knew that many would marry her with just a nod from Jordan. However, I still pretended to be surprised. For a moment, I wondered if I had made a mistake. After thinking for a while, I hurriedly stood up and took my leave.
tr: She was in her golf clothes; I remember thinking she looked like a beautiful painting with her proudly raised chin, hair the color of autumn leaves, and sunburned skin that matched the color of the golf glove she held in her lap. When I finished telling her everything, without making any comments, she simply said she was engaged to someone. Even though I knew she had many suitors she could marry immediately if she approved, I didn't really believe what she said. Still, of course, I didn't neglect to pretend to be surprised. For a moment, I seemed to hesitate about whether I was doing the right thing, but when I thought it over again, I quickly pulled myself together.
es: She was dressed like a golfer, and I remember thinking that she looked like a good picture for an illustrated magazine, with her chin gracefully raised, hair the color of autumn leaves, and her face the same tanned tone as the fingerless glove resting on her knee. When I finished, she told me without further comment that she had gotten engaged to someone else. I didn't quite believe it, although there were several with whom she could have married with a simple nod, but I pretended to be surprised. For a moment I wondered if I might be mistaken, then I quickly thought it all over again and stood up to say goodbye.

en: “Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”
vi: "Anyway, it was you who left me." Jordan suddenly said. "You abandoned me over the phone. Now I don't care about you anymore, but anyway, it was a new experience for me, it made me feel dizzy for a while."
tr: When I stood up to say goodbye, she suddenly said, "Still, you brushed me off."" That's exactly what you did on the phone. I don't care about you anymore, but it was a very new experience for me, so I felt dazed for a while."
es: —But you were the one who left me —said Jordan suddenly—. You left me over the phone. You no longer matter to me in the slightest, but that was a new experience for me, and for a while, I felt a bit disoriented.

en: We shook hands.
vi: We shook hands.
tr: We shook hands.
es: We shook hands.

en: “Oh, and do you remember”—she added—“a conversation we had once about driving a car?”
vi: "Oh, do you still remember?" "Remember the conversation we had once while we were in the car," Jordan added.
tr: “Do you remember?” he asked, “We had a conversation about driving.”
es: —Ah, do you remember —he added— a conversation we had once about driving a car?

en: “Why—not exactly.”
vi: "What?" "I don't remember clearly."
tr: “Actually, I don't remember exactly.”
es: —No, I don't remember.

en: “You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”
vi: "You said that a bad driver is only safe until they meet another bad driver. Actually, I met another bad driver, didn't I? I mean, if I misunderstood that idea, then it's my mistake. I thought you were an honest, straightforward person. I suppose that is your hidden pride."
tr: “You said a bad driver is only safe until he meets another bad driver. Well, I finally met another bad driver, didn't I? So the reason I couldn't predict it correctly was my own carelessness. I thought you were honest and straightforward and took pride in it.”
es: —Didn't you say that a bad driver is only safe until they meet another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn't I? I mean, if I made so many mistakes, it was due to my own carelessness. I thought you were a pretty honest and sincere person. I thought that was your secret pride.

en: “I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honour.”
vi: "I am already thirty years old. Five years past the age where one can deceive oneself and still call it honor."
tr: “I am thirty,” I said, “I am five years too old to lie to myself and call it honor.”
es: —I am thirty years old —I said—. I have surpassed by five years the age of lying to myself and calling it honor.

en: She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.
vi: I said. Jordan did not answer. Angry, with a lingering bit of love in my heart and feeling immensely regretful, I turned and walked away.
tr: He did not respond. I was angry at him, still a little in love, and very sad. I turned my back and walked away.
es: She didn't answer me. Angry, half in love with her and tremendously hurt, I turned around and left.

en: One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewellery store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.
vi: One late afternoon near the end of October, I met Tom Buchanan. He was walking in front of me on Fifth Avenue with his usual brisk and aggressive stride. Tom's arms were spread out from his body as if ready to fend off anyone who might bump into him. Tom's head was turning sharply from side to side to match his darting eyes. When I slowed down to avoid overtaking Tom, he stopped and frowned while looking into the window of a jewelry store. At that moment, Tom suddenly saw me, turned around, and extended his hand.
tr: At the end of October, one evening I ran into Tom Buchanan. On Fifth Avenue, with his usual aggressive demeanor, walking ahead of me with his hands slightly forward as if ready to fight anyone who crossed his path, moving his head side to side to match his restless scanning eyes. While I slowed down to avoid catching up to him, he stopped and began to frown at a jeweler's display window. Then he saw me, came over, and extended his hand.
es: One late October afternoon, I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me on Fifth Avenue, alert and aggressive as always, his hands slightly away from his body as if to fend off any intrusion, and jerking his head in rhythm with his restless eyes. At the moment I slowed down to avoid overtaking him, he stopped to look, frowning, at a jewelry store window. Then he saw me and stepped back, extending his hand to me.

en: “What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”
vi: "What's going on, Nick? Don't you want to shake my hand??"
tr: “What's the matter, Nick? Aren't you going to shake my hand?”
es: —What's wrong, Nick? Are you refusing to shake my hand?

en: “Yes. You know what I think of you.”
vi: "That's right. You know how I feel about you."
tr: “Yes. You know what I think about it.”
es: —Yes. You know what I think of you.

en: “You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”
vi: "You are really crazy, Nick." Tom said quickly. "Terribly crazy." "I don't know what's wrong with you." "Tom." I interrogated.
tr: “You are crazy,” he said immediately, “Completely insane. I don't understand what your problem is.”
es: —You're crazy, Nick —he said—. Completely crazy. I don't know what's wrong with you.

en: “Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”
vi: "What did you tell Wilson that night?"
tr: "Tom," I said, "what did you tell Wilson that day?"
es: —Tom —I asked—, what did you say to Wilson that day?

en: He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.
vi: Tom glared at me without saying a word, and I knew I had guessed correctly about what had happened during the hours Wilson was missing. I turned my back and walked away, but Tom followed me and grabbed my arm.
tr: He looked without saying a single word! I had realized that I was right in my assumptions about what happened during those lost hours. I turned to leave, but he came up from behind and grabbed my arm, "I told him the truth, Nick!" he said, "We were about to set off when he showed up; I instructed the servant to say we weren't home but the man forced his way in and went upstairs, he was so furious that if I hadn't told him who owned that car, he might have killed me.
es: He looked at me without saying a word, and I knew I hadn't been mistaken about those lost hours. I tried to turn around, but he grabbed my arm.

en: “I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”
vi: "I told Wilson the truth," Tom said. "He came to my door when my wife and I were about to leave the house. When I sent someone to tell him that we weren't home, he forced his way upstairs. At that moment, he was so furious that he might have killed me if I hadn't told him who owned the car. He had a revolver ready in his pocket every moment he was in my house." Tom loudly and defiantly challenged. "So what if I told Wilson? That guy deserved what he got. He had thrown dust in your eyes as well as Daisy's. But in reality, he was a cold-hearted person; he ran over Myrtle like one runs over a dog without stopping the car."
tr: I turned to leave, but he came up from behind and grabbed my arm, "I told him the truth, Nick!" he said, "We were about to set off when he showed up; I instructed the servant to say we weren't home but the man forced his way in and went upstairs, he was so furious that if I hadn't told him who owned that car, he might have killed me. During the entire time he stayed, his hand was on the gun in his pocket." Then he challenged defiantly. "So what if I told him? That scoundrel deserved what happened to him; he had blinded both Daisy and you, but in reality, he was just a thug. As if running over Myrtle like a dog wasn't enough, he didn't even look back!"
es: —I told him the truth —he said—. He showed up at the door when we were about to leave and, when I ordered them to say we weren't there, he tried to force his way in. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn't told him who owned the car. In the house, he didn't let go of the revolver he had in his pocket for a moment —he paused, defiantly—. So what if I told him? That guy got what he deserved. He blinded you just like he blinded Daisy, but he was dangerous. He ran over Myrtle like someone runs over a dog, and he didn't even stop.

en: There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.
vi: I couldn't open my mouth to say another word, except for a truth that I couldn't utter, which was that it was not true.
tr: I didn't say anything except that it wasn't true.
es: There was nothing I could respond to him, except the unspeakable: that it wasn't true.

en: “And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”
vi: "Do you think I am not suffering?" "Listen, when I came to return the house and saw the damn box of dog food lying on the cupboard, I sat down and cried like a child. It was terrible."
tr: “Do you think I wasn't upset? Look, when I went to clear out that apartment, I sat down and cried like a child when I saw the dog biscuit on the shelf. God, it was awful...”
es: —And if you think I haven't had my share of suffering... Look, when I went to leave the apartment and saw the damn box of dog biscuits on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a child, my God, it was terrible...

en: I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made…
vi: I cannot forgive Tom or have any sympathy for him. I witnessed what Tom did, which to him was completely justified. The story was just careless and mistaken. Tom and Daisy are careless people; they smashed up things and people and then retreated back into their money, or into their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together. They let other people clean up the mess they had made.
tr: I didn't like him at all and I was never going to forgive him. However, I saw that he found himself completely justified for what he did. Everything was chaotic and reckless; Tom and Daisy were extremely reckless, smashing up everything and everyone around them, then retreating into their money or their carelessness, or whatever it was that held them together, leaving others to clean up their mess.
es: I couldn't forgive him or show him sympathy, but I understood that, for him, what he had done was completely justified. It was only inconsideration and confusion: Tom and Daisy were inconsiderate people. They destroyed things and people and then hid behind their money or their immense inconsideration, or whatever it was that united them, and left others to clean up the mess they made...

en: I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.
vi: I shook hands with Tom, otherwise, I would clearly be a fool, because I suddenly felt like I was talking to a child. Then Tom went into the jewelry store to buy a pearl bracelet, or maybe just to buy a pair of cufflinks - to forever avoid my rustic and strict nature.
tr: This time I shook the hand he extended. Refusing was pointless, at that moment I felt like I was shaking a child's hand. Tom entered the jeweler's to buy a pearl necklace or perhaps a pair of cufflinks, and thus, he was forever freed from my provincial sensitivity.
es: I shook his hand; it seemed absurd not to do so, because suddenly it was as if I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewelry store to buy a pearl necklace —or perhaps some cufflinks—, forever free from my provincial scruples.

en: Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. One of the taxi drivers in the village never took a fare past the entrance gate without stopping for a minute and pointing inside; perhaps it was he who drove Daisy and Gatsby over to East Egg the night of the accident, and perhaps he had made a story about it all his own. I didn’t want to hear it and I avoided him when I got off the train.
vi: Gatsby's mansion was still vacant when I left. The grass in his yard had grown as tall as the grass in mine. One of the village taxi drivers, whenever he drove passengers past there, would always stop at the gate for a few minutes to point inside. Perhaps he was the one who drove Daisy and Gatsby through East Egg on the night of the accident, and perhaps this driver had fabricated the story to tell his passengers. I did not want to hear the story and avoided him when I got off the train.
tr: As I was leaving West Egg, Gatsby's house was still empty. The grass in his garden had grown as tall as mine. A taxi driver in town wouldn't pass by here for even a minute without stopping and showing the inside. Maybe he was the one who took Daisy and Gatsby to East Egg on the night of the accident; who knows, maybe he had made up a story about the event. I didn't want to hear any of it, so I avoided getting into his car when I got off the train.
es: Gatsby's house remained empty when I left: its lawn had grown as much as mine. One of the town's taxi drivers never passed by the entrance without stopping for a moment to point out the house to his passengers; he might have been the one who took Daisy and Gatsby to East Egg the night of the accident, and perhaps he had invented his own story about the case. I didn't want to hear it and avoided him when I got off the train.

en: I spent my Saturday nights in New York because those gleaming, dazzling parties of his were with me so vividly that I could still hear the music and the laughter, faint and incessant, from his garden, and the cars going up and down his drive. One night I did hear a material car there, and saw its lights stop at his front steps. But I didn’t investigate. Probably it was some final guest who had been away at the ends of the earth and didn’t know that the party was over.
vi: On Saturday nights, I always had to go sleep in New York, because the dazzling, eye-catching parties at Gatsby's house still vividly appeared in my mind, making me able to hear the indistinct sounds of music and laughter continuously from his garden, along with the bustling cars going up and down the driveway. One evening, I actually heard the sound of a car over there. I saw the car lights shining on the steps in front of Gatsby's house. But I did not step out to look. Perhaps it was from some last guest coming from the ends of the earth, not yet knowing that the festivities had ended.
tr: Since I couldn't get Gatsby's dazzling and enchanting parties out of my mind, I spent Saturday nights in New York, downtown; I could still hear the music, the endless faint laughter spilling out from his garden, and the cars coming and going on the road in front of his house. One night, I actually heard a car passing by, saw its headlights illuminating the steps in front of the door, but I didn't inquire who it was. Perhaps it was the last guest, unaware that the party had ended, as they had been on the other side of the world for some time.
es: I spent Saturday nights in New York because those dazzling parties were still so alive in me that I could still hear the music and the endless, faint laughter coming from the gardens of the house, and the cars going up and down the driveway. One night I heard a real car, and I saw how the headlights illuminated the staircase. But I did not investigate. It must have been some late guest who had been at the ends of the earth and did not know that the party was over.

en: On the last night, with my trunk packed and my car sold to the grocer, I went over and looked at that huge incoherent failure of a house once more. On the white steps an obscene word, scrawled by some boy with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, drawing my shoe raspingly along the stone. Then I wandered down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.
vi: On the last night, with the luggage packed and the car sold back to the grocery store owner, I went to gaze at the incomprehensible vast destruction of the house one more time. On the white stepping stones, an obscene word scrawled in chalk by some child lay glaringly clear under the moonlight. I rubbed my shoe on the stone to erase it. Then I wandered down to the sea and lay down on the sand.
tr: On my last day there, after selling my car to the grocer and stuffing my suitcase to the brim, I went at night to see the misfortune that was inconsistent with the size of the house. On the white marble steps, written in tile by a child, I saw an unspeakable word that could be clearly read even in the pale light of the moon. I erased the writing by scraping my shoe sole against the stone with a squeak. Then I went down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.
es: The last night, after packing and selling the car to the grocery store owner, I went to see once again that extraordinary and incoherent house disaster. On the white steps, an obscene word, scribbled by some kid with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, rubbing the stone with my shoe. Then I walked down to the beach and lay down on the sand.

en: Most of the big shore places were closed now and there were hardly any lights except the shadowy, moving glow of a ferryboat across the Sound. And as the moon rose higher the inessential houses began to melt away until gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors’ eyes—a fresh, green breast of the new world. Its vanished trees, the trees that had made way for Gatsby’s house, had once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams; for a transitory enchanted moment man must have held his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled into an aesthetic contemplation he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something commensurate to his capacity for wonder.
vi: Now, most of the large houses along the coast have closed, leaving no trace of light except for the faint, shimmering, moving light of the ferry gliding across the strait. As the moon rose higher, those unnecessary houses gradually faded away, allowing me to recognize that this was indeed the island of yesteryear, which once blossomed before the eyes of Dutch sailors like the fresh breasts of a newly discovered piece of the world. The trees that were here back then are now gone, cleared away to make room for Gatsby's house, trees that once whispered sweet temptations about the grandest dreams of mankind. In that mesmerizing moment of transformation, people had to hold their breath at the appearance of this continent, compelled to submit to the aesthetic image they neither understood nor desired, forced to face, for the last time, the history of what was truly worthy of their remarkable capabilities.
tr: Since most of the large places on the shore had closed, I could see nothing except for the faint light of a ferry crossing the Bosphorus. As the moon rose, those unnecessary buildings melted away one by one, and I understood how this view might have appeared to the first Dutch sailors who arrived here: it was the fresh and verdant bosom of a brand new world. On the road to Gatsby's house, the now non-existent trees had once whispered and satisfied man's greatest and ultimate dreams. When mankind set foot on this continent, he must have held his breath at that magical moment, forced to turn towards that aesthetic feeling he did not understand and perhaps did not even want, and for the last time in history, faced something that satisfied his curiosity.
es: The majority of the large beach houses were already closed, and hardly any light could be seen except for the moving and cloudy glow of some ferry crossing the strait. And, as the moon rose higher, the insubstantial houses began to fade, and little by little I became aware of the old island that had once blossomed right there before the eyes of a few Dutch sailors: a breast of the new world, green and young. Trees that had disappeared, the trees that would give way to Gatsby's house, once provoked with their whispers the last and greatest of human dreams: for an enchanted and fleeting moment, man had to hold his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled to an aesthetic contemplation that he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something proportional to his capacity for wonder.

en: And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
vi: As I sat there pondering the barren world that I still did not fully understand, I thought about Gatsby's amazement when he first realized the green light at the end of Daisy's dock. Gatsby had spent so much time to reach this green lawn and his dream at that moment seemed so close, he thought he could grasp it in his hand. In fact, Gatsby did not know that his dream was already right behind him, somewhere in the vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
tr: While thinking about that old, mysterious world, I thought of the amazement Gatsby must have felt when he first noticed that green light at the end of Daisy's dock. He had probably come a long way to reach his mansion rising over this blue lawn and thought he had come close enough to his dream to touch it. At that moment, he was unaware that this dream had already receded far behind, somewhere in the vast unknown where the dark lands of the country stretched out beyond the city in the endless night.
es: And there, thinking about the old unknown world, I remembered Gatsby's amazement when he discovered the green light at the end of Daisy's dock. He had come a long way to that blue lawn and his dream must have seemed so close that it could hardly escape him. He did not know that he had already left it behind, somewhere, beyond the city, in the vast darkness, where the dark fields of the republic stretch out into the night.

en: Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning—
vi: Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that's no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther.... And one fine morning....
tr: Gatsby believed in the green light. In the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that's no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther… And one fine morning…
es: Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgiastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eludes us now, but no matter, tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther... And one fine morning...

en: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.
vi: And so we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past
tr: While we row against the current and struggle with the waters, aren't we actually continuously moving backward, that is, towards the past?
es: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.
